title: Bush on Obama and Clinton

title: Biden Unwraps His Bid for 08 With an Oops!
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware described Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat running for president, as the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy.

title: Hey, Sleepy, Want to Buy a Good Nap?
description: ALEXIUS OTTO, a junior at Hunter College in Manhattan, has a perfectly good bed in his apartment in the East Village. But twice over the last month he has paid to take short snoozes at Yelo, a new salon on West 57th Street that sells anxious New Yorkers the promise of a brief but cocooning sleep.

title: Hunting for History to Bring Back Home
description: FOR those who are seeking a no- or low-cost historic home  and are willing to invest the considerable money and time required to move and restore it  there are several resources worth investigating.

title: Arts Groups Seek Plums in a New Budget Pie
description: While some arts groups are likely to benefit from a change announced last week in New York Citys process for dispensing culture funds, those that fared well under the old system may face significant losses.

title: Palestinian Shootout Kills 6 as Truce Breaks Down
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1  A fragile truce between Palestinian factions in the Gaza Strip broke down on Thursday when members of Hamas fired on a convoy from the rival Fatah faction, touching off an intense gun battle that killed six and wounded at least 50 in the coastal territory.

title: Staten Island: Ex-Husband Questioned in Parking Lot Shooting
description: The former husband of a woman fatally shot as she sat in her car in a Staten Island park-and-ride lot was being held by the state police in South Carolina yesterday, a law enforcement official said. The former husband, John Galtieri, a retired New York City police sergeant, was stopped in South Carolina because the car he was driving matched the description of a car seen leaving the parking lot where the body of the woman, Jeanne Kane, was found Tuesday, the official said. The police said Mr. Galtieri retired in 1980 after 14 years with the Police Department. Ms. Kane, 58, and Mr. Galtieri were divorced in 2003, according to relatives. Maureen Kane Pullman, Ms. Kanes sister, said of Mr. Galtieri, He was obsessed with her. The couple appeared together in State Supreme Court earlier Tuesday over litigation that Mr. Galtieri had brought against Ms. Kane, according to the law enforcement official, who would not elaborate on the nature of the suit.

title: Legislature Grants Chvez Broad New Powers to Shape Venezuela
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 31  Venezuelas legislature on Wednesday granted President Hugo Chvez the power to rule by decree for 18 months, enhancing his ability to both increase government control over the economy and assert greater personal authority over areas of society he considers crucial to his aspiration to build a socialist state.

title: On Pins and Needles, but Not Missing a Stitch
description: I NEVER expected to have fond memories of the fringed throw pillow that I had to sew to pass Home Economics.

title: Mining the Raw Stuff of Rhythm, Movement and Ritual
description: Something happens in much of Ronald K. Browns choreography that seems to have little to do with concert or stage dance, for all his highly developed craft and the expertise of his performers. Watching Mr. Browns Evidence, A Dance Company perform on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, thoughts came to mind of what were probably the earliest forms of dancing, driven by impulse, then by the desires to communicate individually and through communal ritual.

Feb. 1  Staging a series of raids that spanned from the northern suburbs of Philadelphia to the Jersey shore, the police said today that they had arrested 20 members of a street gang that is accused of widespread drug dealing and gun violence in Trenton and central New Jersey.

title: After Police Search, Hells Angels Brace for Fight
description: By the time a search warrant was issued late Monday, dozens of heavily armed police officers had spent hours in the biting cold outside a fortresslike East Village tenement that has served for decades as the New York headquarters of the Hells Angels. As sharpshooters looked on from rooftops and a police helicopter circled overhead, the standoff lasted all afternoon.

title: Home After 5 Road Games, Nets Still Have Miles to Go
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 31  The Detroit Pistons Jason Maxiell missed a jump shot midway through the second quarter, but a teammate, Antonio McDyess, kept the play alive by tapping the ball back out to Maxiell. McDyess then missed a jump shot, but another teammate, Carlos Delfino, corralled the rebound.

description: First, a Long Island couple used a popular online dating site to find people going through divorces and arranged to have consensual sexual encounters with them, the authorities said yesterday. Then they secretly videotaped the encounters and blackmailed the victims.

title: Jews Support Ordination of Gays
description: A study of more than 5,500 leaders in Conservative Judaism found that about two-thirds of the movements rabbis, cantors and seminary students in the United States favored the ordination of gay men and lesbians. Support was even higher among educators and lay leaders. The study was commissioned by the Jewish Theological Seminary, based in New York, which is now deciding whether to admit openly gay students. Last December, the movements law committee adopted three conflicting legal opinions on the issue, one of which opened the door to ordaining gay people.

title: Molly Ivins, Columnist, Dies at 62
description: Molly Ivins, the liberal newspaper columnist who delighted in skewering politicians and interpreting, and mocking, her Texas culture, died yesterday in Austin. She was 62.

title: Malawi: Vice Presidents Treason Trial Begins
description: Malawis tumultuous politics crossed another threshold Tuesday as the vice president, Cassim Chilumpha, went on trial for treason, accused of conspiring to assassinate President Bingu wa Mutharika. Mr. Chilumpha says he is being persecuted because he refused to join the new political party Mr. Mutharika formed after he was elected in 2004.

title: Battle Over School Bus Service in New York City
description: It seemed like an easy way to save millions of dollars: consolidate yellow school bus routes so New York City was no longer paying for buses for hundreds, if not thousands, of children who never actually rode them.

description: Manhattan

description: Q.Ive kept my files in cardboard boxes long enough. Where can I find good-looking cabinets?

title: Decision to Have Baby Isnt Political, Mary Cheney Says
description: Mary Cheney, the lesbian daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney, for the first time yesterday publicly defended her decision to become pregnant and asserted that same-sex couples were equally capable of raising children as heterosexual couples.

title: Agudio and Hofstra Top Virginia Commonwealth
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 31  Already playing with his left thumb wrapped and his left calf encased in an elastic sleeve, Hofstra guard Antoine Agudio came up limping late in a tight game Wednesday. He grimaced, tightened his shoelaces and stayed in the game.

title: A Partnership in Several Ways, Overcoming a Bad Trump Break
description: Bridge has seen its fair share of marriages and divorces. Tomorrow, though, is the 20th anniversary of the first date of Eileen Brenner and Michael Pickert of Livingston, N.J.

title: In London, Revivals for Now and Posterity
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  How achingly alive they are, these people who insist that they have never really lived. The marvel of Ian Ricksons rapturous interpretation of Anton Chekhovs Seagull, which opened last week at the Royal Court Theater and quickly became a must-have and largely unhaveable ticket, is how seamlessly it captures the vital paradox that so often escapes productions of this masterwork: the bursting theatrical fullness to be found in its unfulfilled lives.

title: Manhattan: Panel to Study M.T.A. Costs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to name a panel to study why costs are rising so quickly for construction projects that are part of its long-term spending program. The authority has budgeted $21 billion for major projects from 2005 to 2009, but increasing construction costs are causing estimates for many of those projects to rise far beyond expectations. The panel will also review budget estimates and timetables for what are known as megaprojects, including the Second Avenue subway, a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal, and an extension of the No. 7 subway line, the authoritys executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander, said yesterday. He said the panel would take up to three months to do its work, which would include recommending ways to keep costs down.

title: Can His Kid Brother Follow in Barbaros Huge Footsteps?
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 31  Just 75 miles from where Barbaro first captured the nations attention with a remarkable run in the Kentucky Derby, a young colt, a baby in many ways, spends much of his day frolicking in a large paddock at Mill Ridge Farm. He is just one among thousands of yearlings living on thoroughbred farms throughout Kentucky, and all of them are still months away from their first chance at showing what they might amount to on a racetrack.

title: Berlusconi Flirts. Wifes Fed Up. Read All About It.
description: ROME, Jan. 31  Dear Editor, began a letter published Wednesday on the front page of La Repubblica, the newspaper that Silvio Berlusconi hates most. The scalding letter demanded an apology from Mr. Berlusconi for flirting publicly  and it was signed by his wife.

title: A Better Way to Burn With Macintosh and Even Use the New Blu-ray Discs
description: Most modern Macintosh computers can record CDs and DVDs just fine on their own with software built into the Mac operating system, but third-party programs often add more flexibility.

title: Hong Kong Democracy Advocate Says He Faces Long Odds in Vote
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 31  Hong Kong is poised to hold the first election in more than half a century that includes a democracy advocate seeking high office in territory controlled by the Chinese government in Beijing.

title: Somalia: Parliament Elects a New Speaker
description: Lawmakers chose a former Koranic teacher, Sheik Adan Mohammed Nur, as the new speaker of Parliament, the third highest political position in the country after the president and prime minister. The previous speaker was ousted last month after he tried to broker a peace treaty between the transitional government and the Islamist movement that used to control Mogadishu. Meanwhile, American officials announced that for the first time since 1994 they were resuming Voice of America radio broadcasts into Somalia.

None of them had sky-dived before, and Sumeet Haldankar, a program engineer, said the 14,500-foot plunge delivered such an adrenalin rush that people hugged and laughed giddily when they landed safely.

title: Trenton to Investigate Financing of a Meadowlands Project

title: Ms. Chicago, Party of 39? Your Tables Ready in Brooklyn
description: Judy Chicago says that even at 67 her early struggles as a female artist remain fresh. So, yes, seeing The Dinner Party in its permanent home  a luminous new gallery at the Brooklyn Museum, expressly designed for her provocative installation of plates  qualifies as progress after 33 years. But Ms. Chicago is not triumphant.

description: PARIS, Feb. 1  Hundreds of climate scientists and government officials from around the world have worked all week behind closed doors and frequently darkened windows in a United Nations building here to summarize the factors behind global warming in a report to be released Friday.

title: 2 Arrested in Boston Over Bomb Scare
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1  Two men charged in connection with placing electronic advertisements for a cartoon around Boston, sending the city into a panic when people feared they were bombs, pleaded not guilty today, responding to the charges with grins and buffoon-like comments.

title: Indefinitely Grounded
description: Travelers and airlines have a deal. In exchange for transporting them safely, passengers agree to give up a great deal of freedom of movement. Once aboard a plane, theres no getting off until the crew says so. People have to sit when theyre told, buckle up and raise their seatbacks on command. In return, passengers expect the airlines to take care of them.

title: Palo Alto Board Rejects Classes in Mandarin
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 31  It would have seemed to be a perfect fit: an academically ambitious plan for an ambitiously academic city.

title: France: Majority of Blacks Suffer Bias
description: More than half of 1.8 million black adults living in France say they have been the victims of racism in their everyday lives, according to a survey commissioned by the Representative Council of Black Associations, a black advocacy group, and conducted by TNS-Sofres for the newspaper Le Parisien. It found that 56 percent believed they had been discriminated against, with 61 percent saying they had endured at least one incident of discrimination in the last year. Close to one in four said they had been insulted or verbally abused. These statistics show what this society does not want to hear or see, said Patrick Lozes, the president of the representative council.

title: In the Land of Lost Men, No One Asks for Direction
description: Let us now profile superfluous men. Charlie LeDuff, a reporter for The New York Times, often writes about folks who claw and hang on by their fingernails. For his new book, US Guys, he spent a year roaming  sometimes rambling  through masculine America, mainly parts West and South. He hung out at a biker club, a gay rodeo, a circus, a snake-handler revival church, a male modeling agency and a Little Big Horn re-enactment among other sites of lowlife, high jinks and fall-downs. He has a taste for the legions of men who are known today, with a curl of the lip, as losers  or, as he writes about a semipro football team in Amarillo, Tex., that he joins in homage to George Plimpton, dudes grasping at the frayed end of the rope of hope.

title: Sidney Sheldon, Author of Steamy Novels, Dies at 89
description: Sidney Sheldon, an Oscar- and Tony-winning writer of squeaky-clean fare for stage and screen who became world famous for his later career as a writer of steamy, best-selling novels, died on Tuesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 89 and had homes in Malibu and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: A Nashville Near-Star, Downsizing for a Night
description: Has Miranda Lamberts career developed in reverse? First came national television exposure: she finished third on the first season of Nashville Star, the country music version of American Idol. Then came the arena tours, as the opening act for Keith Urban, George Strait and, as of last week, Toby Keith. And then, on Tuesday night, came a low-key show at Mercury Lounge, the cozy downtown rock club. At this rate, shell be busking in the subway by 2008.

title: Girl, 2, Dies in Bronx Fire, and Neighbor Is Accused of Murder

title: Lakers? Big Victory. The Bobcats? Big Problem.
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 31  The Knicks arrived at Charlotte Bobcats Arena on Wednesday in search of some consistency, having struggled to put consecutive victories together through most of January. But the Knicks faced a Bobcats team that has inspired anything but consistency in them in recent seasons.

title: Ford and G.M. Expect January Sales Drops

Living room soirees, four-handed piano music and fraternity group sings are not exactly the mothers milk of todays music business. Neither is the curious instrument for which this sonata was written: a kind of guitar with a bow, invented in the first part of the 19th century and pretty much extinct by the end of it.

title: In an Enclave of Serious Wine Lovers, a Mesmerizing Theft
description: ATHERTON, Calif.  It was perhaps the most Californian of crimes. Behind the electronic gates and freshly clipped hedges of an exclusive cul-de-sac, the thieves worked in the dead of night, ignoring watches, laptops and other ho-hum booty to cart away the ultimate prize: 450 bottles of wine, including a rare $11,000 1959 magnum from the Chteau Ptrus in Bordeaux, France.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., defending the administrations approach to China, told a Senate committee on Wednesday that American efforts to persuade China to let its currency rise in value had achieved some results but that Beijings leadership needed to do far more.

description: ON a warm massage table at Sothys Spa, far from the January chill, Fran Glennon, 52, was cocooned in white terry cloth and enjoying a facial. On another massage table, about five feet away, was a smaller cocoon: Ms. Glennons daughter, Emma, 9.

description: PARIS, Jan. 31  President Jacques Chirac said this week that if Iran had one or two nuclear weapons, it would not pose a big danger, and that if Iran were to launch a nuclear weapon against a country like Israel, it would lead to the immediate destruction of Tehran.

title: Colts' Dallas Clark Finds His Place in the Big Time
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 31  Something inside Dallas Clark has always driven him to accept challenges, to persevere, to overcome long odds and tough times. When Clark was a senior in high school, his mother, Jan, died of a heart attack at 49. A few days later, stricken with grief, Clark competed in a district track meet for Twin River Valley High School in Bode, Iowa.

title: The Apartment Was Mostly Empty, Except for the Love
description: The new apartment in the Bronx that Lorraine Robinson shares with her 12-year-old cousin, Tyrik Sherman, was mostly empty in January, two months after they moved in. They kept plastic patio chairs in the kitchen, a substitute for more permanent furniture. A plastic storage bin became a table.

title: Times Co. Lowers Valuation of New England Newspapers
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was writing down by $814.4 million the value of its New England newspapers, The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, which have suffered from sluggish advertising and a migration of readers to the Internet.

title: Fashion Muscles In
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom dictates that gym clothes be low-key and functional  a shredded T-shirt, a sweat-drenched tank  the better to pump incognito, under cover of ones workout gear. But conventional wisdom has no place at Manhattan temples of fitness like the Reebok Sports Club or David Barton. Habitus seem to view them as platforms for showing off vulcanized chests, swelling abs and Popeye biceps, all enhanced by wildly colorful second-skin uniforms. Earlier this month some even chose to underscore the bird-of-paradise effect, wearing gobs of gold  stacked rings and matching bangles, festoons of chains  while others placed the accent on their shoes.

title: Bronx: Parents Arrested in Babys Death
description: The parents of an infant girl whose body was found at the bottom of a trash chute in a Mott Haven apartment building were arrested yesterday after a tip was received, the police said. The babys father, Juan Rodriguez, 32, was charged with second-degree murder, and her mother, Maribel Caceres, 21, with unlawful disposal of a human body, the police said. The death of the 5-week-old girl, identified as Giovonna Marie Rodriguez, has been ruled a homicide, the result of smothering and blunt impact injuries to her head, said a spokeswoman for the medical examiners office, Ellen S. Borakove. The police said that the couple dropped Giovonna down the chute in the Willis Avenue building on Monday. Mr. Rodriguez and Ms. Caceres had been living together in Hempstead, on Long Island, a law enforcement official said. The police said that it was unclear what connection they had to the Bronx building, but that Mr. Rodriguez may have lived in the neighborhood at one time.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 15 about a dispute between Wendy P. McCaw, the owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press in California, and the newsroom staff misstated the job title of a former editor at the paper who commented on the controversy. (The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Jan 18.) Don Murphy was the deputy managing editor, not the managing editor.

title: Material Guys: Pollock-Inspired Artists, All About the Process

The current exhibition at his Chelsea gallery  sculptures by Bill Bollinger, paintings by Tom Evans  takes us back to the early 1970s and the heyday of Process Art.

title: Gordon Macklin, 78, Pioneer in Electronic Stock Trading, Dies
description: Gordon S. Macklin, who guided the growth of one of the worlds largest securities trading systems, the computerized service known as Nasdaq, died Tuesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 78.

title: Senate Critique of Bushs Iraq Plan Wins New Support
description: WASHINGTON  A revised Senate resolution criticizing President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq, offered by Senator John Warner, Republican of Virginia, drew new support today as two of the authors of a sterner resolution of disapproval said they would accept the Warner compromise.

title: An Island of Moguls Is Latest Front in Union Battle
description: FISHER ISLAND, Fla., Jan 26  The class struggle is coming to paradise.

title: Gian Carlo Menotti, Opera Composer, Dies at 95
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, who wrote his first opera before he was 11 and went on to become perhaps the most popular and prolific opera composer of his time, winning two Pulitzer Prizes, died today in Monaco. He was 95.

title: Execution, if It Occurs, Is Years Away for Killer
description: Ronell Wilson sits alone in a prison cell near Gowanus Bay in Brooklyn. He has been on suicide watch since his return late Tuesday evening from federal court in Brooklyn, where a jury called for his execution.

title: Harry Potters Final Act Is Set for July 21
description: J. K. Rowling, the author of the record-setting Harry Potter series, announced today that the seventh  and last  book in the series, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, will be published on July 21.

title: A Higher Bid for REIT Is Expected by Vornado
description: A consortium of investors led by Vornado Realty Trust planned to raise its bid for Equity Office Properties Group to more than $40 billion, escalating a showdown with a rival suitor, the Blackstone Group, people involved in bidding said last night.

title: New Blow to a Law Firm Under Inquiry
description: A few years before he faked the theft of two works of art from his home in Brentwood, Calif., Steven G. Cooperman, a former ophthalmologist, received a personal check from a partner of the law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad for $175,000 as an option payment on one of those works, Picassos Nude Before a Mirror.

title: Immigrants Are Facing Big Increases in U.S. Fees
description: Federal immigration authorities proposed yesterday to raise fees for visas and citizenship documents by an average of 66 percent, promising to use the added money to modernize and speed up an antiquated, overburdened bureaucracy.

title: U.S. Agency Finds New Waste and Fraud in Iraqi Rebuilding Projects
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 31  A federal oversight agency reported Wednesday that despite nearly $108 billion that had been budgeted for the reconstruction of Iraq since the 2003 invasion, the countrys electrical output and oil production were still below prewar levels and stocks of gasoline and kerosene had plummeted to their lowest levels in at least two years.

title: Britain: Police Send Poisoning Case to Prosecutors
description: The British police handed their findings in the poisoning death of a former K.G.B. agent to the Crown Prosecution Service, which will determine whether suspects should be charged. The former agent, Alexander V. Litvinenko, died in London in November after ingesting a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210. The British police have traveled to Moscow to interview people who met with Mr. Litvinenko on the day he is believed to have been poisoned, but they have persistently denied poisoning him.

title: Affirmative Action Ban (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Moves to End Touch-Screen Voting
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1  Gov. Charlie Crist today announced plans today to abandon the touch-screen voting machines that many of Floridas largest counties installed after the disputed 2000 presidential election, instead adopting a statewide system of casting paper ballots counted by scanning machines.

title: France: Workers of the World, Zzz
description: The health minister, Xavier Bertrand, plans to spend $9 million this year to improve public awareness of sleeping problems. One thing he wants to know is whether French workers should be allowed to nap on the job. They enjoy a 35-hour work week and generous vacations, yet 56 percent complain that a poor nights sleep has affected their job performance, according to the ministry. Why not a nap at work? Mr. Bertrand told a news conference. It cant be a taboo subject.

title: Awarder of Space Prize to Add Others
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31  Reduce poverty, win millions.

title: Suspicious Devices in Boston Turn Out to Be Ad Campaign for Cartoon
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31  Boston temporarily closed parts of bridges, subway stations, an Interstate highway and even part of the Charles River on Wednesday after the authorities found what the police described as suspicious devices at nine places.

title: France Tells U.S. to Sign Climate Pacts or Face Tax
description: PARIS, Jan. 31  President Jacques Chirac has demanded that the United States sign both the Kyoto climate protocol and a future agreement that will take effect when the Kyoto accord runs out in 2012.

title: US Airways Withdraws Its $10.2 Billion Offer for Delta
description: Someday, the long-predicted wave of consolidation in the airline industry could occur.

title: What Could Bog Down the Bull
description: Stocks surged yesterday afternoon, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to within a hair of a new high, after the Federal Reserve pointed to strength in the economy and a moderation in inflation.

title: An Evenings Star Appears, but Only in Vivid Memories
description: You have three chances this month to see Essential Balanchine, one of 11 thematic programs newly created by the New York City Ballet as a way of packaging its extensive repertory.

title: Governor Spitzers Pivotal Budget
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer described his first New York State budget yesterday as a pivot from the old way of doing things. He wants to turn away from a financial system that rewards political favorites to one that focuses on what regular people  students, patients, taxpayers, workers  actually get when New York spends a stunning $120 billion. That emphasis has resulted in one of the boldest, bravest budget proposals in Albany in many years.

title: Smithsonian Executives Pay Tops Presidents, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Salaries for some Smithsonian Institution executives are higher than those for other top federal jobs, including those of the United States president and vice president, according to the institutions acting inspector general.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column last Thursday about plans by the tenor Plcido Domingo to sing the baritone title role in Verdis Simon Boccanegra misstated the day he turned 66. It was Jan. 21, not Jan. 22.

title: A New Cordless Phone From Uniden. Just Add Water.
description: If you wanted to place a call to Captain Nemo, Uniden has the phone you need. The new WXI477 comes in a yellow and black color scheme, and its submersible  at least for depths up to three feet.

title: Judges Weigh Arguments in U.S. Eavesdropping Case
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 31  Three federal judges hearing the first appellate argument about the legality of a National Security Agency domestic surveillance program on Wednesday indicated that they were not convinced that the issue was moot now that the Bush administration had agreed to submit the program to a secret court.

title: The Super Ad Bowl: Two Decades of Players
Newspaper Readers of a Different Kind
description: ACCORDING to Sheryl Crow, all she wants to do is have some fun. According to a new ad campaign, that includes reading The Wall Street Journal.

title: A Health Care Plan Both Ambitious and Contentious
description: The budget Gov. Eliot Spitzer laid out yesterday represents the first stages of an ambitious health care agenda, including covering hundreds of thousands of uninsured people with government health plans, and broadly revising how Medicaid money is distributed.

title: Students Recording of Teachers Views Leads to a Ban on Taping
description: After a public school teacher was recorded telling students they belonged in hell if they did not accept Jesus as their savior, the school board has banned taping in class without an instructors permission, and has added training for teachers on the legal requirements for separating church and state.

title: Key Lawmakers Getting Files About Surveillance Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Bowing to bipartisan pressure from lawmakers, the Justice Department announced Wednesday that it was turning over to selected members of Congress secret documents with details of the National Security Agencys eavesdropping program.

title: General Says Iraq War Is Winnable
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The recently returned commander of the American forces in Iraq faced pointed questions and criticism at a Senate hearing today as lawmakers maneuvered over wording of a resolution criticizing President Bushs troop increase

title: Chiracs Second Interview on Iran
description: Following are excerpts from an interview by President Jacques Chirac of France with The New York Times, The International Herald Tribune and Le Nouvel Observateur on Jan. 30, 2007. The interview was conducted in French and recorded and translated by The New York Times.

title: Owners of Mining Company Say Theyll End Partnership
description: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Thursday.

title: South Dakota: New Effort to Limit Abortions
description: Less than three months after state voters defeated a proposal that would have outlawed most abortions, legislators introduced a scaled-back version. Unlike its predecessor, the new proposal provides exceptions for abortions in cases when the womans health or life is at risk or when the pregnancy is a result of rape or incest. The bill would also require physicians who wish to perform an abortion for health reasons to get another doctor to verify that the womans health was at risk.

title: Putin Considers Ties With Iran on Gas Sales
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1  Even as the United States intensifies its efforts to isolate Iran, President Vladimir V. Putin said Thursday that Russia would consider OPEC-like cooperation with Tehran on sales of natural gas. He stopped short of endorsing price-fixing, however, saying he was concerned only with insuring stable supplies for consuming nations.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,073 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Dell Chief Is Replaced by Founder
description: Michael S. Dell has taken back the leadership of the computer company he founded, replacing Kevin B. Rollins after more than a year of mounting problems at Dell.

title: Now That a Penny Isnt Worth Much, Its Time to Make It Worth 5 Cents
description: How dumb do you have to be to mint money at a loss? In the latest only-in-Washington episode, we find that the government may have lost as much as $40 million coining pennies and nickels last year.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Jan. 21 about a soccer program for refugee boys in Clarkston, Ga., rendered incorrectly a quotation from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution in which Mayor Lee Swaney of Clarkston commented on the use of a town park. He said, There will be nothing but baseball down there as long as I am mayor. He did not say baseball and football.

title: Exxon Sets Record on Annual Profits
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1  Exxon Mobil reported a record annual profit today but a modest decline in fourth-quarter earnings because of falling oil and gas prices. Meanwhile, its competitor Royal Dutch Shell reported an unexpected rise in quarterly earnings, a sign that the industry is still going strong.

title: Leadership Needed Now (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Visiting Israelis Strike Up the Chestnuts
description: The 70th-anniversary party the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra gave itself at home was far more lavish, with a parade of star soloists and conductors taking part in a dozen concerts over two weeks. But the orchestra brought a hint of its celebration to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, when it played the first concert in a weeklong American visit. Lorin Maazel was on the podium on Tuesday, but the orchestras music director, Zubin Mehta, is on hand as well; he will lead a second Carnegie program tonight.

title: Why We Mourn Barbaro
description: HE never talked about himself in the third person.

title: Vow at Citigroup to Fill Post Soon
description: The chief executive of Citigroup, Charles O. Prince, said yesterday that he expected to name a successor quickly to Sallie L. Krawcheck as Citigroups finance chief.

title: Ethnic Unrest in Southern Plains Undermines Peace Pact in Nepal
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 31  A fragile peace was fraying in Nepal on Wednesday, as ethnic violence went on unabated on its southern plains, a police officer was hacked to death and the prime minister was prompted to call for an end to the bloodletting.

title: Nerves as Frayed as the Sofa? Call Your Own Dog Whisperer
description: SOMETIMES Bill Berloni feels like a phone psychic. People call about their adopted pets, and Ive never seen their home, he said. One woman had a dog who was afraid of thunder, and neglected to mention that she lived next to an airport.

title: Sheriffs Wife and a Deputy Die in Shooting
description: MARIANNA, Fla., Jan. 31  The Jackson County sheriffs wife and a deputy who was responding to a call for help were killed Tuesday in a shooting at the sheriffs home in which the two suspects were also shot to death.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Be the Next American Idol With Karaoke You Can Carry
description: If you cannot get enough karaoke at the local sushi house, the engineers at Griffin Technology have created a low-cost karaoke system you can carry anywhere.

title: Propane Blast Hits a Small Town Hard
description: GHENT, W.Va., Jan. 31  For the 800 people in this spartan town in southern West Virginia, the Ghent Fire Hall is the heart of the community. It is where gospel concerts and political debates are held in winter, and a town fair with rides and games is a summer favorite.

title: House Approves Measure for Temporary Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The House of Representatives on Wednesday approved a $463.5 billion measure to keep the federal government running until Oct. 1, making about $10 billion in token adjustments to last years spending levels to increase financing for education grants, scientific research and international health programs.

title: Restaurant Helps N.F.L. Diners Keep a Low Profile
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31  When Brian Griese, the Bears backup quarterback, was a child, Joes Stone Crab in Miami Beach was like his dining room away from home. He frequently ate there with his father, Bob, the Dolphins Hall of Fame quarterback, so of course it was the first place he thought to bring some of his teammates for dinner.

title: Chinese Official Gives Rare Rebuke to Bush
description: BEIJING, Feb. 1  A senior Chinese government official issued a rare public rebuke of President Bush on Thursday, accusing him of waging a unilateral battle against terrorists that had worsened global tensions.

title: In Fighting Troop Increase, Senator Finds Few Old Allies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Senator John W. Warner, a lawmaker often admired for his demeanor and experience, has long wielded influence on military policy given his own years at the Pentagon and his tenure as the Republican chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

title: Holiday Drinks Gives Starbucks a Lift
description: Starbucks said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 18 percent as consumers spent more for holiday drinks like peppermint mocha.

title: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of Il Signor Bruschino, by Rossini, which is being performed in New York through Saturday. The current production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.) A correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the name of the group that is currently presenting the work, at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. It is the Gotham Chamber Opera, not Orchestra.

title: Citizen Anna
description: IF there is one thing that no one doubts about Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, it is her power. To many she is the dominant figure in the fashion world, her influence greater than any contemporary editor and running close to a press baron, because she has sought through her magazine and its spinoffs to set the agenda for an industry and through her civic causes, like the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to influence the cultural life of New York.

title: Tests of Drug to Block H.I.V. Infection Are Halted Over Safety
description: Efforts to develop a topical microbicide to prevent H.I.V. infection during sex suffered a surprising setback yesterday when researchers announced that they had stopped two full-scale trials for safety reasons.

title: Celebrity Architects Reveal a Daring Cultural Xanadu for the Arab World
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Jan. 31  In this land of big ambition and deep pockets, planners on Wednesday unveiled designs for an audacious multibillion-dollar cultural district whose like has never been seen in the Arab world.

title: U.S. Issues Guidelines in Case of Flu Pandemic
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1  Cities should close schools for up to three months in the event of a severe flu outbreak, ball games and movies should be canceled and working hours staggered so subways and buses are less crowded, the federal government advised today in issuing new pandemic flu guidelines to states and cities.

title: Bears Long Snapper as Left-Handed Reliever
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31  When his son-in-law, Patrick Mannelly, complains of sore elbows, all Tommy John can do is laugh. Before Mannelly married Johns daughter, Tamara, nine years ago, John had no idea that long snappers and baseball pitchers could have anything in common.

title: Chiracs First Interview on Iran
description: Following are excerpts from an interview by President Jacques Chirac of France with The New York Times, The International Herald Tribune and Le Nouvel Observateur on Jan. 29, 2007. The interview was conducted in French and recorded and translated by The New York Times.

title: Geography and Emotion Helped Sway Jurors Vote
description: They were police detectives, shot at close range, in the backs of their heads. Fellow officers and relatives filled the courtroom, day after day, during the trial of the man accused of pulling the trigger, who mostly kept his emotions to himself.

title: Search for Remains Will Go Beneath an Asphalt Lot
description: THE unending hunt for the body parts of 9/11 victims is likely to intensify this month as excavations begin on an asphalt-covered staging area opposite ground zero. This was once an entire city block, where the little St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church stood, and the rubble under that asphalt has lain pretty much undisturbed for five years.

title: Former Israeli Official Guilty of Sexual Misconduct
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31  An Israeli court convicted a former justice minister, Haim Ramon, on Wednesday of charges that he forcibly kissed a young female soldier in a highly publicized case that added to the aura of scandal surrounding the countrys leadership.

title: Theres No Shuffle in His Step
description: Miami

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 9:30 P.M. (Showtime) BUD GREENSPAN PRESENTS PRIDE AGAINST PREJUDICE: THE LARRY DOBY STORY Mr. Doby (1923-2003) joined the Cleveland Indians in 1947 just 11 weeks after Jackie Robinson signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers. But until a Sports Illustrated article in 1997, his accomplishments had been largely forgotten. In this 90-minute documentary, Mr. Greenspan chronicles Mr. Dobys three-decade career, his induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame and the restoration of his rightful place in sports history. Louis Gossett Jr. narrates.

title: Agriculture Dept. Urges Big Overhaul in Farm Policy
description: The Bush administration yesterday proposed legislation that would reduce payments to farmers by $10 billion over the next five years and cut off support for wealthy ones entirely.

title: Irans President Reaffirms Nuclear Ambitions
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 1  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, under increasing criticism at home, said today that his nation is becoming a superpower and that the United Nations sanctions will not deter it from pursuing its nuclear program.

title: A Digital Camera Accessory With a Creative Bag of Tricks
description: The Lensbaby 3G might look like a mini-hibachi grill, but its actually a unique lens system for digital cameras. It creates odd images by allowing the point of focus to be selected anywhere in a scene.

description: BASEBALL

title: Outdoor Home Heater Makers Agree to Pollution Cutbacks
description: Ten of the top manufacturers of a popular wood-burning device that reduces home heating costs but releases high levels of pollutants have agreed to start making cleaner and more efficient machines, the Environmental Protection Agency announced this week.

title: Manhattan: Councilman Seeks Divestment in Sudan
description: A city councilman said yesterday that he planned to introduce a bill today asking that the city and the state stop investing pension money in companies that do business in Sudan, whose government has been accused of committing genocide against civilians. The city has invested $725 million and the state $1 billion in such companies, the state and city comptrollers offices said. The bill, by Councilman Eric N. Gioia, left, is set to be co-sponsored by Councilman David Yassky and Councilwoman Inez E. Dickens. It would identify companies that provide revenue to the Sudanese government and fail to use their influence to end the fighting. At least six states, including California, have passed similar laws.

title: Fed, Leaving Rate at 5.25%, Is Optimistic on Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, as it has since June, but it was more optimistic than in the past that inflationary pressures were ebbing.

title: Bullying Iran
description: Given Americas bitter experience in Iraq, one would think that President Bush could finally figure out that threats and brute force arent a substitute for a reasoned strategy. But Mr. Bush is at it again, this time trying to bully Iran into stopping its meddling inside Iraq.

title: In a Daylong Drill, an Agency Tries to Prepare for a Real Outbreak of Avian Flu
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 31  This is not a real article. This is an exercise.

title: German Court Challenges C.I.A. Over Abduction
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 31  A German court on Wednesday issued an arrest warrant for 13 people in the mistaken kidnapping and jailing of a German citizen of Lebanese descent, in the most serious legal challenge yet to the Central Intelligence Agencys secret transfers of terrorism suspects.

title: Report Says 14 in Fire Dept. Used Fake Degrees
description: Fourteen employees of the Fire Department of New York bought phony diplomas over the Internet and submitted them to the city in an attempt to meet educational requirements for being promoted or hired, according to a report released yesterday by the Department of Investigation.

title: Britain Arrests 9 Suspects in Terrorist Kidnapping Plot
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  The British police conducted a series of raids on Wednesday, arresting nine suspects on terrorism charges in what appeared to be a shift in the tactics of terrorism in Britain. The suspects are accused of devising a plot that included plans to kidnap, torture and behead a British Muslim soldier and broadcast video images of his killing on the Internet.

title: Florida: Battle Over Inmates Ends
description: A state judge dismissed contempt of court charges and $80,000 in fines against the Florida Department of Children and Families and its former secretary, ending a court battle over the handling of dozens of mentally ill inmates who have been housed in county jails while waiting for state hospital beds. The judge, Robert J. Morris Jr. of Pasco-Pinellas Circuit Court, dismissed the case after the new secretary, Bob Butterworth, disclosed a plan to create 373 new state hospital beds by June 30.

title: Better Shoeboxes for Digital Photos
description: PHOTO management once meant finding room to stash yet another box filled with snapshots. While digital photography has freed up that closet space, sorting and retrieving pictures in the era of the 250-gigabyte hard drive has created a set of challenges of its own.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a preliminary State Department finding that Israel may have violated agreements with the United States in using American-supplied cluster munitions in southern Lebanon during the fight against Hezbollah last summer misstated the number of Israeli citizens killed by Hezbollah rocket attacks in the conflict. It was about 40  not 159, which was the total number of Israeli fatalities. (Most were Israeli soldiers killed in fighting inside Lebanon.)

title: Ferraro to Join Lobbying Firm
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former New York representative who was the Democratic candidate for vice president in 1984, will join the lobbying and public relations firm Blank Rome Government Relations as a principal, the firm said yesterday.

title: Vigorous Consumer Spending Helped Economy Grow 3.5% at the End of 2006
description: The economy regained momentum at the end of 2006, pulling out of a midyear slowdown as gas prices fell and Americans reached into their wallets with renewed confidence.

title: Full Disclosure of Back-Scratching
description: Now that House Democrats are beyond the spotlight of their ballyhooed first 100 hours, there are signs of foot-dragging on the keystone of their promised lobbying reform: forcing disclosure of the huge sums in campaign donations that lobbyists package to grease privileged access in the Capitol. This practice  called bundling  has lobbyists mass hundreds of donations of a few thousand dollars each into special-interest piatas of hundreds of thousands. Full disclosure of bundling is the sine qua non of lobbying reform. Speaker Nancy Pelosi cannot let the new House majority backslide.

title: Spacewalkers Start Switch of Stations Cooling System
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Working gingerly in a cramped area outside the International Space Station, two spacewalking astronauts successfully switched half the outposts coolant lines on Wednesday into a permanent cooling system.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Monday about the Rev. Robert F. Drinan, a Jesuit priest who served in Congress for 10 years, attributed an erroneous distinction to him. He was the first of two Catholic priests to serve as a voting delegate in Congress  not the only one. (Robert J. Cornell of Wisconsin was the second, serving two terms. At least two Episcopal priests have also been members of Congress.) The obituary also incorrectly described Father Drinans attire while serving in Congress. He normally wore a dark suit with clerical collar, not the robes of his clerical order.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies yesterday about the writer and producer Sidney Sheldon misstated his date of birth. He was born on Feb. 11, 1917  not on Feb. 17. An obituary by The New York Times appears today at http://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/01/obituaries/01sheldon.html.

description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Rivals Report Fund-Raising Totals
description: Senator John McCain reported that he had collected $1.7 million in his presidential campaigns first few weeks and his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, reported $1.4 million raised. Financial documents detailing 2006 year-end totals showed that Mr. McCain, an Arizona senator, had $472,000 on hand while Mr. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, had about $1 million available. Both spent money setting up campaign headquarters, buying equipment and hiring workers. With the race for the Republican nomination just getting under way, the reports detail a period before any candidate began presidential fund-raising efforts in earnest.

title: Suspension Training: How Risky Is It?
description: NAVY Seals are legendary for their tiptop physical condition, but have you ever wondered how they stay fighting fit out in the field?

title: One of the Worlds Poorest Countries Is Rich in Distance Runners
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28  Halfway through the womens 5,000 meters race Saturday at the Boston Indoor Games, Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia was left with nothing chasing her closely but her pompom of a ponytail.

description: These are the answers to the Super Bowl trivia quiz. Obviously, the idea is that you read the questions first.

description: Step right up and test your Super Bowl IQ.

title: Guest Columnist Jess Faneuf
description: (Jess Faneuf was another medalist in the reader column contest, and as a reward, he has this space to write a column. He chose to write about the advantages of watching the Super Bowl as a neutral observer. But first he answered a few questions from the Fifth Down)
