description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about Bernie Friedkin, a boxer from Brooklyn who was known as Schoolboy, missated his height and the place of residence of a surviving granddaughter, Sabrina Saltz, who announced the death. Mr. Friedkin was 5 feet 6 inches, not 5 feet 3 inches; and Ms. Saltz lives in Staten Island, not Brooklyn. An updated obituary appears today at http://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/01/sports/othersports/01friedkin.html.

title: Poetry in Paint
description: Images from Jasper Johns: An Allegory of Painting, 1955-1965 at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Pamuk Cancels Trip to Germany
description: Orhan Pamuk of Turkey, the 2006 Nobel laureate in literature, has canceled a trip to Germany, but his publisher declined to confirm a newspaper report that Mr. Pamuk feared he might be assassinated, Agence France-Press reported yesterday. The newspaper Klner Stadt- Anzeiger said Mr. Pamuk believed he might be killed, as was Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor gunned down in Istanbul on Jan. 19. Like Mr. Pamuk he had challenged the official Turkish version of the 1915 Armenian genocide. Mr. Pamuks German publisher, Hanser, gave no reason for the cancellation of his visit, which was to have taken him to the Free University in Berlin for an honorary doctorate before lectures in Hamburg, Cologne and Munich. A spokesman for the German interior ministry said the government had no information on any threat to Mr. Pamuk.

title: Investors Sweeten Honest Teas Pot
description: Honest Tea, a maker of organic bottled tea, has landed $12 million in equity financing from a handful of investors to help the company hire more workers and roll out new products. Honest Tea, a privately held company co-founded by Seth Goldman and Barry Nalebuff about nine years ago, says the new investment comes from Stonyfield Farm, Inventages Venture Capital Investment and several beverage distributors.

title: Vow at Citigroup to Fill Post Soon
description: The chief executive of Citigroup, Charles O. Prince, said yesterday that he expected to name a successor quickly to Sallie L. Krawcheck as Citigroups finance chief. I expect to have that job filled in 45 days, Mr. Prince said at the companys financial services conference. Ms. Krawcheck, the current chief financial officer, has been named to succeed Todd S. Thomson as head of wealth management.

title: Bush Tells Wall St. to Rethink Pay Practices
description: President Bush yesterday called on corporate boards to hold their chief executives more accountable by tying their pay to performance  a new message from a president who is closely allied to the business community. Addressing business leaders on Wall Street, Mr. Bush said the salaries and bonuses of C.E.O.s should be based on their success at improving their companies and bringing value to their shareholders.

title: Judge Throws Out a Conviction in Enron Case
description: A federal judge in Houston on Wednesday threw out the conviction of Kevin A. Howard, the former chief financial officer for Enrons Broadband unit, citing a ruling in a similar case in which the jurys verdict was vacated. The decision was based on a ruling in August by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, that essentially exonerates employees who provide so-called honest services while keeping with corporate goals and do not rob their employers of any money.

title: Report on Wall Streets Decline Draws More Skepticism
description: A study released this month by New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Charles E. Schumer, which flagged an exodus of foreign offerings from New York exchanges as a sign that Wall Streets dominance is on the wane, has sparked a debate over what the data really mean.

title: Times Co. Lowers Valuation of New England Newspapers
description: The New York Times Company said Wednesday that it was writing down by $814.4 million the value of its New England newspapers, The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, which have suffered from sluggish advertising and a migration of readers to the Internet.

title: New Blow to Milberg Weiss Under Inquiry
description: A few years before he faked the theft of two works of art from his home in Brentwood, Calif., Steven G. Cooperman, a former ophthalmologist, received a personal check from a partner of the law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad for $175,000 as an option payment on one of those works, Picassos Nude Before a Mirror.

title: N.Y.S.E. Makes Alliance With Tokyo Exchange
description: In a deal that allies the two biggest stock markets in the world, the NYSE Group, parent of the New York Stock Exchange, confirmed yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to form a strategic alliance with the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The alliance calls for cooperation on joint listings, trading technology and marketing, with the possibility of investing in each other in the future.

title: Russia Moves to Restrict Foreign Ownership of Energy Fields
description: The Russian government on Wednesday tentatively approved two laws that would sharply restrict foreign ownership of oil and natural gas fields, putting in writing a growing practice there. One law bans foreign majority ownership of companies in the aerospace, military and nuclear power industries, while stating that all others should be open equally to Russian and foreign capital. The second law limits foreign ownership of specific oil and gas fields.

title: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Extends Moratorium
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Wednesday extended for one year a moratorium on considering nonfinancial companies applications to establish or acquire banks. The decision suspends applications from companies like Wal-Mart Stores, Home Depot and DaimlerChrysler, and gives Congress time to consider legislation that would prohibit them from running their own lending banks, called industrial loan corporations.

title: Platinum Looks Set to Win Delphi Unit
description: Another private equity firm has joined the auto-parts fray. Platinum Equity became the lead bidder Wednesday for Delphis steering and hallshaft business, which has sales of $3.4 billion. Delphi, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, did not disclose terms of the deal, saying only that they would remain confidential until an asset purchase agreement is filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan.

title: SunCom Hires Goldman to Consider Sale
description: SunCom Wireless Holdings, a mobile phone carrier, announced a complex restructuring Wednesday that it said would eliminate about $680 million in debt. The company also said it had hired Goldman Sachs to consider a sale or other alternatives.

title: Carlyle Smooths Out Deal for Philosophy
description: The Carlyle Group said Wednesday that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Philosophy Inc., a fast-growing brand of lotions and personal-care products, for an undisclosed sum. The Deal.com said the company had been expected to go for about $450 million.

title: Head of Boston Buyout Shop Denies Ties to Terror
description: The chief executive of Overland Capital Group, a Boston private equity firm under federal investigation for its connection to groups accused of financing Islamic extremists, denied Wednesday that his company is linked to terrorism. We do everything appropriately and by the book, and we adhere not just to the letter of the law but to the spirit of the law, the executive, James M. Godec, told The Boston Globe. I am extraordinarily cautious about this kind of stuff.

title: Wall Street Journal Likes Looks of a Rival
description: As speculation mounts that The Financial Times may go on the block, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal positioned the company as a possible bidder for the newspaper. Gordon Crovitz, publisher of The Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, told The Guardian that the company would be interested in buying the Financial Times should its owner, Pearson, ever put it up for sale. If the F.T. ever were to come on the market we would look at it, he told The Guardian. But so far Pearson has [maintained] its not for sale.

title: The Rise of the Perk
description: Would bankers who took home part of last years juicy bonus pool be willing to trade it in for a sky-diving adventure on the companys tab? Maybe not, but for entrepreneurs, the perk, not the cash bonus, is gaining popularity, The New York Times says. In a tight labor market where large employers can lure workers with bigger salaries and the opportunity to work for a known company, entrepreneurs said they could gain an edge by offering generous perks, which range from sky-diving to pet sitting and spa visits.

title: Senators Criticize S.E.C. on Pequot Inquiry
description: Two prominent Republican senators renewed their criticism Wednesday of the way the Securities and Exchange Commission carried out its investigation into a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management. In separate speeches on the Senate floor, the senators, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, said the S.E.C.  which filed no charges against Pequot  had failed to aggressively follow up on investigative leads developed by the lawyer who led the inquiry, Gary J. Aguirre.

title: India I.P.O.s May Smash Records
description: A harmonic convergence of near double-digit economic growth, a roaring bull market, and expansion-minded executives has set the stage for another year of high-volume initial public offering activity in India, says BusinessWeek. And this year could be a record-buster.

title: Al Gore, the Silicon Valley Guy
description: As pundits, voters and Washington insiders wonder whether former Vice President Al Gore will jump into the 2008 presidential race, The San Jose Mercury News discusses what it calls a political problem for Mr. Gore should he choose to run. The newspaper writes that Mr. Gore has become enmeshed, and enriched, in Silicon Valley through his association with a close-knit elite that includes Apples founder and chief executive Steven P. Jobs, Googles chief executive, Eric Schmidt, and a venture capitalist, John Doerr, a Google director.

title: Chandlers Said to Extend Deadline in Tribune Bid
description: Tribunes largest shareholder, the Chandler family, on Wednesday extended the deadline on an offer for the Chicago-based media company, The Chicago Tribune reported. Talks are continuing between the special independent committee of the Tribune board considering options to maximize shareholder value and the Chandler family, which owns 20 percent of the company, the report said.

title: C.I.B.C. Executives Charged in Mutual-Fund Inquiry
description: The fallout from a four-year-old investigation into the mutual fund industry in the United States continues to haunt the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, after several former officials at the banks New York brokerage arm were accused Wednesday of taking part in an improper fund trading scheme. The Securities and Exchange Commission levied allegations against four officials, who it claimed collaborated with hedge funds to make deceptive trades. The S.E.C. also fined a former CIBC World Markets manager $100,000 as part of a settlement over allegations he repeatedly ignored warnings about his brokers.

title: Power Announces $3.9 Billion Deal for Putnam
description: The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan said on Thursday that it would sell its troubled money manager, Putnam Investments, to a unit of Power Financial of Canada for $3.9 billion. The sale price was in line with recent press reports, but toward the lower end of initial estimates of how much Putnam would fetch when Marsh & McLennan said in September that it was considering a sale.

title: Deutsches Fourth-Quarter Profit Surges
description: Deutsche Bank , Germanys biggest bank, said fourth-quarter profit more than tripled, helped by lower taxes and higher revenue from trading stocks and bonds. Net income rose to 1.8 billion euros ($2.35 billion), or 3.55 euros a share, from 487 million euros, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier. Profit beat analysts estimates of 1.39 billion euros as the companys tax rate unexpectedly fell to 22 percent from 31 percent in the third quarter. Revenue advanced 9 percent to 7.16 billion euros.

title: Tim Draper Backs Vibrator Maker
description: JimmyJane, a startup that makes high-end sex toys, has raised $1.1 million in financing from a group of investors that includes an entity controlled by Tim Draper, the veteran venture capitalist, according to Private Equity Week.

title: Courage Through Rhymes
description: So much of American pop thrives on a bratty facsimile of courage that when you see the real deal, it's a revelation. "East of Havana" is the real deal. Directed by Jauretsi Saizarbitoria and Emilia Menocal, it's a nonfiction feature about young Cuban rappers exercising the artist's prerogative to tell the truth in a country that muzzles free speech.

title: Losing  a Job, Making a Film
description: In "Fired!" the comedian Annabelle Gurwitch builds a ramshackle documentary around her dismissal from the cast of Woody Allen's 2003 Off Broadway play, "Writer's Block." A bizarre re-enactment of her final meeting with Mr. Allen features an unidentified Allen impersonator pouring out insults.

title: The Aftershocks of Racist Violence
description: If earnestness equaled skill, "Constellation" would be a classic.

title: A Gambling, Scrambling Life
description: "Tazza" is a Korean word referring to a gambler at the height of his powers. It could be applied to this film's writer and director, Choi Dong Hoon, who transforms what could have been another chronology-scrambling time waster into a terrific film about the sensual energy and reckless optimism of youth.

title: Is Barneys Headed to Market?
description: The Jones Apparel Group has had conversations with investment bankers about a potential break-up of the company, including an initial public offering of the Barneys New York luxury department store chain, The New York Post reported. The company has hired Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to help it explore all possible options, short of an outright sale of the company, according to the report. Jones Apparel put itself up for sale last year, but eventually called off the auction as a result of disappointing bids.

title: Time Warner Chief Says Cable Spinoff Is Top Priority
description: Time Warners chief executive, Richard Parsons, told the Financial Times that splitting off Time Warner Cable into a separate company is a top priority this year, though when the cable units shares will begin trading remains unclear. He also said he did not expect the new shares to be used to fund cable acquisitions right away. With the spinoff delayed by a ruling in the Adelphia Communications bankruptcy case, Time Warner is also exploring a traditional initial public offering for the cable unitl.

title: Dells Chief Is Replaced by Founder
description: Michael S. Dell has taken back the leadership of the computer company he founded, replacing Kevin B. Rollins after more than a year of mounting problems at Dell. The company announced Wednesday that Mr. Rollins had resigned as chief executive and as a director. Mr. Dell, who is the chairman, immediately assumed Mr. Rollinss duties as well.

title: Vornado Raises the Stakes in Equity Office Showdown
description: Vornado Realty Trust said Thursday it had raised its offer to buy the Equity Office Properties Group to $56 a share in cash and stock, marking the latest escalation in an increasingly personal contest to acquire the largest office landlord in the United States. Vornados latest bid surpasses last weeks offer of $54 a share in cash, or $38.3 billion, from the private equity firm Blackstone Group. Blackstone has already raised its price once since announcing its bid for Equity Office in November. Whoever wins, the transaction will be the biggest buyout in history.

title: Cellphone Camera Exposes Gagged Babies in Russian Hospital
description: Score another one for citizen journalists, as well as the digital technologies that have given rise to their number  and made institutional bad actors much more prone to discovery.

title: And No Axes To the Forehead, Either
description: In what sounds like an outtake for a Canadian version of Borat, the town council of Herouxville, Quebec, warned immigrant arrivals that they must not stone women to death in public, burn them alive or throw acid on them. Swearing at them, as long as its in French, is still allowed.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Ilan!
description: And was anyone really surprised?

title: Five Ways to Win
description: Variety describes the path to victory that each best picture nominee might take  and what hurdles might be in the way.

title: If Only Theyd Listen
description: Kris Tapley, one of the best awards handicappers around, was not his usual self on the SAG Awards  both he and the Bagger had some misses. But unlike the Bagger, he didnt blow it  the Screen Actors Guild did.

title: The Departed Deux
description: SPOILER ALERT: DONT READ IF YOU HAVENT SEEN THE DEPARTED

title: Start the Coffee Marge, Its Oscar Time
description: At 6 a.m this morning, Turner Classic Movies began a 31-day Oscar marathon. On Sunday, put yer camo on for The Dirty Dozen, the winner for best sound effects in 1967.

title: Money Talks
description: The House passed its  spending bill on Wednesday, with some Republicans pleasantly surprised by the content. Most, however, were irritated that no amendments could be offered. Senate Republicans will probably get to contribute more when that chamber takes up the bill.

title: You Mean There Were Movies Showing?
description: The Bagger ran into a New York film exec at Sundance and asked him what movies he liked so far. Hey, Im just out here making drug deals in the snow, he said. I havent see that many movies.

title: Neither Rain, Nor Sleet, Nor Hail of Gunfire
description: The Oscar ballots went out on time yesterday, despite a little ripple in the process reported by Defamer.

title: Disappearing Dreamgirls Reason No. 13
description: Nikki Finke reports that Sumner Redstone told a Hollywood gathering that he was told by Brad Grey that Dreamgirls didnt make the best pic cut because everyone hates David. Geffen, that is.

title: The Jennifer People Still Talk About
description: Last night, Jennifer Holliday belted out And Im Telling You Im Not Going, at the Rainbow Room with the same juice she had in 1981, when she originated the role of Effie in Dreamgirls on Broadway. (She performed at a party for Inspirations, a new book by Preston Bailey, a Hollywood event planner.)

title: National Treasures
description: Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu, Alfonso Cuarn, and Guillermo del Toro have a few things in common, including their Mexican heritage and a total of 16 Oscar nominations this year. And even though they are competing in a number of categories, they have never broken ranks as friends, compatriots and artists. When the Bagger talked to Mr. Irritu, who directed Babel, at the SAG awards, he emphasized the threesomes collective accomplishment of this awards season, saying that it marked a year of arrival for Mexican cinema. Mr. del Toro (whose biggest concern on the day that Pans Labyrinth was nominated for best foreign film was the exclusion of Pedro Almovodars Volver) and Mr. Cuarn have been similarly supportive and generous in their praise.

title: Tokyo Exchange Considers Alliance in Chicago
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange, which agreed this week to collaborate with the New York Stock Exchange, is discussing a potential alliance with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, an official at the Tokyo exchange said Thursday. We are in negotiations for a possible alliance with the C.M.E., especially in the area of futures trading of Japan government bonds, The spokesman, Toru Onoda, told The Associated Press.

title: Court Approves Settlement of Merrill Analyst Suits
description: Merrill Lynch won approval of a $40.3 million settlement of three lawsuits over claims it provided misleading analyst research about Internet companies. Judge John Keenan of United States District Court in New York on Wednesday approved settlements reached after investors appealed the 2003 dismissal of two of the cases. Judge Keenan also awarded $9 million to lawyers who represented almost 400,000 investors who sued.

title: Revolving Door: HSBC, Ernst & Young, J.P. Morgan
description: HSBC appointed Frank Slevin as its head of global banking, Asia-Pacific, a move aimed at building up its investment banking in the region. Mr. Slevin, who was formerly the chief operating officer of Citigroups Asia-Pacific investment-banking unit, will report to the heads of corporate and investment banking and markets and to the co-heads of global banking.

title: Tick Tock
description: The Bagger looked at all the plastic I.D. badges he has acquired in the last month  each with a photo that looks like it came off a post office wall  and he realized that, despite everything, he is still only pretending to know what he is talking about when it comes to this awards season. So much time, money and effort expended, and nothing to show for it except, thanks to all the free food, a trip to the local seamstress to let out the Baggers tuxedo pants.

title: Lehman Takes Stake in London Hedge Fund
description: Lehman Brothers bought a 20 percent stake in a London hedge fund, the Spinnaker Capital Group on Wednesday, marking its latest move into hedge funds. Terms of the deal were not available, but The New York Post reported Lehman may have paid between $75 million and $100 million for the stake in Spinnaker, a $5.4 billion fund. The paper also said that Lehman plans to raise its stake in Spinnaker to 25 percent by years end.

title: Just How Experienced Is Hillary?
Selected Times Articles by Molly Ivins
description: Elvis Presley Dies; Rock Singer was 42 (August 17, 1977)   Why They Mourned for Elvis (August 24, 1977)   Rites for Daniel P. O'Connell, 91, Draw Key New York Democrats (March 2, 1977)   Polygamy, Growing in U.S. West, Is Encountering Little Opposition (October 9, 1977)   A Lack of Ski Bums Creates Labor Shortages at Resorts (Feb. 8, 1979)   'Killer Bees' Follow Texas Tradition of Legislative Antics (May 232, 1979)   Conservatives in Idaho Pressing Drive to Defeat Senator Church (Dec. 27, 1979)   Census by Mule and Snowmobile (April 2, 1980)   Bad Day for Chickens in Southwest Town (July 13, 1980)

title: Portable Internet Phones
description: The latest options in portable Internet phone-calling equipment.

title: What Biden Meant
description: Suffice it to say that Joe Biden was not being the best Biden he can be in his interview with The New York Observer when he said, I mean, you got the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy.

title: 2008: More Biden Fallout, Pataki Out for Now
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden got serious on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show with Jon Stewart last night. After the fallout from the harsh criticism and insensitive remarks he directed at his Democratic presidential foes, including Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards, he very carefully clarified his comments.

title: Savings Rate at Depression-Era Lows  Does it Matter?
description: Whatever else might be on the minds of Americans, it certainly doesnt seem to be a rainy day. Not since the Great Depression have Americans been saving money at such a low rate, The Associated Press reports this morning. The rate, in fact, is a negative number for the second year in a row, according to the Commerce Department, suggesting that consumers have been taking away from their nest eggs, rather than contributing to them.

title: I Got YouTube
description: A couple of weeks back, I laid one of my famous high-tech song spoofs on you ("R.I.A.A."). I was certain the Pogue Grumpy Squad would lash out, condemning me for abandoning my usual gig of tech reviews. But no-they liked it just fine.

title: War at Home: Warner Revises His Resolution
description: Carl Hulse, our chief congressional correspondent, tells us that today could be the day for Senator John Warner to clear the path for debate next week on a compromise Senate resolution over President Bushs plan to increase troops in Iraq.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Translations" and "The Fever."

title: Why Paterson Doesnt Teach
description: After Gov. Eliot Spitzer briefed the Legislature on his budget proposal, his lieutenant governor, David Paterson, gave a speech on the benefits of universal pre-kindergarten.

title: LVMH Said to Buy Aston Martin
description: LVMH, the French conglomerate that owns luxury brands such as Louis Vuitton and Fendi, may be adding Aston Martin to its collection as well. MarketWatch said that the German trade publication Autobild was expected to report Friday that LVMH is set to buy Aston Martin, the British sports-car maker that is part of Ford Motors Premium Automotive Group. A spokesman for the Premium Automotive Group told Dow Jones Newswires that the sale process for Aston Martin was ongoing.

title: Tiny Little Bugs in Need of Squashing
description: David Mamet, from his new book, Bambi vs. Godzilla: On the Nature, Purpose, and Practice of the Movie Business.

title: Hedge Fund Moguls Back Giulianis Presidential Fund
description: Former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is getting support from some high-flying financiers as he considers whether to run for president in 2008. Data published on Wednesday by PoliticalMoneyLine.com show that contributors to Mr. Giulianis presidential exploratory committee, formed in November, include T. Boone Pickens, the Texas mogul who runs the hedge fund BP Capital Management; and Paul Tudor Jones II, the chairman of the hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. The fund also got money from Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, filings show.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the Market Place column, about private equity firms investing in suppliers of automotive parts, misstated the involvement of one financier, Wilbur L. Ross, in the Lear Corporation. Although Mr. Ross bought Lears unprofitable automotive interiors division in 2006, he does not hold any shares in Lear itself and does not control the company.

title: Bondss Deal Isnt a Deal Yet
description: The contract that Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants signed Monday after a 52-day delay was not a completed contract after all.

title: Clemens Still Undecided on Pitching in 2007
description: Roger Clemens offered little insight last night as to whether he would return to play this season.

title: Why Did Bush Step Into C.E.O. Pay Debate?
description: Business leaders applauded nearly everything President Bush said Wednesday during his visit to Wall Street. An exception was his call for more accountability on executive pay, which was met with silence from the crowd of business leaders at Federal Hall National Memorial. The compensation of chief executives should be based on their success at improving their companies and bringing value to their shareholders, Mr. Bush said, adding that Americas corporate boardrooms must step up to their responsibilities.

title: A Brutal Legacy of the Civil Rights Movement
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 1 column, A Death in Destrehan.

title: We Must Turn Outward
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Feb. 1 column, The Iraq Syndrome.

title: Bracing  or Just Praying?  for an I.P.O. Comeback
description: Could initial public offerings rebound this year? Some hopeful private equity managers and venture capitalists seem to think so. There is, Rob Garver of CFO.com declares, a growing feeling that the future may be 2007. One reason is that startups are getting restless. Going public is the goal, David Spreng, a partner at Crescendo Ventures, told CFO.com. When a C.E.O. is rallying the troops, hes not planting his flag and telling everyone, Lets build this company so that we can sell it to a private-equity firm.'

title: American Standard Finds Joy in Splitsville
description: Wall Street loves a good breakup these days. Case in point: American Standard, whose shares soared 7 percent Thursday after the company said it would carve itself into three separate companies through a spinoff of its vehicle-control systems unit and a sale of its kitchen and bath fixtures business. With those divisions gone, American Standard would be left with its air-conditioning business, called Trane.

title: Goodbye, Molly
description: Molly Ivins, the liberal columnist who wrote about politics with a poison pen and a caustic wit, as The Houston Chronicle put it, succumbed to breast cancer on Wednesday at 62.

title: Three Firms Top Bernsteins Trading Awards
description: If their year-end bonuses were not satisfying enough, traders at Lehman Brothers, Goldman Sachs, and Merrill Lynch can savor this latest prize: Bernstein Researchs 2006 Trading Awards.

title: Civilian Body Count in Iraq Maintains Upward Momentum
description: Attempts to total up the civilian casualties in Iraq always provide an opaque picture of things, given that various sources  the United Nations, the Iraq Interior Ministry and groups like Iraq Body Count  are only consistent at being at odds with one another.

title: What Exxon Mobil Does With Its Money
description: Here are a couple of highlights from Exxon Mobils report on its record profit of $39.5 billion in 2006:

title: Sen. Johnson Reading
description: Good news from Senator Tim Johnsons office today. The South Dakota Democrat, who has been at the George Washington University Hospital since he had emergency surgery for a brain aneurysm in mid-December, has made significant progress in his recovery, according to a release from his office.

title: Boston Ad Duo Plead Not Guilty  Take Questions on Hair
description: UPDATE: The two men arrested for decorating Boston with cryptic electronic advertisements for the Cartoon Networks popular animated show Aqua Teen Hunger Force were charged with disorderly conduct and, invoking a new state law in Massachusetts, according to Bostons WCBV TV, with placing, transferring or possessing a hoax device that results in panic.

title: Bloomie on His Dad
description: Mayor Bloomberg was in Israel today, far away from the outcry over the school bus snafu, but talking about something he doesnt talk about too much: his father. Diane Cardwell was there with him, and files this report.

title: Noh Advertising
description: The art of advertising, which people call obvious and shameless, has actually become impenetrable.

title: Movie Minutes: 'An Unreasonable Man'
description: Chief movie critic A. O. Scott reviews 'An Unreasonable Man,' the new documentary about Ralph Nader.

title: Nuclear Safety
description: The condition of a steel liner on a reactor is at the center of a license extension dispute in New Jersey.

title: N.F.L. Losing Its Religion
description: Can anyone make heads or tails of this? Why does the N.F.L. care that a church wants to use a 12-foot-wide projector to show the Super Bowl?

title: Osama bin Laden Surfaces in War Talk
description: Just when the pressure is building on both sides, or all sides, over resolutions in the Senate that generally oppose President Bushs plan to increase troop levels in Iraq by 21,500, the White House invokes Osama bin Laden.

title: Blogtalk: Gore and Pelosi
description: Congressional travel arrangements and Democratic presidential candidates both old and new played large roles on the blogs today.

title: 2007 Superbowl Ad
description: Kevin Federline appeared in a commercial for Nationwide Insurance.

title: I Got YouTube
description: A couple of weeks back, I laid one of my famous high-tech song spoofs on you (R.I.A.A.). I was certain the Pogue Grumpy Squad would lash out, condemning me for abandoning my usual gig of tech reviews. But no-they liked it just fine.

title: March of the Penguin Researchers
description: In the icy annals of emperor-penguin research, Apsley Cherry-Garrard has been one-upped.

title: The Irrational Voter
description: The ever-controversial Linda Hirshman, had an article in the Washington Post this past week, in which she depicted American women voters  and suburban stay-at-home moms in particular  as politically ignorant, disinterested and ultimately self-defeating.

title: Urlacher  Out of This World
description: How can a linebacker be so fast that he can keep up with slot receivers 30 yards downfield?

title: Severe Storms Strike Central Florida, Killing 19
description: Severe thunderstorms accompanied by at least one tornado ripped through central Florida early today, killing at least 19 people and tearing up houses, trees and power lines and blowing tractor-trailers off Interstate 4.

title: Canadian Insurance Giant to Buy Putnam Investments
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 1  Ending a month of speculation, Great-West Lifeco, which is controlled by the Montreal-based Power Corporation of Canada, said on Thursday that it would acquire Putnam Investments, a troubled mutual fund manager, from the Marsh & McLennan Companies for about $3.9 billion.

title: Closings and Cancellations Top Advice on Flu Outbreak
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1  In the event of a severe flu outbreak, schools should close for up to three months, ballgames and movies should be canceled, and working hours should be staggered so subways and buses are less crowded, the federal government said Thursday in issuing new pandemic flu guidelines to states and cities.

title: Historys Tangled Threads
description: FEW aspects of the American past have inspired more colorful mythology than the Underground Railroad. Its probably fair to say that most Americans view it as a thrilling tapestry of midnight flights, hairbreadth escapes, mysterious codes and strange hiding places.

title: In Uproar, Chirac Again Retracts Remarks on Nuclear Iran
description: PARIS, Feb. 1  President Jacques Chirac, seeking to limit the diplomatic reaction over his remarks on Irans nuclear ambitions, reaffirmed Thursday that France remained committed to preventing Iran from becoming a nuclear power.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,448,079.12

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: It Takes a Village to Put These Ratings in Perspective
description: It was only one of 82 games for the Devils this season, on the road last Saturday night against the Florida Panthers. Not much will be recalled. The Panthers won, 4-2, in front of 18,136 fans at the BankAtlantic Center.

title: Better Security for Judges
description: One of the more refreshing changes in Congresss mind-set growing out of the November election is that the House is no longer led by Republicans who demonize judges for sport. This change to more judge-friendly leadership should, at long last, lead to the Houses joining the Senate in passing a much-needed bill to protect federal judges from physical attack.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 10 P.M. (Showtime) DREAM CRUISE Dont bite the hand that feeds you: Norio Tsuruta, the mind behind Ringu O and Premonition, directs this Masters of Horror season finale about an American lawyer (Daniel Gillies) working in Tokyo who, though he is terrified of the ocean, takes a pleasure trip with an esteemed client (Ryo Ishibashi) and the clients wife (Yoshino Kimura)  whom he secretly loves.

title: Little Progress Seen for Poorest After Hurricane
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1  The recovery from Hurricane Katrina has stagnated for the poorest families displaced by the storm, a new study shows. Many still suffer from a significant loss of income, a higher-than-normal rate of chronic diseases like hypertension and an exponential rise in mental health problems among children.

title: F.B.I. Agent Says Libby Denied Being Leak Source
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  An F.B.I. agent told a jury Thursday that I. Lewis Libby Jr. claimed during formal interviews she conducted that he had not disclosed to two reporters the identity of Valerie Wilson, a Central Intelligence Agency operative.

title: The Oil-Addicted Ayatollahs
description: MOSCOW

title: Ex-Aide Says Party Boss Pressured Judge to Hire Vendor
description: Clarence Norman Jr.s former second-in-command in the Brooklyn Democratic Party testified yesterday that he saw his boss angrily threaten to withhold support for a judge on his ticket in 2002 if she refused to pay for fliers designed by the partys favored vendor.

title: Chinese Official Publishes Rebuke of Bush
description: BEIJING, Feb. 1  A senior Chinese government official issued a rare public rebuke of President Bush on Thursday, accusing him of waging a unilateral battle against terrorists that had worsened global tensions.

title: City Tells Parents It Understands as School Bus Crisis Eases a Bit
description: A deputy mayor and a deputy schools chancellor called a news conference yesterday to reassure parents that they were working hard to solve problems caused by changes to the citys school bus routes this week. At the same time, they said they were sorry for any inconvenience or confusion.

title: Behind the Asphalt Walls, Hopes and Heavy Burdens
description: Literally and existentially down and dirty, In the Pit is an absorbing documentary about work and the transformation of men into laborers. Directed and shot with sensitive attention to detail by Juan Carlos Rulfo, the film takes us into a world apart, populated by members of the construction crew building the second deck of the Perifrico beltway in Mexico City. For the citys inhabitants, each of whom apparently spend an estimated 1,485 hours a year commuting, and mostly on public transportation, the construction is at once a nuisance and a possible solution. For the most part, like construction sites everywhere, it is also hidden in plain sight.

title: Cuomo and Sharpton in Post-Election Conciliatory Mode
description: It has been just a month since Andrew M. Cuomo became New York States attorney general. But in that short time he has worked to establish a relationship with one prominent New Yorker from whom many elected officials stay at arms length.

title: Venezuela: Chvez Attacks Bush, Continued
description: President Hugo Chvez said President Bush should be tried for war crimes in relation to the Iraq war. He showed further disdain for Mr. Bush, saying he was unfit to manage even a Little League baseball team, in reaction to Mr. Bushs publicized concern about Mr. Chvezs new power to rule by decree. They should be tried and thrown in prison for the rest of their days, Mr. Chvez said of Mr. Bush and John D. Negroponte, who is designated for the No. 2 position in the State Department. Mr. Chvez also called Mr. Bush the devil, as he did in a speech at the United Nations in September.

title: U.S. Dialogue With China Suffers Setback
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The Bush administrations efforts to ease economic strains with China suffered two setbacks today with the resignation of a top official in charge of the China dialogue and an announcement that talks on a key trade dispute had failed to resolve differences.

title: Manhattan: Settlement in Landmarks Suit
description: The owners of Sushi Samba, a restaurant at 87 Seventh Avenue in the Greenwich Village Historic District, have agreed to pay $500,000 and build a new rooftop in a settlement with the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, the city announced yesterday. In 2000, the commission gave the restaurant permission to build a wooden open-air trellis on its roof. The restaurant built the trellis, but added several steel arches and covered the structure with a canvas-and-plastic enclosure, making it a year-round second story. The commission refused to approve the structure, and a Civil Court judge upheld the decision in 2003. The same year, the commission sued Sushi Samba after the restaurant refused to remove the addition. In June, a judge ruled in favor of the city and directed a referee to set civil damages.

title: A Disabled Girls Rights (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Manhattan: Settlement in Landmarks Suit
description: The owners of Sushi Samba, a restaurant at 87 Seventh Avenue in the Greenwich Village Historic District, have agreed to pay $500,000 and build a new rooftop in a settlement with the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, the city announced yesterday. In 2000, the commission gave the restaurant permission to build a wooden open-air trellis on its roof. The restaurant built the trellis but added several steel arches and covered the structure with a canvas-and-plastic enclosure, making it a year-round second story. The commission refused to approve the structure, and a Civil Court judge upheld the decision in 2003. The same year, the commission sued Sushi Samba after the restaurant refused to remove the addition. In June, a judge ruled in favor of the city and directed a referee to set civil damages.

title: Fund Officer Indicted
description: The former head of an Idaho hedge fund, Wood River Capital Management, has been indicted on charges that he engaged in securities fraud that cost investors $88 million, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Canada: Five Dead in 20-Vehicle Crash
description: Five people were killed in a multi-vehicle pileup east of Toronto that brought traffic on Canadas busiest route, Highway 401, to a standstill. As heavy snow fell and people worked to rescue victims trapped in cars, a tanker truck, one of at least 20 vehicles involved in the accident, burst into flames, producing a plume of black smoke that marked the site for hundreds of cars and trucks backed up for miles in both directions.

title: So Far, Obama Cant Take Black Vote for Granted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  He is hailed by his supporters as the hope of an increasingly multicultural nation, a political phenomenon who can wow white voters while carrying the aspirations of African-Americans all the way to the White House.

title: Complex, Contradictory Robert Moses
description: Few shows force you to rethink an urban legend. Thats the challenge posed by Robert Moses and the Modern City, a sweeping, scholarly exhibition that breathes fresh air into one of the most tired, overworked and misunderstood subjects in the citys history.

title: Gian Carlo Menotti, Composer of Amahl and Other Popular Operas, Dies at 95
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, who wrote his first opera before he was 11 and went on to become perhaps the most popular and prolific opera composer of his time, winning two Pulitzer Prizes, died Thursday in Monaco, where he had a home. He was 95.

title: New Man in the Hot Seat of State Health Commissioner
description: THE doctors office at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where he has been chief executive since 2002 but has abruptly forsaken to become state health commissioner in the Spitzer administration, looks pale and lifeless, with bare hooks on the beige walls where framed diplomas and memorabilia lately hung.

title: Theater Listings
description: BILLBOARD Two years ago Andrew Fischer, a Web site designer from Omaha, went on eBay with an offer to hawk someone elses product on his forehead. He eventually accepted a bid of $37,375 to wear a temporary tattoo of the SnoreStop logo for 30 days, went on to start a Web site (humanadspace.com) and encouraged others to sell out too. Mr. Fischer may not have started a movement but he has inspired a play. Billboard, by Michael Vukadinovich, uses the premise as a springboard to examine art, commercialism, love and the nexus of all three. I had these questions about art versus advertising and how much art has sold out, Mr. Vukadinovich said in a telephone interview. And I wanted to explore them in the context of a relationship. In the play Andy (Ken Matthews, center above) is paid a lot of money to wear a tattoo on his forehead for the fictional company Questa for a year, but his girlfriend, Katelyn (Sarah K. Lippmann, right), is not amused. At least not until she finds a way to use it, and him, to her advantage. Joey Piscopo (yes, the comedians son and the creator of the solo show Joe Piscopos Son), left, is the goofy best friend. The shows director, Tania Inessa Kirkman, and her design team have created a set that enthusiastically embraces commercialism by including a slew of obvious (but nonpaid) product placements, commercials for everything from Red Bull to Campbells Soup that play during intermission and corporate logos, made of light, dancing across the stage floor. To see Billboard is to be bombarded with advertising, but aint that America? (Tonight at 8:30, tomorrow at 3:30 and 8:30, and Sunday at 3:30, 59 East 59 Theaters, 212-279-4200, ticketcentral.com; $20, $14 for members.) STEVEN McELROY

title: Take Band, Add Singer on TV, Put Onstage, and Stir
description: La-di da-di, who wants to party? Lukas Rossi, wanted to know, though he neednt have asked. It was Wednesday night and Radio City Music Hall was full  O.K., maybe not quite full  of people who had paid good money to party with Mr. Rossi and his band. In a sense those people got what they deserved, though it could also be argued that no audience truly deserves what this one got.

title: 20 Members of Violent Street Gang Arrested in New Jersey Raids
description: WEST TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1  Staging a series of raids that ranged from the suburbs of Philadelphia to the Jersey Shore, the police on Thursday arrested 20 members of a street gang that is accused of widespread drug dealing and gun violence in Trenton and central New Jersey, the authorities said.

title: Bulls-Eyes and Body Parts: Its Theater, From Jasper Johns
description: WASHINGTON  Art and crass are all but inseparable. So its no surprise to find an exhibition that brings together a record number of Jasper Johnss famous target paintings being bankrolled by Target. You pass the corporate bulls-eye logo, small but vivid, on a wall on your way into Jasper Johns: An Allegory of Painting, 1955-1965 here at the National Gallery of Art.

title: U.S. Proposal on Farmers Subsidies Unlikely to Influence Trade Talks
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 1  A new United States proposal that would cut billions in government subsidies to American farmers is unlikely to inject new momentum into the Doha round of global trade talks, European trade negotiators said Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the testimony by Judith Miller, a former reporter for The New York Times, in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. referred incorrectly to an unrelated investigation by the Libby prosecutor in a case involving Ms. Millers reporting on Islamic charities. The prosecutor is trying to find out who Ms. Millers sources are, including by obtaining her telephone records. Ms. Miller is not herself under investigation in that case. The article also misstated the prosecutors surname at one point. He is Patrick J. Fitzgerald, not Fitzpatrick.

title: Girl Leaves Girl, Meets Boy and Then Meets Boys Girl
description: Snappy repartee with the ring of real conversation among people who are never at a loss for a remark is something every self-respecting Manhattan sophisticate imagines can be channeled into a screenplay with the crackle of vintage Woody Allen. That elusive tone is sustained through enough of Maria Maggentis film Puccini for Beginners to make it a rarity.

title: Court Rejects Tax Shelter Once Sold by KPMG
description: A federal judge in Texas has ruled that a widely used aggressive tax shelter was based on fake bank loans and is therefore not legitimate, giving an unexpected boost to federal prosecutors overseeing a widening criminal investigation into tax shelters.

title: For the Record
description: A news analysis article in The Arts yesterday about the effect on arts groups of New York Citys new process for dispensing culture funds misstated the name of a theater organization whose producing director, Liz Jones, commented on the process. It is Page 73 Productions, not Playwrights 73.

title: Spitzer Signals Concern Over Sale of Housing Tract
description: Tenants groups girding for a fight over the sale of Starrett City, the sprawling low- and middle-income housing complex on the south shore of Brooklyn, have a powerful new ally: Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

title: Suspects in Fishkill Familys Deaths Are Indicted on Undisclosed Charges
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., Feb. 1  The two men arrested last week in connection with the murder of a family of five were indicted by a Dutchess County grand jury Wednesday evening, hours after investigators found a rifle and a lockbox in a lake near one of the suspects homes, the authorities said.

title: Mayor Dedicates Israeli Medical Facility in Fathers Name
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1  As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has evolved from a billionaire media mogul to a billionaire public servant, his mother, Charlotte, 98, has been a constant vibrant presence, whether as an honored guest at special events or an oft-mentioned confidante in the mayors remarks.

title: Snowbirds Flock Together for Winter
description: IT takes a big state to absorb the entire North every winter, but once again, Florida is pulling it off. From Miami to Pensacola, the cold-weather escapees have been filtering in, completing the midwinter migration to the Northerners' land of dreams  or at least, the land of polo shirts and khaki shorts. And with more than 50,000 square miles of territory, Florida has plenty of room for all of them  sun-hungry retirees, peripatetic second-home owners and seasonal settlers  to spread out.

title: The Many Sides of Sidney Sheldon
description: Some of the novels, films and television shows by Sidney Sheldon or based on his work that are available in print, on tape or on DVD:

title: Somber Words and Images, Etched in Blue or Gray
Regrets, He Has Quite a Few, and All Are Mentioned
description: Yasmina Rezas latest novel, Adam Haberberg, like her hit play, Art, is a polished, pared-down, professionally turned production that appears to tackle big ideas  Time, Mortality, the Possibility of Human Connection, the Meaninglessness of Life  but does so with the paint-by-numbers breeziness of a television mini-series. While Adam Haberberg starts off promisingly as a sympathetic portrait of a writer filled with regrets about his life and art, it soon devolves into a kind of dumbed-down, user-friendly imitation of Krapps Last Tape  Beckett Extra Lite, as it were, transported to the Paris suburbs.

title: Bush Seeks Big Medicare and Medicaid Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Bush will ask Congress in his budget next week to squeeze more than $70 billion of savings from Medicare and Medicaid over the next five years, administration officials and health care lobbyists said Thursday.

title: Colts and Bears and Kevin Federline
description: If you think politics makes strange bedfellows, consider the advertising hookup that grabbed so much attention this week: Nationwide Insurance and Kevin Federline.

title: Snow or No, Its a Party
description: NECESSITY, it is said, is the mother of invention. So when exceptionally warm weather last month threatened St. Pauls ice maze  the centerpiece of the annual Winter Carnival  organizers were forced to improvise. Lake Phalen, from which the 2,500 giant, 400-pound blocks of ice to build the maze are usually cut, just wasnt frozen enough.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Once Again, a Question of Execution, but in a Dual Killing Much Overlooked
description: Some death penalty cases are less equal than others. Take the capital murder trial of a man known to his admirers as Preme, short for Supreme.

title:
Late for Court: Connecticut Case
Draws Scrutiny
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 1  Some call the failure to appear charge a prosecutors best friend because it is relatively easy to prove and can swiftly bring a defendant to the bargaining table. Others see the long-accepted but little-discussed practice of punishing late or absentee defendants as a crutch for overworked judges to maintain decorum and keep criminal cases from clogging their courtrooms.

title: Ariza Is Gone, but Trade Continues to Confound Knicks
description: Whatever goes wrong for the Knicks this weekend  and something surely will, given their recent ill fate  Coach Isiah Thomas will at least be spared one cringe. He will not have to see Trevor Ariza soaring over his team for a thunderous, momentum-altering dunk.

title: S.E.C. Approves New Method for Companies to Value Stock Options
description: Can an auction of a new type of security prove that stock options are not worth as much as financial models say they are  and therefore allow companies to report higher profits while handing out options to employees and executives?

title: Connecticut Parishioners Still Admire Ousted Priest
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 1  The Rev. Michael R. Moynihans taste for the good life was an open secret.

title: Senate Democrats Warn F.C.C. of Tough New Oversight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Signaling tougher oversight, Democrats who recently gained control of the Senate urged the head of the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday to take a more aggressive approach to the industries he oversees.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: British Theaters Shut Museum in DVD Dispute

title: Regulators Challenge Kentucky Ruling Favoring Religion-Based Health Plan
description: A Christian ministry that helps its members pay one anothers medical bills has won an important round in its legal battle with insurance regulators in Kentucky, but regulators have already taken steps to challenge that victory.

title: Two Americans Killed in Helicopter Crash in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 2  An American Apache attack helicopter was shot down today just north of Baghdad, and both crewmembers were killed, an American military official said.

title: Presidential Records (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dark Days Follow Hard-Hitting Career in N.F.L.
description: Ted Johnson helped the New England Patriots win three of the past five Super Bowls before retiring in 2005. Now, he says, he forgets peoples names, misses appointments and, because of an addiction to amphetamines, can become so terrified of the outside world that he locks himself alone inside his Boston apartment in bed with the blinds drawn for days at a time.

title: Art in Review
description: COSMOLOGIES James Cohan Gallery  533 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through Feb. 10

title: Warhols Anointed Starlet, Drowning in the Glitterati
description: Its not entirely inappropriate that Factory Girl, George Hickenloopers biography of Edie Sedgwick, the most glamorous of Andy Warhols so-called superstars, should suggest a magazine layout masquerading as a film. The world through which Sedgwick blazed and burned out was one that lived and died by the camera. It existed to be seen and drooled over. But God help you if you actually lived in it.

title: Democracy Rules, and Pop Culture Depends on It
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1  No one will vote to declare the winner of the Super Bowl on Sunday. But you might be excused for thinking it possible.

title: Manhattan: Subway Maintenance Criticized
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has routinely fallen behind in its plan for bringing crucial areas of the subway system up to a state of good repair, according to a report released yesterday by the citys comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr. The report warned that the authority might backslide further if it is forced to cut its long-term spending budget because of increasing construction costs. The document cited goals set by the authority in 1992 and showed how they have been pushed back over time. For instance, the original target for full renovation or replacement of all the subways fan plants, which draw smoke out of the system during a fire, was 2007, but over time it was postponed to 2028, according to the report. The authority said in a statement that it would look into the reports findings.

title: After a Death Sentence, a Flurry of Questions for Widows
description: By any standard, the topic yesterday was oddly grim for a news conference: Would you attend the lethal injection of your husbands killer?

title: A Bit of Bavaria in a Mountain Town
description: When Erika and Chris Price were searching for a vacation cabin two years ago, a couple of friends who knew their way around snowshoes and hiking boots suggested they try the Leavenworth region in Central Washington.

title: Nissan Reports 23% Drop in Profits for Quarter
description: Nissan, Japans third-largest automaker, today reported a 23 percent decrease in quarterly profit and said it expects full-year earnings to fall for the first time in seven years.

title: Exxon and Shell Report Record Profits for 2006
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1  Oil prices have fallen, but Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell left their smaller competitors in the dust and reported record annual profits Thursday.

title: Vornado Raises Offer for REIT
description: The bruising fight over Equity Office Properties, the nations biggest office landlord, has entered its final round. But neither side has managed to land a knockout blow.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Clashes Between Hamas and Fatah Escalate
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2  In some of the worst fighting between Palestinian factions so far, security-force members loyal to Fatah stormed the Hamas-aligned Islamic University today, setting the library and other buildings on fire, as the two factions battled today in several parts of the Gaza Strip.

title: Dollar Still Almighty, for Now
description: Is New Yorks status as financial capital of the world in danger?

title: A Bipartisan Trade Policy
description: The newest Democratic members of Congress have arrived in Washington with an important message from the voters: American workers are feeling economically insecure, and globalization and trade are heightening their fears. The White House and the new Congress still have a chance to create a bipartisan consensus on trade. They should seize it, for the good of the American economy, and for the good of the worlds poorest nations, which need freer trade to pull themselves out of poverty.

title: Albany Raises State Limit on Donations to Candidates
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1  New York, which already allows people to contribute more money to candidates for statewide office than any other state that limits contributions, is about to allow people to donate even more: more than $55,000 to each candidate, a nearly 10 percent increase.

title: Ulsters Last Holdout
description: Northern Ireland has lost thousands of lives, billions of dollars in economic opportunity and decades of democratic self-rule to what its people euphemistically call the troubles. One man now has it in his power to help this British-ruled province finally put this lamentable era behind it and move on to a brighter future  or to stand in the way. That man is the Rev. Ian Paisley, the fiery Protestant preacher, now 80 years old, who leads the provinces largest party, the Democratic Unionists. Mr. Paisley, though, has yet to rise to the moment and acknowledge that the times have changed and his former foes have changed with them.

title: A New Ski Tour Brings Snow, a Show and Many Parties
description: TOMMY LEE, the former Motley Cre drummer, steps into a makeshift D.J. booth in Sun Valley, Idaho, tattoos and nipple rings in full splendor like a peacocks feathers. Throngs of tipsy women in eerily similar outfits  designer jeans, studded belts and skintight T-shirts  suddenly materialize on the living-room dance floor, vying for his attention.

title: New Orleans Coroner Sees No Evidence Yet for Indictments
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1  More than seven months after Louisianas attorney general recommended that a doctor and two nurses be prosecuted for putting patients to death in Hurricane Katrinas aftermath, the coroner here said Thursday that he had not yet found evidence that would show that the cases were homicides.

title: Whitney Balliett, Jazz Critic, Is Dead at 80.
description: Whitney Balliett, a jazz critic at The New Yorker magazine for more than 40 years whose vivid, highly metaphorical writing encouraged readers to hear jazz through his prose, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Ken Kavanaugh, 90, Former Bears Receiver and Giants Aide, Is Dead
description: Ken Kavanaugh, an All-Pro receiver for the Chicago Bears in the 1940s and an assistant coach and scout for the New York Giants for 45 years, died Jan. 25 in Sarasota, Fla., where he had lived since retiring from football in 1999. He was 90.

title: Barclays Arena Deal Raises a Reputed Link to Slavery
description: Hakeem Jeffries, a state assemblyman who supports the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, has denounced an important facet of it  the name for the new arena for the Nets basketball team, which he called an affront to the black community.

title: Hong Kong: Leader Agrees to Debate Pro-Democracy Rival
description: Donald Tsang, Hong Kongs chief executive, agreed to debate his challenger, Alan Leong, before the 796-member Election Committee votes on March 25 to choose who will lead the territory for the next five years. The campaign debate will be a first for the territory, but television signals from Hong Kong during the debate are likely to be blocked in mainland China because Mr. Leong favors introduction of full democracy in Hong Kong.

title: The Iraq Debacle and U.S. Power (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Town, Sized Down, Jazzed Up
description: There is a spot in New York City where you can watch the dawn blush over Jamaica Bay in Queens and slip swiftly down the shore to Coney Island in Brooklyn, then hop across New York Harbor to suburban stretches of Staten Island.

title: Manhattan: Historical Society Revises Blueprints
description: The New-York Historical Society unveiled a redesign of its proposed new facade, left, before a turbulent meeting of 450 community residents on Wednesday night. The meeting took place in the church of the Fourth Universalist Society at Central Park West and 76th Street, across the street from the historical societys headquarters. The plan calls for a granite portico at the main entrance and a less prominent exposure of glass than the previous design, which the public policy committee of the New York Landmarks Conservancy rejected in December. After Louise Mirrer, the historical societys president, declined to discuss a possible 23-story luxury residential tower atop its building until the society selected a real estate developer, there were catcalls and some residents walked out. The journalist Bill Moyers, who lives a block away, won a standing ovation when he commented that a tower would permanently disturb a skyscape that is unique.

title: Girls Team Encounters Big Angles on Learning Curve
description: Randolph, N.J.

title: Even Before Its Release, World Climate Report Is Criticized as Too Optimistic
description: In its 2001 assessment, its third, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimated that in the next hundred years sea level would rise globally by at least a few inches and perhaps as much as three feet, a catastrophe for low-lying coastal areas and island nations.

title: Corrections
description: The headline with an article on Wednesday about a Senate proposal to raise the minimum wage misstated the action taken by senators. By a vote of 87 to 10, the Senate agreed to limit the debate on the bill, clearing the way for a final vote, which resulted in passage yesterday. The Senate did not pass the wage bill on Wednesday.

title: Many Old Master Drawings, One Anonymous Collector
description: When the Metropolitan Museum exhibited Leonardo da Vinci drawings in 2003, visitors had to stand in line to see individual works. While waiting, they could pass the time reading the wall labels, where amid the fine print the works lenders were listed. Most were auspicious collections: the Louvre, the Vatican, the Met, the Royal Library at Windsor Castle.

title: Clinton Setting a $1 Million Goal for Donors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is establishing record-setting goals for presidential campaign fund-raising, her advisers say, asking donors to raise at least $1 million for the honor of being in her top echelon of supporters.

title: Homeless Given Apartments in Buildings Called Unsafe
description: The city agency in charge of helping homeless people move into permanent housing has placed thousands of families in dangerous apartments plagued by a range of conditions that include lead paint hazards, collapsing ceilings and inadequate heat and hot water, according to a report released yesterday by the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: Mets Look to Sosa After Williams Has Surgery
description: The Mets are casting a large net to find pitchers for opening day this season, and one has already fallen through.

title: Afghans Urge Legal Amnesty for Those Involved in Wars
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 1  Afghanistans lower house of Parliament has approved a nonbinding resolution urging the government to grant immunity to all Afghans involved in the wars of the last 25 years.

title: Iran Leader Calls Nuclear Sanctions Ineffective
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 1  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, under increasing criticism at home, said Thursday that his nation was becoming a superpower and that the United Nations sanctions would not deter it from pursuing its nuclear program.

title: Its Squawk Box Meets Saturday Night Live
description: A few years ago, a video on the stock performance of Jack in the Box might have involved a sit-down interview with the fast-food restaurants chief executive, dryly discussing its fundamentals.

title: Missing Molly Ivins
description: Molly Ivins, the Texas columnist, died of breast cancer on Wednesday. I first met her more than three years ago, when our book tours crossed. She was, as she wrote, a card-carrying member of The Great Liberal Backlash of 2003, one of the half-dozen or so writers now schlepping around the country promoting books that do not speak kindly of Our Leaders record.

title: A Backups Job Is to Be Ready to Go in a Snap
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about steps that the utility PacifiCorp must take in order to renew its license to produce electricity carried outdated information about its parent company. It is now a division of MidAmerican Energy Holdings Company, not ScottishPower.

title: Blair Gives 2nd Interview in Inquiry About Graft
description: LONDON, Feb. 1  After a news blackout lasting six days, the British police acknowledged Thursday that officers interviewed Prime Minister Tony Blair a second time last Friday over allegations that high honors had been traded for campaign contributions.

title: Ryszard Kapuscinski
description: Where does the truth of history lie? In coups and revolutions, in wars and treaties and the chronicles of our textbook heroes and antiheroes? Or does it lie in the pulse of ordinary life, in a dailiness that looks almost hallucinatory if you venture outside it? I think of Ryszard Kapuscinski, who died at 74 on Jan. 23, as an emissary between those two versions of history. His writing life divides between the conventional reporting he did for the Polish press agency PAP  a voluntary slavery, as he described it, that made the whole world available to him  and the literary journalism that has found its way into books like Imperium, The Soccer War and The Emperor.

title: A Journalist and Beauty, Working It in Iraq
description: Exploitation cinema of the most narcoleptic kind, The Situation stars Connie Nielsen, the blank-faced Danish beauty, as a correspondent sniffing around wartime Iraq. When we first see Ms. Nielsens character, Anna Molyneux, shes swathed in a black chador, her press credentials swinging under the billowing fabric like ropes of pearls. Riding shotgun in a car in the middle of the country, dust and intimations of intrigue swirling around her, Anna comes across as a reconstituted Lee Miller, the outrageously glamorous photojournalist who, when not bedding Man Ray or hanging out with Picasso, reported on World War II battles and death-camp atrocities.

title: Inmate Who Fled With Officials Wife Is Sentenced for Escape
description: MANGUM, Okla., Feb. 1  A confessed murderer who slipped out of prison with the deputy wardens wife and hid for more than 10 years before being recaptured was sentenced Thursday to the maximum seven years for escaping.

title: Company Will Pay Boston After Scare Over Ads
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1  Turner Broadcasting agreed Thursday to cover all the costs that Boston incurred as a result of an advertising campaign that set off fears of a possible terrorist action, the mayors office said.

title: How Tax-Cut Plan Favors Middle-Income Households
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1  First, some bad news. New York State is expecting to collect nearly $61 billion in taxes next year.

title: Clorox Reports 16% Higher Profit
description: The Clorox Company, maker of bleach and Glad trash bags, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 16 percent as higher prices overshadowed an increase in advertising costs. The results beat analysts estimates, sending the stock up the most in more than four months.

title: Intelligence Report Predicts Spiraling of Violence in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A much-anticipated assessment of Iraq by Americas intelligence agencies describes a worsening cycle of chaos in the country, and predicts that the sectarian strife will continue to fracture the country without bold actions by Iraqi politicians.

title: World View Podcast
description: SIMS. Welcome to The New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe. Im Calvin Sims of The Times. I spent 10 years as a foreign correspondent for the paper.

title: A Blend of New and Old Germanic Expressionism
description: The Argento Chamber Ensemble has been in business since 2000, but its players look as if they are only moments out of conservatory. They play that way too  in a good way. Their technical polish lets them move easily through the rhythmic and harmonic thickets of the contemporary styles that are their specialty, but they also bring to their performances the kind of unsettled, restless energy that seems a special province of the young. Michel Galante, the groups conductor, is able to transform these warring qualities into readings that make even relatively static pieces sound dynamic and charged.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: U.S. Reconfigures the Way Casualty Totals Are Given
description: Statistics on a Pentagon Web site have been reorganized in a way that lowers the published totals of American nonfatal casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Senate Report Says S.E.C. Botched Hedge Fund Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission mishandled its inquiry into suspect trades by a prominent hedge fund, then may have tried to cover up those mistakes after its chief investigator on the case complained, according to an interim Senate report released yesterday.

title: Ex-Players Say Increase in Pensions Is Needed
description: MIAMI, Feb. 1  Disenchanted with the National Football League and its players union, a group of retired players has organized an online auction to raise money for former players in need.

title: General Parries Senate Attacks on Iraq Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The departing American commander in Iraq defended his record on Thursday against withering criticism from some Senate Republicans and said Baghdad could be stabilized with far fewer additional troops than President Bush planned to send.

title: Serbia Rejects U.N. Plan for Independent Kosovo
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Feb. 2  Serbia rejected a United Nations proposal today that paves the way for an independent Kosovo, setting up a possible showdown between its supporter, Russia, and the West over the disputed territorys final status.

title: Detroit Slips in January as Market Share Declines
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1  Detroits automakers fell into virtually a dead heat with their foreign competition in January.

title: For the Record
description: The Our Towns column on Sunday, about the chances of a candidate from the Northeast being elected president, referred imprecisely to Millard Fillmore, the first in an almost unbroken line of presidents, from 1850 to 1944, who were either born or made their name in the Northeast or Midwest. Fillmore, then the vice president, ascended to the presidency when Zachary Taylor died in office; Fillmore was not elected president. (Two other presidents during that time span  Andrew Johnson and Chester A. Arthur  also took office upon the death of the incumbent, not by election.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: INSIDE THE BASKETBALL TRIANGLE

title: Divisions on War Seen at Gathering of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  To shouts and cheers from thousands of Democrats assembled here, the partys leading presidential contenders condemned President Bushs handling of the war in Iraq today but sharply differed over how to end it, particularly whether Democrats should settle for a non-binding Senate resolution expressing opposition to Mr. Bushs war policies.

title: Profit Fell at CA Inc. in 3rd Quarter
description: CA Inc., the maker of software for mainframe computers, said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell 12 percent because of restructuring costs.

title: Mother, Please, Id Rather Do It Myself
description: In Because I Said So, Diane Keaton plays Daphne Wilder, the single mother of three grown daughters: Maggie (Lauren Graham), the responsible one; Milly (Mandy Moore), the single, flaky one; and Mae (Piper Perabo), the one who wears the skimpiest clothes. Mom, while a bit scattered in other ways, is a fanatical micromanager when it comes to her girls emotional lives, and she is especially worried that Milly, who manages a catering business, will end up with the wrong guy or no guy at all.

title: Sidney Sheldon, Literate Master of Pulp Panache
description: In Sidney Sheldons pulp-fiction lollapalooza The Other Side of Midnight, the heroine is an aspiring French actress named Noelle Page. She is destined to become a world-famous movie star, but early in the story she remains humble. Well, humble-ish. In wartime Paris as an ambitious young thing, she attends a performance of Jean-Paul Sartres No Exit.

title: Bolivias Only Ski Resort Is Facing a Snowless Future
description: CHACALTAYA, Bolivia, Jan. 28  The lodge here at what bills itself as the worlds highest ski resort has fraying black-and-white photos evoking memories of the years when this country had an Olympic ski team.

title: Pole-Vaulter Keeps a Low Profile During Her Ambitious Ascent
description: Yelena Isinbayeva has heard many things about New York. She has heard that those who visit New York for the first time tend to fall in love with it. But on the ride from the airport to her hotel, she saw nothing of interest, none of the designer shops or gourmet restaurants she would like to visit, and certainly not the Statue of Liberty.

title: Judges Pose Questions on Bush Detainee Policy
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 1  In a series of probing and sometimes testy exchanges with a government lawyer, two of three judges on a federal appeals court panel here indicated Thursday that they might not be prepared to accept the Bush administrations claim that it has the unilateral power to detain people it calls enemy combatants.

title: Shootout in Gaza Deepens Bitter Split
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1  A fragile truce between Palestinian factions in Gaza broke down Thursday when Hamas members fired on a convoy from the rival Fatah group, touching off an intense gun battle that killed six people and wounded at least 50.

title: Dungy and Smith Are Proving Nice Coaches Can Finish First
description: MIAMI, Feb. 1  On a Monday morning more than a decade ago, after the Tampa Bay Buccaneers lost their first five games of the season, the first-year head coach Tony Dungy gathered his assistants. One of them was Lovie Smith, the linebackers coach, in his first N.F.L. season.

title: Judge Explains His Dismissal of Scientists Suit Against Times
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  A federal judge who dismissed a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times acted after concluding that the scientist who brought the case, a bioterrorism expert investigated over deadly anthrax mailings in 2001, was a public official and could not show that the newspaper had knowingly published false information.

title: 2 Men Cleared of Charges of Aiding Hamas Violence
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1  Two men were acquitted Thursday of federal charges that they provided money and other aid to the Palestinian organization Hamas in the early 1990s.

title: Retailers Shake-Up Continues as Executive in Charge of Gap Resigns
description: The Disney team is out at Gap.

title: Bush Gets Aid of Democrats in Fighting Pandemics
description: At a time of intensifying conflict between President Bush and Democrats in Congress over the Iraq war, the Democratic-led House acted this week to rescue another of Mr. Bushs international priorities: the global fight against AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, diseases that kill millions of Africans each year.

title: Consumer Spending Up the Most in 5 Months
description: Consumer spending rose in December by the most in five months, helping the economy weather a slump in manufacturing that extended into 2007.

description: Coca-Cola said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Fuze Beverage to add more juice, tea and energy drinks in an effort to catch up with PepsiCo.

title: Jobs Growth Slows but Remains Strong
description: Employers across the nation added 111,000 jobs last month, a pullback from the pace of previous months but still enough to sustain the recent trend of steady strength in the labor markets, the government reported today.

I just thought she was going to live a long time. I didnt think she was going to die before my graduation.

Putin said Thursday that Russia would consider OPEC-like cooperation with Tehran on sales of natural gas.
