description: PARIS, Feb. 2  In a bleak and powerful assessment of the future of the planet, the leading international network of climate change scientists has concluded for the first time that global warming is "unequivocal" and that human activity is the main driver, "very likely" causing most of the rise in temperatures since 1950.

title: Compromise Senate Measure Rebuffing Bushs Iraq Buildup Gathers Support
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  A revised Senate resolution criticizing President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq drew new support Thursday as two authors of a sterner resolution of disapproval said they would accept the compromise, fashioned by Senator John W. Warner.

title: South Africans Mourn a Figure From the Fight Against Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 1  In banner newspaper headlines and broadcast biographies, South Africans on Thursday mourned the death of Adelaide Tambo, a figure in the nations battle against apartheid and the wife of Oliver R. Tambo, an icon of the liberation struggle.

title: Florida to Shift Voting System With Paper Trail
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1  Gov. Charlie Crist announced plans on Thursday to abandon the touch-screen voting machines that many of Floridas counties installed after the disputed 2000 presidential election. The state will instead adopt a system of casting paper ballots counted by scanning machines in time for the 2008 presidential election.

title: Raytheon Surpasses Sales and Profit Forecasts
description: Raytheon, the worlds largest manufacturer of missiles, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 26 percent on higher foreign sales and electronics work for a new Navy ship. The company increased its sales and earnings forecasts for 2007.

title: Albany: Campaign to Highlight New Minimum Wage
description: The states acting labor commissioner, M. Patricia Smith, announced yesterday that the Labor Department would begin a campaign to alert businesses and workers that the states minimum wage rose to $7.15 an hour on Jan. 1, up from $6.75. The federal minimum wage is $5.15 an hour. To publicize this change, the state plans to distribute thousands of palm cards and posters in English, Spanish, Chinese, Creole, Russian and Korean. The department also plans to ask more than 2,000 community groups and social service agencies to help spread the word.

title: Tennessee: Review of Executions Is Ordered
description: Gov. Phil Bredesen has ordered a review of state execution procedures and delayed four executions planned in the next 90 days. Mr. Bredesen, a Democrat, said he called for the review because of deficiencies with our written procedures found during preparation for litigation over legal injections. He said he was convinced there were no problems with two previous executions but wanted to ensure that no cloud hangs over the states actions in the future. He asked the Department of Correction to write new protocols by May 2.

title: Armory Raises Rent for Art Fairs
description: Organizers of the many art, antiques and crafts fairs at the Seventh Regiment Armory got the news that theyve been dreading: Their rent is being doubled, to $20,000 a day, effective immediately. By the fall it will be raised to $30,000 a day. Two annual shows that donate their admission fees to charities, the Winter Antiques Show and the Art Dealers Association Art Fair, will be charged a special rate of $15,000 a day.

title: Trenton: Nominee for Human Services Chief
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday announced his nomination of Jennifer Velez, 41, currently a deputy commissioner of the State Department of Human Services, to lead the agency; his previous appointee, Clarke Bruno, resigned for personal reasons. Ms. Velez, of Summit, was previously the first assistant at the Office of the Child Advocate. Mr. Bruno will become a special counsel in the Office of the Governors Counsel.

title: Engineers Say 120 Levees Are Flood Risk
description: More than 120 levees around the country could fail in a major flood and need to be better maintained, the Army Corps of Engineers said yesterday.

He is Eric N. Gioia, not Jioa.

title: Pretending to Like the Little People
description: That species of star known as the celebrity altruist is a creature in whom the British comic Ricky Gervais seems to have absolutely no faith. The actors, directors and rock singers who give money to Holocaust foundations and adopt babies from impoverished places and expound before the United Nations General Assembly on the crisis of African debt  these people simply do not figure in his consciousness, one consumed by a brilliantly uncharitable view of fame.

title: Manhattan: Court Rejects Graffiti Law
description: A federal appeals court panel yesterday upheld a lower courts ruling that a widely criticized city law designed to cut down on graffiti was unconstitutional. The panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit said that the city could not ban the sale of spray paint and broad-tipped markers to people ages 18 to 20. The city had already been prevented from enforcing the law, which took effect on Jan. 1, 2006, because of a preliminary injunction issued in May by Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court in Manhattan. The three-judge appeals court panel said that portions of the law appear to burden substantially more free speech than is necessary. Seven high school and college students had filed suit, saying the law illegally limited their rights under the First Amendment.

title: Chirac's First Interview on Iran
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France with The New York Times, the International Herald Tribune and Le Nouvel Observateur on January 29, 2007. A: Je voudrais dire qu'il y a d'abord deux problmes diffrents: c'est l'lectronuclaire et le nuclaire militaire. Ce qui nous inquite en Iran, ce n'est pas l'lectronuclaire. C'est le nuclaire militaire, l'enrichissement de l'uranium. C'est a qui nous inquite. C'est le refus de l'Iran d'accepter les contraintes de l'AIEA et donc d'arrter d'enrichir l'uranium. C'est trs dangereux. Il faut y faire trs attention. Je dirais que ce n'est pas tellement dangereux par le fait d'avoir une bombe nuclaire - une, peut-tre une deuxime un peu plus tard, ce n'est pas trs dangereux. Mais ce qui est trs dangereux c'est la prolifration. a veut dire que si l'Iran poursuit son chemin et matrise totalement la technique lectronuclaire, le danger n'est pas dans la bombe qu'il va avoir, et qui ne lui servira  rien. Il va l'envoyer o, cette bombe ? Sur Isral ? Elle n'aura pas fait 200 mtres dans l'atmosphre que Thran sera rase. Ce qui est dangereux c'est la prolifration. Il est quand mme trs tentant pour d'autres pays qui ont de gros moyens financiers, dans cette rgion, de dire " Eh bien, nous aussi, on va le faire. On va aider d'autres  le faire ". Pourquoi est-ce que l'Arabie Saoudite ne le ferait pas ? Pourquoi n'aiderait elle pas l'Egypte  le faire galement ? C'est a le danger. Donc il faut trouver un moyen de rgler ce problme. Alors a, c'est le nuclaire militaire. Q: Jusqu'o les Occidentaux peuvent-ils aller dans la menace de sanctions contre l'Iran, sans risquer de reprsailles, notamment sur le Liban aussi ? A: Ce n'est pas tout  fait le sujet de notre entretien. J'ai pour le Liban les sentiments que vous connaissez, je ne suis pas suspect. Comment peut-on faire en ralit, c'est la question, pour imposer des contraintes suffisamment fortes  l'Iran ? Alors, c'est difficile. Il faut savoir ce que l'Iran peut supporter ou non. L'Iran [] a un rgime qui est tout de mme un peu fragile. Un peu fragile. Et les dernires lections ont prouv en particulier que le prsident n'avait pas toute l'autorit que l'on pouvait escompter. Ce rgime un peu fragile a peur. A peur de quoi ? A peur d'tre contest. Qu'est ce qu'il veut ? Il veut maintenir le rgime des mollahs. Pour maintenir le rgime des mollahs, il faut qu'il ne soit pas contest ou menac par la communaut internationale. Et la communaut internationale, c'est qui ? C'est les Etats-Unis. Alors quelle est la part, dans la raction de l'Iran, quelle est la part de dsir d'avoir la matrise du nuclaire militaire et le dsir d'avoir la reconnaissance de la communaut internationale et notamment des Etats-Unis de faon  viter de mauvaises surprises susceptibles  un moment ou  un autre de dstabiliser le rgime des mollahs ? C'est une question difficile, parce que les chiites sont des gens trs particuliers. Oui, il [Jrme Bonnafont, spokesman of the Elyse] me dit qu'il faut revenir  l'environnement. Les chiites sont des gens trs particuliers. Les chiites, depuis l'origine, sont des gens qui ont une culture de minoritaires. Ce sont des minoritaires, ils ont une culture de minoritaires. Ils n'ont pas la raction des Sunnites ou des Europens. [] Q: Mais est-ce qu'il y a un dilemme fondamental dans ce monde o on est,  un moment donn, o il faut rduire les missions de carbone, donc l'lectronuclaire est trs important surtout dans les puissances comme l'Inde et la Chine, mais en mme temps on vit dans un monde o le terrorisme et la prolifration sont une inquitude majeure. Et tous les experts disent A: [] Aucun expert ne dit qu'il y a un rapport entre l'lectronuclaire et la bombe nuclaire []. Ce sont deux choses, deux technologies compltement diffrentes. Tout notre problme avec l'Iran que l'on voquait tout a l'heure, c'est parce que l'Iran veut, par l'enrichissement de l'uranium, faire une bombe nuclaire. Mais avec l'lectronuclaire, vous n'avez aucun moyen de passer  la bombe. Il n'y a aucun risque. L'AIEA qui surveille a. Il y a un contrle. Il n'y a aucun risque. Q: Il n'y a aucun risque ? A: Aucun, strictement aucun. Vous ne pouvez pas prendre une centrale nuclaire lectrique pour faire une bombe. a, a ne marche pas. Q: Donc la technologie de l'enrichissement de l'uranium, parce que c'est une question de  A: C'est l'enrichissement de l'uranium, dans des conditions d'ailleurs trs particulires et contrles par l'AIEA. L'AIEA inspecte en permanence pour s'apercevoir qu'en douce on ne fait pas de l'enrichissement. Mais l'enrichissement ne sert  rien pour l'lectronuclaire. Non, il n'y a pas de rapport entre les deux.

title: Text (French): Chiracs Second Interview on Iran
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France with The New York Times, the International Herald Tribune and Le Nouvel Observateur on January 30, 2007. The interview was conducted in French and recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.A: Je voulais donc vous dire un peu comment je voyais rellement le problme de l'Iran. L'Iran a engag une action, une procdure que l'AIEA considre comme de nature  conduire vers une technologie, la matrise d'une technologie militaire, une technologie atomique militaire. Bon, ceci vous le savez est contraire aux engagements de l'Iran qui est signataire du TNP. Le TNP c'est le trait de non-prolifration qui a t sign par l'Iran. Il y a donc de la part de l'Iran une mise en cause des engagements qu'il a pris, d'o les travaux qui ont t faits par l'AIEA qui ont constat, considr que l'enrichissement de l'uranium tait de nature  conduire vers une technologie militaire, lectro-militaire. Et que par consquent, il y avait l quelque chose qui n'tait pas normal ni acceptable. A partir de l, les grands pays se sont consults, notamment les six grands pays, c'est--dire les trois pays europens - la France, l'Allemagne et l'Angleterre - et d'autre part les Etats-Unis, et puis la Russie et la Chine. L'objectif tant d'exposer  l'Iran qu'il se mettait dans une situation qui n'tait pas conforme  la loi internationale et que par consquent il devait interrompre l'enrichissement nuclaire et tout ce qui concernait une technologie militaire, sur le plan nuclaire. [] L'Iran qui est tout de mme une grande nation et une nation importante qui compte []. Nous avons expliqu  l'Iran qu'il ne pouvait pas se mettre dans cette situation, et que par consquent il nous fallait discuter, ngocier pour obtenir l'interruption de l'enrichissement de l'uranium, l'enrichissement de l'uranium tant le symbole, en quelque sorte, le cur d'une technologie militaire nuclaire. Nous avons pens en ralit que l'on pourrait discuter. Je rappelle que la France d'ailleurs a fait une proposition qui tait une proposition ouverte  l'Iran en lui disant - ne mettant pas en cause l'autorit de l'Iran - mais en disant " voil, nous allons, vous allez prendre la dcision vous-mme comme vous l'entendez d'interrompre provisoirement l'enrichissement de l'uranium, et les six pays vont en change prendre la dcision d'interrompre les procdures, les procdures de sanctions au sein du Conseil de Scurit de l'ONU ". C'tait tout de mme, je crois, honntement, une position qui tait convenable, dans le sens qu'on disait  l'Iran, " le jour o vous voulez reprendre, vous reprenez, et nous nous reprendrons les procdures de sanction ". Chacun faisait un pas dans la direction de l'autre, et nous avions pens que c'tait l une procdure qui pouvait tre accepte compte tenu des exigences iraniennes. En fait, les Iraniens n'ont pas accept cette procdure. Ils n'ont pas accept d'interrompre leur travail d'enrichissement de l'uranium, et par voie de consquence les Six ont poursuivi leur action, leur action au Conseil de Scurit conduisant  des sanctions qui dans un premier temps sont des sanctions qui touchent, en ralit, ce qui concerne les approvisionnements, ou les exportations en matire de nuclaire militaire de l'Iran, importations ou exportations, et les sanctions ont donc t prises par la rsolution 1737 du Conseil de Scurit. A partir de l, nous nous trouvons dans une situation qui est quand mme confuse. Alors bien entendu on peut procder en allant de plus en plus loin, de plus en plus haut dans les ractions de chaque ct. Ce n'est certainement pas notre pense et notre intention. Ce que nous souhaitions c'est d'arriver  un rsultat, celui que j'ai voqu tout  l'heure, qui soit conforme aux engagements du TNP et conforme aux contrles de l'AIEA. Dans l'tat actuel des choses, nous n'avons pas de rponse positive de la part de l'Iran, alors j'ai dit - c'tait un peu une manire schmatique de parler - j'ai dit " mais au fond quand on pense  l'Iran,  quoi peut lui servir une bombe "? Si vritablement l'objectif de l'Iran c'est de se doter d'une puissance nuclaire - c'est--dire d'une bombe nuclaire - il est vident que cette bombe,  partir du moment o elle serait lance, serait  l'vidence mme immdiatement dtruite. On a les moyens, beaucoup de pays ont les moyens de dtruire une bombe, enfin d'observer le lancement d'une bombe et de la fuse qui la porte et de dtruire cette bombe. Donc on ne voit pas trs bien quel est l'avantage que pourrait trouver l'Iran dans une action consistant  lancer une bombe. Elle serait dtruite videmment  peine lance. C'est tout de mme un lment important. Q: Elle serait dtruite, la bombe ? A: La bombe serait dtruite, oui. Q: Et quelles seraient les rpercussions sur l'Iran ? A: Alors les rpercussions sur l'Iran devraient tre examines, naturellement. J'ai eu un mot rapide, et que je retire naturellement, quand j'ai dit " on va raser Thran ". C'tait videmment une boutade dans mon esprit. Je n'imagine pas que l'on puisse raser Thran. Mais je rpte, l'Iran est une grande nation historiquement, culturellement, qui compte dans cette rgion du Moyen Orient, et il est important d'avoir un dialogue avec ce pays pour essayer d'avoir une stabilit dans le Moyen Orient. Q: Je voulais vous remercier A: C'est moi qui vous remercie d'tre revenus, parce que ce sont des sujets extrmes dlicats et dangereux et qui comportent des consquences - et qui peuvent tre dramatiques. Moi, j'ai honntement cru que les questions qui taient en dehors de l'environnement taient des questions " off ". []. Q: [] C'est moi qui ai pos la question. Mais c'tait aprs votre analyse en ce qui concerne l nergie nuclaire, donc j'ai pos une question honntement et gentiment. Je m'excuse si cela vous a donn l'impression A: Chre Madame, non, je n'ai pas cette impression, c'est moi qui ai eu tort. Je ne veux pas le contester. J'aurais mieux fait de faire attention  ce que je disais et de comprendre que peut tre c'tait " on ". Nous avions parl des problmes dans l'environnement, des problmes nuclaires [.] C'tait moi qui aurais d faire attention et qui aurait d dire, " nous sommes 'off' ", et je ne l'ai pas dit, et alors du coup je me suis un peu laiss aller. Q: Mais vous dites "il faut trouver un moyen de rgler ce problme" mais quels sont les moyens de rgler ces problmes? A: Je vais vous dire rapidement ce qui dans l'tat actuel des choses [], ce qui est souhaitable pour l'Iran c'est la division de la communaut internationale. C'est la raison pour laquelle nous pensons qu'il est indispensable de maintenir la cohsion de la communaut internationale. [] Alors il y a les Franais, les Allemands, les Anglais qui ont un point de vue pratiquement identique. Il y a les Amricains et puis il y a les Russes qui pour des raisons qui sont les leurs, et les Chinois, ne sont pas toujours exactement sur la mme ligne. Alors si nous nous divisons, c'est une grande victoire en quelque sorte pour ceux qui en Iran sont les plus durs. Si, au contraire nous restons unis, notamment au sein des rsolutions du Conseil de Scurit, au moins sur la 1737,  ce moment-l nous restons solides. Et donc je crois que ce qui est important c'est de faire en sorte qu'il n'y ait pas de divisions de la communaut internationale et que les six pays en questions restent unis face  ce problme qui est un problme dangereux. title: The Circuit
description: Scenes from the Honda Ski Tour, a four-city event with bands, fireworks, countless parties and top-notch skiing, which aims to bring glamour back to the sport.

title: Carlyles Great Experiment
description: In the past five years or so, famed private equity firm Carlyle Group has transformed itself from a company that focused primarily on buying and selling defense companies that did business with governments, to one that now deals in a broad swath of alternative assets. The firm also cut ties with some of its high-profile political advisers, including George H.W. Bush and John Major. BusinessWeek takes a look at how  and why  the firms founders undertook this radical overhaul.

title: Senate Democrats Warn F.C.C. of Tough New Oversight
description: Signaling tougher oversight, Democrats who recently gained control of the Senate urged the head of the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday to take a more aggressive approach to the industries he oversees. In his first appearance before the Senate Commerce Committee under Democratic leadership, Kevin J. Martin, the agencys chairman, and the other commissioners faced sharp criticism from some senior senators on the handling of the recent acquisition of BellSouth by AT&T.

title: Santander Takes Stake in Italys Capitalia
description: Grupo Santander, Spains largest bank, has moved deeper into the Italian market with the purchase of a 2 percent stake in Capitalia, the Italian bank at the center of merger speculation, The Financial Times reported. Santander also reported a 13 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits.

title: S.E.C. Approves New Method for Companies to Value Stock Options
description: Can an auction of a new type of security prove that stock options are not worth as much as financial models say they are  and therefore allow companies to report higher profits while handing out options to employees and executives? The Securities and Exchange Commission has given a tentative approval to one auction method, while warning that auditors should study the results of the auction before actually using the results in their financial statements.

title: Court Rejects Tax Shelter Once Sold by KPMG
description: A federal judge in Texas has ruled that a widely used aggressive tax shelter was based on fake bank loans and is therefore not legitimate, giving an unexpected boost to federal prosecutors overseeing a widening criminal investigation into tax shelters. The shelter, known as Blips, plays a central role in the criminal inquiry of Deutsche Bank over questionable tax shelters and in the pending criminal trial in federal court in Manhattan of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG and two outsiders.

title: Hedge Fund Officer Is Accused of Fraud
description: The former head of an Idaho hedge fund, Wood River Capital Management, has been indicted on charges that he engaged in securities fraud that cost investors $88 million, prosecutors said Thursday. The United States attorneys office in Manhattan said John H. Whittier, Wood Rivers majority shareholder and principal executive, was charged with securities fraud and failure to disclose a beneficial interest in a publicly traded security. Mr. Whittier is expected to be arraigned next week.

title: Coca-Cola Swallows Fuze Beverage
description: Coca-Cola said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Fuze Beverage to add more juice, tea and energy drinks in an effort to catch up with PepsiCo. Coca-Cola gains a half-dozen new products, including Fuze Tea, NOS energy drinks and Fuze Slenderize, which has chromium and amino acids that Fuze says help promote weight loss.

title: Big Dividend for Lone Star
description: Lone Star Funds, the United States buyout firm whose sale of Korea Exchange Bank was blocked by a corruption investigation, will collect $445 million in dividends from the bank. Korea Exchange will pay 1,000 won ($1.10) a share, it said in a regulatory filing to the stock exchange Thursday. Lone Star, based in Dallas, controls 64.6 percent of the bank. Lone Star halted a $6.8 billion sale of the bank because of an investigation by prosecutors into its original acquisition of Korea Exchange four years ago for $1.49 billion. The dividend is the first in 10 years by the bank, South Koreas fifth-largest.

title: 2 Megadeals Warm Europes Energy Sector
description: Consolidation in Europes energy sector ramped up yesterday, as two $31 billion deals loomed on the horizon. Dutch utilities Essent and Nuon unveiled an agreement to create a 24 billion euro ($31 billion) energy giant that will rank among Europes top 10. The new company, to be called EssentNuon, will have 12 billion euros in sales and have a 20,000-strong work force in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany and supply 5 million customers. Both firms are owned by local governments, and ownership of the new entity will be split 55 percent to 45 percent in Essents favor.

title: Onex Unloads Aerospace Firm
description: Six years after buying aerospace components maker CMC Electronics, Canadian private equity firm Onex has sold it to aerospace company Esterline Technologies for C$391.5 million ($335 million). Montreal-based CMC makes global positioning systems and other aviation parts, including vision systems, flight bags and flight management tools.

title: Pfizer Buys Experimental Drug Start-Up
description: Pfizer is acquiring a small Pennsylvania start-up developing experimental treatments for Type 2 diabetes. Pfizer said yesterday that it would buy BioRexis Pharmaceutical, which has 50 employees and two key drug compounds in early testing, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Hospira Seals Deal for Mayne
description: Hospira, a hospital products maker, said Thursday that it had completed the $2.1 billion acquisition of Mayne Pharma Limited, an Australian maker of generic cancer medicines and other specialized injectable drugs. Hospira, based in Lake Forest, Ill., is already a U.S. leader in injectable drugs and intravenous solutions used primarily in hospitals. With its purchase of Mayne Pharma, Hospira adds a significant global presence, doubling international sales to account for nearly 30 percent of the companys total sales.

title: Balfour Betty Hammers Out Deal for Centex Unit
description: British construction group Balfour Beatty said yesterday it was buying U.S. rival Centex Construction for $362 million in cash. The company, part of Americas fourth-biggest housebuilder, Centex, specializes in military housing with an order book worth $5.6 billion.

title: Another Prosecutor Moves to the Greener Pastures of Private Law
description: Former Enron prosecutor Kathy Ruemmler has joined the law firm of Latham & Watkins in Washington, D.C., confirming speculation that she would follow some of her former colleagues into private practice  and a higher income bracket. Ms. Ruemmler was one of three Assistant U.S. Attorneys who took leading roles in the 2004 Enron Nigerian barge case and the criminal trial of former Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay last year. The move again puts her in the same office as her ex-boss, former Enron Task Force chief Sean Berkowitz, who joined Latham in November.

title: Tata Would Have Gone Higher on Corus Bid
description: In what cant possibly be music to Corus shareholders ears, Indian steel magnate Ratan Tata has said he would have been prepared to pay even more to clinch control of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker. In an interview with The Times Of India today, the chairman of Tata group said: Let me put it this way. At 608 pence ($11.97), we hadnt reached the limit we had set ourselves.

title: Blackstone Said to Raise Real-Estate Megafund
description: Whether or not Blackstone Group emerges victorious in its takeover battle for real estate investment trust Equity Office Properties, the buyout shop appears poised to continue its real-estate deal making on a grand scale. Reuters reported that Blackstone is currently raising $10 billion for one of the biggest ever global property funds.

title: Buyout Team Considers Bid for British Supermarket Giant
description: In what would be Europes largest leveraged buyout, Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and CVC Capital Partners say they are considering an offer for the British supermarket company J. Sainsbury. Sainsbury shares soared as much as 18 percent Friday, giving the London-based company a market value of 8.8 billion pounds ($17.3 billion).

title: One Hedge Fund Takes Some the Risk Out of Investing
description: In a highly unusual move, RAB Capital, one of Londons leading hedge funds, is demanding money back guarantees before it invests in mining companies. The Telegraph reported that RAB, which is one of natural resources sectors leading investors, recently inked a deal with Energy Capital to invest 500,000 pounds in the shell company.

title: Equity Office Board Supports Blackstone Offer
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord at the center of a takeover battle, on Friday reaffirmed its support for a $38.3 billion, all-cash bid from private equity firm Blackstone Group, saying it was less risky for shareholders than a $41 billion cash-and-stock offer from Vornado Realty Trust. Equity Office also said a vote on Blackstones offer will probably take place Feb. 7, two days later than previously planned, to give shareholders time to review new information about the bid.

title: Who Put the 40 in Oscar?
description: Alreet, you are so over Lazy parodies in YouTube, but the Bagger is always in search of that elusive video hook to service the mouth-breathing illiterates of his demo, so he cant be especially picky.

title: Senate Report Says S.E.C. Botched Hedge Fund Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission mishandled its inquiry into suspect trades by a prominent hedge fund, then may have tried to cover up those mistakes after its chief investigator on the case complained, according to an interim Senate report released Thursday. The report, released by the former chairmen of the Senate Judiciary and Finance Committees, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, also asked the S.E.C. or the Justice Department to consider investigating whether false testimony was given to S.E.C. officials who examined the hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management.

title: Theater Chain Previews $400 Million Stock Sale
description: Cinemark Holdings, which owns 392 cinemas in the U.S. and Latin America, filed to sell shares in an initial public offering valued at about $400 million and use the proceeds to pay back debt. The company, which is controlled by Madison Dearborn Partners, was created through the October merger of Cinemark USA and Century Theatres. Cinemark plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol CNK.

title: RPath Gets $9.1 Million From Investors
description: rPath raised $9.1 million in a second round of venture capital from existing investors General Catalyst Partners and North Bridge Venture Partner, and new investor Wakefield Group to increase sales and marketing of products to help developers create and maintain software on dedicated appliances.

title: Assume the Worst
description: The early word on Breach, the they-done-it movie about the C.I.A., is excellent and NPR gets some words in edgewise in an interview with Billy Ray, the director who brought you Shattered Glass, one of the few movies about journalists that doesnt include reporters having sex with sources.

title: Oscar Dressing Neither Right Nor Left
description: Last year, the Final Five transformed the awards season into a civics lesson, but Vanity Fair suggests that this year, Oscar has little or nothing going on between his tiny, golden ears.

title: A Marriage of Inconvenience
description: The suspense for duly-elected-leader-of-the-free-world-turned-documentarian Al Gore wont end on Oscar night. The talent behind An Inconvenient Truth is being nominated for another little award, something to do with peace.

title: Storm Damage in Central Florida
In Clint We Trust
description: The Motion Picture Association of America, upon hearing of a critical hardware shortage in Clint Eastwoods home workshop, is stepping into the breach with a tsotschke named for the man who headed the organization for 38 years.

title: Thinking Aloud, Typing Quietly
description: The Queen was a lock for the final five from the start  then again, so was Dreamgirls  but its backers spent like crazy right up to the nominations just to make sure. Do they wish some of that powder was still dry and available now that the race for The Win is wide open?

title: The Haters Punch In
description: Idle hands, especially ones that do a lot of typing, tend to engage in the devils handiwork when things slow down.

title: High Falls, Cont.
description: If you want to see the short that features some of the Most Talented Actors of This Generation, you might have to wait a bit. But Bagger irregular Mike came up with the trailer, in hi-def, no less.

title: On Common Ground
description: The Bagger went to one of those highfalutin Manhattan dinners last night where people politely do the intellectual dozens on each other while ironing out things like the Iraq War and the loss of civil liberties. He had nothing to add to the conversation, but did grab a moments sidebar with Gayle King, editor at large for O magazine and host of the Oprah and Friends show on XM satellite radio.

title: Locking Up the Knitting Vote
description: Ryan Gosling, a best actor nominee for Half Nelson, on what he does when he is not making small movies that garner major acclaim: I knit. Yeah. I really do. I knit scarves. I bake.

title: If It Quacks Like a Doc
description: The doctor took a long hard look into the Baggers slightly crossed eyes and at his neck, which seems stuck at an awkward, craning, angle. Then he noticed the raw patches of skin near the Baggers knees.

title: Ex-Morgan Consultant Pleads Guilty to Data Theft
description: A former information technology consultant for Morgan Stanley pleaded guilty in federal court late Wednesday to stealing data on the investment banks hedge fund clients, The New York Post reported. Ira Chilowitz, 44, faces a maximum of 26 years in prison and an $850,000 fine on charges of conspiracy, theft of trade secrets and other crimes. In court, Mr. Chilowitz admitted that he and an unnamed co-conspirator had set up their own business advising hedge funds on how to negotiate the fees investment banks charge.

title: Viacom Asks YouTube to Remove Clips
description: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded yesterday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.

title: 2007 Super Bowl Ad With Kevin Federline
State of the Union Lullaby Revisited: Tucker Carlson Apologizes
description: We have to circle back to Sleepy John McCain affair this morning  an old chestnut dating from last week  in which Sen. John McCain of Arizona appeared to be in the arms of Morpheus during the presidents State of the Union address.

title: Red-Faced in Boston
Health Care Versus the Budget
description: Social Security gets all the attention, but the real budget busters among the entitlement programs are Medicare and Medicaid, which cover more than 1 in 4 Americans.

title: DE-fense! DE-fense!
description: Allen St. John, the By the Numbers sports columnist for The Wall Street Journal, crunches the data and concludes that Sundays Super Bowl is a mismatch. The Indianapolis Colts, whom bettors have deemed to be seven-point favorites, are greatly outclassed by the Chicago Bears according to several historically important metrics. [T]he Bears not only have a chance this Sunday  the numbers suggest they should be the favorites, St. John writes. And if the Colts cap their playoff run with a win, theyre not just meeting expectations, but pulling off one of Super Bowl historys biggest upsets. [$]

title: Nobel Nominations  Left and Right
description: Just as the deadline for recommendations was closing yesterday, the former vice president, Al Gore, was nominated for the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize, The Associated Press reports. Two Norwegian parliament members, Boerge Brende and Heidi Soerensen, put forth the nomination  as well as one for a Canadian Inuit activist, Sheila Watt-Cloutier.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Because I Said So'
description: Chief movie critic A. O. Scott reviews "Because I Said So," starring Diane Keaton and Mandy Moore.

title: Hearst Tried to Sell Chronicle
description: Hearst has recorded $330 million in losses in its investment in the San Francisco Chronicle and attempted to sell the newspaper to MediaNews Group, according to court documents made public Thursday in a media antitrust case. Terms of the 2005 proposal were not revealed. But MediaNews did not offer enough, so no deal was made, James Asher, Hearsts chief legal officer, said in the documents. The New York-based publisher acquired the Chronicle for $660 million in 2000.

title: Why We Travel
description: "My wife and I, we both believe that we shouldnt waste our time during vacation by visiting places where we wont learn anything or where we cannot give something back to the community."

title: 2008: Democrats in Town
description: Most of the Democratic field is in Washington today for the Democratic National Committees winter meeting. See the On Deck section below for the list of whos speaking today and Saturday. Youll notice that all of the speakers have already have declared their candidacy or formed an exploratory committee except Gen. Wesley Clark. Hmmm.

title: Hedge Fund Shoppers or Status Seekers?
description: It is not so surprising that some of the most-expensive hedge funds  as measured by the fees they charge  can deliver below-average returns. After all, anyone can have a bad year (or two). The more remarkable part about Financial News recent analysis of hedge funds with high fees is the suggestion that investors, who are mainly institutions and wealthy individuals, sometimes intentionally avoid funds that charge lower fees, preferring the cachet of a top-dollar fund even if its recent performance is lackluster.

title: Intel Report Out on Iraq
description: Requested by Congress last summer, the long-awaited National Intelligence Estimate on conditions in Iraq has just been released this morning and its assessment is rather grim.

title: Storms Rip Through Central Florida
description: The city of Lady Lake in Lake County was one of the hardest hit by the severe thunderstorms and possible tornadoes.

title: War at Home: Restive Resolve
description: With key Democratic senators bolting from a compromise resolution offered by Republican Senator John Warner, and some of his G.O.P. allies stiffly resisting criticism of President Bushs war plans, well have to wait until next week to see how things play out.

title: New York Times Family Pulls Funds From Morgan Stanley
description: The family that controls the The New York Times Company is withdrawing most of its assets from the custody of Morgan Stanley. The decision by the Sulzberger family, which a spokeswoman for the Times Company confirmed, comes as the Times Company is fighting a proposal by a Morgan Stanley fund manager that would allow shareholders to vote on whether to end the companys two-tier stock structure and make it more vulnerable to a takeover.

title: A Very Expensive Piece of Dirt
description: As fate would have it, the office of the real estate agent listing the empty lot my wife had fallen in love with was right around the corner.

title: Can a Condo Board Ask About a Buyers Finances?
description: Q  Does a condo board have the right to request sensitive financial information from a buyer?

title: So Who Must Repair the Shower Diverter?
description: Q The shower diverter valve in the bathroom of my Brooklyn co-op needs replacing, and I was told by the board and the managing agent that I am responsible for having this done even though the valve is inside the wall. Is there anything in city or state law about who pays for this kind of work?

title: The Man Behind Pirate Capital
description: Magnum Global Investments is a former client of Pirate Capital, a Connecticut-based hedge fund. According to a lawsuit filed by Magnum, Pirate reneged on its promise to pay for steering it $28 million in investments. David Friedland, Magnums president, tells Bloomberg News that his firms relationship with Thomas Hudson, the chief Pirate, got pretty ugly. If, he said, wed known this was the kind of character he had, we wouldnt have invested.

title: Gratuitous Groundhog Holiday Blog Post
description: Well, its Groundhog Day, and according to The Staten Island Advance, Chuck, New York Citys resident rodent prognosticator, is predicting an early spring.

title: Direct-to-YouTube Ads
description: From reader Miguel G:

title: A Little Campaign Music, Please
description: So, you want to be president of the United States of America? Well heres a few things that should be on your early to-do list: Hone your message, assemble a good staff and, of course, pick out some memorable campaign music.

title: Geffen Did It. Again.
description: A few days ago, David Geffen was fingered for the failure of Dreamgirls to get a best picture nomination. Now hes taking heat for helping deny The Departed stars their due.

title: The Science of Merger Predictions
description: TheStreet has added a feature to Stockpickr, its automatic stock-recommendation site: system trades of the day. TheStreet tested several trading systems that is says have resulted in significant and consistent gains during the past five to 10 years. But we found the most interesting to be the Takeover Targets System. It rebalances every month, generating a new set of stocks that are most likely to be acquisition candidates.

title: Rudys Wealthy Friends
description: Among the donors to Rudy Giulianis exploratory committee are a couple of high-profile moguls: T. Boone Pickens and Paul Tudor Jones. The two were among the donors who cropped up in Giulianis most recent campaign filings.

title: Jacques Chirac's Views on Iran
description: IHT columnist John Vinocur analyzes the aftermath of the French president's statements about Iran.

title: Should Bristol and Sanofi Link Up?
description: Despite the enthusiasm of analysts and investors, the rumored acquisition of Bristol-Myers Squibb by Paris-based Sanofi-Aventis is probably a bad idea in the long term, writes Forbes Matthew Herper. Such a deal would be a short-term fix that does nothing to address the drug industrys big problems: a declining pipeline and fewer medicines reaching patients.

title: Out and About: Maremma
description: Since the restaurant Maremma opened in the West Village in the summer of 2005, its owner and chef, Cesare Casella, has tweaked it and reportedly focused more intensely on it, something that selling his interest in Beppe helped him to do. And I spotted Mr. Casella at Maremma on the recent night when I dined there. He was standing just inside the entrance, and it was almost impossible not to notice him. As he always does, he had a clump of rosemary peeking out of a breast pocket.

title: Trial to Start Next Week For Soldier Who Refused to Fight in Illegal Iraq War
description: Court-martial proceedings are scheduled to begin on Monday in the case of First Lt. Ehren K. Watada, an Army officer who refused to ship out with his brigade when it set off for Iraq last June  citing his opposition to the continued war in Iraq, the deception used to wage this war, and the lawlessness that has pervaded every aspect of our civilian leadership.

title: The Democratic Dean
description: This was definitely Howard Dean day as the Democratic National Committee convened in Washington to hear the Democratic presidential candidates.

title: A Political Know-It-All Who Really Knew It
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Feb. 2 column, Missing Molly Ivins.

title: A Soviet Example We Dont Want to Follow
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Feb. 2 column, The Oil-Addicted Ayatollahs.

title: Where Not To Go for Spring Break
description: Winter is turning to spring on Titan, giving scientists their first look at a gigantic cloud that has taken shape above the north pole of Saturns moon. Its about 1,500 miles in diameter and presumably formed from methane evaporating from the lakes spotted last year by the Cassini spacecraft.

title: Was the Globes Best Picture (Drama) Winner Officially Eligible for the Award?
description: A thought occurred to someone the Bagger knows that Babel, of which less than an hour of its nearly two-and-a-half hours is in English, might have been in the foreign film, not the best picture, category of the Globes.

Today, after speaking with other presidential nomination-seekers in the morning to the Democratic National Committees winter meeting in Washington, Mr. Obama addressed a crowd of more than 3,000, mostly sign-waving, students.
