description: The book is called Diplomat Heroes of the Holocaust, and perhaps the most telling thing about it is that it is very slim.

title: Bob Carroll Jr., 88, a Writer of the Zany I Love Lucy, Dies
description: Bob Carroll Jr., a founding writer of I Love Lucy who helped introduce millions of viewers to the joys of frenzied grape stomping, warp-speed chocolate-stuffing and the increasingly tasty 46-proof patent medicine Vitameatavegamin, died on Jan. 27 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: Whitney Balliett, New Yorker Jazz Critic, Dies at 80
description: Whitney Balliett, a jazz critic who in more than 40 years at The New Yorker magazine encouraged readers to hear jazz through his vividly metaphorical writing, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Push to Resolve Fading Killings of Rights Era
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 2  For every infamous killing that tore at the South in the 1950s and 60s, there were many more that were barely noted, much less investigated.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: At the Crossroads of Money and Art

title: Twisters Hit Central Florida, Killing at Least 19
description: PAISLEY, Fla., Feb. 2  At least 19 people died when thunderstorms and tornadoes devastated parts of Central Florida before dawn Friday, flattening hundreds of homes and leaving thousands of residents who had little or no warning of the storms in grim shock.

title: To Explore Race, Sometimes You Focus on the Explorer
description: For Whites Only is the title Joe Ovelman gave his solo show at the Oliver Kamm/5BE Gallery. So you know right away that hes playing with race, which means that hes playing with fire. The show is in two sections, and the first, a project titled Rosa Parks 381, is straightforward enough.

title: Altered Deal Hardly a Done Deal
description: It would seem that a player would be delighted if the commissioners office struck from a contract he signed a clause that benefited the club and not the player. Thats what happened with the contract that Barry Bonds signed Monday with the San Francisco Giants.

title: Cellphone Envy Lays Motorola Low
description: When the sleek Motorola Razr V3 cellphone first hit the stores just over two years ago, it carried the price tag of a must-have status symbol: $500.

title: City Sues Albany Official Over Police Contract Impasse
description: The Bloomberg administration filed a lawsuit against a top state labor relations official yesterday in an effort to break a stalemate over a contract dispute involving the city police union.

title: Republicans Plan to Block Iraq Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said Friday that his party would unite to block Senate debate next week on a bipartisan resolution opposing President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq unless the Democrats allowed votes on at least two Republican alternatives.

title: Shawangunk: Car Crash Kills Two
description: Two Ulster County teenagers were killed yesterday morning when the car they were riding in smashed into an oncoming sport utility vehicle, the state police said. The accident took place about 7 a.m., when the driver of the car, Karon Lawrence, 17, lost control along Route 300 near the border of Orange and Ulster Counties and swerved into the other lane, hitting the sport utility vehicle, the police said. Mr. Lawrence, a student at Wallkill High School, was in the car with three other classmates, all of whom were on their way to school. Andrew Davis, 17, who was seated in the front, and John Lopez, 15, a passenger in the back, were killed, the state police said. Mr. Lawrence and his other passenger, Jenna Neri, 16, were taken to local hospitals with serious injuries. The driver of the sport utility vehicle, Glen Bo, 41, of Wallkill, was airlifted to Westchester Medical Center with knee and back injuries.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,079 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Factional Violence Continues in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 3  Forces loyal to Hamas appeared to consolidate their hold on northern Gaza and much of Gaza City today, with at least 12 more people wounded in continuing clashes between Palestinian factions.

title: Official Quits After Remark on Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The senior Pentagon official who set off a controversy last month with remarks suggesting that corporations should consider severing business ties with law firms that represent Guantnamo Bay detainees has resigned.

title: Mothers Harness Grief to Try to Save Lives
description: The women live in a half light between what they wish and what is true. Between daydreaming that their children are, say, quietly watching television in the next room, and knowing that once they open their eyes they will be home alone.

title: Detective Is Accused of Drunken Driving
description: A New York City detective with more than 20 years experience was arrested yesterday on charges of driving while intoxicated after he slammed into a car late Thursday night in Rego Park, Queens, the police said.

title: Cost of House-Passed Terror Bill Touches Off a Partisan Clash
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The antiterrorism bill that the House passed last month as part of the new Democratic majoritys first-100-hours push would cost the federal government $21 billion over the next five years, according to a new Congressional estimate.

title: Trenton: McGreevey Files for Divorce:
description: James E. McGreevey, the former governor of New Jersey who resigned after revealing that he was gay, yesterday filed for divorce from his wife, Dina Matos McGreevey. Mr. McGreevey left office in 2004 after announcing that he had had an affair with a man on his staff. The divorce complaint, filed in State Superior Court, included standard information like the date of the couples marriage, Oct. 4, 2000, their respective residences in New Jersey  he in Plainfield and she in Springfield  the fact that they have a 5-year-old daughter, Jacqueline, and that they have lived apart since November 2004, when Mr. McGreevey left office and moved out of the governors mansion.

title: Elaines Boyfriend Returns to TV as a Sitcom Husband
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2  Patrick Warburton, whos been doing this long enough to know how the game is played, was saying all the appropriate things about his new ensemble sitcom, Rules of Engagement (which has its premiere on Monday night on CBS): how the writers are smart and talented, the actors are phenomenal and easy to work with, how the show has the potential to be really good, if the audience gives it a chance.

title: A Night, Live and Filmed, of Retrospection, Reunion and Birthday Cake
description: Please, would you take your seats, said the exasperated Danspace Project official for the third time as the intermission at Thursdays opening night performance of Janis Brenner & Guests: A 25th Anniversary Celebration, threatened to extend indefinitely.

title: Even the Sexually Free Find That There Are Costs
description: In general, the battle over sex, as depicted in the theater, pits the sexually liberated rebels against the repressed fuddy-duddies. Its an unfair fight, of course, but it has the benefit of making stodgy ticket buyers feel a little less uptight by encouraging them to root against those ridiculous squares.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about criticism by Venezuelas president, Hugo Chvez, of President Bushs handling of the Iraq war described one comment incorrectly. Mr. Chvez did indeed call Mr. Bush the devil, as he had done in a speech at the United Nations in September.

title: Salvation Army Unit Seeks to Gain More of a Huge Gift
description: The Salvation Army has gone to court in Seattle to challenge a trust dividing more than $260 million among eight charities, including Greenpeace.

title: 2 Killed as U.S. Helicopter Is Shot Down Near Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 2  An American Apache attack helicopter was shot down on Friday just north of Baghdad and its two-member crew was killed, an American military official said.

title: Good News on Economy, Except for a Dell Executive
description: LED by growing exports, the economy expanded faster than expected in the last quarter of 2006 and remains strong. That is good news for most people, including most workers, who are seeing robust wage growth, but was not good enough for the chief of one consumer electronics company, who was shoved aside for poor performance.

title: Where the Foodies Are on the Web
description: Among the many New York restaurant blogs, here are a few that are considered to be top-shelf by other food bloggers.

title: Knicks Say Curry Is Playing Like an All-Star
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 2  Eddy Curry is not an All-Star in the view of N.B.A. fans or coaches, with the notable exception of the fans who reside in the Knicks locker room and the coach who sits on the Knicks bench.

title: The Photograph of a Dying Soldier (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Calm. Look Out for a Storm.
description: TRADING in the stock market has been quiet, maybe too quiet. The ups and downs are among the mildest experienced in more than a century, and that is provoking anxiety in some investment advisers.

title: Iran Installs Equipment for Large-Scale Uranium Enrichment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  International nuclear investigators have confirmed that Iran is beginning to install equipment in the large underground chamber in Natanz, the center where Iranian officials have said they will move to industrial-scale enrichment of uranium, according to foreign diplomats and American officials.

title: A Conductors Concerto, Influenced and Inspired
description: Composers who are also active conductors gain direct experience with a wide array of music, especially if the conductor is as adventurous as Esa-Pekka Salonen, the dynamic music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Mr. Salonen has learned from the inside the techniques and tricks of composers he admires, from giants like Ligeti to colleagues like John Adams.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Business Day yesterday about management changes at Gap Inc. misstated the circumstances surrounding the departure of Cynthia Harriss, the president of Gap brand. She resigned; she was not "ousted" or "removed." (Go to Article)

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about a death sentence handed up by a federal jury for a man who killed two police detectives on Staten Island misstated the marital status of one victim, Rodney J. Andrews, and referred incorrectly in some copies to the federal trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who was convicted of terrorism charges related to Sept. 11 but did not receive the death penalty. Detective Andrews and his wife were separated, not divorced, and Mr. Moussaouis case was tried by prosecutors in Virginia, not New York.

title: The Groundhog Emerged, and Sounded a Lot Like Al Gore
description: Groundhog Day has been part of the Western calendar since around the fifth century, which means it has survived centuries of Catholicism, the Reformation, the Enlightenment, the Industrial Revolution, and the advent of the agriculture of cloned sheep.

title: Memorial on Tuesday for Judge Bolin
description: A memorial service for Jane Bolin, the first black woman to become a judge in the United States, will be held on Tuesday from 1:30 p.m. to 5 p.m. at the New York Bar Association, 42 West 44th Street in Manhattan. Judge Bolin died on Jan. 8 at the age of 98. The service is open to the public.

title: Afghan Town Is Overrun by Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 2  Taliban militants overran the town of Musa Qala in southern Afghanistan just three months after NATO troops had withdrawn and handed over control to a tribal council, officials said Friday. The insurgents detained police officers and tribal elders, seized weapons and government equipment and bulldozed part of the district offices, according to residents.

title: Court Clears Way for Suit on New Orleans Flooding
description: Residents of several neighborhoods in the New Orleans area that were hardest hit by flooding after Hurricane Katrina can sue the Army Corps of Engineers over their claims that a government-built navigation channel was largely to blame, a federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: The Governors Health Plan
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to freeze Medicaid payments at current levels for hospitals and nursing homes is causing understandable consternation among health care institutions that are already in precarious financial straits. But the governors new budget proposal looks like a responsible way to free up money to help pay for a huge increase in state aid for education and subsidize the property tax cuts he deems necessary to win approval of his education proposals  and accelerate much-needed reform in the way medical care is delivered.

title: When the Real Numbers Are Rosy, but the Others Are Less So
description: SOMETIMES real numbers are anything but.

title: Science Panel Calls Global Warming Unequivocal
description: PARIS, Feb. 2  In a grim and powerful assessment of the future of the planet, the leading international network of climate scientists has concluded for the first time that global warming is unequivocal and that human activity is the main driver, very likely causing most of the rise in temperatures since 1950.

title: A Study of Memory Looks at Fact and Fiction
description: The beautiful and deeply religious Madame de Tourvel is so distraught after cheating on her husband in the 1782 novel Les Liaisons Dangereuses that she blacks out the betrayal altogether, arriving at a convent with no idea of what had brought her there. Soon the horror of the infidelity rushes back, in all its incriminating force.

title: California: $1.1. Billion in Freeze Damage
description: The freeze last month cost farmers more than $1.1 billion, according to a statement released by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger. The statement, part of a request to President Bush for a federal disaster declaration, outlined damage in 31 counties to citrus crops, avocados, strawberries and leafy greens. The five-day freeze sent temperatures into the teens and 20s as far south as the Mexican border. The estimate would put the damage on a par with a long freeze in 1990 that devastated the orange and lemon crops and killed thousands of trees.

title: The Colts Get Up to Speed as the Stakes Get Higher
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  Jack del Rio saw up close what was wrong with the Indianapolis Colts defense. Standing on the Jacksonville sideline on Dec. 10, he watched as poor tackling and ennui undid the Colts, creating the gaping holes that allowed the Jaguars to rush for 375 yards in a 44-17 victory that Colts defensive end Robert Mathis described this week as one of the most embarrassing games of his career.

title: Tough Women in Office (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Enter Police Recruit, Underpaid
description: Underpaid civil servants are hardly a new story. Teachers, nurses and many other municipal workers do challenging, critically important work for much less than they deserve. Still, it is jarring to think that New York Citys newest police hires are being forced to work for the paupers sum of $25,100.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a 29-year-old sex offender who is accused of posing as a boy to enroll in schools misspelled the name of an Arizona city where administrators of the Shelby School say he attended school for 21 days in 2005. It is Payson, not Peyson.

title: Greater Scrutiny on Colleges and Ties to Lenders
description: Colleges and universities from Massachusetts to California began receiving formal requests for information yesterday from the New York attorney generals office as part of an investigation of financial relationships they or individual college officials have with student loan companies.

title: Rare Winners at Temple Have Unlikely Reunion
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  Call them the Temple three, former college teammates having an unlikely reunion at Super Bowl XLI.

title: Harsh Accusations Intensify in L.I. State Senate Contest
description: The already ferocious campaign to fill a State Senate seat on Long Island reached a new pitch yesterday with a mass mailing featuring Osama bin Laden, accusations of improper donations, and a request for federal monitors to guard against voter intimidation at the polls on Tuesday.

title: Sure, They Sound Funny. After All, Theyre British.
description: The secret of The Secret Show, a new animated series whose third episode will be shown on the Nicktoons Network tonight, is that its a British production. The British may not be funnier than we are, but they clearly have a corner on infantile silliness. An American cartoon character called Nanny Poo Poo would be merely vulgar; with a British accent, Nanny Poo Poo is perfect.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Business Day yesterday about management changes at Gap Inc. misstated the circumstances surrounding the departure of Cynthia Harriss, the president of Gap brand. She resigned; she was not ousted or removed.

title: Teenagers Run Straight Into Fences, and Trouble
description: DEER PARK, N.Y., Feb. 2  Bored teenagers here have a new way of entertaining themselves on a weekend evening, local authorities say: a pastime that combines the latest technological skill with good old teenage blockheadedness.

title: Censorships New Clothes
description: Casablanca, Morocco

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about the political humor columnist Molly Ivins included incorrect information from Creator Syndicate about the year she began writing for the syndicate. It was 1992, not 2001. The obituary also incorrectly described River Oaks, where she was reared, in some copies. It is part of Houston; it has not been a suburb since the 1920s.

title: After Crash, Police Hiring in Jersey City Is Questioned
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 2  Jersey City was in need of police officers in December 2005, and the news had filtered down to an officer in Middletown Township, N.J., who was looking for a fresh start.

title: Fire on Second Floor Kills 3, Including Would-Be Rescuer
description: BRENTWOOD, N.Y., Feb. 2  A woman, her 11-month-old son and the homeowner who tried twice to save them were killed early Friday morning in a fire that swept through their two-story home here, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Lawmakers Appeal for Guantnamo Release
description: Almost half of Parliaments lawmakers signed a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi asking for the return of David Hicks, an Australian who has been detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, for more than five years after being picked up in Afghanistan. It was the strongest political support to date for a growing movement in Australia to have him sent home.

title: Envy, Anxiety, Secrecy, Taboos: The Subject Must Be Money
description: IM as guilty as the next person. Ive sat around with my pals wondering how a neighbor, a colleague, or, yes, a good friend, can possibly afford to put that huge addition on their house. Or take those many overseas vacations. Or pay for the private schools and the fancy summer camps and the second home.

title: Nassau County: L.I.R.R. Service Disrupted
description: About 30,000 people were stranded or delayed during the evening rush last night after Long Island Rail Road officials suspended service in some parts of Nassau County to remove downed power lines, the company said. The delays began about 6:30 p.m. after several power lines were spotted lying across train tracks just east of the Valley Stream station. Susan McGowan, an L.I.R.R. spokeswoman, said that before the wires could be cleared away, company officials had to shut off power to the third rails at seven tracks in its Babylon, Far Rockaway, Long Beach and West Hempstead branches. Several trains were stalled between stations. Ms. McGowan said that some commuters on those trains got off and walked onto the tracks, forcing officials to keep the rails turned off longer. Service was eventually restored at 10 p.m. Bert Cunningham, a spokesman for the Long Island Power Authority, said it was unclear what caused the wires  which were not live  to fall.

title: N.F.L. Culture Makes Issue of Head Injuries Even Murkier
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  Diagnosing a concussion is difficult. But it may be harder to determine just who is at fault for the long-term effects of concussions among N.F.L. players.

title: Ethiopian Pulls Away to Overpower Field in Womens 3,000
description: Ethiopia produces dozens of world-class distance runners, men and women, and the young ones do not necessarily have to wait their turn. Tirunesh Dibaba is only 21 but she is already a world-record holder and now a Millrose Games champion.

title: Among Hispanics, N.F.L. Mania Hits Cultural Wall
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  In October 2005, the National Football League played its first regular-season game outside the United States. It drew 103,467 people in Mexico City. The league expects huge audiences this year for a preseason game in Beijing and a regular-season game in London.

title: Fake Degrees Bought by 14 Confound Fire Officials
description: The Fire Department has not decided whether to take disciplinary action two days after a report revealed that 14 of its employees had used, or tried to use, bogus diplomas to be promoted or hired.

title: Massachusetts: Ad Company Apologizes for Stunt
description: A company that devised the advertising effort with light boards that ignited fears of terrorism in Boston on Wednesday issued an apology and said it had not tried to hide its involvement. The company, Interference Inc., said it learned of the situation after a man installed the devices, advertisements for a Cartoon Network show that were mistaken for bombs, on bridges and in other public areas. Interference said it immediately contacted the company that hired it, Turner Broadcasting, part of Time Warner, and the authorities in Boston and 10 other cities with the boards. A spokeswoman for the Boston police said that to her knowledge Interference did not call.

title: Germany: Parliament Adopts Health Reform
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a long-awaited deal for new financing of the national health care system, which is under strain from the rising cost of care, an aging population and high unemployment. The legislation, which is expected to be adopted by the upper house, requires everyone in Germany to have health insurance by 2009, when a state-run central fund will pool contributions and distribute money to insurers. The fund is intended to force inefficient health insurers to cut costs.

title: From Raider to Activist, but Still Icahn
description: A large number of companies in this country are badly run, Carl C. Icahn said the other day. Terribly run. Thats one of the reasons Im successful.

title: One Latte, Hold the Milk
description: If you believe, as I do, that darkness shrouded the Earth until someone thought to brew coffee at breakfast, at which time the stupor lifted, the neurons engaged and the Enlightenment dawned, then Robert Bohannon may be your new best friend. Dr. Bohannon is the North Carolina molecular biologist who six years ago sat down before a glass of milk and a doughnut and had the audacity to think that there was something wrong with that picture. Why not add caffeine  to the doughnut?

title: Democratic Hopefuls Split Over the Best Path to Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  To shouts and cheers from thousands of Democrats assembled here, the partys leading presidential contenders condemned President Bushs war in Iraq on Friday but sharply differed over how to end it  and particularly whether Democrats should settle for a nonbinding resolution expressing the Senates opposition to Mr. Bushs war policies.

title: Vornado Under Pressure to Sweeten Its Bid for Office Landlord
description: How high is too high?

title: Texas Is First to Require Cancer Shots for Schoolgirls
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2  Texas on Friday became the first state to require all 11- and 12-year-old girls entering the sixth grade to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.

title: A Big Baby Last Year, but Not Anymore
description: This time, Glen Davis has a gas pedal to step on. When a loose ball is skidding on the floor of Stegeman Coliseum at the University of Georgia, Davis, the 6-foot-9 center for Louisiana State, is there first to snatch it.

title: Analysis Is Bleak on Iraqs Future
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The release on Friday of portions of a bleak new National Intelligence Estimate about Iraqs future left the White House and its opponents vying over whether its findings buttressed their vastly different views about how to arrest the worsening sectarian chaos there.

title: Trenton: Further Investigation Into Chemists Death
description: A stalled investigation into the death of a chemist whose body was found nearly two years ago at the bottom of a tank at a water treatment plant has been taken up by the state attorney general and the state police. A spokesman for Attorney General Stuart Rabner said yesterday that the office had begun investigating the death of the chemist, Geetha Angara, at the urging of her family. Ms. Angara, 43, a resident of Holmdel, is believed to have been choked and then dumped into the 35-foot storage tank at the Passaic Valley Water Commission plant, where her body was found on Feb. 9, 2005. Compiled by Kathleen A. Flynn

title: Super Bowl Catches Up to Orange Blossom Classic
description: Decades before Super Bowl XLI, with its history-making confrontation between African-American head coaches, similar encounters took place every year. The setting was the Orange Blossom Classic, the unofficial but de facto championship game for the all-black colleges of the segregated South.

title: Commissioner Wants Fewer Off-Field Incidents
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  National Football League Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that he was concerned about the number of off-field incidents involving players this season.

title: No Way Out
description: WASHINGTON

title: Uffizi Expansion Is Finally (Well, Maybe) to Begin
description: FLORENCE, Jan. 27  A bright yellow crane has recently gone to work, the most solid sign yet that the reconstruction of the Uffizi Gallery here may really, finally, actually happen.

title: U.S. Trade Effort on China Suffers 2 More Setbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The Bush administrations efforts to ease economic strains with China suffered two setbacks Friday with the resignation of a top official in charge of the China dialogue and an announcement that talks on a critical trade dispute had failed to resolve differences.

title: Two Buildings, Once Stripped of Landmark Status, Regain It
description: When a New York City building becomes a landmark, it generally stays one. So it is highly unusual that two six-story buildings on the Upper East Side  part of a Progressive Era model tenement complex that offered airy and light-filled apartments to poor workers  have become landmarks again, for the second time in 16 years.

title: Former Judge Cites Pressure to Pay Friends of Party Boss
description: A former Brooklyn judge told a jury yesterday that she feared her career would be over if she did not pay $10,000 to associates of Clarence Norman Jr., the longtime leader of the boroughs Democratic machine, for get-out-the-vote efforts and fliers during her re-election campaign in 2002.

title: Even on the Big Screen, Things Are Never as They Seem
description: Good always triumphs over evil in classic Hollywood-style murder mysteries and westerns. In typical whodunits, the murder takes place in the first act and is solved in the second, so the killer can be put behind bars in the third. Westerns follow similar patterns; only, after cowboys restore order to the world, they ride off into the sunset.

title: Consumers Have Allies on the Web
description: Ben Popken is an unlikely consumer crusader.

title: Hartford: Car Tax Phase-Out to Be Proposed Again
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rells budget for next year will include a five-year phase-out of the states car tax, her office said in a statement yesterday. The two-year budget, scheduled to be released on Wednesday, will revise the governors proposal from last year that called for eliminating the car tax, which was roundly rejected by Democratic lawmakers and local officials. Mrs. Rell said the new plan would use revenues from slot machines at casinos to reimburse cities and towns for the loss of car-tax receipts, while a reduction in the property-tax credit will offset the decline in revenues to the state. The plan faces an uphill climb in the Democratic-controlled State Legislature. The governor has said she would not make it a top priority. Compiled by Kathleen A. Flynn

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Jan. 13 about Ukrainian orphans who visited American families in hopes of being adopted included imprecise information from Vincent Rosini, the president of a humanitarian agency that brought the orphans, about a favor an orphanage director had sought from him. The director asked for a loan to buy a new coat, not for a new coat. (Mr. Rosini said he made the loan, which was repaid.)

title: Sites for the Socially Conscious
description: THERE are many Web sites devoted to criticizing industries and companies. Many are of the Wal-Mart Watch variety (walmartwatch.com) and are decidedly one-sided.

title: Titillating or Not, Washington Gossip Blossoms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Some big doings in the nations capital this week.

title: Serbia Rejects Plan That Could Lead to Kosovo Independence
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Feb. 2  Serbia rejected a United Nations proposal on Friday that paves the way for an independent Kosovo, setting up a possible showdown between its supporter, Russia, and the West over the disputed territorys final status.

title: South Africa: Suspect in Historians Killing
description: A day after South Africans buried the renowned historian David Rattray, the leading expert on the 19th-century Anglo-Zulu war and a close friend of Prince Charles, a 23-year-old man pleaded guilty to killing him at his KwaZulu-Natal lodge, and a second man was arrested in connection with the crime. Mr. Rattray was killed in an apparent botched robbery at his property on Jan. 26, the latest in a string of killings that has riveted South Africans attention on security issues.

title: Crashworthy Motor Vehicles
description: The federal government is exploring ways to strengthen its tests and its ratings system for the crashworthiness of motor vehicles. The effort is long overdue but still likely to fall short of whats needed. In far too many cases, the tests are weaker than they should be and fail to address current kinds of accidents, like what happens when one of todays larger vehicles collides with a smaller one.

title: Journalist Group Criticizes Press Freedoms Under Hu Jintao
description: BEIJING, Feb. 2  A leading media watchdog group on Friday accused President Hu Jintao of China of seeking to bring the media to heel and instigating an expanding crackdown on the press despite Chinas pledge to enhance media freedoms before the 2008 Olympics, which are to be held in Beijing.

title: Expenses Cited for End of Nissans 6-Year Run of Record Profit
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2  Carlos Ghosns six-year streak of record profits is about to be snapped.

title: Pavano Hopes His Pitching Will Silence His Critics
description: Off-season conference calls with most baseball players take on a casual mood. Questions about a players credibility in his clubhouse or the public perception that he is a loafer are hardly staples.

title: 17 Die as Fatah-Hamas Warfare Spreads
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2  In some of the worst internal Palestinian fighting to date, Fatah security force members stormed the Hamas-aligned Islamic University in Gaza City on Friday, setting ablaze the library, computer center and other buildings while the rival factions battled throughout the Gaza Strip.

title: An Opinionated Orchestra, an Indulgent Conductor
description: National orchestras go on international tours for a number of reasons. One is to advertise their countries cultures. Another is to seek support, spiritual and otherwise, for their work. The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Thursday gave off even more resonance in this regard, as the cultural representative of an embattled nation met with its large and committed American constituency.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK Strangers on a train? No more, as Michael (Wentworth Miller) and Sara (Sarah Wayne Callies) share a kiss en route to confront the president. Meanwhile, Mahone finds a new ally in his bid to capture the fugitives. And the Hollanders keep up appearances now that T-Bag  thats Daddy to you  is home.

title: Pakistan Says Taliban Activity Is Hard to Stop
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 2  Faced with mounting criticism that Pakistan is not doing enough to thwart incursions into Afghanistan by Pakistan-based Taliban militants, the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said Friday that securing the porous border was not the sole responsibility of this country.

title: Eric von Schmidt, 75, a Performer and Inspiration to Folk Singers, Dies
description: Eric von Schmidt, a performer and composer of folk music who as a boy instantly fell in love with the blues when he heard Leadbelly on the radio, and who went on to be a mentor to and to inspire singers like Bob Dylan and Joan Baez, died yesterday in Fairfield, Conn. He was 75.

title: Silicon Valleys High-Tech Hunt for Colleague
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2  When James Gray failed to return home from a sailing trip on Sunday night, Silicon Valleys best and brightest went out to help find him.

title: Simpson Transcript Describes Murder
description: In November O. J. Simpson sat for what would have been one of the most unusual interviews in television history  a hypothetical recounting of how, if he had been the killer, he might have murdered his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman more than a decade ago.

title: Lone Starlets
description: HOUSTON

title: The Recurring Stain Should Be a Tipoff
description: A key scene in The Messengers finds an anxious mom, Denise (Penelope Ann Miller), waking up in the farmhouse her family has just moved into, and discovering that the hideous dark stain she scrubbed out of her bedroom wallpaper just yesterday has reappeared at full strength.

title: Emotional Resonance Amid Blocks of Harmony
description: Bright Sheng, Leon Kirchner and Nicholas Maw are the season composers at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and if the title is awkward, at least it is direct. Each is represented by a handful of works, interspersed through this seasons subscription concerts. They also shared a concert on Thursday evening at the Rose Studio.

title: Assets Shifted by Family That Controls Times Co.
description: The Ochs-Sulzberger family, which controls The New York Times Company, said yesterday that it was withdrawing most of its personal assets, worth hundreds of millions of dollars, from Morgan Stanley.

title: David Byrne Honors Joints That Connect the Limbs
description: Inviting David Byrne to play host to a Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall seems redundant. The point of Perspectives is to allow artists free rein to explore their interests, wherever they may lead, and Mr. Byrnes entire career, from his days as leader of the Talking Heads (1976-88) to a recent gallery exhibition of drawings of chairs, has already been about just that.

title: Diabetes in New York (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Bars Government Benefit for Same-Sex Domestic Partners
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2  Same-sex domestic partners are not entitled to health benefits from public universities or local and state governments under the State Constitutions two-year-old marriage amendment, the Michigan Court of Appeals said in a ruling released Friday.

title: Slower Job Growth, at Least for Now
description: Job growth slowed in January, the government reported yesterday, offering a tentative sign that the economy may be shifting down a notch from its unexpectedly robust pace of growth at the end of last year.

title: Accessible Subways (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lagat Needs Every Yard to Win Wanamaker Mile
description: Like nearly everyone else in Madison Square Garden last night, Bernard Lagat believed his biggest challenge in winning his fifth Wanamaker Mile would come from his fellow American Alan Webb, roundly considered Lagats rival-to-be.

title: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about the murder trial of Ben Odierno, a Manhattan landlord accused of killing his wife, Christine, referred incorrectly to her injuries and to a defense witness, Allegra Lugo. According to prosecutors, Mrs. Odierno had more than 40 injuries on her body, including scrapes, cuts, bruises and stab wounds; she was not stabbed more than 40 times. Ms. Lugo is a former girlfriend of the Odiernos son Stephan  not of his brother, Marcus. The article also misstated a point made by a prosecutor, Kerry OConnell. She said that Mr. Odierno and his sons loathed Mrs. Odierno, not the other way around.

title: In Kenyas Capital, a Sense That Danger Is Ever Stronger
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 2  Maybe it was a stubborn seat belt. Or just the pure, paralyzing shock of having an AK-47 thrust in your face.

title: Our Moral Guide (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankruptcy. Hostile Bid. What Next?
description: Gerald Grinstein, 74, thought most of the heavy lifting was done preparing Delta Air Lines to exit bankruptcy  until a hostile takeover bid arrived in November from US Airways. What followed was nearly three months of furious maneuvering for the favor of the official committee of Deltas unsecured creditors, the group representing those who will become Deltas new owners.

title: Spring Floods (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving Winter Worries Behind and Zooming to a Small Slam
description: Most bridge teachers work in their local areas, but some go to attractive locations around the United States and abroad. One lucky traveler is Augie Boehm, who last month had a five-day course of lessons and playing sessions at the Mill Reef Club in Antigua.

title: Kidd Says Hes Still Motivated to Play at a High Level
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 2  During a recent conversation about the consistency that has allowed him to play at a high level into his 30s, Jason Kidd smirked after making this particular point: Theres no change in my game. Im just shooting the ball a little bit better right now.

title: Viacom Tells YouTube: Hands Off
description: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded yesterday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.

title: Victims of Success
description: YOUR past success could be holding you back.

title: Saluting William Styron With His Own Words
description: Searching for the words to honor the best-selling author William Styron yesterday at a memorial service at St. Bartholomews Church in Manhattan, his friends and family members turned to the words of William Styron.

title: On This Stagecoach, Finish Is Hard to See
description: NEWDIGATE, England  In the obscure sport of carriage driving, whose marquee discipline consists of four horses or ponies dragging what looks like an open stagecoach through three events  presentation, dressage and the marathon  five years is just long enough to assemble a competitive team. But that is only if one is lucky enough to have horses with the right temperament.

title: Lone Star Gets Big Dividend in Korea Deal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 2  Lone Star Funds, the United States buyout firm whose multibillion-dollar sale of its investment in Korea Exchange Bank was blocked by South Korean prosecutors, will recoup almost a third of its original investment in a move that drew divided reaction.

title: 2nd Acts in the Executive Suite
description: When James R. Houghton began a second stint as chief executive at Corning Inc. in 2002, the company was reeling. The first thing he did, Mr. Houghton recalled yesterday, was to see if there was somebody I should shoot.

title: Consultants Draw Fire in Bus Woes
description: When Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein hired the consulting firm Alvarez & Marsal, without competitive bidding, one provision of the $15.8 million contract called for restructuring the Office of Pupil Transportation to obtain annual cost savings. Simply put: drive down the cost of busing children to school.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an agreement by 10 manufacturers of outdoor wood-fired boilers to make cleaner and more efficient machines misstated the day that a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency commented on the agreement. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

title: Albany: Inspector General Is Appointed
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday named Kristine Hamann as his inspector general, aiming to bolster what has been a largely invisible job. The appointment of Ms. Hamann, an experienced prosecutor from the Manhattan district attorneys office, sends a very powerful signal to everybody in my administration that we care about their ethical conduct, Mr. Spitzer said in an interview. Ms. Hamann has worked for three decades in the Manhattan district attorneys office. Since 1998, she has been an executive assistant district attorney. In that position, she created a child-advocacy center and established procedures for DNA testing. The inspector general, who earns $145,500 a year, is responsible for investigating fraud and corruption in the agencies and authorities led by the governors appointees.

title: Number of People Stopped by New York Police Soars
description: The New York Police Department released new information yesterday showing that police officers stopped 508,540 individuals on New York City streets last year  an average of 1,393 stops per day  often searching them for illegal weapons. The number was up from 97,296 in 2002, the last time the department divulged 12 months worth of data.

title: Dont Let Iran Become the Next War (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Saved From the Brink of Homelessness After Illness Struck
description: There can be a plunge in fortunes, or a gradual slide, until the accumulating setbacks become too much to overcome without help from outside the family.

title: On Ryans Farm, Memories Fresh and Fading
description: SHELBYVILLE, Ky.  Each morning at 5 a.m., Buddy Ryans day begins in solitude, mucking out the stalls of his horses. He has 17 of them, and three mares in particular are named for milestones in his colorful and sometimes cantankerous lifetime.

title: Chiracs Iran Gaffe Reveals a Strategy: Containment
description: PARIS, Feb. 2  When President Jacques Chirac said this week that he would not be overly worried if Iran obtained a nuclear weapon, he inadvertently said aloud what some policy makers and arms control experts have been whispering: that the world may have to learn to live with a nuclear Iran.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Analysis: On the Polarization of Iraqis and Their Ready Recourse to Violence
description: Following is the text of the key judgments of the new National Intelligence Estimate about Iraqs future that was released yesterday. The report, most of which remains classified, is titled Prospects for Iraqs Stability: A Challenging Road Ahead and is dated January 2007. Italic emphasis and parenthetical abbreviations are from the report.

title: Record $622 Billion Budget Requested for the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The Bush administration is seeking a record military budget of $622 billion for the 2008 fiscal year, Pentagon officials have said. The sum includes more than $140 billion for war-related costs.

title: Totals
Kindred Spirits in Groove
description: The drummer Scott Amendola could fairly be described as a jazz musician with an investment in the imperatives of groove. He seems to come by his eclecticism naturally: when rock, bebop and Afrobeat take turns surfacing in his music, they do so in a way that feels loose and unforced. Perhaps it says something that Mr. Amendola makes his home in Berkeley, Calif., a place where cosmopolitanism jibes with crunchiness. Or maybe his aesthetic just reflects the interests of a peer group weaned on myriad musical cultures.

title: Device Breaks Up in Pipeline, and Search Is on for Lost Piece
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A device designed to clean waxy buildup from the walls of the 800-mile Alaska pipeline broke apart inside the pipeline in December, raising the possibility that any remaining shards of machinery might damage sensitive valves, an executive of Alyeska, the company that runs the pipeline, confirmed Thursday.

title: For the Record
description: A picture yesterday with an article about the corruption trial of Clarence Norman Jr. carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photographer was Jeremy M. Lange, not Chang W. Lee.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) KING KONG (2005). Beauty and the beast, retold by Peter Jackson with a Lord of the Rings flourish but still surprisingly sweet. Naomi Watts plays Ann Darrow; Adrien Brody is her favorite writer; Jack Black is the film director who got them into this mess on mysterious Skull Island; and Andy Serkis does double duty as Kong and a cook named Lumpy.

title: In an Israeli Town Prone to Attacks, New Yorks Mayor Denounces Terror
description: SDEROT, Israel, Feb. 2  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg touched down by helicopter on a bare patch of dirt here on Friday, bringing his message against terror to a town shaken by persistent attacks from Palestinian militants firing rockets over the border from Gaza.

title: Chinese Official Warns Against Independence of Courts
description: BEIJING, Feb. 2  Enemy forces are seeking to use Chinas legal system to Westernize and divide the country, and the Communist Party must fend them off by maintaining its dominance over lawyers, judges and prosecutors, Chinas top law and order official said in a detailed speech whose text was published Friday.

title: U.S. Talks With Palestinians and Israelis Gain Support
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Middle East peace negotiators gave broad endorsement on Friday to American designs for three-way talks led by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and involving Israeli and Palestinian leaders. But discord immediately surfaced with Russian comments that Syria, too, could play a constructive role.

title: A Rare Bill in Congress
description: The Democratic-led House has made the most of a sorry budgetary business, stripping out billions of dollars in earmarked pork from a spending measure urgently needed to keep the government running this year. The $463.5 billion bill is an omnibus mop-up device necessitated by the fact that nine of 11 major spending bills were left unfinished last fall by the Republican leadership in its final weeks of power. The Democrats, who promised to cut out special-interest budget goodies, killed thousands of earmarks custom-designed by lawmakers.

title: After Western Trip, Nets Seem to Have Run Out of Fuel
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 2  The days of thrilling basketball for the Nets, though not far removed in actual days, seem like a lifetime ago.

title: Echoes of a Killing
description: The grisly killing of a doctor 80 years ago after the death of his young patient still resonates.

title: Op-Chart: 31 Days in Iraq
description: In January more than 1,900 people  soldiers, security officers and civilians  were killed in the insurgency in Iraq, up from 800 in January 2006. Many corpses showed signs of torture, meaning the victims were probably killed by religious and tribal death squads. This map, based on data from the American, British and Iraqi governments and from news reports, shows the dates, locations and circumstances of deaths for the first month of the year. Given the vast size of Iraq and the communications difficulties inherent in war, the information may be incomplete. Nonetheless, it is our effort to visually depict the continuing human cost of the Iraq war.

title: Escalating Tensions
description: Sectarian tensions have been blamed for vandalism and student confrontations in American Muslim communities.

title: Pound the Pavement
description: A day trip with the United Hispanic Construction Workers as they visited job sites.

title: Drawn to the Table
description: When cartoonists of The New Yorker assemble for an informal lunch.

title: Kosovo's Serbs
description: As the U.N. nudges Kosovo toward what it calls final status and what Belgrade calls independence, many of northern Kosovos Serbs are threatening to break away.

title: Stanley Wilsons Super Bowl
description: Most people who look back at the 1989 Super Bowl remember Joe Montanas winning touchdown drive in the final minutes. But something that happened before the game will never be forgotten by the Bengals.

title: Programming Note
description: A whole lot of blogging going on tomorrow  to match the occasion. Feel free to send in your comments.

title: Paper Is for Lovers
description: Ardor, it seems, cannot be pixelated: despite the e-volution of correspondence, paper Valentine's Day cards are still in style. "Because of technological advances the number of elite letterpress card companies is going through the roof," said Melanie Nerenberg, the marketing director at Kate's Paperie, the New York paper shops chain, "as is the number of customers who want and appreciate them." Last February the company sold 22,000 cards, compared with 14,000 in February 2004. Numbers aside, Ms. Nerenberg said, "An e-valentine is the death of romance." Below are a dozen ways to keep love alive.

title: The Democrats and Bush
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  President Bush is, as we know, the decider.

title: Biden: More Mea Culpa
description: Here in Washington, the Joe Biden apology tour continued this morning, following the infelicitous remarks he made about Barack Obama to the New York Observer earlier this week.

title: Correction: You Can Teach a Spy a Novelists Tricks
description: Because of an editing error, the Word for Word feature last week excerpting passages from the fiction of E. Howard Hunt, who died last week, referred incorrectly to a burglary he committed. Mr. Hunt burglarized the office of the psychiatrist of Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg, not Dr. Ellsberg's office.

title: Iraq and G.O.P. Campaign Cash
description: We told you last week that Hugh Hewitt, conservative talk show host and columnist, had started a pledge drive, asking people to promise not to donate money to any Republican senator who opposed President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq.

title: At Retreat, Bush Plays With Party Names
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  Its too early to know if President Bush won over the House Democrats, but he did get them to laugh today.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about an essay titled  Progressive Jewish Thought and the New Anti-Semitism on the Web site of the American Jewish Committee referred incorrectly to the committee. Its stance on issues ranges across the political spectrum; it is not conservative.

title: Wake Up and Smell the Award
description: Sometime in the wee hours of the (East coast) morning, the Directors Guild of America will probably announce that Martin Scorsese is their choice for the year. The Bagger is not on site, but he is on highest alert and will do lots of on-the-scene reporting from his basement in New Jersey when word comes down. Right after he wakes up.

title: Veterinarian Shortage for Farms
description: A nationwide shortage of livestock veterinarians is causing difficulties for farmers.

title: Democrats Quiz Bush
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. - President Bushs speech to House Democrats today - 16 minutes, according to our watch - was interrupted by applause 21 times. Respect for the presidency, it seemed, overruled any feelings of rancor toward Mr. Bushs policies.

title: Power Conference
description: Ohio State was a seven-and-a-half-point favorite to win the B.C.S. title game against Florida last month. We all know how that turned out.

title: Too Much Super Bowl?
description: Are you considering skipping the Super Bowl?

title: The Halftime Act Currently Known as Prince
description: Like a bad general manager, the N.F.L. continues to pick performers who are past their prime. If it were up to you, who would be the Super Bowls halftime act?

title: Rank the Best Commercials
description: If the game is a blowout by halftime, the second half will be about the commercials (of course, some will say its about the commercials regardless). Click on some of the following links listing the best commercials in Super Bowl history, and send along your own list of favorites.

title: Editors Choice
description: THOMAS HARDY, by Claire Tomalin. (Penguin Press, $35.) Tomalin presents Hardy as a fascinating case study in mid-Victorian literary sociology.

description: New Brunswick

description: CLAD in black clothes and moonlight, our guide Poncho adjusted his ski mask and faced us to speak. The desert has claimed many lives, he said, but tonight we would make it across the border.

title: American Dream Deferred
description: Call him Ishmael. Its one of a few placeholders the protagonist of Michael Thomass first novel, Man Gone Down, offers up as a clue to his identity. It doesnt matter if thats really his name, though, because like Melvilles enlightened nonhero, this man does not expect to survive the journey. He has long known himself lost to this world.

title: Inside the List
description: UNTAPPED POWER: There are good self-help books and bad self-help books. But once in a while one comes along thats so comically and so brazenly cynical and manipulative that it produces a kind of inverse sonic boom  you can practically hear the sound of shattered bookstore windows rippling up and down the coasts. Picking it up, you know youre in the presence of demented genius. And you know, somehow, its going to sell.

title: Far Away, Super Bowls Losers Will Be Champs
description: MIAMI, Feb. 3  In some parts of the world, the Seattle Seahawks are the reigning Super Bowl champions, the Buffalo Bills are the last great football dynasty and Tom Brady is some frustrated quarterback from New England who can never win it all.

title: Robert Moses; Persepolis
description: ROBERT MOSES

title: Up Front
description: In her cover review of Michael Thomass first novel, Man Gone Down, Kaiama L. Glover notes that the book raises the question of how the narrator negotiates a color line that runs smack through the middle of his family. Shes no stranger to that reality.

title: Olympics for Hipsters: The Indy 500 Its Not
description: Nobody was supposed to show up for the Idiotarod, the annual absurdist shopping cart race, until 1 p.m. last Saturday. The races starting point was a closely guarded secret until the day before, and the Carts of Brooklyn Racing Association, its sponsor, had urged people gathering for the 1:30 start time to keep a low profile.

title: Frances Wu and Rommel Nobay
description: FRANCES WU said she was pushing 30 in 2000 when she fled New York for Tokyo. She did so partly to put distance between herself and a beau, who she said had wasted four years of her life. She also hoped to find a husband in Japan. But there she heard herself heartlessly referred to as a Christmas cake.

title: Engine Sludge: When Good Oil Goes Bad
description: FOR people buying a used car, there is a very important but rarely checked factor to consider that goes beyond kicking the tires: original sin.

title: An Enclave at Once Snug and Inclusive
description: ONE recent morning on an avenue of tidy brick houses and tiny front yards in Sunnyside, a cat mewed at a trembling beagle, followed quickly by a white-haired neighbor from a few doors down who shooed them both away.

title: Second-Story Story
description: MOST Manhattan dwellers carry a torch for at least one departed neighborhood merchant: the shoe repairer, the locksmith, the surly hardware man who piled what looked like rusting scrap metal behind his smudged plate-glass window but who could, on demand, unearth items Home Depot never dreamed of.

title: In the Playoff Hunt and Hunting for Players
description: When it comes to being traded, no one understands like me and my family, Islanders center Mike Sillinger said. Sillinger has 499 points in 959 games in his N.H.L. career. And he has done that with 12 teams (not including Dallas, to whom he was traded in 2003 and by whom he was traded away later that day).

title: County Sued Over Lack of Affordable Homes
description: IN the 1980s, Yonkers almost went bankrupt fighting a federal judges order to integrate public housing before finally relenting. In the years since, the fair-and-affordable housing debate has gone largely unspoken in the county and in the country, with Congress appearing reluctant to push local communities and housing advocates stymied at getting the courts involved.

title: What MapQuest and G.P.S. Dont Tell You Can Get You Lost
description: GETTING driving directions is an easy process these days with computer software, mapping Web sites and G.P.S. systems. They will indeed get you from Point A to Point B, but they often do it in standard English, bland as a news anchors accent. Whether youre headed for a Brooklyn brownstone or an Indiana office park, the route will be described as a series of intersections and turns.

title: Going Kosher and Signaling a Change
description: On the east side of the street, North Riverdale seems as solidly Irish Catholic as it has for generations.

title: When Good Causes Collide
description: IN the past 18 months, Christopher and Margaret Stefanoni have made few friends and many enemies. Since announcing that they want to replace their house in a shoreline neighborhood of Darien with an affordable housing complex, the couple and their neighboring opponents on Nearwater Lane have warred across yards, through the media and in multiple lawsuits.

title: The Nurse Practitioner Will See You Now
description: WHEN Melanie Klein needed a vaccination recently to attend community college, she had few affordable options. She is a German citizen working as a live-in nanny for a Westchester family and says she has only emergency health coverage.

title: Getting a Good Sleep at 30,000 Feet, for Less
description: Regarding your recent advice on how to find the best seats in the air (Q&A, Nov. 19), why not suggest my solution? For years I have bought three adjoining seats in coach and slept like a baby, completely flat. The price is always much less than business class, and you get more real estate. I would add three warnings, however: Never buy the first row in the coach section (the armrests cannot be raised); never buy just two seats; and bring an extra pillow.  Janys Harvey, Paris

title: The Touts Favor the Colts; the Statistics Favor the Bears
description: If it is true that offense wins games but defense wins championships, Bears Coach Lovie Smith will hoist the Vince Lombardi Trophy tonight.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Hunan Resources
description: General Tsos (or Zuos) chicken is the most famous Hunanese dish in the world. A delectable concoction of lightly battered chicken in a chili-laced sweet-sour sauce, it appears on restaurant menus across the globe, but especially in the Eastern United States, where it seems to have become the epitome of Hunanese cuisine. Despite its international reputation, however, the dish is virtually unknown in the Chinese province of Hunan itself. When I went to live there four years ago, I scoured restaurant menus for it in vain, and no one I met had ever heard of it. And as I deepened my understanding of Hunanese food, I began to realize that General Tsos chicken was somewhat alien to the local palate because Hunanese people have little interest in dishes that combine sweet and savory tastes. So how on earth did this strange, foreign concoction come to be recognized abroad as the culinary classic of Hunan?

title: Court Upholds Evasion Ruling in a Tax Case
description: The federal tax court has ruled in favor of the Internal Revenue Service in a 14-year-old evasion case involving a now-dead lawyer who was one of the nations leading tax advisers, millions of dollars in reported real estate kickbacks and a Supreme Court ruling that ended a longstanding practice of secrecy in tax court.

title: Roots of an Artist, Traced Through His Appropriations
description: In the mid-1970s the young Richard Prince, a recent art school graduate, saw a gray clapboard home in a field while driving through Maine. The house reminded him of the one in Andrew Wyeths famous painting Christinas World, so he stopped the car and asked his girlfriend to get out and go lie in the field in front of the building so that he could take a photograph in imitation of the original. Their intrusion did not amuse the propertys owners.

title: Yaphank as a Destination Point
description: THE design of a new community is beginning to emerge in western Suffolk County, as the county investigates just how many needs it can meet with one development, perhaps even including an indoor motor-sports arena.

title: Chastened Suozzi Taking a Mellower Tack
description: GARDEN CITY

title: Interest Payments on Security Deposits
description: Q I recently received a check for what was described as interest on my security deposit. The interest was $32.26, but $22.16 was deducted as a 1 percent management fee. I dont understand any of this  this seems like more than 1 percent to me.

title: 36 Hours in Aspen, Colo.
description: EVEN though Aspen regards itself as an international ski playground, the town is still oddly provincial. Calibrating the pros and cons of change is an Aspen obsession, and Topic A this season is the new cabins on the Silver Queen gondola. The floor-to-ceiling windows allow riders better views of the majestic Elk Mountains, as well as to critique less graceful skiers below. Yet some riders bemoan the loss of the middle vent (although there is a larger one at the top), and there's lots of whining about the fact that seats now face each other (rather than the old back-to-back configuration)  forcing you to acknowledge your cabmates rather than merely eavesdrop on their conversations. Of course, some people think Aspen went soft when the original gondola was built in 1986.

title: A Jew at Harvard
description: Sometimes he might toss in a twist or fiddle with the vermouth. But it needs to be cold, and lets not have any nonsense about vodka. He knows his ingredients, and success lies in how he puts them together. Anyone coming to Matters of Honor after reading one of Louis Begleys seven previous novels is going to find some familiar things. Theres New York and money, a white-shoe law firm and the genteel anti-Semitism associated with it. A narrator who sits just off the main action. Poland and the Holocaust. Add a bit of Latin; add Harvard in the 50s and stir.

title: Murder Most Suburban
description: WHEN P. D. James, the grand master of the well-made detective story, said, You can gain a far more accurate impression of what it is like to live and work in a city from a mystery than from more pretentious forms, she probably wasnt thinking about Great Neck. Or Upper Montclair. Or any of the other thinly disguised locales found in dozens of mysteries set in the suburbs of New York.

title: A Woman of Many Parts, Some Exposed
description: "OUCH, ouch, ouuuccch, Julie Atlas Muz moaned from the floor of P.S. 122 last Saturday. She was on a break from the final rehearsal for her first solo show, and the process was taking its toll. This even though Ms. Muz, the burlesque dancer and downtown performance artist, is in enviable shape, creatively and physically. title: The Terminated
description: After a silence dictated by shame, pain and politics that lasted the better part of a century, the suffering of Armenians massacred by the Ottoman Turks and their Kurdish allies during World War I has recently become an urgent issue. The parliaments of several countries in the European Union, a club Turkey wants to join, have labeled the massacres genocide. The Turks refuse to do so. Of all those involved in this slow, bitter process of remembering, it is writers and journalists, not politicians, who have touched the rawest nerves. On Jan. 19, Hrant Dink, a prominent Turkish-Armenian who had promoted both reconciliation and an honest appraisal of the past, was murdered, apparently by a Turkish nationalist. Earlier, Orhan Pamuks reference to the massacres in an interview and an allusion to the Armenian genocide in a novel by Elif Shafak led to the prosecution of both on charges of insulting Turkishness. Neither was convicted (unlike Dink, who received a suspended sentence on the same charge) but the countrys reputation has suffered.

title: In a New Direction
description: A landmark event for Modernism in America occurred in 1934, when James Laughlin, a Harvard sophomore, went on a leave of absence to spend a few months in Italy with Ezra Pound. The heir of a Pittsburgh steel fortune, Laughlin (1914-97) was fed up with the reactionary views of teachers like the poet Robert Hillyer, who made a point of leaving a room when Pound or T. S. Eliot was mentioned. With a letter of introduction from his English master at Choate, Dudley Fitts, the 19-year-old Laughlin was admitted to what Pound called his Ezuversity at Rapallo, the idea being that Pound would help the young man with his poetry. As it happened, the two got along swimmingly, except for the poetry part. Youre never going to be any good as a poet, Pound said. Why dont you take up something useful? That Laughlin saw fit to follow this advice would prove an immeasurable boon for American literature. While still at Harvard, Laughlin founded New Directions, which would soon become the most important publisher of experimental prose and poetry in the United States. Laughlin piled books into his Buick and drove as far as Omaha to extol the greatness of Pound and Henry Miller and Elizabeth Bishop and many other heroes of contemporary lit.

They argued that slowness in completing the vaunted new American security plan has made Shiite neighborhoods much more vulnerable to such horrific attacks.

title: Elegant, Exotic Food, and Belly Dancing, Too
description: AS a boy growing up in Marrakesh, Alain Bennouna was the only one of nine siblings allowed to linger in the kitchen alongside his mother. And diners can count their lucky stars for that. Mr. Bennouna, the genial owner of Zitoune, a new Moroccan restaurant in Mamaroneck, learned some lovely tricks at her elbow.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: From the Hope Program, a Path to a Fresh Start
description: SHAWN LIPSCOMB has spent 13 of his 32 years in prison for two robberies; in one of them he shot and wounded the victim. He says the holdups were to support his cocaine addiction and live the life of the guys who had the cars, the females and the jewelry. Now, he says, he is determined to become a law-abiding, job-holding member of society.

title: Family Failings
description: Certain words and phrases tell you a lot about a book. Forevermore is one of them  a once upon a time for adult readers. In Alice Hoffmans latest novel, Skylight Confessions, the word appears almost exactly halfway through the story: Lost and then found. Discovered in some deep way. He was stuck there, he realized that now; that young girl with red hair sifted through his reality forevermore. This rhetorical flourish  not just forever, but forevermore  is a clear sign that Hoffman is aiming for the kind of lofty truths that can be reached only by going to extremes.

title: Catherine Morrison, William Golden
description: Catherine Morrison and William T. Golden were married last evening at their home in Manhattan. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated.

title: Correction: A Few Raindrops Fall on the Big-Money Collector Car Auctions in Arizona
description: An article last Sunday about four recent collector-car auctions in Arizona misstated some sales results for this year and previous years. A total of 1,916 cars were reported sold, not 3,923, at an average price of about $86,000, not $41,000. The average price at one auction company, Russo & Steele, was $72,213, not $68,000. Another company, Barrett-Jackson, had sales of $37 million, not $34 million, at the 2004 auction, and $62 million, not $65 million, at the 2005 event.

title: Beyond Criticism
description: It may be heretical, or just foolish, for a book review editor to admit it, but there are times when criticism is beside the point. This was brought home to me recently when I read the Library of Americas new edition of Saul Bellows major fiction from the 1950s and 60s, a volume of nearly 800 pages that includes Seize the Day, Henderson the Rain King and Herzog.

title: With Curls and a Haircut, a Billboard Is Reborn
description: THE first time, the boy ended up with a smear of black paint across his face. But after some digital alterations  adding curls on the sides of his face, shortening his haircut and buttoning his shirt higher at the collar  he was ready to try again.

title: Easy Comfort, With Satisfying Dishes
description: WHAT I always like best about neighborhood restaurants is the sense of intimacy and personal relationship they afford  the feeling of knowing and being known. This sense of belonging to a place is so rewarding that I can forgive a lot about the food; if I like one or two of the dishes, Im well satisfied.

title: Hungry Heart
description: Growing up in Oakland in the 1950s, I came to dislike Chinese food. That may have been, in part, because I was Chinese and desperately wanted to be American. I was American, of course, but, being born and raised in Chinatown  in a restaurant my parents operated, in fact  I didnt feel much like the people I saw outside Chinatown, or in books and movies.

title: Paperback Row
description: AT CANAANS EDGE: America in the King Years, 1965-68, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $20. ) This is the third and final volume of Branchs monumental history of the life and times of Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil rights movement. The book opens with the marches for voting rights in Selma, Ala., and chronicles other developments from the riots in Watts and the rise of the black power movement to the uneasy relationship between the civil rights and antiwar movements after Lyndon Johnsons escalation of the Vietnam War. A National Book Award finalist last year, At Canaans Edge is a thrilling book, marvelous in both its breadth and its detail, Anthony Lewis wrote in the Book Review.

title: At the Crossroads, Between Red Tape and Red Hot
description: IT is past midnight in downtown Strasbourg, and hip-hop and remixed dance classics reverberate around Living Room, a red-walled lounge packed with fashionistas sipping cocktails. Around the corner, a small rave begins at Salamander, a former factory space whose new owners have skimped on every detail, letting the dance floor speak for itself. Across town, a 30-something crowd chatters amicably at Les Aviateurs, a Chicago-style rock bar with dcor that blends old movie and concert posters with early-20th-century model airplanes.

title: At Least 130 Die as Blast Levels Baghdad Market
description: BAGHDAD, Sunday, Feb. 4  A mammoth truck bomb obliterated a popular central Baghdad market on Saturday, ripping through scores of shops and flattening apartment buildings, killing at least 130 people and wounding more than 300 in the worst of a series of horrific attacks against Shiites in recent weeks.

description: After 50 years, The Patent Trader, a weekly newspaper that circulated in northern Westchester County, was replaced last week by a new publication, The Northern Westchester Express.

title: In Cuba, Finding a Tiny Corner of Jewish Life
description: CLAUDIA BARLIYA, a 6-year-old Cuban-Jewish girl, stood on a cobblestone street in Trinidad, a small centuries-old city on the south coast of Cuba. A donkey carrying an old man passed behind her; a group of 30 Jewish-Americans, including this reporter, stood before her. The girl had asked if she could perform a song for the group, which was on a humanitarian mission with the Westchester Jewish Center of Mamaroneck, N.Y. She now had their full attention. When her song rang out  not in Spanish, but in the Hebrew words of Yerushalayim Shel Zahav, or Jerusalem of Gold  the group couldnt help joining in.

title: Ameliorate, Contain, Coerce, Destroy
description: Karl von Clausewitz, the greatest of all military theorists, learned the art of war the hard way. As a senior Prussian officer, he was on the receiving end of the Napoleonic revolution in warfare at the Battle of Jena in 1806, ending up a prisoner. Watching how Bonaparte used the French army to redraw the map of Europe convinced Clausewitz that war was not merely an act of policy but a true political instrument, a continuation of political intercourse, carried on with other means (the most famous and most frequently misquoted sentence in On War).

title: Why Dick Cheney Cracked Up

The vice president who boasted of enormous successes in Iraq and barked hogwash at the congenitally mild Wolf Blitzer has been roundly judged delusional, pathologically dishonest or just plain nuts. But what else is new? We identified those diagnoses long ago. The more intriguing question is what ignited this particularly violent public flare-up.

title: Sympathy for a Devil: Hannibal, Manic Avenger
description: EMPATHY, everybody knows, can be kind of a mixed blessing. Fine human quality though it may be, it is not obviously useful in pursuits like business and war, which seem to be shaping up as the major occupations of the 21st century. So theres no reason, really, to be surprised that the movies (and television and commercial fiction) can now, with relative impunity, offer up the once despised psychopath  who feels no empathy  as at least a semiheroic figure, a fulfillment of one of those fantasies that grow like pesky molds in the unfinished basements of our pop-culture souls.

The French bistros have not yet arrived, nor have the tapas bars or businesses re-embracing the neighborhood name, which once made the area menacing to outsiders.

title: My New Look
description: When I landed a job teaching writing at Carleton College, the first thing I did was buy a hip new wardrobe. Twenty years earlier I was a slovenly underachiever at this small, Midwestern liberal-arts school, and new clothes would mark my triumphant return. Also, I had never taught before. If I failed as a teacher, at least my students would think I was cool.

Whats really impressive is that no matter what country they infiltrate, they speak the native language flawlessly  that would be English of course, with a dusting of a Latin or Balkan accent. Impossible indeed.

title: Whats Going On? Everything Soul Is New Again
description: SOUL music has been making quite a comeback of late. Stax Records, once home to the gritty sounds of Otis Redding and Booker T. & the MGs, was revived last year, with Isaac Hayes, the best-selling artist in the labels history, again on its roster. Motown, Staxs slick Northern contemporary, is evoked in the movie Dreamgirls, an adaptation of the thinly veiled musical about its most famous female singing group, the Supremes.

title: Young Buyers, Prepared and Fearless
description: DANIEL AND LUCIANA HYMAN are quick to admit that they are insufferably sentimental about how they fell in love. Seated on the half-finished floor of their Midtown co-op, they relate every detail about how they met at a nightclub in Rio de Janiero, how he asked her to move to Manhattan in the sculpture garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and how he proposed on a trip to Paris at the Eiffel Tower  well before Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes became engaged at the same spot.

title: The Price of Citizenship

Its not an appealing image, but thats where we are, now that Citizenship and Immigration Services, the beleaguered federal bureaucracy that makes new Americans, has announced plans to increase fees sharply to cover its costs.

title: A Billion-Dollar Election Warning
description: Once upon a time, Washington managed to fully confront a corruption scandal and invent a government solution that actually worked for 30 years. The scandal was Watergate. The solution was the innovative option of providing public financing to presidential campaigns as a means of curbing the influence of big money donors like those who ran amok in President Richard Nixons 1972 re-election.

title: Youve Seen the E-Mail, Now Buy the Art

He set a giant Excedrin box, made from dozens of cut-up Excedrin boxes, on the floor near the entrance. He placed three identically crumpled wads of paper on a shelf. And he affixed to the ceiling a bunch of colorful papier-mch balloons, which magically appeared to float despite their weight. Their strings were held together not by a hand but by a pair of mens briefs suspended in midair.

title: Whatever Happened to Now?

What cabal was put in place to decide that the most interesting way to make culture relevant  or the fashionable part of it at least  would be to constantly dredge up the recycled past or, even sadder, the future. By this I am referring not to the actual fact of tomorrow (assuming it is a fact). I mean that dust-covered, capital-F version retailed by prognosticating fantasists since Jules Verne.

title: The Peace Paradox
description: Historical analogies have always been popular in foreign-policy debates, and the present day is no exception. For liberals, the best description of our current situation is Vietnam II (as Maureen Dowd dubbed it in a Times column): another ghastly quagmire from which we can do little but walk away. Nonsense, reply conservatives. Its really World War IV (the words of Norman Podhoretz, who counts the cold war as III): another deadly struggle against totalitarianism for which we must mobilize every possible resource. As for the Harvard historian Niall Ferguson, writing in Vanity Fair, the best analogy is what could be called Rome II. We are another colossal empire, perched on the brink of decline and fall.
