title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: SINS OF THE INNOCENT: A Memoir. By Mireille Marokvia. (Unbridled, $24.95.) Marokvia is no Sophie Scholl, the Munich student who was beheaded in 1943 for distributing antigovernment fliers, though they seemed to feel the same way about Hitler. The French-born Marokvia was married to an ambitious German artist  handsome, built like a ballet dancer, chic in pants on which he wiped his paintbrushes. When she presents her best pome en prose, he admonishes her, Write a sonnet! He works as a government-sponsored artist-reporter, painting mines, barracks and soldiers, and she lives quietly in a mill near the Swiss-German border. Her memoir describes what its like to hate the Nazis  as she and her husband did  but to protest unheroically: making a snide comment when a building super rants against unpatriotic people; not finding humor in a party members joke; walking out of a movie in which a Jewish prime minister is executed (the audience burst into applause). In December 1941, Marokvia, the author of a previous memoir called Immortelles, studies weaving in an art school as the Jews of Stuttgart board buses and are put on a train that never arrived anywhere, in the words of a local lawyer. She may have lacked moral courage, but she has literary talent, conveying the everyday horror of Nazi Germany. Eventually, a police chief accuses her of being a spy and tracks her movements  until a Berlin acquaintance intervenes. Why didnt you kill Hitler? her husbands Parisian friends ask after the war. In this book, we can all discover the reason.

title: Descartes
description: "The fumes which rise from the bottom of a swamp produce frogs, ants, leeches, and vegetation ... Cut a groove into a brick, fill it with crushed basil, and put another brick on top to seal the groove. Within a few days the vegetable matter will have turned into scorpions." So claimed a seventeenth-century savant called Jean-Baptiste Van Helmont. But although Van Helmont lived in the seventeenth century, he belonged far more to its past than its future, for he was one of those whose understanding of the world relied on ideas developed centuries before his own time. The ideas in question belonged to an intellectual tradition that encouraged belief in miracles, spontaneous generation, and phoenixes rising from ashes. In this tradition it was an unquestionable fact that the sun and stars go round a stationary earth, with God's heaven above and hell-fire at the earth's centre. Yet even as Van Helmont premised these notions in his writings, a new world of ideas was coming into existence around him. One of the chief of those bringing about this change was Ren Descartes.

It was a somber gathering: a dozen neighbors seated around the heavy mahogany dining-room table no one had used for over a decade. Now there were pans of macaroni and cheese and a red velvet cake and a huge platter of fruit, food enough to last a month if Arlie had had an appetite.

title: In Spite of the Gods
description: It took a long time. But finally in the late 1990s India started to build roads that could get you from A to B at something better than a canter. Until then, India's most significant highway was the Grand Trunk Road that bisects the country from north to south. Laid at various stages by the late medieval Mughal dynasty, then upgraded and extended by the British in the nineteenth century and popularized by Rudyard Kipling in his novel Kim, most of the "GT Road," as it is known, got acquainted with asphalt only after independence. But it is a single lane and one can rarely exceed an average of thirty miles an hour. So the relative novelty of India's double-lane expressways still generates a buzz. By 2006, India had all but completed the 3,000-mile "Golden Quadrilateral" expressway linking the country's four largest cities: Delhi to Mumbai (formerly known as Bombay) to Chennai (formerly known as Madras) to Kolkata (formerly known as Calcutta) to Delhi. Average speeds on the better stretches are closer to sixty miles an hour.

title: The Utility of Force
description: Our understanding of military forces, military operations and wars stems from the nineteenth century, when the paradigm of interstate industrial war was forged. The Napoleonic Wars were its starting point, and it evolved throughout the century as its two crucial elements came into being and matured: states and industry. The American Civil War, the German wars of unification, and finally the two world wars of the twentieth century all contributed, amongst other events, to the military development of the paradigm, each in its way. I am not a professional historian, but I am a student of history, and have often used writings of and about the past not just to learn and understand how issues were handled in times past but also to test my own ideas about how to handle the matters I faced when in command and in the field. The study of history will tell you why you and your adversary are where you are now: it will establish in broad political terms the context in which both of you will take the decisions that lead you into the future. This study begins with establishing the chronology of events so as to understand the "march of time" and to recognize cause and effect. Once one understands these facts one can begin to comprehend the decisions taken by the various actors, not necessarily to judge them but to understand why they were taken, in those circumstances and at that time. This is how one can begin to understand the story, "His Story." that each of us individually and in our social groups carries in our head as the context for the decisions we take in the present.

title: Skylark Farm
description: Uncle Sempad is only a legend, for us-but a legend that has made us all cry. My great-grandfather then remarried an "evil stepmother," who bore him many other children; my grandfather couldn't stand her, and so, at the age of thirteen, he requested and was granted permission to leave the little city and go to Venice, to study at Moorat-Raphael, the boarding school for Armenian children.

Bailey was the son she lived with, her only boy. He was sitting on the edge of his chair at the table, bent over the orange sports section of the Journal. "Now look here, Bailey," she said, "see here, read this," and she stood with one hand on her thin hip and the other rattling the newspaper at his bald head. "Here this fellow that calls himself The Misfit is aloose from the Federal Pen and headed toward Florida and you read here what it says he did to these people. Just you read it. I wouldn't take my children in any direction with a criminal like that aloose in it. I couldn't answer to my conscience if I did."

That squawk, an anarchic battle cry that evokes a warped yodel and is sounded over martial equestrian drum rolls, was heard again on Saturday evening at Radio City Music Hall, where Mr. Morricone conducted 200 musicians performing excerpts from his film scores. Although he has written music for 400 movies, the musicians had prepared so little material that the last fourth of the two-hour event billed as Morricone in Concert was devoted to reprises of highlights from the previous 90 minutes.

The campaign began in London in December and will also reach Italy and Spain. Returning from a trip to Israel, the mayor met in London yesterday with Sir Callum McCarthy, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, which regulates the banking, securities and insurance industries in Britain, before flying to County Mayo, in northwest Ireland.

Songs From Here Lies Love  offered 20 selections from his forthcoming multimedia production about Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines and an enduring symbol of despotic extravagance and shoe love. At best, the work, which regrettably fails to show Robbins at his most masterly, falls under the category of an interesting misstep.

description: Firing another round in the high-stakes battle to acquire Equity Office Properties, Vornado Realty Trust offered last night to modify its $41 billion bid for the company, the nations largest owner of office buildings, by paying the cash portion of its offer within a few weeks.

title: The Other Frank Zappa, Chamber Music Composer
description: Frank Zappa was a kind of Rev. Howard Finster of music: an outsider artist eventually discovered and embraced by the establishment without ever losing his outsider cachet. A brilliant self-taught musician, Zappa needed to justify what he did as serious music at a time when rock was not seen as serious, and he produced a string of classical pieces that were taken up by European luminaries like Pierre Boulez and the Ensemble Modern.

title: Iraqis Fault Pace of U.S. Plan in Attack
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 4  A growing number of Iraqis blamed the United States on Sunday for creating conditions that led to the worst single suicide bombing in the war, which devastated a Shiite market in Baghdad the day before. They argued that the Americans had been slow in completing the vaunted new American security plan, making Shiite neighborhoods much more vulnerable to such horrific attacks.

title: Child Safety Seats: A Compelling Need Now (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Shiites Fear Gains Could Be Lost
description: QATIF, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 30  As young men beat their chests in street processions marking the Shiite Muslim holiday of Ashura in this Shiite stronghold in eastern Saudi Arabia, Ibrahim al-Mugaiteeb looked on nervously, bracing for the regions political conflicts to close in on this downtrodden community.

title: Moving Toward Greater Drug Safety
description: The Food and Drug Administration is making encouraging moves to strengthen its regulation of drugs that are already on the market. But the changes fall far short of whats needed to protect millions of unsuspecting patients whose adverse effects may show up only after years of use.

title: Jules Olitski, 84, American Abstract Painter, Dies
description: Jules Olitski, a painter and sculptor who became a widely admired and controversial member of the second generation of American abstract artists, died yesterday in New York. He was 84 and lived in Islamorada, Fla., and Meredith, N.H.

title: A Bad Santa and Other Inscrutttable Bits
description: To paraphrase a line from a well-known nursery rhyme, when D D Dorvilliers new work is good it is very, very good, but when it is bad, it is horrid. Nottthing Is Importanttt (above all, spelling, it seems) is subtitled a suite of three conditions, but as in most of Ms. Dorvilliers work, what this means remains a mystery.

title: Palestinians Say Clashes Hurt Their Cause
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 4  The fierce internal clashes between Palestinian factions have shocked many Palestinians and Arab governments, who fear that the continuing bloodshed is damaging the Palestinian image before the world, Palestinians say.

title: No Calm, Just Storm in Spitzers First Month
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has certainly had an eventful first month in office.

title: Yellowstone Proposal Sets Greater Snowmobile Access
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.  The latest installment in the long-running debate over the use of snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park is a proposal to allow as many as 720 to enter each day, nearly three times as many as permitted in the last several years.

title: Jakarta Remains Partly Submerged After Flood
description: JAKARTA, Tuesday, Feb. 6  Much of this capital city was under water Tuesday after torrential rains, overflowing rivers and clogged sewers brought widespread flooding over the weekend. Authorities warned of the possible spread of illness through the contaminated water.

title: Jimmy Choo Sold for $364 Million
description: TowerBrook Capital Partners has agreed to buy Jimmy Choo Ltd., whose shoes are worn by celebrities including Jennifer Lopez, for 185 million ($364 million).

title: Making Schools Work for Our Kids (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Koons Plans Dangling Engine (Smokin!)
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4  It was like pulling a rabbit from a hat. Only the rabbit was a train. And the hat was an event at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art last week billed as a conversation between its director, Michael Govan, and the artist Jeff Koons.

title: News Quiz: Trials and Tribulations
description: UPDATE: Due to technical difficulties, our news quiz did not reach many of our readers. We will therefore be running it for another day.

title: Who Was Most Valuable? (Was  It Prince?)
description: Who deserved to be named the most valuable performer in last nights Super Bowl?

title: The Political is Personal
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: An American in London
description: In the world's most expensive city, Siri Eklund found an affordable apartment in an ideal neighborhood.

title: Homes Under $150,000
description: Two-bedroom condos in Orlando, Fla., and Angel Fire, N.M., and a house in Washburn, Wis.

title: Thom Browne
description: Photos from Thom Browne's fall show.

title: Redrawing the Lines in I.P.O. Suits
description: Underwriters facing lawsuits over tech-boom stock offerings recently won an important legal victory, while the plaintiffs lawyers face a much tougher playing field for securities litigation, according to TheDeal.com.

title: New Suitor Ignites Battle for Ailing Mills Corporation
description: Another major battle has surfaced in the commercial real estate market, this time over the ailing mall developer Mills Corporation. Confirming a report in The New York Times, the Simon Property Group, the nations largest mall developer, and Farallon Capital Management, a $26 billion hedge fund, on Monday announced a $1.56 billion cash bid for Mills, challenging its already agreed-upon deal to be sold for $1.4 billion to Brookfield Capital Management.

title: Vornado Adjusts Its Bid for an Office Landlord
description: Firing another round in the high-stakes battle to acquire Equity Office Properties, Vornado Realty Trust offered last night to modify its $41 billion bid for the company, the nations largest owner of office buildings, by paying the cash portion of its offer within a few weeks.

title: A Medical ID Business, Much Criticized, Plans a Stock Offering
description: Applied Digital Solutions has made headlines in recent years and appalled privacy advocates with its technology to implant radio chips into humans.

title: Author, Facing Court Date, Must Limit His Book Tour
description: A court date is not the only thing marked on the spring calendar of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International. At the same time that he is scheduled to be in court facing charges of criminal fraud and money laundering in Chicago, Mr. Black will also be promoting his new biography of Richard M. Nixon, The Invincible Quest: The Life of Richard Milhous Nixon, to be published in May.

title: The Netherlands, the New Tax Shelter Hot Spot
description: If your tax haven sports warm weather, tropical fish, off-the-shelf holding companies sporting post-office-box addresses, you may be behind the times.

title: 2nd Acts in the Executive Suite
description: When James R. Houghton began a second stint as chief executive at Corning in 2002, the company was reeling. The first thing he did, Mr. Houghton told The New York Times, was to see if there was somebody I should shoot. Now Michael S. Dell will be taking aim. This week he reclaimed the chief executive job that he had handed over to Kevin B. Rollins two years ago, resuming day-to-day leadership of the computer company he founded.

title: Ex-Secretary at Coke Guilty of Trade-Secrets Theft
description: A federal jury rejected a former Coca-Cola secretarys claim that she was duped by two accomplices and convicted her on Friday of conspiring to steal trade secrets from the worlds largest beverage maker in an effort to sell them to its rival, Pepsi. The former secretary, Joya Williams, showed no visible reaction when the verdict was announced. She remains free on bond, pending sentencing.

title: YouTube, Viacom and Some Unfriendly Dealmaking
description: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded on Friday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.

title: Australias Multiplex Elicits Interest from Consortium
description: Canadas Brookfield Asset Management and the founders of Australias Multiplex have approached the $3 billion construction firm about a possible takeover as it struggles with the troubled Wembley stadium project in London. No value for any bid was given, but analysts told Reuters that around 5 Australian dollars a share might be the most offered for Multiplex, which has a market capitalization of 4.04 billion Australian dollars ($3 billion). Shares in Multiplex rose 8 percent to 4.91 Australian dollars on news of the talks.

title: Redstone Said to Have Settled With Son
description: Sumner Redstone, chairman of the CBS Corporation and Viacom, settled a lawsuit with his son, according to The Wall Street Journal. The lawsuit, filed last year in the Circuit Court of Maryland for Baltimore, claimed that Mr. Redstone had tried to freeze out his son, Brent Redstone, from National Amusements, the family firm that holds a controlling stake in Viacom and CBS.

title: Hyundai Head Found Guilty by South Korean Court
description: A South Korean court on Monday found the head of the Hyundai Motor Group, the worlds No.6 auto maker, guilty of breach of trust and embezzling company funds. The countrys prosecutors last month demanded a six-year jail term for the executive, Chung Mong-koo, who was the groups chairman.

title: At Goldman, a Push for Middle-Market Deals
description: As the merger and acquisition boom rages on, Goldman Sachs, top banker to blue-chip companies, is eyeing middle-market deals as a way to further increase its banking fees, which hit record levels last year. In this case, says Reuters, middle market means companies ranging from $500 million to $2 billion in market value.

title: Corruption Charges Follow Siemens to the U.S.
description: A corruption affair that has shaken the German industrial conglomerate Siemens has spread to the United States with investigations by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The U.S. Department of Justice is conducting an investigation of possible criminal violations of U.S. law by Siemens in connection with these matters, Siemens said in its first-quarter financial report. The company is being investigated by German prosecutors for suspected bribery related to telecoms contracts.

title: Endesa Board Likely to Accept E.ON Offer, Report Says
description: The board of Endesa will meet Tuesday to consider its response to a 41 billion euro ($53 billion) bid by E.ON of Germany in what should mark the final stage of the battle for control of Endesa, Spains largest electricity group. The Financial Times reported that directors are likely to recommend the 38.75-euro-a-share offer, which is 41 percent higher than the original bid presented by E.ON almost a year ago

title: Texas Pacific May Also Like the Looks of Europes Biggest L.B.O.
description: The private equity firm Texas Pacific Group may try to elbow in on a possible deal for the British supermarket giant J. Sainsbury and is working on building a consortium, the Financial Times reported. The rival buyout shops CVC, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone said on Friday they were in the early stages of assessing a bid for Sainsbury, Britains third-largest supermarket owner, in what would be Europes biggest leveraged buyout.

title: Overstock Takes Banks to Court Over Short Selling
description: Overstock.com, whose chief executive has been roundly criticized for his crusade against naked short selling and what he claims is a vast conspiracy to bring down the stock of his company, filed a $3.5 billion lawsuit in California state court Friday accusing 10 of the largest securities firms in the nation of participating in a massive, illegal stock market manipulation scheme to distort the retailers stock.

title: Apollo May Buy British Real Estate Firm, Reports Say
description: British estate agency firm Countrywide is in talks to be acquired by the Apollo Management buyout group of the United States, according to press reports. The Sunday Times reported that Apollo was planning a bid for Countrywide worth about 950 million pounds ($1.9 billion), and Reuters said the targeted firm was likely to put out a statement confirming the discussions on Monday.

title: Paul Allen Takes Back Rose Garden
description: Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder and Seattle-area billionaire, has agreed to buy back the Rose Garden Arena in Portland that he previously owned. Mr. Allen is making the acquisition through his investment vehicle, Vulcan. As part of the agreement, a subsidiary of Vulcan plans to purchase Portland Arena Management, which has held the notes to the Rose Garden since Mr. Allen put the facility into bankruptcy about three years ago.

title: Jimmy Choo Sold for $364 Million
description: TowerBrook Capital Partners has agreed to buy Jimmy Choo, whose shoes are worn by celebrities including Jennifer Lopez, for 185 million pounds ($364 million). TowerBrook, the buyout firm spun off from George Soross fund management business, and Jimmy Choos management, including its founder, Tamara Mellon, and chief executive, Robert Bensoussan, will buy the company from Lion Capital.

title: Bloomberg Takes His Message to London
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took his message that New York City is losing its edge as a global financial center to London on Sunday, where he contrasted the British system of regulating financial markets with that of the United States. The mayor met with Sir Callum McCarthy, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, which regulates the banking, securities, insurance and investment industries in Britain.

title: British Homebuilder Buys Developer in Record Deal
description: Barratt Developments, the largest homebuilder in Britain, agreed to buy Wilson Bowden for 2.2 billion pounds ($4.32 billion) in what Bloomberg News said is the biggest-ever takeover of a British housing developer. Barratt, based in Tyne, said it would will pay 2,257 pence in cash and stock for each Wilson share. Thats 23 percent higher than Wilsons close on Nov. 24, the last day of trading before the company put itself up for sale.

title: Merrill Hires Former Citigroup Exec for China
description: Merrill Lynch hired Margaret Ren, a former Citigroup executive, as chairman of China investment banking after regulators in the United States cleared her of wrongdoing in a 2003 initial public offering. Ms. Ren, the daughter-in-law of former Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang, will report to the China region chairman, Liu Erh-fei and the Asia banking head, Sheldon Trainor.

title: Outcome of Techem Deal May Disappoint Hedge Funds
description: Hedge funds will not see a richer payday after two financial investors for Techem, a German utility metering group, abandoned their 1.4 billion euro ($1.8 billion) bid on Friday. The bidders, the Macquarie Bank of Australia and the private equity shop BC Partners of Boston, retreated after they failed to win commitments for 70.5 percent of Techems stock. The announcement comes after weeks of press reports that hedge funds, including Elliott Associates of New York, which reportedly now owns 10 percent of the group, had snapped up Techem shares, hoping for a higher bid.

title: State Street Takes Investors Financial for $4.5 Billion
description: State Street agreed to buy Investors Financial Services in a stock transaction valued at about $4.5 billion. Investors Financial holders will receive 0.906 share of State Street for each of their shares, State Street said.

title: Private Equity Firms to Buy Triad Hospitals
description: Triad Hospitals, which runs 54 hospitals and 13 ambulatory surgery centers across the United States, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, CCMP Capital Advisors, and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs. Triad, spun off from the hospital chain HCA in 1999, valued the deal at $6.4 billion, including $1.7 billion in assumed debt. Some analysts have considered Triad a potential buyout candidate since HCA agreed to go private in a $33 billion transaction last year.

title: Even More Hope for Kun Sokkea
description: On Friday, ABC news aired a very nice story on the Overlake School in Pailin, Cambodia, and the Overlake School in Redmond, Washington, that Nick wrote about in December. They spent time with Kun Sokkea, who was profiled by Nick in this video. Shes become quite the video star.

title: Venture Funds Think Big
description: Last years $2-billion-plus funds from Oak Investment Partners and New Enterprise Associates underscore how venture firms have been raising larger investment pools and targeting more established companies, BusinessWeek reports.

title: A Predators Ball for a New Age
description: Todays wave of buyouts reminds many of the 1980s, the last great age of highflying takeovers. But a small investment banks parties may be drawing a different page from the Predators Ball era. The New York Post highlights Roth Capital Management, a small-cap underwriter whose pricey bashes have included rappers like Ludacris and exotic entertainment like topless models painted with the ticker symbols of Roth Capitals clients. In an age in which Wall Street firms still host big-ticket celebrations but have shunned anything that smacks of a potential lawsuit, the Post says, Roth is the exception to the rule.

title: Cats in a Bag
description: Ever wonder where those pesky Oscar bloggers go over the weekend while you get on with your life? Tom ONeil found some of their footprints, and it aint a pretty picture. Turns out Oscar Ninnies spend time backchannel squabbling over, gee, the Oscars.

title: Playing to Type
description: Speaking of casting, Arianna Huffington suggests that Hollywood will likely dump Hilary Clinton like a box of rocks and put their arms around Barack Obama. She says it comes down to casting:

title: Budget Battles Loom on Iraq, Taxes
description: Washington knows not to party too hard on Super Bowl Sunday. The following Monday is budget day. That means today the White House will release its 2008 proposal for a $2.9 trillion budget. USA Todays Richard Wolf writes that the release comes amid a charm offensive intended to woo Democrats, which included President Bushs visit to the House Democrats retreat over the weekend.

title: A Broken Clock Finally Starts Ticking
description: At a time when a United States Senator, one who thinks he should be president no less, acts surprised that a fellow senator and candidate, who happens to be black, is familiar with the rudiments of language and hygiene, it would be tough to suggest that we are living in enlightened age. Still, Newsweek asks the question, Color Blind at Last? in a story about the number of black nominees  five  in the Oscar race for actors this year.

title: Los Nios de Goya
description: Guillermo del Toro, the director of the exquisite Pans Labyrinth, is a habitual sketcher and his drawings serve as a portal into the mystical realm of Pans. The Bagger resents people who are good at more than one thing  Mr. del Toro is probably also a good cook and the Bagger bets he can play Satisfaction on the guitar  but when the boss goes on one of those interminable lunches to God knows where, spend some time at this section of the films Web site.

title: War at Home: The Senates Battleground
description: Obstructionism in the Senate is obviously in the eye of the beholder.

title: Right Between the Uprights
description: Like a lot of Americans, the Bagger was ready for some football last night. He put a buck twenty on the Colts to cover  the only good bet hes made all season  ordered up a bucket of chicken and kicked back. The only problem is this Oscar blog needed feeding, so he spent time searching for the ever-elusive Oscar hook. He came up with, well, not much.

title: New Off Broadway Discounts
description: The Off-Broadway Brainstormers, a group of theater professionals who have been meeting for the last year, have announced that from March 4 to 11, any tickets remaining 20 minutes before curtain time at 27 participating Off Broadway shows will be available for $20.

title: Lingua Franca
description: Theres been some backchannel developments re: Babel and its inclusion in the best dramatic picture category of the Globes. Stay tuned, or better yet, if you have some first-hand knowledge of how the decision was made to place Babel what is an English language category of the awards, e-mail the Bagger (carpetbagger@nytimes.com).

title: Bird Flu Fight: 160,000 Turkeys Gassed and Burned in Britain
description: Yes, its the A(H5N1) strain. Thats what British authorities confirmed over the weekend, in determining just what sort of bird flu had infected thousands of turkeys in the eastern town of Lowestoft.

title: Rios Divided Beaches
description: In Brazil, some bodies  and some beaches  are more equal than others.

title: Of Free Trade and South Koreas Beef With U.S. Beef
description: Moving from bird flu to mad cow disease, United States trade officials will be meeting with their South Korean counterparts this week to try to sort out what continues to be a de facto ban on U.S. beef imports to that country.

title: Women, Politics and the Idiot Box
Steam Pipes and Sequins
description: Early this morning, the wind blowing up my little Alice & Olivia tunic, I hurried on to The Times. This is my favorite hour, bar none, the hour of the vacant street, the steaming manhole cover and the good intention before it goes haywire.

title: A Critical Season
description: People often ask me how designers react to a bad review. The classiest example is Giorgio Armani. One day, maybe four or five years ago, when he was venting about all the coverage that Miuccia Prada and Tom Ford were getting, I asked Armani through an interpreter if his resentment toward those other designers didnt qualify as sour grapes, since he had been king of the road in 80s and early 90s.

title: New York Collections
description: Benjamin Cho, Diane Von Furstenberg, Oscar de la Renta, Phillip Lim, Tracey Reese and Tuleh runway photos.

title: How Clinton is Shielded by the Web
description: The first post-YouTube candidate: Joshua Green, a senior editor for The Atlantic who profiled Hillary Clinton in November, argues in The New Republic that online video will help Senator Clinton surmount her awkward public-speaking style during the 2008 presidential campaign. Green writes:

title: Londons Pickle Sold as Real Estate Heats Up
description: One of Londons most recognizable skyscrapers was sold Monday for 600 million pounds ($1.18 billion) in a deal that could kick off a wave of high-priced British commercial real estate sales. Swiss Reinsurance said that it would sell its London headquarters, the 40-story glass skyscraper nicknamed The Gherkin, to the real estate comapny IVG Immobilien and the investment bank Evans Randall. The deal, which is expected to close in February, may set a record for a London office building, the Telegraph said.

title: Brookfield to Acquire Paper Maker for $2.15 Billion
description: Brookfield Asset Management will acquire Longview Fibre, a paper and container maker, for $2.15 billion including debt. The Canadian real-estate firm will pay $24.75 a share, or an 18 percent premium to Longviews closing price Friday. Through the deal, Brookfield will gain 588,000 acres of timberland in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Revolving Door: Credit Suisse, C.E. Unterberg
description: Credit Suisse said Monday that it hired Michael D. Ryan, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs, as head of securities for its investment banking division. Mr. Ryan will join Credit Suisses New York office some time midyear, Credit Suisse said. He will oversee Credit Suisses global securities businesses and serve on the management committee of its investment banking group. At Goldman Sachs, Mr. Ryan had been co-head of global equities.

title: Any Fresher, and It Might Be Banned in Boston
description: A campaign for a seafood restaurateur is giving a new twist to the old saying on Madison Avenue that advertisers ought to fish where the fish are.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Agency.com, part of the Omnicom Group, opened an office in Rome. It is the second office in Italy, coming after the opening of an office in Milan last August. Franco Ricchiuti, who oversees the Milan office, will also oversee the new Rome office.

title: War at Home: McCains Resolution
description: Senator John McCains office just released the language of the resolution he is introducing that supports President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq, and also sets 11 benchmarks for the Iraqi government to meet. In a statement, Mr. McCain said that his resolution, unlike others in circulation (including Republican Senator John Warners compromise proposal), avoids sending an inappropriate message to our troops.

title: 2008: Iraq and All Over the Map
description: Iraq is the top concern for voters in Iowa and New Hampshire, according to the Los Angeles Times. Among the Democrats, the more anti-war, the better. Republicans, on the other hand, need to be a bit more nuanced.

title: Online Smut: More Young People Getting an Eyeful
description: It will probably come as no surprise to most Internet users that a new survey, published in the February issue of the journal Pediatrics (an abstract is available here), found that nearly half of all young people reported exposure, intentional or otherwise, to online pornography.

title: Music-Label Merger Losing Its Allure, Analyst Says
description: Sales of music  both compact discs and downloads  are off to a weak start this year. So weak that Richard Greenfield, a media analyst at Pali Research, said Monday that total 2007 sales are likely to be even worse than he had previously expected (and he had expected them to be pretty bad). With such gloomy thoughts in mind, Mr. Greenfield cut his rating on shares of the Warner Music Group, the label whose artists include the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Madonna, to sell. He also suggested that a merger between Warner, which is backed by private investors including Edgar Bronfman Jr., and EMI of the United Kingdom looks increasingly unlikely.

title: Eliot Breaking the China
description: In todays Empire Zone column, Eliot Spitzer acknowledges to Danny Hakim that hes breaking some china and not whispering, and holds out hope that fights over single issues wont poison the move for reform in Albany.

title: Schumer and Clinton on War and the Budget
description: Capping the numbers of troops in Iraq, yes. But capping funds for the war?

title: Ads Turn Violent
description: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this years Super Bowl commercials.

title: DKNY Fall Collection
description: Donna Karan presents her DKNY fall 2007 line.

title: We Just Cant Afford This
description: Still in shock over the price tag for the vacant lot my wife had fallen in love with, I let her lead me around to take a look at the other places for sale on the island, as the real estate agent had suggested.

title: Hillary, Chuck and the War
description: New Yorks two senators, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer, were sharply critical of President Bushs new budget plan for Iraq war spending at a news conference in Manhattan this morning. Senator Clinton said she would continue pushing for some kind of strictures on the administrations war plan. And Senator Schumer calked about a capping of funds and capping of troops as options for the Democratic Congress.

title: Caucus Chatter
description: On the politically playful side of things, a few pieces drew our amused attention, as a diversion from the heavy-laden news of the day. (At least we smiled, however briefly.)

title: Bloomberg Takes On His Neighbor
description: Mayor Bloomberg has often been criticized for not being aggressive enough in battling for the citys share of funding from Albany and Washington, but today he came out swinging against the budget of his Upper East Side neighbor, Eliot Spitzer.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Aim for $6 Billion Buyout Fund
description: As part of its return to the buyout business, Morgan Stanley plans to raise $6 billion or more for its latest private equity fund, Financial News Online reported, citing undisclosed sources close to the bank. In September, the firm announced that it was creating a private equity group within its asset management division, but Morgan Stanley has stayed fairly quiet on the effort since then. Three years ago, Morgan Stanley spun off its private equity business as Metalmark Capital.

title: Oscar Talk
description: During his LA trip, the Bagger had a conversation with Sid Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Check it out here and find out whether or not the Academy does an Oscar pool.

title: A Day Without Solitaire in Albany
description: After testifying before a joint legislative hearing in Albany on the state budget this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was scheduled to pay a visit to New York Citys Office of State Legislative Affairs.

title: The Good and the Bad
description: Ive been reading everyones posts and am totally gratified, amused, touched, and wondering what I can do to stump yall. To Amor in Shanghai (#7), I agree that the Dior Homme collection was pretty good and very wearable; I just wanted a little more news and direction. That doesnt happen every season, of course.

title: Advertising at the Speed of Private Equity
description: It seems everyone wants a piece of the buyout boom. As private equity firms continue to spend billions of dollars to acquire public companies, M&C Saatchi, the advertising group, is creating an agency to serve the businesses they buy. Why would private-equity-backed companies advertise any differently than anyone else? The theory, according to Reuters article on the new firm, goes like this: To maximize their profits, buyout shops need to turn around their investments quickly. So they need to act faster to burnish their brands.

title: Giuliani Moves a Step Closer to Running
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani moved one step closer to running for president by filing a statement of candidacy today with the Federal Election Commission, declaring that he would seek the Republican nomination if he runs, according to two officials in the Giuliani campaign.

title: Rudy Wades Farther In
description: In another step toward running 2008, Rudolph W. Giuliani is filing a federal statement of candidacy and dropping the phrase testing the waters from his application to raise money for his presidential exploratory committee, Patrick Healy reports at The Caucus.

title: Icahn Offers to Buy Auto-Parts Maker Lear
description: After placing a big bet on the beaten-down auto-parts business in October, Carl C. Icahn is doubling down. Mr. Icahn, who recently spent $200 million to increase his stake in Lear  to nearly 16 percent, has offered to acquire the entire company, Lear said in a news release early Monday. American Real Estate Partners, which Mr. Icahn controls, will offer $36 a share in cash for Lear, valuing the auto-parts maker at about $2.4 billion based on the number of shares outstanding on Nov. 3. The offer was about 4 percent more than Lears closing price of $34.67 on Friday.

title: Nader for Bloomberg in 08?
description: In the with friends like these department, Ralph Nader claims inside information about a possible Bloomberg run, and suggests hes intrigued by the idea of the ultimate corporatist running for national office. He made the remarks in his recent interview with Wolf Blitzer:

title: Gorbachev to Bill Gates: Show Mercy for Accused Pirate
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, has issued a plea to Bill Gates of Microsoft on behalf of a Russian school principal being prosecuted in Russia after being accused of using unlicensed versions of the Windows operating system on computers in his school. The message took the form of an open letter  available here in Russian  posted to the Web site of the Gorbachev Foundation, a social and political think tank in Russia.

title: The Season Distilled
description: If you had to know one thing, and one thing only, about this N.F.L. season

title: Diaz to Bloomberg: I Loved You
description: It is rare for emotions like love to be paraded about in the hallowed halls of Albany, but that is exactly what happened at an otherwise subdued hearing on the state budget, where Mayor Bloomberg testified.

title: Thanks, Mayor, but No Thanks
description: An amusing exchange occurred at a joint legislative budget hearing this morning in Albany. State Senator Liz Krueger, a Manhattan Democrat, had asked the mayor for his views on Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposal to expand the bottle bill, which encourages recycling.

title: Immigrant Entrepreneurs
description: In New York City, more immigrant entrepreneurs are starting businesses each year than natives. A tour of one bustling ethnic enclave.

title: Overstock Losses Grow
description: There is a rhythm to Overstock.com. Every three months the Internet retailer produces dismal financial results, and Patrick Byrne, the chairman and chief executive, abjectly apologizes and promises things will get better.

title: A Robust G.O.P. Blocks Senate War Debate
description: On the Senate floor just a short while ago, a pretty hot debate ensued before any real debate on Iraq resolutions was allowed, or actually not allowed by the vote following the debate about the proposed debate. The Senate went 49-47, the Democrats well shy of the 60 votes needed to move ahead on one of the war resolutions.

title: Hobbitville
description: As much as I wanted to like , I wanted more to tell the fellows from Brooks Brothers, Good luck! Browne, you may recall, signed a deal last year with Brooks to design a special line of mens and womens clothes. The collection he presented today, in a make-believe wood veiled in mist, was for his own label.

title: New York Fashion Week: The Scene
description: Fashion designers unveil their fall collections inside the tents at Bryant Park.

title: Climate Report Predicts Rising Seas
description: Science reporter Andy Revkin examines the long-term social consequences of  rising temperatures and seas around the globe.

title: More on Boycotting the Chinese Olympics
description: Theres a flourishing debate that has been carried on in the comment section of this blog, and in loftier settings, about whether to boycott the 2008 Beijing Olympics unless China stops underwriting genocide in Darfur.

title: What Did Dick Cheney Know and When Did He Know It?
description: If you want to comment on Tuesdays column on Dick Cheney, and his need to come clean, you can do so here. Just hit the comment button.

title: Girl or Boy? As Fertility Technology Advances, So Does an Ethical Debate
description: Some parents would love the chance to choose their babys sex before pregnancy, while others wouldnt dream of meddling with nature. The medical world is also divided over the issue.

title: Melding Science and Diplomacy to Run a Global Climate Review
description: More than a few scientists think that Susan Solomon must be a glutton for punishment.

title: Immigrant Entrepreneurs Shape a New Economy
description: Manuel A. Miranda was 8 when his family immigrated to New York from Bogot. His parents, who had been lawyers, turned to selling home-cooked food from the trunk of their car. Manuel pitched in after school, grinding corn by hand for traditional Colombian flatbreads called arepas.

title: Missouri: New Charges in Kidnappings
description: Michael Devlin, who is accused of kidnapping two boys and holding one of them for years, has been charged with two additional counts of kidnapping and 69 counts of forcible sodomy, officials said. The charges are the first in which Mr. Devlin, 41, has been accused of molesting the boys. Devlin acknowledged committing these acts, said Robert P. McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecuting attorney. Mr. Devlin had already been charged with kidnapping one of the boys, William Ownby, 13, who is known as Ben, from his home on Jan. 8, and with kidnapping the other, Shawn Hornbeck, 15, at gunpoint from his home in 2002, when he was 11.

title: George Becker, Who Led Steelworkers Through Period of Growth, Dies at 78
description: George Becker, who at 15 literally followed his fathers footsteps into a steel mill in his Illinois hometown and rose to become the sixth president of the United Steelworkers union, died on Saturday at his home in Gibsonia, Pa. He was 78.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Chevron Will Split Chief and Chairman Jobs
description: The Chevron Corporation announced yesterday that it would separate the positions of chief executive and board chairman and make it easier for shareholders to remove directors.

title: Bloomberg Says Spitzers Proposed Budget Would Carve a Hole in City Finances
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg strongly criticized Gov. Eliot Spitzers budget proposal on Monday, arguing that a recommended cut of $327.9 million in annual state aid to New York City would produce an enormous hole in the municipal budget.

title: Actors Who See With More Than Their Eyes
description: A Midsummer Nights Dream, so dependent on sights misperceived and incongruous, makes a fascinating choice for Theater by the Blind, a company that blends actors who are blind and vision-impaired with those who have full sight. But perhaps the most delightful extra layer of meaning in the production at the Barrow Group Theater comes not from Shakespeares references to the eyes but from the presence of a wheelchair on the stage.

title: Detectives Killer Breaks Windows in Jail
description: A man who has been ordered to die for the murder of two police detectives shattered the windows of a jail visiting room with a chair over the weekend, a federal judge said yesterday. No one was hurt.

title: An Ancient Theory Inspires Two Sets of More Modern Sounds
description: My first contact with the title Music of the Spheres came at a traveling carnival in my youth at which a half-naked damsel with two tassels strategically attached rotated them in perfect harmony with the universe.

title: Bush Releases Budget Aimed to Erase Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  President Bush unveiled a $2.9 trillion budget on Monday that he said would wipe out the deficit in five years without raising taxes, setting up a clash with the Democratic-run Congress and charting a course for Republicans to continue his policies long after he leaves office.

title: Iranian Diplomat Kidnapped in Baghdad by Iraqis With Official ID
description: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, Feb. 6  An Iranian diplomat was abducted Sunday evening when his convoy was stopped by men with official Defense Ministry identification in the Karrada neighborhood here, senior Iraqi and American officials said Monday.

title: Leetch Deciding When to Call It a Career
description: Brian Leetch remembers sitting on his couch, watching his children play. He had no energy in his tired body to join them, and his mind would stray to hockey. He was home, resting with his family between games and practices, but not really there at all.

title: Nasdaq to Increase Fees to Listed Companies and Add Services
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market has won regulatory approval to increase fees and offer more services to the 3,200 companies listed on it.

title: Manhattan: Ground Zero Room to Close
description: A viewing room at the southern edge of ground zero where relatives of 9/11 victims have gathered privately and left mementos since 2002 will be closed on Feb. 27 for excavation and construction, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. It will be replaced. On March 5 a trailer closer to the north end of the World Trade Center site, off Church Street, will take its place. Personal items left in the viewing room will be moved to the trailer by family members. We will maintain this special space for as long as we possibly can, said the authoritys executive director, Anthony E. Shorris, in the hope that perhaps some of the families will take solace in the rejuvenation of the site going on around them.

title: In Rigorous Test, Talk Therapy Works for Panic Disorder
description: The field of psychoanalysis has struggled with a disabling internal conflict in recent years: whether to subject the therapy to rigorous testing, like the process through which new drugs are approved, or to insist that the insights it provides are self-evident and cannot be put under a microscope.

title: Shocking!
description: Q. Why is there a sound when a plane breaks the sound barrier?

title: Littered Skies
New DVDs: Cinema Classics
description: ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT

title: Manhattan: H.M.O. Representatives Unionize
description: District Council 37, the citys largest union of municipal workers, announced yesterday that it had unionized more than 300 sales representatives and assistants who work in the MetroPlus health maintenance organization of the citys Health and Hospitals Corporation. District Council 37, which is part of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, announced that 149 of the workers voted to join District Council 37, while 64 voted to join a competing union, the Organization of Staff Analysts. For nearly two years, Local 1549, which represents clerical and administrative employees, had sought to organize the workers, who handle enrollment applications for people who use the H.M.O. within the citys hospital system.

title: Ralph de Toledano, 90, Writer Known as a Nixon Friend, Dies
description: Ralph de Toledano, a news magazine editor, syndicated columnist and author of 25 books who was best known for his friendship with Richard M. Nixon and his passionate embrace of the conservative cause, died Saturday in Washington. He was 90.

title: Giuliani Steps Closer to a Run in 2008
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani took another step toward running for president by filing a statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission yesterday, declaring that he would seek the Republican nomination if he runs, according to his campaign.

title: Charges Expected in Case of Pupil, 26
description: The authorities in Oklahoma are preparing molestation charges against a 29-year-old convicted sex offender from Oklahoma who had posed as a 12-year-old to enroll in four Arizona schools.

title: Assembly Closer to Naming a Comptroller
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  The Legislature plans to renege on a deal it had with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and select a lawmaker as the next state comptroller on Wednesday, officials said, and at least one Democratic county chairman wants Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli to get the post.

title: Chief of PepsiCo to Get Chairmans Post
description: PepsiCo said that its board had elected its chief executive, Indra K. Nooyi, to succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chairman when he retires in May.

title: Home Depot Proxy Fight Is Settled
description: Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, reached an agreement last night with a large shareholder, Relational Investors, that will prevent a proxy fight over the companys strategy.

title: When a Visa Becomes a Headache
description: Last summer, Dimitry Smirnov, a sales director in Moscow, was planning to attend a conference in New York City being held by his employer, HelmsBriscoe, an American company that helps clients book sites for meetings. To get a visa, Mr. Smirnov made an appointment at the United States Embassy about four weeks before his meeting for an in-person interview, a requirement introduced after Sept. 11, 2001. It was when he showed up, he said, that he became frustrated.

title: A.B.A. Panel Would Weaken Code Governing Judges Conduct
description: A commission of the American Bar Association has recommended that the group weaken its code of judicial conduct by changing, from a mandatory rule to nonbinding advice, an instruction to judges to avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety.

title: Lawmaker in Iraq Convicted for Embassy Blasts in 83
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 6  Iraqi and American officials confirmed today that a sitting member of the Iraqi parliament is the same man who was convicted of planning bombing attacks on the American and French embassies and other sites in Kuwait in 1983. Five Americans were killed and 86 others were wounded in those attacks.

title: A New Problem for Farmers: Few Veterinarians
description: GORHAM, Me.  Rainbow had the bad luck to try to have a baby on a Thursday.

title: Bushs and Spitzers Budgets Hit New York Hospitals Hard
description: The budget that President Bush proposed yesterday includes deep cuts in spending to train young doctors, cuts that would hit New York especially hard, eliminating several hundred million dollars a year in payments to teaching hospitals around the state.

title: Indian Army and Police Tied to Kashmir Killings
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Feb. 3  Amid a grove of poplar trees in a village just north of here, a grave was unearthed Thursday afternoon. Out came the body of a man, shot dead nearly two months ago, whom the Indian police described at the time as an anti-Indian militant from Pakistan.

title: Drawing Lines Across the Sand, Between Classes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazilians like to say that the beach is their countrys most democratic space. But some bodies  and some beaches  are more equal than others.

title: The Price of Corn
description: The current price of corn is $3.23 a bushel, which is more than half again what it was a year ago, and beginning to bring to mind the record $5.545 a bushel set in July 1996.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday about the conviction of Kenneth McGriff, a crack kingpin, on federal charges of racketeering and conspiracy for hiring a hit team from Harlem to murder two rivals misstated the relationship of Mr. McGriff to a woman being shielded from news cameras by friends and relatives as they left court. The woman, Barbara McGriff, is his sister, not his mother.

title: Reclaiming a Black Research Scientists Forgotten Legacy
description: On the day that Percy L. Julian graduated at the top of his class at DePauw University, his great-grandmother bared her shoulders and, for the first time, showed him the deep scars that remained from a beating she had received as a slave during the last days of the Civil War. She then clutched his Phi Beta Kappa key in her hand and said, This is worth all the scars.

title: Germany Agonizes Over a Brain Drain
description: ESCHBORN, Germany, Feb. 3  Benedikt Thoma recalls the moment he began to think seriously about leaving Germany. It was in 2004, at a New Years Day reception in nearby Frankfurt, and the guest speaker, a prominent politician, was lamenting the fact that every year thousands of educated Germans turn their backs on their homeland.

title: Looking Beyond the Runway for Answers on Underweight Models
description: While a vast majority of Americans spent Sunday on a sofa watching men shaped like large appliances move a football up and down a 360-foot field, 15,000 New Yorkers, who probably wouldnt know a pump fake from a wishbone formation, spent the day ogling women shaped more or less like coat racks move dresses up and down 400 feet of runways in Bryant Park.

title: Americans Complete Liverpool Soccer Deal
description: Two American businessmen completed a $340 million acquisition Tuesday of the Liverpool soccer club of the English Premier League.

title: From the Cover of Magazines to the Back Page of a Career
description: The Continental Basketball Association may seem like an odd place to find a player once considered so gifted that he was featured on the cover of Sports Illustrated. But that is where Felipe Lopez is now, and like the other players in the league, he is not playing for the money, but to keep the faint hope alive that the N.B.A. is part of his future.

title: Edwards Details His Health Care Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  John Edwards proposed a detailed plan on Monday to provide health care coverage to the 47 million Americans who now go without, becoming the first major presidential candidate to do so.

title: A Change in Ownership, but Not in Leadership
description: Based on his vast experience with the sale of baseball teams, Steve Greenberg, a managing director at Allen & Company, said of the pending sale of the Atlanta Braves, Its always optimal to close a baseball sale during the off-season.

title: Astronaut Charged With Attempted Murder
description: The police in Orlando, Fla., filed attempted murder charges today against Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak, a NASA astronaut who the authorities say attacked a rival for another astronauts affection at Orlando International Airport on Monday after driving more than 900 miles from Houston to meet her flight.

title: Hospital Chain Accepts Buyout by a Partnership for $4.7 Billion
description: Triad Hospitals, under pressure from its biggest stockholder to raise its share price, agreed yesterday to be acquired by CCMP Capital Advisors and a Goldman Sachs unit for $4.7 billion.

title: Senate Takes Up Idea to Lease New Jersey Roads and Lottery
description: Attention, New Jersey shoppers.

title: Mr. Cheney, Tear Down This Wall
description: At the Republican National Convention in 2000 that nominated him for vice president, Dick Cheney told a rapturous crowd that Democrats will offer more lectures, and legalisms, and carefully worded denials. We offer another way, a better way, and a stiff dose of truth.

title: Troops in Iraq Kill Official Who Worked for Shiite Cleric
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 5  The director of the political office in Diyala Province for the powerful anti-American Shiite militia leader Moktada al-Sadr was shot and killed by troops during a raid on Sunday, a Sadr political spokesman said Monday.

title: On the Climate Change Beat, Doubt Gives Way to Certainty
description: In the decade when I was the lead reporter on climate change for this newspaper, nearly every blizzard or cold wave that hit the Northeast would bring the same conversation at work.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Whitney Balliett, the longtime jazz critic for The New Yorker, misstated the date of his death. It was Thursday, not Friday.

title: Rickie Lee Jones Receives Some Divine Inspiration
description: Whatever it is Christ said doesnt get a fair shake, Rickie Lee Jones said. On a rainy December day, she was sniffling and coughing, fighting a bad cold and losing. Theres not much written, it was done 150 years later, and it was used to create an empire. So can we get rid of all that and just see what the guy said?

title: Young Spirits, One of Them an Old Master
description: Phillip Lim manages to make commercial clothes that look smart, while Benjamin Cho hates the commercial and designs clothes that make us think. Their collections, along with a breezy show from Oscar de la Renta, gave wit and depth to the fall 2007 collections.

title: Feuding Palestinian Leaders Hold Talks in Mecca
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 6  Leaders of the two main Palestinian factions, Hamas and Fatah, on Tuesday began a two-day Saudi-brokered effort to agree on a unity government that could end a wave of violence in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank and resume relations with donor countries.

title: Girl or Boy? As Fertility Technology Advances, So Does an Ethical Debate
description: If people want to choose their babys sex before pregnancy, should doctors help?

title: Orbiting Junk, Once a Nuisance, Is Now a Threat
description: For decades, space experts have worried that a speeding bit of orbital debris might one day smash a large spacecraft into hundreds of pieces and start a chain reaction, a slow cascade of collisions that would expand for centuries, spreading chaos through the heavens.

title: Giuliani Is Definitely Interested but in No Rush
description: Former Senator John Edwards stood in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans and declared, Im a candidate for the presidency of the United States. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proclaimed on her campaign Web site: Im in. And Im in to win. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts plans to formally announce his White House run in Michigan on Feb. 13.

title: China Places AIDS Activist Under House Arrest
description: BEIJING, Feb. 5  A retired Chinese doctor acclaimed for helping people with AIDS has been placed under house arrest to stop her from traveling to the United States to receive an award from a nonprofit group connected to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a friend of the doctor said Monday.

title: Democrats Face Limits in Changing Bushs Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  With its military spending increases, reductions in popular domestic programs and calls to extend tax cuts, President Bushs $2.9 trillion budget for 2008 drew fire from Democrats the minute it landed on Monday.

title: No Altar, No Pews, Not Even a Roof, but Very Much a Church
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Homeless off and on since 1991, Rickey Robinson figures he needs to get close to God as often as he can. So on an especially icy Tuesday afternoon, as on many Tuesday afternoons, he bundled himself in a long black coat and joined a small group gathered in a corner of Franklin Square Park, where they prayed, sang a hymn and recited the 23rd Psalm.

title: Identity Fraud Has Dropped Since 2003, Survey Shows
description: The number of Americans who are victims of identity fraud has declined steadily since 2003, according to a new survey sponsored by credit-card and financial services companies. Last year, 3.7 percent of people surveyed said someone had stolen their identity in the previous 12 months, down from 4.7 percent in 2003, according to the report.

title: Hurry Up and Wait
description: House Democrats got off to a blazing start on their agenda, but things are slowing down a bit now. The floor schedule for the week consists almost entirely of what are known as suspension bills, noncontroversial measures naming post offices and federal court houses and the like. The schedule is in some ways a consequence of the initial 100 hour Democratic push. By zipping through their top bills in the first few weeks, leaders of the new majority set themselves up for a lull while new committee chairmen put together other legislation and begin oversight hearings on the Bush administrations performance. Preparing for what they say will be a busy period ahead, they are taking Friday off. CARL HULSE

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about pandemic flu guidelines issued by the federal government referred incorrectly to Tamiflu, which the government is stockpiling. It is an antiviral drug, not a vaccine. The article also misstated the estimated cost of stockpiling Tamiflu. It is about $1.4 billion, not $4 billion.

title: A Week After Bus Changes, Parents Complaints Continue
description: A week after the city cut and consolidated school bus routes, parents once again flooded a telephone hot line with complaints yesterday, a sign that anger and confusion over the changes has not abated.

title: Recalling Days of Rebellion, Tear Gas and Kinship
description: THE gay Yippie, the three-times-wounded Vietnam veteran, the militant mother who once led an armed resistance in rural Maryland. The rock guitarist turned public defender who brags of having played a benefit concert to raise money for an armored truck for the Black Panther Party. One-seventh of the Chicago Seven.

title: U.N. Chief Returns to Headquarters, Where Battles Await Him
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 5  Ban Ki-moon, the new United Nations secretary general, returned to his headquarters on Monday after a two-week working trip to Africa and Europe and ran into dissension over restructuring changes he has proposed and concern at the slow pace of his appointing top officials since taking office on Jan. 1.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the successful womens hockey program at Mercyhurst College reversed the duration of losses in recent seasons that cost the team a chance to play for a national title. Mercyhurst lost in triple overtime in 2005 to Harvard and in double overtime last year to Wisconsin.

title: Missed Free Throws Prove Costly to the Nets Again
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5  When a team is as erratic as the Nets, what should be routine  making free throws and beating teams that are competing for lottery picks  becomes surprisingly difficult.

title: Hans Wegner Dies at 92; Danish Furniture Designer
description: Hans Wegner, whose Danish Modern furniture  most famously his chairs  helped change the course of design history in the 1950s and 60s by sanding modernisms sharp edges and giving aesthetes a comfortable seat, died on Jan. 26 in Copenhagen. He was 92.

title: Microsoft Spurns Appeal to Intervene in Russian Piracy Case
description: PARIS, Feb. 5  Microsoft rebuffed a public appeal by Mikhail Gorbachev on Monday for its chairman, Bill Gates, to intervene on behalf of a Russian school principal charged with software piracy.

title: Flood Toll Rises, and Indonesia Braces for Disease
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Feb. 6  Much of this capital city was underwater on Tuesday, and the authorities warned of the possible spread of disease after torrential rains, overflowing rivers and clogged sewers brought widespread flooding over the weekend.

title: Simon Property Revisits a Deal It Abandoned
description: Simon Property Group, the nations largest mall operator, had always seemed like a logical buyer for its troubled rival, the Mills Corporation, and its portfolio of discount shopping and entertainment centers and traditional malls.

title: From Single Notes, a Spectrum of Sound
description: Introducing the last concert of his Carnegie Perspectives series on Sunday night at Zankel Hall, David Byrne said that the evenings program, One Note, had been the hardest to explain to his friends. Music that consisted of just one note? Not quite. What Mr. Byrne intended to illustrate was something musical seekers of the transcendental have understood since time immemorial: Less is more.

title: To Help Iraq, Let It Fend for Itself
description: Chevy Chase, Md.

title: The Gangs of Los Angeles: Roots, Branches and Bloods
description: Vintage film of gang members digging graves and attending funerals introduces Cle Sloans incisive documentary, Bastards of the Party, about the origins of the murderous street gangs of Los Angeles.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a coming surge in the construction of high-rise residential buildings on the Far West Side of Manhattan misspelled the surname of the architect who has designed five of the buildings, on 42nd Street west of 11th Avenue. He is Costas Kondylis, not Condylis.

title: Nutrition: Adolescents Arent Eating Their Vegetables
description: Young children often turn up their noses at healthy food, and the skepticism seems to reappear during the teenage years.

title: Brooklyn: Police Shoot Robbery Suspect
description: A police officer shot and wounded a 27-year-old man trying to rob a Citibank branch in Brooklyn Heights yesterday when the man threatened the officer with a knife, the police said. The man, whom the police did not identify, was shot once in the torso and was in stable condition at Lutheran Medical Center yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man apparently entered the bank, on Montague Street, about 10 a.m., the police said, and demanded money from a teller. When two officers arrived, he approached one of them brandishing a 12-inch knife, the police said, and the officer shot him.

title: Icahn Offers to Acquire Rest of Auto Parts Company
description: After placing a big bet on the beaten-down auto parts business in October, Carl C. Icahn is doubling down.

title: Totals
A New Boss at NBC, and Even Newer Issues
description: When Jeff Zucker is named the new chief executive of NBC Universal today, succeeding Bob Wright, he will be completing one of the most spectacular ascents of any recent media executive: from part-time sports researcher in 1986 to corporate C.E.O two decades later.

title: Israel: Army Says It Uncovered Hezbollah Bombs
description: The Israeli military said that it found and detonated four bombs placed just on its side of the border with Lebanon and that it believed Hezbollah guerrillas were responsible. The bombs, disguised to look like rocks, were placed near a road used by Israeli soldiers, it said. Israel and Lebanon fought a month-long war last summer, and an enlarged United Nations peacekeeping force is now monitoring the Lebanese side of the border.

title: Richardson on Course for Long-Awaited Return to N.B.A.
description: The ship, apparently, is not sinking. Micheal Ray Richardsons life, whether personal or professional, is on an upward course, he said. He is the hottest coach in the Continental Basketball Association and still has hopes of fulfilling a major goal  returning to the N.B.A.

title: Embodying the Past and Future of an Old Form
description: Flamenco was hybrid from the start: Gitano, Sephardic Jewish, Moorish, Andalusian Christian. But from its origins until the 1970s, it became an elegantly closed-in form of music; from there it could only reconstitute itself into a new hybrid.

title: Revisiting a Poison Control Database on Supplement Risks
description: A national poison control database suggests that some diet supplements may pose risks to consumers, raising questions about a 1994 federal law stating that safety problems with the supplements are relatively rare. But an essay in Science Times on Jan. 16 about those risks overstated the number of adverse reactions to supplements reported in the database.

title: S.E.C. Is Looking at Stock Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a broad examination into whether Wall Street bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients, like hedge funds, in an effort to curry favor with those clients, executives at Wall Street banks said.

title: Inexperience Noted in Yankees Plane Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Cory Lidle spent fewer than four hours flying his new plane before the day it crashed into a building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan in October, according to information released on Monday by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: A Sport Out on the Edge Takes Aim at the Mainstream
description: In the primal pursuit known as mixed martial arts, Renzo Gracie may be the closest thing to a philosopher one will find.

title: Both Sides Use Race as Tactic in Brooklyn Corruption Case
description: In his latest corruption trial, Clarence Norman Jr. has been portrayed by his lawyers to the mostly black jury as an avatar of racial equality who, when he was head of Brooklyns Democratic Party, refused to factor in race when deciding how to mount a winning campaign.

title: Delays Hinder Security Plan, Top Iraqi Says
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 6  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki acknowledged for the first time on Tuesday that his government had stumbled in its efforts to carry out a new security plan in Baghdad and that the delays and mounting violence were hurting its credibility with the Iraqi people.

title: Trial Starts for Officer Who Refused to Go to Iraq
description: FORT LEWIS, Wash., Feb. 5  A court-martial started here on Monday against an Army officer who refused to serve in Iraq last summer because, he has said, the war is illegal.

title: Virtual Hostages on a Plane
description: TALK about history repeating itself. On New Years weekend in 1999, a blizzard left thousands of passengers stranded for hours on Northwest Airlines planes at the airport in Detroit as food and water ran out and toilets became unusable.

title: For Wolves, a Recovery May Not Be the Blessing It Seems
description: HELENA, Mont., Feb. 5  The news for the wolf last week was the opposite of a cloud with a silver lining. At first glance, it seems like a win for conservation that wolves are now successful enough that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service proposed taking wolves in Idaho and Montana off the endangered species list.

title: Thanks to the Web, the Scorekeeping on the Super Bowl Has Just Begun
description: FOR the teams that play in the Super Bowl, the day after the game is reserved for planning victory parties or promising, Wait till next year. For Madison Avenue, the day after has become D-Day, given over to discussing and debating the myriad data that become available about the response to the commercials from the game.

title: Two Misdemeanor Charges in Lake George Capsizing
description: QUEENSBURY, N.Y., Feb. 5  The captain and the boat operator involved in one of the worst boating accidents in the states history were each charged with a misdemeanor on Monday, more than a year after their tour boat capsized in Lake George, killing 20 elderly passengers.

title: The Other Defense Budget
description: American troops under fire in Iraq and Afghanistan deserve every penny requested for them in President Bushs new $622 billion Pentagon budget. And the overstretched Army and Marine Corps clearly need support, along with the extra troops that will eventually come their way. But that still leaves more than half of the overall request for Congress to carefully scrutinize and significantly prune.

title: Democratic Support Wilts, Endangering Tax Relief Plan
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  What was to have been a routine vote for final approval of key property tax relief legislation backed by the governor and the Legislature bogged down in the Senate on Monday after the Democrats support for the bill weakened.
