description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Deaths May Put Focus on Elevators Hardware
description: The deaths of three men who plunged down elevator shafts over the weekend underscore a danger that experts say is not widely recognized in a city of more than 50,000 elevators: a door can come unhinged from its bottom tracks, leaving a sudden gaping hole over an empty shaft.

title: Slip Sliding Away
description: Football season is over, but there is no cause for despair. We are smack in the middle of an all-star backpedaling tournament.

title: Believers and Doubters, Inspired by the Word
description: If Biblical Art in a Secular Century were a larger show, it might be divided into sections devoted to grand, sweeping themes, following the model currently popular for blockbuster exhibitions. There would be a room for artists identified as True Believers, an area for Atheists, a separate nook for Artists With Christ Complexes, and gallery space for Cynics, Martyrs and the Post-Religion crowd.

title: Manning Shows Off Smile of a Champion
description: Miami

title: Toyota Stays on Track with 7.3 Percent Gain in Quarter
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6  The Toyota Motor Corporation, the worlds second-largest car maker, reported a 7.3 percent gain in profit in the most recent quarter on Tuesday, bolstered by strong American sales of its Camry sedan and the remodeled FJ Cruiser sport utility vehicle.

title: Settlement in Terror Scare Is $2 Million
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5  The Turner Broadcasting System and a Manhattan marketing agency have agreed to pay $2 million in restitution and other costs for a Cartoon Network advertising campaign that set off fears of terrorism, the state attorney general, Martha Coakley, said Monday.

title: Dispatch From Gomorrah, Savaging the Cultural Left
description: With this book, Dinesh DSouza, the Rishwain research scholar at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, has officially become the Ann Coulter of the think tank set.

title: James Is a Knicks Starter Again
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 5  Scrawled in shorthand, Jerome Jamess New York career so far looks something like this: optimism, injury, recovery, optimism, suspension, injury, recovery, injury, optimism, injury.

title: A Small Part of the Brain, and Its Profound Effects
description: The recent news about smoking was sensational: some people with damage to a prune-size slab of brain tissue called the insula were able to give up cigarettes instantly.

title: Criminal Case Likely to Put All of Yukos in State Hands
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  New criminal charges filed Monday against former leaders of the Yukos oil company, once Russias largest private energy concern, are likely to ease what remains of the company into state hands, strengthening the Kremlins control over the industry, analysts and company officials said.

title: Hyundai Chief Sentenced to Prison for Embezzling
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 5  The chairman of Hyundai Motor Company, sentenced on Monday to three years in prison for embezzling corporate funds, will continue to run the corporation while his case is appealed.

title: Memo Pad
description: FREE PASSPORT PHOTOS In a marketing tie-in to new federal requirements that air travelers present passports when returning from Canada, Mexico, Central and South America and the Caribbean, JetBlue is offering free passport photos this month to customers traveling through Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport. The photos will be taken Thursdays through Saturdays near Gate 12A. The promotion is offered in partnership with the Bermuda Department of Tourism and the Nassau Paradise Island Promotion Board.

title: Lawmaker in Iraq Convicted for Embassy Blasts in 83
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 6  Iraqi and American officials confirmed today that a sitting member of the Iraqi parliament is the same man who was convicted of planning bombing attacks on the American and French embassies and other sites in Kuwait in 1983. Five Americans were killed and 86 others were wounded in those attacks.

title: Mets Plan Lottery for Prime Tickets
description: For fans who want to attend specific high-profile games at Shea Stadium this year but do not have season tickets or a multigame ticket package that includes those games, buying a ticket has become a matter of chance.

title: The Week Ahead
description: While Congress takes up the resolutions on Iraq, here are a few other developments to watch on the weeks political calendar:

title: In the Rain, Fans and Analysis Are Washed Away
description: The absence of crowd shots during Super Bowl XLI surprised me, as I wrote here yesterday. With time on my hands, I replayed the game and found that CBS showed fans four times and cut to faraway crowd shots twice. CBS cut to cheering fans only twice after scores.

title: A Better Civil Service (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about the Chicago Bears top running backs misstated the university that Thomas Jones attended before being drafted into the National Football League. It was the University of Virginia, not Arizona.

title: The Flora Among Us
description: Dont look now, but theres a complex ecosystem living practically under your nose.

title: At Risk: Study Finds Broad Category of Problem Drinkers
description: Alcoholics are not the only people with a drinking problem, a new study says.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Sunday about Dr. Calvin H. Plimpton, who was president of Amherst College and later of the American University of Beirut, misidentified the college from which he received his undergraduate degree. It was Amherst, not Harvard.

title: Medicare Will Not Cover Nerve Device in Depression
description: Regulators who oversee Medicare said yesterday that they did not think it was reasonable or necessary to begin covering Cyberonics implanted electrical stimulator to treat severe depression in patients who had failed with other therapies.

title: Bush Creates New Military Command for Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Pentagon will establish a new military command to oversee its operations in Africa, President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced today.

title: Battling Disease That Has Already Claimed One Mother
description: Michelle Flores was barely older than her teenage daughter, Ashley, is now when she watched her mother slowly descend into atrophy, seizures and a coma.

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: Bushs 2008 Budget Request Doubles Spending on Replacing Military Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  More than a quarter of the money the Bush administration is requesting in the 2008 fiscal year for military operations in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere would go toward repairing and replacing military equipment, according to budget figures released Monday by the Pentagon.

title: How Do We See Red? Count the Ways
description: Valentines Day is nearly upon us, that sweet Hallmark holiday when you can have anything your heart desires, so long as its red. Red roses, red nighties, red shoes and red socks. Red Oreo filling, red bagels, red lox.

title: The Comptroller Choice
description: New Yorks Legislature appears poised to make a highly irresponsible decision about one of the states most important offices. Legislators, who have the authority to pick a replacement for the former comptroller, Alan Hevesi, seem to be ready to throw aside qualifications  and a selection process they agreed to  and give the job to one of their own. In particular, they seem to be rallying around Thomas DiNapoli, who has been the assemblyman from Great Neck on Long Island for 20 years.

title: Barbara McNair, 72, a Singer, Actress and Host of a TV Show, Dies
description: Barbara McNair, a cabaret singer, actress and television personality of the 1960s who was noted as much for her stunning appearance as for her versatile voice, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 72.

title: Libbys Grand Jury Tapes Are Heard in Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Prosecutors in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on Monday played audio tapes in which Mr. Libby was heard testifying under oath before a grand jury that he had not discussed the identity of a Central Intelligence Agency operative with fellow administration officials in the summer of 2003.

title: A Vote Likely to Linger
description: Congressional votes on Iraq have long political shelf lives.

title: Race for State Senate Seat Breaks Spending Record
description: ELMONT, N.Y., Feb. 5  The price tag for the all-out battle in Tuesdays special election to fill a State Senate seat on Long Island has surpassed $5 million, breaking the state record for a legislative race, campaign officials say.

title: Insurers Foresee No Problems After Tornadoes
description: As insurers assess the damage from the tornadoes that struck Central Florida on Friday, killing 20 people, they say they do not expect serious effects on the state insurance market.

title: New Charges in Russia Against Oil Executives
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  Russian prosecutors brought new charges Monday against the imprisoned founder of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent.

title: The Claim: The Back Seat of a Car Is the Safest Place to Sit
description: THE FACTS  Automobiles may not be the safest mode of transport, but many people wonder whether where they choose to sit can improve their odds.

title: Manhattan: Delivery Truck Kills Woman, 82
description: An 82-year-old woman crossing a street in Chelsea was fatally struck by a delivery truck about 11 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The truck driver, who was turning onto West 16th Street from Ninth Avenue when he struck the woman, continued driving down 16th Street and parked about a block away, apparently not realizing that he had hit the woman, Amelia Chimienti, of West 14th Street, the police said. Investigators found the truck about 30 minutes after the accident and later located the driver, whose identity the police did not release. The police said they did not expect to file any charges.

title: Politicians Are Doing Hollywood Star Turns
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5  As Hollywood closes in on Oscar night with its attendant round of awards galas, politicians are popping up everywhere but the podium, and the envelope, please might just mean the kind with a check inside.

title: G.O.P. Senators Block Debate on Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Republicans on Monday blocked Senate debate on a bipartisan resolution opposing President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq, leaving in doubt whether the Senate would render a judgment on what lawmakers of both parties described as the paramount issue of the day.

title: Rangers Trade for Gritty Avery
description: The Rangers shook up their lineup yesterday, adding scoring and grit by trading for Los Angeles left wing Sean Avery. The Rangers also received a prospect in the deal in return for the veteran forward Jason Ward and two Rangers prospects.

title: Two Top Executives to Leave Discovery Communications
description: The departure of two of the most senior executives at Discovery Communications reflects an effort by the new chief executive, David M. Zaslav, to play a more hands-on role in running the companys core cable TV channels.

title: Rangers Score Early but Cant Stop the Red Wings
description: After the last horrid bounces finished off the Rangers last night in a 4-3 loss to Detroit, goaltender Henrik Lundqvist sat at his locker in Madison Square Garden, drenched in sweat, a stunned look on his face.

title: Video of 2003 Friendly Fire Incident in Iraq is Released
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  The videotape is jolting enough, but it is the audio portion  the conversation between two American pilots in Iraq  that is most unnerving.

title: From Lead Percussionist to Different Drummer
description: CHICAGO  As the principal percussionist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Ted Atkatz had reached a pinnacle in his profession.

title: Fidelity to Pay Fine for Failure to Supervise Gifts to Traders
description: Fidelity Investments will pay $3.75 million in fines for supervisory failures, including allowing traders to accept gifts like Super Bowl tickets and chartered flights, NASD, the brokerage industrys main regulator, said yesterday.

title: Diagnosis: An Easier Path to the Treatment of Sleep Apnea
description: People who have obstructive sleep apnea know how hard it can be to adjust to the breathing apparatus used to treat it. But just getting a diagnosis poses its own challenges, generally requiring two nights hooked up to wires in a sleep laboratory.

title: India Is Reveling in Being the Buyer
description: MUMBAI, India, Feb. 5  Many in this nation, which gained independence from Britain in 1947, are discovering that it is far more appealing to belong to a nation doing the takeovers rather than being taken over.

title: Homeless Man Found a Place on East 21st
description: He could not have had a more fitting surname: Street. Alvin Street was the full name. A street person he was.

title: After Long Dispute, Two Apples Work It Out
description: The long and winding road has come to an end for the Beatles, at least as far as the dispute over their Apple logo is concerned.

title: Cemetery Offers Refuge After Flood in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Feb. 6  Strings of bright laundry hang among the gravestones and the people who are brave enough to sleep among the dead, taking refuge on the high ground of the Karet Cemetery from the worst flooding in Jakarta in decades.

title: Poland: Defense Minister Resigns
description: Defense Minister Radoslaw Sikorski, who has strong ties to Washington, resigned after apparently losing a power struggle with the director of the military counterintelligence agency, Antoni Macierewicz, a close ally of Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski. News reports said Mr. Sikorski confirmed that he had unsuccessfully sought to have Mr. Macierewicz dismissed. Mr. Sikorskis departure comes as Poland is about to increase its military contingent in Afghanistan to about 1,000, from 100, and begin negotiations with the United States on a missile defense base.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,086 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: The Decline of a Family, Played Out on the Stand
description: In a drab courtroom in Manhattan Supreme Court, everyone from spectators to warring family members to true-crime novelists is witnessing the unraveling of an upper-middle-class, Upper East Side family, in a story of love, devotion, anger and rejection that is at once unique and hauntingly familiar to any husband and wife who have ever had their differences. In this case, however, it ends in horror and bloodshed.

title: Hes Articulate: A Compliment or an Insult? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: California: Mayor Seeks Alcohol Treatment
description: Less than a week after admitting to an affair with his campaign managers wife, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco announced he had stopped drinking and would seek counseling for alcohol abuse. Mr. Newsom said in a statement that he accepted responsibility for his mistakes and that his problems with alcohol were not an excuse. He said he would begin outpatient treatment at a local rehabilitation program. On Thursday, Mr. Newsom acknowledged having had a brief affair with Ruby Rippey-Tourk, the wife of Alex Tourk, a former deputy chief of staff who had been running the mayors campaign for a second term. Mr. Tourk learned of the affair after Ms. Rippey-Tourk confessed as part of her own substance-abuse rehabilitation.

title: Insights: The Ticking Clock in the Doctors Office
description: Patients on routine visits to their primary care doctors often have a lot of questions but not enough time to get good answers.

title: Yes, Thats a Head in My Baggage. Is There Some Sort of Problem?
description: HERES a packing tip Ive picked up in my travels: If theres a head in your luggage, you might want to allow yourself a few extra minutes at the security checkpoint.

title: Global Warming: No Question Now (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Shiite Calls for U.S.-Iran Talks
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 5  A senior Iraqi Shiite leader said Monday that his country had urged Iran to hold talks with the United States and that such talks were important for the security of the region.

title: For Teenagers, the Car Is the Danger Zone
description: Parents of teenagers worry about lots of things: drugs, sex, poor choices of friends. But the activity that causes the most harm to older teenagers is none of the above.

title: As New Cop on the Beat, Congressman Starts Patrol
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Halliburton? Tobacco executives? Vice President Dick Cheney? Youve been warned.

title: U.N. Lifts Ban on Beluga Caviar, Overruling Environmentalists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  A year-old international ban on the export of beluga caviar, the most expensive and most endangered variety of the delicacy, harvested largely by Caspian Sea countries, has been lifted by the United Nations agency charged with controlling trade in endangered species.

title: In Public View, Saudis Counter Iran in Region
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 5  With the prospect of three civil wars looming over the Middle East  and Iran poised to gain from them all  Saudi Arabia has abandoned its behind-the-scenes checkbook diplomacy and taken on a central, aggressive role in reshaping the regions conflicts.

title: State Street to Acquire Investors Financial for $4.5 Billion
description: State Street Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Investors Financial Services Corporation in a $4.5 billion stock deal that highlights the accelerating pace of consolidation in the securities processing business.

title: Tested by Tribulation, a Coach Discovers New Vigor
description: MIAMI, Feb. 5  As the final 15 seconds ticked off the Super Bowl clock Sunday night, Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy said a little prayer of thanks for his team. His players had carried him through the agony of his sons death last season, and in the week he spent away from them afterward, he had come to appreciate how important his players were to him. This seasons team was not his most talented, Dungy said, but it was the closest, bonded by the on- and off-field trials it had endured. And this team was the one that finally delivered him a title.

title: About That Mean Streak of Yours: Psychiatry Can Do Only So Much
description: When have you ever heard of a therapist telling a patient that he is mean or bad? Probably never.

title: Outsize Talent Who Took the a Train to Anonymity
description: In Visions of Jazz the gifted jazz critic Gary Giddins opens his essay on the composer Billy Strayhorn by noting that Strayhorn, who died on May 31, 1967, at 51, began his rebirth that day. His music has since been paid great tribute. The project of mythologizing Strayhorn has been a continuing affair, culminating in David Hajdus acclaimed 1996 biography, Lush Life. It is revisited in a comprehensive if unintentionally undermining documentary by Robert Levi, appearing on PBS this evening, Billy Strayhorn: Lush Life.

title: Wrestling With Sinatra, but Its a Very Friendly Fight
description: Sooner or later, every man who sings standards has to wrestle with the ghost of Frank Sinatra. And on Saturday evening at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, it was John Pizzarellis turn.

title: Italian Authorities Propose Barring Fans
description: ROME, Feb. 5  Many of the top soccer teams in Italy will play their games in empty stadiums if a proposal by government ministers is approved at a special cabinet meeting Wednesday.

title: Officer Is Clubbed by Attacker Who Wanted Gun, Police Say
description: A rookie police officer was beaten with a baseball bat early yesterday while on foot patrol in Queens for what the police said was a simple motive: the suspect wanted to steal his gun.

title: Jail Record Near for Videographer Who Resisted Grand Jury
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5  A freelance videographer who refused to cooperate with a grand jury investigation will become the longest incarcerated journalist in modern American history on Tuesday. The freelancer, Josh Wolf, will pass Vanessa Leggett, an investigator and a journalist who served 168 days in 2001 and 2002 for refusing to surrender information in a murder case.

title: Wal-Mart and Studios in Film Deal
description: Wal-Mart Stores may have lost the online DVD rental battle, but it has no plans to lose the higher-stakes video downloading war.

title: New Suitor Ignites Battle for Ailing Mills Corp.
description: Another major battle has surfaced in the commercial real estate market, this time over the ailing mall developer Mills Corporation.

title: A Vaccine to Save Womens Lives
description: Congratulations to Texas for becoming the first state to require vaccinating young schoolgirls  ages 11 and 12  against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer and genital warts. Other states would be wise to follow the same path.

title: Lawyers May Keep Libby Off Witness Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The jurors deciding the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. listened to his voice on audiotape for hours today as his lawyers quietly explored a surprise strategy  keeping him off the witness stand  that would insure the jurors would never hear his voice in person.

title: Consolidation in the Timber Industry
description: Brookfield Asset Management of Toronto said it would buy Longview Fibre, a specialty paper and packaging company, for $1.6 billion. Longview has a pulp and paper mill in Longview, Wash., and 15 corrugated-container plants, but its chief asset for Brookfield appears to be its 588,000 acres of woodlands in Washington and Oregon. They will join other timberlands owned by Brookfield, including 635,000 acres in British Columbia it bought from Weyerhaeuser in 2005. As part of the Longview deal, Brookfield will also assume about $550,000 in debt. Longview put itself up for sale in 2006 after rejecting a $1.33 billion bid from two private equity firms.

title: The Money Race
description: Candidates in tight races usually give it their all and then some. Many go to sleep on election night with campaigns deep in debt. But several of last falls losers ended the year with money in the bank, sometimes enough to buy a lot of second-guessing.

title: What the Iraq Report Makes Even Clearer (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: High Level of Building Permits
description: New York City, in the throes of the biggest residential building boom in three decades, issued permits for 30,927 new units of privately owned housing in 2006  a near-record number, according to figures released yesterday by city officials. The 2006 number falls just short of the 31,599 units for which permits were issued in 2005, according to the new figures, which were collected by the United States Census Bureau. But the combined total for those two years is the highest two-year total since 1965, the first year for which city officials say there are reliable statistics. The 2005 number is topped only by the 33,084 permits issued in 1972, at the height of the Mitchell-Lama subsidized housing program.

title: Bikes, Buses and Plazas (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fudging the Budget
description: WHEN President Bush sent his new budget to Congress yesterday, he trumpeted a continuing decline in the deficit and projected a swing back into the black by 2012.

title: Humana Profit More Than Doubles, Aided by Medicare Gains
description: Humana, the health insurer, said yesterday that profit more than doubled as enrollment increased in the companys Medicare plans for older Americans.

title: Britain: Renowned Building Sold
description: A London office tower known as the Gherkin was bought by IVG Immobilien, a German property company, and Evans Randall Investment Management, a British investment bank, for 600 million ($1.2 billion), a record for a building in the citys main financial district. The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the towers owner, said it would remain the principal tenant in the 41-story building. Swiss Re, which is based in Zurich, will book a profit of 250 million ($500 million) from the sale. The Gherkin was designed by Norman Foster, winner of the Pritzker Prize, and opened in 2004. The tower, formally known as 30 St. Mary Axe, is a genuine landmark with excellent long-term letting prospects, IVG said.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Cheeta Paints

title: Banks Appeal Ruling Allowing Enron Investors to Sue as Class
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (Bloomberg News)  Two investment banks, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse, asked a federal appeals court yesterday to end a class-action lawsuit by Enron investors seeking $40 billion that they lost when the energy trader collapsed in 2001.

title: Under Pressure, Gates Details Iraq Expectations
description: American troops could start leaving Iraq by the end of this year if the plan to suppress sectarian violence with reinforcements in Baghdad is successful, Robert Gates, the secretary of defense, said today.

title: Dueling Agendas Stifle Critical Debate on War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  At a time when even President Bush acknowledges the war in Iraq is sapping the nations spirit, the Senate has tied itself up in procedural knots rather than engage in a debate on Iraq policy.

title: Britain: Poison Victims Widow Asks Putin to Find Killers
description: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer and Kremlin critic who died in London in November of a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210, has written to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, challenging him to help bring her husbands killers to justice. If you and the state are innocent, then please help, she wrote in the letter, which was made available by a family friend. If you did not make every effort to assist the U.K. authorities. I could only assume that you must have something to hide. On his deathbed, Mr. Litvinenko asserted that he had been poisoned by Russias government. Last week, the Metropolitan Police handed their file on the investigation to the Crown Prosecution Service. British newspapers have said three Russian businessmen who met Mr. Litvinenko on the day he is believed to have been poisoned are suspects. In Moscow, Dmitri S. Peskov, a Kremlin spokesman, said Russian investigators were hoping to travel to London to interview suspects in their own case. The investigation is going at full speed from both sides, he said. There is no need to ask for any extra help from the president.

title: Jakarta Under Water
description: More than 220,000 people remained homeless after several days of torrential rains and overflowing rivers in Indonesia.

title: Shaken, Stirred and Poured in London
description: In London today, bartenders are turning out more sophisticated mixed drinks than in any other city on the globe.

title: Oscar Nominees Luncheon
description: Times photographer Monica Almeida goes to the Academy Awards Nominees luncheon.

title: Blackstone Raises Its Bid for Equity Office
description: The oneupmanship continued early Tuesday in the largest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Roy G. Biv Has Feelings Too
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 36 Hours in Sedona
description: Enjoy the quirks this Arizona city has to offer, like a cactus margarita, a church built into the rocks or a spiritual vortex.

title: Treasure-Seeking in Trabzon
description: This former Byzantine capital is becoming known for its untrammeled bazaars, spectacular cultural treasures and other picture-perfect attractions.

title: Herbalife to Consider Take-Private Offer
description: Shares of Herbalife International of America rose 21 percent on Monday after J.H. Whitney & Company offered to take the nutritional supplement company private for $38 a share, or $2.7 billion. J.H. Whitney took Herbalife private in 2002 and took it public again two years later at a big profit, TheDeal.com reports.

title: Security Software Startup TriCipher Raises $15 Million
description: TriCipher, which makes security software and appliances, said it raised $15 million in a third round of venture funding led by RBC Technology Ventures. The investment brings TriCiphers total equity funding to more than $30 million and is expected to be its final private round.

title: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $39 Billion
description: The oneupmanship continued early Tuesday in the largest leveraged buyout ever. The Blackstone Group, a private equity firm, raised its offer to acquire Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust, to $55.50 a share, increasing the value of the transaction to about $39 billion, Equity Office said shortly after 1 a.m. Tuesday. Equity Office said the latest Blackstone offer had been unanimously approved by its board, which is led by the founder, Samuel Zell.

title: As Home Depot Settles Proxy Fight, Sale Talk Lingers
description: Home Depot reached an agreement Monday night with a large shareholder, Relational Investors, that will prevent a proxy fight over the companys strategy. But the move could increase pressure on Home Depot to sell one of its units. Under the terms of the agreement, Relational, a San Diego investment fund, will receive a seat on the companys board and four directors involved in hiring Robert L. Nardelli, the recently dismissed chief executive, will leave the board in 2008. A founder of Relational, David H. Batchelder, will join the Home Depot board on Feb. 22, and the investment fund will drop its proxy challenge, the two companies said in a joint statement.

title: India Is Reveling in Being the Buyer
description: Many in India, which gained independence from Britain in 1947, are discovering that it is far more appealing to belong to a nation doing the takeovers rather than being taken over. Much of India erupted with jubilation last week when the Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate, won the bidding for the Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel company, with an $11.3 billion offer, the largest acquisition ever by an Indian company.

title: Hyundai Chief, Awaiting Appeal, to Stay on Job
description: The chairman of Hyundai Motor, sentenced on Monday to three years in prison for embezzling corporate funds, will continue to run the corporation while his case is appealed. The presiding judge, Kim Dong-oh, said that the chairman, Chung Mong-koo, committed a clearly criminal act by raising and using a large-scale secretive fund that greatly undermines the transparency and soundness of business management and has many adverse effects on our business culture.

title: New Charges in Russia Against Oil Executives
description: Russian prosecutors brought new charges Monday against the imprisoned founder of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent. The former executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, and his partner, Platon A. Lebedev, were charged with embezzlement and money laundering, which his lawyers said together could carry prison sentences of 15 years.

title: Banks Seek to Stop Enron Class-Action Suit
description: Two investment banks, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse, asked a federal appeals court on Monday to end a class-action lawsuit by Enron investors seeking $40 billion that they lost when the energy trader collapsed in 2001. The banks argued that a Houston judge was wrong to allow Enron investors to sue as a group and contended that they could not be sued because they did not participate directly in the accounting fraud that led to Enrons bankruptcy. The investors argued the court could address only whether the plaintiffs could sue as a group. Trial is set for April in Houston.

title: Nasdaq to Increase Fees to Listed Companies and Add Services
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market has won regulatory approval to increase fees and offer more services to the 3,200 companies listed on it. The higher fees were effective Jan. 1, Nasdaq said Monday. The decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission also allows Nasdaq, an all-electronic exchange, to provide news-release distribution and Internet broadcasts at no additional charge. Nasdaqs chief executive, Robert Greifeld, has tried to lure companies from the New York Stock Exchange through a series of acquisitions that helped Nasdaq expand beyond the business of matching buyers and sellers of shares.

title: With Mills Bid Simon Property Revisits a Deal It Abandoned
description: Simon Property Group, the nations largest mall operator, had always seemed like a logical buyer for its troubled rival, the Mills Corporation. But the announcement yesterday that Simon had teamed with Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund that owns 10.9 percent of Millss shares, to challenge a rival suitor and make an all-cash bid for Mills of $24 a share surprised the real estate industry because of its timing.

title: Fidelity to Pay Fine for Failure to Supervise Gifts to Traders
description: Fidelity Investments will pay $3.75 million in fines for supervisory failures, including allowing traders to accept gifts like Super Bowl tickets and chartered flights, NASD, the brokerage industrys main regulator, said Monday. Fidelity, the worlds biggest mutual fund company, did not assign supervisors to 1,000 registered employees and let at least nine people at one subsidiary take the gifts, NASD said.

title: Credit Suisse Brings in Banker From Goldman
description: Two years ago, Credit Suisse was trying to sell its bankers on yet another turnaround plan at the securities firm and looking for ways to keep frustrated investment bankers and traders from walking out the door. So Mondays announcement of a high-level hire at Credit Suisses investment banking group  recruited from no less than Goldman Sachs, which is coming off a year of record profits, could be seen as a highly symbolic achievement for the firm.

title: Two Executives to Leave Janus Capital
description: The asset manager Janus Capital Group said Monday that its chief financial officer, Dave R. Martin, and general counsel, John H. Bluher, were leaving the firm in unrelated departures. Three months ago, the chief executive, Gary D. Black, stepped down as chief investment officer in favor of two co-chief investment officers to focus on growing the business.

title: F.T.C. Reaffirms Rambus Antitrust Ruling
description: The Federal Trade Commission made final its ruling that the memory chip designer Rambus violated antitrust laws, imposing limits on the royalties the company can charge. Wall Street was bracing for a potentially harsher order than the one the commission released Monday, and Rambus stock rose sharply.

title: S.E.C. Examines Improper Stock Tipping at Major Banks
description: Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Deutsche Bank are among major Wall Street banks that were sent letters last month by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of a broad examination into whether bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients, The New York Times reported.

title: Former Westar Chief Given Two-Year Sentence for Bank Fraud
description: A federal judge on Monday resentenced the former chief executive of Westar Energy, David C. Wittig, to 24 months in prison for bank fraud, cutting his original sentence by more than half. But the judge, Julie A. Robinson, of United States District Court, still surpassed the six-month prison term recommended by an appellate court, saying it failed to reflect the seriousness of the offense.

title: I.B.M. Details Its Chief Executives Pay
description: International Business Machines, whose stock rose 18 percent last year as it expanded in software, said on Monday that its chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, would be paid a $1.8 million salary in 2007 and stands to receive $5 million in incentive pay, the same as last year. Mr. Palmisano also received restricted stock units worth $3 million, vesting in 2011, and performance share units worth $7 million, payable in 2010, according to a spokesman, John Bukovinsky, and a regulatory filing.

title: LinkedIn Hires New Chief Executive
description: LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts, announced Monday that it had hired a new chief executive to succeed Reid Hoffman, one of Silicon Valleys most active angel investors. While Mr. Hoffman will remain the start-ups chairman, the move to hire Dan Nye, the former executive vice president of publicly traded Advent Software, could fuel speculation about a potential initial public offering, possibly as early as this year.

title: Deutsche Borse Introduces Luxury Index
description: Deutsche Borse, the operator of the Frankfurt stock exchange and one-time bidder for Euronext, said Monday that it had launched a new index to track the share performance of luxury goods makers. Dubbed the World Luxury Index and made up of 20 companies, it was put together by Deutsche Borse for the Paris-based bank and investment group BNP Paribas and started on Feb. 2.

title: Does Gap Need a Little Privacy?
description: Gap management may want to take a page out of J.Crews playbook and try to sell itself to a private equity firm, suggests BusinessWeek. The magazine looks at how the Texas Pacific Groups buyout of J. Crew transformed the retailer from an also-ran to a trend-setting retailer. Echoing a sentiment increasingly expressed by chief executives and start-up founders, BusinessWeek puts the bottom line at this: with no public shareholders to answer to, J.Crew had the time to grow.

title: Berkshire Partners Medical Double-Header
description: Berkshire Partners said Monday it had acquired a majority stake in the medical-equipment businesses Masterplan and ReMedPar from Three Cities Research and Camden Partners Holdings for undisclosed terms. Berkshire, which is based in Boston, typically invests $50 million to $350 million in transactions valued at $250 million or more, according to The Deal.com.

title: German Bank Auction Piques Interest
description: The most eagerly anticipated auction in the German banking sector in recent years kicked off Monday with several public and private banks declaring their interest in buying Landesbank Berlin. The sale is expected to be a hotly contested affair and the outcome will be closely watched by bank executives around the world because it presents the first real opportunity for private banks to enter the previously protected savings banks sector.

title: Funnier Still
description: The Grammys wont be the only vacuous award contest on Sunday night. The Writers Guild is going to load up on comedians  Tina Fey, Sacha Baron Cohen and Jon Stewart, among others  and give the whole hardware thing a whirl.

title: Burger Kings Backers Fire Up Stock Offering
description: The Texas Pacific Group, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs Funds have placed an order for a whopper of a profit. The private equity firms said Monday that they planned to sell at least 20 million of their shares in Burger King, which at Mondays market price would raise about $400 million before fees and commissions, or up to $460 million if the underwriters over-allotment is exercised for another 3 million shares, The Deal.com calculated. They now stand to make more than four times their money on their 2002 investment.

title: Chevron Will Split Chief and Chairman Jobs
description: Chevron announced Monday that it would separate the positions of chief executive and chairman and make it easier for shareholders to remove directors. The company, based in San Ramon, Calif., said in a public filing that the chairman will now be elected annually by the board. Previously, the oil producers chief executive automatically occupied the role of chairman.

title: Little Miss, Big Hit
description: The backstory of Little Miss Sunshine is being furiously peddled all over town, and it isnt losing any steam. Co-director Valerie Faris mentions that it is weird for a movie about a beauty contest to be in the midst of one itself, and that winning might be a little uncomfortable. Wed like to feel insecure when we go to make our next movie, she said. Losing might be the best things for us.

title: Tabloid Offense
description: Over at the Reeler, someones delicate sensibilities are mortally wounded by a story about Ben Affleck  in the New York Post, of all places. Turns out entertainment reporting is often a crude, morally equivocal pursuit. The horror.

title: Thanks for Nothing
description: Did any of us really expect that a partnership involving names like Geffen, Spielberg and Grey would be anything but a donnybrook waiting to happen? One of the points of contention continues to be Brad Greys decision to say a few words before the premiere of Dreamgirls on both coasts. The Bagger attended the New York event and remembers thinking how nice it was of Mr. Grey to embrace Dreamgirls, a product of David Geffen and his buddies at Dreamworks. Turns out it was a violation of some territorial imperative and that folks are still seething about it.

title: The SAC and Icahn: Different Styles Linked by Investments
description: SAC Capital, the giant hedge fund run by Steven Cohen, has recently invested in some of the same companies as the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, a coincidence that The New York Post said links investors with very different styles.

title: Gold-plated Lunch
description: Think of it as carb-loading for the ego marathon. Yestereday, 140 nominees turned up at the annual Academy Awards lunch at the Beverly Hilton. By tradition, everybody is all smiles and good lucks, while plotting and seeking votes behing the curtains. Monica Almeida, a staff photographer for The New York Times, was there and briefed the Bagger on this years scene.

title: MGIC to Buy Radian for $4.9 Billion
description: MGIC Investment, a Milwaukee-based private mortgage insurer, agreed to buy Radian Group for $4.9 billion in stock. MGIC will exchange 0.9658 share of its stock for each share of Radian, the two companies said Tuesday in a statement. That values Philadelphia-based Radian at $60.78 a share, less than its closing value of $60.84 on the New York Stock Exchange Monday.

title: An Astronauts Alleged Crimes of Passion
description: Well, we just cant ignore this one, and can only surmise  at least at this stage  that the truism holds: love makes you crazy.

title: A Vote to Linger
description: Congressional votes on Iraq have long political shelf lives.

title: War at Home: Resolution Resistance
description: With Senate Republicans blocking a resolution against the Iraq troop build up Monday night, leaders on both sides of the aisle said they would continue talking about ways to deal with the issue.

title: Edwards on Gay Marriage, and Giuliani on Abortion
Hurry Up and Wait
description: House Democrats got off to a blazing start on their agenda, but things are slowing down a bit now.

title: The Money Race
description: Candidates in tight races usually give it their all and then some. Many go to sleep on election night with campaigns deep in debt. But several of last falls losers ended the year with money in the bank, sometimes enough to buy a lot of second-guessing.

title: Thanks and So Long
description: Before we express our appreciation for all the people who made the blog possible, we wanted to ask one last favor of readers, who have been our 12th man this season (please, Texas A&M, dont sue).

title: Marc Jacobs
description: Photos from Marc Jacobs fall 2007 line.

title: Going With the Grain
description: Hudson Baby Bourbon Whiskey (Courtesy of Tuthilltown Spirits).

title: Get Out There and Vote
description: What special election would be complete without last-minute calls to get out the vote?

title: Two Democratic Stars (Who Are Not Clinton or Obama)
description: Scouting the Democratic field for rising stars not named Clinton or Obama: Howard Deans position as the star of the 2003 portion of the 2004 presidential campaign began after he gave a February 2003 speech (which began, What I want to know is why in the world the Democratic party leadership is supporting the presidents unilateral attack on Iraq) at the winter meeting of the Democratic National Committee. David Broder, who wrote some of the most respectful early coverage of the Dean campaign in The Washington Post, uses his column this week to assess the performances of the 2008 crop of candidates at this past weekends winter D.N.C. meeting, four years later.

title: A Fundamental Test
description: Governor Eliot Spitzer said this morning that he considered the choice of the next state comptroller to be a fundamental test. As Albany bureau chief Michael Cooper explains this morning, the Assembly, which controls the process, appears poised to select one of its own, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, to fill the job and replace Alan G. Hevesi, who resigned in disgrace.

title: Whos Next: Hospital Chains
description: This weeks deal to take Triad Hospitals private for $4.7 billion has rekindled speculation about which hospital chains might become targets for buyout firms. Such talk began in earnest last year when HCA agreed to be acquired by a private equity consortium in a $33 billion deal, a transaction that briefly claimed the title of the largest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Forgive Me, Im a Little Nervous
description: Is GoogleTV really around  in beta? Or is it a hoax?

title: Love Scorned! Pepper Spray! A BB Gun! Houston, We Have a Problem.
description: This cannot be a happy day at the NASA press office.

title: Bush Stays True to Self in Budget
description: President Bush released his $2.9 trillion, 2,500-page budget on Monday and, well, its not receiving good reviews from the Democrats. Granted, his budget usually doesnt win much praise from the opposition, but this is the first time the Democrats have the power to do anything about it (though they may have a tough time asserting their own priorities, The Timess Steven R. Weisman writes).

title: Too Big to Rise?
description: The stock market is up so far in 2007, but Howard Silverblatt, Standard & Poors senior equity analyst, points out that the move has come without any help from the five largest compamies in the S.&P. 500, which between then make up 12 percent of the index.

title: Bruno: I Like Tom DiNapoli
description: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno said this morning that his understanding, coming out of the negotiations with the governor over the process for picking the next comptroller, is that the special panel of ex-comptrollers would be picking up to five candidates that the legislature would then choose from.

title: Forecast From Davos: More Media Deals Ahead
description: As moguls and financiers gathered last month in the snowy slopes of Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, they were predicting a flurry of media and entertainment deals. That was one of the findings from a session called The M&A Landscape: Developing the 2007 Heatmap, in which a global collection of bankers, private equity executives and government officials were asked to forecast which industries would see the most deals in each of three regions: the Americas; Europe, the Middle East and Africa; and the Asia Pacific.

title: Friendly Fire  Seen and Heard On Tape
description: Friendly Fire (mp3)In this excerpt, the American fighter pilots realize that theyve fired on friendly troops. (Graphic language has been masked.)

title: Law Firm Facing Gay-Bias Suit Fires Back
description: Forget the reports of rising salaries for law-firm associates. The story that seems to be gripping the corporate law world these days is the escalating battle between white-shoe firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a former associate who claims he was harassed because he is gay. Aaron B. Charney, who until recently worked in the firms mergers and acquisitions practice (ranked No. 2 for merger-advisory work last year), sued the firm last month, accusing several partners of discriminating against him and then papering over his complaints.

title: 2008: Edwards on Health, Campaign Cash
description: The Caucus Question of the Day: Would you be willing to pay higher taxes so that everyone could have health insurance?

title: Big City Mayors With Big Dreams
description: After Rudolph W. Giuliani took one more step  toward running for president, a reader and local history buff, Jeff Wald, e-mailed some trivia about New York City mayors who have run for higher office:

title: Whos Next: Auto-Parts Suppliers
description: With billionaires, hedge funds and private equity firms sifting through the auto-parts industry for bargains, it may not be long until another parts maker attracts a takeover offer. After Lear announced Monday that Carl C. Icahns firm offered to buy it for about $2.4 billion, a Citigroup analyst, John Rogers, offered his list of other suppliers of automotive components that could receive buyout interest. Topping his list were Harman International Industries, with a market capitalization of about $6.4 billion, and Magna International, with a market cap of about $8.7 billion.

title: Fortress Gets Ready to Open the Gates
description: Hedge funds love bold bets, and Fortress Investment Group is no exception. The fund is about to try something no other United States-based hedge fund has done before: an initial public offering. With the I.P.O. expected to price Thursday, Absolute Return writer Michelle Celarier is calling the deal brazen, and not just because of the valuation it puts on the firm. Writing in the magazines February issue, she also notes the I.P.O.s unusual structure, in which she says Fortresss top guys are offloading risk and maintaining voting control through a complicated structure: two classes of shares for a multitiered entity topped by a new holding company in which they have no economic interest.

title: Behind the Scenes With Oscar de la Renta
description: The Timess Eric Wilson interviewed Oscar de la Renta about his process of selecting pieces for his fall 2007 runway collection.

title: The Ladys Desktop Torch
description: Torch singers must have secrets (heroin, violent home lives, sex changes). They cant be American Idol pop n fresh; they cant be frank and forthright and rock n roll.

title: Eliot to Lawmakers: Dont Disappoint Me
description: From a letter that Governor Spitzer just sent to his soon-to-be-former friends on the Legislature:

title: Thomas Weisel C.F.O. to Resign
description: Thomas Weisel Partners, the technology-oriented investment bank that went public a year ago, said that its chief financial officer, Robert K. West, would leave the firm April 6 to pursue other interests. Announcing the move in a regulatory filing Tuesday, the firm did not say when or how it planned to fill the vacancy. Mr. West is just the latest finance chief at a financial firm to try something new. In the past two months or so, Bank of America, Citigroup and Charles Schwab each announced that their finance chief would be leaving the post.

title: Allied Acknowledges Getting Fund Managers Records
description: Hedge-fund manager David Einhorn was looking a lot less paranoid on Tuesday. That is because Allied Capital announced that, contrary its previous denials, someone working for the company had obtained what appeared to be the telephone records of Mr. Einhorn, who has accused Allied of fraud and has sold it shares short for the past five years.

title: Romneys Not-So-Romantic Announcement
description: Were not predicting a particularly romantic Valentines Day for Mitt and Ann Romney. More likely it will be harried and public.

title: Bored and Beautiful: Marc Jacobs
description: Marc Jacobs  always claims he has no real ambition beyond making beautiful clothes for the moment. Yet, to look at his last three shows, with sets by Stefan Beckman and lighting by Jan Kroeze, is to see a designer go beyond the temporal limits of the runway and give clothes the emotional charge of looking at a film or a painting. I suspect that a lot of designers have a movie playing in their heads, and of course many follow contemporary art. But, whether because of a lack of money or imagination, they cant do much more than cite, during the postshow recap, their sources of inspiration.

title: Trailer: Vanguard: Saga of Heroes
description: Pegasus flies through the skies in a scene fromVanguard: Saga of Heroes.

title: The Week Ahead
description: International Herald Tribune managing editor Alison Smale looks ahead at the  events occurring worldwide this week.

title: Deceptive Mortgage Marketing
description: As odd mortgage products have proliferated in recent years, the promotional materials have sometimes made them sound too good to be true. Todays Washington Post has an interesting report  on one such case.

title: The Face-Off Tomorrow
description: The State Assembly just voted to proclaim Feb. 5 through Feb. 9 school counseling week. Oh, and they called for a joint session of the State Legislature to select the next state comptroller for Wednesday afternoon. The vote was 138 to 1.

title: Diaz: Spitzer Letter Unfortunate
description: Assembly Democrats reacted to the governors letter shortly before they went into a meeting Tuesday night.

title: Whither Norma Rae? A Face-Off Over Unionizing Rules
description: A new version of legislation dubbed the Employee Free Choice Act  a bill heavily supported by labor unions that foundered in committee during the last Congress  was introduced in the House last night. At its heart, the measure seeks to amend the National Labor Relations Act and allow for a more efficient system to enable employees to form, join, or assist labor organizations.

title: Senate: Thumbs Down on Budget Plan
description: How do Senate Republicans feel about the governors budget? The Empire Zone is not getting the warm fuzzies after reading through the Senate analysis of Mr. Spitzers first budget, which was posted online this week. A few examples:

title: Blogtalk: Filibuster Debate
description: After the Democrats won control of Congress in November, the questions started in earnest; How would they oppose President Bush on the war in Iraq, the issue on which the president was most vulnerable? The blogs covered every speech, every change in inflection, deriding and praising along partisan lines. And the Republican filibuster Monday, blocking a vote on a relatively bi-partisan, non-binding resolution criticizing the presidents plan to increase troops in Iraq, also brought bloggers into the debate.

title: The Impossibility of February
Marc Jacobs - Fall 2007
description: Reporter Eric Wilson interviews designer Marc Jacobs about his Fall 2007 runway collection.

title: Jobs Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
description: Apples chief, Steven P. Jobs, said record companies should allow songs to be sold online without anticopying software, in part because the technology does not stop piracy.

title: Long Live Mia Farrow
description: Mia Farrow, who has been a passionate advocate for Darfur, turns out to be as exceptional a photographer as she is an actress. Check out her website, MiaFarrow.org, for a haunting collection of photos that she has taken in Darfur and Chad. She also has rare photos of the Janjaweed. Even if youve seen lots of Darfur photos, do go to her site and see these  and weep.

title: Why Im Out of Touch
description: Im in the middle of the Carribbean, speaking on another one of those Geek Cruises. Thats why Im not blogging much this week.

title: Wal-Mart and a Union Unite, at Least on Health Policy
description: They have established one of the fiercest rivalries in the American economy, attacking one anothers organizations through dueling blogs, newspaper advertisements and news conferences.

title: France: Revenue Rises at Ad Agency
description: The Publicis Groupe, the advertising company, said fourth-quarter revenue rose 4.8 percent helped by growth in Europe and gains in North America. Revenue increased to 1.25 billion euros ($1.62 billion), Publicis said. Publicis had $500 million of net new business in the fourth quarter as it won business from Renault, Walt Disney and the Marriott Group, among others. Revenue in Europe was 530 million euros in the fourth quarter, a gain of 5.5 percent, excluding acquisitions and currency swings.

title: Brooklyn: New Charges Against Bonanno Family
description: Federal prosecutors unveiled racketeering charges yesterday against 19 people they said were members of the Bonanno crime family. The indictment, unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court, includes charges of racketeering, conspiracy to commit murder, loan sharking and drug offenses, federal prosecutors said. One suspect is Nicholas Santora, above, described as the acting underboss, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. All 19 pleaded not guilty yesterday, prosecutors said. Ms. Mauskopf said that as part of an ongoing investigation, more than 100 Bonanno family members and associates have been prosecuted.

title: Rodriguez Avoids a High-and-Tight Pitch
description: It seemed like a harmless enough event for Alex Rodriguez  a book signing for his new childrens book at a Barnes & Noble store in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Before the Wall Fell, a Kafkaesque Nightmare
description: Nina Toussaint and Massimo Iannettas 2003 documentary, The Decomposition of the Soul, would make a reasonable double bill with the forthcoming fiction film The Lives of Others. Both films tackle the still unsettling topic of the East German Stasi, the fearsome secret police that, under the auspices of the Ministry for State Security and armed with the foreboding motto Shield and Sword of the Party, kept the populace in check for decades, often by forcing ordinary people to spy against one another. Both might also make your flesh crawl, though perhaps for different reasons.

title: Zuckers Bumpy Ride to the Top
description: In announcing the appointment yesterday of Jeff Zucker as the president and chief executive of NBC Universal, his boss at General Electric said that what could have been Mr. Zuckers biggest vulnerability  NBCs plunge in prime-time ratings starting three years ago while he led the companys television group  had actually worked to his advantage.

title: Pipeline Company Settles Charges Involving Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 7  The El Paso Corporation, the largest American natural gas pipeline operator, agreed today to pay the federal government $7.73 million to settle allegations that it was involved in illegal payments under the United Nations-run oil-for-food program in Iraq.

title: Ousted Pastor Completely Heterosexual
description: Forced by a gay sex scandal to resign as president of the National Association of Evangelicals, the Rev. Ted Haggard now feels that after three weeks of intensive counseling, he is completely heterosexual, says an overseer of the megachurch Mr. Haggard once led.

title: Bridging Gaps Early On in Oklahoma
description: TULSA, Okla.

title: Bronx: Man Fatally Shot
description: An unidentified man was fatally shot on a Bronx street last night, the police said. The man, who investigators said appeared to be in his mid-20s, had multiple gunshot wounds in his chest when he was found about 8:30 p.m. in front of 1415 Burke Avenue in Eastchester. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Jacobi Medical Center. Witnesses said they saw a man wearing blue jeans flee the scene of the shooting in a two-door black sedan.

title: Iraqi Premier Admits Errors in Introducing Security Plan in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 6  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki acknowledged for the first time on Tuesday that his government had stumbled in its efforts to carry out a new security plan in Baghdad and that the delays and mounting violence were hurting its credibility with the Iraqi people.

title: Canada: Finance Executive to Leave Nortel
description: The chief financial officer of Nortel Networks, Peter Currie, who rejoined the company in 2005 to help it recover from accounting problems, will step down on April 30. Nortel, the maker of phone equipment, said it had begun seeking a successor. Mr. Currie decided to pursue other interests, a spokesman, Jay Barta, said. Mr. Currie was chief financial officer from 1994 to early 1997 before leaving to become chief financial officer at the Royal Bank of Canada.

title: Indonesians Still Seeking High Ground
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 6  Strings of bright laundry hang among the gravestones and people who are brave enough sleep among the dead, taking refuge on the high ground of the Karet cemetery from the worst flooding in Jakarta in decades.

title: Seven Killed as U.S. Copter Crashes in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 7  Seven people were killed Wednesday when a Marine transport helicopter crashed into an insurgent-heavy region northwest of Baghdad. It was at least the fifth American military or security helicopter to crash or be shot down since mid-January.

title: Manhattan: City Opens More Warming Centers
description: Responding to cold temperatures, the city has opened nine warming centers and doubled outreach by workers from the Department of Homeless Services, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The city chose the locations for the centers, which are operated in cooperation with the Red Cross, based on the volume of 311 calls, the mayor said. He advised people without heat to stay with relatives or friends if possible.

title: NASA to Review Astronaut Screening
description: NASA officials said today they will review their psychological screening process in the wake of an astronauts arrest Monday on charges she tried to murder a woman she believed was her romantic rival for a fellow astronauts affections.

title: Cabinet Members Go to Congress to Push the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  One day after the Bush administration proposed deep cuts in domestic spending, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. told Democratic critics in Congress on Tuesday that the proposals for Medicare and Social Security were a starting point for a discussion and could be revised.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,091 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: A Big Bargain in the Diamond District
description: TAAM-TOV is the best deal on a street where you can end up spending a fortune. Perched two floors above 47th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, its smack in the middle of the diamond district.

title: Court Approves Class-Action Suit Against Wal-Mart
description: Wal-Marts efforts to block the nations largest sex discrimination lawsuit suffered a big setback yesterday when a federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled that the case should proceed as a class action.

title: Army Is Going Wrinkle-Free; Velcro Becomes Norm
description: FORT LEWIS, Wash., Feb. 5  Besides the hidden slots for knee and elbow pads, the extra room in the shoulders and the mod mandarin collar, the new Army uniform has a revolutionary feature critical to a nimbler military.

title: Samsung to Pay $90 Million in Chip Price Case
description: Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the worlds largest maker of memory chips, agreed yesterday to pay $90 million to settle civil charges that it conspired with six other makers of computer chips to fix prices, the attorneys general of 41 states announced.

title: U.S. to Create a Single Command for Military Operations in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The Pentagon will establish a new military command to oversee its operations in Africa, President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced Tuesday.

title: Timberlake, Pop Juggernaut, Is Gaining Some Unusual Fans
description: He won over the teeny-boppers long ago, but in his incarnation as a sexy-smooth crooner with a hip-hop edge, Justin Timberlake has gained some unusual fans: hipsters.

title: Government Inside Out
description: The United States is quickly becoming a government of the contractors, by the contractors and for the contractors. While the private security personnel in Iraq have attracted the most attention, many day-to-day operations are no longer in the hands of federal employees. Functions as disparate as clerical work and tax collection are handled by private companies, while oversight of this always for-profit work is being sorely neglected.

title: Canada: Military Inquiry of Afghan Abuse Claims
description: Defense Minister Gordon OConnor said the military was investigating allegations that at least one prisoner, and perhaps three, were beaten in Afghanistan while in Canadian custody last April.

title: Germany Relives 1970s Terror as 2 Seek Release From Jail
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 6  Thirty years ago this October, the leaders of the Baader-Meinhof gang committed suicide in their high-security German prison cells, putting a bloody exclamation mark on an anarchic season of kidnappings and killings now known as the German autumn.

title: From Spaceflight to Attempted Murder Charge
description: Like most of todays astronauts, Lisa Marie Nowak worked in relative obscurity  even last July, when she took the spaceflight that she had spent 10 years at NASA hoping for.

title: U.S. Military Contractors Seek Deals at Bangalore Air Show
description: BANGALORE, India, Feb. 6  Encouraged by the passage late last year of the first agreement on nuclear cooperation between India and the United States, American military contractors and technology companies have flocked to the technology hub of Bangalore this week in the hope of winning some of the biggest military contracts.

title: Challenging the Mullahs, One Signature at a Time
description: Well-behaved women rarely make history, my favorite bumper sticker says. It surely applies to Shirin Ebadi, the Iranian lawyer and 2003 Nobel Peace Prize winner whose relentless campaign against discrimination has enraged the mullahs for more than 25 years.

title: M. Lamar Muse, 86, Dies; Led Southwest Airlines
description: M. Lamar Muse, the first president of Southwest Airlines and a pioneer of airline deregulation, died Monday in Dallas. He was 86.

title: Conservatory Tries to Raise Its Profile
description: The views are stunning from this 1,500-square-foot terrace.

title: What You Get for... Under $150,000
description: Orlando, Fla.

title: Federal Law Drains Resources for the Gifted
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.

title: Hamas and Fatah Promise to Reach Compromise
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia Feb. 7  The leaders of the two main Palestinian political groups ended their first day of an emergency summit meeting on Wednesday promising to stay until they agree on a new government to end a wave of violence in Gaza and the West Bank and salvage the moribund Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: Tape Recounts U.S. Attack That Killed British Soldier
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  The videotape is jolting enough, but it is the audio portion  the conversation between two American pilots in Iraq  that is most unnerving.

title: China Says Rich Countries Should Take Lead on Global Warming
description: BEIJING, Feb. 6  China said Tuesday that wealthier countries must take the lead in curbing greenhouse gas emissions and refused to say whether it would agree to any mandatory emissions limits that might hamper its booming economy.

title: Under the Radar but Well Worth Their Grammy Invitations
description: ON the Grammy Awards telecast Sunday night on CBS, many musicians names will flash by just before commercials: the winners in dozens of categories that dont fit in prime time. The Grammys try to notice every niche of popular music and, with 108 categories this year, they cant keep up. But they do delve well beyond the Top 10 and the familiar names on the television show. Im not picking winners here. The Grammys are inscrutable, especially in categories with only a coterie of voters, but these nominated albums and songs deserve their instant of Grammy attention.

title: U.S. Military Contractors Seek Deals at Bangalore Air Show
description: BANGALORE, India, Feb. 6  Encouraged by the passage late last year of the first agreement on nuclear cooperation between India and the United States, American military contractors and technology companies have descended on Bangalore, the countrys technology hub, this week in the hope of winning some of the biggest military contracts.

title: Keeping the Fruits of Research Close to Home in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  In the late 1990s, Dr. William H. Danforth, chancellor emeritus of Washington University here, watched as a faculty member in the universitys engineering department tried to market an innovative device  a switch to speed transactions on the Internet  that had emerged out of a research project.

title: Early Morning House Fire Leaves 10 Dead in Kentucky
description: BARDSTOWN, Ky., Feb. 6  A fast-moving fire engulfed a house here early Tuesday, killing 10 people, including 6 children, and injuring 2 others, the authorities said.

title: Drug Treatment Is Cheaper Than Prisons (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Federation Says Success Is Best Way to Promote U.S. Stars
description: More than 50,000 tickets have been sold, and a sellout is expected, for tonights exhibition match between the United States and Mexico at University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz. And although the match is called a friendly, games between the two powerhouse nations in the region are usually everything but.

title: Russia Tycoon May Talk to Police on Poisoning
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  Boris A. Berezovsky, an exiled Russian tycoon and bitter opponent of the Kremlin, said Monday that he was prepared to be interviewed by the Russian police investigating the poisoning in London last November of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a dissident former K.G.B. agent he had advised and financed.

title: Keeping a Home Secure, From Afar
description: Alison Mattus clients want to keep an eye on their Florida vacation homes, even though some live as far away as Britain.

title: In Court, as on Gambling Floor, Casinos Have the Better Odds
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.

title: When Boy Meets Gay Hustler, Some Personal Truths Are Sure to Emerge
description: American plays have imparted many a life lesson over the past century. We have learned that attention must be paid to salesmen, for instance, and that depending on the kindness of strangers is not a workable strategy, particularly in New Orleans.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the availability of consumer-help features on the Internet misstated the address of one such site. It is GetRichSlowly.org, not GetRichSlowly.com.

title: White House Bid? Giuliani Is Still Undeclared
description: Former Senator John Edwards stood in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans and declared, Im a candidate for the presidency of the United States. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proclaimed on her campaign Web site: Im in. And Im in to win. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts plans to formally announce his White House run in Michigan on Feb. 13.

title: Pure or Molten, Chocolate Prepares for Its Day
description: Kathy Moskals quest to find a line of fine minimally sweetened chocolates led her to become a chocolate expert and start her own line. Her one-year-old company, Vere (pronounced ver-EE), specializes in chocolates for people who like theirs on the bitter side. They are sweetened with crystalline fructose and agave nectar, not refined cane sugar.

title: Assembly Calls for a Vote on a Comptroller Today
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  It was just a few weeks ago that Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver stood beside Gov. Eliot Spitzer to announce, with great fanfare, their agreement that an outside panel should screen the candidates who wanted to succeed Alan G. Hevesi as state comptroller after he had confessed to a felony and resigned in disgrace.

title: The Best Town to Make an Upper Lip Stiff
description: LONDON is the best cocktail city in the world right now, Audrey Saunders said. I hate to admit it, but its true.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about the tense relationship between DreamWorks and Paramount misidentified an actor in the film Transformers. He is Shia LaBeouf  not Sam Witwicky, Mr. LaBeoufs character.

title: Baghdad Day to Day: Librarians Journal
description: Saad Eskander, the director of Iraqs National Library and Archive in Baghdad, finally had some time to catch up on his diary after a couple of very busy weeks. As he wrote in his latest entry, he was having trouble repairing the Internet system; the Restoration Laboratory was hit by 5 bullets; and another librarian, who works at the Periodical Department, received a death threat. He has to leave his house and look for another one, as soon as he can; otherwise, he will be murdered.

title: More on Child Development
description: The best overview of the research on early childhood that Ive seen is a book called What Children Need, by Jane Waldfogel. Shes a professor at Columbia Universitys School of Social Work.

title: Searching, and Finding, in Costly London
description: LONDON  Siri Eklund looked at 54 apartments here before finding one with a perk that she simply could not resist: proximity to Britains first Whole Foods supermarket, scheduled to open in June.

title: Heres a Risky Pickup Line: Im Obsessed With Annie Hall
description: Its strangely fitting that Woody Allens Annie Hall, a thoroughly postmodern romantic comedy, would inspire an entire movie about a young man obsessed with Annie Hall. Titled Burning Annie, the film is a soup-to-nuts homage that makes references not just to the originals story, characters and tone, but also to specific jokes and shots, including a straight-into-the-camera narration.

title: In a Bottle, the Scent of a Mouse
description: I MADE my first rice wines last week, and they werent nearly as bad as I expected. I didnt attempt homebrew versions of Chinese jiu or Japanese sake. My rice wines were a storebought sauvignon blanc and a chenin blanc into which I threw some rice. I dont think grain-infused wine will ever catch on as an alternative to a kir or sangria (though these days you never know). But I was relieved that it didnt remind me of Billy Goodmans pet mice.

title: Hawaiian Music Star, Maker of Hybrid Hits, Seeks a Bigger Stage Beyond Waikiki
description: HONOLULU  Henry Kapono spends most Sunday afternoons here, on the beachfront patio of Dukes Waikiki restaurant at the Outrigger Waikiki hotel. His standing engagement has become something of an island institution over the years. Its a bar gig, maybe not what you might expect from a Hawaiian music veteran of Mr. Kaponos stature. But he throws himself into it nonetheless, routinely playing for two hours without a break, to stoke the fires of a dancing-and-drinking crowd.

title: Fight Over Pay Causes Some Judges to Sit Out Cases Involving Legislator-Lawyers
description: Now that some New York State judges have sued the Legislature for pay raises, a handful of them are refusing to hear cases in which clients are represented by lawyers who are legislators or their law firms.

title: Amazon and TiVo in Venture to Put Downloaded Videos on TV
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6  Amazon.com, the online retail giant, and TiVo, pioneer of the digital video recorder, are teaming up to help downloaded movies and TV shows make the leap to television screens.

title: Mackerel: Good Eating, and a Looker
description: MACKEREL is one of the loveliest of fishes, one of the tastiest, one of the cheapest and one that is still plentiful. Yet its scorned by nearly everyone, considered too strong-flavored, oily and, well, fishy.

title: Cleaner Shopping Carts Are Bills Goal
description: When he was campaigning for office last fall, Fred Allen, a freshman Arkansas legislator from Little Rock, heard from a number of older women who were afraid to go to the grocery store because of what might lurk on their shopping cart handles.
