description: The feverish competition over Equity Office Properties Trust, the nations largest office landlord, appeared to be nearing an end yesterday, with the original suitor, the Blackstone Group, leading the bidding.

title: For the Record
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the high cost of minting pennies and nickels, misidentified a country that has stopped making its smallest coins; it was Australia, not Canada. The article also misstated the countries within the European Union that had stopped minting their smallest coins. Only two countries, Finland and the Netherlands, have done so; not all countries that use the euro have abolished their smallest coins.

title: Sather Not Ready to Let Messier Have His Job
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 6  Glen Sather, the Rangers president and general manager, said Tuesday that he had no plans to step down in the near future and would not specifically discuss comments by Mark Messier that he hoped to take Sathers place at the helm of the Rangers.

title: Racial Gains on the Sidelines, a Message for the Polls
description: While people fussed over Super Bowl commercials that ranged from crass to droll, the most touching was the Frito-Lay spot that showed African-Americans intently following the Colts-Bears game.

title: No Action From Gallaudet Against Arrested Students
description: Gallaudet University said it would not take disciplinary action against students arrested in protests that forced the ouster in October of its chosen president. No student who was arrested will receive additional punishment, Robert R. Davila, the interim president, said in a video on the universitys Web site. But arrested students may face job-related consequences if they work at the Clerc Center, where Gallaudet helps develop teaching strategies for deaf children, said Mercy Coogan, a university spokeswoman. And Mr. Davilas statement did not preclude the possibility of university sanctions against students involved in the protests but not arrested, Ms. Coogan said.

title: House Panel Questions Monitoring of Cash Shipped to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A House committee report on Tuesday questioned whether some of the billions of dollars in cash shipped to Iraq after the American invasion  mostly in huge, shrink-wrapped stacks of $100 bills  might have ended up with the insurgent groups now battling American troops.

title: Spitzer Reappoints Kaye as States Top Judge
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer today nominated Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye to continue serving as the states chief judge when her current term ends next month.

title: Edwardss Bloggers Cross the Line, Critic Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Two bloggers hired by John Edwards to reach out to liberals in the online world have landed his presidential campaign in hot water for doing what bloggers do  expressing their opinions in provocative and often crude language.

description: Shockingly, there was a fashion show this week to which Tinsley Mortimer was not invited. To be honest, there were a few.

description: THOSE who closely watched the finale of the television series Top Chef last week probably came away from it with a vexing question: What is Surinam cherry?

title: Iraqi Lawmaker Was Convicted in 1983 Bombings in Kuwait That Killed 5
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 5  A sitting member of Parliament was convicted more than two decades ago of planning the attacks on the American and French Embassies in Kuwait that left five Kuwaitis dead in 1983, Iraqi and American officials said Tuesday.

description: LONDON, Feb. 7  A British court today ordered the release of two men arrested last week as suspects in a terror plot that the authorities said involved kidnapping a British Muslim soldier and broadcasting video images of his killing on the Internet.

title: As Inflation Soars, Zimbabwe Economy Plunges
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 6  For close to seven years, Zimbabwes economy and quality of life have been in slow, uninterrupted decline. They are still declining this year, people there say, with one notable difference: the pace is no longer so slow.

title: Nigerias Antigraft Agency Blocks Candidates
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 7  More than 130 candidates who are running for various posts in Nigerias next election, scheduled for April, are unfit for office because of serious corruption allegations, Nigerias antigraft agency declared on Tuesday.

title: Riverhead: Former School Official Sentenced
description: A former school administrator was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to two to six years in prison, a result of his guilty plea last year to stealing from the William Floyd School District in Brookhaven and the state retirement fund, prosecutors said. The former administrator, Daniel Cifonelli, 72, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and money laundering, said a spokesman for Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney. A former district treasurer, James Wright, 58, of Bohemia, is awaiting sentencing for stealing district funds.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday about a butterfly missing from a cast-iron statue of Cupid that was on display at the Young Collectors Night party, at the Annual Winter Antiques Show, misstated the name of the organization for which the party was held as a benefit. It is the East Side House Settlement, not the East Side Settlement House.

title: Muslims Protest as Israel Digs at Jerusalem Shrine
description: Israel began excavation work near Jerusalems most fiercely contested religious shrine, drawing Palestinian protests. Israel insisted that it was just replacing a damaged walkway and that the work would not harm the site in the Old City, known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount. Palestinian religious leaders condemned the excavation, taking place about 50 yards outside the hilltop mosque compound, which is built atop the ruins of the biblical Jewish temples. Nothing in the work touches the wall of the Temple Mount, said Gideon Avni of Israels Antiquities Authority. We are not hiding anything.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPEN NOW

title: In Midwest, a Bitter Turn in a Temperate Winter
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6  The winter that seemed as though it would never arrive finally struck in full, uncomfortable force on Tuesday, and it showed signs of lingering.

title: Southampton: Funds for Landfill Cleanup
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday that the state had obtained more than $1.5 million from 29 private and public groups to pay for the cleanup of the North Sea Landfill in Southampton. The town, with partial financing from the state, cleaned up the landfill in the mid-1990s. After an investigation, state lawyers identified groups that had disposed of waste in the landfill since it opened in 1963, Mr. Cuomo said. Under the agreement, the groups will pay $1,575,000 to the state Superfund, to help pay for other cleanups, he said.

description: LONDON  I like a challenge, said Johan Kobborg, backstage at the Royal Opera House, where he is a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet.

title: Right Candidates, Wrong Question
description: EVEN before Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton threw their exploratory committees into the ring, every reporter seemed to be asking which candidate are Americans more ready for, a white woman or a black man?

title: Playing Politics With Justice
description: The Bush administration has pushed out at least seven United States attorneys recently for what appear to be purely political reasons. Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, has opened an investigation, and not a moment too soon. The American justice system would be seriously damaged if United States attorneys were stripped of their independence.

title: Queens: Fire Damages Concrete Plant
description: A fire that required more than three hours of effort by 85 firefighters to be extinguished heavily damaged a concrete-mixing plant in Long Island City yesterday afternoon, fire officials said. They said the fire appeared to have started about 3 p.m. near a conveyor area before spreading to the rest of the factory, which is owned by the Nycon Supply Corporation, at 47-17 27th Street. One firefighter suffered a minor injury to his knee, said Edward Kilduff, an assistant fire chief. Chief Kilduff said the fire did not seem suspicious, and added, Were assuming its electrical in nature.

title: Advanced Placement Tests Are Leaving Some Behind
description: More high schools across the nation are offering Advanced Placement courses to help students get into college and get ready for its academic rigors. In the process, however, many minority students who often need help most urgently are missing out.

title: S.& P. Buys 3 Indexes
description: The Standard & Poors unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies agreed to buy the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index and two other products from Goldman Sachs Group, S.& P. said.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by Microsoft not to intervene on behalf of a Russian school principal charged with software piracy misstated the name of a trade organization that has monitored the use of illicit software. It is the Business Software Alliance, not the Business Software Association.

title: Mexico: Acapulco Gunmen Attack Police, Killing 7
description: Commandos armed with machine guns and dressed in khaki with red berets invaded two police stations in Acapulco, leaving seven officers dead. The invaders were believed to be the hired guns of drug smugglers. The attacks took place on the same day that a police commander in Sinoloa State, Jorge Valdez Fierro, was killed in his car by gunmen. President Felipe Caldern has sent thousands of troops and federal agents into both areas to rein in drug-gang violence.

description: MARIO BATALI was supposed to cut off the pigs head.

title: Man Who Gives Support Finds There Is Some for Him
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.  Over the past 30 years, the slow creep of multiple sclerosis has cost Bill Ferrer his business, his ability to walk, and ultimately his ability to live unaided.

title: Video Gear Helps to Lift Ciscos Profit and Shares
description: The Internet equipment maker Cisco Systems reported a 36 percent jump in profit in its second fiscal quarter yesterday, benefiting from growing demand for bigger, faster networks that can handle video.

title: Libby Speaks on Tape, but May Not in Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The jurors deciding the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. listened to his voice on audiotape for hours on Tuesday as his lawyers quietly explored a surprise strategy, keeping him off the witness stand, that would ensure that the jurors never hear his voice in person.

title: Ford Will Resurrect the Taurus Brand
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 6  The Ford Taurus, the car credited with reinvigorating American automotive design two decades ago before falling into virtual irrelevance by the time it was retired last year, is coming back to life.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 9 about the problems of a Coast Guard modernization project called Deepwater and its management by the defense contractors Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin incorrectly described a campaign in mid-2005 by the Navy League, a nonprofit group, in support of the project. The organization wrote letters to lawmakers urging them to restore funds for the program; the group says it did not remind them that hundreds of contractors across the country were working as suppliers on the project. The error was pointed out by the Navy League shortly after the article appeared, and again on Jan. 2. This correction was delayed because those responsible initially decided no correction was warranted and were slow to follow up on additional complaints.

title: Rural Colleges Seek New Edge and Urbanize
description: CONWAY, Ark.  Across from the red-brick Collegiate Gothic campus of Hendrix College in central Arkansas lie a few beat-up ball fields, tennis courts and an expanse of woods. Downtown Conway is only a half-dozen blocks away, but it is not overflowing with amenities, as Frank H. Cox, a member of the Hendrix board of trustees, diplomatically put it.

title: A Football Standouts Final Uniform Is Red, the Color of His Gang
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 6  At a funeral visitation Saturday at Fairview Baptist Church here, nearly 1,000 mourners gathered to pay final respects to Mandrell Dean.

title: Back on the Road, Tracking the Red, White and Odd
description: Do not flinch if an alien approaches. Their pale, elongated bodies and big, shiny eyes take some getting used to, but extraterrestrials mix well with Earth people and share many of the same tastes. The members of one colony, sponsored by the C.I.A., spoke English and enjoyed chaperoned trips to Las Vegas. They liked to go for entertainment in casinos, a U.F.O. buff tells Louis Theroux. Theyre just like we are.

title: For Budget, Spitzer Is Seeking Corporate Allies
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer turned to New Yorks top business leaders yesterday to build support for the health care overhaul, school aid increases and property tax reductions in his $120.6 billion budget.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Ralph de Toledano, a conservative columnist and author, incorrectly described his relationship with his contemporary at Columbia, the Trappist monk and writer Thomas Merton. Merton was a fellow student of Mr. Toledano, not his teacher.

title: An Indulgence for a Wine That Asks for Hearty Meat
description: AMARONES take no prisoners. You want subtlety and grace? Talk to the folks who make red wine in the Alto Adige, and find yourself a veal roast to cook. Amarones are all about depth, tannins, earth, tar and black truffles. If you plan to open one for dinner, you might as well go into the woods and shoot a wild boar.

title: Public Television Plans a Network for Latinos
description: In a move to take public broadcasting closer to Spanish-speaking viewers, executives are expected to announce today that a new network, V-me, will go on the air on March 5 in major American cities with large Latino populations. It will offer a mix of Spanish-language childrens and adult programming with an educational focus.

title: Europe Compromises With Automakers on Carbon Limits
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 6  The European Commission on Wednesday will unveil a compromise proposal on limiting emissions from new passenger cars, in a battle that has pitted Europes ambitious environmental goals against some of the worlds biggest carmakers.

description: A CRAVING that Americans share, to the exclusion of the rest of the world, is a penchant for cold cereal at dinner.

title: Frankie Laine, 93, the Hit-Making Crooner Who Used His Voice Like a Horn, Is Dead
description: Frankie Laine, a singer who achieved enormous popularity in the 1940s and 50s with a robust voice and a string of hits including Thats My Desire, Mule Train, Ghost Riders in the Sky and Jezebel, died on Tuesday in San Diego. He was 93.

title: Techies Cyber Odyssey: Magic in Bits and Bolts
description: I know what Microsoft wants. I know because I have been exploring its new operating system, Vista, which was released last week after five years of false starts, persistent bugs and great expectations. I also know because after spending three weeks building a computer from scratch to test out Vista, piecing the PC together from parts bought online, I want the same thing. What we want is to eliminate the PC altogether, to dismantle that box of green circuit boards and crammed-in wires, to break through even the most glorious flat-screen monitor and open up a new ... vista.

title: From Searing Flames, a Bleak, Cold Landscape
description: There is no cold like the cold after a big New York City fire. The flames take everything that is soft and warm, and then they take the walls and the roof, letting in the black winter sky and the wind off the water so cold it sears before it numbs.

title: For Many Colonial-Era Walls, No Tumbling Is Allowed
description: REDDING, Conn.  Across New England, the past is preserved in fieldstone walls, stacked by the hands of colonial farmers and worn down by the wind and rain. In few places is this more so than in this southern Connecticut town, where in some spots stones must go unturned unless the authorities give written permission.

title: N.Y. Assembly Democrats Settle on Comptroller
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7  The Democratic-led State Assembly dealt a setback today to Gov. Eliot Spitzer by agreeing to elect Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli as the next state comptroller, reneging on a deal it made with the governor to choose only from candidates deemed qualified by an outside screening panel.

title: To Sell Trucks, Toyota Shuns the Subtle
description: WITH its new full-size Tundra pickup, Toyota is not simply moving forward, as the automakers advertising slogan asserts. It is taking its product and marketing strategy in a new direction.

title: Indonesia May Sell, Not Give, Bird Flu Virus to Scientists
description: Indonesia, which has had more human cases of avian flu than any other country, has stopped sending samples of the virus to the World Health Organization, apparently because it is negotiating a contract to sell the samples to an American vaccine company, a W.H.O. official said yesterday.

title: 3rd Letter Bomb Explodes in Britain in 3 Days
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  A letter bomb exploded at Britains drivers licensing agency today, extending what the police depicted as a coordinated series of attacks that has troubled the nations leaders and inspired comparisons with the Unabomber in the United States.

title: A Tribe Dreams of a Casino, and of a Less Spartan Life
description: SEA BREEZE, N.J.  It is unlikely but not impossible that a tiny band of American Indians could open a huge casino complex 10 miles north of the George Washington Bridge.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) LOST Season 3 of the series picks up where it left off in November  with Bens (Michael Emerson) life literally resting in Jacks (Matthew Fox) hands. Meanwhile, Kate (Evangeline Lilly) and Sawyer (Josh Holloway) find an ally in one of the Others, and Juliet (Elizabeth Mitchell) makes a decision that could endanger her standing with her people.

title: Minor Milestones Add Up for Knicks
description: They celebrated an evening of modest achievements at Madison Square Garden last night, and really, for the Knicks there is no other kind.

title: Illinois Has Rivals Fuming About Its Recruiting Coup
description: Illinois, one of the worst teams among the major conferences in college football in recent seasons, has astounded experts and enraged rivals by putting together one of the nations best recruiting classes.

title: Lawsuit Reveals Many Rifts in a Villages Police Force
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6  For the past two years, tension has pervaded police headquarters in Harrison, N.Y., a tranquil Westchester County community of emerald lawns and $3 million homes where crime is scarce.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Eric von Schmidt, an influential folksinger, misspelled part of the name of the country music show that kindled his interest in music when he listened to it on the radio. It is the Grand Ole Opry, not Grande.

title: New Jersey Senate Passes Tax Plan, Ending Impasse
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6  The New Jersey Senate found itself in an unenviable spot on Tuesday morning.

title: Toyota Reports Record Profits and Sales in 4th Quarter
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6  Another quarter of record profits and sales released Tuesday by Toyota Motor painted a picture of a company whose momentum is pushing it into a virtuous cycle and relentlessly closer to becoming the No. 1 global auto company, analysts said.

title: Manhattan: Vertical Hour to Close Early
description: The Vertical Hour, David Hares play about the political divide between Americans and the British, will close on March 11, three weeks earlier than scheduled. The play, directed by Sam Mendes and starring Julianne Moore and Bill Nighy, opened at the Music Box Theater on Nov. 30 to reviews that ranged from glowing to glum. Weekly grosses dwindled in January, a hard time for most Broadway shows. A spokesman for the show wrote in an e-mail message that Hour was still expected to recoup its original investment.

title: Weight-Loss Drug to Be Sold Over the Counter
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first officially sanctioned weight-loss drug that will be sold without a prescription.

title: Koreans Share Their Secret for Chicken With a Crunch
description: WHEN Joe McPherson moved to Seoul in 2002, he thought he was leaving fried chicken behind. I grew up watching Popeyes training videos, Mr. McPherson said. His father managed a Popeyes franchise near Atlanta and fried chicken was a constant presence in his life.

title: S.E.C. Query to Adobe
description: Adobe Systems, which makes design software, said yesterday that it had received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission asking for more information about its stock option practices.

title: The Unseen and Unexplained, Inching Closer to the Truth
description: Anyone who thinks its a good sign that Lost is back has not spent enough time at the Web site of James Randi, a skeptical scholar of the pseudoscientific and the supernatural.

title: Suicide Bomber Dies at Airport in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 6  A suicide bomber armed with pistols and grenades killed himself and at least one other person after a shootout with security guards at Islamabads international airport on Tuesday night, in what the police described as a thwarted but brazen terrorist attack.

title: Two American Buyers Purchase Liverpool Club
description: Two American businessmen and sports team owners  Tom Hicks and George Gillett  completed yesterday a $340 million acquisition of the Liverpool club of the English Premier League.

title: Marc Jacobs: Beautiful and a Little Bored
description: Marc Jacobs always claims he has no real ambition beyond making beautiful clothes for the moment, and because he demonstrates this on a fairly regular basis, we must assume his thinking is as simple as that.

title: Democrat Wins Senate Seat on Long Island
description: Democrats captured a traditionally Republican State Senate seat on Long Island yesterday, winning the costliest battle for a state legislative seat in New York history in a fight that became a test of Gov. Eliot Spitzers political muscle.

description: Time: 15 minutes

title: George Kaiser Speech on Childhood Education
description: The following speech was given by George Kaiser, a Tulsa billionaire whose foundation finances early-education programs, in Chicago on April 28, 2005.

title: Cruise Line to Lady Liberty Is Up for Bid, With Caveats
description: For tourists who huddle in Battery Park on summer days, getting to the Statue of Liberty is no luxury cruise.

title: Bronx: Guilty Plea in Killing of Two Men
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court in connection with the fatal shootings of two men during a 2003 robbery. The man, Marlon Henry, was charged in the killings of Robert Melendez, 24, who had just completed a tour of duty with the Army in Iraq, and Kristopher Jimenez, 18, during a robbery in the courtyard at the Boston Secor Houses in Edenwald, prosecutors said. A second assailant, Apolinar Roque, 22, of the Bronx, has also pleaded guilty to manslaughter, prosecutors said. Mr. Henry is expected to be sentenced to 29 years in prison and Mr. Roque to 25 years, prosecutors said.

title: What the Egg Was First
description: DAN BARBER had a culinary epiphany in Italy a couple of months ago over a plate of tagliatelle, one that sent him running back to his kitchen in an experimental mode. When he inquired about the pasta, he was told that its secret ingredient, what made it especially absorbent, were the eggs. But these were something quite different from the ordinary kitchen staples that come 12 to a cardboard carton.

title: Its the War, Senators
description: It is not an inspiring sight to watch the United States Senate turn the most important issue facing America into a political football, and then fumble it. Yet that is what now seems to have come from a once-promising bipartisan effort to finally have the debate about the Iraq war that Americans have been denied for four years.

title: A U.S. Attorney Was Removed Without Cause, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A top Justice Department official said on Tuesday that one of several United States attorneys forced from their jobs last year was dismissed without a specific cause in order to give the job to a lawyer with close political ties to the White House.

title: A New Boss at NBC, and Even Newer Issues
description: Jeff Zucker, who was named the new chief executive of NBC Universal today, succeeding Bob Wright, has completed one of the most spectacular ascents of any recent media executive: from part-time sports researcher in 1986 to corporate C.E.O. two decades later.

title: Rell Proposes More Money for Schools and Tax Increases
description: Months after a decisive victory in her bid for re-election, Gov. M. Jodi Rell on proposed increasing education spending by $3.4 billion over the next five years and increasing the states income tax by half a percent over the next two years to pay for it.

title: David W. Denton, Former Federal Prosecutor, Dies at 57
description: David W. Denton, once the third-ranking prosecutor in the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, died Monday. He was 57.

title: Lyrics and Diaries Offered as a Portrait of a Killer
description: Prosecutors introduced about 50 pages of diaries and song lyrics yesterday that exposed years of thoughts about love, heartbreak, sex and violent death written by Paul Cortez, a personal trainer accused of killing a dancer who spurned him.

title: Jobs Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6  Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, jolted the record industry on Tuesday by calling on its largest companies to allow online music sales unfettered by antipiracy software.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: France: 58 Nations Vow to End Use of Child Soldiers
description: Representatives of 58 countries signed a nonbinding accord not to use children under 18 in wars. The accord came at the close of a two-day conference in Paris organized by Unicef and the French Foreign Ministry. Signers included 10 of 12 countries identified by the United Nations as places where child soldiers are used. They were Burundi, Chad, Colombia, Congo, Ivory Coast, Nepal, Somalia, Sri Lanka, Sudan and Uganda. Myanmar and the Philippines, also on the list, did not take part in the conference. The meeting heard an appeal from Ishmael Beah, above, who fought in Sierra Leones civil war as a teenager. Mr. Beah, now 26, a New York resident and the author of A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier, was rehabilitated with help from Unicef.

title: Fatah and Hamas Leaders Meet Saudi King for Peace Talks
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 6  Leaders of the two main Palestinian parties, Hamas and Fatah, on Tuesday began a two-day Saudi-brokered effort to agree on a unity government that could end a wave of violence in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank and resume relations with donor countries.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about Roy Kuhlman, a graphics designer for Grove Press who was noted for his abstract work, misspelled the given name of an abstract artist who was a friend of Barney Rosset, publisher of Grove Press. He was Willem de Kooning, not Wilhelm.

title: Hollywood Takes Its Concerns About Piracy and Taxes to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Hollywood has often been a whipping boy here, but with a new Congress in session, the heads of the major movie studios converged on the capital Tuesday to pitch their industry in the unaccustomed role of good guy: boon to the trade balance, engine of economic growth, polisher of the nations image and employer of a big, uncelebrated, middle-class work force.

title: Rangers Take It to a Shootout, but Brodeur and the Devils Prevail
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 6  The Rangers would ordinarily feel good heading into a shootout with Henrik Lundqvist in goal. He had won all five he had been in this season, stopping the first 22 shots he faced. And the last time the Rangers took the Devils to a shootout, on Jan. 2, Lundqvist had skated out a winner.

title: Removing a Sunken Treasure, With Millions of Stories
description: For millions of immigrants, the final leg of the journey to America was a 20-minute ride to Manhattan on the ferry Ellis Island. Now, without much ceremony or sentiment, federal officials plan to cut up the rusted skeleton of that historic ship and remove it from New York Harbor.

description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts: Man Charged in Hoax Videotaped Bomb Squad
description: One of two men facing criminal charges for placing advertisements that were mistaken for bombs in the Boston area videotaped the bomb squad investigating the devices and notified his employer but not the authorities, his lawyers said. The man, Peter Berdovsky, 27, began filming when he heard that officers were investigating a possible bomb at a subway station near his home, the lawyers said. Mr. Berdovsky realized he had hung the device in question and called Interference Inc., the company that had hired him. Prosecutors have been working with the lawyers for Mr. Berdovsky and Sean Stevens, 28, the other man facing charges, to negotiate a settlement.

title: Madeleines, Turkey Stuffing and Other Thoughts on Loss
description: In works like bobrauschenbergamerica, Big Love and Orestes 2.0, Charles L. Mee Jr. has pulled off impressive feats of literary juggling. His characteristic method is to throw far-flung pop and classical sources together with his own writing to create complex admixtures that read as marvelous distillations of contemporary moods, rhythms and myths. The plays are like Frankenstein-esque porpoises that shouldnt be able to live, much less swim, but nevertheless, in production, manage to dive beneath the surface and emerge with glittering, transcendent fish.

title: Newark: Man Convicted of Fraud
description: A Union City man was convicted yesterday of identity theft and credit card fraud for cheating retailers and credit card companies of more than $100,000, federal prosecutors said. The man, Richard Tagliamonte, 57, was convicted in Federal District Court, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Christie said that Mr. Tagliamonte was arrested in 2004 after he tried to pay a New York parking ticket with a counterfeit credit card.

title: North Korea Talks to Resume in Beijing
description: BEIJING, Feb. 7  The long-stalled six-way talks on North Koreas nuclear weapons program will resume here Thursday amid tentative signs that a breakthrough may be in the offing, in a diplomatic process that seemed shattered four months ago when North Korea tested its first nuclear bomb.

title: Gallaudet Wont Punish Arrested Protesters
description: Gallaudet University said yesterday that it would not take disciplinary action against students arrested in protests that forced the ouster of its chosen president last October.

title: G.E. Finds Strength in Its Diversity
description: NISKAYUNA, N.Y.  Christoph Hergersberg stands before a wall-size diagram with far too many arrows, symbols and letters for an untutored eye to decipher.

title: Military Wants More Civilians to Help in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Senior military officers, including members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have told President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the new Iraq strategy could fail unless more civilian agencies step forward quickly to carry out plans for reconstruction and political development.

title: Lew Burdette, Masterful Pitcher, Dies at 80
description: Lew Burdette, the Milwaukee Braves right-hander who beat the Yankees three times in the 1957 World Series, twice on shutouts, in one of the most dominant pitching performances in baseballs postseason history, died yesterday in Winter Garden, Fla. He was 80.

title: Daytona 500 Purse Goes Up
description: The Daytona 500s purse will be about $18.4 million, the highest ever for a race in the United States. The winner of the Feb. 18 race, Nascars showpiece, will get at least $1.44 million, another record, according to a news release from Daytona International Speedway. Prizes for the top finishers are about $350,000 higher than last year.Purses for the event, which starts the season for Nascars top-level Nextel Cup series, have grown since television ratings for the Daytona 500 overtook those of the Indianapolis 500 in 1995. Last years Indy 500 purse was $10.2 million.

title: Test to Predict Breast Cancer Relapse Is Approved
description: A new genetic test that tries to predict whether a woman with breast cancer will have a relapse won approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration, marking a step toward an era in which medical treatments are personalized for each patient.

title: Giving Luxury the Thrill of Danger
description: ITS a rare and less than propitious moment when dinner out begins with a server asking: Are you scared? But that eerie query set the stage for a recent meal at Kobe Club, and it was prompted by one of this bizarre steakhouses many design oddities.

title: NBCs Russert Rebuts Libby Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The television journalist Tim Russert testified today that, contrary to what I. Lewis Libby Jr. has maintained, the two of them never discussed a C.I.A. agent whose unmasking touched off a scandal.

title: Totals
Apples Chief Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
description: The chief executive of Apple Inc., Steven P. Jobs, is calling on the four largest music companies to license their music for distribution without digital anti-piracy protection, shifting away from a nearly four-year-old philosophy that helped steer the iPod music player to worldwide success.

title: Correction: Sharing Romanian Under a Sphinx
description: The $25 and Under column last Wednesday, about Acasa, a Romanian restaurant in Sunnyside, Queens, misstated the duration of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. It lasted 51 years, not a century. The article also misstated the amount of territory in Romania that was part of the empire. Regions, including Transylvania, were part of it; the entire country was not.

title: Many Voices, No Debate, as Senate Is Stifled on War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  At a time when even President Bush acknowledges that the war in Iraq is sapping the nations spirit, the Senate has tied itself up in procedural knots rather than engage in a debate on Iraq policy.

title: Allied Records Are Subpoenaed in Pretexting Case
description: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed records of Allied Capital, a business development company that provides financing to smaller firms, in an effort to discover how private investigators it hired may have obtained the phone records of one of its leading critics.

title: Game On: Hero Returns to Slay His Dragons
description: THESE days, when MySpace and YouTube seem as ubiquitous as television and newspapers, it can be tough to remember that just eight years ago the Internet was still a gee-whiz curiosity for most people. But 1999 was the year online entertainment really began, not with grainy streaming video but with a game that let millions of players explore a vibrant 3-D fantasy world for the first time.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 29 about Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, who were visiting Manhattan for a publicity tour, referred imprecisely to the royal title for Camilla at one point. (The same error appeared in the picture caption.) She is the Duchess of Cornwall; the phrasing Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, is properly used only for a royal widow or divorce, according to a spokeswoman for the royal household. The article also referred incorrectly to the necklace she was wearing. It was a triple stand of pearls, not a double strand.

title: Lebanon: Agreement With U.N. on Hariri Tribunal
description: The United Nations signed an agreement with the government to begin the process of creating a tribunal to try suspects in the 2005 car bomb assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in which Syrian intelligence agents have been implicated. The agreement must be approved by Parliament, but the speaker, Nabih Berri, has refused to convene the legislature, while the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora remains weakened by challenges to its authority by Hezbollah and the pro-Syrian president, mile Lahoud.

title: When the Welcome Mat Wears Out
description: Because of a recent state court ruling, the man who came to dinner  or his equivalent among office tenants in New York City  may be presented with a rather hefty bill for damages.

title: Kildow Sheds a Label and Wins a Silver
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 6  Carving smooth turns on hard snow is a skill that ski racers spend a lifetime perfecting, but on some level, it is simply about who dares to go the straightest on race day.

title: Willye B. White, the First 5-Time U.S. Track Olympian, Dies at 67
description: Willye B. White, who willed her way out of the Mississippi Delta cotton fields and became the first American track and field athlete to compete in five Olympics, died yesterday in Chicago. She was 67.

title: Out of Italy, and Packing a Jolt
description: CONTRARY to a widely held belief, big, powerful, almost monstrously concentrated wines are not a California invention. No, before the first California wines sent the alcohol meter reeling toward 17 percent, Amarone from Italy was setting the standard for dense, lush red wines that were routinely 15 to 16 percent alcohol.

title: For the Record
description: The On the Road column in Business Day yesterday, about the criticism over passenger treatment during air travel delays in late December, omitted the byline. It was by Joe Sharkey.

title: World View Archive
Great Performers
description: Twenty-two portraits by 10 photographers of the actors who made the films of 2006 so memorable.

title: Lone Wolves
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Currents
description: A Milanese company founded by architects turns on its lights in SoHo.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardts Feb. 7 column on preschool in Oklahoma:

title: New Head for Actors Equity
description: John P. Connolly, the national president of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, will step down in March to become the national executive director of Actors' Equity Association, the two unions announced yesterday.

title: Theater Briefs
description: "Radio Golf," the final work of August Wilson's 10-play cycle about African-Americans in the 20th century, will begin previews at the Cort Theater on Broadway on April 20 and open officially on May 8.

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Underwater Cameras
description: Mary Osborne, a professional long-board surfer, tests underwater cameras.

title: Teaching Speed
description: Eighteen pro football prospects are training in Fair Lawn, N.J., to improve their speed and performance before the N.F.L. combine later this month.

title: Equity Office Bidding Battle Goes to a Vote
description: Going up?

title: D.B. Zwirn Executives Resign
description: D.B. Zwirn & Companys chief operating officer, Harold Khan, and the companys general counsel, David Proshan, have stepped down as the $5 billion hedge fund seeks to restructure, The New York Post reported.

title: G.E. Finds Strength in Its Diversity
description: Biotechnology, security, energy services and green products are just some of the areas that Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electrics chief since 2001, has singled out as the companys growth platforms. He has jettisoned reinsurance and advanced materials, two slow-growth businesses, and the plastics business is on its way out.

title: Libby's Grand Jury Testimony
description: Audio tapes of I. Lewis Libby Jr.'s two grand jury appearances in March 2004, were played in court this week. During his testimony, Mr. Libby repeatedly testified under oath that he had no recollection of several conversations about Valerie Wilson, a Central Intelligence Agency operative. His denials were in sharp contrast to the testimony over the last two weeks of reporters and government officials who were colleagues of Mr. Libby, the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Tycos Profit Rises as It Prepares to Become 3 Units
description: The manufacturing conglomerate Tyco International, which is preparing to split into three separate companies, said Tuesday that its profit climbed 43 percent in its most recent quarter. Net income for the company rose to $793 million, from $556 million a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Dec. 29 and was the first quarter of Tycos fiscal year, rose 8 percent, to $10.33 billion from $9.6 billion.

title: S.E.C. Queries Adobe on Stock Options
description: Adobe Systems, the maker of design software like Photoshop and Acrobat, said Tuesday that it had received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission asking for more information about its stock option practices. The S.E.C. asked about factors affecting the quarter ended Sept. 1, 2006, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing.

title: S.& P. Buys 3 Indexes
description: The Standard & Poors unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies agreed to buy the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index and two other products from Goldman Sachs, S.& P. said. Goldmans index, created in 1991, tracks 24 commodities to provide investors with a reliable benchmark, S.& P. said. S.& P. also agreed to buy Goldmans Sector and Technology Indexes. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: News Quiz: Acknowledgements
description: And now for something completely different  answers to this weeks quiz:

title: RenaissanceRe Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The insurance company RenaissanceRe Holdings agreed on Tuesday to pay a $15 million fine to settle civil charges of securities fraud over what federal regulators said was a sham transaction created to burnish the companys earnings by smoothing their volatility.

title: S.E.C. Files Suit in Options Case
description: Two former top executives of the military contractor Engineered Support Systems enriched themselves and others in a five-year scheme to manipulate the timing of stock option grants, federal regulators charged Tuesday.

title: Personal Shopper
description: At the Maison & Objet show in France, the tastes and trends of the '80s resurface.

title: Former Massachusetts A.G. to Join Greenberg Traurig
description: The former Massachusetts attorney general, Thomas F. Reilly, who left the post after an unsuccessful bid last year for the Democratic nomination for governor, will join the Boston office of the law firm Greenberg Traurig.As a partner at the firm, Mr. Reilly will draw on his breadth of experience as the states former top prosecutor to work on a wide range of client matters, including litigation and healthcare, environmental, and insurance issues, according to the firm. He will begin his new job in about two weeks.

title: Allianz to Sell BMW Stake
description: Allianz, Europes biggest insurer, is selling a stake worth as much 750 million euros ($973 million) in BMW, the worlds largest maker of luxury cars. Merrill Lynch is managing the offer of 16.1 million shares of BMW. The stake is being offered for between 45.55 euros and 46.55 euros a share to investors today, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Endesa Board Backs E.ON Bid
description: Endesa, the Spanish utility, said Tuesday that it viewed the 41 billion euro takeover bid from E.ON of Germany favorably, and its board recommended that shareholders accept the offer. The board of Endesa has unanimously agreed that the terms of the offer are favorable, Endesa said, adding that the offer of 38.75 euros a share from E.ON, which valued the deal at $53 billion, was adequate from a financial standpoint.

title: World Bank Blacklists More Than 100 Firms
description: World Bank investigators blacklisted more than 100 firms and individuals for fraud and corruption in projects financed by the development agency over the past two years, a new report said Tuesday. The report by the Institutional Integrity Department, the banks investigative arm that looks into abuse of development funding, said it had investigated and closed 441 cases involving fraud and corruption in projects in 2005 and 2006.

title: Short-Sellers and the Companies That Hate Them
description: An inquiry by the Justice Department into pretexting allegations at Allied Capital raises questions about how far companies may be going to fight hedge funds that have sold their stocks short. Allied, a business development company that provides financing to smaller firms, said Tuesday that federal prosecutors had subpoenaed documents in an effort to discover how private investigators it hired may have obtained the phone records of David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager and one of its leading critics.

title: Zell Said to Consider Tribune Deal
description: Sam Zell must be one very busy man. The Chicago real estate magnate, whose Equity Office Properties Trust is the focus of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, is considering a move for part of the Tribune Company, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Samsung to Pay $90 Million in Chip Price Case
description: Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the worlds largest maker of memory chips, agreed Tuesday to pay $90 million to settle civil charges that it conspired with six other makers of computer chips to fix prices, the attorneys general of 41 states announced. The six other companies have yet to settle with the states, which are pursuing the case in Federal District Court in San Francisco.

title: Hicks and Gillett Team Up to Buy Liverpool Club
description: Is a British soccer team the new must-have for entrepreneurs in the United States? Financiers seem lately to feel the need to have one in their closet.

title: Svedka Vodka to Become a Star in Constellations Sky
description: Beverage giant Constellation Brands continues to roll up prominent labels, the latest being the $384 million purchase of the rapidly growing Svedka Vodka that was announced Tuesday.

title: 3i Plans $2.5 Billion Infrastructure I.P.O.
description: the 3i Group of London, a publicly listed private equity group, will become the latest buyout firm to establish a separately listed infrastructure fund through an initial public offering of up to 1.3 billion pounds ($2.56 billion) of shares in a new vehicle.

title: N.Y.S.E. to Delist Navistar
description: Navistar International said Tuesday that the New York Stock Exchange has informed company officials that the N.Y.S.E. plans to proceed with its previously announced plan to delist Navistar from the exchange. Navistar, whose Big Board trading will be suspended at the end of trading on Feb. 13, said it intends to appeal the N.Y.S.E.s decision. The N.Y.S.E. is moving to delist Navistar, a maker of trucks and diesel engines, because the company is so late in filing its financial results.

title: Chicago Merc Gets Green Light for Credit-Derivatives Trading
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the biggest futures market in the nation, can move forward with plans to offer the first exchange-traded credit derivative contracts, after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission gave approval. Regulators will allow the exchange to trade so-called credit event futures contracts that are modeled after credit-default swaps, the privately negotiated contracts that have surged to $26 trillion in global value since they were created about a decade ago, according to a statement on the commissions Web site.

title: SideStep Raises $15 Million to Expand Horizons
description: A travel search company, SideStep, has raised $15 million in a Series C round of funding led by Norwest Venture Partners, CNet News.com reported. The investment, which CNet said SideStep plans to announce on Wednesday, is the largest single injection yet for the company, bringing its total venture capital to $32 million. Other investors reportedly include Trident Capital, Leader Ventures and Saints Capital. The report said that the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to use the cash to pay for acquisitions in the United States, Europe and Asia.

title: Tango Says Hello to Motorolas Cash
description: Motorola said on Tuesday that Motorola Ventures, its venture-capital arm, made an investment in Tango Networks, a closely held maker of communications equipment. The company did not disclose the size of its investment.

title: Mills Board Tells Management to Open Talks With Simon
description: Directors of The Mills Corporation, a mall developer, told company leaders Tuesday to start discussions with the Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management over their offer to buy the company. Responding to the pairs offer, which would top a $1.35 billion deal with a Canadian investor, Brookfield Asset Management, the Mills board determined that the competing $1.6 billion bid is reasonably likely to lead to a superior competing transaction, company officials said in a statement.

title: Novelis May Be a Bid Target
description: Shares in Novelis, a former division of Alcan, rose almost 11 percent to a record high on Tuesday following reports that it will receive a takeover offer in the coming weeks. Novelis, an aluminum maker, confirmed last month it was in talks with several parties to sell the company. And on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that Hindalco Industries, part of the Aditya Birla Group of India, may make a takeover bid this week valued at $6 billion to $8 billion, citing the Indian financial Web site, MoneyControl.com.

title: Lazards Stock Hits New High as Profits Rise
description: Lazard said Wednesday that strength in its merger-advisory business helped lift profits 50 percent in the fourth quarter to $85.8 million, a record for the investment bank.

title: Vetco Gray Settles Nigerian Bribe Charges
description: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. The companies  Vetco Gray Controls, Vetco Gray Controls Ltd. and Vetco Gray UK  agreed on Tuesday to pay a combined $26 million under criminal plea agreements, a record fine under the federal law that prohibits bribing foreign officials.

title: Russias Sitronics Raises $350 Million in I.P.O.
description: Sitronics, a technology company owned by a Russian conglomerate, Sistema, priced its initial public offering on Wednesday at the low end of the expected range, raising about $350 million through a dual listing in Moscow and London.

title: Blurbs are His Mtier
description: Which actor was never-better? Whose performance was a comic and dramatic tour de force? Who gave a staggering performance? Whos got renewed comic edge? Who is the real deal? Who has an eye for telling detail? Who needs to set down the box of face-licking adjectives and slowly back away?

title: The Great Man Theory of Advertising
description: We know, we know, Clint Eastwood may be the greatest living person on either side of the camera, but Warner Brothers is taking this whole thing a bit far. You can almost here the herald of trumpets in a standalone piece that was shipped with the Hollywood Reporter for Letters From Iwo Jima. The copy, quoting some hagiography from the American Film Institute, reads: Clint Eastwood continues to set the standard  telling stories of uncommon sensitivity on a canvas so grand and glorious that his place in Americas cultural legacy seems to have no bounds.

title: Norbit  the Anti-Oscar Ad
description: Sometimes, having your nominee all over television is precisely what you dont want. The airwaves are getting squished by a big old blob of Norbit right now, and the ads serve as a constant reminder that, while Eddie Murphy sparkled in Dreamgirls, his career decisions have mostly been driven by that which folds and goes in his pocket.

title: Leo vs. Leo
description: Put the cover of weekly Variety and daily Variety from Monday side by side. Same dude, same trademark goatee, same type font, same pitch for votes. But different movies. The Departed and Blood Diamond have both used Leonardo DiCaprio in their ads and because his version of playing mature involves facial hair and a piercing glare, he looks like the same character.

title: The Queen Goes for the Crown
description: Harvey and Bob Weinstein may be gone from Miramax, but the company seems to have retained some of their notorious hardware aggression. On Monday, the Daily Variety came polybagged with a lush, expensive standalone book for The Queen. It is not the kind of thing that you do when you are just trying to make sure that Helen Mirrens lock on best actress doesnt loosen.

title: Whither the Frontrunner?
description: Why is Babel not the frontrunner in this race? It is the most ambitious film, has a stellar cast, won the Golden Globes dramatic nod and most important of all, has the most nominations, with seven.

title: The Baggers All-Ads-All-the-Time Blog.
description: The ad season is reaching the shrieking stage  Vote for our movie or we will annihilate a bunch of defenseless kittens!  so it seemed like time to step back and do a little deconstruction.

title: Narciso Rodriguez
description: Narciso Rodriguez presents his fall 2007 collection.

title: Is Nigerias Anti-Corruption Commission Corrupt?
description: Nigerias Economic and Financial Crimes Commission released an advisory list of more than 130 politicians  including Nigerias current vice president, Atiku Abubakar  whom the commission considers too corrupt to hold office.

title: YouTubes Payoff: Hundreds of Millions for the Founders
description: Everyone suspected that the investors, founders and early employees of YouTube made tidy sums when the video sharing site was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year.

title: Preventing War With Iran
RBC Capital Names Co-Presidents
description: RBC Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada, said Wednesday that it had named two co-presidents as part of its long-term succession planning. The co-presidents, Doug McGregor and Mark Standish, will report to Chuck Winograd, chief executive of RBC Capital Markets. Mr. McGregor, based in Toronto, had been head of global investment banking and equity markets for RBC Capital, while Mr. Standish, based in New York, had been head of global markets.

title: The Odds on Rudy Just Got Better
description: Old conventional wisdom: Rudy Giuliani is too socially liberal to win the Republican nomination for president, no matter what the early polls say. New CW: Rudys the front-runner!

title: On the Hill: Toe the Line, or Else
description: With Democrats pushing to accomplish their legislative goals after years of languishing in the minority, efforts to enforce ideological discipline are meeting with mixed results.

title: Zuckers Bumpy Ride to the Top
description: Is General Electric considering a sale of NBC Universal? Amid all the hubub surrounding the appointment of Jeff Zucker as the president and chief executive of NBC Universal, a report surfaced suggesting that the increased involvement of G.E.s chairman, Jeff Immelt, in the direction of its entertainment filial could be a sign that it is mulling an eventual exit from the TV and film business.

title: Corruption Threatens Long Tradition of Civil Service
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Feb. 5 column, The Green-Zoning of America.

title: Still Seeking Justice for Gary Tyler
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 5 column, Gary Tylers Lost Decades.

title: Brunos Election Hangover
description: With the capitol abuzz over last nights Democratic victory in the Nassau County Senate race, Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno was blaming the unpopularity of President Bush and the popularity of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who campaigned heavily for Senator-elect Craig Johnson.

title: He Likes Me, He Loves Me
description: Comptroller update! Yesterday Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno said I like Tom DiNapoli. This morning, he said I love Tom DiNapoli. He stopped short of endorsing a candidate in the comptroller race, but Empire Zone is sensing a trend

title: Isaac Mizrahi
description: Isaac Mizrahi showed his fall 2007 collection Monday, Feb. 5.

title: Edwardss Blogger Blooper
description: The efforts by 2008 presidential contenders to exploit the megaphone of the blogosphere has hit a bump, it seems, as former Senator John Edwardss hiring of two controversial bloggers gathers more attention than his health care plan or even his new McMansion spread in North Carolina.

title: 2008: HillRaisers and Sunshine Staters
description: Todays theme is one that has been and will be repeated throughout the campaign season: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her bank of money. Last night, she had a soiree at her Washington home for about 70 heavy fundraisers committed to gathering between $250,000 and $1 million for her bid, and today shell meet with the HillRaisers, a broader set of donors whove pledged to collect $25,000, at the Hyatt Regency on Capitol Hill.

title: The Proper Care, Feeding and Discipline of Astronauts
description: The bizarre case of Lisa Marie Nowak, a Naval officer and NASA astronaut who was arrested on Monday and formally charged yesterday with attempted kidnapping and murder, continues to animate online discussions (including in our own forums). Much of the chatter centers on NASAs psychological screening process, as well as the degree to which Ms. Nowaks conduct falls under the jurisdiction of civilian authorities, Naval rules and NASA regulations.

title: Creative Accounting
description: When Paul realized that the price of the cute little lot on Anna Maria Island was really  no kidding  $259,900, he added up our assets and subtracted our liabilities, and concluded that there was no way we could afford to buy the property.

title: A Lawmaker Bucks the Majorities
description: State Senator John J. Bonacic, of the Hudson Valley, was the only member of the Republican majority to voice concerns last month about re-electing Senator Joseph L. Bruno as majority leader, given the F.B.I. inquiry into his business dealings.

title: Midwestern Utilities Strike a 3-Way Deal
description: In a three-way Midwestern energy deal, Great Plains Energy will buy Aquila for $1.7 billion in cash and stock, after Aquila sells assets in four states to Black Hills for $940 million. Great Plains, the parent of Kansas City Power & Light, will pay $4.54 a share, a 2.8 percent discount to Aquilas closing price on Tuesday of $4.67. Each acquisition is dependent on the other.

title: Equity Office Shareholders Approve Blackstone Buyout
description: The Blackstone Group emerged Wednesday as the winner in the feverish battle to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust after shareholders overwhelmingly approved the buyout firms offer. The $39 billion deal now stands as the largest buyout ever.

title: Lobbing Verbal Grenades at a Private-Equity Party
description: Michael M. Thomas, the investment banker turned financial fiction writer, uses his New York Observer column this week to describe a disturbing (and, we hope, fictional) potential plot. His violent vision was inspired by the mogul-packed party planned to celebrate the 60th birthday of the Blackstone Groups co-founder Steve Schwarzman on Tuesday at the Park Avenue armory.

title: Assembly: Its DiNapoli
description: The Democratic-led State Assembly dealt a setback today to Gov. Eliot Spitzer by agreeing to elect Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli as the next state comptroller, reneging on a deal it made with the governor to choose only from candidates deemed qualified by an outside screening panel to succeed Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Single Female Seeks Genetically Worthy Partner. Will Travel.
description: It turns out female Antarctic fur seals have something in common with female humans: theyre not content to settle for the males in their neighborhood.

title: The New Math
description: A faithful reader recently sent me a letter about a tipping situation he encountered while eating out in our fair city, and I want to share it, because the wider subject of tipping  whats right, whats wrong, whats what  is one that seems to perplex and provoke diners in a way that few other restaurant-related subjects do.

title: Defending the Management Buyout
description: New York Times columnist Ben Stein and the legions of other critics of management-led buyouts have it all wrong, according to TheEconomist.com. Calling the reaction a tad hysterical, it argues that M.B.O.s are not, as Mr. Stein has repeatedly argued, an inherent conflict of interest, and shareholders are often enriched by them.

title: Telecom Dealmaker Joins Bank of America
description: Bank of Americas investment banking arm has hired a former dealmaker from Sprint Nextel as its global head of telecom mergers and acquisitions. Marc Montagner joins Banc of America Securities after serving as head of mergers and acquisitions at Sprint Nextel, formed through a $35 billion merger in 2005. Before Sprint Nextel, he was an investment banker at Morgan Stanley.

title: The Mike Bloomberg Experience
description: Sounding a bit peeved that he is still answering for the school bus confusion that has left children shivering and route-less across the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg attacked his critics this morning as do-nothing complainers with no experience in, well, anything at all.

title: Lehman Chiefs Next Hire: a Good Contractor?
description: Here is one way that Richard Fuld, chief executive of Lehman Brothers, can spend some of the $186 million in stock grants he is expected to get over the next 10 years: sprucing up what The New York Post describes as his new 16-room fixer-upper on Park Avenue, for which he reportedly paid $21 million. The apartment had been owned by Evelyn Annenberg Jaffe Hall, the publishing heiress who died in 2005 at age 93. The four-bedroom, 5-1/2 bath apartment has great bones but needs a ton of work a broker told the Post. Renovations will cost another $10 million, the broker estimated.

title: Online Marketing Boom Attracts Private Equity
description: The Web is still mostly a hodgepodge when it comes to advertising and marketing. Interactive agencies abound, as do marketing outfits, affiliate programs and technology firms that create the platforms for serving and tracking ads. But the business is booming, and, according to an article in Adweek magazine, ripe for consolidation by private equity firms.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: The Russell 3,000  an index of the 3,000 largest stocks in the United States  closed today at 845.78, exactly one point higher than its previous closing high of 844.78, set March 24, 2000.

title: Hedge Fund Launches Slowed in 2006, Survey Says
description: Launches of new hedge funds, as measured by total assets raised, slowed in 2006 for the second year in a row, according to a survey published in Absolute Return magazines February issue. Among the reasons for the decline, according to the magazine, were last springs equity market meltdown and last falls implosion of Amaranth Advisors.

Thats the final vote for Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli for state comptroller. Martha E. Stark, the city finance commissioner, got 56 54 votes, mostly from Senate Democrats and Assembly Republicans  the less powerful legislative majorities. That makes Mr. DiNapoli the states top fiscal officer until 2010.

title: Berger Interview on Formula1.com
description: The Formula1.com put up an interesting interview with Gerhard Berger today. Im not sure it can be considered quite a substitute for a Toro Rosso car launch, just yet, but it has the makings of a few news announcements.

title: Gaining Leverage With a Gas Tax
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Feb. 7 column, Yes, We Can Find the Exit.

title: Taking Aim at iPod Oblivion
description: Lets end the day with something frothy, shall we?

title: Readers Respond to Mr. Cheney, Tear Down This Wall
description: The majority of the more than 230 comments that Nick got on his Tuesday column about Vice President Cheney were congratulatory. Many lauded his stance and Eric Munck warned him to make sure your tax returns are in order.

title: Blogtalk: Comptrolling
description: Comptroller DiNapoli  is he a wise man or a wiseacre: Im driving myself home tonight. [The Politicker]

title: DiNapoli: No Steamroller Here
description: In his first press conference, held seconds after being sworn in as the new state comptroller, Thomas P. S. DiNapoli struck a peaceable tone, though a noticably firm one at times.

title: The Incredible Allure of It All
description: I was sitting this morning at Michael Kors show (luxe babes, chic glen plaid) and wondering about my hair. Ive been wearing a black knit cap all week. I know what everyones thinking. When is she going to take that stupid hat off? But its almost too late, at this stage, to take it off, and I dont have time to get to the hairdressers. I was thinking I could get a wig.

title: 2008 P.M. Update
description: In yet another sign of how expensive the 2008 election is likely to be, Senator Barack Obama is foregoing federal matching funds, allowing him to spend as much as he can. He joins John Edwards, Mitt Romney and Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain. This probably means the public financing system, as former Federal Election Commissioner Michael Toner predicted, is kaput for now.

title: Blogtalk: A Rock and a Hard Place
description: According to Homer, Odysseus once found himself in the delicate position of leading his ship and his few remaining men down a narrow strait with dangers lurking on both sides. John Edwards found himself in a similar spot today after the Catholic Leagues Bill Donohue complained about the posting history of two newly hired bloggers for the Edwards campaign.

title: Dead Men Walking
description: About the only designer in New York who doesnt attempt to resuscitate the dead is Narciso Rodriguez. I mean, if I see another Adrian, Mainbocher, Alaia or quietly finessed McCardell look And let us not to talk about the Sisters Mulleavy. I took the R train downtown to their Rodarte show and watched with mild surprise as they sent out every kind of shapeless sack with pastry ruffles and gobbets of chiffon.

title: Ghost Stories
description: To the hundreds of people who responded to my previous column on language and to those who urged more on the same subject, thanks loads. Will you forgive a radical change of subject? If I promise, with the help of your emails, to do another language piece? (My special regards to the fellow who didnt like the column and who found it repitious [sic].)

title: Mormon Candidate Braces for Religion as Issue
description: As he begins campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, is facing a threshold issue: Will his religion  he is a Mormon  be a big obstacle to winning the White House?

title: EMC Plans Public Offering for 10% of Software Division
description: EMC announced yesterday that it planned to sell 10 percent of its fast-growing software subsidiary, VMware, in an initial public offering this summer.

title: A French Theater Where Even Those Who Cant Hear Share One Language
description: PARIS, Feb. 7  Emmanuelle Laborit is a strikingly expressive actress. While her lively face is conveying her feelings, her fast-moving hands and arms elucidate her thoughts. Being deaf since birth has never deterred her. Talented and determined, she has built her stage and screen career around her gift for communication. Now, at 35, she is embarking on her greatest theatrical adventure so far.

title: Profile of Thomas P. DiNapoli
description: BORN Feb. 10, 1954, Rockville Centre on Long Island.

title: From Wall Street, an Evening Tour Dedicated to the Holy
description: Owen Burdick has arranged his choral programs at Trinity Church this season as An Early Music Tour of Europe, with installments devoted to England, Germany, Italy, Austria and France. England and Germany have been seen to, more or less: one could argue that Handels Messiah was the wrong work to represent Germany, given its stature as the quintessential English oratorio, composed well into Handels English period. But never mind. On Tuesday evening at Trinity Church Mr. Burdick offered an inarguably Italian program, with works by Monteverdi, Cavalli and Carissimi.

title: Jersey City: Former Deputy Mayor Charged
description: Ador L. Equipado, a former Jersey City deputy mayor, who resigned over charges that he solicited donations from couples he had just married, was charged yesterday with official misconduct, the Jersey City police said. Mr. Equipado resigned last month after he was accused of asking for money after performing marriage ceremonies at City Hall, the police said. Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy said the city has taken steps to ensure that the type of infractions alleged in this case never happen again. Mr. Equipado, who was released without bail, could not be reached for comment yesterday.

title: Noted Arab Citizens Call on Israel to Shed Jewish Identity
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7  A group of prominent Israeli Arabs has called on Israel to stop defining itself as a Jewish state and become a consensual democracy for both Arabs and Jews, prompting consternation and debate across the country.

title: Palestinians Reach Deal on Government
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 8  The main rival Palestinian factions agreed late Thursday to form a government of national unity aimed at ending a wave of violence between them and an international boycott.

title: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream, of My Beloved Green Pants
description: THERE was a time when a person who had the right sweat pants didnt really need to own much else in the way of pants. Lets say, for the sake of argument, that said pants were a green frayed, paint-spattered pair that disappeared mysteriously.A person who had Green Pants could wear them on a run, in the garden, walking the dog or even to the market to get a quart of milk. Day after day after day.

title: Mormon Candidate Braces for Religion as Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  As he begins campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, is facing a threshold issue: Will his religion  he is a Mormon  be a big obstacle to winning the White House?

title: Nortel to Cut Another 3,900 Jobs in Europe and North America
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 7  Nortel Networks, the large but troubled maker of communications equipment, said on Wednesday that it would eliminate more than 3,900 jobs in Europe and North America.

title: Irans Supreme Leader Lashes Out Against U.S.
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 8  Irans supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, warned the United States today that Iran would respond to any aggression by striking at Americas interests worldwide.

title: U.S. May Be Mishandling Asylum Seekers, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A bipartisan federal commission warned on Wednesday that the Bush administration, in its zeal to secure the nations borders and stem the tide of illegal immigrants, may be leaving asylum seekers vulnerable to deportation and harsh treatment.

title: Mistrial for Officer Who Refused to Go to Iraq
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 7  A military judge on Wednesday declared a mistrial in the court-martial of the Army officer who called the war in Iraq illegal and refused to join his unit when it deployed there last June.

title: Blackstones Bid for Equity Office Prevails
description: The feverish competition over Equity Office Properties Trust, the nations largest office landlord, ended today with the original suitor, the Blackstone Group, coming out on top.

title: Disney Profits Double on Strong DVD Sales of Cars and Pirates
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that first-quarter profit more than doubled on asset sales and income from last years two biggest-selling DVD releases: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Mans Chest and Cars.

title: Violence Said to Increase on Mexican Border
description: Efforts to stop smuggling and illegal immigration have led to increased violence along the southern border of the United States as criminal organizations seek to continue their operations, Michael Chertoff, the secretary of Department of Homeland Security, said today.

title: Feeling Parched? Itching Like Crazy? It Must Be Winter
description: IT gets worse as the winter drags on, and weeks of air that is too cold and heat that is too dry take their toll. Arms, thighs, knees, elbows and calves start looking like the surface of the moon: cracked, chalky and stretched. And then comes the itch.

title: Two Thieves and Picasso: Whos Robbing Whom?
description: Some of the finest plays of recent years have taken a modest story and wrapped it in heady ideas about art, mathematics or nuclear physics. For the first few minutes of the Abingdon Theaters Frugal Repast you have the sinking feeling that youre going to be looking at an amateurish imitation of those challenging works. But the playwright, Ron Hirsen, has a refreshing surprise in store: He knows the difference between just enough and too much.

title: Chirac Hints He Wont Run for Third Term
description: PARIS, Feb. 8  President Jacques Chirac of France, in remarks to be televised on Sunday and confirmed by his office today, gave his first hint that he may not run for a third term in the French elections in April.

title: Copter Crashes Suggest Shift in Iraqi Tactics
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 7  With two more helicopter crashes near Baghdad, including a Marine transport crash on Wednesday that killed seven people, the number of helicopters that have gone down in Iraq over the past three weeks rose to six. American officials say the streak strongly suggests that insurgents have adapted their tactics and are now putting more effort into shooting down the aircraft.

title: Bloomberg Adds Safety Measures in Response to Rise in Construction Deaths
description: Responding to an alarming spike in fatal construction accidents, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a raft of measures yesterday to improve worker safety. These steps include creating a new inspection team at the Buildings Department, increasing regulations and training, and sharply increasing the penalties for violations.

title: Whatever Happened to Jane Fonda in Tights?
description: OLIVIA SIEMENS, in a shiny blue Speedo swimsuit and with goggles pinching her forehead, climbed out of the pool and draped a towel over her shoulders. Before she walked (stiffly) toward the womens locker room at the Koret Center at the University of San Francisco, she complained: Swimming is just about the only exercise I can do these days. Im a fashion victim  the fashion of aerobics.

title: House Committee to Examine Recent Performance of S.B.A.
description: A House committee is holding the first of several hearings today to discuss the Small Business Administration, an agency that has come under criticism for its disaster relief program in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, as well as its operating, lending and contracting practices.

title: The Alarm Clock as a Moving Target. Catch It if You Can.
description: If a screeching buzzer is not enough to get you moving in the morning, consider Clocky.

title: Lions and Tigers. No Bears? Oh, My!
description: HAVE jewelry designers gone Disney?

title: British Court Frees 2 Arrested as Suspects in Terrorism Plot
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  A court on Wednesday ordered the release of two men arrested last week as suspects in a terrorism plot that the authorities said involved kidnapping a British Muslim soldier and broadcasting video images of his killing on the Internet.

description: To the Editor:

title: Home Depot Gets a Fresh Coat of Less-Glossy Paint
description: For six years, it was a perk that Home Depots chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, could not do without: a catered lunch for his top deputies, served daily on the 22nd floor of the companys headquarters in Atlanta.

title: Queens: Man Charged in Fatal Accident
description: A 34-year-old Long Island man was charged yesterday with leaving the scene of a fatal accident in Queens. The police said the man, Christopher Savini, of Roslyn, crashed into a car stopped on the Grand Central Parkway near Utopia Parkway whose occupants were standing near it, pushing it into them. The driver of the stopped car, Christian Melendez, 28, of Elmhurst, was killed, and a 16-year-old passenger, whom the police did not identify, was critically injured, the police said. Mr. Savini drove off, the police said, but returned to the scene and told the police that he had hit Mr. Melendezs car. Mr. Melendez had apparently hit a guardrail and then stopped in the westbound lanes.

title: They Know When the Show Can Move On
description: Two quick thoughts on the fall collections to date. First, the worlds supply of black stockings will soon surely be exhausted, if designers in New York have not used them all up already. And second, just because Miuccia Prada didnt show any pants for spring does not mean no one else can for fall.
