description: For the Record

title: Clothes Make the Man ... Scared
description: The plot of Joe Hills first novel can be summarized simply: An aging heavy-metal star buys a haunted suit over the Internet. He thinks it will be perfect for his ghoulish-artifact collection. The suit agrees, but for all the wrong reasons.

title: Allied With Democrats, Lieberman Easily Aligns With Republicans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  It came as little surprise that when Senate Republicans blocked debate Monday on a resolution that would have opposed President Bushs plan to increase troop levels in Iraq, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, erstwhile Democrat, sided with them.

title: Group Seeks End to Law Against Insulting Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 8  A group of civic organizations today proposed changes to Article 301, a controversial section of the Turkish penal code that makes insulting Turkey or Turkishness a crime. The section has been used against intellectuals, journalists and writers like the Nobel Prize winner Orhan Pamuk and the newspaper editor Hrant Dink, who was shot dead in an Istanbul street in January.

title: Suspects in Journalists Killing Came From a Hotbed of Turkish Ultranationalist Sentiment
description: TRABZON, Turkey  With fishing boats pouring in and out of a busy harbor, white minibuses crisscrossing in all directions and shopping streets bustling, this regional capital nestled on the Black Sea appears to be a vibrant city.

title: Wal-Mart and a Union Unite, at Least on Health Policy
description: They have established one of the fiercest rivalries in the American economy, attacking one anothers organizations through dueling blogs, newspaper advertisements and news conferences.

description: To the Editor:

title: Takeover Battle Ends With Sale of Big Landlord
description: Roses are red, violets are blue; I hear a rumor, is it true?

title: Gates Seeks Troops for Afghanistan Offensive
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Feb. 8  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, attending his first conference of NATO defense ministers, will tell Americas allies that they must fulfill their commitments to provide troops for Afghanistan in time for a spring offensive against the Taliban, senior American officials said.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills 2 Girls and Injures 5 People
description: A three-alarm fire tore through an apartment house in Brooklyn this morning, killing two children and leaving five others injured, fire officials said.

title: Landis Agrees Not to Race in Tour de France This Year
description: The American cyclist Floyd Landis agreed today not to defend his controversial 2006 victory in the Tour de France.

title: After 2nd Arrest, Woman Finds a Life Free of Drugs
description: Whos out? said the voice in the darkness, slurring his words. He sounded slow-witted. Whos out? he cried, using street argot to plead for sellers of crack cocaine.

title: Trial Over Muhammad Cartoons Begins in France
description: PARIS, Feb. 7  Hearings began Wednesday in a suit brought by two influential French Muslim organizations against a satirical weekly newspaper for printing cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad that had touched off international rioting.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys Face Safety Issues in Icy Cold
description: Chuck Lopez knows that riding on a February afternoon at Aqueduct can be a pretty miserable experience for a jockey. He has been riding here during the last 14 winters, braving frigid temperatures, performing in front of empty grandstands and riding the type of ordinary horses that will never take him to the Kentucky Derby.

title: A Member of the Club
description: With yesterdays choice of a new comptroller, the New York State Legislature failed to select the best candidate for the job. Instead, lawmakers  particularly the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and his Democratic majority  stuck to their conviction that the position belonged to them. The person they chose, Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli of Nassau County, has been a member of Albanys inbred club for two decades.

title: Belarus Threatens to Charge Russia for Facilities and Transportation
description: A summary of the top news in Russian newspapers on Thursday.

title: What They Design, Real Women Wear
description: ELIE TAHARIS fall fashion presentation in Midtown last Thursday, which drew a respectable turnout of decision makers from the retail and magazine worlds, offered an encyclopedic overview of the seasons directions. Mr. Taharis ideas were luxurious, if not daring, sophisticated but never so tricky or ethereal that they would fly over his customers heads.

title: Breaking the Myth of Megapixels
description: For an industry thats built on science, the technology world sure has its share of myths. Thousands of people believe that forwarding a certain e-mail message to 50 friends will bring great riches, that the gigahertz rating of a computer is a good comparative speed score, or that Bill Gates once said 640K of RAM ought to be enough for anybody.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2-Party Talks on Budget Fall Apart Amid Friction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A leading Democratic senator said Wednesday that previously undisclosed behind-the-scenes bipartisan budget talks with the administration had collapsed because of comments by Vice President Dick Cheney and others in the administration.

title: Newark: Man Sentenced for Drug Dealing
description: A man who prosecutors said controlled much of the citys heroin trade for years was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, Hakeem Curry, 31, of Newark, was convicted of drug charges and money laundering in July, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Currys organization is believed to have supplied nearly 85 percent of the heroin dealt on the streets of Newark and roughly 50 kilograms of cocaine a week for the last several years, Mr. Christie said.

title: Numbers Out on How Rich the YouTube Deal Was
description: Everyone suspected that the investors, founders and early employees of YouTube made tidy sums when it was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year.

title: Cracked Skin Could Be Path to Asthma
description: RESEARCHERS have long noted that many asthma sufferers also have atopic dermatitis  often called eczema  a chronic disease of the skin that can leave it red, raw, scaly, tender, oozy and excruciatingly itchy. But scientists are looking at whether such ravaging of the skin creates the conditions that can trigger asthma.

title: Manhattan: Couple Charged With Murder Conspiracy
description: A couple arrested on narcotics and weapons charges were accused of trying to hire a hit man to kill the superintendent of their apartment building, the police said yesterday. They said that the husband, who was in jail, wrongly suspected the superintendent of giving detectives information that led to a search of their home. The couple, Francisco Diaz, 38, and Maria Diaz, 34, of 657 West 161st Street, were charged with conspiracy to commit murder, said Inspector Kenneth M. Cully, the commanding officer of the Manhattan North narcotics unit. He said that the alleged plot came to light in late December, about a month after detectives arrested the couple and said they seized a loaded .45-caliber handgun, 100 grams of cocaine and $1,300 from their home. Inspector Cully said that after the police got wind of what he called the plot, an undercover officer posing as a potential assassin visited Mr. Diaz in jail, and also spoke to Ms. Diaz about it. Despite Mr. Diazs suspicions, the superintendent was not the source of the information that led us to do the search warrant, Inspector Cully said.

title: Correction: The Lady Regrets
description: The At Home With article last Thursday about Dr. Rene Richards omitted the byline. It was by Joyce Wadler.

title: Semi-Frozen in a Remote Dream World
description: In her latest choreographic experiment Karole Armitage takes on the hypnotic music of Gyorgy Ligeti, a composer of spellbinding imagination whose compositions are hardly unknown in the dance world. For Ligeti Essays, performed by 10 members of Armitage Gone! Dance on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Ms. Armitage places her own stamp on the music and, along with it, something other choreographers dont have: David Salle.

title: Sending  Giant Files
description: Q. How can I send a 50-megabyte file to a friend since its way too big for an e-mail attachment? Are there ways to do it other than burning a CD and using the mail?

title: El Paso Corp. to Pay $7 Million as Settlement in Oil-Food Case
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 7  The El Paso Corporation, the largest American natural gas pipeline operator, agreed Wednesday to pay the federal government $7.73 million to settle allegations of involvement in illegal payments under the oil-for-food program run by the United Nations in Iraq.

title: Insurers Financial Weakness May Imperil Trade Center Project
description: A new financing gap may be about to open in the rebuilding plan for ground zero. One of the insurance companies that provided coverage for the World Trade Center is in financial trouble and may not be able to pay the $250 million claim that the developer Larry A. Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey say they are owed as a result of the destruction of the complex by terrorists in 2001.

title: Obama Proposes Candidates Limit General Election Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, a contender for the Democratic presidential nomination, issued an unusual challenge to his rivals on Wednesday. He proposed a voluntary agreement between the two major party nominees that would limit their fund-raising and spending for the general election.

title: Warning! This Flashing Red Light Means the Tires Are Low on Air
description: Low tire pressure increases fuel consumption, speeds up tire wear and can change a cars handling from precise to mushy. And with todays low-profile tires, you cannot detect low pressure by the bulge of the sidewalls. On many new cars tire-pressure monitor systems can provide a warning, but many drivers who lack such a system ignore the need for regular pressure checks.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Thomas P. DiNapoli, a Nice Guy Who Wound Up Finishing First
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7  Thomas P. DiNapoli could easily win a popularity contest in the State Legislature.

title: Riverhead: Man Charged With Police Impersonation
description: A man was arrested yesterday on charges of impersonating a police officer by using a badge, a fake pistol and a car similar to an unmarked police cruiser to stop people and confiscate their property, the Suffolk County police said. The suspect Henry L. Terry, 24, of Holbrook, who was arrested after an investigation, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court to grand larceny and criminal impersonation. The police said that he stole a Toyota Land Rover, which they said he told its owner was needed for an undercover operation.

title: The Fog of Accountability
description: The details are graphic: billions of dollars of Iraqi oil revenues  363 tons of cash  bundled up and urgently flown to Baghdad on 484 pallets from the Federal Reserve Bank to jump-start a new Iraqi government. Four years later, the unanswered questions are just as graphic: Who was responsible for the money? What became of it?

description: Previously recorded: $7,597,465

title: Camden: Campbell Soup Announces Expansion
description: The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday that it would expand its corporate headquarters, anchoring itself to the poorest city in the state, where it has been for 137 years, at a cost of $72 million. Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who was in Camden for the announcement, said the state, Camden County and the City of Camden would invest $26 million in improvements around the 110-acre development, which would include an office park. Campbell plans to build an 80,000-square-foot building for a company store, an employees fitness center, a cafeteria and a credit union, and then renovate its current headquarters and research facility. About 1,200 people work at the headquarters.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about the theft of 450 bottles of wine, valued at $100,000, in Atherton, Calif., misstated the price of the average bottle stolen in some copies. It was $222, not $3,000.

title: Italy: At Peace, and Mrs. Berlusconi Still
description: Correction Appended

description: EL CERRITO, Calif.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: The Orchid Curators Secret

title: Nets Find Right Mix to End Four-Game Losing Streak
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 7  The desperate Nets watched a floating jumper from a player with a 10-day contract sail toward the basket from the corner with three seconds remaining. The shot, if it was good, could have won the game, and if it had fallen through, who knows if the Nets could have recovered.

title: Utility in Kansas City Buys Crosstown Rival
description: Great Plains Energy, the owner of Kansas City Power and Light, has agreed to buy the crosstown utility operator Aquila for about $1.7 billion to try to gain the scale needed to reduce costs and expand its electricity system.

title: Alan MacDiarmid, 79, Who Won Nobel for Work With Plastic, Dies
description: Alan G. MacDiarmid, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2000 for the discovery of plastics that conduct electricity like metals, died yesterday at the age of 79.

title: What He Learned While Writing His Book, Whether or Not Its Theater
description: Lawrence Wright is not an actor, nor is he a monologuist; he has even struggled with a fear of public speaking. So whats he doing in a one-man show that has a six-week run at the Culture Project?

title: Interior Dept. Gets Reprieve on Its Decision on Bald Eagle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  With a court-ordered deadline looming for removal of the bald eagle from the endangered species list, the Interior Department, rejecting the advice of its staff wildlife biologists, tried to limit a separate set of protections for the majestic bird that has served as a national symbol for centuries.

title: Cracked Rail Delays Thousands on Subway
description: A cracked rail, probably due to the cold weather, between the Queensboro Plaza and the 59th Street and Lexington Avenue subway stations delayed thousands of commuters today on the N and R subway lines in New York City.

title: Ads Made by You, in a Click
description: The Internet has allowed consumers to trade stocks without using high-priced brokers and travelers to book flights directly from airlines.

title: House Democrats Set Framework for Iraq Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  House Democratic leaders said today that the Iraq war resolution scheduled to be debated next week would be limited to President Bushs plan to dispatch more troops to Baghdad, leaving any controversial decisions over war spending for a later discussion.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Yukos, the oil giant, as it braces for fallout from new charges against its former leaders, misidentified the participant in a conference call who said that prosecutors had accused the companys former chief, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, of embezzlement. It was Sanford Saunders, a lawyer for Mr. Khodorkovsky; it was not Charles Krause, a spokesman for Mr. Khodorkovsky.

title: From the Jurassic to the Patio
description: I WENT to the Plant-O-Rama, the annual horticultural hoo-hah at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, in search of new plants two weeks ago, and fell in love with one of the oldest on earth: the Wollemi pine, which grew among the dinosaurs 200 million years ago.

title: Records Show Extra Scrutiny of Detainees in 04 Protests
description: When more than a thousand people were swept up in mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention, defense lawyers complained in court that the protesters had to wait much longer to see a judge than those accused of far more serious crimes like robbery or assault.

title: North Carolina Rallies, Extending Dukes Skid to 3
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 7  Tyler Hansbrough, North Carolinas premier forward, was aghast at discovering an enemy Duke sticker strategically placed on his truck not long ago. Hansbrough, a leading all-America candidate, affectionately known in these parts as Psycho T, immediately tore it off.

title: Hamas and Fatah Pledge to Meet Until They Agree
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 7  The leaders of the two main Palestinian political groups ended their first day of an emergency summit meeting on Wednesday promising to stay until they agreed on a new government to end a wave of violence in Gaza and the West Bank and salvage the moribund Israeli-Palestinian peace effort.

title: Officials See a Spread in Activity of Gangs
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7  The authorities warned Wednesday that street gangs with ties to El Salvador and other Central American nations have been growing in size and violence, with two gangs based in Los Angeles counting thousands of members here and in El Salvador.

title: Italian Court to Try Soldier
description: ROME, Feb. 7  An American soldier was ordered to stand trial in Italy in connection with the shooting death of a top Italian intelligence agent in Iraq in 2005. But the trial, set for April 17 in Rome, is likely to occur without the defendant.

title: A Childrens Camera That Lets Piglet Say Cheese
description: The Disney Pix Max from Digital Blue is designed for the child who is longing for a real digital camera. Its most fun feature is the ability to superimpose Disney characters over the picture in your viewfinder in real time. If you want to have Piglet smiling at your dog, you press a magic wand button and line up the picture so Piglet is posed right where you want him.

title: Offer to Buy a Liberal Radio Network
description: Stephen L. Green has offered $4.25 million for the assets of Air America Radio, the liberal talk-radio network, setting up an auction for the company, court documents show.

title: Anna Nicole Smith Dies at 39
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7  Anna Nicole Smith, a former Playboy centerfold, actress and television personality who was famous, above all, for being famous, but also for being sporadically rich and chronically litigious, was found dead on Thursday in her suite at the Seminole Hard Rock Caf Hotel and Casino in Hollywood, Fla. She was 39 and the cause of her death was not immediately known.

title: Bradley Krause, 58, Kinkos Partner, Is Dead
description: Bradley Krause, who by raising his hand in his college graphics arts class became a founding partner of Kinkos, the office supply and printing company, died on Jan. 24 near his home in Cutchogue, N.Y. He was 58.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Wizardry at Harvard: Physicists Move Light
description: Its like three-card monte. Now you see it. Now you dont. Then you see it  over there.

title: Iraqi Health Official Is Arrested for Militia Ties
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 8  Iraqi and American troops arrested the second-highest official in the Iraqi Health Ministry on Thursday, charging that he funneled millions of dollars to rogue Shiite militants who kidnapped and killed Iraqi civilians.

title: Electronic Data Systems Nearly Doubles Quarterly Net Income
description: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit almost doubled after it reduced costs and generated more revenue from government orders.

title: Mayor Strikes at Critics of Bus Plan
description: Displaying impatience with questions about the school bus confusion that has left children shivering across the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg attacked his critics yesterday as do-nothing complainers lacking experience in anything at all.

title: 8-Year Lapse in Safety Procedures Adds to Debate on New Jersey Power Plant
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, N.J.  After inspectors found 10 years ago that rust had eaten nearly a third of the way through parts of the steel containment liner that surrounds the Oyster Creek nuclear reactor, the plants owner signed an agreement with federal regulators promising to stop further damage before it became a safety hazard.

title: Bargain Time for Antiques
description: WHEN Stacy Becker decorated her new homes in Houston, Tex., and Aspen, Colo., four years ago, she got rid of most of the 18th- and 19th-century antiques she had collected since the 1980s. Ms. Becker, whose husband, Brian, is an entertainment executive, wanted a more comfortable, more practical environment. She replaced the antiques with modern pieces, like geometric sectionals for her four teenagers to flop on, and sleek marble coffee tables that dont need coasters beneath perspiring sodas. Her former furnishings were sold off in an open house for designers.

title: Europe Proposes to Reduce New Cars Carbon Dioxide
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 7  The European Commission on Wednesday proposed binding rules that require automakers to cut carbon dioxide emissions for new cars, prompting criticism from European auto companies that said the rules went too far and environmentalists who said the regulations did not go far enough.

title: The President Shows His Environmentalist Colors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  After six years in the Oval Office, George W. Bush may have found his inner Teddy Roosevelt.

title: Letter Bombs Are Coordinated, Britain Says
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  A letter bomb exploded at Britains main motor vehicle agency on Wednesday, extending what the police depicted as a coordinated series of attacks that has troubled the nations leaders and inspired comparisons with the Unabomber in the United States.

title: California: Greens Safety Program
description: In response to an E. coli outbreak in September in California-grown spinach that killed three people and sickened more than 200, the states Department of Agriculture said it had certified a plan to establish an inspection program for handlers of leafy greens. The agreement was created by the handlers themselves in the wake of last falls outbreak, which resulted in the removal of spinach from grocery store shelves for several weeks. The agreement will also create a label for products that meet with new standards for packing, growing and shipping.

title: A Story in Every Box
description: TIFFANY & Company has long enjoyed a gilded reputation, conferred by its association with the happy things in life: engagements, weddings, babies, trophies, retirements, anniversaries and romantic Hollywood movies. Most notable among the last category is Breakfast at Tiffanys, the 1961 version of the 1958 Truman Capote novella. In the movie, Holly Golightly and the writer find the cat and decide to get married and live happily ever after.

title: Edwards Learns Perils of Political Bloggers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  John Edwards learned the hard way this week of the perils of trying to graft the raucous culture of the Internet to the decidedly more staid world of a presidential campaign.

title: Iraq: U.S. Forms Refugees Task Force
description: With concern mounting in Congress about the slow pace of resettling Iraqi refugees in the United States, the State Department has announced the creation of a new task force to be led by Paula J. Dobriansky, the under secretary of state for democracy and global affairs. It will coordinate the Bush administrations efforts to resettle Iraqi refugees in the United States and offer assistance to those living elsewhere. The United Nations estimates that two million Iraqis have fled Iraq and that 1.7 million are displaced within the country.

title: Brooklyn: Womans Death Attributed to Cold
description: An 84-year-old Brooklyn woman was the citys first victim of the recent cold snap, the medical examiners office announced yesterday. The woman, whose identity was not released, was found in her apartment on Sunday afternoon and taken to Interfaith Medical Center where she died later that day, according to Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. An autopsy, which was completed yesterday, found that the woman died of hypothermia, Ms. Borakove said. The autopsy also showed that the woman had a heart ailment and diabetes. Ms. Borakove said she had no information about whether the womans apartment had heat..

title: What Do You Play in the Evening? Serenades. Moonlight Becomes Them.
description: Sera makes the word serenade. The evening, when the workday is done and the hard sell exhausted, is the time for a gentler form of persuasion. Serenades pitch woo or pitch for whatever entitlement the serenader is looking for. What survives from these original meanings is an understanding that the salesmanship will have a certain grace.

title: Woodss Schedule May Aid Pursuit of Nelsons Mark
description: Tiger Woods says he has kept every handwritten note Byron Nelson gave him, each letter a piece of personal history both men shared. Several generations separated them, but Nelson and Woods found plenty in common, including the time they spent at a Masters champions dinner using their Augusta National silverware for more than cutting their food.

title: Riding the Rails All Over Union Sq.
description: When Yale Cousino and his friends in Vermont wanted to snowboard during the summer, they would fill the back of a pickup truck with snow found piled outside a local hockey rink. In Salt Lake City, Aaron Bittner would drive to the mountains and truck snow into the city.

title: With Bid of Well Over $1 Billion, Starrett City Auction Intensifies
description: A real estate partnership is attempting to outmaneuver rival bidders for Starrett City, the sprawling low- and moderate-income complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, by making a blockbuster offer of well over $1 billion to bring the auction to an abrupt end.

title: Cuomo to Sue Exxon Over Pollution in Brooklyn
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo moved today to sue ExxonMobil and four other companies over millions of gallons of oil lying under the Greenpoint neighborhood in Brooklyn and to repair environmental damage inflicted on the nearby Newtown Creek.

title: Mr. Bushs Improbable Budget
description: President Bush claims that his new $2.9 trillion budget request is a tough-minded plan for balancing the books by 2012. In reality, its a smokescreen for making Mr. Bushs tax cuts permanent  and either hollowing out the government in the process or digging the country deeper into debt.

title: City Was Billed for Tutoring of Dead Youth
description: From late January through mid-June of last year, Cheryl Edwards, a fifth-grade teacher at Public School 288 in Brooklyn, was paid nearly $6,000 to tutor a 15-year-old student who had become so ill that he was homebound.

title: A Big, Heartfelt Serving of the Old Razzle-Dazzle
description: Were just making it up as we go along, Ben Vereen remarked early in Tuesdays opening performance of his new cabaret show at Feinsteins at the Regency. And so it seemed. At one point he peered into the back of the club for a signal, then said: Ten minutes? Im just getting warmed up. In the past, he boasted, he was accustomed to going for two hours nonstop.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: J. K. Rowling Feels the Pain

title: Germany: A Siemens Ban on Consultants
description: Siemens, the German engineering company, banned its sales managers from using consultants for winning new orders after an investigation into whether money was embezzled through such agreements to bribe customers. We decided to introduce a general ban on the use of consultant agreements in our sales organization, a spokeswoman, Monika Bruecklmeier, said. Exceptions can be granted only through the companys head of compliance, she said. An investigation of such payments has spread to at least six countries and forced the company to review 420 million euros ($544 million) in payments, and has put pressure on Siemens to explain how the suspected system of bribes went unchecked by top management.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Army Says It Will Withhold $19.6 Million From Halliburton, Citing Potential Contract Breach
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The Army announced during a House oversight committee hearing on Wednesday that it would withhold $19.6 million from the Halliburton Company after recently discovering that the contractor had hired the company Blackwater USA to provide armed security guards in Iraq, a potential breach of its government contract.

title: Talking the Talk and Compiling the Clues
description: Hotel Dusk: Room 215, a noirish adventure game from Cing, has a beginning so stylish and artful that as I watched it, I could think only one thing; this game has nowhere to go but down.

title: Johnson Adjusts to Nascars Winners Spotlight
description: Still wearing his overcoat and gloves, Jimmie Johnson plopped down at a table at Gallaghers Steak House in Midtown yesterday, pining for a warmer seat inside a rumbling stock car on a big racetrack 1,000 miles south.

title: Louisiana: Discipline Change Is Opposed
description: A group representing the highest judicial officers of every state announced its opposition to an American Bar Association commissions recommendation that the association abandon the appearance of impropriety as a basis for disciplining judges in its model code. The group, the Conference of Chief Justices, unanimously passed a resolution at a meeting in New Orleans urging the bar associations house of delegates, which will consider the proposal next week in Miami, to retain the standard. We are disappointed, Chief Judge Robert M. Bell of the Maryland Court of Appeals said, that the original draft of the proposed revision has been amended at the last minute to eliminate appearance of impropriety as a basis for disciplinary enforcement.

title: Amaechi, Former Player in N.B.A., Says Hes Gay
description: In an announcement made yesterday in advance of a forthcoming book, the former journeyman center John Amaechi became the first N.B.A. player to acknowledge that he is gay.

title: In Books, a Clash of Europe and Islam
description: Award nominations are generally occasions for exaggerated compliments and air kisses, so it was something of a surprise when Eliot Weinberger, a previous finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award, announced the newest nominees for the criticism category two weeks ago and said one of the authors, Bruce Bawer, had engaged in racism as criticism.

title: Pair of Inexact Sciences: Computer Play and Bidding
description: Bridge players have to bid with a limited 15-word vocabulary: one through seven, the five strains, pass, double and redouble. It is impossible to describe all hands perfectly. It would be much simpler with adjectival bidding. Instead of a two-club opening bid being strong and artificial, it could suddenly be two Precision clubs, showing six-plus clubs and 11-15 points. Or in the middle of the auction you could bid three game-invitational  or game-forcing  spades. In the real world, though, some flexibility and imagination are required.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Gian Carlo Menotti, the opera composer, referred imprecisely to the number of times his work Amahl and the Night Visitors has been performed since its creation for television in 1951. While it has indeed been performed more than 600 times, the number of performances since that time exceeds 2,500.

title: Bank Settles Shelter Suits by Investors
description: Correction Appended

title: Landis Is on Tour to Finance Defense
description: Floyd Landis, who won the 2006 Tour de France but has been accused of doping to do so, held a fund-raiser last night in Brooklyn, taking part in a question-and-answer session about his legal battle and efforts to clear his name.

title: Emotions Run High at Hearing in Bias Killing
description: The three men accused of killing a gay man arrived for a pretrial hearing yesterday and found a courtroom filled to near capacity. Spectators clutched one another and sobbed openly. The process took no more than 20 minutes, but it set the tone for an emotionally and politically charged case, one that most likely remains months away from trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: P.G.A. Removes International From Schedule
description: The International, known for its milkshakes and a unique scoring system, has been removed from the PGA Tour schedule after the tournament failed to find sponsorship for this years event at the Castle Pines Golf Club in Castle Rock, Colo. Commissioner Tim Finchem and Jack Vickers, the tournament founder, have scheduled a news conference today at the Denver Athletic Club to address the situation.

title: Downtown, Scavenging for Castoffs
description: FROM the roof of the Cosmopolitan Hotel at the corner of Chambers Street and West Broadway, Craig Bero has a hawks-eye view of his new hunting ground, the 10-block radius that surrounds his year-old restaurant, the Soda Shop, below. On a recent frozen Thursday afternoon, Mr. Bero chain smoked Merit cigarettes and demonstrated the areas potential.

title: Averys Arrival Injects Rangers With a Sense of the Possible
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 7  As a team employee screwed a new nameplate above Sean Averys locker Wednesday after practice, the Rangers were left to hope that Avery brought with him some sort of winning magic, not merely a penchant for taking penalties and dating starlets.

title: Reynoldss Pact Is Included in Amended ESPN Suit
description: Harold Reynolds, a baseball analyst who was accused of sexual harassment and fired by ESPN last year, was scheduled to earn at least $4.875 million in a six-year contract that went into effect last March.

title: Europe Cool to Apples Suggestions on Music
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  Is digital music turning into another issue on which Europeans and Americans just cant sing from the same hymn sheet?

title: House Sets Path for Iraq Vote, but Must Decide What to Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  As the House prepares for three days of debate next week on Iraq, Democratic leaders sought Wednesday to reconcile deep differences within the party in order to shape a symbolic resolution denouncing President Bushs troop buildup plan.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column yesterday, about the shows Lost and Heroes, referred imprecisely to the character Walt on Lost. While he is missing from the story, having left the island with his father at the end of last season, he is not still missing because of his kidnapping.

title: With Oscar and Felix as Co-Founders, Does a Company Have a Chance?
description: When the Lamp Dude and the Academic decided to go into business together, it had all the makings of a minidisaster. He, after all, could remember every Grateful Dead show he ever attended. She, on the other hand, was more interested in womens issues and public policy. She is analytical and reflective and thrives on team-building. He is a free spirit who prefers to work solo.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the Ink feature on Tuesday, about a book party in Manhattan for Generation on Fire, on the protests of the 1960s, misidentified a guest, one of several who had been interviewed for the book. The man pictured was Barry Melton, a public defender and former rock guitarist  not Barry Levine, another guest, whose girlfriend Allison Krause was killed at Kent State.

title: Nuclear Talks on North Korea Set to Resume in Beijing
description: BEIJING, Feb. 7  Negotiators on Thursday will resume the long-stalled talks aimed at North Korean nuclear disarmament amid tentative signs of a possible breakthrough in a diplomatic process that seemed shattered four months ago when North Korea tested a nuclear device.

title: A Winter White That Works for Spring
description: WHATEVER the charms of the International Tennis Hall of Fame gala, held every year during the United States Open, looking for mens fashion trends there would seem to be a fools errand.

title: A380 Test Flight: 2 Bars, 15 Lavatories and 200 Reporters
description: TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 7  John J. Leahy, the master salesman of Airbus, was reeling off trivia as the A380 barreled down a rain-swept runway here on Wednesday, carrying 200 journalists on the first flight for the news media of this double-decker jet, the worlds largest passenger plane.

title: Scope of Hospital Cuts (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Kaizen, That Continuous Improvement Strategy, Finds Its Ideal Environment
description: Remember when Japanese manufacturing techniques were all the rage? You could hardly read the business press without encountering mention of lean manufacturing, just-in-time inventory systems and total quality management.

title: What May Have Made Good Neighbors Now Present a Puzzle
description: The walls are not the Wall.

title: The Tragedy of Lisa Nowak
description: The charge of attempted murder lodged against Capt. Lisa Nowak is not just a tragedy for the astronaut and her family. It strikes at the cherished image of astronauts as superior individuals who can cope with stresses that might crumple the rest of us. However the criminal charges are ultimately resolved, there is already a clear lesson of this bizarre case: astronauts are human, subject to the same marital strains and mental aberrations that afflict more ordinary mortals.

title: Few Veteran Diplomats Accept Mission to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  While the diplomats and Foreign Service employees of the State Department have always been expected to staff hardship postings, those jobs have not usually required that they wear flak jackets with their pinstriped suits.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Jan. 30, about the Arab League, misstated the subtitle of a book by the writer, Milton Viorst. The book is Storm From the East: The Struggle Between the Arab World and the Christian West, not The Conflict Between the Arab World and the Christian West.

title: Manhattan: Train Jumps Tracks at Grand Central
description: Several hundred passengers aboard a Metro-North train were stranded for about an hour yesterday morning, after it jumped the tracks as it was pulling into Grand Central Terminal, the railroad said. None of the passengers aboard the train, the 7:42 from Stamford, were hurt, according to Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman for the railroad. She said the train was going about five miles an hour when it jumped the tracks, and that the passengers would have felt a little bump. The first two cars of the seven-car train had reached the platform when the third car and the front set of wheels on the fourth came off the rails as the cars went over a switch.

title: Such Cheek! Those Were the Days, Architects
description: If you are revolted by todays slick and fashion-obsessed architecture scene, hurry over to Clip/Stamp/Fold: The Radical Architecture of Little Magazines at the Storefront for Art and Architecture. Youll feel even worse.

title: At Libby Trial, Russert of NBC Gives and Gets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The prosecution in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. neared the end of its case Wednesday with a final dramatic flourish  putting Tim Russert of NBC News on the witness stand to deliver what could be a serious blow to Mr. Libbys defense.

title: Apartment Complex in Brooklyn Sold for $1.3 Billion
description: An investment group agreed at 3 oclock this morning to buy Starrett City, the sprawling low- and moderate-income complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, for $1.3 billion, a price that experts say illustrates an exuberant real estate market.

title: Nigerian Agency Calls 135 Unfit to Run for Office
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 7  More than 130 candidates running in Nigerias next state and national elections, scheduled for April, are unfit for office because of serious corruption allegations, Nigerias antigraft agency declared Wednesday.

title: Rell Seeks Tax Increase to Raise $3 Billion for Connecticuts Public Schools
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 7  Using a decisive election victory to take a political risk, Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Wednesday proposed raising Connecticuts income tax to 5.5 percent from 5 percent to pay for a $3.4 billion increase in education spending over the next five years.

title: Olympic Construction Unearths Ancient Treasure Trove
Waiting List Gone, Incentives Are Coming for Prius
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7  Toyota has hardly needed to do anything to sell its hybrid-electric Prius, which always had more buyers than Toyota had cars, but sales have flattened just as the carmaker is able to produce more Priuses.

title: Prospect of Seizing Control of the State Senate Leaves New York Democrats Giddy
description: Savoring their triumph in a pivotal special election for a State Senate seat on Long Island, exultant New York Democrats suggested yesterday that they were poised to seize control of the Senate for the first time in decades. Republicans called the idea preposterous.

title: Saban and Davis Show They Can Still Recruit
description: They have yet to coach in a game since returning to college football, but Alabamas Nick Saban and North Carolinas Butch Davis are well on their way toward transforming the programs they were hired to revive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study finding that talk therapy is an effective treatment for panic disorder misstated the credentials of two experts quoted. The researchers, Dianne Chambless of the University of Pennsylvania and David H. Barlow of Boston University, are psychologists, not psychiatrists.

title: They Beat Gary So Bad
description: ST. ROSE, La.

title: News Corporation Earnings Decline 24%
description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdochs media company, said yesterday that quarterly profit fell 24 percent from a year earlier, when it had a one-time gain from asset sales. Revenue rose 18 percent, partly on the box-office hit Borat.

title: How Not to Inflame Iraq
description: BEFORE the United States invaded Iraq on false pretexts nearly four years ago, the overwhelming view of analysts and diplomats was that war would plunge the region and the world into greater turmoil and instability. Echoing the views of my colleagues from the region and beyond, I told the Security Council on Feb. 18, 2003, that while the ramifications of the war could go beyond anyones calculations, one outcome is almost certain: extremism stands to benefit enormously from an uncalculated adventure in Iraq.

title: Queens: Sitter Guilty of Shaken-Baby Assault
description: A former baby sitter was convicted yesterday of shaking an 8-month-old boy, causing severe brain injuries, while caring for him seven years ago, prosecutors said. The baby sitter, Yun Zapana, 54, of Astoria, was convicted of assault after a monthlong trial in State Supreme Court, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said. He said that Ms. Zapana shook the boy while watching him in her home in March 1999. The boy, now 8, does not speak or respond to his name, Mr. Brown said. Ms. Zapana faces up to 25 years in prison.

title: If Leonardo Had Made Toys
description: LEONARDO DA VINCIS 15th-century vision of mechanical flight apparently never included fixed wings assisted by propellers or jet engines. His chief inspiration was birds, reflected in drawings of a flying machine fashioned to stay aloft by flapping its wings.

title: Libby Defense Takes on NBCs Russert
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  A lawyer for I. Lewis Libby Jr. tried to chip away at the credibility of the television journalist Tim Russert today, suggesting at Mr. Libbys trial that there was bad blood between Mr. Libby and NBC News.

title: A Pint-Size Navigator for Those Traveling Light
description: A G.P.S. navigation device is needed most when you are trying to drive around an unfamiliar city. But you dont want to lug a bulky gadget if your trip involves leaving the car at home.

title: Were Not Dating: A Morning Show With Sex on the Brain
description: Hes smarmy. Shes contrived. He leers at girls like an old stage ham. She talks about freezing her eggs and getting her breasts done. Together theyre Mike Jerrick and Juliet Huddy, Foxs new morning pair, who use their unholy chemistry to pervert the breakfast hour on The Morning Show With Mike and Juliet. We owe these two a warm, warm welcome.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the response by the New York Fire Department and the fire officers union to a report revealing that 14 of the departments employees had used, or tried to use, bogus diplomas to get promoted or hired misidentified the union. It is the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, not the Uniformed Firefighters Association.The article also referred incorrectly to the firehouse in Chelsea where a retired firefighter, Arthur Jens, who said experience was more important than education, had worked. It was at Engine 3, Ladder 12  not Engine 13.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture yesterday with a report in the Arts, Briefly column about the new head of Actors Equity Association was published in error. It showed a business executive named John P. Connolly, not the John P. Connolly who is national president of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and who will step down in March to take the Actors Equity post.

title: Athletes Embrace Size, Rejecting Stereotypes
description: NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 5  The University of Oklahoma tells womens basketball fans a lot about Courtney Paris, the Sooners 6-foot-4 center. They know that she ranks third in the country in scoring, second in rebounding and that her dream job is to be a novelist. That her best friend is her identical twin and teammate, Ashley Paris, and that her father, Bubba Paris, won three Super Bowls as a lineman for the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Leon J. Thal, Neurologist Who Led Study for Alzheimers Drugs, Dies at 62
description: Leon J. Thal, a leading researcher on drugs to treat Alzheimers disease and other forms of dementia, died on Saturday in a plane crash near Borrego Springs, Calif. He was 62.

title: The Knicks Fortunes Are Improving on the Court and at the Ticket Booth
description: An odd disturbance coursed through Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, a tremor that bounced from section to section and made the Knicks stop and gaze in wonder.

title: Newark Squandered Millions, Audit Sought by Booker Shows
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7  An audit of the way Newark City Hall sends out its water bills, inspects its restaurants and pays private tow-truck operators has documented an antiquated and disorganized bureaucracy that has been squandering millions of dollars, encouraging municipal malfeasance and potentially putting the health of its residents at risk.

title:
Legislators Pick a Comptroller,
Defying Spitzer
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7  State lawmakers rebuffed Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Wednesday by choosing one of their own as the next state comptroller, reneging on a deal they made with the governor to choose from candidates deemed qualified by an outside panel.

title: A Player Serves Notice to Homophobic Sports Culture
description: Penn State Coach Rene Portlands gaydar is obviously haywire.

title: Astronauts Arrest Spurs Review of NASA Testing
description: NASA is reviewing its psychological screening and checkup process in the wake of the arrest of Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the astronaut accused of attempted murder, space agency officials said yesterday. It will also try to determine whether indications of concern in Captain Nowaks case were overlooked.

title: Souls Hungry for Salvation, but Thirsty for the Bottle
description: LONDON  To drink or not to drink. In The Seafarer, the booze-drenched new drama by Conor McPherson at the National Theater, the question isnt simply social, medical or moral; its metaphysical. Bringing that glass of poteen or lager to the lips  and doing it again and again and again  becomes an existential choice in this electrically acted work, which is directed by Mr. McPherson and was nominated last month for an Olivier Award for best new play.

title: Calendar
description: Gardening Lectures

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: FIJI It only sounds like paradise. In this seriess latest installment, 19 Americans start out as one tribe on an island rich with supplies and resources with which they set up what is being promoted as an exceptionally comfortable camp. But on Day 3, trouble starts to brew as the castaways are split into two teams and the losing tribe must relocate to a new island with only a pot, a machete and a water source. Castaways who dont play well with others will be further banished  one per episode  to Exile Island, miles away from civilization.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,093 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Faculty Resists Vote on Bush Institute
description: The Faculty Senate at Southern Methodist University in Dallas rejected a proposal yesterday for a faculty referendum on plans for an independent policy institute on campus that would accompany President Bushs future library and museum.

title: N.F.L. Prospects Head to Boot Camp
description: At the end of a recent workout, Mario Henderson and Gabe Hall shook hands at the 15-yard line of a football field in North Jersey. Only they did not let go. An impromptu thumb-wrestling match unfolded, with each man leveraging his 300-pound frame. From afar, they looked like sumo wrestlers jostling for survival.

title: Mexico: Pemex Oil Field Declining
description: Production at Mexicos giant Cantarell oil field will fall by 15 percent this year, Jess Reyes Herles, left, the director general of Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexicos state-owned oil monopoly, said. Output dropped 13.1 percent last year. Mr. Reyes Herles, a former energy minister who took over at Pemex in December, said other projects would help make up for the shortfall at Cantarell, which last year accounted for about 55 percent of Pemexs overall production of 3.26 million barrels a day. Mexico is a top supplier of imported oil to the United States. Mr. Reyes Herles said that the company needed additional investment of $8 billion to $10 billion a year to keep up production, develop new reserves, expand its refining capacity and modernize its storage and transport network. But Pemex is closed to private investment and cannot finance the investment itself. Last year, Pemex sales surpassed $100 billion but it paid $79 billion in taxes, which accounted for almost 40 percent of Mexicos federal budget.

title: VeriSign Moves to Address an Internet Security Problem
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7  To keep up with the growing strains put on the Internet by both legitimate users and online attackers, a Silicon Valley company is undertaking a $100 million expansion of a crucial part of the system that speeds Web users to their destinations.

title: Hey, George, What Song Do You Have Playing on My iPod?
description: Perhaps Chestnut Hill Sound ran out of more generic names and is kicking off a new product line honoring our nations presidents. Whatever the reason, the companys new iPod dock is called George.

title: Private Virtue, Public Vice
description: Deep in the bowels of Washington, hidden from public scrutiny and prying cameras, there is an illicit underworld where people are subtle, reasonable and interesting. I have occasionally been admitted to this place, the land of RIP (Reasonable in Private).

title: After Record Profit, Chief Says Hell Leave
description: SINGAPORE, Feb. 7  Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through Chinas bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

title: Russia: Khodorkovsky Dismisses New Charges as Absurd
description: In a statement from prison, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the imprisoned founder of Yukos Oil who was charged this week with embezzlement and money laundering, declared the new charges an ungrounded, absurd indictment. He predicted that he would be convicted nonetheless. In the statement, which was posted on his Web site, he also wrote about the state of Russias judiciary and called for honest presidential elections next year. He said the politician who replaced President Vladimir V. Putin should have nothing in common with the giant corruption machine that has paralyzed Russia. Mr. Khodorkovsky, nearly halfway through an eight-year prison term, faces as many as 15 more years if convicted on the new counts.

title: Merger Activity Lifts Lazard to Record 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that strength in its merger-advisory business helped lift its fourth-quarter profit 50 percent, to a record $85.8 million.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the abduction of an Iranian diplomat in Baghdad rendered incorrectly the name of a spokesman for Irans Foreign Ministry in Tehran who was quoted as saying he could not immediately confirm the abduction. He is Mohammad Ali Hosseini, not Mohammad alHosseini.

title: Cutting to the Bone Without the Angst
description: Misguided though it may be, American fashion is not complacent. One can point to the provocative designs of Thom Browne and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte, recent winners of industry laurels, as proof of an independent, even transgressive, spirit.

title: Price of Next Big Thing in Physics: $6.7 Billion
description: The price of exploring inner space went up Thursday.

title: From Italy, a Pianistic Palette With Playful Dashes of Humor
description: American jazz audiences best know Stefano Bollani as the pianist of choice for the trumpeter Enrico Rava, Italys most accomplished jazz musician. In Italy Mr. Bollani is considerably more: a novelist, a media personality, almost a comedic brand. His first ECM album as a leader, Piano Solo, arrived in the United States this week; when it was released in his own country six months ago, it breached the Top 20 on the pop charts.

title: The U.N. in Bosnia (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Charges That Nursery Mistreated Laborers
description: The 12 men were recruited in Guatemala and granted legal work visas to plant pine trees in North Carolina. But when they landed in Greensboro last spring, eager to work for promised wages of $7.50 an hour, a very different fate awaited them.

title: Security Debate Centers on Tougher Standards for Inspections of Air Cargo
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The suitcases loaded onto a Seattle-bound flight at Dulles International Airport each went through an electronic device that can sniff out explosives. But the planes belly also held bins filled with cargo  as varied as decorative plates and computer supplies  most of which got no such scrutiny.

title: Yes, You Do Look Fat
description: IT is Fashion Week, the temperatures are subfreezing, and so an ode to the snug down coat is due.

title: China: Survey Suggests Greater Religious Belief
description: The number of religious believers in China could be far higher than previously reported, according to a new survey. Nearly a third of the 4,500 people surveyed described themselves as religious in the poll, by two professors at East China Normal University in Shanghai. The proportion suggests that 300 million people in China could be religious, three times the official figure of 100 million. China Daily, the official English-language newspaper, said two-thirds of the respondents followed traditional religions like Taoism or Buddhism. The survey also suggested that China might have 40 million or more Christians; the latest official estimate, in 2005, put the figure at 16 million.

title: Peter Doig Canoe Painting Gets $10 Million
description: LONDON  A painting by the Scottish-born artist Peter Doig fetched $10 million on Wednesday at an auction at Sothebys, breaking the artists record and underlining the enduring market influence of the works latest owner, the collector Charles Saatchi.

title: Room to Improve
description: A. Many people complain that they cannot find childrens furnishings that are durable or stylish. But there are adult-caliber designers who focus on children, and there are furniture stores whose designs will work for young children and can grow with them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies on Jan. 31 about the writer and producer Sidney Sheldon erroneously credited him with an award for a television show he created and produced, I Dream of Jeannie. He was nominated for an Emmy but did not win.

title: Child Pornography on Vienna Computer Prompts Worldwide Hunt
description: PARIS, Feb. 7  Austrian authorities have gathered information on more than 2,360 individuals from 77 countries who tried to view child pornography through a Russian Web site stored on a Vienna computer, the countrys Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Tuesday about a decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission to give Nasdaq Stock Market permission to increase fees and add company services referred imprecisely to the scope of the regulatory approval. While the market needed permission to raise fees, no approval was needed to offer services like news-release distribution and Internet broadcasts of company presentations.

title: At the Garden, a New, Racy Justin Timberlake
description: After a few songs at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, Justin Timberlake needed a break. Like a man whod just spent a hard day hip-thrusting at the office, he shrugged off his white suit jacket. Loosened his tie. Rolled up his sleeves. Then he kicked back with a relaxing cocktail. He hadnt played the Garden since 2000, with N Sync, and certainly that deserved a toast.

title: For Williams and Yankees, Clock Is Ticking
description: The next road trip on Bernie Williamss schedule is not to Tampa, Fla., for Yankees spring training. He will not be packing bats and gloves. Instead, he will bring his guitar to a church in New Milford, Conn., tomorrow, for a benefit concert with Chynna Phillips.

title: Over-the-Counter Weight-Loss Drug Is Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the first officially sanctioned weight-loss drug to be sold without a prescription.

title: Two Things to Get Us Out of Iraq (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellis W. Williamson, Who Led Troops in Vietnam, Is Dead at 88
description: Maj. Gen. Ellis W. Williamson, who led the first Army combat troops into South Vietnam, died on Jan. 28 in Arlington, Va. He was 88.

title: Gaping Reminders of Aging and Crumbling Pipes
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  After a sinkhole swallowed a sewer-repair truck here on the day after Christmas, the trucks crew crawled to safety, muddy and mystified.

title: Haunting Images
description:
Additional works from Armando Revern at the
Museum of Modern Art.

title: A Breeding Ground for Anger
description: All eight suspects in the plot to kill Hrant Dink, a prominent editor in Turkey, came from near the regional capital of Trabzon.

title: The International Linear Collider
description: The International Linear Collider is a proposed electron-positron collider that would be 20 miles long and cost $6.7 billion.

title: Commercial Success?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Michael Chabon
description: Michael Chabon has written eight books, among them The Yiddish Policemens Union, to be published in May by HarperCollins. Gentlemen of the Road is dedicated to Michael Moorcock.

title: A Prolific Life
Life as a Tabloid Tale
description: Anna Nicole Smith -- Playboy centerfold, widow of an octogenarian billionaire, reality-show subject, tragic mother -- died at 39.

title: Curios in Oxford
description: The academic town of Oxford, England, is a cabinet of historic curiosities.

title: The Next Coney Island Point Guard
description: High school basketball phenom Lance Stephenson has the potential to be the next great New York City point guard.

title: J. K. Rowling Feels the Pain
description: Now that J. K. Rowling has finished the seventh and concluding volume of the adventures of the boy wizard Harry Potter, sadness has become a companion. On her Web site, jkrowling.com, she says: I always knew that Harrys story would end with the seventh book, but saying goodbye has been just as hard as I always knew it would be. Even while Im in mourning, though, I feel an incredible sense of achievement. I can hardly believe that Ive finally written the ending Ive been planning for so many years. Ive never felt such a mixture of extreme emotions in my life, never dreamed I could feel simultaneously heartbroken and euphoric. Ms. Rowling acknowledges that Charles Dickens put it better than I ever could and proceeds to quote from his preface to David Copperfield: It would concern the reader little, perhaps, to know how sorrowfully the pen is laid down at the close of a two-years imaginative task; or how an Author feels as if he were dismissing some portion of himself into the shadowy world, when a crowd of the creatures of his brain are going from him for ever. Ms. Rowling adds, To which I can only sigh, try 17 years, Charles.

title: How Rich Was the YouTube Deal? Now We Know
description: Everyone suspected that the investors, founders and early employees of YouTube made tidy sums when it was acquired by Google for $1.65 billion in stock late last year.

title: Bank Settles Shelter Suits by Investors
description: Deutsche Bank has reached a settlement with hundreds of wealthy investors who bought aggressive tax shelters, a major shift in how it is dealing with the legal woes surrounding its tax shelter work.

title: Greens Air America Bid Rings In at Just $4.25 Million
description: Stephen L. Green has offered $4.25 million for the assets of Air America Radio, the liberal talk-radio network, setting up an auction for the company, court documents show.

title: Imperial Tobacco Strikes Deal for Commonwealth
description: The Imperial Tobacco Group, the British maker of Lambert & Butler cigarettes, agreed to buy Commonwealth Brands for $1.9 billion from Houchens Industries to enter the United States cigarette market. Bristol said it expects the acquisition of the company, which makes USA Gold and Sonoma, to increase profit this year. The purchase will probably be completed by April, according to the Imperial Tobacco.

title: HSBC Reports Rise in Loan Losses
description: The British bank HSBC Holdings said on Wednesday that its charge for bad debts would be more than $10.5 billion for 2006, some 20 percent above analysts average forecasts, because of problems in its mortgage portfolio. HSBC said in a trading update late on Wednesday that slowing growth in house prices was being reflected in accelerated delinquency trends across the subprime mortgage market, particularly in more recent loans.

title: EMC Plans Public Offering for Software Unit
description: EMC announced Wednesday that it planned to sell 10 percent of its fast-growing software subsidiary, VMware, in an initial public offering this summer. EMC, which specializes in data storage, bought VMware for $635 million three years ago. Industry analysts said the public offering could well value the company at more than 10 times that.

title: After Record Profit, Mining Chief Says Hell Leave
description: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through Chinas bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

title: V.C.s Tend Greenplums Garden
description: Greenplum, a start-up developing open-source business intelligence software, announced $19 million in financing and the hiring of Bill Cook, a former executive at Linux, as its new chief executive. Sierra Ventures led a $15 million financing round, and Comerica Bank extended a $4 million line of credit.

title: Egyptian Billionaire Takes Control of Greeces TIM Hellas
description: An Egyptian billionaire, Naguib Sawiris, agreed Wednesday to buy TIM Hellas Telecommunications from two buyout firms in a deal that valued the Greek cellphone company at about 3.4 billion euros and extended his reach in Europe. The deal provides an exit for sellers Apax Partners Worldwide and the Texas Pacific Group, which bought TIM Hellas two years ago for 1.4 billion euros. Mr. Sawiris, through his holding company, Weather Investments, will pay 500 million euros, or $650 million, and take on 2.9 billion euros in debt.

title: Motorola Seals Deal for Netopia
description: Motorola said Thursday it had formally completed its previously announced $208 million acquisition of Netopia, an Emeryville, Calif.-based maker of high-speed Internet modems and software. The communications-equipment giant first announced its agreement to buy publicly traded Netopia in November.

title: Australias WorleyParsons Buys Canadian Oil Sands Firm
description: Colt Engineering, a private Canadian company focused on the oil sands, is selling itself for 1 billion Canadian dollars ($843 million) to Australias WorleyParsons, saying that being part of a larger foreign company is the best choice to pursue further growth.

title: L.S.E. Rival Said to Lure More Investment Banks
description: Leading investment banks are considering joining Project Turquoise, the trading platform being created by seven financial firms to rival the London Stock Exchange. The banks developing the platform have received tentative requests  believed to be from ABN Amro and HSBC  to join forces, The Guardian reported.

title: General Atlantic Dumps EGL Deal
description: The private equity firm General Atlantic has pulled out of a $1.65 billion bid to take the shipping company EGL private, but the targets chief executive plans to seek new backers for a buyout. EGL, which is based in Houston and does business as EGL Eagle Global Logistics, said Wednesday that General Atlantic had withdrawn its support because the companys 2006 fourth-quarter earnings will fall short of estimates.

title: Immelt Slaps Down Stupid Deal Chatter
description: This, apparently, is what General Electrics chairman and chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, had to say about a report that he is considering selling NBC Universal: That was more or less made-up stupid drivel.

title: N.Y.S.E. Fines Morgan Stanley for Disruptive Trade
description: The New York Stock Exchange Wednesday said it had fined Morgan Stanley $300,000 for its failure to stop a trader from entering an order to buy $10.8 billion of stocks  not $10.8 million as intended  an error that disrupted trading in nearly 700 listed stocks. The N.Y.S.E. said Morgan Stanley did not have appropriate blocks within its trading systems to prevent an erroneous order from being routed to the N.Y.S.E. floor and failed to properly supervise and train traders.

title: Bain Bags South African Retailer
description: Edgars Consolidated Stores, South Africas biggest retailer by market value, agreed to be bought by Bain Capital for about 25 billion rand ($3.5 billion) in what would be the countrys largest private equity transaction. The offer is worth 46 rand a share, 15 percent above Wednesdays closing price. Edgars, which has more than 900 stores in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia and Swaziland, said that it recognizes that although its prospects remain positive, its future performance and corresponding growth profile are not without risk.

title: Murdoch Confirms Interest in Tribune
description: Tucked at the bottom of some news reports on the News Corporations quarterly earnings (profit fell 24 percent) was the notable nugget that Rupert Murdoch was indeed considering stepping into the auction of Tribune Company. Mr. Murdoch, News Corporations chairman, told reporters at a news conference that he might join the Chandler family, the Tribunes largest shareholder, in a bid for the publishing and broadcasting group.

title: Disney Backs Video Start-Up
description: The streaming video software developer Move Networks has emerged from stealth mode to announce its first institutional round of venture funding, an $11.3 million installment intended to spur the company to positive cash flow by years end. Steamboat Ventures, Walt Disneys investment arm, and Hummer Winblad Venture Partners co-led the round.

title: Jewelry Rack
description: Beyonc Knowles, who will not be playing a huge role at this years Oscars, as far as we know, set a record for ratio of pounds of bling to overall body weight back in 2005.

title: Mint Theater Wins Grant
description: The second annual Tony Randall grant, a $100,000 award given by the Tony Randall Theatrical Fund to a nonprofit theater in the New York metropolitan area for the production of a classic play or a play inspired by the classics, will go to the Mint Theater for a production of Tolstoy's 1886 play "The Power of Darkness," scheduled for this fall.

title: Measuring Particulates in the Atmosphere
description: Anne Thompson, who knows her way around a room, put on the mood ring the other day at the Academy luncheon and came up with the following conclusions: Helen Mirren and Martin Scorsese are locks. Supporting actors are up for grabs because of a power outage at Dreamgirls. And nobody knows anything about best picture  still.

title: Unusual Options Grants May Complicate Caremark Battle
description: While it battles CVS over Caremark Rx, Express Scripts may have some trouble in its own backyard. The prescription benefits manager has given stock option grants to its management at unusually lucrative times, The New York Post reported Thursday. The report arrives as Express Scripts criticizes Caremark executives for planning to enrich themselves through a $24.6 billion merger with CVS. Though its $26 billion bid was rejected, Express Scripts has already begun a tender offer for Caremark shares.

title: In Full Bloom
description: Images from New York City's Flower District.

title: Madness in Mumbai
description: Epic and raw, "Black Friday" is cut from the same bloody cloth as "Salvador" and "Munich." Although it's a period piece set in 1993, its subject matter couldn't be more urgent: how religious hatred (in this case, between India's Hindu majority and Muslim minority) manifested itself in institutionalized discrimination, race rioting and ultimately a series of terrorist bombings by Muslim guerrillas that killed 257 people in Mumbai, the nation's financial and filmmaking capital. (History repeated itself last year, when bombings killed 186 people in Mumbai.)

title: Right in the Thick of the Madding Crowd
description: Have you always felt that you were just a little smarter than the rest? You know, theres the keepers of the conventional wisdom, and then there is little old idiosyncratic you?

title: G.E. to Take 50% Stake in Sanyo Unit, Report Says
description: Goldman Sachs and Sanyo Electric are set to sell their combined 50 percent stake in the leasing firm Sanyo Electric Credit to G.E. Capital for about 45 billion yen ($372 million), Reuters reported Thursday, citing unidentified sources. The General Electric unit beat Shinseki Bank and Mitsui for the stake, those sources said. A Sanyo Electric spokesman said no official decision has been made to sell its stake in the credit unit.

title: Former S.E.C. Chair Donaldson to Join Perella Weinberg
description: William H. Donaldson, who co-founded the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and later became chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined Perella Weinberg Partners as chairman of its advisory council, the firm said Thursday.

title: Dame Helens New Age Appeal
description: This months AARP cover girl is Helen Mirren. (The Baguette saw a copy when it arrived for her mother, of course.) The headline says Hail to the Queen and is a close-up of Ms. Mirrens face. She looks oddly placid, drained of any emotion, which may be because the picture appears so airbrushed that not a single line or wrinkle is visible.

title: Golden Marathon
description: Stepping up to the Oscars a little undermovied? You can take care of all five best picture nominees in one butt-testing sitting on Feb. 24, the day before the Oscars. The programmers lined them up just right, in the Baggers estimation. The day starts with Babel, so you can mix some brain busters with a box of Dots, and then goes into The Queen, a nice single narrative after the four-pronged assault of Babel. Then the credits roll on The Departed, best viewed with a jumbo bucket of corn, after which everybody calms down with Letters From Iwo Jima. Then its into the van for Little Miss Sunshine so the long day ends in a hug.

title: Blackstone Prevails in Epic (and Poetic) Takeover Duel
description: The buyout battle for Equity Office Properties, the fiercest since the epic contest for RJR Nabisco in the late 1980s, immortalized in the book Barbarians at the Gate, had all the makings of good theater. Big money, big egos, a hot market and even poetry made the the takeover duel one of the most entertaining in years.

title: Oscar Drama
description: In the Baggers house, when we want to signal that someone or something has jumped the shark, we clench our right fist and bounce it off our chest before finishing with hand upraised and fingers splayed, which is otherwise known as getting in touch with our inner Celine Dion. Now as sure as we are that composer Ennio Morricone deserves his tribute, were also pretty sure no good can come of the decision to unleash Dion again (its her fifth appearance) at the Oscars. Were still trying to recover from the trauma of those Chrysler commercials.

title: Police Put Spotlight on L.A. Gangs  But Might They Enjoy It?
description: Los Angeles officials began a new offensive against criminal gangs  which are apparently growing like weeds despite years of anti-gang efforts in the city and a general decline in crime rates.

title: The Hill: Taxes Hamper Budget Talks
description: The Bush tax cuts that are to expire in 2010 pose problems for many leading Democrats, who contend that eliminating them would ultimately help balance the budget.

title: From Clinton, No Regret on the Iraq War Vote
Anna Sui-Fall 2007
description: Photos from Anna Sui's fall 2007 presentation in the Tent at Bryant Park.

title: In Mexican Drug Crackdown, Its Hard to Separate the Good Guys From the Bad
description: From the gangs of Los Angeles, we move to the drug gangs of Mexico. Machine-gun-toting, fatigue-wearing commandos stormed two police stations Tuesday and killed five police officers and two civilian employees.

title: The Magic Behind the Superzoom Lens
description: I've never reviewed a camera lens before. I mean, only a fraction of digital camera owners have digital S.L.R.s (the kind that accept interchangeable lenses), only a fraction of those are non-professionals like me, and only some of those shop more than a couple of times for lenses.

title: Trouble for Edwards in Blogland
description: Deciding whether to fire Amanda Marcotte, the blogmaster for John Edwardss campaign Web site, for anti-Catholic (and anti-Duke lacrosse players) posts on the feminist blog Pandagon last year is shaping into a make or break moment for John Edwardss young campaign, writes Conn Carroll at The Hotlines On Call blog. Already on the defensive from his netroots base for hawkish rhetoric on Iran, if Edwards relents to MSM pressure to fire Marcotte, his lefty blogger credibility will be destroyed.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "All That I Will Ever Be" and "A Spanish Play."

title: Goldilocks Goes Drinking
description: As I read the terrific article about London mixologists and bars by Kate Sekules in yesterdays Dining section, I got to thinking about all the things that go into a perfect cocktail, be it the drinks balance of sweetness and tartness or its color in a glass or the glass itself. (I also got to wondering about plane fares to London and just how much alcohol a liver can safely absorb in a long weekend, but thats another matter.

title: 2008: Religion and Money
description: Former Gov. Mitt Romney, Republican of Massachusetts, confronts a distinct hurdle that other possible presidential contenders in the 2008 field do not: hes a Mormon.

title: The Magic Behind the Superzoom Lens
description: Ive never reviewed a camera lens before. I mean, only a fraction of digital camera owners have digital S.L.R.s (the kind that accept interchangeable lenses), only a fraction of those are non-professionals like me, and only some of those shop more than a couple of times for lenses.

title: Revolving Door: Greenhill, Gibson Dunn
description: The turnaround veteran Martin F. Lewis joined Greenhill & Company as a managing director to help the New York-based investment bank expand its restructuring practice. Mr. Lewis recently worked at middle-market investment bank Rhone Group and before that was a name partner at Miller Buckfire, a firm that frequently advises bankrupt and financially distressed companies.

title: Bears, Colts and (Corporate) Jets
description: A composite radar image of corporate jets departing the Miami area on Monday morning  the day after the Super Bowl took place there  appears to show a parade of planes making beelines for New York, many of them doubtless hauling their human cargo back to jobs on Wall Street. A considerable number were headed to Chicago, and another handful seemed to be flying to, well, flyover country. The image, accessible Wednesday at the Air Transport Associations smartskies.org, has since been removed from that site, but not before it was picked up by other sites to be made the object of snarky comments. (Update: The image is back, at least for now.)

title: The Name, but Not the Price
description: In my column on Amarones, I mention briefly the legendary producer Giuseppe Quintarelli, only to excuse the absence of his Amarone from our tasting lineup. It does, after all, cost upwards of $300 a bottle, and as these are not the flushest of times for our beloved institution, we must occasionally forgo a treasure in our quest for vinous excellence. I think we all know this feeling.

title: Edwards Stands by Bloggers
description: John Edwards issued a statement today defending his hiring of two bloggers, Amanda Marcotte of Pandagon and Melissa McEwan of Shakespeares Sister, saying he believes in giving everyone a fair shake.

title: Italy Confronts Its Soccer Hooliganism
description: England, once known as the capital of soccer hooliganism, now has rivals for the title, according to The Associated Press:
