title: The Full Film
description: Seven actors talk about the films that made early impressions on them.

title: Ken Watanabe
description: 'Letters From Iwo Jima'

title: Brad Pitt
description: 'Babel'

title: Leonardo DiCaprio
description: 'The Departed'

title: Cate Blanchett
description: 'Notes From a Scandal'

title: Penelope Cruz
description: 'Volver'

title: Abbie Cornish
description: 'Somersault'

title: Helen Mirren
description: 'The Queen'

title: On Fortress I.P.O., Fans and Skeptics Abound
description: Demand for shares in Fortress Investment Group, which will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, is insane and ridiculous, an unnamed source told the Financial Times, bringing to mind the hype that surrounded many Internet offerings several years back. The amount of commentary on Fortresss initial public offering was also off the charts, as market pundits weighed in, often with a heavy dose of skepticism, on the first I.P.O. by a United States hedge fund.

title: Q & A: Modern Love
description: My name is Daniel Jones; I edit the Modern Love column in Sunday Styles. Since the column launched in October 2004, we have published nearly 120 personal essays covering a wide range of relationship experience: marriage, death, divorce, parenthood, dating. From a high school student in Seattle to a grandfather in Albany, these writers explore the complexities of love in all its forms, often through a contemporary lens.

title: Richardsons World Policy
description: Governors love to tout their executive experience, but they usually face a challenge establishing foreign policy creds. Not so for Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico. As a former United Nations ambassador and energy secretary, Mr. Richardson has dealt directly with issues that linger today, including a potentially nuclear North Korea.

title: In the Law-Firm Pay Race, Whos Really Ahead?
description: On Thursday, Holland & Knight became the latest law firm to raise the pay of its first-year associates. In doing so, it joins a long line of firms that are increasing compensation offers as competition to attract and retain young lawyers gets hotter. Still, the National Law Journal suggests that, while increases for associates may sound impressive, as measured against what law firms partners are getting, associates pay is actually falling.

title: Diller 1.0 Sounds Off on Web 2.0
description: Barry Diller has for more than a decade been resolutely skeptical about the Internet, even as he has become one of the industrys most powerful moguls. During the early part of the dot-com boom, before he became the head of a company (IAC/InterActiveCorp) that would own such Internet properties as CitySearch, Ask.com, and Ticketmaster, he often surveyed the Internet landscape  planted with capital-rich and profit-poor WebVans and Pets.coms  and professed to be mystified at how anyone could expect to make enough money from such ventures to justify their valuations.

title: Credit Suisse Adds Energy Banker
description: Credit Suisse has brought in John Thorndike, a longtime energy banker from Merrill Lynch, as a managing director and chairman of power in the Americas for its investment banking group, according to an internal announcement. Mr. Thorndike was most recently vice chairman of investment banking at Merrill and was previously a co-head of Merrills global energy and power group, Credit Suisse said.

title: Blogtalk: Functional Albany?
description: Some say the Capitol is dysfunctional, but the Web technicians are on the ball. Yesterday Tom DiNapolis Assembly page was revised almost immediately after his elevation to comptroller and now less than 24 hours later, the same goes for the comptroller site. Also: More about the vote. And Assemblyman Greg Balls 15 seconds. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Parsing the Casey Vote
description: The Senate voted today to confirm General George Casey as the next Army chief of staff.

title: Greenlands Glaciers Take a Breather
description: Greenland isnt melting as fast as we feared.

title: Anna Nicole Smith Dies
description: Word on the wires is that Anna Nicole Smith  the buxom former Playboy model, occasional actress and singer, reality-television star, diet-pill peddler and, arguably most famously, the wife of billionaire oil baron J. Howard Marshall II  has died.

title: Pelosi One
description: It is quite a ways from Washington to San Francisco by air but evidently nowhere near the size of the divide separating House Democrats and Republicans when it comes to the travel arrangements of Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

title: Chipping Away at Family Leave
description: An interesting new chapter in the family wars has been playing out lately under the radar. In response to pressure from business groups, the Department of Labor has put out an official request for information on the Family and Medical Leave Act to find out if, as critics contend, the law is too generous and places an undue burden on employers who are required to comply with it.

title: Double Burger, Part I
description: The citys love of burgers blazes bright as ever, and the burger places keep on coming, sometimes faster than those of us at The Times can keep up with them, be it on this blog or in the newspapers $25 and Under column. What to do?

title: Dogfighting in Russia
description: In the former Soviet Union, dogfighting competitions have surged in popularity since the collapse of Communism.

title: Proenza Schouler - Fall 2007
description: Reporter Eric Wilson interviews designers Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler about their Fall 2007 runway collection.

title: Perinatal Hospice Care
description: After learning that their unborn babies carried fatal genetic flaws, two families turned to specialized hospice programs for support.

title: Speakers Plane Becomes a Point of Criticism
description: Republicans accused Speaker Nancy Pelosi of putting on royal airs because her cross-country travel could require a larger military jet than the one used since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to ferry Speaker J. Dennis Hastert home to Illinois. Ms. Pelosi and fellow Democrats said that House security officials insisted that she travel in a government plane and that if she had her way she would fly on commercial craft. They suggested that Republicans were hypocritical, scheming sexists trying to deny the speaker the same protection afforded her male predecessor.

title: Albany: Further Delay for River Cleanup
description: A huge project to dredge tons of dangerous chemicals from the Hudson River has been delayed again  this time to 2009. Alan J. Steinberg, regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said in a statement yesterday that the latest delay was caused by legal challenges to a consent decree ordering the General Electric company to take responsibility for removing tons of polychlorinated biphenyls and decontaminating 43 miles of the river, a project considered the largest industrial cleanup in United States history. Environmental groups have long accused G.E. of dragging its feet on the project, which has already been delayed several times. Mr. Steinberg said construction was expected to begin this spring on a riverside dewatering plant in Fort Edward. Actual dredging will take more than five years and will not start until the spring of 2009.

title: France: French Doctor to Lead Global Disease Fund
description: Dr. Michel Kazatchkine, the top official in Frances battle against AIDS, was chosen as the new chief of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, the organization announced in Geneva. He succeeds Dr. Richard G. A. Feachem. The fund has disbursed $3.4 billion since 2001, provided AIDS treatment to more than 500,000 people in 127 countries and handed out 11 million mosquito nets to fight malaria. Dr. Kazatchkine has treated people with AIDS for more than 20 years.

title: Media Censors for the Jury Let a Style Item Get Through
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  The trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. had a brief brush with disaster first thing Thursday when the clerks whose job is to clip from the jurors morning newspapers any mention of the case failed to notice one of the articles in The Washington Post.

title: Whos Afraid of an Artist Who Loved Flowers?
description: Notes on Marie Menken shines a quavering if welcome ray of light on a largely forgotten figure in the American avant-garde film scene of the 1940s, 50s and 60s, a strange, unwieldy figure who, moreover, happened to be the inspiration for that harridan of all times: Martha in Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: Unemployment Rate at 31-Year Low
description: Australias jobless rate fell to a 31-year low in January as fewer people sought work, worsening a worker shortage that may fuel wages and inflation. The rate fell to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent in December, the lowest since May 1976. Australian employers hired an extra 300,000 workers last year, the largest gain since 1989..

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Should U.S. Markets Be Wide Open?
description: As markets globalize, the Securities and Exchange Commission is considering a fundamental change in regulatory philosophy that would make it possible for overseas brokerage firms to sell most foreign stocks directly to American investors, even if the companies do not comply with American disclosure rules.

title: Give Me Scotland Yard and Dial M for Music
description: Alloy: a combination of elements that come together to make something new. The aptly named Alloy Orchestra combines live music and silent film into a kind of low-key performance art. And it combines different instruments, from accordion to a rack of junk percussion, into a single evocative soundtrack.

title: Hes Bringing Commitment Back (and Not in a Box)
description: After a few songs at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, Justin Timberlake needed a break. Like a man who had just spent a hard day hip-thrusting at the office, he shrugged off his white suit jacket. Loosened his tie. Rolled up his sleeves. Then he kicked back with a relaxing tequila shot. He hadnt played the Garden since 2000, with N Sync, and his return certainly deserved a toast with the band.

title: Queens: Man Sentenced for Shooting
description: A Jamaica man was sentenced in State Supreme Court to 25 years to life yesterday for fatally shooting a man who allowed him to stay in his house in Whitestone, prosecutors said. The man, Mark Koki, 30, was convicted of murder in November, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Koki had been staying at the home of a friend, Alan Schneiderman, 42, when he shot him in the head on Oct. 30, 2002. Mr. Koki stole $1,000 from Mr. Schneidermans wallet and stuffed his body in a closet, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Schneidermans family reported him missing to the police after he did not show up in Florida as planned.

title: European Central Bank Warns of Higher Interest Rates
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 8  The European Central Bank warned Thursday that it could lift interest rates even further from an expected increase in March if European labor unions win wage gains that amplify the risks for higher inflation.

title: Student Is Found Dead, Apparently of a Suicide, at a New Jersey High School
description: GLEN ROCK, N.J., Feb. 8  At first, students, parents and employees were turned away by the police without explanation, yellow tape stretched across an entrance to the sprawling middle and high school campus here. Only later on Thursday did word begin trickling out: Early that morning, a high school senior known for his brilliance and bright prospects had apparently taken his own life at the school.

title: NBCs Russert Wraps Up Prosecution Case in Libby Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  The prosecution finished presenting its case in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on Thursday, leaving his defense lawyers to try to undo the governments contention that Mr. Libby lied under oath during an investigation into the leak of a C.I.A. officers identity.

title: Civic Groups Seek to Amend Law on Insults to Turkish State
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 8  A group of civic organizations on Thursday submitted suggestions for rewording a section of the Turkish penal code under which noted intellectuals and writers had been charged with the crime of insulting the Turkish identity and the state.

title: Making Democracy Credible
description: Time is growing short to head off more embarrassing voting machine scandals. The presidential election looms, yet nearly half of the states offer no reassuring paper trail so voters who use electronic voting machines can check that their ballot choices are accurately recorded.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Observatory column of Science Times on Jan. 30, about the Japanese grass snake, which obtains toxins from eating poisonous toads, misstated the number of nuchal glands, organs on the snakes neck where the toxins are stored. It has 10 to 20 nuchal glands, not 2.

title: Better Ways to Spend Our Money (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Astronauts and Their Families, Lives With Built-In Stress
description: An astronauts life can stretch family ties to the breaking point, and astronauts are not immune to emotional stress.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 27 about "contagious shooting" - gunfire that spreads among police officers who believe that they, or their colleagues, are facing a threat - referred incorrectly to a 1995 Bronx bodega robbery in which multiple shots were fired. Officers fired 107 rounds at the robbers - not 125, the number initially provided by the police; and the robbers did in fact return fire. (The number of shots fired by the police was revised during the investigation, which also revealed that the robbers had fired back, according to law enforcement officials.) A reader pointed out the errors in an e-mail message in November; this correction was delayed while the Police Department and the Bronx district attorney's office checked their records. (Go to Article)

title: Knicks Looking to Get on the Good Side of 23
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 8  The number 23 has become a benchmark for the Knicks. Last season, the number represented futility as they only won 23 games. This season, it inspires hope.

title: Products No Longer So Personal
description: THE advertising theme for a new pregnancy test kit, So advanced. Its easy, might apply to the trend the campaign embodies.

title: Speakers Plane Becomes a Point of Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  It is quite a way from Washington to San Francisco, but evidently nothing like the distance separating House Democrats and Republicans when it comes to the air travel arrangements of Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

title: Oswego County Is Buried Under Six Feet of Snow, and More Is Expected
description: For the sixth straight day, powerful squalls of snow pounded a string of towns and villages along eastern Lake Ontario yesterday, burying parts of upstate New York, shutting down highways, schools and government offices, and blanketing homes in layers of snow that at times came down as fast as five inches an hour.

title: Eight Months After a Life-Changing Injury, a Homecoming
description: The painters finished retouching the kitchen last week. An electrician was in the basement. The hospital bed arrived Monday and was placed in Steven Domalewskis new room.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Hedge Funds Walk a Hard Line Between Silence and Sharing
description: How do you become less secretive about your business without actually talking about it?

title: Making Weight (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont: Firehouse to Get New Tenants
description: Barres 103-year-old firehouse, which the city put on the market last summer to generate revenue, will become a flower shop. Richard and Valerie Beaudets proposal to move Flowers by Emslie and Company into the firehouse and transform it into a garden center and cafe was approved by the Barre City Council last week. The Beaudets will pay $150,000 for the building, but plan to make thousands of dollars of renovations to the space, which Ms. Beaudet said would contain firefighter memorabilia and rental space in what once was the stations living quarters.

title: Shrinking Pains at Kodak
description: On Tuesday, as the Eastman Kodak Company unveiled its long-anticipated consumer inkjet printer in New York, the mood at the companys Rochester headquarters could not have been more positive.

title: Edwards Learns Blogs Can Cut 2 Ways
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  John Edwards learned the hard way this week of the perils of grafting the raucous culture of the Internet to the decidedly staider world of a presidential campaign.

title: A Fugue for Good German Men
description: The Lives of Others is haunted by a piece of music called Sonata for a Good Man, composed for the film by Gabriel Yared and, at the same time, magically familiar to some of its characters. Like the story that surrounds it  a suspenseful, ethically exacting drama, beautifully realized by the writer and director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck  Mr. Yareds piece is melancholy, elegant and complicated.

title: Tutoring Company Is Paid Far More Than Contracts Specify, Comptroller Says
description: Education officials have paid a troubled tutoring company almost nine times the amount it was to receive under agreements worth roughly $7.6 million over five years, City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday.

title: Louisiana: More Hearings on Housing
description: A federal judge overseeing the dispute over whether New Orleanss housing projects should be demolished has ordered more court hearings on how many units are habitable, what kind of repairs might be needed, how many tenants want to return and whether the Department of Housing and Urban Developments voucher program to help former residents pay rent in the meantime is adequate. The judge, Ivan L. R. Lemelle, noted, however, that efforts by tenants to return to the now-shuttered projects may actually perpetuate segregation more than government plans to demolish the buildings and redevelop the area to include mixed-income housing.

title: Five Face Terrorism Charges in British Court
description: LONDON, Feb. 9  With sirens wailing and streets blocked off to permit its passage, a convoy of police vehicles sped across Britain and wound through central London today to bring five terrorist suspects to court here from Birmingham.

title: Family of Police Shooting Victim Protests Prosecutors Actions
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 8  A plan by the district attorney to seek murder charges against three narcotics officers involved in the shooting death of an elderly woman during a bungled drug raid may jeopardize a broad, federal investigation into civil rights violations by the Atlanta Police Department, a spokesman for the victims family said Thursday.

title: Fox to Begin a More Business Friendly News Channel
description: No one has ever accused CNBC, the cable TV home of Jim Cramer, Larry Kudlow and Maria Bartiromo, of being antibusiness. Until now.

title: The Pragmatism and Poetry of Isabel Toledo
description: Historically, the road to the Great American Designer has led to some weird forks, a lot of shimmering mirages and the occasional dead end. Perhaps, like the search for the Great American Novel (which, lets face it, was written by Herman Melville in 1851), the reality may be that the crowning achievements in the field are already behind us. Arent Claire McCardell, Norman Norell, Charles James and Mainbocher long dead?

title: A Real-Life Mystery: The Hunt for the Lost Leonardo
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Maurizio Seracini claims not to be pleased that he is the only person mentioned by his real name in The Da Vinci Code. A scientist turned art detective, he has no need for any manufactured mystery around Leonardo. For 32 years he has chased a real one  and he seems now, finally, poised to solve it.

title: Queens: Woman Killed in Fire
description: A 57-year-old Queens woman was found dead at the scene of a fire in her Far Rockaway home last night, the police said. The fire took place shortly before 7:30 p.m. at 11-40 Bay 24 Street. The woman, whom the police did not identify, was found unconscious and declared dead at the scene. The medical examiner will determine the cause of death.

title: Duke Comes Out on Top in Battle of No. 1 vs. No. 2
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 8  The second half of rare back-to-back basketball games between Duke and North Carolina was played Thursday night at Carmichael Auditorium, a double dose of vitriol with the womens teams facing off a day after the mens showdown at Cameron Indoor Stadium in Durham, N.C.

title: Relics of the 19th Century, in a Sentimental Mood
description: Americans in the 1800s did not limit their tokens of affection to Valentines Day. They produced poems and friendship cards all year long and often kept them in memory albums. These scrapbooks were painstakingly filled with letters, watercolors, ribbons, even hearts made from the woven strands of hair.

title: On the Housatonic, a Destination for Anglers and Skiers
description: THE way bumper stickers and T-shirts tell it, husbands would rather be fishing. But that doesnt mean they cant be house-hunting at the same time.

title: In Indonesia, Theories Abound to Explain Run of Disasters
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 9  Too many shopping malls. Too many squatters on the riverbanks. Too many villas on the southern hillsides. Or a curse hovering over the president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.

title: Not Their Parents Russia
description: MOSCOW

title: Another Bad Idea From the Kremlin
description: The Russian energy minister, Viktor Khristenko, piously declared on Tuesday that Russias meetings with other gas producers were intended only to improve energy security, and that any talk of a cartel was the product of a sick imagination. A curious insistence since the idea of a cartel has been discussed by President Vladimir Putin, who recently called OPEC-like cooperation with Iran for gas an interesting idea  though, of course, its goal would be to better serve customers, not fix prices.

title: France: Police Officers Investigated in Deaths That Led to Riots
description: Two police officers were placed under formal investigation, a step short of charges, in the deaths of two teenagers that set off three weeks of urban rioting across France in November 2005. The officers are accused of not taking action to ensure the safety of the youths, Zyed Benna, 17, at left in photo, and Bouna Traor, 15, right, who were electrocuted by a power transformer as they hid from the police in Clichy-sous-Bois, a working-class Parisian suburb. A police report in December confirmed that officers had been chasing the youths and had shown surprising irresponsibility.

title: Chirac Discusses Life After Politics in TV Interview
description: PARIS, Feb. 8  President Jacques Chirac, in remarks that his office confirmed Thursday, has given his first hint that he may not run for a third term in the French elections in April.

title: N.Y. Governor Escalates Feud With Legislature
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  The battle between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the state lawmakers erupted into an all-out war on Thursday, as the governor began to visit the districts of fellow Democrats in the Legislature to assail their decision to make one of their colleagues the states top financial officer.

title: Still Room in New Orleans
description: DESPITE its near-universal reputation for spontaneity, Mardi Gras in New Orleans has traditionally favored the prepared traveler  the one who reserved a place to stay weeks or months in advance. Latecomers usually found themselves in far-flung suburban chain hotels or no-frills trucker motels miles away from the celebration in the compact city center of New Orleans. In 2007, however, there is an unusual opportunity for the last-minute crowd.

title: A Brutal Sport Is Having Its Day Again in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8  The two opponents padded and paced on a snowcovered basketball court, waiting for their fight to begin.

title: The Complicated End of an Ex-Law Firm
description: At one time, the breakup of a big, prestigious law firm was rare. But since the technology boom and bust, implosions of once highflying firms like Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison and Testa, Hurwitz & Thibeault have occurred with more frequency.

title: South Africa: Lethal TB Strain Kills 5 More
description: Five residents of Eastern Cape have died of a virulent strain of tuberculosis that leaves patients virtually untreatable, and 28 others are being kept isolated in hospitals, the health department said. Eastern Cape, one of the nations poorest areas, sends many people to work in adjacent KwaZulu Natal, the center of an outbreak of the recently identified strain, known as XDR-TB, for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis. Nearly 330 South Africans are known to have contracted it, and half have died. Officials fear its spread to neighboring countries that send migrants to work in South Africa.

title: Preventing Car Crashes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: That Was No Elephant, That Was My Wife
description: Norbit, a raucous, sloppy comedy directed by Brian Robbins, is primarily a showcase for the talents of its star, Eddie Murphy (also credited as a producer and a screenwriter), and Rick Baker, who was in charge of special makeup effects. Mr. Murphys polymorphous sketch-comedy chops have previously been enhanced by Mr. Bakers mastery of fat-suit and latex-mask techniques in the two Nutty Professor movies. In this film the makeup, along with editing tricks and visual effects, allow Mr. Murphy to play three different characters.

description: WHO Betty Wanek, 82, retired owner of a solar-heated swimming pool business

description: CLASSICAL

title: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the Nets game against the Atlanta Hawks referred incorrectly to Joe Johnson, a leading player for the Hawks. He is not, and has never been, an All-Star selection.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about Indonesias decision to stop sending samples of the avian flu virus to the World Health Organization referred imprecisely to the structure of genes. A gene contains nucleotides, not amino acids. Different sequences of the nucleotides encode for different amino acids.

title: Signs of a Deal Seen in North Korea Nuclear Talks
description: BEIJING, Feb. 9  North Korea and the United States appeared closer to a deal today that could, within weeks, start the process of shutting down the Norths nuclear weapons program. But the top American negotiator on the matter cautioned that the two sides remained stuck on one or two issues.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Cigar Isnt Just a Cigar? Ay-Ay-Ay
description: Emotion is a hormonal disorder, declares Salvador (Luis Tosar), a conservative psychiatrist in Joaqun Oristrells Freudian farce, Unconscious. We are in Barcelona in 1913, and Salvadors hare-brained theories about mental health are under assault by rabid acolytes of that subversive new philosopher of human behavior, Sigmund Freud. Suddenly the world of psychiatry is abuzz with scientific-sounding terms like penis envy and Oedipus complex.

title: A Turnaround Born of Pain, Now Yielding Opportunity
description: The first few weeks were nightmarish, but in the end, the experience changed him for the better, Elmer Blanco says.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Recombinant Japan: Carp and the Modern Why
description: Channeling the theme of East meets West, Big Dance Theater, the brainchild of Paul Lazar and Annie-B Parson, bites off a lot in its latest production: ancient Okinawan dance, two short stories by the Japanese writer Masuji Ibuse and the bizarre world of the Million Dollar Round Table, a global gathering of competitive life insurance salesmen.

title: With Ideas, Overpacking Has Its Merits
description: Left to their own devices, children pack outlandishly for trips: sticker collections, tins of candy hearts, zero changes of clothes. Their belief that ossified sugar will serve them better than clean underpants is exasperating and humbling. Really, whos to say it wont?

title: Sea Change for a Dad
description: DISNEY theme parks, with their perpetually long lines and aggressive merchandising, have always seemed about as enticing to me as getting mugged by the Seven Dwarfs. Which is a pity, as I happen to be the father of four young boys. Guess what they wanted to do for their birthdays, three of which fall in the same week in November?

title: Qwest Records Quarterly Profit and Rise in Internet Subscribers
description: Qwest Communications, the phone company, reported a fourth-quarter profit, helped by a gain tied to the sale of real estate and an increase in high-speed Internet subscribers.

title: Miles to Ski Before They Sleep
description: IF you want to spend a winter vacation with Penn and Kir Newhard at their Colorado cabin, you better be prepared to elevate your heart rate.

title: Fox Will Launch Business Channel This Fall
description: Rupert Murdoch and Fox News are adding Wall Street to their news portfolio.

title: Profit at Embarq, Sprint Spinoff, Rises 25%
description: The Embarq Corporation, the communications company, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 25 percent as it added more high-speed Internet subscribers and lost fewer local phone customers than expected.

title: People
description: People

title: Tracing a Radicals Progress, Without Any Help From Him
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  Most well-known artists have an early phase when ambition outstrips originality and all their ideas are secondhand. If they are lucky, they know this, but it hurts. They want something they havent yet defined to themselves, and their fledging art is raw, vulnerable and derivative. It radiates longing and insufficiency in equal parts. There may be no other way to start being an artist, but as maturity dawns, artists often come to feel ambivalent about their early attempts, which reveal both too much and too little.

title: Soccer in Italy to Resume, With Stadiums Vacant
description: ROME, Feb. 8  Italy announced on Thursday a novel compromise between this nations love of soccer and violence at games: Matches can resume this weekend, a week after a police officer was killed at a riotous match in Sicily, but most can be played only if the stadiums are empty of spectators.

title: Comedy in Lo-Fi and of the Highly Subterranean Variety
description: A quarter of an hour can go by in a flash  or last an eternity. Two new 15-minute live-action shows, which join the Cartoon Networks Adult Swim block Sunday night, bear out both these truths.

title: Inventories Fall, Hinting at Rebound in Manufacturing
description: Inventories at the nations wholesalers declined in December by the most since May 2003 as sales surged, suggesting a manufacturing rebound in coming months.

title: More Records Subpoenaed in U.S. Inquiry Into Bruno
description: A federal grand jury investigating the business dealings of Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, has issued subpoenas to two more companies that had been affiliated with an Albany businessman who is his friend and business associate, according to documents filed with securities regulators.

description: THEATER

title: Perception of Being Slighted Stoked Revolt by Lawmakers
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  Pity the New York State lawmaker, if only for a moment.

title: Nelson W. Polsby, 72, Author and a Scholar of Politics, Dies
description: Nelson W. Polsby, who marshaled intellectual rigor, lucid writing and a knack for drawing striking lessons from real-life observation in his enduring studies of Congress and the presidency, died on Tuesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 72.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Rock Reunions

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a proposal to put a permanent limit on snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park referred incorrectly to the number of snowmobiles that have been allowed in the park in recent years. It is 720 a day  not 250, which is the average number of snowmobiles that entered the park daily during the past few years. (The 720 limit was set temporarily in 2000, but will become permanent if the plan is approved.)

title: In the Land of the Euro, Small Towns Adopt Alternative Currencies
description: ROSENHEIM, Germany  Christian Gelleri, with his straightforward manner of speech, rumpled suit and home office, hardly resembles the polished central bankers whose every breath captivates financial markets. But just as Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, lays claim to the title Mr. Euro, Mr. Gelleri can plausibly call himself Mr. Chiemgauer.

title: Manhattan: Eviction for Sex Offenders
description: The New York City Housing Authority has begun expedited eviction proceedings against 59 sex offenders found to be living illegally in public housing complexes in the city, Councilman Eric N. Gioia of Queens announced yesterday. Under federal law, Mr. Gioia said, public housing authorities must deny residency to people listed in the states sex offender registry. He and his staff found about 200 people listed in the registry who had provided addresses that matched public housing complexes. Several agencies, including the federal inspector generals office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, investigated his findings, and found 78 sex offenders living in public housing, he said. In addition to the 59 who will be evicted, 19 who were on parole were ordered by their parole officers to leave their residences, he said. Also, 118 others, who were not living at the addresses they had registered under, are considered fugitives, he said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,095 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

description: DANCE

title: Lacey Township: A-Plant License Review
description: A panel of nuclear safety experts recommended yesterday that the Oyster Creek nuclear reactor be allowed to run for an additional 20 years, but with several conditions added to its license. The nuclear reactor is surrounded by a metal shell that has been thinned by rust. The panel said that the corrosion appeared to have been stopped, but that the operator, AmerGen Energy Company, should be required to take additional steps to eliminate water leakage, inspect the metal shell more frequently and promptly perform a computer analysis of how much thinning is acceptable. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission could make a decision on the plants license in the next few months.

title: A Matter of Fair Play
description: Financial markets run on information. Knowledge turns into money for whoever reacts to changes the fastest and makes the right bets. Most part-time investors working with their nest eggs know theyre a step slower than the top professionals at Wall Street banks and hedge funds. But that doesnt mean they deserve an unfair playing field.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a television review on Jan. 29 about The Power of Choice: The Life and Ideas of Milton Friedman, a documentary on PBS, misidentified the agency that prints United States currency. It is the Bureau of Engraving and Printing  not the Mint, which makes coins. (In a series Mr. Friedman had on PBS many years ago, which, like the documentary, showed his enjoyment of being a public intellectual, he was once shown pressing a button to stop the printing.)

title: Meet the Relatives. Theyre Full of Surprises.
description: Our ancestors have arrived at the American Museum of Natural History. They are very old, and we are only beginning to recognize them and ourselves in them. They remind us of our origins long ago and how we have emerged as modern humans in the fullness of time.

title: Sun Always Sets on the British Vampire
description: The latest film adaptation of Dracula, Bram Stokers rollicking 1897 novel of circulation and invasion, warns viewers that it includes adult content. Maybe so, although virgins with fangs, avengers with crucifixes and the travails of the undead seem as much catnip for teenagers as a solemn matter for grown-ups.

title: Modernist in Loincloth and Feathers
description: Unless you have spotted his single smoke-puff of a painting in the Museum of Modern Art, Armando Revern probably means nothing to you. Why should he? Revern, who died in 1954, spent most of his life in a shack by the sea in his native Venezuela. Many of his contemporaries dismissed him as nuts. His white-on-white pictures are practically unphotographable.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: $1.3 Billion Buys Giant Brooklyn Complex
description: An investment group agreed at 3 a.m. yesterday to buy Starrett City, the sprawling low- and moderate-income apartment complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, for $1.3 billion, a price that experts say illustrates an exuberant real estate market.

title: Art in Review
description: ELLIOTT ERWITT Personal Best Edwynn Houk Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street Through Feb. 23

title: How He Arrived at That Acquired Taste
description: Given the recent spate of horror-movie prequels, we can at least be grateful that the makers of Hannibal Rising, in perhaps their sole moment of clarity, decided that Hannibal: The Beginning might be a tad obvious. As it turns out, the title, with its priapic agency and whiff of retribution, is the high point of a back story that ought to have remained firmly in our imaginations. Like Leatherface and Freddy Krueger, Hannibal Lecter is a monster who thrives in the dark; probe his past, and theres a danger of finding only banality.

title: British Commuters Cry, Once More Into the Aisles!
description: KEYNSHAM, England  Inside, they might be peeved; they might be indignant; they might feel like hitting someone very hard over the head with their umbrellas. But faced with the maddening challenges of their erratic railroad system, most British commuters do what they have been brought up to do: nothing.

title: British Deny Witch Hunt in Arrest of Muslim
description: LONDON, Feb. 8  The British police on Thursday arrested an outspoken advocate of fiery Islamic views, a week after seizing nine people accused of a separate conspiracy to kidnap and kill a Muslim British soldier.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,605,786.05

title: Senate Panel Debates Iraq Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senate Democrats and Republicans differed sharply today on whether Pentagon officials deliberately used faulty intelligence to justify the Bush administrations war against Iraq.

title: Old Celtics Are Untainted by Failure
description: Imagine if it were Isiah Thomass team that since November 2004 had led the N.B.A. in behavioral lines crossed, combinations of punches thrown and shots fired from an actual gun.

title: In Arizona, a Railway Town Rediscovers a Touch of Past Glory
description: THE words standing on a corner in Winslow, Arizona have swirled in American imaginations since 1972, when the Eagles recorded Take It Easy. What youll see from those corners today is an old railroad town of one-way streets and two-story buildings resting on a high grassland plateau beneath spacious skies. In the distance, snow-capped mountains, volcanic buttes and flat-topped mesas appear sharply silhouetted in the clear air.

title: Anna Nicole Smith Is Found Dead in Florida
description: MIAMI, Feb. 8  Anna Nicole Smith, a former Playboy centerfold, actress and television personality who was famous, above all, for being famous, but also for being sporadically rich and chronically litigious, was found dead on Thursday in her suite at the Seminole Hard Rock Cafe Hotel and Casino in Hollywood, Fla. She was 39, and the cause of her death was not immediately known.

title: Protesters and Israeli Police Clash at Holy Site
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9  Israeli troops charged onto the grounds of Jerusalems most contentious religious site today, firing tear gas and stun grenades at stone-throwing Palestinians who were protesting Israeli excavation work taking place just outside the hilltop shrine.

title: EMI May Sell Recordings Online With No Anti-Copying Software
description: The EMI Group, the British music giant, has been considering a plan to offer a broad swath of its recordings for sale online without anti-copying software, executives involved in discussions with the company said.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Iraqs No. 2 Health Official Is Held and Accused of Financing Shiite Militants
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 8  Iraqi and American troops arrested the second highest official in the Iraqi Health Ministry on Thursday, charging that he funneled millions of dollars to rogue Shiite militants who kidnapped and killed Iraqi civilians.

title: German String Quartet Warms Up With Webern
description: Artemis was the Greek goddess of the hunt (Romans called her Diana) and a high roller in the Olympian pantheon. So is it by coincidence or intent that a string quartet that bears the name Artemis has for its first-chair violinist Natalia Prischepenko?

title: Irans Leader Warns the U.S. About Carrying Out Any Attack
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 8  Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, warned the United States on Thursday that Iran would retaliate against American interests worldwide if it was attacked. It was the latest volley in an escalating war of rhetoric between the countries.

title: New York Moves Toward Suit Over a 50-Year-Old Oil Spill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  New York State moved to sue Exxon Mobil and four other companies on Thursday to force them to clean up a half-century-old spill of millions of gallons of oil lying under the Greenpoint neighborhood in Brooklyn and to repair environmental damage inflicted on nearby Newtown Creek.

title: Queens: Man Sentenced for Killing
description: A South Ozone Park man was sentenced in State Supreme Court to 50 years to life in prison yesterday for robbing a man in a Jamaica crack house and then fatally shooting the mans stepson. The defendant, Timmy Lee Walker, 33, was convicted of murder on Jan. 17. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said Mr. Walker robbed the man, James Hubbard, 48, in a basement crack den on Sept. 5, 2004. Mr. Hubbard, his stepson Tony Brunson, 22, and another man returned about an hour later and rushed Mr. Walker, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Walker shot Mr. Brunson four times and Mr. Hubbard once in the leg, Mr. Brown said.

title: The Big Bang and the Bucks Set to Collide in Inner Space
description: The price of exploring inner space went up yesterday.

title: Brodeur Gives the Islanders Nothing, and the Devils Like It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 8  The Islanders stormed Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur with such ferocity in the third period Thursday night that during one flurry they knocked off his helmet. Brodeur plopped it back on his head and played on, unruffled.

title: Rising Costs Prompt Changes in Transit Hub at Ground Zero
description: Faced with construction cost estimates up to $1.2 billion over budget, the Port Authority said yesterday that it would re-engineer, but not fundamentally alter, the birdlike World Trade Center transportation hub designed by Santiago Calatrava.

title: Ex-Chief of S.E.C. Joins Perella Weinberg Investment Bank
description: William H. Donaldson, a co-founder of the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and later chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank, as chairman of its advisory council, the firm said yesterday.

title: From Mecca, an Invitation to Form a Government
description: Following is the text of the Palestinians Mecca accord, which came in the form of a letter from President Mahmoud Abbas, of Fatah, designating Prime Minister Ismail Haniya, of Hamas, to form the government, as translated by The Associated Press:
