description: To the Editor:

title: In Remote Minnesota, a Hall of Fame Is on Thin Ice
description: EVELETH, Minn.  Tucked on a road aptly named Hat Trick Avenue, the United States Hockey Hall of Fame sits about a quarter-mile from the United Taconite Company mine. Blasting still occurs in this little town on Minnesotas Iron Range, and the vibrations often rattle the Halls windows.

title: The Romance of a Dozen Roses, the Gritty Reality of a Truckload
description: THEY were already stockpiling roses in the New York flower district last week, some of the blossoms having recently worn little mesh caps, or condnes (condoms) as the South American growers call them, to keep them from erupting too soon. If youre in the flower trade, Valentines Day, when almost a third of all adult Americans buy cut flowers or a plant, may account for 30 or 40 percent of your yearly business, and you cant have too many roses on hand. Who cares that, according to Amy Stewart at least, roses are really lab rats, bred to live in a factory and be fed by machine.

title: Spring Training Nears, Citi Field Begins to Sprout
description: Citi Field, the Mets new home for 2009, is slowly but surely taking shape. A portion of the main concourse along the first-base line, a pile of steel bars now, should be filled with concrete by opening day.

title: Landis Agrees to Skip Racing in France This Year
description: In a deal with French antidoping authorities, Floyd Landis has agreed not to compete this year in the Tour de France, or any other race in France.

title: Calm Before and During a Storm
description: Timothy F. Geithner is 45, but he looks considerably younger, with an easy smile and hardly a wrinkle in sight.

title: Letters: Baseball Demographics
description: To the Editor: Re United States of Florida (Feb. 2): Your article missed an important reason for people flocking to certain areas of Florida  Major League Baseballs spring training. For example (and referencing the great map): Clearwater is the site of the Philadelphia Phillies, the Pittsburgh Pirates are a little south in Bradenton and the Minnesota Twins are in Fort Myers. I am not sure which is the chicken and which the egg, but the teams do a great deal to maintain the demographics that the story so accurately describes.Marvin Jaffe

title: Kerry Joins Fans Upset by the Plan for Extra Innings
description: The pending deal to shift Major League Baseballs Extra Innings package exclusively to DirecTV starting in April is still not ready to be announced, but Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, would like to undo it.
A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.

title: Max Lanier, 91, Who Challenged Baseballs Reserve Clause, Is Dead
description: Max Lanier, a leading left-handed pitcher of the early 1940s with the St. Louis Cardinals who was later barred from organized baseball for jumping to the Mexican League, prompting him to challenge baseballs reserve clause in federal court, died Jan. 30 in Dunellon, Fla. He was 91.

title: Japan: Corporate Spending Slows
description: Japans machinery orders fell in December, signaling that economic growth may slow this year as companies scale back spending on factories and equipment. Non-government machinery orders, excluding shipping and utilities, declined a seasonally adjusted 0.7 percent from November, the Cabinet Office said.

title: Bronx: FedEx in Harlem River Yards
description: FedEx Express has begun construction on a 98,400-square-foot center that is expected to open in the fall in the Harlem River Yards, company and city officials said yesterday. The company is relocating from 34th Street in Manhattan to allow for construction of the No. 7 subway extension, the company said. About 250 workers will be stationed at the $29 million center, which will also serve as the base for 84 FedEx Express delivery trucks.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about new uniforms for the Army and other branches of the military referred incorrectly to Cynthia Depoe, who said she was pleased that a new Air Force uniform being developed was supposed to be wrinkle-free. She is a senior master sergeant in the Washington Air National Guard, not a senior staff sergeant.

title: More Big Changes on Way for Newark, Booker Vows
description: NEWARK, Feb. 8  More police on the streets, more computers in City Hall, more affordable housing, a new municipal magazine and perhaps fewer mistakes. In a speech that sounded at moments like a mea culpa but more often roared with the triumphs and promises of a politician running for re-election, Mayor Cory A. Booker gave a State of the City address on Thursday night that took stock of his first seven months in office and laid out an ambitious agenda for the next three and a half years.

title: Less Is More, but in Idaho, Not for Long
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 2  When Gov. C. L. Otter took office last month and immediately halted construction work on the state Capitol his objections went beyond the $130 million price tag for the renovation and addition.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Nov. 27 about contagious shooting  gunfire that spreads among police officers who believe that they, or their colleagues, are facing a threat  referred incorrectly to a 1995 Bronx bodega robbery in which multiple shots were fired. Officers fired 107 rounds at the robbers  not 125, the number initially provided by the police; and the robbers did in fact return fire. (The number of shots fired by the police was revised during the investigation, which also revealed that the robbers had fired back, according to law enforcement officials.) A reader pointed out the errors in an e-mail message in November; this correction was delayed while the Police Department and the Bronx district attorneys office checked their records.

title: Footballs, Funhouses and Fries
description: Daniel M. Snyder, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins, has agreed to acquire Johnny Rockets, the 1950s-inspired restaurant chain known for employees that sing and dance to vintage pop tunes every half-hour.

title: Letters From Our Donors
description: Today is the last day to donate to the 95th annual fund-raising campaign for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The following are some comments from some people who have donated to the Neediest Cases.

title: After Waiting So Long, Neighbors Are Skeptical
description: For the nearly 50 years he has managed the Josephs Furniture store in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Howard Josephs has never forgotten what lurks menacingly below.

title: Whitney Looks to Itself for the Next Biennial
description: Although the Whitney Museum of American Arts next Biennial doesnt open until March 2008, the museum has decided who will organize it.

title: Cause of Anna Nicole Smiths Death Uncertain
description: Officials in Broward County, Fla., said today they have found no evidence so far of foul play or illegal drug use in the death of Anna Nicole Smith.

title: Victims in a 1910 Railroad Tragedy Live, and Die, Again
description: On Feb. 21, 1910, snow began falling heavily in the Cascade Mountains of Washington State. Snowfall in winter was nothing unusual for the Cascades, but this storm was different. Rather than the usual one- or two-day blast, it raged on and on, dumping snow at the rate of three feet a day on mountainsides already buried under a full winters load. Meanwhile two trains, one carrying the mail, the other carrying Seattle-bound passengers, sat idle on a narrow ledge midway down a steep mountainside, waiting for snowplow trains to clear the tracks ahead.

title: The A.B.A.s Judicial Ethics Mess
description: At a moment when judicial independence is under heightened political attack, the nations legal establishment should be doing everything it can to shore up public trust. Instead, the special commission charged with recommending revisions to the Model Code of Judicial Conduct of the American Bar Association has been flip-flopping around on some of the most important aspects of the code, which the states use to set standards for their courts.

title: Defendant Denies Killing Dancer, and Offers Theory on Evidence
description: His testimony ranged from describing their first kiss in Washington Square Park, through breakups over her work as a stripper, to the origins of a bloody fingerprint that the police say clinches the case against him.

title: For the Record
description: The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, referred incorrectly to Richard L. Armitage, the source of columnist Robert D. Novaks information on Valerie Wilson, whose naming as a C.I.A. operative is at the center of the Libby case. From 2001 to 2005, he was deputy secretary of state, the No. 2 position  not merely a former aide at the State Department.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 1 about a visit to New York City by President Bush, and his relationship with the city, referred incorrectly to the Ford to City: Drop Dead headline that appeared in The Daily News following President Gerald R. Fords decision not to bail the city out from a financial crisis. It was published more than 31 years ago, on Oct. 30, 1975  not 30 years ago.

title: Prewar Intelligence Unit at Pentagon Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  A Pentagon investigation into the handling of prewar intelligence has criticized civilian Pentagon officials for conducting their own intelligence analysis to find links between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda, but said the officials did not violate any laws or mislead Congress, according to Congressional officials who have read the report.

title: In the Coney Island Footsteps of Marbury
description: Just minutes before the start of a game between the Brooklyn high school rivals Lincoln and Boys and Girls on Jan. 30, nearly 200 people were still waiting in the cold to experience the thrill of Coney Islands latest attraction, Lance Stephenson.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the disclosure that a member of Iraqs Parliament had been convicted more than two decades earlier in the 1983 attacks on the American and French embassies in Kuwait misidentified the nationalities of the five people killed in those attacks. They were Kuwaiti, not American.

title: Former Hedge Fund Executive Enters Plea
description: The former head of Idaho hedge-fund company, Wood River Capital Management, pleaded not guilty yesterday to securities fraud and other charges after investors lost at least $88 million when two of its funds collapsed in 2005.

title: New York to Test Ways to Prevent Nuclear Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  New York City is about to become a laboratory to test ways of strengthening the nations defenses against a terror attack by a nuclear device or a radioactive dirty bomb.

title: Italy: Cabinet Approves Rights for Gay and Unwed Couples
description: Italys fragile government approved a draft bill legally recognizing unmarried couples, including gay ones, over the opposition of the Vatican and a member party of Prime Minister Romano Prodis nine-party center-left coalition. The compromise bill, making good on a campaign promise, is more restrictive than other similar laws in Europe. But it would guarantee registered couples such rights as inheriting property and receiving a deceased partners pension. The bill will face debate in Parliament, which must approve it.

title: Pelosi Backs Restrictions on Heat-Trapping Gases
description: The United States has to cut its greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2050, and mandatory restrictions are the only way to do it, Speaker Nancy Pelosi told the House Science and Technology Committee yesterday.

title: The Skis Come Out in the Adirondacks
description: OLD FORGE, N.Y., may not be the place for a glitzy ski weekend, but a few days at this village in the southern Adirondacks is an appealing, family-friendly way to to get a good taste of winter.

title: U.S. Accidentally Kills Kurdish Fighters in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 9  An American helicopter apparently fired on friendly Kurdish pesh merga fighters by mistake, killing as many as nine people.

title: Ken Kennedy, 61, a Pioneer of Computer Software, Dies
description: Ken Kennedy, a Rice University computer scientist whose software design work paved the way for the broad scientific and engineering use of modern supercomputers, died Wednesday in Houston. He was 61.

title: Beijing Orders Investigation of Health Agency
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 9  Concerned about a growing number of cases that involve the sale of fraudulent or dangerous medicine, the Chinese government said today that it had ordered a thorough investigation into the agency that is supposed to be the national regulatory watchdog, the state food and drug administration.

title: Boy Killed by Truck in Brooklyn
description: A 3-year-old boy was killed in a hit-and-run accident after he got caught in a wheel of a pickup truck in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. But the driver of the truck, who was taken in for questioning last night, was not charged, according to the police, because he said he did not know that he had hit the child.

title: Manhattan: Charges for Firefighters
description: The Fire Department said yesterday that it had filed disciplinary charges against 13 fire officers after the City Department of Investigation reported that they had submitted invalid degrees or education credits to qualify for promotion. The Fire Department also charged that one firefighter had submitted invalid education credits to qualify for an appointment. The Fire Department said that the 14 submitted credits from a bogus online school and said they could face suspension, fines or dismissal. Capt. Peter Gorman, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, which represents the officers, said most of them never used the online credits to qualify for promotion. There was never any intent by any of our members to deceive the department, he said.

title: Talisker Club and Marisol at Punta Dominical
description: Talisker Club

title: Democrats Set House Debate to Rebuke Bush Over Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  House Democratic leaders persuaded members of their party on Thursday to limit the scope of an Iraq war resolution next week to a simple repudiation of President Bushs troop buildup plan, hoping to temporarily set aside divisive decisions over war financing and troop redeployments.

title: New Hampshire: Memorial to Fallen Image
description: Plans for a memorial to the Old Man of the Mountain, the rock figure that collapsed in 2003, have been unveiled by officials. The tribute, shown in a rendering above, designed by two Massachusetts artists, will feature five massive slabs of granite that, when viewed from a nearby platform, recreate the image of the Old Man. In addition, five steel beams will be set up below the original formation, allowing visitors looking up at the cliff at the correct angle from Profile Lake to see a representation of the craggy face. The Old Man of the Mountain Legacy Fund, a nonprofit group, and the state have set up a quasi-public agency to raise the roughly $4.5 million needed to complete the project.

title: For the Record
description: A brief article yesterday about an Italian court ruling that Specialist Mario Lozano, an American military serviceman, must stand trial for the shooting death of an Italian intelligence agent in Iraq in 2005 misidentified Specialist Lozanos branch of service. It is the Army, not the Marines.

title: Shiite District, Flash Point in Baghdad, Rebuilds
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 8  Just past the main checkpoint into Sadr City, children kick soccer balls at goals with new green nets, on fields where mounds of trash covered the ground last summer. A few blocks away, city workers plant palm trees by the road, while men gather at a cafe nearby to chatter and laugh.

title: NATO Asked to Meet Promises Already Made to Afghanistan
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Feb. 8  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, attending his first conference of NATO defense ministers, told these American allies that they must fulfill their commitments to provide troops for Afghanistan in time for a spring offensive against the Taliban.

title: Two Children Are Killed in a Blaze in Bay Ridge
description: Amal Lazhir watched from a few yards away as flames licked through the buildings hollowed guts, biting through its roof and windows and bursting from the second-floor bedrooms where she left her little girls sleeping just hours earlier.

title: In a Buttoned-Up Frame of Mind
description: Proenza Schouler was of two minds. Anna Sui summoned home furnishings, while Maria Cornejo politely said no to sex. In a funk, the American collections slouched toward fall.

title: The Hemingway Effect, From Recent Battlefields
description: Writing about experience necessarily sanitizes it, theorizes Sangjoon Han, a Korean-American soldier who fought in Iraq and is one of many articulate talking heads in Richard E. Robbinss documentary Operation Homecoming. Built around the firsthand recollections of soldiers fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan, the film is a spinoff from an anthology of essays, e-mail messages, poems and letters compiled by the National Endowment for the Arts and published by Random House.

title: Remember the Original Scores Category? Its Back on Broadway
description: Heres a musical question that wont be answered anytime soon: in the big, brassy world of Broadway, where American Idol meets Las Vegas in jukebox hell, what is the place of the small, serious show whose songs are unlikely ever to come under the scrutiny of the Cowell-Abdul-Jackson triumvirate or be covered by Celine Dion? To listen to the original-cast albums of Grey Gardens and Spring Awakening, two shows competing with behemoths like Wicked, is to bring to mind two phrases seldom linked nowadays: Broadway musical and artistic integrity.

title: Revamping Appointments
description: Concerned about the recent dismissal of several prosecutors by the Justice Department, the Senate Judiciary Committee moved to strip the department of some of its power to appoint interim United States attorneys. Voting 13 to 6, the panel sent legislation to the full Senate that would limit the attorney generals appointment of an interim United States attorney to 120 days. After that, a federal judge would have to appoint the prosecutor. The bill revokes a provision inserted in the USA Patriot Act last year that gave the sole authority for naming interim attorneys to the attorney general.

title: Judge Imposes Death in Killing of North Dakota Student
description: A convicted sex offender was formally sentenced to death yesterday in the abduction and murder of a North Dakota college student as she left a shopping center in 2003.

title: Harvard Plans to Name Its First Female President
description: Harvard University is planning to name the first woman president in its 371-year history  Drew Gilpin Faust, a historian who runs a research institute at the university, according to university officials close to the selection process.

title: Museum for African Art Finds Its Place
description: The Museum for African Art, which has had a nomadic existence since it opened in 1984, will finally gain a permanent home in a soaring new building designed by Robert A. M. Stern, on Fifth Avenue between 109th and 110th Streets, officials announced yesterday.

title: Losses in Home Loans Prompt HSBC to Shake Up Management of Unit
description: A day after HSBC issued its first-ever profit warning, the banks chief executive started a management shake-up at the American consumer finance unit where losses from home loans to high-risk borrowers increased more than expected last year.

title: The Morning Rush Is Slowed by a Cracked Subway Rail
description: The beating of a butterflys wings, it is said, can lead to a hurricane an ocean away. And a break in a Manhattan subway rail, though it may lack poetry, can really foul up the morning trip to work in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER When the members of a cheerleading squad start taking nasty tumbles, Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) soon centers in on the vengeful spirit of a former teammate. The singer Mary J. Blige, a nominee in both the record and song of the year categories at the 49th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday, does a guest turn as the coach, whose past life is hindering her ability to put a stop to the teams adversities.

title: Thomas Mann Dances to the Strains of Bach and Wagner
description: The first thing to be said about John Neumeiers Death in Venice is that it is not terrible. Like Glen Tetley, who died last month, Mr. Neumeier has become a prophet without full honor in his own country, having left the United States in the 1960s for Germany, where he has directed the Hamburg Ballet since 1973. He makes unfashionably big ballets that tell stories on an operatic scale, danced to scores by composers of equally large-scale music who are unfashionable for ballet, among them Shostakovich and Mahler.

title: Sex, Repressed and Unleashed
description: If you follow the fortunes of Broadway, you know that the revival of Stephen Sondheim and George Furths Company, mounted late last year, has been a highlight of this theater season, and that Spring Awakening, a transformation of Frank Wedekinds 1891 play about adolescent longing, has been another. Youve heard too, perhaps, that both have drawn audiences from beyond the ranks of the typical musical-theater fan, from those cultural consumers in late youth or early middle age who disdain much of what does not originate on HBO or the walls of a gallery in Chelsea or Berlin. You are acquainted with such people; quite possibly you are one of them. And if you are, you assume that your intellectual demands exceed what the musical  benighted, reductive and emotionally anodyne  could ever supply.

title: Study Puts Rate of Autism at 1 in 150 U.S. Children
description: About one child in 150 develops autism or a related disorder like Aspergers syndrome by the age of 8, according to a study released yesterday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Your Money at War
description: Washington

title: A Quirky Mountain Is Keeping Its Quirks
description: ITS not true that there has never been a ski area like Mad River Glen. But it is true that there will never be another one like it.

title: Schools Official Deflects Query About Stocks
description: Chris Cerf, the deputy schools chancellor who is a former president of Edison Schools Inc., the commercial public school operator, said yesterday that he held an equity stake in the company until Wednesday, the day before a citywide parents group planned to question him about his ties to Edison.

title: From the Corner Bodega, the Music of Everyday Life
description: Coffee, light and sweet, is the fuel that keeps a busy world in motion in the new musical In the Heights, a singing mural of Latin-American life that often has the inspiriting flavor of a morning pick-me-up on a warm summer day. Light and sweet are actually just the words to describe this amiable show, which boasts an infectious, bouncy Latin-pop score by a gifted young composer, Lin-Manuel Miranda, an unfortunately underspiced book by Quiara Alegra Hudes, and a stage full of energized, energetic performers you cant take your eyes off and wont want to.

title: Illegal Immigrants Slain in an Attack in Arizona
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8  Three illegal immigrants were shot to death, three were wounded and others were missing Thursday near Tucson after gunmen accosted them as they traveled north from the Mexican border, the authorities said.

title: In Defense of the Desperate (and the Notorious)
description: REGRETTABLY, Ephraim Savitt is a little late for this friendly cross-examination, but not because he shrewdly anticipates that its subtext will be something scathing along the lines of Dont you worry that everyone despises you for your emphatic defense of a cold-blooded murderer like Ronell Wilson? Where are your scruples?

title: South Korea: Interest Rates Held Steady
description: South Koreas central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged for a sixth month after consumer prices increased at the slowest pace in seven years. The Bank of Korea, led by its governor, Lee Seong-tae, left the overnight call rate at a five-year high of 4.5 percent. Economic growth has weakened, Mr. Lee, left, said. Consumer prices have stabilized. The bank raised rates three times in 2006. Recent reports showing that the economy grew at the slowest pace in 18 months and that household debt fell for the first time in a year ended expectations that the central bank would raise rates in the first half of this year.

title: Cats May Be Cuter, but Cattle Need Vets, Too (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Pays to Stop a Pandemic?
description: Baltimore

title: Vornado Chief Loses a Deal but Keeps His Reputation
description: The real estate magnate Steven Roth has let deals slip away before. He came within an inch of buying the World Trade Center in 2001. He lost out in the bidding for the prestigious General Motors building on Fifth Avenue in 2003.

title: Yonkers: Rapper Indicted on Gun Charge
description: The rapper Jadakiss was indicted yesterday on a gun possession charge in Yonkers, prosecutors said. The rapper, left, 31, whose real name is Jason Phillips, was arrested in October after the police stopped a vehicle in which he was a passenger and found an unregistered handgun, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Mr. Phillips has pleaded not guilty. His lawyer, Clement Patti, said yesterday that the police had said they found the gun in a center console in the vehicle. He said Mr. Phillips, who was riding in the back seat, was charged along with two other occupants of the vehicle. We have yet to see any evidence connecting him with the weapon, Mr. Patti said.

title: Fortress Goes Public, a First for Hedge Funds Inside U.S.
description: The first hedge fund and private equity company to go public in the United States will make its market debut today at $18.50 a share  at the high end of its expected price range.

title: In a Search Refinement, a Chance to Rival Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8  Early in the decade, a struggling Xerox Corporation was trying to sell off a stake in its Palo Alto Research Center, which it could no longer afford to support. But with the technology bubble bursting, the price that investors were willing to pay for a piece of PARC, as the center is known, kept going down.

title: Edwards Gets It Right
description: What a difference two years makes! At this point in 2005, the only question seemed to be how much of Americas social insurance system  the triumvirate of Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid  the Bush administration would manage to dismantle. Now almost all prominent Democrats and quite a few Republicans pay at least lip service to calls for a major expansion of social insurance, in the form of universal health care.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Accord Is Signed by Palestinians to Stop Feuding
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 8  The main rival Palestinian factions agreed late Thursday to form a government of national unity aimed at ending a wave of violence between them and an international boycott.

title: Loose Lips
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: At Sea With Mickey
description: A family cruise aboard Disney Magic has a well-planned something for just about everyone.

title: Scenes of Winter
On the Market
Pulse
description: What designer Joy Gryson is wearing now, new luxury Nikes, stockbrokers gone wild and more.

title: Keeping the Peace in Haiti's Slums
description: United Nations forces have taken on powerful street gangs in an effort to restore order to the troubled capital, Port-au-Prince.

title: Once Again, Its Your Turn
description: Late last year, we tried a bit of an experiment called Your Turn to Tell the Story. Were back to try it again based on our recent trip to Cambodia.

title: Big-Screen Future for High School Musical
description: "High School Musical," the cable TV movie made for the Disney Channel that became a juggernaut as measured by its cable ratings, DVD and CD sales, will expand its franchise to the big screen next year, Disney said yesterday.

title: Casting Is Announced for Coram Boy
description: Jan Maxwell ("Chitty, Chitty, Bang, Bang"), Dashiell Eaves ("The Lieutenant of Inishmore") and Bill Camp ("Heartbreak House") will be among the cast of 40 when the English National Theater production of "Coram Boy" opens on Broadway at the Imperial Theater on May 2, after previews beginning on April 16.

title: Stoppard to Discuss Utopia
description: Tom Stoppard, the author of "The Coast of Utopia," playing at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, will give a preperformance talk from 5 p.m. to 6:15 on Wednesday at the Kaplan Playhouse on the 10th floor of the Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street, at Lincoln Center.

title: A Baghdad Neighborhood in Transition
description: The Times's Damien Cave reports on the vast Shiite slum long neglected by the Sunni-led minority rule of Saddam Hussein during his three decades in power.

title: Eddie Bauer Shareholders Reject Buyout
description: Two private equity firms have gotten the cold shoulder from shareholders of Eddie Bauer. In a surprise turn, the chain of outdoorsy clothing stores said Thursday that its agreement to be bought by Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital failed to win enough votes from shareholders, meaning that the company will stay publicly traded for now. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported that Thursdays special meeting to vote on the deal, held in Bellevue, Wash., drew only 22 people, including Eddie Bauer directors, executives, employees and the media. No shareholders spoke at the meeting, the Post-Intellegencer said.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Makes Deep Post-Merger Cuts
description: Alcatel-Lucent, the worlds biggest maker of telecommunications equipment, will deepen job cuts after reporting a fourth-quarter loss, increasing its savings target to 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion) within three years. The company plans to axe 12,500 jobs following its $11.6 billion merger last year, an increase from an original plan to shed 9,000 workers, it said in a statement Friday.

title: Hedge Funds Walk Line Between Silence and Sharing
description: How do you become less secretive about your business without actually talking about it? Such is the conundrum faced by hedge funds, which are described more often than not as secretive. Hedge funds are governed by a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that prohibits them from engaging in anything that could be construed as advertising or any kind of general solicitation. To hedge funds cautious general counsels, that means no talking on the record to the news media about the fund.

title: Losses in Home Loans Prompt HSBC to Shake Up Management of Unit
description: A day after HSBC issued its first-ever profit warning, the banks chief executive started a management shake-up at the American consumer finance unit where losses from home loans to high-risk borrowers increased more than expected last year.

title: Vornado Chief Loses a Deal but Keeps His Reputation
description: The real estate magnate Steven Roth has let deals slip away before. He came within an inch of buying the World Trade Center in 2001. He lost out in the bidding for the prestigious General Motors building on Fifth Avenue in 2003. But never before has Mr. Roth, the chairman and chief executive of Vornado Realty Trust, been an also-ran in such a heavily publicized contest as the bidding war for Equity Office Properties, the nations largest office landlord.

title: In a Search Refinement, a Chance to Rival Google
description: Palo Alto Research Center, the Xerox spin-off that is hoping to sustain itself by licensing technology and forming partnerships with outside companies, is announcing a deal Friday that underscores that strategy. The New York Times reports that PARC, as its known, is licensing a broad portfolio of patents and technology to a well-financed start-up with an ambitious and potentially lucrative goal: to build a search engine that could some day rival Google.

title: The Complicated End of an Ex-Law Firm
description: At one time, the breakup of a big, prestigious law firm was rare. But since the technology boom and bust, implosions of once highflying firms like Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison and Testa, Hurwitz & Thibeault have occurred with more frequency.

title: Trading Halted in Auto Parts Maker Wooed by Icahn
description: The United States auto parts maker Lear, which has received a $2.31 billion buyout offer from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, was silent on the reasons behind a long trading halt in its shares Thursday.

title: Former Hedge Fund Executive Enters Plea
description: The former head of Idaho hedge-fund company, Wood River Capital Management, pleaded not guilty yesterday to securities fraud and other charges after investors lost at least $88 million when two of its funds collapsed in 2005.

title: Four Plead Guilty in Trading Case
description: A New Jersey man and his two sons pleaded guilty Thursday to insider trading charges in what federal authorities described as a crooked family business that took in more than $3.7 million over four years. Zvi Rosenthal, 62, of Tenafly, N.J., pleaded guilty to a conspiracy count before Judge John Gleeson of United States District Court in Brooklyn. Mr. Rosenthal was preceded by his son Amir and followed by his son Ayal in admitting the conspiracy.

title: Cisco to Buy Social-Networking Software Maker
description: Cisco Systems, the maker of equipment for computer networking, said early Friday that it planned to buy the social-networking software maker Five Across for an undisclosed sum, expanding into user-generated content. CNET News.com described the latest deal as part of Ciscos effort to diversify beyond being plumbers of the Internet into more consumer-focused areas. InfoWorld suggests that Cisco also expects social-networking technology to be embraced by businesses as well.

title: V.C.s Boost Targeted Growth With $22 Million
description: Targeted Growth announced it has raised $22.3 million to continue development of genetic technology that it says can improve crop yields by about 20 percent. The Seattle-based company said its focus is applying the patented technology to corn, soy and canola, which are in growing demand as raw material for producing ethanol and biodiesel. Capricorn Management and AllianceBernstein led the round.

title: Zuckerman Sold $75 Million of REIT Shares
description: Mortimer Zuckerman, chairman of Boston Properties, sold about $75 million of shares in the real estate investment trust, benefiting from a soaring market for commercial office properties. Mr. Zuckerman, who also owns the New York Daily News, sold 579,222 common shares according to data from Securities and Exchange Commission filings compiled by the Washington Service.

title: Is One of Bostons Stars on the Wane?
description: Convexity Capital Management, the record-setting hedge fund launched by former Harvard Management stars famous for beating the markets, apparently couldnt keep up in 2006. Convexitys $6 billion hedge fund offers clients a variety of investment strategies. Each earned about 4.5 percent less than their benchmark indexes in 2006, the funds first year of operation, according to the Boston Globe.

title: Yahoos Little Shop of Start-Ups
description: Yahoo, tapping into what BusinessWeek calls its inner start-up, is preparing to launch Brickhouse, its answer to the slew of Web 2.0 start-ups that have been giving the Silicon Valley giant a run for its money in recent years.

title: Carlyle to Exit Qinetiq
description: The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it was selling its remaining stake in Qinetiq, the British defense and security company that went public a year ago. The move is likely to reignite the debate over Carlyles involvement in Qinetiq, which the British government privatized last year.

title: Sins Devoured, Hope Restored
description: Handsomely produced, earnestly performed and 100 percent irony-free, "The Last Sin Eater" is religious art for mainstream consumption.

title: National CineMedia Jumps on Debut
description: The initial public offering of National CineMedia, which provides movie theater advertising services, jumped as much as 26 percent in its market debut on Thursday, a day after pricing above a forecasted range. National CineMedia shares rose as high as $26.50 in morning trading and was trading up nearly 20 percent on Nasdaq in midday trade. The company raised $798 million Wednesday from the sale of 38 million shares sold at $21 apiece, above the forecasted range of $18 to $20.

title: Calm Before and During a Storm
description: High on the to-do list of Timothy F. Geithner, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is understanding and monitoring the $26 trillion credit derivatives market  twice the size of the United States economy  the fastest-growing financial market there is. And to deal with the byzantine market of credit derivatives, Mr. Geithner will need to call on the equanimity he is known for, says The New York Times.

title: Footballs, Funhouses and Fries
description: Daniel M. Snyder, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins, has agreed to acquire Johnny Rockets, the 1950s-inspired restaurant chain known for employees that sing and dance to vintage pop tunes every half-hour. And in an interview with The New York Times, he couldnt seem more excited.

title: Harrahs Chief Looking at Big Payday
description: Gary Loveman, the chief executive of casino giant Harrahs Entertainment, will receive about $94 million in stock options and other rights if the worlds largest casino buyout deal is consummated, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: ESPN Subpoenaed in Reynolds Case
description: The State of Connecticut has subpoenaed ESPN to produce by next Friday the personnel files of Harold Reynolds, whom the cable network fired last July after 11 years as one of its baseball analysts.

title: Goldman Said to Raise Big Buyout Fund
description: The Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may need to watch their backs. Goldman Sachs may raise more than $18 billion for leveraged buyouts, almost double what it initially sought, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Goldman will use its capital and money from investors and employees to pursue takeovers in the U.S., Europe and Asia, said the people, who declined to be identified until the New York-based firm closes the fund next month.

title: Diana Dreamette?
description: This is probably one of those scurrilous Internet quarks, but the Little Gold Men at Vanity Fair linked it and it is just too juicy to check. Diana Ross and Celine Dion on the same broadcast? Theyre going to have to hire another crew of hair wranglers to pull this one together.

title: Mark, Hold the Marky
description: Mark Wahlberg spends time with the empathic Terry Gross, host of Fresh Air, and gets through the whole thing without speaking the effenheimer.

title: Toastmaster Toasts Whitaker
description: Your content is fine and all, Forest, but your delivery makes you sound like the human rain delay. Susan Wloszczyna of USA Today reports out some tips for the guy in the lead to give the speech as best actor. The Baggers advice? Channel your inner Idi Amin.

title: Greyhound Bus Operator to Be Sold for $2.8 Billion
description: Laidlaw International, the company that runs Greyhound buses that are a fixture of North Americas highways, agreed to be acquired by FirstGroup of the United Kingdom for for $2.8 billion plus debt.

title: Helen and the Lads
description: Back in the day  well, the Bagger is one of the whitest people alive, so what he actually means to say is: A couple of years ago, the Bagger was covering publishing and lad magazines. Photo spreads of models tugging and twisting their garments were all the rage back then. The Bagger asked Bob Guccione Jr. who published Gear magazine, an American version of the British lad mag, what was the deal with all of the clothing being pulled about, and he said, We, weve got a problem with sand on our shoots.

title: Lear Agrees to Buyout by Icahns Firm
description: Lear, the auto-parts maker, said Friday it agreed to be acquired by American Real Estate Partners, the investment firm controlled by Carl C. Icahn, for $36 per share, or about $5.3 billion including the assumption of debt. The offer, which was announced Monday, is being opposed by one of Lears major shareholders.

title: In Search of the Grim Reapers Funny Bone
description: We are not going to discuss You Know Whos death because we generally dont think that dead people, regardless of their backstories, should be treated like piatas  hit with sticks by bloggers and commentators until their insides fall out and their demise somehow becomes comic. Not to get all prissy or anything, but the Bagger always wonders what is so funny about someone, anyone, turning up dead.

title: Charlize Theron Changes the Subject
description: Charlize Theron, insert obligatory Oscar hook here winner of the best actress Oscar in 2003 for Monster, was being interviewed by Rich Sanchez on CNN about East of Havana, a documentary she produced on rappers in Cuba. After Ms. Theron compared the lack of artistic freedom in the United States to those in Cuba, Mr. Sanchez, who is of Cuban heritage, incidentally, got a little puffed up and did that TV thing they do when they know they have a whiff of controversy before them. Ms. Theron pushed back gamely for a while until she, well, sort of flipped out. Heres a transcription of the last part of the interview.

title: High Anti-Whaling Drama on High Antarctic Seas
description: A strange story from Antarctic waters: It seems some swashbuckling conservationists, after chasing and tormenting a Japanese whaling fleet, briefly lost two of their crew at sea. The Japanese ship was then enlisted in an eight-hour search for the missing men, who were found tethered to an iceberg. After the rescue, thank-yous were exchanged, and the cat-and-mouse resumed.

title: How Do You Say Id Like to Thank My Agent in Swedish?
description: Being an Oscar blogger during the first few weeks of February is, ah, I think the technical term is a long, frickin haul, but it does have some upsides. A while back, the Bagger took time out to do a podcast for Voccine, a Swedish pop culture site run by Christina Jeurling and Tomas Seo. They were smart and funny, and the Bagger didnt think much about it until he recently received a gorgeous, hand-built invitation to their annual Oscar party.

title: Behind the Veil
description: A colleague of the Bagger saw The Painted Veil the other night and arrived at work with a question: How come that movie is not in the running for something this year?

title: Ralph Lauren- Fall 2007
description: Photos from Ralph Lauren's fall collection at Bryant Park.

title: An Interrogators Confession
Who Was Boss Platt?
description: In this article by Michael Cooper and Danny Hakim this morning, William T. Cunningham, who has served in the Carey, Cuomo and Bloomberg administrations, compared Gov. Eliot Spitzers confrontational approach with the legislature to a predecessor, Theodore Roosevelt:

title: Cowboys and New Englanders
description: Even though efforts in big states like California and Florida to move up their presidential primary dates have been shaking up the campaign process, the primacy of New Hampshires primary reigns on. But the nations least-populous state could be mounting one of the most aggressive efforts yet to chip away at the Granite States position.

title: Did Edwards Make the Right Decision?
description: John Edwards released a statement yesterday saying he was personally offended by some of the posts made by Amanda Marcotte, his campaign blogmaster, last year on the feminist blog Pandagon. Its not how I talk to people, and its not how I expect the people who work for me to talk to people, Edwards said. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, but that kind of intolerant language will not be permitted from anyone on my campaign, whether its intended as satire, humor or anything else. But I also believe in giving everyone a fair shake. Marcottes intention was not to malign anyones faith, he added, and she will keep her job.

title: Primedia to Consider Selling Enthusiast Magazines
description: Shares of Primedia soared 19 percent Friday morning after the publishing company said it was considering the sale of its enthusiast media group, which includes magazines such as Motor Trend, Hot Rod and Surfer. It said it hired Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers to oversee the process. The enthusiast magazines, which make up Primedias largest business segment, brought in revenue of more than $500 million last year, excluding a group of outdoor-themed magazines that were already sold, Primedia said.

title: Fortress I.P.O. Opens Sharply Higher
description: Fortress Investment Group, the first hedge fund and private equity company to go public in the United States, made its market debut Friday at $35 per share, nearly double the offer price of $18.50. The opening price gave the company, which manages about $30 billion in assets, a market value of $14 billion.

title: Calvin Klein-Fall 2007
description: Calvin Klein was one of the designers who wrapped up New York Fashion Week.

title: 2008: Internal Conflict
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, a social moderate trying to win the Republican nomination, is trying a new strategy: disagreeing with himself.

title: Gore Seeks Technological Solutions for a Few Inconvenient Truths
description: In  An Inconvenient Truth, the Oscar-nominated documentary on Al Gores drive to limit global warming, the former vice president stressed that personal and political will were the only missing factors in limiting smokestack and tailpipe emissions linked to rising temperatures.

title: Probably Not an Endorsement He Wanted
description: The newly selected state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, earned praise from an unexpected quarter yesterday: Alan G. Hevesi, the guy he replaced.

title: Anna Nicole Smith, 1967-2007
description: Vicki Lynn Hogan, of the white-gold hair and eye-popping figure, has left this world.

description: Readers respond to David Brookss Feb. 8 column, Private Virtue, Public Vice.

description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 8 column, They Beat Gary So Bad.

title: Bloomberg: Starrett Deal Problematic
description: During his weekly WABC radio appearance this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was asked by John Gambling about the sale of Starrett City in Brooklyn for $1.3 billion to a partnership led by David Bistricer. Some excerpts from the mayors interview:

title: Shopping for Retail Buyout Candidates
description: Eddie Bauers proposed buyout collapsed this week, and last years auction of Jones Apparel Group ended with no sale. Even so, analysts at Citigroup say that cash-rish private equity firms could still find many tempting takeover targets in the retail industry. Liz Claiborne was one company they said had the kind of strong cash flows and low debt levels that often get private equity firms attention. One of the least attractive targets, the analysts said, is Gap, whose weak sales and management turmoil have made it the subject of buyout speculation.

title: We Respond to Questions About Timing
description: Many of our loyal (and not-so-loyal) readers have posted comments over the past week expressing confusion about the time frame of our chronicle of building our dream home.

title: For US Airways Chief, a Very Bad Day
description: Last Wednesday brought a double whammy of unpleasantness for US Airways chief executive W. Douglas Parker. On Jan. 31, his companys $9.8 billion bid for Delta Air Lines was rejected by its bankrupt rivals committee of creditors. Hours later, he was arrested on suspicion of drunk driving.

title: A Flight on the Airbus A380
description: The world's largest passenger aircraft took off on its first major demonstration flight with 200 journalists on board.

title: Connecticut Considers Stricter Hedge-Fund Rules
description: Both investors and regulators continue to be obsessed with hedge funds. Investors on Friday showed that their interest is unlikely to abate anytime soon by bidding up the shares of the newly public Fortress Investment Group. Regulators interest comes from both the federal government and from the states, which are increasingly looking for ways to monitor hedge funds.

title: Who Was the Mystery Suitor for Harrahs?
description: Harrahs Entertainment, the worlds largest casino operator, has filed a preliminary proxy statement for its proposed $15 billion acquisition by private equity firms Texas Pacific Groupand Apollo Management. The statement includes the usual section describing how the deal came to be, but, as is the custom, the names of many firms involved are left out, replaced with generic terms like PE Firm #1 and Company B.

title: Please Keep Your Carnival Quiet
description: Seems that one of the worlds great civic celebrations, the 200-year-old Carnaval de Santa Cruz de Tenerife  the ten-day Bacchanal that unfolds round this time of year on Tenerife in Spains Canary Islands  has been stifled, and tempers are flaring.

title: Cartoon Network Chief Steps Down
description: In an effort to atone for a guerrilla marketing campaign that mistakenly fell under suspicion as a far-reaching terrorist plot last week, turning sections of Boston upside down while law-enforcement investigated, the head of the Cartoon Network, Jim Samples, resigned today.

title: Proxy Adviser Criticizes Caremark-CVS Deal
description: A proxy advisory firm has weighed in on the continuing battle over drug benefits manager Caremark Rx, advising shareholders to reject a $24 billion bid by CVS. In a report released Friday, Glass Lewis criticized what it said was a lack of transparency and openness in the bidding process. Caremark has rejected a $26 billion offer by rival Express Scripts, citing issues like antitrust concerns.

title: Insurgent Video
description: Insurgents released this video, which they claim is of a U.S. helicopter being shot down in Iraq.

title: 2008: Your Weekenders Online Guide
description: Candidates (and the reporters who follow them) will be racking up lots of frequent-flyer miles with all the travel this weekend, which includes a probable announcement of candidacy by Senator Barack Obama and a long-awaited trip to New Hampshire by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. For exact dates and locations, see our On Deck section. To help you follow all the festivities, heres a list of resources:

title: Believe the Hype
description: For sometime now, the Bagger has been hearing that the The Lives of Others, a nominee for best foreign film in the Oscars, is a great movie, regardless of idiom or category or anything else. He saw it last night and found that it was one of those movies that dont require attention  they rivet it. He could, and would, go on, but thankfully, A. O. Scott came up with a review today:

title: Walk of Shame?
description: The Hollywood Walk of Fame is crumbling, not under the weight of all that celebrity, but for a variety of technical reasons that are still being argued about. Bob Pool writes in the Los Angeles Times that the section in front of the Kodak Theater is much the worse for wear, which could pose a hazard for the glitzy goings on coming up in just a few weeks. And by the way, the price of stardom in cement is going up.

title: Supplemental Auction
description: How luscious was the special booklet they put together for The Queen? Right now, the advertising insert is up for auction on eBay, which would seem to indicate a significant cult interest in the film and everything associated with it.

description: Dick Cavett's 1971 interview with Woody Allen.

description: The honeymoon known as Obama-mania may soon be coming to a close.

description: Amy Taykan and Brett Goffin were innocently introduced by  Brett's father.

description: Someone paid $500,000 for the rights to this video of Anna Nicole Smiths last moments, which was broadcast on German TV.

title: Diagnosing the Videos With Dr. Sanjay Gupta!
description: Online video makes physicians of us all. And Anna Nicole Smith was everbodys patient.

title: John Edwards Raises the Bar on Health Care
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Feb. 9 column, Edwards Gets It Right.

title: Russias Growing Pains
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Feb. 9 column, Not Their Parents Russia.

title: Congressmans Imam Is Taking a Lead in Interfaith Efforts
description: MINNEAPOLIS  On the evening after Minnesotas Democratic primary last September, Makram El-Amin picked up his ringing cellphone to hear the raspy, exhausted voice of Keith Ellison. The men had known each other for a decade, long enough for Mr. El-Amin to become the imam of a mosque in their North Minneapolis neighborhood and Mr. Ellison to win a seat as the areas state representative.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) NEW ORLEANS It began as a small French settlement surrounded by water and became a party zone for the nation  a city at once the most integrated in the country and the site of some of the most vicious white supremacist violence. What, then, would America be without New Orleans? Thats the question at the heart of this American Experience documentary, which looks at more than 200 defining events in the history of the city, from the Reconstruction Constitution and the Great Flood of 1927 to the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. Among those offering opinions: the restaurateur Leah Chase, known as the queen of creole cuisine; Toddy Pierre, a stonemason; the jazz musician Irvin Mayfield, who is also heard on the films soundtrack, and members of the irreverent Krewe DVieux, which was the first Mardi Gras organization to parade after Katrina.

title: Arizona: Immigrant Injured in Attack Is Charged With Smuggling
description: An illegal immigrant injured in an ambush on a group of people crossing the border on Thursday has been charged with smuggling, the federal customs agency said. The immigrant, Pedro Luis Beltran-Camargo, 21, was shot in the hand in the attack. He was arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents after survivors of the attack identified him as their smuggler, said Lauren Mack, a spokeswoman for the agency. Mr. Beltran-Camargo, who is from Mexico, sought help from the authorities and was treated at a hospital; he was then taken into custody, Ms. Mack said. Another person injured in the attack, which left three immigrants dead, is still in a hospital, and several others in the group, which numbered about 30, appear to have escaped from the gunmen and fled, Ms. Mack said.

title: Inviting Africas Anglicans to Gather Under a Bigger Tent
description: BISHOPSCOURT, South Africa

title: Walking on Eggshells in a World of Traumas
description: Jill Sigman has a prodigious imagination and intelligence. She is also a fearless performer who does not hesitate to expose the painful truths within us all. And her new piece, Rupture, bursts with unruly, tumultuous life for about its first two-thirds. But then it becomes very much like an exercise in mind control. Heavy gates close, locking in some audience members and leaving others unable to find their way into the work.

title: Exxon Mobil Just Wants to Be Loved
description: Late last week, Exxon Mobil announced that it had made an astonishing $39.5 billion in 2006. No company in history, not Microsoft, not Wal-Mart, has ever come close to making the kind of annual profit that this 134-year-old oil giant generated last year.

title: Cramer vs. Cramer vs. Blodget
description: IF Joe Piscopo and Andrew Dice Clay engaged in a war of words over how best to manage a career in comedy, would you take sides?

title: Sports Briefing
description: pro football

title: Peru: President Questioned in 1986 Massacre
description: President Alan Garca was questioned by a judge about his actions during the killing of more than 100 suspected Maoist guerrillas during his first presidency in the 1980s. Perus Congress declined to bring criminal charges for the deaths against Mr. Garca in 1990 for the incident, in which Peruvian soldiers suppressed a rebellion at El Frontn prison in 1986 and then transferred the bodies of prisoners to anonymous graves on Limas outskirts. Reuters reported that Mr. Garca was not a target of the judges investigation. The questioning of Mr. Garca raises uneasy memories of his first term, which was haunted by political and economic chaos.

title: Hospice Basics
Haunted Spirits in a Mexican Mystery
description: Before a word is spoken in The Crying Woman, Kathleen Anderson Culebros imaginative new play at the Beckett Theater, the character of La Llorona wanders onstage, singing an ominous lament for her dead children. La Llorona is the crying woman of the title and a ghost from the 16th century. She shows up from time to time throughout the play, warning in mournful song of bad things to come. Certainly she gives the audience a strong hint that the opening scenes of placid domesticity are illusory at best.

title: Vehicles Crossing the Pond
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9  American auto companies have long talked globally but acted locally.

title: Gears of War Is Victor at Game Awards
description: Gears of War, the intense but glossy combat romp for Microsofts Xbox 360, owned the competition (to use the online vernacular) on Thursday night as the Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences announced the winners of its 2006 video game awards. Games for Nintendos innovative Wii console also did well, while Sony titles mostly came up short.

title: Chevron Said to Be Interested in Buying Assets of Yukos of Russia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8  Chevron intends to bid for assets of Yukos, the bankrupt oil producer, Russian officials said Friday. If Chevron succeeds, such an acquisition could help close the final chapter on the downfall of Russias largest oil company.

title: Playing Past 100, Still Eager to Hunt Down the Overtrick
description: Who and what age is the oldest active tournament director in the world?

title: Harriett Woods, 79, Womens Political Leader, Dies
description: Harriett Woods, who started in politics by protesting a rattling manhole cover and went on to become the first woman to win statewide office in Missouri before leading a national effort to promote women as candidates, died on Thursday at her home in University City, Mo. She was 79.

title: Google Encounters Hurdles in Selling Radio Advertising
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9  When Google acquired dMarc Broadcasting, a company whose software allows marketers to place ads on radio stations, for up to $1.24 billion early last year, it was seen as a clear sign of Googles ambitions to extend its dominance over Internet advertising to other media.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Every Picture Tells a Story: Collazo Set for Title Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 9  The assortment of tattoos crisscrossing Luis Collazos upper body are difficult to miss when he steps into the ring. Even Collazo is not sure how many tattoos he has. He stopped counting at 30.

title: Britain: Man Detained in Letter Bombing
description: A 48-year-old man called a BBC radio phone-in show to take responsibility for sending one of seven letter bombs that exploded in British offices in recent weeks. The station did not permit him on air. The man, whose name was not made public, was later detained under the Mental Health Act. The police are investigating if the bombs, which have not caused serious injuries, were sent by animal rights protesters or by people angered by restrictions on motorists.

description: To the Editor:

title: $25 Million to Encourage Cleaner Air
description: LONDON, Feb. 9  Imagine a giant vacuum cleaner for the atmosphere.

description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 9  Donna Washington loves riding the Las Vegas Monorail, but not for a reason that would cheer its owners.

title: Nets Begin Winning as Celtics Keep Losing
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9  To finally win with ease, after gut-wrenching finishes had become the norm for them, the Nets needed only to play physical defense, make their free throws and, most of all, play a team in as much disarray as the Boston Celtics.

title: Mets Add Park to List of Rotation Hopefuls
description: Chan Ho Park has worn No. 61 since 1994, his first season in the major leagues. A high uniform number like that is usually given to a long-shot roster candidate, which may describe Parks status as he prepares for spring training with the Mets.

title: World Atomic Agency Suspends 22 Programs of Aid to Iran
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said yesterday that it had suspended 22 of its 55 technical aid programs with Iran, giving Washington a modest victory in its efforts to isolate Tehran internationally in the hope of curbing its nuclear ambitions.

title: 2nd Death Attributed to Cold Snap
description: An 85-year-old woman has become the citys second victim of the recent cold snap, the medical examiners office announced yesterday.
