title: Inquiry on Intelligence Gaps May Reach to White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Friday that he would ask current and former White House aides to testify about a report by the Pentagons inspector general that criticizes the Pentagon for compiling alternative intelligence that made the case for invading Iraq.

title: Heels Over Hemingway
description: WASHINGTON

title: Deal to Shut Major North Korean Nuclear Facilities Appears Closer
description: BEIJING, Feb. 9  North Korea and the United States appeared on Friday to be inching closer to a deal that would establish a schedule for the North to shut down and seal its main nuclear facilities within two months, in return for shipments of fuel oil from South Korea and the beginning of talks over normalization of relations with Washington.

title: Spare Change for the War Effort? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Instructive Moment
description: A meeting of an organization of New York public school parents this week turned into a lesson in how a school system can go wrong in trying to win parents trust. As chronicled in yesterdays Times by Elissa Gootman, the parent groups chairman asked Chris Cerf, a new deputy schools chancellor, a direct question about his finances. Mr. Cerfs response was not untrue, but it was hardly forthcoming. School administrators will have to do better if they want to improve their standing with parents and the general public.

title: Ian Richardson, 72, Versatile Scottish Actor, Dies
description: Ian Richardson, the Scottish film, television and stage actor who was a major figure at the Royal Shakespeare Company before gaining international fame for his television portrayal of a deliciously villainous politician, died yesterday at his home in London. He was 72.

title: Jury Votes Against Execution in Trial of Drug Dealer Convicted in 2 Killings
description: A notorious street-corner crack kingpin with ties to the rap music industry was spared the death penalty yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn when a jury failed to reach a unanimous verdict to execute him for ordering the killing of two rivals.

title: Fortress Shares Rise 70 Percent in Wall Street Debut
description: Shares in Fortress Investment Group surged more than 70 percent this morning as shareholders rushed to grab a piece of the first hedge fund and private equity company to go public in the United States.

title: Arab Protesters in Jerusalem Clash With Israeli Forces
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9  Israeli troops charged onto the grounds of Jerusalems most contentious religious site on Friday and fired tear gas and stun grenades at stone-throwing Palestinians who were protesting Israeli excavation work taking place nearby.

title: U.N. Troops Fight Haiti Gangs One Street at a Time
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 5  For years, street gangs have run Haiti right alongside the politicians. With a disbanded army and a corrupted wreck of a police force, successive presidents have either used the gangs against political rivals or just bought them off.

title: Even Amid Its Wealth, India Finds, Half Its Small Children Are Malnourished
description: MUMBAI, India, Feb. 9  Even after Indias years of sustained economic growth, child malnutrition rates here are comparable to some of the poorest countries, and at times worse.

title: Mancuso Finishes Second to Paerson in Super-Combined
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 9  It was so cold Friday at the Alpine skiing world championships that many of the public toilets froze. As a result, Swedish fans danced from foot to foot as they waited for another victory from their countrywoman Anja Paerson.

title: TV Official Quits Over Ad Stunt
description: The executive vice president and general manager of the Cartoon Network cable channel resigned suddenly yesterday in the wake of a marketing campaign in Boston that went awry.

title: Looking for a Paycheck? Dont Look to the Internet
description: THE Internet is the wave of the future, the technology that changes everything.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the United States Hockey Hall of Fame referred imprecisely to the number of teams in the National Hockey League in the 1930s and 40s. The league ranged from 7 to 10 teams in the 1930s; there were not just six. The 1942-3 season did have six teams. Also, a report in the Sunday Shootout column on Dec. 17 misstated the year the so-called Original Six era of hockey began and the number of seasons that it lasted. It began in 1942, not 1945, and it ended in 1967 after 25 seasons, not 22. (The errors in the Dec. 17 article were discovered during research on the number of teams.)

title: In Palestinian Peace Deal, Hope and a Political Snare
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9  The agreement in Mecca between Fatah and Hamas on how to form a unity government was greeted with relief by many Palestinians on Friday as their best hope for an end to the fighting among them that has killed nearly 100 Palestinians since December.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Posts Big Loss, Plans Further Job Cuts
description: PARIS, Feb. 9  Uncertainty among the worlds phone companies left Alcatel-Lucent with a bruising net loss on Friday in its first quarterly report as the worlds largest maker of telecommunications equipment, and the company moved to eliminate thousands of additional jobs.

title: River Ruling Is a Boost for Proponents of Public Access
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9  Pennsylvania won a battle last month in the war over public access being waged on fields and streams nationwide.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about demands by the Catholic League that the John Edwards presidential campaign fire two women who wrote anti-Catholic opinions on their personal blogs misstated the Catholic doctrine that one blogger described using vulgar language. It was the virgin birth of Jesus, not the Immaculate Conception. (Go to Article)

title: Novelist Endangered by Her Book
description: It is rarely a simple thing to be a novelist in Turkey. For Elif Shafak, it has never been more complicated.

title: U.N. Chief Gives Key Post to American
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 9  Stirred by criticism of the slow pace of senior appointments, Ban Ki-moon, the new United Nations secretary general, on Friday named four new cabinet members, including an American diplomat, while keeping a dozen other senior officials in place.

title: The Names of the Game
description: I wouldnt be writing this if I hadnt been cheated.

title: Mandatory Costs at University Break $50,000
description: George Washington University, already the most expensive major university in the country, became the first to raise tuition, fees and other mandatory costs above $50,000. Trustees set tuition for students entering the university in September at $39,210, an increase of 3.8 percent; mandatory fees including housing will push that cost to $50,660, a university spokesman said. The tuition will affect only next years freshmen; the university sets costs for each class and then freezes the costs for the duration of the students attendance.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Banks Razing at 9/11 Site Will Be Soon, Officials Say
description: In what has become a familiar ritual downtown, officials said yesterday  and this time they really, truly meant it  that demolition would soon begin at the damaged and contaminated former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero.

title: In a Daughters Film Tribute, a Celebration of a Life Lived Through Art
description: Allan Stone, the art collector and dealer, lived life in abundance, and the celebration planned for his 75th birthday this week had plenty of what he relished: from Latin jazz, mojitos and the ice cream he could never refuse to the wife, six daughters and artists he always cherished.

title: Forgive Me, Viewer, for I Have Confessed in a Banner Ad
description: Courtney Stecker is obsessed with the idea of surviving a car crash over a bridge, he confided to the camera. And every time he drives over a bridge, he said, he shuts everyone else out and imagines his car sailing over the rail.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on the Fashion Page on Wednesday about socialites and their invitations to Fashion Week shows carried incorrect information from a publicist for the Yigal Azroul show about the socialite Tinsley Mortimer. Mr. Azroul did indeed invite Ms. Mortimer to his event.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Feb. 2 with a review of exhibitions devoted to Robert Moses at the Museum of the City of New York, the Queens Museum of Art and the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University referred incompletely to the Chatham Green housing project in Lower Manhattan. While Moses oversaw the development plan and chose the projects sponsor, it was the sponsor  the Association for Middle Income Housing  that selected the architect and constructed the buildings, not Moses.

title: Russia: Border Incident Shows Tensions With Ukraine
description: Russian immigration authorities recently turned back a close ally of President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine at the St. Petersburg airport in a sign of lingering animosity between the countries after the 2004 revolution in Ukraine. Russian officials said they banned Petro O. Poroshenko, a chocolate and television magnate and former Ukrainian national security adviser, on Feb. 3 in retaliation for Ukraines visa ban on Russian ultranationalist politician Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky and others, Interfax reported.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Bonds at Big Bank
description: Bank of America said yesterday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.

title: Testimony Is Completed in Murder of Dancer, 21
description: Despite a yoga teachers private school education, good looks and talent, he was bested by a rube from Ohio, a prosecutor told the teacher at his murder trial yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Bacon Brings It Home

title: A Guests Youthful Vigor at the Podium
description: The New York Philharmonic is cultivating relationships with a handful of young (or youngish) conductors, and one of them, Alan Gilbert, returned to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday for the first of two visits this season.

title: There Is Life After Hospice, and Even Golf in Florida for Some
description: Hospice does not have to mean an immediate death sentence  as the late humorist Art Buchwald demonstrated. Last year, much to his and others amazement, he survived for five months in a hospice program before being well enough to leave in July. It was not until last month that he died of kidney failure.

title: Voting Isnt Like Banking (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Criticizes U.S. Plan for Missile Defense System
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Feb. 9  Russias defense minister chose a NATO session here on Friday for a pre-emptive verbal assault on American plans to base elements of a missile defense system in Eastern Europe.

title: A Pianist Returns, a Little Bit Shy, a Little Bit Sly
description: Thoughtful. Honest. Sensitive. Musicianly.

title: Legacy of Ashe Receives a Breath of New Life
description: Time flies, Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe said earlier this week.

title: Figuring Out Gift Giving in the Age of $2,000-a-Pound Chocolate
description: If you are still seeking the perfect gift for Valentines Day, have you considered a box of Noka chocolates?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a $400 million gift from T. Denny Sanford to the Sioux Valley Hospitals and Health System referred incorrectly to medical research financed by two other philanthropists, John D. Rockefeller and Bill Gates. Mr. Rockefellers money was used to develop a vaccine to prevent yellow fever; it did not result in a cure. Mr. Gates has focused primarily on H.I.V. prevention, rather than on searching for a cure.

title: The Build-a-War Workshop
description: It took far too long, but a report by the Pentagon inspector general has finally confirmed that Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfelds do-it-yourself intelligence office cooked up a link between Iraq and Al Qaeda to help justify an unjustifiable war.

title: Main Break Disrupts 5 Towns in New Jersey
description: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Feb. 9  An early-morning water main break here on Friday left tens of thousands of people without water in five towns in northern New Jersey and forced the evacuation of dozens of residents, including some who had to flee on rafts in the frigid water.

title: A Chance to Pick Hospice, and Still Hope to Live
description: The American health care system has long given patients a terrible choice: people told that they have a terminal illness must forgo advanced medical treatment to qualify for hospice care. Cancer patients have to pass up chemotherapy, for example, or patients with kidney failure must abandon dialysis.

title: Scolding Peers, Legislator Draws Notice
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  It is normally hard to imagine ways by which Republicans in the State Assembly, the chambers oppressed and powerless minority, could become well known. Being attacked in broad daylight might do it. Or being indicted for bribery. Or saving small children from a burning house.

title: Bad Faith on Social Security
description: In 2005, President Bush put his political capital where his mouth was, and lost. He went all-out to convince Congress and the American people that privatizing Social Security would be good and necessary. Its neither  and his plan was justifiably and soundly rejected. This year, with his political capital on empty, Mr. Bush is talking about a bipartisan effort to reform Social Security. But his actions suggest that he has no intention of making any serious compromises.

title: U.S. Gives Tour of Family Detention Center That Critics Liken to a Prison
description: TAYLOR, Tex., Feb. 9  Responding to complaints about conditions at the nations main family detention center for illegal immigrants, officials threw open the gates on Friday for a first news media tour.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about demands by the Catholic League that the John Edwards presidential campaign fire two women who wrote anti-Catholic opinions on their personal blogs misstated the Catholic doctrine that one blogger described using vulgar language. It was the virgin birth of Jesus, not the Immaculate Conception.

title: California Split
description: Washington

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) A CHARLIE BROWN VALENTINE Will you be mine? Thats the question on the minds of the Peanuts gang as the Valentines Dance approaches and Sally dreams of Linus, Lucy longs for Schroeder, and Peppermint Patty goes weak for Charlie Brown  who in turn pines away for the little red-haired girl, if only she knew he existed. But will Snoopy turn out to be the beau of the ball?

title: A Tribe Turns to 3-D Animation for Modern Storytelling
description: VERNON, N.Y.  In a stately country house on a quiet stretch of upstate New York dominated by agribusiness, an American Indian tribe is using high-tech animation to preserve hundreds of years of history.

title: Drawing Up a Menu for America
description: The $87 billion casual dining sector is in the doldrums, and analysts dont see much improvement in the months ahead. Clarence Otis Jr., 50, the chairman and chief executive of Darden Restaurants, owner of Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains, said consumer uncertainty, prompted by higher gas prices and interest rates, was mostly to blame.

title: Follow That Lobbyist
description: Atlanta

title: Greenwich Village Hospital Opts for Smaller but More Efficient
description: St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village plans to build an entirely new hospital, probably across the street from its current site, and then sell most of its valuable real estate on Seventh Avenue to a developer.

title: Weather for Ice Fishing Is Late in Adirondacks
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.  Ernie and Dan Jessie, first cousins and native Adirondackers, sat quietly in the small translucent ice-fishing shack they have shared winter after winter, waiting. Their lines disappeared into the 60-foot depths of Upper Saranac Lake through the perfect circles they had just finished drilling in the ice.

title: The iNanny Alert
description: Heres the bad news: not everybody is capable of multitasking on a city street. Some people, presumably sober, start weaving like pub-crawlers as they madly send text-messages from the crosswalk. Some turn glassy-eyed, their brains tuned to loud music or their vision narrowed to an empty space a few inches away.

title: China Detains Ex-Official in Inquiry on Fake Drugs
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 9  With a growing number of cases involving the sale of fraudulent or dangerous medicines, China said Friday that it had ordered a thorough investigation into its government agency that is supposed to be the national watchdog.

title: Why Did We Watch? The Answer Isnt Pretty
description: Becoming famous is relatively easy: Anna Nicole Smith was born with a beautiful face, a big smile and a voluptuous body she was happy to bare for Playboy. Staying famous for nothing much is hard work, and that is the real story of Ms. Smiths life and death. Her desperation for fame was so raw that she didnt mind being the butt of the joke if it helped maintain her place in the spotlight. Her career started out tacky, went downhill from there and ultimately says more about the cultures fascination with celebrity than it does about Anna Nicole Smith.

title: So Theyre Running for President, Right?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  It can be hard to keep track of everyone running for president, let alone those who are merely exploring it, unofficially running, testing the waters or starting a conversation with the American people.

title: Lear Agrees to Buyout Offer of $2.8 Billion From Icahn
description: DETROIT, Feb. 9  One of the biggest shareholders of the Lear Corporation, a manufacturer of automotive seats, criticized the companys deal on Friday to sell itself for $2.8 billion to the investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: A Bachelor Pad With a View: A Giant Bottle Cap
description: When Yo Han Cho wakes up in the morning, one of the first things he sees out his window is the top of the Pepsi-Cola bottle, 50 feet tall and tipping south. When he returns to his apartment 18 or 19 hours later to go to sleep, there is the bottle cap, silhouetted against the lights of Manhattan.

title: A Princeton Lab on ESP Plans to Close Its Doors
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6  Over almost three decades, a small laboratory at Princeton University managed to embarrass university administrators, outrage Nobel laureates, entice the support of philanthropists and make headlines around the world with its efforts to prove that thoughts can alter the course of events.

title: First-Place Yale Is Turning Ivy League on Its Head
description: Yale is known for a lot of things, but a winning basketball tradition is not one of them. The Bulldogs have not been to the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1962, have had 29 losing seasons since and can usually be found near the bottom of the Ivy League standings. But it may finally be Yales turn.

title: California: Elie Wiesel Is Attacked
description: Elie Wiesel, left, the Holocaust survivor, author and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, was attacked at a San Francisco hotel last week by an unknown assailant, the police said yesterday. Sgt. Neville Gittens, a police spokesman, said Mr. Wiesel, 78, was attending a conference when a man approached him in an elevator and asked to interview him. After a brief discussion, the man dragged Mr. Wiesel off the elevator and tried to restrain him, but Mr. Wiesel screamed, and the attacker fled. Mr. Wiesel was not injured. No arrests were made, though Sergeant Gittens said the police had a person of interest in the case. The Associated Press reported that a Holocaust denier calling himself Eric Hunt had claimed credit on an anti-Semitic Web site for accosting Mr. Wiesel, but the police could not confirm whether he was the suspect.

title: Fatal Accident Brings Charges for 17-Year-Old
description: A 17-year-old high school student was charged with reckless driving and speeding in connection with a crash last month in Freehold Township, N.J., that killed four people, the Monmouth County prosecutor said.

title: Young Guitarist Shows Some Things He Learned From His Famous Father
description: One of the ways the Malian guitarist Ali Farka Tour impressed Western listeners was that he never made you think much about technique. Of course it was there  in his control over the curled, stammering phrasing of his lines; in his slow, easy-moving confidence while implying more than one meter. But hearing him work within a single scale, you received a perfect lesson in how much more there is to music than what notation or academic pedagogy can impart.

title: How Much Does It Cost to Buy a $110 Theater Ticket?
description: A little fee here, a tiny charge there, and before you know it, youre talking about real money.

title: 5 Held in Plot to Kill British Soldier
description: LONDON, Feb. 9  With sirens wailing and streets blocked off to permit its passage, a convoy of police vehicles sped across Britain and wound through central London on Friday to bring five terrorism suspects to court here from Birmingham.

title: Brimming From a Ray of Light, the Glare of Elusiveness
description: Terence Kohs untitled installation at the Whitney, his first solo museum show in New York, is a one-liner in the form of a bright light (a very, very bright light) projected across the lobby, near the elevator bank, of the museum. A guard in dark sunglasses, like the Whitneys own Secret Service agent, prevents visitors from getting too close and warns against looking directly at the beam. If hes a bit testy, who can blame him? Standing there all day must be like having to stay in one of those interrogation cells where the lights never go off. I watched for half an hour or so as visitors mostly walked by, barely pausing or not bothering to notice, their passing bodies briefly turned white by the glare.

title: Given a Fine, Hevesi Praises His Successor
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  The former state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, praised his replacement on Friday, after a hearing at which a judge sentenced him to pay a $5,000 fine for his use of state employees to chauffeur his wife.

title: For Kidd and Hill, Bond Stays Strong Despite Divergent Paths
description: When the Nets and the Magic play tonight, it will be another example of the divergent career paths of Jason Kidd and Grant Hill.

title: First Offering of a Hedge Fund Is Bid Up 67% on Opening Day
description: Investors stormed Fortress Investment Group yesterday, driving its shares up 67.6 percent in the first American market debut of a hedge fund manager.

title: A Day in the Life of an Extra, Er, Background Artist
description: I DROVE directly from LAX to the Hollywood Walk of Fame on a sun-thirsty Thursday afternoon, desperately seeking some luck of the break-a-leg variety. I was on a fanciful pursuit of show business fame and fortune that had suddenly turned serious. Back at J.F.K., the airline claimed I had canceled my $280 e-ticket. I had to fork over $948 to fly to L.A. in time to make my gig as an extra on the ABC sitcom George Lopez.

title: Stoic Link to Baseball History Stands Guard
description: Once upon a time in Brooklyn, they used to play baseball here.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Jan. 31 of The Great Divorce at Theater 315 in Manhattan, which closes tomorrow, gave an incorrect telephone number for tickets. It is (212) 868-4444.

title: Requiring a Vaccine for Young Girls (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Requiem for the Good Times
description: ECONOMIC growth is almost certainly decelerating and could soon cease altogether. The implications of a significant U.S. slowdown or extended depression, accompanied by inflation, are frightening.

title: And Baby Breaks the Budget
description: WHEN I got pregnant, my goal was to spend as little as possible on maternity wear, baby goods and all the assorted, adorable items that can put a big hole in your budget.

title: On Randalls Island, New Ball Fields via Deal With Elite Schools
description: Few would disagree that the baseball and softball diamonds on Randalls Island, which in some cases have devolved into pitted fields of rock and dirt with the occasional patch of sickly-looking grass, need work.

title: Ten-Hut! This Is Your New Uniform, Soldier (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Wealthy Nations Announce Plan to Develop and Pay for Vaccines
description: ROME, Feb. 9  Officials from a handful of wealthy nations initiated a long-awaited plan on Friday to support and finance the development of vaccines for children in poorer countries, and to purchase the vaccine once it is produced.

title: After Acquiring Equity Office, Blackstone Begins Selling It
description: The Blackstone Group completed its $39 billion purchase of Equity Office Properties yesterday and simultaneously began to dismantle its new portfolio of office buildings, the largest in the country.

title: Hungry for Change, a Pair of Governors Are Served Humble Pie
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9  Eliot Spitzer, the people of California have seen the likes of you before.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with a theater review of The Frugal Repast, at the June Havoc Theater, carried an erroneous credit provided by the publicist. The photograph was by Kim T. Sharp, not Carol Rosegg.

title: Hank Bauer, 84, World Series Star, Dies
description: Hank Bauer, a bruising pipe fitter and decorated combat veteran who became an All-Star outfielder for the Yankees, playing in nine World Series, and who later managed the Baltimore Orioles to a stunning Series victory, died yesterday in Shawnee Mission, Kan. He was 84.

title: City Backs Off Scanner Idea for Employees
description: The Bloomberg administration is backing away from using hand scanners to keep track of the comings and goings of city employees, after intense resistance from the workers and the union representing them, an official said yesterday.

title: A Musician Examines His Roots With Ingenuity and Ambivalence
description: After many years of requests from Mr. John Zorn, I finally made a Jewish record. That was the woodwind player Ned Rothenberg at Tonic on Thursday night, explaining the impetus behind Inner Diaspora, his new release on Mr. Zorns Tzadik label. Mr. Rothenberg added that his ensemble would be playing all the music from the album, in sequence. He probably didnt intend for this to sound as dutiful as it did.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,098 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Colombia Receives Drug Suspect Sought by U.S. and Jailed in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9  The leader of a Colombian drug cartel that American prosecutors say flooded New York City streets with cocaine remained in custody in Colombia on Friday awaiting extradition, after Cuba turned him over to the authorities there.

title: Deadliest Bomb in Iraq Is Made by Iran, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  The most lethal weapon directed against American troops in Iraq is an explosive-packed cylinder that United States intelligence asserts is being supplied by Iran.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a new study of the prevalence of autism spectrum disorders misstated the age range for the estimated 560,000 Americans who suffer from the disorders. They are age 21 or under, not 18 or under.

title: Autopsy Gives No Fast Clues to Smiths Death
description: As a medical examiner on one coast conducted an autopsy and a judge on another coast ordered her body preserved for 10 days, Anna Nicole Smith monopolized the gaudy, gossipy celebrity stage yesterday as she had tried to do in life.

title: Hezbollah Wants Its Guns Returned
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 9  Hezbollah acknowledged Friday that it owned a truckload of arms seized Thursday by Lebanese customs authorities in an East Beirut suburb and demanded their return.

title: Williams Says Hell Wait for a Guaranteed Spot
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Feb. 9  Bernie Williams came to this Connecticut town Friday night to play his guitar in a benefit concert at a church. He will be back home in Westchester County in the days to come. But where he will not be any time soon is in Tampa, Fla., where the Yankees will begin spring training next week without their longtime center fielder.

title: A Mission Statement in Outline Form
description: Much about the New York shows always feels superfluous  a lot wouldnt cut the mustard in Milan or Paris  and maybe thats because of the showbiz element. Watching the parade of Russian peasant finery at Vera Wang on Thursday, you half expected Barbra Streisand in a skullcap to burst out with The Way He Makes Me Feel.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A subheading for a sports article yesterday about an agreement by the cyclist Floyd Landis not to race in France this year referred incorrectly to his decision. Landis is skipping serious competition to focus on doping cases against him in France and in the United States; he says he is not doing so because he had hip-replacement surgery in September.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A jazz listing in Weekend yesterday for Miles Okazaki at 55 Bar in the West Village gave an incorrect date for his appearance. It is Monday, not tomorrow.

title: Stony Miens and Sad Hearts
description: The women of White Road Dance Media seemed a lively bunch at first. They let the audience at the Joyce SoHo pick the last song to be danced to at their new show, titled Youre Coming With Me Young Lady: A Night for the Wolves. They got cute with their biographical notes in the program, which also included a fairy tale written by the director, Marisa Gruneberg. They draped the lobby table with pink panties.

title: A Giddy Time for Owners of Office Towers
description: NEVER mind the maddening data on the residential property market. Commercial real estate is positively smoking. That was made plain by two big deals this week, one of them (nominally) the biggest leveraged buyout in history.

title: Lundqvist and Fourth Line Help Rangers End Their Losing Streak
description: Ryan Hollweg was a one-man demolition derby for the Rangers last night. Three minutes after scoring his first goal in more than 13 months, he flattened Tampa Bays Nikita Alexeev along the boards, then thumped Martin St. Louis into the end boards.

title: India Finds Its Economy on the Verge of Overheating
description: MUMBAI, India, Feb. 8  With breakneck growth, an outsourcing industry that leads the world and hundreds of millions of consumers demanding more class and comfort, India has an economy many countries would envy.

title: Chinas Influence in Africa Arouses Some Resistance
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 9  China is often depicted as a juggernaut of sorts, its untroubled and unfettered rise into the ranks of global powers a fact that lesser nations can only watch with awe and trepidation. On Friday, President Hu Jintao of China completed a 12-day tour of Africa that suggested the reality was more nuanced.

title: Giuliani Shifts Abortion Speech Gently to Right
description: As he prepares for a possible run for president  a road that goes deep into the heart of conservative America  Rudolph W. Giuliani takes with him a belief in abortion rights that many think could derail his bid to capture the Republican nomination.

title: U.S. Accidentally Attacks Kurdish Outpost, Killing Several
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 9  An American military helicopter killed as many as nine Kurdish militia fighters early Friday in the northern city of Mosul when the aircraft mistakenly attacked a guard post.

title: Francis Set to Return, but Where Will He Fit?
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 9  At long last, Steve Francis appears set to rejoin the rotation during the Knicks three-game western trip, which begins Saturday against the Utah Jazz.

title: Harvard Plans to Name First Female President
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 9  Harvard, the nations oldest university, plans to name Drew Gilpin Faust, a historian of the Civil War South, to be the first female president in its 371-year history, university officials said Friday.

title: Oh, Those Sharp Stones in a Dance Down Memory Lane
description: Memory is a twisting knife in Follies, Stephen Sondheim and James Goldmans beautiful, broken-hearted musical from 1971 about a showbiz reunion that ends not just in tears but also in nervous breakdowns. The pain that surprises and seizes those who would recall even happy times  or times they thought were happy  has always been the cornerstone of this much adored, much misunderstood show.

title: Discovery to End Sponsorship of Team
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9  The Discovery Channel will drop its sponsorship next year of the professional cycling team that was formerly led by Lance Armstrong. The decision by Discovery leaves the top United States team scrambling to find a primary sponsor at a time when the sport is in turmoil because of accusations of widespread use of performance-enhancing drugs by riders.

title: Lincolns Birthday
description: Alternate-side parking regulations in New York City will be suspended on Monday in observance of Lincolns Birthday. Other regulations remain in effect. All government offices will be open, but most courts will be closed. No trash or recyclables will be collected, but trash may be placed outside after 5 p.m. In New Jersey and Connecticut, courts and state offices will be closed.

title: E.P.A. Limits the Benzene in Gasoline by 2011
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  The Environmental Protection Agency is requiring significant reductions in the amount of cancer-causing benzene and other toxic hydrocarbon gases in gasoline and released into the air during storage and use, under a rule released Friday.

title: And God Made Isabel
description: Today, Isabel Toledo presented her first collection for Anne Klein, and her husband, the illustrator Ruben Toledo, made some note cards that were placed in a box on each guests seat, a personal gesture that says a lot about the kind of people that Ruben and Isabel are. She received a standing ovation, the only one I witnessed during Fashion Week, and waiting in the throng to congratulate her backstage were Narciso Rodriguez and Howard Sokol, the chief executive of Barneys New York.

title: Missing Billions in Iraq
description: There are a lot of good reasons to criticize the Bush administration in Iraq. But lately Henry Waxman, who normally is a shrewd investigator, has focused on the administrations lack of accounting for billions of dollars of cash. Waxman said it was crazy for the U.S. to ship huge crates of hundred dollar bills into a war zone.

title: You vs. the Tax Code
description: IF tax season makes you feel like David facing Goliath, remember that David won and that today's tax software gives you an accurate slingshot with plenty of stones. What is more, you need relatively little knowledge of either taxes or computers in order to use it.

title: 'Follies'
description: Photos from the latest staging of Stephen Sondheim's musical, at City Center.

title: Waiting for Obama
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.  The sun was not anywhere near up this morning, and the temperature was close to zero. But the Old State Capitol, the building where Abe Lincoln served as an Illinois senator, was ablaze in spotlights, And out front, on risers, were hundreds of photographers and television crews, setting up way in advance for a good position for the speech that happens later this morning.

title: Correction: Sharp Bites
description: An article last Sunday about the new breed of restaurant bloggers on the Internet misidentified the blog that first reported the reopening in Manhattan of the Russian Tea Room, with Gary Robins as the chef. It was the blog Snack, written by Jennifer Leuzzi  not the blog Restaurant Girl, written by Danyelle Freeman.

title: Senator Obamas Announcement
description: Following is the prepared text of Senator Barack Obama's announcement for president on Saturday in Springfield, Ill., as provided by his campaign:

title: Counterprogramming: Clinton in New Hampshire
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wrapped up the first event of her presidential campaign in New Hampshire at 10:30 a.m.  getting a good half-hour jump in the news cycle on Senator Barack Obamas campaign kick-off speech in Illinois.

title: Darfur and Divestment
description: To comment on my column for Sundays paper on divestment from Sudan, please hit the comment button below.

title: Niger Grows Greener
description: Farmers in Niger have used simple techniques to help a once-barren region become greener. The Times's Lydia Polgreen reports.

title: A Woman in the House: Isabel Toledo
description: I got up this morning to talk to Warren Pierce of WJR radio in Detroit about Fashion Week. It already seems so far away  Fashion Week, I mean. Detroit is where I first went to write about fashion, a rather chubby young mother who had the foolish idea that she looked good in dolman sleeves. WJR has a big signal, reaching as far as central Ohio. At various times Warren would have me on his show, and my father, a newspaperman in Columbus in his younger years, would get in his car and drive across the river to one of the higher hills and park and listen to me talk about the New York collections. He was my best editor, my father. He loved brevity in writing and in most things. He once told me, when I had a particularly idiotic boss, that the best way to handle the man was to reduce contact with him by 25 percent. It works.

title: New Soul Mates? Giuliani and the Clash
description: Pop songs are always a little risky for politicians, something Rudy Giuliani knows all about. Seven years ago, he was incensed at the use of the Billy Joel song Captain Jack at campaign event for his then-opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Size Matters: Clinton and Obama Duel Over Crowds
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.  Well, its come to this: The Clinton and Obama campaigns spent this afternoon engaged in a cross-country chest thumping competition, as Hillary Rodham Clinton traveled across New Hampshire and Barack Obama announced his campaign here in Illinois.

title: The Rise of Indian Television
description: The last decade has seen an explosion in India's television market. The Times's Vikas Bajaj explains how the industry is meeting the demand for content.

title: Obama Weathers Day 1 and the Weather
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - With his formal presidential announcement now in the books, Senator Barack Obama landed here for the campaigns real beginning.

title: Obama Formally Joins '08 Race
description: Senator Barack Obama's campaign now enters a more difficult phase as the march toward the Democratic presidential nomination continues. The Times's Jeff Zeleny reports.

title: Where the Winery Itself Is a Little Tipsy
description: NAPA, Calif.

title: A Boutique on the North Fork
description: THERE is no countess behind Comtesse Thrse wines; the principal owner of the brand is Theresa K. Dilworth, a New York tax lawyer and avowed francophile.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE HIGHER POWER OF LUCKY. By Susan Patron. Illustrated by Matt Phelan. Richard Jackson/Atheneum. $16.95. (Ages 9 to 11) The winner of the 2007 Newbery Medal features the resourceful, bug-collecting Lucky Trimble and the colorful town of Hard Pan, Calif., pop. 43. It was briefly pop. 42, after Luckys mother was electrocuted by a downed power line; then her fathers first wife came from France to act as Luckys guardian, and the status quo was restored. (The father himself is somehow out of the picture.) This is the kind of novel where a smart 10-year-old can run away from home into a dangerous dust storm, lugging her dead mothers ashes and wearing a red silk dress. Still, Luckys story has its charm, along with (naturally) an upbeat ending.

title: Take Heart, All You Amateurs: A Big Upset May Be Possible
description: Chess is not like poker. In chess, an unknown like Chris Moneymaker cannot come out of nowhere to win a championship, as Moneymaker did at the World Series of Poker in 2003.

title: China Beats Iran to the Punch on Nuclear Tourism
description: Iran talked about it, but China is now really doing it. Visitors to Guangdong Province in southeastern China can now add the Dayawan Nuclear Power Base to a growing list of local sights. Xinhua, the official news agency, reported that the China Guangdong Nuclear Power Holding Company has opened an exhibition hall, a lookout point, a wharf and a road at Chinas largest nuclear base by the South China Sea  all for tourists.

title: How Green Is Your Playground?
description: San Diego

title: Taliban Stepping Up Attacks in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 10  Taliban insurgents have stepped up attacks in southern Afghanistan in recent days, killing four Afghan policemen in an ambush on Friday night and aiming at NATO troops with the second suicide bombing in a week in what seems to be the opening of the fighting season, officials said Saturday.

title: Correction: Catherine Morrison, William Golden
description: A report last Sunday, about the marriage of Catherine Morrison, 72, and William T. Golden, 97, misstated the age of the bridegroom when he received his masters degree in biology from Columbia. He was 69 not 75.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Vintage International, $13.95.) In this harrowing yet exhilarating memoir, Didion writes about the year she spent coming to terms with a pair of tragedies. In December 2003, her husband, the writer John Gregory Dunne, died of a heart attack, while their only daughter, Quintana Roo, lay in a coma. (She recovered, but died in August 2005 after a series of abdominal infections.) Didion runs these events  and several decades of family life  through her mind again and again. She finds herself thinking as small children think, as if my thoughts or wishes had the power to reverse the narrative, change the outcome. In 2005, The Year of Magical Thinking won a National Book Award and was named one of the years 10 best books by the Book Review. Didions book is thrilling and engaging  sometimes quite funny  because it ventures to tell the truth, Robert Pinsky wrote here.

title: Environmental Effects of Wood-Fired Boilers; Medical Treatment at Your Supermarket (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Web of Spies
description: A few years ago, in a moment of doubt and dissatisfaction, I drove to an unloved spot on the map where Ive always found solace: the middle of Ohio. At the end of a dull highway, past cornfields and car-tire hillocks and signs proclaiming Jesus imminent arrival, I came upon an enormous covered market full of what television calls antiques and the rest of us call junk. Scattered among the several hundred stalls was a virtual taxonomy of great-grandfatherly things for sale, an ersatz museum of the years before the First World War: bent spectacles as heavy as brass knuckles; ear trumpets and obscure ointments; slumped rag dolls and cockeyed teddy bears wondering why the make-believe had stopped; broken buttons for William Jennings Bryan; dressers with names nobody will choose for their children for another century lovingly carved in the back. Everything was worthless yet beyond value; seeing it was heartbreaking and heartmaking all at once, like seeing the endless rows of graves at Arlington.

title: Here, There and Everywhere
description: I am an American consumer, and the battle to catch the corner of my eye is growing more desperate by the hour. Desperate and counterproductive, it now seems clear. We all know what happened in Boston the other week, when the guerrilla marketing of a cartoon series triggered a grand mal metro seizure, but only I know what happened in Los Angeles several days earlier. I was standing in an airport security line when I spotted an advertisement for Rolodexes printed across the bottom of the tub into which I was about to set my shoes. The ad bewildered me for a couple of reasons. First, I didnt expect to see it there (even though, by now, I should have, since researchers estimate that the average city dweller is exposed to 5,000 ads per day, up from 2,000 per day three decades ago). The second and greater mystery, however, was why a major company would want me to associate its product with the experience of being searched. Rolodex  the official corporate sponsor of airport paranoia. It didnt make sense.

title: Old-Fashioned Forensics
description: If it sometimes seems as if civilization is hurtling back into the Middle Ages, any number of medieval mysteries will obligingly corroborate your worst fears. Few historical novelists can match the literary panache and apocalyptic vision of Peter Ackroyd, whose treatment of 14th-century political intrigue in The Clerkenwell Tales transforms Chaucers Canterbury into a training camp for bomb-throwing terrorists. But even writers who work within the limits of a series manage to cover all the major paranoia points: religious superstition (P. C. Dohertys Hangmans Hymn); civil rebellion (Margaret Frazers Traitors Tale); barbaric medical practices (Philippa Morgans Chaucer and the Doctor of Physic); rotten government (Sharon Kay Penmans Prince of Darkness); a corrupt clergy (Priscilla Royals Tyrant of the Mind); and endless foreign wars (Michael Jeckss Last Templar). Not to mention plague, pestilence and appalling sanitary conditions  all of which are handled with saintly compassion in Ellis Peterss Brother Cadfael series.

title: A Town Revived, a Villain Redeemed

Even those newly arrived to the city knew enough to boo when his name came up at dinner parties. Moses (1888-1981) lived a long time, and his impact on the physical character of New York City was greater than that of any other individual in its history.

If lost to experience, the poet gets lost along with it: to feline self-regard, to the sly messaging of the in-group. The danger to an English poet is probably greater than to an American counterpart. There the apparatus of public acclaim sits, spring-loaded and ready to descend upon the promising young talent. This inevitably alters the way the promising young talent thinks and feels and writes. Maybe it is preferable, when young, to be stranded amid philistines than dandled by old toadies.

title: Erasing Slavery

But the book is also  this must be stressed  splendidly written, driven by this writers prodigious narrative gifts. She combines a novelists eye for telling detail (My appearance confirmed it: I was the proverbial outsider. Who else sported vinyl in the tropics?) with the blunt, self-aware voice (On the really bad days, I felt like a monster in a cage with a sign warning: Danger, snarling Negro. Keep away ) of those young writers who have revived the American coming-of-age story into something more engaging and empathetic than the tales of redemption or of the exemplary life well lived, patterned on Henry Adams, Benjamin Franklin and Frederick Douglass.

title: Customer Is Always Right
description: Inside out, upside down, bits and pieces. Clothes are seldom worn as shown on designer runways. The customer is the ultimate arbiter of how the collections, like those shown over the last 10 days in New York, will be worn. The large photos, top row, are of women last fall putting their own spin on Balenciagas much-heralded collection, which was shown in Paris last February (small photos). The Balenciaga designer, Nicolas Ghesquiere, insisted that magazines publish pictures just as he showed his reinterpretation of Cristobal Balenciagas designs, accessories and all; Balenciaga himself was equally insistent in the 1950s and 60s. In Diana Vreelands exhibition of the label at the Metropolitan Museum in 1973, the museum staff dressed the mannequins as Balenciaga had specified. Decades after an era of epic legal struggles, including the federal lawsuit over desegregating public housing in Yonkers, the issue has gone largely underground. Every elected official seems to agree that places like Westchester desperately need affordable housing  which is more often called workforce housing or next-generation housing these days, to avoid provoking race-based jitters in white suburban enclaves  but nobody really builds any.

Calling themselves a band rather than a chamber ensemble, the players  Todd Reynolds and Mary Rowell, violinists; Ralph Farris, violist; and Dorothy Lawson, cellist  flouted convention at every turn. They played exclusively with amplification, used choreography and theatrical lighting in their concerts and improvised segues between compositions like a D.J. fashioning a seamless flow of dance music.

title: Time-Traveling in Oxford, England
description: OXFORD'S first museum was a kind of cabinet of curiosities (elephant molar, sawfish bill and so on) known as Tradescant's Rarities, displayed in the 1630's, and later housed in the city's second museum, the Ashmolean. In the late 19th century the Pitt Rivers Museum was built, a neo-Gothic brick hall crammed  crammed in a way no other museum on earth is  with tribal treasures from around the world. There are cases of shrunken heads, canoes of every design hang from the ceiling, crowding the vaulted space, and unnumbered axes, plows, arrows, swords, pipes, staffs, tunics, paddles, shoes and all manner of witching paraphernalia occupy glass cases, drawers, cabinets and display windows. The building heaves with the collective juju of the known world, gathered by Victorians as they traveled their vast empire and beyond.

Three distinct typefaces represent the three voices  of a narrator, of Tubman and of God, who sends her guidance. When Tubman travels at night with the help of a farmer, Weatherford writes: As the wagon wobbles along, Harriet worries that it is heading to jail. Should I leap, Lord? title: Nature Girl

Following a period of depression and tired of tamed thinking, the author of Wild: An Elemental Journey leaves her home in Britain and seeks wisdom in solo passage. Her singular interest is wildness. In the Amazon, the Arctic, the Australian desert, the mountains of West Papua and on the Indonesian seas, she travels almost exclusively with indigenous people, her conduits to telluric wisdom.

The tour guide will point out blue boxes  emergency call buttons for the campus police  and extol the security systems in the residence halls. The spiel usually includes a bit about how, if a student feels uncomfortable walking alone at night on campus, he or she can simply call security for an escort.

Pause to think about it more clearly, though, and even a basic knowledge of geography or history turns up examples in almost every corner of the globe of the kinds of intercourse that turns global into globalization.

An all-American at Oklahoma, she went on to the Womens National Basketball Association, playing for the Washington Mystics and now the Chicago Sky. Dales, 27, also works for ESPN, as a college football sideline reporter and as a studio analyst and sideline reporter for mens and womens college basketball games. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

title: My Not-Even- Remotely-Funny Valentine
description: IN Margaret Atwoods story Hairball, the protagonist has just had a benign ovarian tumor removed when her married lover-boss informs her that she has been fired. When she arrives home to an engraved cocktail party invitation from him and his wife, she knows exactly how to respond. She goes to a fancy food shop and buys a box of chocolate truffles, the kind he gave her after their first tryst. She takes the tumor she has kept as a souvenir, dusts it with cocoa powder, nestles it in the elaborately wrapped box, and sends it to her lover with a note expressing her regrets.

title: Jodi Rells Startling Moves
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell has been more cautious than visionary in her two and one-half years in office. With the exception of one or two high-profile issues such as campaign finance reform and ethics reform, shes reacted to most problems by tinkering rather than calling for an overhaul.

description: A top utility official in New Brunswick, N.J., shot himself to death after learning that federal prosecutors had subpoenaed his personal and official records, the authorities said yesterday.

Thompson, or maybe Johnny Depp, an ambition palpable in his latest book, US Guys, a collection of antagonistic essays ostensibly about the looming implosion of the common man.

title: What Not to Wear
description: Theres some evidence that middle-aged heavy metal rock stars lead quiet, blameless lives, doing nothing more satanic than working on their golf and riding A.T.V.s. But things are very different for Judas Coyne, the protagonist of Joe Hills first novel. Coyne, once the guitarist and presiding genius behind a band called Judes Hammer, is a collector of macabre artifacts, including a trepanned skull, a snuff film and Aleister Crowleys childhood chessboard (not all that macabre this last one, I think). So when he has the chance to buy a haunted suit from an online auction site, how can he resist?

title: Inside the List
description: MIXED MAILER: Norman Mailers 36th book, the novel The Castle in the Forest, lands on the fiction list this week at No. 5  its his first book to appear here since The Gospel According to the Son in 1997. A bunch of Mailers books have made the Times list in hardcover, but his most successful, by far, was his first. The Naked and the Dead spent 62 weeks on the list in 1948 and 1949, 19 of those weeks at No. 1. (Second place goes to The Executioners Song, which sat on the list for 25 weeks in 1979 and 1980.) Over the decades it has been possible not only to read a lot of Mailer but to compile  though its painful to contemplate  a Norman Mailer-centric mix tape. According to his Wikipedia entry, Mailer has been name-checked in songs by John Lennon, Simon and Garfunkel, Lloyd Cole, Savage Garden, Talib Kweli, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, the Australian pop-art band TISM, Warren Zevon, GWAR, the Manic Street Preachers and 10cc.

title: 1907: Soupe  lOignon Gratine
description: For reasons of tradition, and perhaps inertia, the custom of separating sweet and savory foods  begun when meals took on a more sequential structure and sugar was considered a digestive  largely continues, especially now that sugar is viewed as anything but health-giving. There has been some cautious overlap (chocolate souffl and cheese souffl), the occasional misfortune (bacon ice cream) and even a few revelations (pineapple tartare seasoned with chili and salt), but for the most part, cooks stick to the rules. They fear that if sweets start arriving too early in a meal, they will inspire doubt rather than surprise and pleasure.

title: Crowd Pleaser
description: On May 3, 1989, I popped a VHS tape into my machine and recorded an entire game of the Chicago Bulls and Michael Jordan to save for posterity. It was an ordinary first-round playoff game against the Cleveland Cavaliers, admittedly a team Jordan often torched, but I had no idea what would happen. Jordan ended with 44 points and delivered a few signature moments  a steal and a breakaway dunk, a series of fadeaway jumpers, an end-to-end rebound, sprint and layup. In an ESPN world of quick-cut highlights where a players dunk dissolves into the next clip before he hits the ground, I wanted to preserve what snippet-sports often denies us: context. While the most sensational exploits of our athlete gods become as luminescent in public consciousness as stained glass (Julius Ervings behind-the-backboard layup, Willie Mayss over-the-shoulder catch), the proof of greatness often lies in their ability to amaze every day. Arguably, no basketball player, not even Jordan, met that test as regularly as Pete Maravich, whose between-the-legs assists and next-ZIP-code jumpers still defy belief. Too bad he played mostly pre-VCR.

title: Food for the Soul
description: As surely as any celebrity chef touting extra virgin olive oil to the masses, the novelist and poet Jim Harrison has made a vocation out of appetite. But the hungers he addresses are as much those of the spirit as the belly, not that he makes much of a distinction between the two. For Harrison, to tuck into a slab of bacon is to feed the soul. His books glisten with love of the world, and are as grounded as Thoreaus in the particulars of American place  its rivers and thickets, its highways and taverns. Bawdily and with unrelenting gusto, Harrisons 40 years worth of writing explores what constitutes a good life, both aesthetically and morally, on this planet. On the basis of that work, which now includes the authors ninth and most recent novel, the quietly magnificent Returning to Earth, we can extract what might be called Harrisons Five Rules for Zestful Living.

Medical opinion held that she had suffered brain damage during birth. The effect of her departure on her brother, born five minutes later, was separation anxiety, a terrible constellation of emotions, ranging from guilt to relief to the sense of having been betrayed by my parents.

title: The Needle and the Damage Done
description: On a warm spring day last June in Kansas City, a doctor identified only as John Doe No. 1 sat behind a screen to testify in the case of Michael Anthony Taylor v. Larry Crawford on his practice of executing prisoners by lethal injection for the State of Missouri. To protect the doctors identity, only five people were in the room  the judge, one lawyer for each side, the court reporter and John Doe No. 1. The Taylor case, which is still going on, pits a murderer against the director of the Missouri Department of Corrections. That afternoons testimony was widely considered to be the end of the legal rope for Michael Taylor, who was awaiting execution for one of Kansas Citys most notorious crimes: he had kidnapped Ann Harrison, a 15-year-old honor student and flutist, from a bus stop at 7 a.m. on March 22, 1989, raped her and stabbed her through the heart, lungs and throat. Nobody was contesting Taylors guilt or even the death penalty. On trial was the legality of the way lethal injection is being carried out, on the grounds that it violates the Eighth Amendment ban on cruel and unusual punishment. According to Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, legal challenges to lethal-injection procedures are taking place in virtually every state with an active death penalty. As a result of those cases, about 12 of the 38 states that have the death penalty have issued temporary bans on executions, and in one, New Jersey, a legislative commission recently recommended abolishing its death penalty altogether. Until these cases, contesting the constitutionality of lethal injection seemed like little more than a delaying tactic  how could a method of execution be more benign than lying on a gurney and drifting to sleep?  but little was known about how lethal-injection procedures actually worked.

title: The Wizard and the Web
description: There are hundreds, if not thousands, of Web sites around the world devoted to the Harry Potter books. Two large sites run mostly by teenagers and young adults are the self-described "No. 1 Harry Potter Fan Site," MuggleNet.com, which claims more than 15 million hits per month, and The Leaky Cauldron (www.leakynews.com). Then there's thesnitch.co.uk, www.veritaserum.com, immeritus.org and the elegant potterish.com, which, though it's entirely in Portuguese, has been praised by J. K. Rowling for its style, expertise and responsible reporting. The major Potter sites tend to have much in common: they sponsor fan writing and art contests, games and forums where aficionados can discuss the Potter movies and debate fine points of plot in the six books. Speculation about the release date of the seventh, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows," is also a popular topic: July 7, 2007, is a leading contender for obvious numerical reasons, but that date is hotly disputed, since it would step on the July 13 release of the latest movie, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix." ("Implausible," MuggleNet.com judiciously concludes, betting on late summer or fall.) The MuggleNet.com producers also run a podcast that gets around 50,000 downloads a month, and The Leaky Cauldron has its own PotterCast. In addition to the community sites, there are more encyclopedic offerings, like the Harry Potter Lexicon (www.hp-lexicon.org) and the Harry Potter Automatic News Aggregator (www.hpana.com), with more than 11,500 articles collected. Proving herself a fan of fan sites, Rowling invited Emerson Spartz of MuggleNet.com and Melissa Anelli of The Leaky Cauldron to Scotland for a rare interview the day "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" was released in 2005. As she noted on her own site (www.jkrowling.com), she did it so readers would know "I had been put on the spot by people who knew where the spot was."

title: Why Do Writers Write?
description: Last week, as I was rolling along the Florida Turnpike on the way to work, I heard Colm Toibin, the Irish novelist and short story writer, being interviewed by Diane Rehm. Toibin is the author of the award-winning novel The Master, a fictional but fact-based account of Henry Jamess life and art. Toibin was in the studio to talk about his new book of short stories, titled Mothers and Sons.Most of the stories, he said, focus on sons who have grown into manhood, but still struggle to come to terms with a childhood full of silences, rejections and abandonments, including the abandonment of death. In one story, a portion of which Toibin read aloud, a man whose mother left home long ago recognizes her as she sings a song in a pub. She seems to be looking straight at him, and he suspects that she knows who he is, but he leaves without saying anything, thus preserving their history of distance and nonconnection. Apparently, these stories are not uppers.
