title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Some Tormented by Homosexuality Look to a Controversial Therapy
description: Corey Larsen spent years hiding the feelings that drew him to other men, at first refusing to acknowledge them and then praying daily for them to be taken away.

title: After Winning One Title, Mosley Is Seeking Another
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 11  Shane Mosley is not ready for the rocking chair, the gold watch or the retirement speech just yet.

title: Monkey Fishing Author Admits to Falsehood
description: When two Columbia University graduate students in journalism began work earlier this month on an article about Jay Forman, a writer whose 2001 article in Slate about fishing for monkeys in Lois Key in Florida proved to be riddled with lies, their investigation prompted Mr. Forman to take new action. After long silence on the topic, last week he called Jack Shafer, his editor for that article, and admitted that he had fabricated the entire piece.

title: Steinbecks Suffering Okies Head West, Operatically
description: ST. PAUL. Feb. 11  The Grapes of Wrath is an epic in a peculiarly American way. Famously in John Steinbecks novel of migrant workers in the Depression, and now in an opera by Ricky Ian Gordon and Michael Korie, its knights and ladies are poor people of little natural distinction, ennobled by the desperation of their lives. Their shining ambition is to survive, although a lot of them dont.

title: Bronx: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting
description: A Bronx man was shot to death yesterday, and another Bronx man was later arrested and charged with killing him, the police said. During a dispute in an apartment on Parkchester Road around 3:30 a.m., the victim, Georgie R. Lopez, 26, of Metropolitan Avenue, was shot in the chest with a 9-millimeter pistol, the police said. The suspect, David Leak, 27, was arrested after he sought treatment at Jacobi Medical Center for a stab wound to his hand, and he was charged with murder and manslaughter, the police said. According to the police, Mr. Leak lives in the apartment where Mr. Lopez was shot.

title: French Contender Makes Her Presidential Case
description: PARIS, Feb. 11  Frances Socialist presidential candidate, Sgolne Royal, presented her long-awaited presidential program in a two-hour speech on Sunday, hoping to dispel criticism that she is a pretty face without fundamental policies and to reverse a slide in opinion polls.

title: U.S. Troops Enter Eastern Baghdad as New Push Begins
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 11  American troops locked down a large industrial area of eastern Baghdad on Sunday while Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, without indicating how he would do it, vowed to speed the deployment of Iraqi forces throughout the war-ravaged capital.

title: Protest Vigil Begins at Church Set to Be Closed by Archdiocese
description: A score of parishioners began a protest vigil inside a 120-year-old Roman Catholic church in East Harlem yesterday and vowed to stay until the Archdiocese of New York reverses its decision to close the parish as part of a broad reorganization.

title: Irans President Dismisses U.S. Charges on Iraq
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 12  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Monday dismissed American accusations that Iran was arming Shiite militants in Iraq, saying Iran was opposed to any kind of conflict in Iraq.

title: Security Measures in Italy Leave Fans With Empty Feeling
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 11  Like its host city, the Artemio Franchi Stadium in Florence is one of the most storied in Italy, known for its intimacy and architecture. But on Sunday, it more closely resembled one of the citys famous museums.

title: A Celebration With a Soft Spot for the Oldies
description: How the Grammy Awards love the oldies. A random viewer tuning in to the awards broadcast on Sunday night might have had a long wait for music from the year being judged  October 2005 through September 2006  as songs from the past claimed the airtime.

title: A Deadline May Be Extended for Claims in Holocaust Case
description: Survivors of the Holocaust and their relatives, who have been fighting to compel European insurance companies to pay death benefits for victims of the Nazis, are getting a break from a big Italian insurance company, lawyers for the insurer and policyholders said yesterday.

title: Stricter Road Rules May Empty Irelands Pubs
description: AVOCA, Ireland  Peter Moore used to have no difficulty attracting regular customers from the isolated homes and small farms that dot the Vale of Avoca for an evening drink at his traditional pub, The Meetings, at the confluence of two rivers in County Wicklow, in an area famed in verse for its restful beauty.

title: Passing the Buck on Health Care
description: President Bushs new budget would extend the administrations warped priorities deep into the realm of federally supported health care programs. The administration long ago sacrificed any meaningful domestic agenda to finance tax cuts for the wealthy and its reckless war in Iraq. The White Houses reckless determination to make the tax cuts permanent is now driving it to slash domestic spending in health and other vital programs.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Cheney Testimony in Libby Trial Would Carry High Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  One figure has dominated the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. without even showing up in the courtroom. Day after day, the jury has heard accounts of the actions of Vice President Dick Cheney, watched as his handwritten notes were displayed on a giant screen, heard how he directed leaks to the news media and ordered the White House to publicly defend Mr. Libby, his top aide and close confidante.

title: Rules Prompt Have-Nots to Say Theyve Had Enough
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 11  Senegal was not expected to win medals at the 2007 Alpine skiing world championships, but its skier was definitely supposed to participate.

title: Disaffection, Manifestoes and Plenty of Originality
description: Sifting through the 6,000 or so looks shown by 221 designers over the 9 days of Fashion Week feels a lot like spending too much time walking around a department store. Here and there, something cute catches your eye: an embroidered dress covered with tiny gold safety pins by Cynthia Rowley, a soft gray rabbit jacket with rep stripes from Tory Burch, even a loose little plaid tunic dress from Tommy Hilfiger. But so much of the rest looks like filler that you may as well go home empty-handed.

title: Heres the Online Line on Online Politics
description: Since there are so many blogs about blogs, perhaps it is only natural that someone would start an online political site about online politics.

title: Roger Bacon, 80, Researcher Known for Aerospace Innovation, Dies
description: Roger Bacon, a physicist and materials scientist whose enterprising studies of graphite and carbon fibers contributed to a revolution in the heat-resistant materials used in aircraft and satellites, died on Jan. 26 in Oberlin, Ohio. He was 80.

title: Star Power, Charisma and Ardor in Onegin
description: The Metropolitan Operas affecting revival of its 1997 production of Tchaikovskys  Eugene Onegin,  which opened on Friday night, is all the more impressive because it might have turned out so differently. In a risky move, the production brought major Russian artists steeped in their national operatic heritage together with two Met stars making brave forays into far-afield repertory.

title: Top-Producing Banker Resigns Abruptly at Lehman Brothers
description: The top producing banker at Lehman Brothers, George H. Young III, resigned abruptly late Friday, raising questions about the investment bank on Wall Street.

title: Gates Offers Support and Urges Action in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 12  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made an unannounced trip to Pakistan on Monday for talks with one of Americas most complicated partners. He offered strong words of support for the Pakistani government, even as he urged it to do more to halt the flow of Taliban fighters into Afghanistan.

title: Online Comeback for a Short-Lived TV Channel
description: With the introduction today of getTrio.com, the short-lived but well-loved cable television channel Trio completes its online comeback.

title: Deep Breath as Pitchers Rethink Routines
description: ENCINO, Calif., Feb. 11  A dozen of the best pitching prospects in baseball lay side by side in the dark, their eyes closed, their mouths shut, their minds open.

title: Weeks Equity Offerings
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Taming the Deficit, Together
description: WITH the new Democratic majority in Congress, President Bush finally talking about fiscal responsibility and the 2008 primary season about to begin, finding common ground between Democrats and Republicans on budget issues could not be more important. We are borrowing large sums from foreigners, leaving a legacy of debt, paying more than $1,600 per family in taxes just to cover the interest on the debt, and setting aside nothing to deal with future contingencies or investments.

title: A Flamenco Master Is His Own Ensemble
description: The breathtaking moments in Paco de Lucas sold-out concert on Saturday night came early and often. Presented by Carnegie Hall in conjunction with the World Music Institute and and the yearly Flamenco Festival, the evening showcased Mr. de Luca, the flamenco guitar legend, with as many as six other musicians in various formations. But first there was an expanse of stage and, seated at the center of it, just the headliner, intense, unsmiling and alone.

title: Russian Official Says Insurgency in Chechnya Has Been Tamed
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11  Russias defense minister said Sunday that Russia had succeeded in its latest war in Chechnya, defeating separatists and what he called their emissaries from 50 states.

title: Super Bowl Commercials Echo on the Web
description: The Super Bowl ads for Snickers were criticized for being homophobic and were quickly pulled. But they worked in one respect: Snickers.coms share of all Web visits was almost 16 times larger than it had been a week earlier, according to the traffic-measurement firm Hitwise. Budlight.com saw its share grow by 655.87 percent. (Hitwise reports Web site traffic as a proportion of all Internet activity, rather than an absolute number of visits.)

title: Nuclear Talks on North Korea Hit Roadblock
description: BEIJING, Feb. 11  Negotiations on a step-by-step deal that the Bush administration hopes will lead North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons program appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Koreas demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity before agreeing to a schedule for turning over its nuclear weapons and fuel.

title: Doctors and Drug Makers: A Move to End Cozy Ties
description: More Hippocrates, less Hunan hot sauce. Free lunches for doctors are under attack yet again.

title: City of Feel-Good Music and Feel-Bad History
description: Its the only place Ive ever been where if you listen, the sidewalks will speak to you, the artist John T. Scott says in tonights American Experience on PBS. Ah, yes, dear old Chicago. Er, wait, it must be Brooklyn. Or maybe Boston? Philadelphia? San Francisco?

title: Palestinian Protests at Holy Site Continue
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12  Protests by Muslims continued today over excavation work near a religious compound in Jerusalems Old City, despite efforts by Israeli officials to calm tensions.

title: Putin Seeks Expanded Ties With Saudis on Arab Tour
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 11  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrived Sunday night in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, for a visit intended to expand trade and military links between the nations, among the worlds largest oil producers.

title: Why Are the Pacifists So Passive?
description: BEFORE the November elections, many Democratic candidates and legal academics insisted that the Iraq war was illegal and that only Congress, not the president, had the power to manage it under the Constitution. Interestingly, now that Democrats control Capitol Hill, they are fretting that if Congress tried to cut back on funds or troop levels, it might be, well, unconstitutional. Democrats are suddenly acknowledging that the commander in chief and executive branch may be better off without their micromanagement, after all.

title: Kerrys Sterling Career (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Plan Has a Critic in Australia
description: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 11  On his first trip to Iowa as a presidential candidate, Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, found himself responding to an unexpected critic: John Howard, Australias prime minister.

title: A Neighbor Moves in With Ropes and Shackles, and Some Are Not So Pleased
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11  It is hard to imagine a city prouder of its sexuality than San Francisco, a place with an active strip club district, a union for erotic dancers and an annual parade on Folsom Street where those not wearing leather and chaps are the odd ones out.

title: With Fifth Title, Paerson Stands Alone on the Slopes
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 11  When the record books list the two medals that Lindsey Kildow of the United States has now earned at the 2007 Alpine skiing world championships, they might as well be listed as gold, because the winner of both races, Anja Paerson of Sweden, belongs in a category of her own.

title: Insurgents Stepping Up Efforts to Down U.S. Helicopters in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 11  A deputy commanding general in Iraq whose duties include aviation said Sunday that insurgents had adopted new tactics and stepped up their efforts to shoot down American helicopters, and he acknowledged that the rash of recent incidents included a previously unreported downing of a Black Hawk late last month.

title: Outlet for Rural Colleges (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: What W. B. Yeatss Second Coming Really Says About the Iraq War
description: The Brookings Institution, the prominent Washington research organization, just released a report on the Iraq war entitled Things Fall Apart. When Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, took to the House floor last year to demand that President Bush present a plan for Iraq, he called his speech The Center Cannot Hold. Blogs are full of the observation that the blood-dimmed tide is loosed in Iraq these days.

title: Vodafone Wins Control of Cellphone Giant in India
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, Feb. 12  The Vodafone Group, the British cellphone operator, has won control of one of Indias fastest-growing telecommunications companies, Hutchison Essar, with an offer that values the company at about $19 billion, the company said Monday.

title: Camden: Computer Pornography Charge
description: A man who taught seminars about whales to elementary school students was arrested last week and charged with possession of child pornography, the state police said. The man, Stuart Goldman, 63, was arrested on Friday after the state police found pornographic images on his computer, said Sgt. Stephen Jones, a spokesman. The computer was seized last March when the state police charged Mr. Goldman with having marijuana plants in his house in Barrington, Sergeant Jones said. Mr. Goldman has pleaded not guilty to the drug charges, the state police said.

title: Serious Music and Seriously Danceable Grooves
description: Zankel Hall could have used a dance floor on Friday night when Shiyani Ngcobo, a South African songwriter, made his New York City debut in a concert presented by the World Music Institute and Carnegie Hall.

title: Believing Scripture but Playing by Sciences Rules
description: Marcus R. Ross, who recently completed a doctoral degree in geosciences, is also a young earth creationist. He believes that the Bible is a literally true account of the creation of the universe.

title: Voices From the Trail
description: As the Barack Obama announcement tour swung through Iowa this weekend, potential caucus-goers began to weigh the Democratic field.

title: Timeline of Purdue Universitys Investigation
All You Need Is Love
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Biggest Buyout Ever Could Have Been Bigger
description: Is Samuel Zell the hero in the epic battle for Equity Office Properties?

title: White Knight Turns Pragmatist, and Newspapers Tremble Again
description: Gary B. Pruitt, the head of McClatchy, seems to have lost his long-held place as the darling of the industry and of Wall Street. When McClatchy bought Knight Ridder last March, Mr. Pruitt was hailed as the white knight of newspapers. Since the purchase, however, McClatchy has performed worse than most of its peers. Last week, its stock price hit a 52-week low, $37.82.

title: Vodafone Wins Control of Cellphone Giant in India
description: Vodafone, the British cellphone operator, has won control of one of Indias fastest-growing telecommunications companies, Hutchison Essar, with an offer that values the company at about $19 billion, the company said Monday. Vodafone will pay an estimated $11.1 billion for the 67 percent of Hutchison Essar that is owned by Hutchison Telecommunications International, which is controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing.

title: Upstart Video Game Publisher to Focus on Small Developers
description: Some video-game veterans plan to announce on Monday the formation of a new publisher that they hope will act as the equivalent of an independent film company for small game developers.

title: Hindalco of India Buys Aluminum Rival
description: Hindalco Industries of India, an aluminum producer, said on Sunday that it would buy a North American rival, Novelis, for $3.6 billion, another sign that cross-border deal making is heating up in India.

title: Its Alive! Meet One of Biotechs Zombies
description: Xoma, a biotechnology company founded in 1981, has never earned an operating profit or marketed a drug of its own. And in the quarter-century since its birth, Xoma has managed to burn through more than $700 million raised from investors and other pharmaceutical companies.

title: Jerusalem Suspends Part of Work at Religious Site
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12  Jerusalem Mayor Uri Lupolianski decided on Sunday night to postpone plans for the construction of a controversial new footbridge near the religious compound in the Old City of Jerusalem known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount. But earthworks and a salvage dig at the site, which have aroused Muslim ire and set off two days of disturbances in Jerusalem and some West Bank cities, will continue.

title: Hedge Fund Scrutiny With an International Flair
description: Finance ministers from the worlds leading economies put the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry on the international policy agenda on Saturday, saying they would scrutinize the sector with an eye toward encouraging more self-regulation. Representatives from the Group of 7 nations, who met in the industrial center of the host country, Germany, issued a statement saying that the practices of hedge funds, which have drawn growing concern from financial policy makers over the last few years, have become more complex and challenging in light of the industrys prominence and volatility.

title: First Offering of a Hedge Fund Is Bid Up 67% on Opening Day
description: Investors stormed the Fortress Investment Group Friday, driving its shares up 67.6 percent in the first American market offering of a hedge fund manager. The offering was eagerly anticipated because it gives a much bigger pool of investors the opportunity to share in the returns of hedge funds and private equity. Those alternative private investments are limited to the very wealthy and to large institutional investors like pension funds and university endowments.

title: BofA Cooperating in Bond Inquiry
description: Bank of America said Friday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.

title: After Acquiring Equity Office, Blackstone Begins Selling It
description: The Blackstone Group completed its $39 billion purchase of Equity Office Properties Friday and simultaneously began to dismantle its new portfolio of office buildings, the largest in the country.

title: Questions Grow About CNBC Anchors Ties to Sources
description: Whether it is providing a personalized video tribute  shot from inside the CNBC newsroom  to Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the buyout giant Blackstone Group to celebrate his 60th birthday, or mingling with a source at a benefit for the New York City Ballet, the proximity of the CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo to the people she covers has created a model of journalism that jibes perfectly with the networks mandate to add pizzazz and drama to its coverage.

title: $25 Million to Encourage Cleaner Air
description: The British billionaire Richard Branson and Al Gore, the former vice president, on Friday announced a $25 million prize to meet possibly the biggest challenge faced by humankind: to reduce the planets warming gases that have collected in the atmosphere since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution. We are now facing a planetary emergency, said Mr. Gore, the author of the book An Inconvenient Truth, which formed the basis for an Oscar-nominated documentary film about global warming.

title: Chevron Said to Be Interested in Buying Assets of Yukos of Russia
description: Chevron intends to bid for assets of Yukos, the bankrupt oil producer, Russian officials said Friday. If Chevron succeeds, such an acquisition could help close the final chapter on the downfall of Russias largest oil company.

title: Some Shareholder Grumblings Over Lear Deal
description: Carl C. Icahn may experience some turbulence as he navigates his $2.8 billion deal to buy the Lear Corporation. Several shareholders, including one of Lears biggest, criticized the deal, which the company agreed to Friday.

title: Macquaries Consortium Closing In On Qantas
description: A consortium led by Macquarie Bank came closer to clinching an $8.7 billion takeover of Qantas Airways of Australia on Monday after the airline released an independent report saying the offer was fair. The report said the offer of 5.60 Australian dollars a share was within its valuation range of 5.18-5.98 Australian dollars.

title: Australias APN Agrees to Revised Buyout
description: Australias APN News and Media on Monday agreed to a revised A$2.8 billion ($2.2 billion) offer from a consortium including Tony OReillys Independent News and Media.

title: Siemens Chief Wont Resign Over Corruption Inquiry, Report Says
description: Siemens chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld, ruled out resigning over a corruption affair at the German conglomerate. He told the Bild newspaper, in an interview to be published on Monday, that he did not even for a second consider giving up his position at Siemens.

title: Daimler Shareholder Calls for Possible Spin-Off
description: A DaimlerChrysler shareholder, DWS, has reportedly called on the carmakers management to consider a spin-off of the firms ailing Chrysler unit in the United States as it gets ready to introduce its latest restructuring plan for Chrysler.

title: Portugal Vote on Abortion Doesnt Count; More Liberal Laws May Follow Anyway
description: As Elaine Sciolino writes for The Times this morning, fewer than 50 percent of the electorate turned out for a referendum on expanding and liberalizing Portugals abortion law  among the most restrictive in Europe  but the sentiment among the 44 percent who did vote was clear: change the law, the they said.

title: Eddie Bauer Chief Resigns After Buyout Fails
description: Eddie Bauer Holdings on Friday announced the resignation of its chief executive, Fabian Mansson, one day after the retailers shareholders rejected a $286 million takeover by two private equity firms. Howard Gross, a member of the board and a former chief executive of Limited Stores and Victorias Secret Stores, was named interim chief executive.

title: J.P. Morgan Executive Eyed for Treasury Post, Report Says
description: A J.P. Morgan Chase executive may find himself working for the former boss of a rival investment bank, Goldman Sachs, as the Bush administration continues to cull appointees from the top Wall Street banks. Reuters reported that the administration is considering T. Timothy Ryan, a former top financial regulator who is vice chairman for financial institutions and governments at J.P. Morgan, to become Treasurys point person on international affairs.

description: From: Lefteri H. TsoukalasSent: Sunday, July 02, 2006 3:32 PM To: Mason, Sally K.Subject: Concern

title: Top Bankers Jump Ship as Another Stays Put
description: Lehman Brothers top-producing banker, George H. Young III, resigned abruptly late Friday, raising questions about the investment bank on Wall Street. The reason for the departure was unclear, although people close to Mr. Young said it was the result of a long dispute with senior management over the strategic direction of the firm, The New York Times reported. Separately, there were reports Monday that Bob Maguire, co-head of Morgan Stanleys energy investment banking team, plans to leave the investment bank after more than 20 years there. And Financial News said that George Boutros, a top technology banker at Credit Suisse, has signed a contract that will keep him at the firm for another year.

title: Soros Said to Be Eyeing Nanette Lepore
description: Nanette Lepore is the latest designer to attract the attention of private equity firms, according to The New York Post, which reported that several investment funds, including Soros Private Equity Partners, are circling the designers company, known for pretty, girlish clothes.

title: Apollo Hands Over GNC
description: GNC, the leading retailer of vitamins and nutrition products, agreed to be acquired by Ares Management and the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan in a deal with a total enterprise value of $1.65 billion. In a statement on Friday, Ares and Ontario said Apollo Management, which owns about 97 percent of GNCs common stock and controls all of the voting rights, approved the transaction.

title: Prosecutors Eye Pixar Options, Report Says
description: Apples chairman and chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, whose companys stock-options practices are already the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation, agreed to a large stock-options grant to a key filmmaker at his Pixar Animation Studios in 2001 as well, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: N.Y.S.E. Is Winner in Nasdaqs Failed L.S.E. Bid
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market faces the task of rebuilding its foreign expansion strategy after the emphatic rejection this weekend of its second unwelcome bid to acquire the London Stock Exchange.

title: Should You Buy When Private Equity Sells?
description: Private equity firms seem to be snapping up everything in sight  but theyre also selling stakes in many of the companies they have acquired.

title: Tribune Plans to Shun Outside Bids, Report Says
description: More than four months after Tribune put itself on the auction block, the newspaper and television business is leaning away from accepting any outside offers, favoring a self-help plan instead, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Timberland Said to Call Off Auction
description: Timberland ended an effort to sell itself after bids from major strategic and financial buyers fell short of expectations, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. In November it was reported that the footwear company had hired Goldman Sachs to seek out potential buyers.

title: Whats in a Name? Controversy
description: Under ordinary circumstances, the opening of "The Hoohaa Monologues" on Thursday at the Atlantic Theaters in Atlantic Beach, Fla., near Jacksonville, would not attract much attention. But "The Hoohaa Monologues" by any other name is Eve Ensler's Obie Award-winning, internationally performed play, "The Vagina Monologues."

description: From: "Mason, Sally K."To:Date: Sun, 9 Jul 2006 14:58:31 -0400Subject: RE: Concern

title: Blackstone to Buy Pinnacle Foods for $2.16 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group will acquire the Pinnacle Foods Group, whose brands include Duncan Hines baking mix, Mrs. Buttersworths maple syrup and Swanson frozen dinners, for $2.16 billion in cash, the two companies announced Monday. Pinnacles current owners include the private equity arm of J.P. Morgan Chase and the buyout firm J.W. Childs Associates.

title: War at Home: In the Peoples House
description: One difference between the House and Senate will be made crystal clear this week: when the House majority wants to vote on something, it will vote on something.

title: Four Seasons Agrees to $3.8 Billion Buyout
description: Four Seasons Hotels, the luxury hotelier, said it agreed Monday to be acquired by a group including its chairman and controlling shareholder, Isadore Sharp; Prince Alwaleed bin Talal; and an investment firm owned by Microsofts Bill Gates. The deal, first proposed in November, offers $82 in cash per share, valuing the company at $3.8 billion including debt.

title: London, Milan, Paris: Displaced Persons
description: On the subject of the New York collections, I feel, at this stage, like Mr. Creosote of Monty Python facing one more chocolate. I am full, man.

title: Eberts Mannered Discretion
description: Roger Ebert is a very influential guy when it comes to the Oscars  he campaigned long and hard for Crash last year, while the Bagger just made a lucky guess at the end. Mr. Ebert, who is fighting some health stuff, still has plenty o mustard on his fastball when it comes to his picks.

title: Others Hiding in Plain Sight
description: When the Bagger went on his rant about The Painted Veil hiding in plain sight, readers went bonkers, or at least semi-bonkers. Casey Common wrote to say that he had very similar feeling for Sweetland, a movie set in the Baggers homeland of Minnesota. Check out his argument on behalf of this turn-of-the-century prairie romance.

title: Talking About Your First
description: The Bagger is fashion illiterate and doesnt go for glam shots, but if youll forgive a little link-rolling, his corporate brothers and sisters at The New York Times magazine came up with a pretty amazing set of portraits of this years the Oscar contenders, including some nicely thrown curve balls. Cooler still is a film by Jake Paltrow  hes related to some actress, but the Bagger cant think of which one off the top of his head  that consists of great talents talking about what they watched on screen before they began to live there. Who knew Cate Blanchett was a horror freak?

title: Credit Check
description: The Baggers day job drifts into Oscarland and what is an increasingly robust discussion over credits. Time to call in the deprogrammers.

title: Apocalyptos Biggest Fan
description: The WGA Awards reception was hopping. Unlike past years where the show was a stuffy affair with a sit-down dinner at a ritzy hotel, this year the celebrities  mainly television people and therefore b-list  did their photo ops and then mingled with the crowds.

title: The Best Picture Picture Remains Fuzzy
description: There was a lot to stare at yesterday. The BAFTAs, the Writers Guild, the animation awards, the Grammys. Well, O.K., the Grammys didnt have much to do with anything, unless the Dixie Chickss big night means that awards voters this year are interested in political themes, which would lead somewhat circuitously to Babel as the most politically relevant of the best picture nominees. Aw, never mind.

title: Vilsack on Iraq: Nows the Time
description: Former Iowa Gov. Tom Vilsack  one of those Democratic presidential candidates not named Clinton, Edwards or Obama  writes an op-ed in The Washington Post that calls for an immediate U.S. withdrawal from the most violent areas of Iraq. A modest number of peacekeeping troops would temporarily remain in northern Iraq, protect civilians against sectarian violence, discourage Iran from border incursions and help maintain regional stability  without recklessly endangering American lives, Vilsack writes. He adds, Not in 2008 or 2009, but now.

title: An Emotional Fight
Bombing at Baghdad's Largest Market
description: The attacks came on the anniversary of the 2006 bombing at the Golden Dome shrine in Samarra.

title: Coming Out of Your (Thin Candy) Shell
description: Editors Note: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Feb. 20, rather than Mon., Feb. 19, in observance of the Presidents Day holiday.

title: Spitzers Ace?
description: The Senate minority leader, Malcolm Smith, a Queens Democrat, is the only one of the four legislative leaders who has not had a blowup  or at least not one The Empire Zone knows about  with Mr. Spitzer.

title: Brother, Would You Take a Dollar Coin  Please?
description: Maybe three is a charm. On Thursday, the dollar coin will see its third iteration in a generation go into circulation. These will feature United States presidents  four issued per year, from now through 2016, from Washington to Nixon (yes, Nixon).

title: Staying the Course in [Your War Here]
SXR Uranium to Acquire UrAsia for $3.1 Billion
description: SXR Uranium One, South Africas largest uranium miner, will buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion, forming the worlds second-largest uranium producer as surging demand propels prices. SXR offered 7.05 Canadian dollars ($6.01) a share in stock for UrAsia, a 13 percent premium over the companys closing price on Friday.

Talk to the Newsroom:
Style Editor Trip Gabriel
description: Trip Gabriel, The Times's style editor, answered questions from readers in February 2007. Following are the questions and his answers.

title: 2008: Identity Crises and Claiming Abe
description: The Washington Post published a scathing look at Senator John McCains efforts to reform the campaign finance process while at the same relying on some top donors of soft money. John Solomon writes:

title: A Sore Loser
description: One more tidbit from our weekly Albany notebook:

title: The Bottom Line Uptown
description: A couple of weeks ago, after dinner at a Creole/Cajun restaurant in Harlem called Baton Rouge, the waitress tried to steer my table of four away from the bananas Foster on the dessert menu.

title: A Change for Diners Journal
description: About a year into its existence, Diners Journal is making a change. Its a change that will bring you a wider variety of observations, more perspectives, more tidbits.

title: Fittings Maker Hires Perella Weinberg to Explore Sale
description: After recruiting a collection of well-known dealmakers, fledgling investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners is putting them to work. (A few of them, anyway.) The firm has been hired by Lamson & Sessions, which makes pipes, wiring-outlet cases and other plastic fittings, to explore strategic options including a sale or all or part of the company, Lamson said in a press release Monday. Ramius Capital Group, a major shareholder in the company, has been pressuring it to sell its polyvinyl chloride pipes unit. Shares of Lamson & Sessions rose 6 percent to $28.44 Monday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $450 million.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AKQA, San Francisco, an independent digital agency, sold a majority stake to General Atlantic, Greenwich, Conn., an equity firm, for an estimated $150 million to $250 million. The proceeds will be used to pay off owners that include Accenture and Francisco Partners.

title: Schumer to Fight Starrett Deal
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer is holding a news conference in Brooklyn right at which he was expected to vow to fight the planned sale of Starrett City, the huge Brooklyn apartment complex. Mr. Schumer wrote some of the legislation that granted federal housing subsidies to the complex, and he says the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which must approve a new owner, is skeptical of the plan to sell it to a partnership led by David Bistricer.

title: Prepping for a Run From the Hospital Bed
description: When Senator Tim Johnson was rushed to the hospital for emergency brain surgery in December, Washington swelled with speculation about what would happen to the new 51-49 Democratic majority in the Senate if he had to resign. That possibility seems increasingly less likely as the South Dakota Democrat recovers, and his colleagues are even pitching in to help him run for re-election in 2008.

title: The Great Debate
description: After weeks of talking about buying the lot in Anna Maria, it was clear that my wife and I were in the exact same position as when we started.Alison was for buying the land.

title: WCI Considers Sale After Hearing From Icahn
description: Coincidence? We think not. Only a few weeks after billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn took a 14.6 percent stake in WCI Communities and said he planned to have a talk with the homebuilders management about ways to unlock the inherent value of the shares, WCI announced that it hired Goldman Sachs to review its business plans with the objective of enhancing the companys value for all of its shareholders. Among the actions being considered are share buybacks or a sale of the company, WCI chief executive Jerry Starkey said in a press release Monday (which made no mention of Mr. Icahn).

title: Johnson & Johnson Statement on Voluntary Disclosure
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/  Johnson & Johnson today voluntarily disclosed to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that subsidiaries outside the United States are believed to have made improper payments in connection with the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The actions were contrary to the Company's policies, and the payments may fall within the jurisdiction of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Company will provide additional information to DOJ and SEC, and will cooperate with the agencies' reviews of these matters.

title: Spitzer Strikes Again
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer continued his attacks on Democratic legislators this morning. His latest target: Assemblyman George S. Latimer of Westchester County.

title: The Iraq Resolution, Hot Off the Press
description: The language of the Iraq war resolution to be considered in the House this week has just been crafted and will be circulated shortly to lawmakers across Capitol Hill. The debate, of course, will not be brief, but the text of the resolution is.

title: A Day at the Dog Show
description: On the first day of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Harry, a Dandie Dinmont terrier who won 56 best-in-shows in 2006, had no competition. Literally.

title: Many Investors Fume Over Hedge-Fund Rule
description: As regulators prepare to upgrade the definition of rich  ostensibly to protect the public from getting burned by hedge funds  many members of the public are sounding none too pleased. Fortune magazines Bethany McLean has collected a selection of comments sent to the S.E.C. regarding its proposal to raise the minimum level of wealth required for anyone to invest in hedge funds.

title: Tell Your Boss: A Nap Could Save Money on Health Care
description: Its just after the noon hour and it seems that some of you are still  awake. You need to take a nap!!

title: Bristol Shares Fall After Report That Deal Talks Ended
description: Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb declined as much as 4 percent Monday after the Times of London reported over the weekend that its talks to merge with Sanofi Aventis, a deal that would form the worlds No. 2 drugmaker, had been called off. The newspaper said the discussions  reported late last month but never acknowledged by either side  faltered because of disagreements about price and the legal uncertainty surrounding Bristol Myers top-selling drug, Plavix. A UBS analyst called the report surprising and said in a research note that Bristol-Myers was probably still in play.

title: Is It Time to Bail Out of REITs or Buy Them?
description: Investors in real-estate assets seem to be sending mixed signals these days. Even as Blackstone Group is paying the highest price ever for a property owner, Deutsche Bank Private Wealth Management and MFS Investment Management are selling off shares of U.S. real-estate investment trusts, Bloomberg News reports. At the same time, TheStreet.com reports that Morgan Stanley is raising $8 billion for a fund that would acquire real estate assets around the world.

title: Brunos Lesson in Governing
description: So Senator Joseph L. Bruno  the Republican majority leader that the Spitzer camp would like to see, sooner rather than later, as minority leader  was just asked if Governor Spitzer will be able to get anything done now thats hes at war with the Legislature.

title: Tenaris to Buy Maker of Oil-Drilling Gear
description: Making its second large deal in the United States in a year, Luxembourg-based Tenaris said Monday it agreed to buy Hydril, which supplies connections and pressure control products for oil and gas drilling, for about $2.2 billion. Tenaris, a pipe manufacturer that has recently been the subject of takeover speculation, said it would pay $97 per share for Hydril, of Houston. In June 2006, Tenaris said it would buy Maverick Tube of Missouri for $2.8 billion.

title: Kraft Could Be Hungry for Deals, Analyst Says
description: Quitting smoking can bring on a ravenous appetite. Will that be the experience for Kraft Foods, which was recently spun off from cigarette maker Altria?

title: Notes On Update 0.1.0.5
description: So let me take a guess at what youre thinking. Hey! Whats the big idea? First, Times Reader tells me I cant read my news until I download and install the Times Reader update. And then when I download and run the update Im told I have to update my version of .Net 3.0! Do you think I can just sit around all day installing updates? Im a very busy person!

title: BMO Adds Senior Bankers in U.S.
description: Moving to bolster its deal-advisory offerings in the United States, Canadas BMO Capital Markets said it hired a head of U.S. mergers and acquisitions in its Chicago office and a head of energy investment banking in Houston. Both bankers were previously at Deutsche Bank, BMO said.

title: Pulling Out of Iraq
description: Your comments on my Tuesday column about pulling out of Iraq are most welcome. Just hit the comment button below.

title: "Inner M"
description: An ad for M&M's.

title: Lagerfeld on Film
description: Designer Karl Lagerfeld discusses his photographic work in an interview with Fly, a compilation of music videos, interviews and fashion films.

title: Home Depot Considers Sale of Contractor-Supply Unit
description: Home Depot said Monday that it had hired Lehman Brothers to consider a sale or spinoff of its contractor-supply business, a move that would undo an ambitious and expensive diversification strategy advocated by its recently ousted chief executive, Robert Nardelli.

title: Home Depot
description: An ad from Home Depot's campaign.

title: Home Depot
description: An ad from Home Depot's campaign.

title: The Short, Sad History of Chads Model Oil Project
description: Whenever I receive e-mail from people I met while traveling in Chad, I worry. I visited the deeply poor central African country in 2003, just after it became the worlds newest oil exporter. Back then, kids in the streets told me oil was a blessing, and women wore new dresses reading (in French) Chad, Our economy is petroleum. Chads oil project was the product of a innovative collaboration between the World Bank, Exxon Mobil and the Chadian government, and the hope was that oil money would bring stability and prosperity.

title: Blogtalk
description: Details from Eliot Spitzers unusual  and forceful  meetings with rank-and-file legislators. Plus: Senator Johnson takes a chair, though not his own. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Primary Objections
description: It seems as if nearly every day, another state is weighing or musing whether to move up its presidential primary or caucus. (The weekend brought three: Alabama, New York and Nebraskas Democrats.)

title: Human Origins on Display
description: A tour of the new Hall of Human Origins at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.

title: 2008: Different Flight Paths
description: Its about 1,100 miles from Des Moines to Manchester, N.H., with no direct flights except by private jet. And thanks to new Congressional ethics rules, the trip may feel much longer to some presidential candidates than to others.

title: Greenland Redux
description: Ah, nothing like global warming to stimulate a nice cool-headed exchange of views. Let me first address a recurring question from commenters on my post on the slowdown of melting in Greenland: No, Exxon Mobil did not pay me anything for it. And for the record, the above pictures of a glacier  one of the two in the Greenland report I described came to me not from an oil company but from the Ian Howat, the lead author of the paper in the new Science.

title: Edwards Blogger Quits
description: Amanda Marcotte, the blogger whose hiring by John Edwards came under fire last week from the Catholic League, a conservative organization, announced on her blog today that she was quitting Mr. Edwardss presidential campaign. Ms. Marcotte said that Bill Donohue, the head of the Catholic group, had created a situation where I felt that every time I coughed, I was risking the Edwards campaign.

title: The TierneyLab $0.00 Earth Challenge
description: Unlike Richard Branson, I cant offer you $25 million for saving humanity from global warming. But think of the fame, the sheer glory, of posting your plan for the Labs readers.

title: FuturePhone is Now in the Past
description: Lots of you have been writing to me, asking whatever happened to FuturePhone.

title: Littering the Stage With Bodies
description: Timothy Haskell is one of the great hustlers of downtown theater. Using a mix of salesmanship and gimmickry that would have impressed David Merrick, Mr. Haskell, a publicist, director and sometimes ticket-taker, has turned his unapologetic love of trashy pop culture into his own cult oeuvre.

title: Labeling: Pictures Trump Text on Cigarette Warnings
description: Do health warnings on cigarette packages really work? Yes, but only if they are prominent, include graphics and have recently been updated, an international survey has found.

title: A Familiar and Prescient Voice, Brought to Life
description: Correction Appended

title: Trenton: Petition on Same-Sex Marriage
description: Opponents of same-sex marriages in New Jersey said yesterday that they were organizing a petition drive calling for a referendum on whether marriage should be legally defined as a union between a man and a woman. The organizers of the drive, led by John Tomicki of the New Jersey Coalition to Preserve and Protect Marriage, conceded that their effort would have no effect on civil union legislation that takes effect in the state next week. Nevertheless, Mr. Tomicki said he hoped that the drive would prompt lawmakers to consider changing the New Jersey Constitution to formalize the definition of marriage and prevent civil union laws from being amended to become same-sex marriage legislation.

title: Two Markets Bombed in Central Baghdad, Killing at Least 67 and Wounding 155
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 12  Four back-to-back explosions at two markets in central Baghdad killed at least 67 people and wounded 155 on Monday, charring drivers in their cars, shredding stores and setting ablaze a seven-story building full of clothing stores that burned for more than six hours, witnesses and officials said.

title: Iran and the Nameless Briefers
description: Before things get any more out of hand, President Bush needs to make his intentions toward Iran clear. And Congress needs to make it clear that this time it will be neither tricked nor bullied into supporting another disastrous war.

title: Spikes in the Freezer
description: Q. Why do spikes only sometimes grow from ice cubes?

title: Whats on Tuesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (USA) 131ST WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOW How do I look? More than 2,600 dogs representing 165 recognized breeds compete for best in show in this, the second-longest continuously held sporting event in the United States. (The first is the Kentucky Derby.) Day 2 of the competition, broadcast from Madison Square Garden, includes the judging of the sporting, hound and herding breeds, with the top dog chosen at the end of the evening. Lester Holt, David Frei and Dr. Debbye Turner are commentators. Dr. Robert A. Indeglia, a cardiac surgeon and longtime participant in the world of purebred dogs, will judge the heart-stopping best-in-show category.

title: Chargers Fire Schottenheimer
description: Marty Schottenheimer was fired yesterday as coach of the San Diego Chargers, the latest blow to the team that finished with the best regular-season record (14-2) in the N.F.L. last season.

title: In Shift, Accord on North Korea Seems to Be Set
description: BEIJING, Tuesday, Feb. 13  The United States and four other nations reached a tentative agreement to provide North Korea with roughly $400 million in fuel oil and aid, in return for the Norths starting to disable its nuclear facilities and allowing nuclear inspectors back into the country, according to American officials who have reviewed the proposed text.

title: The Hearth Beckons, So a Coach Stays On, With No Regrets
description: A lieutenant general asked Dave Magarity to stay, but he based his decision more on devotion to coaching than allegiance to country.

title: Inflation in Japan Rises at a Slower Pace
description: Japans producer prices rose at the slowest pace in more than a year in January as oil costs fell, easing pressure on companies to pass expenses on to consumers.

title: Eddie Feigner, Hard-Throwing, Barnstorming Showman of Softball, Dies at 81
description: Eddie Feigner, who for 60 years barnstormed the globe with his four-man softball team, hurling 100-mile-an-hour pitches that struck out Willie Mays and 141,516 other batters, died on Friday in Huntsville, Ala. He was 81.

title: Vaquita Porpoise, and a Way of Life, Face Extinction
description: GOLFO DE SANTA CLARA, Mexico  The fishermen gathered in the early evening light where the desert meets the blue gulf to talk over the way they had always lived off the sea and the fate of a small, endangered porpoise few of them had ever seen.

title: Judy Collins: Wildflower on the Path to Serenity
description: Coming through storms: thats how the singer Judy Collins describes the basic narrative of her original songs.

title: Charles Walgreen Jr., 100, Who Built the Family Drug Chain, Is Dead
description: Charles Walgreen Jr., who helped build his fathers drugstore chain into Americas biggest, died Saturday at his home in Northfield, Ill. He was 100.

title: N.A.I.A.s Future Looms Large for Division III
description: One issue spurring leaders in Division III of the N.C.A.A. to lobby for a realignment is the belief that the membership could expand to almost 600 from 420 in as little as 10 years.

title: East Meadow, N.Y.: Vendor Bans Trans Fats
description: The food vendor for Nassau County parks, golf courses and pools announced yesterday that it had banned trans fats from its menu. Its the right thing to do, said the vendor, Butch Yamali, owner of Dover Caterers, at a news conference at Nassaus Aquatic Center in East Meadow yesterday. The chairman of the County Legislatures health committee, Jeffrey W. Toback, praised the move and said he preferred voluntary action to a mandatory law. A spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association, Bonnie Taub-Dix, predicted, This is going to have a domino effect.

title: Weeks After a Death, Twists in Some 9/11 Details
description: For days, a New York City police officer, Cesar A. Borja, who died of lung disease last month, was held up as a symbol of the medical crisis affecting the thousands of emergency personnel and construction workers who labored on the smoking remains of the fallen World Trade Center after the 9/11 attack.

title: Next Obstacle for Vodafone in Indian Deal Is Maintaining Discipline
description: MUMBAI, India, Feb. 12  A day after Vodafone, the British telecommunications company, agreed to pay $11.1 billion to acquire control of Hutchison Essar, a fast-growing Indian cellphone operator, analysts began questioning whether the British management can impose the cost discipline that is second nature to Indians and the companies they run.

title: West Adds to Strains on Irans Lifeline
description: Western political and economic pressure on Iran over its nuclear program has chilled foreign investment to the extent that it is now squeezing the countrys long-fragile energy industry, adding strains to a government that is burdened by sanctions and wary of unrest at home.

title: Poland: Privatization Plan for Exchange
description: The Polish government is preparing a plan to privatize the Warsaw Stock Exchange by selling shares exclusively to Polish companies, possibly in defiance of European Union rules that require equal treatment for all members of the bloc. In a little-noticed speech filled with patriotic themes, the treasury minister, Wojciech Jasinski, outlined a strategy last month to sell 49 percent of the governments holdings to Polish investors in blocks of 5 percent to 10 percent. The government also intends to introduce rules to prevent companies listed on the exchange from being taken over by foreign companies to ensure that the exchange retains its Polish character, Mr. Jasinski said. The plan appears ripe for a conflict with European Union rules, which require privatizations to be open to all union members. Catherine Bunyan, a spokeswoman for Charlie McCreevy, the union commissioner for the internal market, said Brussels was not aware of Warsaws plans.

title: Responses: Using the Nose to Change Hormone Levels
description: Smelling a compound in mens sweat called androstadienone raises levels of the hormone cortisol in heterosexual women, a small study has found, suggesting for the first time that human pheromones might be useful in clinical medicine.

title: Taiwan Opposition Leader Faces Corruption Charges
description: BEIJING, Feb. 13  Corruption charges were filed today against Ma Ying-jeou, the leader of Taiwans main opposition party who has been seen as a leading presidential candidate in 2008. The countrys high court prosecutor announced the charges.

title: In Doctors War, Battles Are Fought in Maternity Ward
description: Who knows where Americans are getting their news this week, but continuing education increasingly seems to come from television documentaries. You know, documentaries: those high-minded, rule-bound and often densely ideological single-subject nonfiction specials that now appear on virtually every channel, on topics ranging from rich people to evangelicals to fast food.

title: Grammy Sweep by Dixie Chicks Is Seen as a Vindication
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12  The Dixie Chicks big win at the Grammy Awards on Sunday exposed ideological tensions between the music industrys Nashville establishment and the broader, more diverse membership of the Recording Academy, which chooses the Grammy winners, according to voters and music executives interviewed afterward.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Police Go Touring

title: Small and Plastic, With an Upscale Tilt
description: IN a new advertising campaign, Visa USA  whose name is almost synonymous with convenient credit  is hoping to remind certain consumers that it can also be a little more exclusive.

title: European Officials Agree to Widen Economic Sanctions Against Iran Over Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  European negotiators, yielding to pressure from the United States, have agreed to widen a ban on financial transactions with Iran and the export of materials and technology that Iran could use to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Hard to Tell What Causes Fatal Disease of the Lungs
description: Pulmonary fibrosis, the chronic lung disease that doctors believe killed Officer Cesar A. Borja, is a rare and deadly disorder whose causes are poorly understood.

title: Doppler Radar? No, Carol Yerdon Uses a Yardstick Out Back
description: REDFIELD, N.Y., Feb. 12  Carol Yerdon has no doubt that the snowstorm that hit Oswego County was a big one.

title: Queens: Tool in Domestic Violence Cases
description: Councilman Eric N. Gioia of Queens proposed yesterday that the city buy more than 1,500 digital cameras for the police to use in domestic violence cases. Each of the citys 76 police station houses now has about two cameras available to photograph victims of domestic violence, he said. The initiative would equip every patrol car with a camera. Kevin Ryan, a spokesman for the Queens district attorney, said that since a pilot program began there in 2001, the boroughs rate of conviction for domestic violence had increased about 20 percent.

title: Cupid Takes to the Road, Too
description: Michael Zane and Liz Fritz had met up from time to time for four years at bicycle industry trade shows, though there had never been any romantic sparks. He is the founder of the company that makes Kryptonite bike locks; she was an apparel director at Rodale Press.

title: Letters
description: Correction Appended

title: Armed Man Kills 5 People at Utah Mall
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 12  Five people were killed and several others were injured in a Salt Lake City mall Monday night when a gunman went on a shooting rampage that ended when the police fatally shot him, the authorities said.

title: Childbirth: Cutting Caffeine Not Found to Affect Birth Weight
description: Reducing caffeine consumption during pregnancy from three cups of coffee a day to one has no effect on the babys birth weight, Danish researchers report.

title: Pressing to Look Closer at Blood Clots and the Pill
description: At every exit sign that whizzed past, Kathleen Biggins wondered if she should turn off the Saw Mill River Parkway and call for help.

title: Martial Law Declared in Guinea
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 12  Guineas embattled and ailing president declared martial law on Monday, hoping to stop a wave of violent street demonstrations and a general strike that have crippled the country and brought it to the brink of insurrection.

title: House Democrats Unveil Measure Denouncing Iraq Buildup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Democrats unveiled a resolution on Monday that would formally express the Houses disapproval of President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq, beginning an intense debate and political struggle that is to end in a vote on Friday.

title: Terror Attack Takes Aim at Civilians in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 13  A day before Lebanon prepared to mark the second anniversary of the assassination of its former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, three people were killed Tuesday and 19 others seriously wounded when two buses were bombed as they ferried passengers to work, to shop and to bible study classes.

title: Yum Brands Reports Profit and Sales Rose
description: Yum Brands, operator of the Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC chains, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose, helped by increased sales in China, its fastest-growing market.

title: Some Work Delayed Near Jerusalem Holy Site
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12  Jerusalems mayor late Sunday postponed plans for construction work near a religious compound in Jerusalems Old City, but Muslim protests continued Monday over preparatory work at the site.

title: Building a Conversation, One Radio Show at a Time
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 11  At a gathering here Saturday of roughly 10,000 people who came for a conversation concerning the problems confronting blacks, Tom Joyner, the conference co-host, told the audience he had been ready to be angry as he took a tour about the Jamestown settlement nearby and thought of slave ships. What he experienced instead, he said, was not anger but something akin to his feelings about mainstream media coverage of blacks: a story certainly not from a black perspective.

title: Archaeologists Find Signs of Early Chimps Tool Use
description: In the rain forest of the Ivory Coast 4,300 years ago, chimpanzees gathered in groups and cracked nuts the best they could, the Stone Age way. Place the nut on a hard, flat rock. Take a heavy hammer rock, and pound the nut. The chimps must have feasted well and often there under the trees by a black-water river.

title: The Claim: Starve a Cold, Feed a Fever
description: THE FACTS Its one of the most well-known medical bromides around: starve a cold, feed a fever. Or is it feed a cold, starve a fever?

title: On Tour to Talk Up Budget Plan, Spitzer Stays on Attack
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Feb. 12  Gov. Eliot Spitzer stepped up his attacks on fellow Democrats on Monday, suggesting that he may support an opposing candidate if one ran against a local assemblyman here.

title: A Glimpse Back at the Latest in Medical Care
description: A WEATHERED container, bigger than a shoebox and made of three layers of copper, was sawed open from the top. Inside was a rusty glass hypodermic syringe, a pair of forceps, a vial of diphtheria medicine, yellowing newspapers and pamphlets.

title: One Year Later, Golden Mosque Is Still in Ruins
description: SAMARRA, Iraq, Feb. 11  It has been a year since Sunni insurgents ripped a hole in the glorious dome here of one of Iraqs most sacred Shiite shrines, shattering its 72,000 golden tiles and unleashing a tide of national sectarian bloodletting. Not a single brick of the mosque has been moved since.

title: After Vigil to Protest Church Closing, Six Women Are Arrested
description: Six women were led away in handcuffs from an East Harlem church by the police last night, hours after protesting parishioners declared that they would not leave until the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York dropped plans to close it.

title: Bloomfield, N.J.: Car Windows Smashed
description: Vandals broke windows on 17 cars in Bloomfield on Sunday night, causing roughly $10,000 in damage, the authorities said yesterday. Residents began to report the damage just before 11 p.m., and the police said they believed that the spree lasted about 30 minutes. Few details were offered, but the police said they thought the vandals were driving two cars, a red Lincoln and a blue Mitsubishi.

title: Exercise: Working Out May Help Flu Vaccine Do Its Job
description: Mild exercise before having a flu shot may make the vaccine more effective, British researchers have found.

title: In Pakistan, U.S. Defense Secretary Seeks Support to Counter Taliban
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 12  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made an unannounced trip to Pakistan on Monday for talks with one of Americas most complicated partners. He offered strong words of support for the government, even as he urged it to do more to halt the flow of Taliban fighters into Afghanistan.

title: A New School Plans to Teach Half of Classes Using Arabic
description: The New York City school system will open its first public school dedicated to teaching the Arabic language and culture in September, with half of its classes eventually taught in Arabic, officials said yesterday.

title: Jeannette Ordman, Director of Israeli Dance Company, Is Dead
description: Jeannette Ordman, a South African-born dancer and teacher who headed the Bat-Dor Dance Company, one of Israels most important contemporary-dance organizations, died on Wednesday in Tel Aviv.

title: Iraqis Show Us the Door
description: For those like myself who oppose the surge in Iraq and seek a timetable for withdrawal, the hard question is: what happens if all hell breaks loose?

title: Patenting Life
description: YOU, or someone you love, may die because of a gene patent that should never have been granted in the first place. Sound far-fetched? Unfortunately, its only too real.

title: Bushs Economic Advisers Call for Lower Taxes and Freer Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Bush administration reveled in the economys continued expansion on Monday, as the presidents advisers stepped up their calls for freer trade, lower taxes and a continued openness to immigration.

title: Libby and Cheney Wont Testify, Lawyers Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Lawyers defending I. Lewis Libby Jr. against perjury charges surprised the courtroom today by saying that they would rest their case this week and do so without putting on the stand either Mr. Libby or Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Ulysses Without Guilt
description: There are two ways to approach our cultural crossroads. You can either wring your hands and lament  as an eloquent school librarian did recently in The Washington Post  that literacy today has less to do with Wordsworth or Faulkner and more to do with how we find our way through the digital forest of information overload. Or you can be a sport about it, slip your earbuds back in and pick up a copy of Pierre Bayards best-selling How to Talk About Books You Havent Read.

title: Italy: Police Arrest 15 in Leftist Raids
description: The police arrested 15 radical leftists they called heirs to the Red Brigades terror group and said they were actively planning attacks. Probably, this time, we were able to prevent a Brigades attack, the interior minister, Giuliano Amato, said after the sweep in northern Italy. The Red Brigades, Italys most active terrorist group in the 1970s, kidnapped and killed a former prime minister, Aldo Moro, in 1978 but have been inactive for years.

title: Doctors Who Fail Their Patients
description: It was bad enough when pharmacists who call themselves pro-life refused to fill prescriptions for morning-after pills and an emergency medical technician refused to help drive a woman to an abortion clinic. Now a new survey has revealed that a disturbing number of doctors, at the presumed pinnacle of the health professions, feel no responsibility to inform patients of treatments that the doctors deem immoral or to refer them to other physicians for care. Although the close-mouthed doctors claim a right to follow their consciences, they are grievously failing their patients and seem to have forgotten the age-old admonition to do no harm.

title: Auction Is Set for Air America
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (Dow Jones/AP)  Air America Radio, the liberal news and talk radio network, has won bankruptcy court approval to sell its assets at an auction Friday, starting with a $4.25 million bid from a consortium of purchasers formed by Stephen L. Green, the chairman of SL Green Realty of New York.

title: Its Cashmans Team, for Better or Worse
description: There were times in George Steinbrenners ownership of the Yankees when he would not allow his general manager to attend the annual meetings of major league general managers. Other teams, Steinbrenner was convinced, wanted to steal the ideas that made the Yankees so successful, and he wasnt going to let that happen. If the general manager wasnt there, the thieves would have nothing to steal.

title: Shortening the Visa Line (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Curtail Investor Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun to take steps on two fronts to protect corporations, executives and accounting firms from investor lawsuits that accuse them of fraud.

title: Clinton Reminds New Hampshire, Im With Bill
description: As she made her first outing to New Hampshire as a presidential candidate last weekend, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton left her husband at home, yet she tried to tap his old political magic at nearly every turn.

title: Verizon Sells Venezuela Stake
description: Venezuelas government agreed yesterday to buy the 28.5 percent stake held by Verizon Communications in Compaa Annima Nacional Telfonos de Venezuela for $572 million.

title: One Dog Stands Alone Among Champions
description: It was 10 minutes before 2 yesterday afternoon when Harry, a Dandie Dinmont terrier, took his place on the edge of breed judging Ring 2 at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. He seemed uninterested in the dozen Staffordshire bull terriers still in the ring, and not much more affected by the occasional brushing he was receiving from his handler, Bill McFadden.

title: Irans Nuclear Web
description: Washington

title: Romney Declares 08 Candidacy in Michigan
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 13  Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, came to the state where he was born this morning to declare his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, and became the latest presidential candidate to position himself as an outsider running against Washington.

title: Iraq Seeks to End Sectarian Cleansing in Security Push
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 13  The Iraqi government on Tuesday evening ordered tens of thousands of people to leave homes they are illegally occupying, in a surprising and highly challenging effort to reverse the tide of sectarian cleansing that has left Baghdad bloodied and Balkanized.

title: Bayreuth Star Goes on to Ovations in Her 60s
description: Upon greeting her interviewer at the Metropolitan Opera recently, the first matter the soprano Anja Silja wanted to take up was her birth date. She reached into her handbag and produced her passport for inspection.

title: Researcher Cleared of Misconduct, but Case Is Still Murky
description: A professor who contends that nuclear fusion can be generated in a tabletop experiment has been cleared of research misconduct by Purdue University. But the refusal of university officials to answer any questions and their lack of detail in a statement released last week has left scientists to pore over the words like Kremlinologists, looking to divine meaning in what was said and what was not.

title: Germany: Court Backs Airports Closing
description: Tempelhof Airport, the main landing site of the Berlin Airlift in 1948 and 1949, will be permanently closed on Oct. 31, 2008, the citys highest administrative court ruled. Thirteen airlines had challenged the city-ordered closure of the 83-year-old airport.

title: Orbitzs New Challenge: Serving the Maverick Flier
description: I BELIEVE in the adage If it aint broke, dont fix it. I curse, for example, the new and unimproved version of Internet Explorer.

title: In Travel Writing, Even Vacation Is Work
description: I envy business travelers for whom a business trip is a business trip, and a vacation is a vacation. As someone who edits a travel site, my business trips are business trips, and my vacations are  business trips.

title: Police Officer Faces Scrutiny After Shooting of Colleague
description: The police officer charged with covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn has faced four allegations of wrongdoing during her 13-year career, all of which were found to be unsubstantiated, police officials said yesterday.

title: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about The Last Sin Eater misidentified the actor who plays the sin eater, someone who symbolically consumes the sins of the recently deceased. He is Peter Wingfield, not Henry Thomas. (Mr. Thomas plays a preacher.)

title: Russias Moves on Energy (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: States and U.S. at Odds on Aid for Uninsured
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  In the absence of federal action, governors and state legislators around the country are transforming the nations health care system, putting affordable health insurance within reach of millions of Americans in hopes of reversing the steady rise in the number of uninsured, now close to 47 million.

title: Taking the Staid Organ on a Tour Through Some Unfamiliar Neighborhoods
description: The British organist Kevin Bowyer has recorded the complete works of Bach and has been known to give marathon concerts devoted to Charles-Marie Widor, Louis Vierne or Kaikhosru Sorabji. But on Sunday afternoon, he gave a short recital  a tightly packed, virtuosic hour  at St. Thomas Church, devoted to another of his specialties: contemporary, decidedly post-tonal works. The concert was jointly produced by the church and the Miller Theater at Columbia University, as the second of two concerts in Millers celebration of the 20th-century organ repertory.

title: New Economy, Old Spin (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Proof of C.I.A. Illegality, Portuguese Premier Says
description: LISBON, Feb. 12  Prime Minister Jos Scrates said Monday that his government had no concrete evidence to support allegations that the United States had conducted illegal counterterrorism activities on an American air base on Portuguese soil.

title: Putin Visits Qatar for Talks on Natural Gas and Trade
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 12  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrived in Qatar on Monday to discuss trade, security and the possible formation of a natural gas cartel on the second leg of a three-day tour of the Middle East that is widely seen as an attempt to expand Russias strategic role in the region.

title: Companies Pressed to Define Green Policies
description: Tracey C. Rembert, the coordinator of corporate governance and engagement for the Service Employees International Union, acknowledges that Wells Fargo is the countrys largest purchaser of renewable energy offsets and has specialists on staff studying all of the implications of climate change on its businesses.

title: A Womans Despair, a Young Doctors Bewilderment
description: Correction Appended

title: In a Corner of Virginias Switzerland, a Division Over a Planned Wind Farm
description: MONTEREY, Va.  Wes Maupin says he will move this spring to a 20-acre spread here in remote Highland County, a pastoral place where sheep outnumber people and where little has changed since his boyhood, when he fished the countys mountain streams with his father.

title: Long a Target Over Faulty Iraq Intelligence, Ex-C.I.A. Chief Prepares to Return Fire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 _  For the past two years, George J. Tenet has maintained a determined silence even as senior White House officials have laid the blame for the prewar mistakes about Saddam Hussein on him. But now Mr. Tenet, the nations former spy chief, is preparing to return fire.

title: Tribune Sells Hoy New York to Spanish-Language Chain
description: The Tribune Company yesterday sold Hoy New York, its Spanish-language newspaper, to ImpreMedia, a leading Spanish-language publisher. Tribune is keeping its sister Hoy publications in Los Angeles and Chicago.

title: English Chamber Pieces: Elegiac, Poetic and Seldom Heard
description: Classical music, it is often said, is turning into a museum. And whats the problem? Museums today are increasingly user-friendly in their presentation and open-minded about exhibiting unusual and new work, qualities that classical music institutions should want to emulate.

title: Industry Plans National Attack on Proposed Health Care Cuts
description: Hospitals and a health care workers union in New York plan to mount an advertising campaign to defeat spending cuts proposed by President Bush  their first attempt to affect national policy with a strategy they have used statewide.

title: Hard-Knock Lessons From the Concussion Files
description: Midway through a delightful school outing on the local ice-skating rink, my daughter-in-law, a good skater, suddenly fell backward, hitting her head so hard she was knocked out. After she was wheeled into the first aid room, she asked: Where am I? How did I get here?

title: Iraq Then, Iran Now: A Rising Chorus of Skeptics (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Memo Pad
description: LATE TO THE GATE Airlines last year had the lowest percentage of on-time arrivals since 2000, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics in the Transportation Department. In 2006, domestic aircraft arrived on schedule 75.45 percent of the time, compared with 72.59 percent in 2000. The five airlines with the worst on-time arrival rates last year were Skywest (63.9 percent); American Eagle, owned by AMR (64.3 percent); JetBlue Airways (64.8 percent); Alaska Air (66.3 percent); and Northwest Airlines (66.6 percent). As for luggage, with a sharp increase in the number of checked bags because tighter security procedures reduced the number of carry-on bags, airlines mishandled bags at a rate of 6.73 per 1,000 passengers, a slight increase over 2005 (6.64 per 1,000 passengers).

title: Faces, Faces Everywhere
description: More than a decade ago, Diana Duyser of Hollywood, Fla., received a religious message through an unlikely medium: a grilled cheese sandwich she had made herself. As she gazed at the brown skillet marks on the surface of the bread, a familiar visage snapped into focus.

title: This Expansion Looks Familiar
description: It is five years into an economic expansion and most Americans are still waiting for their share. Inflation is swallowing pay raises. Businesses are hiring, but forecasters worry that the economy may be about to stall.

title: Revived St. Johns Gets Back in the Hunt
description: Going on a quarter of a century, the Big East tournament has been one of the great sporting events in New York. Lamont Hamilton has never attended it  not when he was growing up in Brooklyn and not in his first three seasons playing for St. Johns.

title: F.B.I. Lags in Securing Its Laptops and Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (Bloomberg News)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is making progress safeguarding its weapons and laptop computers, though there are still shortcomings to address, the Justice Departments inspector general said in a report issued on Monday.

title: New DVDs: Paul Robeson
Skeptics Doubt U.S. Evidence on Iran Action in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Three weeks after promising it would show proof of Iranian meddling in Iraq, the Bush administration has laid out its evidence  and received in return a healthy dose of skepticism.

title: Hollywood Decameron, Without All the Fun
description: About halfway through Jane Smileys new novel, a therapist and self-professed healer named Paul  who has spent the last couple of days at an interminable house party at a movie directors house overlooking Los Angeles  grows exasperated with his fellow guests.

title: Jury Acquits Man in Stabbing Death of His Wife
description: An Upper East Side landlord who pleaded self-defense in the stabbing death of his wife during an argument in their kitchen was acquitted today by a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Aging Nuclear Plants (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Nat H. Hentel, 87, Former Judge and Prosecutor, Dies
