description: Nat H. Hentel, a former State Supreme Court justice and an interim Queens district attorney in 1966, died Jan. 31 at his home in Tucson. He was 87.

title: Can Executives Find Happiness With a BlackBerry Minus Its Scroll Wheel?
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 12  Executives who are longtime BlackBerry users will have to teach their right thumb some new tricks if they switch to a model introduced on Monday.

title: Nascar Readies for Another Season, and More Cries of Foul
description: Ever since Nascar began sanctioning stock car races, the sports governing body has inspired a legion of skeptics. For every race run, for every yellow, red, black and checkered flag waved, for every winner and every loser, someone is pointing a finger at Nascar.

title: W.H.O. Approves Rotavirus Vaccine
description: The World Health Organization has approved, for the first time, a vaccine against rotavirus, a diarrhea-causing infection that kills up to 600,000 children each year. The approval of the vaccine, Rotarix, made by GlaxoSmithKline, means that United Nations agencies can buy it in bulk and use it in mass vaccination campaigns, as is done with polio and measles vaccines. The W.H.O. has long considered an affordable rotavirus vaccine one of its top priorities. Rotavirus infects nearly all children below 5 years old, but 90 percent of those who die of it are in poor countries, mostly in Africa and Asia.

title: West New York, N.J.: Statues Vandalized
description: A marble statue of Jesus outside Our Lady of Libera Roman Catholic Church was decapitated and knocked over late Sunday or early yesterday morning, the police said yesterday. A second statue, one of the Virgin Mary, had its arm knocked off. James Goodness, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of Newark, said the statue was removed from the grounds for repairs. Vandalism, when it comes to a sacred image, is something were extremely upset about, he said.

title: Sharing of Bison Range Management Breaks Down
description: MOIESE, Mont.  An effort to have two Indian tribes assist government officials in operating a federal wildlife refuge that is surrounded by their reservation has collapsed amid accusations of racism, harassment, intimidation and poor performance. But top federal officials say they are determined to resurrect it.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,115 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Irans Leader Disputes U.S. Charges on Militias
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 12  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Monday dismissed American accusations that Iran was arming Shiite militants in Iraq, saying Iran was opposed to any kind of conflict in Iraq.

title: Obama Restructures a Remark on Deaths
description: DURHAM, N.H., Feb. 12  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois said Monday that he had misspoken when he suggested that the lives of more than 3,000 American soldiers killed in Iraq had been wasted.

title: The Courage of Others Convictions
description: The music industry awarded an armload of Grammys to the Dixie Chicks on Sunday night, in what was celebrated as a blow for freedom of speech as much as tunefulness. The endorsement was about three years too late. The awards  including for the trios fittingly titled album Taking the Long Way and the song Not Ready to Make Nice  ended a desolate period in which their music was boycotted and banned by country music stations, their CDs were burned and smashed, and group members lives were threatened.

title: Unmatched Destruction
description: The recovery along the Gulf Coast and particularly in New Orleans is going too slowly, and there are steps the government can easily take to speed the process. One thing the Bush administration should have done immediately after Hurricane Katrina was to waive the requirement that state and local governments match federal rebuilding funds. The time to correct that mistake is now.

title: Spinners, Spinnees and Echoes of Watergate
description: Its fair to say that the relationship between the press and the Bush White House has often been one of mutual suspicion and sometimes outright hostility. And the administration and its allies have at times been outspoken in their belief that the mainstream press was biased against it. But as evidenced by the Frontline four-part series News War, whose first episode appears tonight on PBS, government skepticism toward the press is just one of the trials faced by todays news organizations. Those challenges include everything from declining audiences, to the warp speed of the 24/7 news cycle, to the Internets undercutting the presss monopoly on information, to news operations beholden to conglomerates that sometimes view news as another entertainment portal.

title: Home Depot May Shed Unit to Focus on Retail
description: Shortly after Robert L. Nardelli was deposed as chief executive of Home Depot, several of the countrys biggest buyout firms welcomed the companys new leader, Frank Blake, with a tantalizing proposal, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Division III Seeks Harmony Between Field and Classroom
description: The N.C.A.A.s Division III, a group of mostly small colleges that prohibit athletic scholarships, has long been viewed as a model of the amateur ideal. But rampant growth has swelled the membership to 420, making it by far the National Collegiate Athletic Associations biggest division, with enrollments ranging from 400 to 40,000.

title: House Begins Debate on Antiwar Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The House opened the most extensive debate over the Iraq war in more than four years as it began considering a resolution today to reject President Bushs plan to send more troops to Baghdad, paving the way for Democrats to attempt to use Congressional powers to intervene in the conflict.

title: North Korea to Close Reactor in Exchange for Aid
description: BEIJING, Feb. 13  North Korea agreed today to close its main nuclear reactor in exchange for a package of food, fuel and other aid from the United States, China, South Korea and Russia.

title: Sleet and Snow Headed for the Northeast
description: Cities in the Northeast braced today for a lashing of sleet, snow, winds and rain as a major winter storm moved across the Midwest and was beginning to arrive in the New York area tonight.

title: Welcoming Testing, Team Battles Cyclings Image
description: JULIAN, Calif.  On these mild, clear winter days in the mountains east of San Diego, one professional cycling team is trying to set itself apart from the doping scandals that have shaken its sport.

title: Libby Lawyers Open Case With Denials by Reporters
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. opened their case Monday with a parade of prominent Washington reporters who testified that Mr. Libby never mentioned the identity of a Central Intelligence Agency operative when they interviewed him during the period the officers identity was leaked to the news media.

title: Zimbabwe: Inflation Rate Nears 1,600%
description: Zimbabwes hyperinflation rose to a record annual rate of 1,593 percent in January, the government said, a rate at which the average cost of goods would increase seventeenfold in a single year. The new figure eclipsed Decembers rate of 1,281 percent and cast fresh doubt on the governments forecast that inflation would decline to 400 percent by years end. Most economists say that hyperinflation is doomed to continue unless Zimbabwe abandons government control of most markets and adopts other reforms, but the government said last month that it would tame inflation by making wage and price increases illegal and building a national consensus against rising wages and costs.

title: Starrett City Sale Draws 2 New Doubters
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer and the federal housing secretary added their voices yesterday to the growing chorus of politicians and community advocates who are demanding that Starrett City, the largest federally subsidized housing complex in the country, remain a haven for poor, working and middle-class families.

title: Survey Puts New Focus on Binge Eating as a Diagnosis
description: Binge eating is not yet officially classified as a psychiatric disorder. But it may be more common than the two eating disorders now recognized, anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

title: German Court Frees Leader of Terror Group
description: BERLIN, Feb. 12  A German court on Monday ordered the release of Brigitte Mohnhaupt, a leader of the terrorist Red Army Faction, who has been imprisoned for 24 years for kidnappings and murders in the 1970s.

title: Suit Seeks to Ensure Ballot Safety in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12  Voters rights activists want a judge to prevent the state from using more than 10,000 electronic voting machines that they say are not properly certified and are highly vulnerable to computer hackers.

title: Regular Midday Snoozes Tied to a Healthier Heart
description: Taking a nap after lunch may be good for your heart. This splendid news arrived in the form of a study published Monday in The Archives of Internal Medicine.

title: Knicks Thomas Admits He Feels the Pressure
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12  To see Isiah Thomas hopping wildly on the sideline, every limb thrashing in a different direction, is to see a coach seemingly on the edge.

title: Duke Program Seeks to Expand Service Work
description: Duke University announced yesterday that it would create a program backed by $30 million, half from a donation from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, to help students work on projects like teaching at a school in Durham, N.C., or building one in Kenya.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Reese Makes Statement as Giants Cut Petitgout, Arrington and Emmons
description: Jerry Reese made his first bold moves as general manager of the Giants yesterday, cutting three injury-plagued veterans  offensive tackle Luke Petitgout and outside linebackers LaVar Arrington and Carlos Emmons.

title: Staten Island: Man Is Shot to Death
description: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot on Sunday while sitting in a 2003 Jaguar near the intersection of Broad Street and Bay Street in Stapleton, the police said yesterday. The man, Carlos Ebanks of Staten Island, was sitting with at least one other person in the car when another vehicle drove alongside and someone fired at the Jaguar, the police said. The unidentified person in the Jaguar drove the car to Richmond University Hospital and then sped off, the police said. The Jaguar was found abandoned on Union Avenue, the police said.

title: At Avant-Garde Jazz Series, Rashied Ali and a Reunion
description: The Sculptured Sounds Music Festival adheres to an appealingly pure-hearted ideal. Organized and anchored by the bassist Reggie Workman, it presents adventurous jazz groups every Sunday night in February. The concerts take place at St. Peters Lutheran Church in Midtown Manhattan, familiar to a certain breed of New Yorker as the site of countless jazz memorial services. That sounds morbid, but it didnt feel that way on Sunday. Well, maybe just at first, as a quiet, expectant rustle could be heard in the pews.

title: A Cool $25 Million for a Climate Backup Plan
description: On Friday, when Richard Branson offered a $25 million prize to anyone who figures out how to remove a billion tons of carbon dioxide per year from the atmosphere, Al Gore sat by his side and called it an important and welcome initiative. For once, Mr. Gore couldnt be accused of hype.

title: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy, 86, an Innovator of Family Therapy, Dies
description: Dr. Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy, a psychiatrist who helped establish a powerful therapy for mental illness that brings patients extended families into treatment as allies, died Jan. 28 at his home in Glenside, Pa. He was 86.

title: MTV Laying Off 5.5% of Staff; Savings to Go to Newer Ventures
description: MTV Networks plans to dismiss 250 people, or 5.5 percent of its staff of 4,500, the networks chief executive, Judy McGrath, told employees in an e-mail message yesterday.

title: The Trick Is in the Antennas
description: Rocket scientists know how to keep a spacecraft stable: with instruments (gyroscopes, say) that detect when the craft is rolling, pitching or yawing, and control devices (thrusters, say) to compensate.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about negotiations to settle copyright-infringement claims by Universal Music Group against Bolt.com, a site featuring user-contributed content, misstated some of the prospective settlement terms. While Bolts chief executive said the terms included a promise to pay royalties in the future, he did not say that Bolt had agreed to admit that music uploads to its site were a violation of Universals copyrights. (Go to Article)

title: Armed Man Kills 5 at Mall in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 12  A lone gunman went on a shooting rampage in a Salt Lake City mall last night, killing five and wounding numerous others, before he was shot to death by police, the Salt Lake City police said.

title: Spitzer, in Reversal, Is Expected to Approve Freedom Tower, Officials Say
description: With the downtown real estate market improving rapidly, Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to abandon his criticism of the Freedom Tower as a looming white elephant and to approve construction of the tower, which would rise 1,776 feet at ground zero, according to city, state and Port Authority officials.

title: J.& J. Says Improper Payments Were Made
description: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries.

title: Safety of Drug-Coated Stents Tough to Assess, Report Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Teenagers Misbehaving, for All Online to Watch
description: DEER PARK, N.Y., Feb. 8  Dozens of teenage boys hovered outside Deer Park High School Thursday afternoon, some holding schoolbooks, some holding skateboards and some holding camera-equipped cellphones to record the proceedings.

title: Big Games Prevent Nets From Thinking Too Far Ahead
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 12  The Nets have avoided calling any regular-season contest a statement game, yet there is little doubt about the importance of the next two games for their psyche and their place in the standings.

title: Deal Would Triple the Size of the Albee Square Mall in Brooklyn and Add a High-Rise
description: The Downtown Brooklyn shopping plaza formerly known as the Albee Square Mall will soon undergo yet another incarnation: It will be razed, rebuilt at triple the size and topped with a high-rise with offices and a thousand apartments, its prospective new owners said yesterday.

title: Canada: Uranium Producer Acquired
description: SXR Uranium One agreed to buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion to form the worlds second-largest uranium producer as rising demand for nuclear fuel drives prices to records. SXR, owner of South Africas largest undeveloped uranium deposit, bid 7.05 Canadian dollars ($6.01) a share for UrAsia, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and owns mines in Central Asia. That was 13 percent more than UrAsias Feb. 9 closing price in Toronto, the companies said. SXRs stock rose 6.8 percent to a record. The combined company, once all its mines are operating, will trail only Cameco in production and be the only producer in Kazakhstan, South Africa, Australia, the United States and Canada, the five largest holders of uranium deposits.

title: Staten Island: Two Charged in Stabbing
description: Two New Jersey men were arrested on Sunday in connection with a fatal beating and stabbing at the Buena Vida nightclub on Port Richmond Avenue in Port Richmond, the police said yesterday. The men, Mario Batalla Hernandez, 19, and Jorge Alejandro Torres Hernandez, 25, both of Bayonne, were charged with second-degree murder in the death of Gabriel Acristain, 34, during an argument at the club. Mr. Acristains brother, whom the police did not identify, was also beaten and stabbed, the police said. The police did not provide an address for the Acristains.

title: Luxury Hotel Chains Board Backs Offer to Go Private
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 12  The directors of Four Seasons Hotels endorsed a $3.37 billion cash bid Monday to take the company private, quashing some investor hopes for a higher offer.

title: U.S. Battles Lawyers for New Jersey Legislature in Effort to Obtain Budget Records
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12  Federal prosecutors are battling lawyers representing New Jerseys state Legislature for access to budgetary records, leading to partisan sniping throughout the state on Monday over whether the inquiry was limited to a single lawmaker who has long been under investigation or had expanded to other members.

title: More than 68,000 Displaced by Mozambique Floods
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 13  The worst flooding of the Zambezi River in Mozambique since a catastrophic 2001 flood has forced more than 68,000 people from their homes, relief officials said today. Scores of thousands more are threatened.

title: Russia: Chechen President Says He Wont Resign
description: Tensions between the Kremlin-selected leaders in Chechnya spilled into public when the Chechen president, Alu Alkhanov, right, insisted that he had no plans to resign. The announcement underscored the pressures on Mr. Alkhanov from Ramzan A. Kadyrov, at left, the young prime minister who is the republics dominant political figure. When Mr. Alkhanov began his four-year term in 2004, replacing Chechnyas assassinated president, Akhmad Kadyrov, the father of Ramzan, Mr. Kadyrov did not meet the posts minimum required age of 30. He reached that age last fall and has been expected to push Mr. Alkahnov aside. Mr. Alkahnov struck back in a statement on his Web site, alluding to the culture of fealty that surrounds Mr. Kadyrov and his violent clan. The cult of personality and deification of one man will not do anything good for the republic or its society, he wrote.

title: Crossed by the Stars They Reach For
description: Ive been haunted all week by the distraught face of Lisa Nowak as it appeared in her mug shot, reproduced endlessly on television and newspaper front pages. She is the astronaut who has been accused of trying to kidnap and perhaps kill a rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut.

title: Clinton Reminds New Hampshire, Im With Bill
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been trying to capture her husbands old political magic, mentioning him at nearly every turn on the campaign trail.

title: Snowstorms in the Midwest
description: A lashing of sleet, snow, winds and rain moved across the Midwest.

title: Fresh Direct
description: Dont be fooled by the leading-lady looks. These indie darlings are calling all the shots.

title: Minding Your Body
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Irish Rep Buying Home
description: After 12 years of leasing, the Irish Repertory Theater, dedicated to presenting works by Irish and Irish-American playwrights, is planning to buy the two floors it uses at 132 West 22nd Street, in Chelsea, said Patrick Kelsey, the managing director.

title: Treasure Underground
description: Explore the lavish 65,000-bottle wine cellar of Park B. Smith, one of the world's most passionate wine collectors.

title: Die, Harry Potter, Die
description: Who wants Harry Potter dead? No, not just his evil nemesis Voldemort. The latest death wish comes from none other than Daniel Radcliffe, who portrays the boy wizard on screen. Discussing J. K. Rowlings Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the sagas seventh and concluding volume, scheduled for publication on July 21, two days before Mr. Radcliffe turns 18 and has access to an estimated $35 million fortune, he told The Observer magazine in London what he thought would happen to the character he plays. Will he die? I think I will, said Mr. Radcliffe. I sort of hope I will, really. I think thats really the only way Jo can end it, he said, referring to Ms. Rowling, if Harry and Voldemort . . . Maybe one can only die if the other one dies. I dont know that for sure. But Im quite looking forward to doing a death scene, if I get that opportunity.

title: UBS Reports Higher Profit from Continuing Operations
description: UBS, the securities company, said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 47 percent from a year ago, when asset sales helped increase profits. Profit from continuing operations rose 19 percent, however. UBS also raised its dividend and announced a three-year stock repurchase program valued at as much as 16 billion Swiss francs ($12.8 billion).

title: McCains 3-Step With Romney
description: Get used to it. Where one top-tier candidate goes, another will surely follow, or lead, or just somehow find a way to pull the spotlight (and the television cameras) his or her way. (Something like that old Carole King song: Where You Lead, I Will Follow. O.K. Its old, but its been resurrected on one of the latest network shows.)

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Curtail Investor Suits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun to take steps on two fronts to protect corporations, executives and accounting firms from investor lawsuits that accuse them of fraud. The New York Times reported that last Friday, the commission filed a little-noticed brief in the Supreme Court urging the adoption of a legal standard that would make it harder for shareholders to prevail in fraud lawsuits against publicly traded companies and their executives.

title: J.& J. Discloses Possibly Improper Payments
description: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The company also said that the executive responsible for the units, Michael J. Dormer, 55, worldwide chairman of medical devices and diagnostics, had retired.

title: MTV Says Staff Layoffs Will Make Room for New Ventures
description: MTV Networks plans to dismiss 250 people, or 5.5 percent of its staff of 4,500, the networks chief executive, Judy McGrath, told employees in an e-mail message Monday. Although Ms. McGrath did not say how much was hoped to be saved from the move, her message said that the money would be used to invest in our television and digital future, and to keep winning in this revolutionary environment. Viacom, MTVs parent company, is rushing to develop new interactive businesses.

title: Next Obstacle for Vodafone in Indian Deal Is Maintaining Discipline
description: A day after Vodafone, the British telecommunications company, agreed to pay $11.1 billion to acquire control of Hutchison Essar, a fast-growing Indian cellphone operator, analysts began questioning whether the British management can impose the cost discipline that is second nature to Indians and the companies they run.

title: Buyout Shops Made Home Depot an Offer It Couldnt Refuse
description: A recent offer by the countrys biggest buyout firms to take Home Depots wholesale supply division off Frank Blakes hands was apparently the spark that lit the flame. The New York Times reports that shortly after Robert L. Nardelli was deposed as chief executive of Home Depot, several private equity firms told Mr. Blake, the companys new leader, that they would consider buying the retailers $12 billion wholesale business.

title: Ex-Westar Executive Gets a Break From Leavenworth
description: David Wittig, the former top executive of Westar Energy, was released from prison on bond Monday pending the appeal of his sentence in a bank fraud case. Mr. Wittig was released from the federal detention center in Leavenworth about 2 p.m. and was greeted by his wife, Beth, and Jeff Morris, one of his attorneys. He had served nearly 13 months in prison.

title: Auction Is Set for Air America
description: Air America Radio, the liberal news and talk radio network, has won bankruptcy court approval to sell its assets at an auction Friday, starting with a $4.25 million bid from a consortium of purchasers formed by Stephen L. Green, the chairman of SL Green Realty of New York.

title: Verizon Sells Venezuela Stake
description: Venezuelas government agreed Monday to buy the 28.5 percent stake held by Verizon Communications in Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela for $572 million. The deal was signed by Jesse Chacon, Venezuelas telecommunications minister, and John W. Diercksen, Verizons executive vice president for strategy and development, on Venezuelas state television channel.

title: Tribune Sells Hoy New York to Spanish-Language Chain
description: Tribune on Monday sold Hoy New York, its Spanish-language newspaper, to ImpreMedia, a leading Spanish-language publisher. Tribune is keeping its sister Hoy publications in Los Angeles and Chicago.

title: Caremark and CVS Raise Deal Payout
description: Caremark Rx, facing mounting opposition to its proposed $23.7 billion acquisition by pharmacy chain CVS, said Tuesday it would triple the special dividend payable to its shareholders after the deal closes. Caremark, a manager of prescription-drug benefits, said it raised the dividend to $6 per Caremark share, up from the previously announced $2 per share. On Monday, two more investment advisory firms urged Caremark shareholders to reject the CVS merger at a vote scheduled for Feb. 20.

title: Wedding Bells for 2 European Travel Firms
description: MyTravel of Britain and Thomas Cook of Germany announced Monday that they would combine to create a more cost-competitive European-based travel company. The new company will retain the Thomas Cook name, one of the oldest established brands in the travel industry, and KarstadtQuelle, the German retailer that owns Thomas Cook, will hold a 52 percent stake in the combined company.

title: Warsaw Exchange to Privatize, Polish-Style
description: The Polish government is preparing a plan the privatize the Warsaw Stock Exchange by selling shares exclusively to Polish companies, possibly in defiance of European Union rules that require equal treatment for all members of the bloc.

title: Blodget and Cramer Lock Horns, Again
description: Henry Blodget is apparently getting a lot of mileage out of his war of the words with colorful stock-picker Jim Cramer. The back-and-forth has provided the former star analyst with enough fodder for a second column on his feelings about Mr. Cramer. In his Bad Advice column for Slate this week, entitled Me Vs. Jim Cramer, Round 2, Mr. Blodget meticulously answers critics of his first column, in which he pilloried Mr. Cramer for leading mom-and-pop investors to believe that they could beat the pros.

title: Quicksilver Gas Files for I.P.O.
description: Quicksilver Gas Services filed for an initial public offering to sell up to $81.5 million in common units, a partnerships equivalent of shares. UBS Investment Bank and Goldman Sachs are underwriting the offering, according to a preliminary prospectus filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which did not disclose an estimated price range for the units.

title: EGL Board to Seek Other Bids
description: EGL, a manager of freight services for companies, said a board committee authorized its financial adviser to seek bids in addition to a management-led $1.2 billion buyout offer. The adviser, Deutsche Bank Securities, began reviewing options even before the chief executive, James Crane, lost his equity sponsor, General Atlantic, last week, Houston-based EGL said Monday.

title: Are Concerns About Club Deals Overblown?
description: As the mergers-and-acquisitions boom hits records, investors and federal regulators have raised concerns about private equitys club deals, when private-equity firms form consortiums to collectively bid on a target. Yet BusinessWeek questions whether theres a reason to worry.

title: Blackstone Sells Off More Equity Office Properties, Report Says
description: Blackstone Group, the private equity firm that bought Equity Office Properties Trust in the biggest leveraged buyout ever, sold buildings acquired in the purchase for $7.55 billion, according to Bloomberg News. Blackstone sold 19 office buildings in Washington and 17 buildings in Seattle to Boston-based Beacon Capital Partners for $6.35 billion and 7 properties in Portland, Oregon, for $1.2 billion to San Francisco-based Shorenstein, Bloomberg reported.

title: Jefferies Executive Forced Out Following Scandal, Report Says
description: Jefferies & Co. reportedly forced out a longtime executive last week as it continues to clean house in the wake of its involvement in a travel and entertainment scandal with Fidelity Investments. While it was couched as a retirement, The New York Post reported that the departure of Jefferiess veteran equity chief, Scott Jones, was anything but voluntary.

title: Time Warner Cable Moves Closer to Offering
description: Adelphia Communications won bankruptcy-court approval on Monday to distribute $17 billion in stock and cash owed to its creditors, clearing a roadblock to the long-awaited listing of shares of Time Warner Cable, a unit of Time Warner.

title: Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show
description: Experts took their measure in the first day of judging at the annual competition as hundreds breeds of dogs vied for the coveted title of Best in Show.

title: Report Stokes Speculation About Alcoa Takeover
description: Shares of Alcoa rose in premarket trading Tuesday after The Times of London reported that two British-Australian mining giants were considering buying the aluminum producer. The paper said that BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto have begun examining the possibilities of a $40 billion buyout of the Pittsburgh-based company, while Alcoa has separately drawn up a list of chief executive candidates.

title: With Megafunds Come Megafees
description: Bigger buyout funds allow for larger-cap targets, where value is ripe. But its really about the fees, according to Breakingviews, which estimates that a $19 billion fund, like Goldman Sachss newest, may generate $7.8 billion of fees over its lifetime.

title: Digital Publishing Firm Zinio Is Sold
description: Zinio Systems, a venture-backed startup that provides digital publishing platforms for magazines and books, said Tuesday it had been acquired by Gilvest, a private equity firm. Financial terms were not disclosed. Zinios investors include New Enterprise Associates, North Bridge Venture Partners and Intels venture capital arm.

title: Live from Michigan, Its Mitt Romney
description: You can see former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts do his official campaign rollout (live in Dearborn, Mich.,) on a webcast here. Hes due to speak at 9 a.m. Eastern time today. Well have the text link to his remarks soon. [Here it is.]

title: The Domestic Abu Ghraib
Credit Suisse to Buy Assets from ResMae Mortgage
description: ResMae Mortgage, a subprime lender, said on Tuesday that it would file for bankruptcy and sell some assets to Credit Suisse. Ed Resendez, ResMaes chief executive, said in a statement that the asset sale will help keep the Brea, Calif.-based lender afloat. Terms were not disclosed. The sale is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

title: Romneys Announcement in Dearborn, Michigan
description: Following is the prepared text of a speech by former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts announcing his formal entrance into the 2008 presidential race.

title: Romney Makes It Official
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Mitt Romney is making it official this morning, declaring his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination at the Henry Ford Museum here. Based on the advanced text, Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, is the latest presidential candidate to present himself as the outsider.

title: Hey, I Know That Guy!
description: What does it mean to be the front-runner at a very early stage in a presidential campaign? Marjorie Connelly of our polling operation took a look and heres what she found:

title: An Oscar Pick From a Star
description: On Sunday night, at the British Film Awards viewing party at the Supper Club in New York, a woman who looked to be in her early 70s approached Farley Granger and said: Years ago I would have attacked you.

title: Might Have Beens
description: What if Uncle Frank in Little Miss Sunshine had been played by Bill Murray? Check out this what-if list of Oscar magic that never came to pass.

title: Shortly
description: Kris Tapley at InContention has been staring at Oscar-nominated shorts for some tells about how awards might go. Mr. Tapleys got good eyes and soft hands when it comes to Oscar guessery, so you might want to spend some quality time at his site. The Bagger watched the animated shorts, which had their charms, but skipped the daunting DVD of live action shorts, a challenge Mr. Tapley proves equal to.

title: Mills Favors Takeover Bid from Simon Property
description: While not on a scale of Equity Office Properties, the battle for Mills Corporation is shaping up to be another hard-fought real estate deal. Mills on Tuesday came out in favor of a $1.56 billion takeover offer from Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital. The company gave Brookfield Asset Management, which had already agreed to buy Mills for $1.4 billion, three days to decide whether to raise its price.

title: Whaling Commission Consensus Is Japans Moby Dick
description: A meeting of only half of the 72 members of the International Whaling Commission is underway this week in Japan, 34 members having boycotted the conference claiming it is a sham aimed only at furthering Japans goal of resuming commercial whaling.

title: Twenty-three Times the Annoyance
description: Kim Masters at Slate points out that those kooky kids at New Line have gone all viral in their marketing of The Number 23, the new Jim Carrey movie, displaying the maddening persistence of a four year old who wants a new toy.

title: Its That Time of Year
description: The Bagger has been avoiding handicapping because he was stinking it up so badly this year, but the rubber is starting to hit the road. Ballots are due in a week. Heres a good cheat sheet from OscarWatch as we round the final bend:

title: Applebees Will Explore Strategic Options
description: Applebees International, the parent company of the casual-dining restaurant chain, said on Tuesday that it had appointed an independent committee to explore strategic options including a sale of the company, as its same-store sales and margins continue to fall. The company, based in Overland, Kan., said that several alternatives could affect previously issued guidance and pulled its forecasts for 2007.

title: Standing Tall at the Oscars
description: The Bagger is hoping for an Oscar photo op involving the diminutive Martin Scorsese and the director of The Lives of Others, German director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, who stands stands six-foot-nine. Reuters checks in with a first-time filmmaker who came up big:

title: Start Revving Up the Toy Van
description: Every year, there are several nominees the Bagger cant help but root for, in spite of his rigorous professionalism, and he has to admit hes a little sweet on screenwriter Michael Arndt, whose Little Miss Sunshine just won the Writers Guild award for best original screenplay. Great writing, against-the-odds back story, and someone who seems genuinely thrilled that his movie is getting attention, never mind the awards  how can the Bagger resist?

title: Obamas Past Was Sometimes Present
description: What does Barack Obama think about partial-birth abortion, parental notification and criminal sentencing, among other issues? You cant always tell by looking at his record in the Illinois Legislature, says Nathan Gonzales of The Rothenberg Political Report.

title: Living in Moscow
description: Tour the Moscow apartment of Peter Falatyn, an American who rents in one of the city's most desirable neighborhoods.

title: Clinton Statement on Officer Borja
description: The office of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton issued a statement last night when told of the apparent discrepancies in accounts about a police officer, Cesar A. Borja, whose death had been attributed to work at ground zero. The officers son had attended the State of the Union speech at the invitation of Senator Clinton, who had cited the case in requesting more federal money for ground zero workers.The full statement from the senators spokeswoman, Nina Blackwell:

title: A Different Coffee Culture
description: A quick tale from the road and since Ethiopia isnt Vegas  what happens in Ethiopia, doesnt have to stay in Ethiopia.

title: For Citi, a Shorter Name and a Sunnier Logo
description: Citigroup is folding up its umbrella and giving group the boot. The financial-services giant said Tuesday that it was rebranding itself under the name Citi and would sell the trademark for its signature red umbrella, which it acquired through its landmark merger with the insurance company Travelers Group. The announcement confirmed last months report by Eric Dash of The New York Times, who said the rebranding is part of an ambitious campaign by [Citigroups] chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, to better integrate the banks sprawling parts after years of acquisitions.

title: $6.5 Million Homes
description: Tour a 50-acre estate in Maryland, a five-bedroom house in Aspen, Colo., and a luxurious condo in San Francisco.

title: Iraq Mosque Still in Ruins
description: Marc Santora reports that a year after insurgents attacked the golden mosque in Samarra, not a single brick has moved.

title: The Obama-Romney Media Rundown
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Ask most political analysts and theyll tell you that at this point, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois and Mitt Romney, the former governor of Michigan - oops, sorry, Massachusetts - both have about an equal chance to win their partys nomination and become president.

title: Goodbye, Vicki Lynn
description: The boyfriend weeps:

title: Edwards Blogmaster, Not Ready to Make Nice, Resigns
description: Amanda Marcotte, the blogmaster for John Edwardss presidential campaign, resigned yesterday. She announced her resignation in a post at Pandagon, where she said that the controversy over her personal blog writings was creating a situation where I felt that every time I coughed, I was risking the Edwards campaign. In the post Marcotte continues to suggest that her resignation was orchestrated by the partisan hatchet work of Bill Donahue and the Catholic League, but many Christian liberals and Democrats also found her writings profoundly offensive.

title: More Reaction to Officer Borja
description: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat who has been a champion of the cause of 9/11 rescue workers and others sickened near ground zero, issued a statement this morning in response to The Timess story on Officer Borja.Here is her statement:

title: 2008: Endorsement Draft
description: And when you decide who you want to vote for, you dont say, Gosh, I wonder what my city councilor is going to do,  said Mitt Romney during a late January visit to South Carolina as he proclaimed his pursuit of grassroots voters, not just top political figures.

title: Martha Stewarts Company: Recipe for a Buyout?
description: The market continues to debate whether Martha Stewart Omnimedia, the publishing empire that has launched countless dinner parties and glue-gun adventures, could inspire a leveraged buyout deal as well. Such speculation has helped to lift the companys stock in the past, but judging from the shares recent decline, hope is fading. Further cooling the takeover chatter, Susan Lyne, the companys chief executive, recently told TheStreet.com that a buyout is unlikely.

title: Reid Takes Leave of Absence From Eagles
description: With two of his sons facing legal troubles, Andy Reid has taken a one-month leave of absence as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: God vs. Evolution in Kansas  Again
description: Evolution and religion are facing off in Kansas once again today, as the board of education there  for the fourth time in eight years  decides just what students should be taught about how things came to be.

title: Steamroller Style
description: That phrase apparently figured prominently in questions posed to New York voters by Quinnipiac Universitys polling operation in a survey released today.Some details: voters approve 61  11 percent of the job Gov. Eliot Spitzer is doing and say 61  24 percent that his Steamroller Style is good for the people. Voters disapprove of the job the legislature is doing and give negative ratings to its leaders, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Senate Majority Leader Joe Bruno.

title: For Goldmans Loftiest, a Salary to Match
description: Goldman Sachs apparently tipped its hand on the base pay level for its elite crew of partner managing directors. Not surprisingly, its a lot. Citing a recent regulatory filing, Financial News reported that the base pay for partner managing directors at Goldman is $600,000 a year, which it said is about three times what regular managing directors make at Goldman and other comparable banks. Of course, the salary is loose change compared with the year-end bonuses awarded to employees with this lofty title, which is a relic carried over from Goldmans days as a private partnership.

title: Frantic in the Streets: London Fashion
description: I arrive in London at 7 a.m., have a full English breakfast ($13) at an Italian place in South Ken, and take a taxi ($24) to Covent Garden to see Christopher Kanes show. Kane is part of the latest English revival, along with Marios Schwab and Todd Lynn, and the magazines Pop and 10, which are having parties this week. I notice on the invitation to the 10 party tonight that Krispy Kreme is a sponsor  Krispy Kreme and Moet & Chandon. While having my bacon and eggs this morning, with a lake of baked beans, I read in the Mirror that theres a campaign to ban 0-size models. I guess fat-dispensing sponsors are O.K., though.

title: A Conclusion on Winter Testing?
description: The more I see of the results of winter testing, the less I feel it is possible to come to any kind of conclusion at all as to who is strong, and who is not. Well, all right, with maybe a few exceptions. Red Bull seems consistently not fast, and Honda doesnt look as strong as I might have thought. But the last two days of testing in Barcelona have confirmed the trend so far this winter. Ferrari, McLaren, Renault, Toyota, BMW and Williams all look close, stealing the spotlight one day after another. And their drivers too seem to be shifting places a lot, the battles between Massa/Raikkonen, Kovalainen/Fisichella, Alonso/Hamilton, Kubica/Heidfeld, Rosberg/Wurz, Webber/Coulthard, etc., are all for me entirely inconclusive at the moment.

title: Grners Bashful Brother Roter
description: Last weekend at a sort of abbreviated Grand Crew lunch to celebrate Mateos birthday, Dr. S pulled out a surprise, a 2005 roter veltliner from Wimmer-Czerny, a producer in the Wagram region of Austria, about 50 miles west of Vienna on the Danube.

title: Are Buyout Bids Being Raised a Lot or Not?
description: Dan Primack of PEHub has a theory: All the buzz surrounding private equity deals is causing public shareholders and strategic buyers to conclude that initial buyout offers are artificially low, causing bids to either be raised or abandoned on a fairly regular basis. He cites several high-profile, albeit anecdotal examples, including Equity Office Properties, Harrahs Entertainment and Elkcorp.

title: Double Burger, Part II
description: At the end of Double Burger, Part I, that riveting (not!) account of the chewing and musings of Peter Meehan and me, we had finished our sampling of the wares at Stand in Greenwich Village and were bound for BRGR, the vowel-challenged burger joint on Seventh Avenue just north of Chelsea.

title: Orlando
description: An ad from the Orlando campaign.

title: Orlando
description: An ad from the Orlando campaign.

title: Russian Soldiers Sold For Sex?
description: Russian authorities are investigating claims this week that young military conscripts have routinely been forced into prostitution, according to several reports. It is the latest in a string of scandals that have plagued the Russian military, this one brought to light by the Soliders Mothers group, a human rights organization dedicated to exposing abuses in the military.

title: Guv Ratchets Down
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer did not take his licks at Albany-area Assemblyman Bob Reilly today, as expected. In fact, he seemed to be in a bit of a ratchet-down mode in his war of words with the legislature. That said, he did take a shot at the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, in response to some of his recent criticisms of the governor.

title: Congressman Norwood Dies at 65
description: Representative Charles Norwood, a Republican representing an area including Augusta and Athens, Ga., died this morning at his home in Augusta. He was 65 and had been battling non-small cell cancer in his lungs that had spread to his liver. Last week, he left Washington to undergo hospice care.

title: From YouTube Guy to San Franciscos Most Eligible
description: Just in time for Valentines Day, The Deals VC Ratings blog has helpfully flagged the latest list of San Franciscos most-promising potential love interests, as determined by the Nob Hill Gazette, a monthly publication that claims to serve the Bay Areas most affluent homes. The 12th Annual List of Eligibles seems surprisingly light on venture capitalists and high-finance types, maybe because many of them live farther south in Silicon Valley. But there are a few, including the newly eligible (and, probably not coincidentally, newly rich) YouTube co-founder Steve Chen.

title: Court to Caremark: Not So Fast
description: In the fierce contest to acquire Caremark Rx, a judge has called time out. Granting a request from a Louisiana pension fund that owns shares of the company, a judge in Delawares Court of Chancery said Tuesday he would block a shareholder vote on Caremarks proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS, which had been scheduled for Feb. 20. The court is not confident that all Caremark shareholders would be able to make an informed decision if they are required to vote on February 20, Judge William B. Chandler III said in a letter, Reuters reported.

title: People Who Dictate
description: Over at Room Eight, Ben Smith notices a certain similarity between Eliot Spitzer and Rudy Giuliani.

title: No Miracle Here
description: Here is an excerpt from a decision by Chancellor William Chandler of the Delaware Chancery Court, in a case involving a consulting contract between Tyson Foods and Robert Peterson, a former chief executive of Iowa Beef Packers, a Tyson subsidiary.

title: Preview of a Budget Fight
description: The Empire Zone checked in with the budget proceedings this morning, only to find legislators on both sides of the aisle picking apart Gov. Eliot Spitzers health care proposals during a joint budget hearing held by the Senate and the Assembly.

title: Mitt Romney Announces His Candidacy
description: The former governor of Massachusetts came to Michigan, the state where he was born, to declare his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Vanishing Growth
description: A couple of weeks ago, Wall Street celebrated a surprisingly strong gross domestic product report, which said the economy grew at an annual rate of 3.5 percent after inflation in the fourth quarter.

title: Blog of Record: Comptroller Roll Calls
description: In voting last week to make Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli the state Comptroller, lawmakers bucked Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who portrayed the vote as a referendum on reforming Albany. Mr. DiNapoli won the final tally, 150 to 56; 107 votes were needed to win. Also in the running was Martha E. Stark, the New York City finance commissioner.

title: A Nip Here and a Tuck There Make for a Nascar Cheat
description: As The Times Viv Bernstein reports today, Nascars signature event, the Daytona 500, is being marred for the second straight year by a cheating scandal before it even gets started. Event officials suspended the crew chiefs for four drivers yesterday  Matt Kenseth, Kasey Kahne, Scott Riggs and Elliott Sadler  docking points from all four teams before the race begins. This means they will start the race in negative territory.

title: Blogtalk: Tuesdays Gone
description: Pataki and Weld: out-of-power lunch? [The Politicker]

title: Basil Rathbones Mysterious Message
description: I know, I know. I promised you several ghost stories. This one requires a longer treatment than I expected. I shant forget the others.

title: War at Home: Debating the Debate
description: Weve been pretty engrossed with the fullblown C-Span coverage of the first day of the House debate on the resolution over the war in Iraq. Our colleague, Jeff Zeleny, is writing about the debate as it unfolds on the floor.

title: Bloombergs Valentines Day
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg turns 65 on Valentines Day. He was born on Feb. 14, 1942, in Boston. And what does he plan to do to celebrate the occasion? Heres what he said when asked at City Hall about it:

title: Chicken Thighs
description: Dining columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, shows how to cook chicken thighs stuffed with chard.

title: 2nd Edwards Blogger Quits
description: The other shoe, er, keyboard, drops.

title: Army Giving More Waivers in Recruiting
description: The number of waivers granted to Army recruits with criminal backgrounds has grown nearly 65 percent in the last three years, increasing to 8,129 in 2006 from 4,918 in 2003, Department of Defense records show.

title: Outside Pressures Broke Korean Deadlock
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  It is hard to imagine that either George W. Bush or Kim Jong-il would have agreed even a year ago to the kind of deal they have now approved. The pact, announced Tuesday, would stop, seal and ultimately disable North Koreas nuclear facilities, as part of a grand bargain that the administration has previously shunned as overly generous to a repressive country  especially one that has not yet said when or if it will give up its nuclear arsenal.

title: Nascar Makes Aggressive Move Against Cheating
description: Another year, another cheating scandal to open the season and overshadow the buildup to Nascars premier race, the Daytona 500.

title: Her Fingerprints Are All Over Bach
description: After Angela Hewitt gave a recital in December at Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow, a piano professor from the Moscow Conservatory remarked how surprised he was to hear such playing from a Canadian pianist, adding that she played like a man.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,118 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Iraqis Announce New Crackdown Across Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 13  The Iraqi government on Tuesday ordered tens of thousands of Baghdad residents to leave homes they are occupying illegally, in a surprising and highly challenging effort to reverse the tide of sectarian cleansing that has left the capital bloodied and Balkanized.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Woman in the News article on Monday about Drew Gilpin Faust, the incoming president of Harvard, referred incorrectly in some editions to Concord Academy, the Massachusetts prep school she attended. It was a girls school when she graduated; it is now co-ed.

title: Springer Bests Crowd Favorites at Westminster
description: Pointers, German short-haired pointers and German wire-haired pointers competed in the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, but the most significant pointing was done by someone standing on two legs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about previous  and unfounded  accusations of wrongdoing against Jacqueline Melendez Rivera, a New York City police officer accused of covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn, gave the incorrect name in some copies of the street where the couple live. It is St. Marks Avenue, in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn  not St. Marks Place.

title: Disputes Emerge on Iran and Roadside Bombs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Bush administration officials, intelligence analysts and some leading Democrats in Congress all agree that a particularly lethal class of roadside bomb is killing American troops at an increasing rate. But fissures have emerged as to whether senior leaders of Irans government are directly involved in the attacks.

title: Chargers Could Set Off a California Shuffle
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13  Football in Southern California is defined by the San Diego Chargers, the University of Southern California Trojans and endless stadium negotiations.

title: Is Radio Still Radio if Theres Video?
description: Ted Stryker, a D.J. at KROQ in Los Angeles, considers it a perk of the job to wear shorts and T-shirts to work. But last Sunday as he dressed for the Grammy Awards, he pulled out his best blazer and a flashy belt buckle, knowing three video cameras would stream live coverage of his show to the Web sites of 147 CBS radio stations.

title: In a Case Worthy of Spade, the Falcon Has Flown Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13  Somewhere out there is a bird burglar with one valuable piece of imitation fowl.

title: Springer Spaniel Chosen Best in Show
description: Pointers, German short-haired pointers and German wire-haired pointers competed in the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, but the most significant pointing was done by someone standing on two legs.

title: CVS Raises Its Bid for Caremark Rx as Judge Delays Vote
description: The battle for Caremark Rx, the pharmacy benefits manager, moved beyond a war of words yesterday as CVS raised its bid for the company for the second time, to $25.7 billion.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about a decision by Dover Caterers, the vendor for Nassau Countys parks, pools and golf courses, to ban trans fats from its menu misstated the surname of a spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association, who predicted that Dovers move would have a domino effect. She is Bonnie Taub-Dix, not Taub-Dixon.

title: For 5th Year, Trade Gap Hits Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The United States ran a record trade deficit in 2006 for the fifth consecutive year, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday in an announcement that quickly reignited the dispute between the Bush administration and Democrats over the value of past and future deals lowering trade barriers.

title: One War Is Enough (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Millions in Lottery Prizes Go Unclaimed
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 13  They are the would-have-beens, could-have-beens, should-have-beens. They would be rich, recipients of the kind of multimillion-dollar jackpots that people dream about.

title: Trenton: State Tries to Limit Greenhouse Gases
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed an executive order yesterday committing the state to reduce New Jerseys greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2020. The order also requires lowering such emissions to 80 percent below 2006 levels by 2050. The State Department of Environmental Protection will monitor progress toward these goals, and in the next six months the director of energy savings in the Department of the Treasury is required to create targets and implementation strategies for reducing energy use by state agencies.

title: U.S. Agency Violated Law in Seed Case, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the Agriculture Department violated the law by failing to adequately assess possible environmental impacts before approving Monsantos genetically engineered alfalfa.

title: A Split After Muhammads Death That Still Resonates
description: Reporters, writers, chatterers and everyone else these days seem to be flaunting their knowledge of Shiite and Sunni Islam. If youve fallen behind, now is your chance to catch up in the privacy of your home or car, where you can pretend its all review. All this week NPRs Morning Edition is presenting a five-part primer on Shiism called The Partisans of Ali: A History of Shia Faith and Politics, with Mike Shuster as host. The series is an attempt, by the nations most popular radio news broadcast, to explain the sect of 150 million to 200 million of the worlds 1.3 billion Muslims.

title: More Flavor Inside and Out
description: STUFFING boneless chicken has long been reserved for breasts, because theyre easy to bone and simple to flatten, stuff and roll. But most chicken breasts have so little flavor that you almost have to stuff them with fat. (The classic example is chicken Kiev, in which the stuffing is butter.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article and chart on Jan. 16 about the rising number of women in the United States living without spouses referred imprecisely to ages of the women included in the Census Bureau survey that was the basis of the finding. The women were 15 and older, not over 15.

title: Saving a Few Hours on a Trip Back to Colonial Times
description: MY friend Dave Wondrich is the proud owner of an authentic earthenware bean pot, passed down from his grandmother Virginia Harding, nee Tubbs, of Maine snowshoe manufacturing fame. The pot is squat and brown, with a deep, bulging belly meant to hold two gallons of beans, molasses and salt pork while it all simmers away, preferably above the orange embers of a wood-burning stove.

title: A Shameful Prosecution
description: An immigration court judges dismissal of 20-year-old deportation proceedings against two Palestinian men  and his criticism of the governments abusive conduct in the case  ought to prick the conscience of the homeland security secretary, Michael Chertoff. Rather than reflexively pursuing an appeal, Mr. Chertoff, a former federal judge, should see the wisdom of finally declaring an end to this sorry legal tale, which has become a big source of distrust in the Arab and Muslim community.

title: Manhattan: More Problems Reported at Schools
description: A mayoral report to be released today will show a citywide increase in school safety incidents, including crimes and other misbehavior, city education officials familiar with the data said yesterday. As a result, officials said, two school buildings, Jamaica High School and Campus Magnet, both in Queens, will be policed more aggressively under the Operation Impact program, which sends more police officers and safety agents to schools deemed unruly. But James Eterno, the teachers union leader at Jamaica, said the school was being unfairly singled out. Were down over all in crime, he said, and then they put us on the impact list. Thats so unfair. Stu Loeser, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, would not comment on the specific data before its release, but noted that the report this year included statistics for five more school days than last years.

title: Robert Moses, Builder, Left Behind His Power Tool
description: A series of splendid museum events across New York City has recharged the 50-year debate about the legacy of Robert Moses. Did this powerful planner, who died in 1981, make todays thriving New York possible? Or did he arrogantly destroy neighborhoods, often the poor and black ones, that got in his way of a grand metropolitan vision?

title: What You Get for ... $6.5 Million
description: Trappe, Md.

title: Congress and Self-Reform
description: Taxpayers have been slowly discovering the bad, the ugly and, lately, a touch of good in Congresss tight relations with the lobbying industry. Last Novembers candidates promised all manner of reform, and the good was the enactment of a long-overdue ban on lobbyists currying insider clout by taking lawmakers on freebie vacations and other junkets. But the bad remains to be dealt with: the practice of lawmakers creating secondary leadership kitties to sock away extra money from lobbyists and other special-interest donors beyond the usual campaign committees.

title: Bomb Kills 11 on Military Bus in Iran
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 14  A car loaded with explosives blew up today in front of a bus carrying members of the Revolutionary Guards in southeastern Iran, killing at least 11 and injuring 34 others, according to state-run news outlets.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) JERICHO Just in time for the seriess return on Feb. 21, this hourlong primer, which gives a recap of the first 11 episodes  from the day the bomb went off in view of the Kansas prairie to the reappearance of Emilys fianc, Roger (Christopher Wiehl).

title: Heres Looking at You, Beloved Movie Clichs
description: The dames are sheathed in satin and attitude, the guys have secrets to spare, and the gags come slathered in soy sauce in Adrift in Macao, the flimsy film spoof that opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters. This miniature musical, which boasts a book and lyrics by a major name, Christopher Durang, and pastiche music by Peter Melnick makes sport of those ludicrous melodramas set in the exotic Orient, wherein Yanks down on their luck fall into one anothers arms and fall prey to the local vices, while the evil-looking denizens smile knowingly and mix up their Rs and Ls.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about New York Citys plans to revisit its 10-year-old price caps on the commercial trash-hauling industry referred imprecisely to Robert M. Morgenthau, whose office said in 1997 that carters were overcharging their customers by extracting a mob tax of $500 million a year. Mr. Morgenthau was then and remains the Manhattan district attorney; he did not just hold that office at the time.

title: U.S. Says Powerful Iraqi Cleric Is Living in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The powerful Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr has left Iraq and has been living in Iran for the past several weeks, senior Bush administration officials said Tuesday.

title: On Different Pages With Bilingual Education
description: When Lafayette High School in Brooklyn was ordered last year to begin shutting down, condemned as an educational failure, Steve Chung stood ready with a plan for what might come next. The city Education Department had decreed that Lafayettes building, in Bensonhurst, would be converted into several new, small schools, and Mr. Chung envisioned one of them serving the neighborhoods large population of Chinese immigrants.

title: Guinea Imposes 20-Hour Curfew as Government Battles Protesters
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 13  Guineas military on Tuesday cracked down hard on protests that had jolted the country all weekend, strictly enforcing a curfew that drove people indoors for all but four hours of the day.

title: Michael Andretti Will Try Again at Indy
description: Michael Andretti ended a three-year retirement last May by racing in the Indianapolis 500. He lost the lead with less than three laps left to his teenage son, Marco, who then lost it to Sam Hornish Jr. at the end of an exhilarating race.

title: Behind the Scenes, Problems Start to Pile Up
description: The best team event in tennis began Friday, without Roger Federer, the best player in the game, who declined to provide his services. Then again, isnt the sport just brimming with internal conflicts these days?

title: Italy: Finalists in Bidding for Alitalia
description: Five companies were picked by the government as finalists in the bidding for its stake in Alitalia, the ailing state-controlled carrier. The bidders include the Texas Pacific Group, the private equity firm; UniCredit, the bank; as well as financier Carlo De Benedettis Management and Capitali, MatlinPatterson Global Advisers; and Carlo Toto, owner of Italys No. 2 carrier, Air One, the finance ministry said. They have until mid-April to submit preliminary offers. Italy decided in December to sell its stake in the countrys largest airline after the government abandoned turnaround efforts. Alitalia last reported a profit in 2002 and has forecast a loss in 2006.

title: Brooklyn: Man Dies in Crash
description: An 85-year-old Brooklyn man died yesterday when his Dodge sideswiped a Toyota before hitting a city fire truck, the police said. The man, Joseph Borrometi of Henry Street, was driving south on Knapp Street shortly before 1 p.m. when he sideswiped the Camry, occupied by a woman and her 12-year-old son, before striking the fire truck stopped at a red light, the police said. Mr. Borrometi was pronounced dead at Coney Island Hospital, the police said. The woman, who was not identified, suffered minor neck injuries, and no one else was hurt, the police said.

title: No Rest for a Feminist Fighting Radical Islam
description: Ayaan Hirsi Ali came to the attention of the wider world in an extraordinary way. In 2004 a Muslim fanatic, after shooting the filmmaker Theo van Gogh dead on an Amsterdam street, pinned a letter to Mr. van Goghs chest with a knife. Addressed to Ms. Hirsi Ali, the letter called for holy war against the West and, more specifically, for her death.

title: Lawmakers Feel Heat Over Comptroller Choice, and Not Just From Spitzer
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  Are you getting a lot of love mail? Assemblyman Albert A. Stirpe Jr., a Democrat from North Syracuse, asked a colleague this week as they both got into an elevator here in the Capitol complex.

title: New Jersey Plans to Increase Bus and Train Fares by 9.9 Percent
description: NEWARK, Feb. 13  Laying out details of a proposed fare increase, New Jersey Transit officials said on Tuesday that interstate train and bus fares would go up an average of 9.9 percent, applied equally to monthly passes and single tickets, to help close a projected $60 million shortfall in next years operating budget.

title: Putin Pushes Back
description: Foreign policy experts are still trying to parse Vladimir Putins weekend blast against America, which he described as a brutish country that has overstepped its national borders, in every area. But rather than asking what exactly motivated Mr. Putin to lash out at the U.S. in this way, the question we should be asking is: why do remarks like these play so well in Russia today?

title: Cellphone Ads May Take Off Soon
description: ADVERTISING on your cellphone?

title: Manhattan: State to Expand Civil Rights Enforcement
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a doubling of the size of his offices civil rights bureau, to 20 lawyers from 10. At a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. Cuomo said the expanded bureau would focus on employment discrimination, wage violations, combating sexual harassment and ending what he called discrimination in marriage laws. Dianne E. Dixon, formerly executive director of the New York City Loft Board, will lead the civil rights bureau; Sandra Jefferson Grannum, formerly a deputy chief in the offices health care bureau, will be in charge of legal recruitment; and Lillian Llambelis, who is legal director of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, will direct intergovernmental relations.

title: Google Said to Violate Copyright Laws
description: PARIS, Feb. 13  A Brussels court ruled Tuesday that Google had violated copyright laws by publishing links to articles from Belgian newspapers without permission. Legal experts said the case could have broad implications in Europe for the news indexes provided by search engines.

title: For Martnez and Snchez, Its Good and Getting Better All the Time
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 13  One is celebrated for dashing through sprinklers and revitalizing a franchise. The other is best recognized by his goggles.

title: Illinois: Hundreds of Flights Are Canceled
description: Airline traffic at Chicagos two major airports became snarled as several inches of snow, high winds and low visibility forced the cancellation of hundreds of flights, the authorities said. By midafternoon, 900 inbound and outbound flights had been canceled at OHare International Airport, and all flights were experiencing delays of two to three hours, said Wendy Abrams, a spokeswoman for the Chicago Department of Aviation. At Midway Airport, 300 flights had been canceled, Ms. Abrams said. At United Airlines, a major carrier at OHare, officials expected to cancel 50 percent of all inbound and outbound flights by the end of the day, said Megan McCarthy, a spokeswoman for the airline.

title: M.T.A. Says It Cant Handle Cost Overruns on No. 7 Project
description: The new leadership of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority signaled yesterday that it had deep concerns over a deal with the city to build a $2.1 billion extension of the No. 7 subway line, saying the authority did not have the money to pay for possible cost overruns or other additional expenses.

title: Melodic Guy, Verbal Gal Meet Cute and Get Lyrical
description: Playing Alex Fletcher, a semi-washed-up British pop star whose heyday was in the haircut-band 80s, Hugh Grant, one of the stars of Music and Lyrics, delivers a reasonably convincing impersonation of, well, Hugh Grant. He stammers articulately, ducks his head coyly to one side and ornaments his line readings with cute qualifications and digressions, as in: We have tonight, the morning and just the teeniest little bit of the afternoon.

title: Chrysler to Announce Job Cuts, Plant Closings
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Feb. 13  The Chrysler Group is set to announce a restructuring plan Wednesday aimed at securing its place in the crowded American car market  and within DaimlerChrysler.

title: Citigroup, Streamlining Its Brand, Will Sell Its Umbrella Logo to St. Paul
description: Citigroup has decided to pack up its signature umbrella as it streamlines its corporate identity.

title: Winter Storm Moves to East Coast
description: Schools were closed, airline flights were delayed and commuters were miserable today as a snow and ice storm reached the East Coast after paralyzing parts of Midwest on Tuesday.

title: A Church Protest Ends Quickly, but the Anger Is Likely to Endure
description: Carmen Villegas did not expect the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to send burly guards into her church, Our Lady Queen of Angels, but it did. She did not expect to be at the center of a chaotic scene, shouting at church officials and flinging open the front door of the church, but she was.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about 10 companies that Ceres, a coalition of investors and environmental groups, says may not be paying enough attention to global warming, rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Mary S. Wenzel of Wells Fargo, who discussed the banks track record on green investing. She said, We are certainly demonstrating that we are addressing risk and seizing opportunities  not ceasing opportunities.

title: Mall Owners Board Accepts Higher Offer From Simon
description: Another real estate bidding war  though on a much smaller scale than the recently concluded $39 billion battle over Equity Office Properties  could well be under way.

title: By Wine Besotted: A Fantasy Fulfilled
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn.

title: Libby and Cheney Wont Testify, Says the Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Lawyers defending I. Lewis Libby Jr. against perjury charges surprised the courtroom on Tuesday by saying that they would rest their case this week and do so without putting on the stand either Mr. Libby or Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Sports of The Times column on Monday about two Yankees dynasties referred imprecisely to a list of players from the four World Series championship teams over the five seasons from 1996 to 2000. The list  Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte  included only players who contributed to the Series titles and are on the current roster, not every player who was on the winning teams and later left or went unsigned by the Yankees. (The list also did not include Jorge Posada, who was a member of the championship teams and remains a Yankee but did not contribute significantly in 1996.)

title: Moscow Market on the Rise
description: MOSCOW  Does an apartment building originally constructed for Heroes of Socialist Labor have market cachet?

description: Correction Appended
