description: To the Editor:

title: California: Navy Rejects Sonar Restrictions
description: The Navy has told the California Coastal Commission that it will continue to conduct training exercises off Southern California using midfrequency sonar, despite scientific concerns that the sonar may kill or injure marine mammals, including whales. In a letter dated Monday, the Navy said the commission had no authority to regulate its exercises, partly because use of the sonar would occur well offshore, in federal waters. The commission oversees a three-mile region off Californias coast and islands, and believes it has jurisdiction if animals spend part of their life cycle in those waters, said Mark Delaplaine, a commission supervisor. Mr. Delaplaine said the commission would meet later in the week to discuss its options, which could include legal action.

title: Libbys Defense Rests Case in C.I.A. Leak Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The lawyers defending I. Lewis Libby Jr. against perjury charges rested their case today, but not before suffering a series of defeats in legal rulings by the presiding judge.

title: Dusting Off a Corporate Haven in the Burbs
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 12  At first glance, the collection of modernist buildings at High Ridge Park Corporate Center resembles a stage set from the Woody Allen film Sleeper.

title: Its Also the Texas Capital of Construction
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 12  Construction cranes are dotting the skyline here after a six-year hiatus. Large swaths of downtown, once largely parking lots, low-slung buildings and warehouses, are being demolished to put up glass skyscrapers, and land that had been vacant for years is being cleared for new offices and homes all over town.

title: Lebanese Mark Date of Assassination
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Feb. 14  The Lebanese military rolled out acres of razor wire and fashioned a no-mans land to separate the hundreds of thousands of pro-government supporters who poured into the center of this city today from the hundreds of opposition supporters who have camped in the downtown since December.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Exxon Chief Cautions Against Rapid Action to Cut Carbon Emissions
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13  The chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Rex W. Tillerson, warned Tuesday that governments should not rush into policies that could damage the global economy in order to limit carbon emissions.

title: Bush Says Iran Is Source of Deadly Bombs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Bush said today he is certain that elements of the Iranian government are supplying deadly roadside bombs that kill American troops in Iraq, even if the innermost circle of the government is not involved.

title: Zimbabwes Slide (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Court Charges Leader of Opposition With Corruption
description: BEIJING, Feb. 13  Taiwans high court prosecutors office said Tuesday that it had filed corruption charges against Ma Ying-jeou, the leader of Taiwans main opposition party, whom many saw as a leading presidential candidate in 2008.

title: Coffee, Tea or an Affair With a Guy?
description: Proving definitively that size matters, Coffee Date, which began life as an award-winning short film, has been expanded into a feature likely to win awards only for bloat. After asking an intriguing question  is it possible to chart the exact point on the sexual continuum where straight becomes gay?  the writer and director, Stewart Wade, now has more than enough time to bail on the answer. In the end, what should have been a welcome challenge to sexual labeling becomes a dispiriting cave-in to conformity and stereotype.

title: Doubts About Iran Because of Iraq (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Larceny Case With It All: Love, Money and a Man Named Cupid
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 13  The only thing lacking in the case file was a dozen red roses.

title: Manhattan: Landmarks Panel Approves Experimental Playground
description: An experimental playground planned for Burling Slip near the South Street Seaport took a step closer to fruition yesterday with unanimous approval by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. At the commissions request, designers at the Rockwell Group, which is developing the playground with the City Parks and Recreation Department, made changes meant to integrate the contemporary structure into the historic seaport district, including replacing a chain link fence with one of wrought iron, lowering a ramp and removing parking spots. The project needs approval from the State Historic Preservation Office before construction can begin.

title: U.N. Commander in Kosovo Resigns After Deaths
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Feb. 14  The commander of the United Nations police in Kosovo resigned today, days after violent clashes between the police and demonstrators left two protesters dead and another critically injured.

title: Charles Gibsons World News Gets Rare Ratings Victory
description: For the first time since the network newscasts led by Brian Williams, Charles Gibson and Katie Couric began competing in September, World News with Mr. Gibson on ABC was the most watched of the three, according to ratings estimates for last week released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research.

title: The Lesson of North Korea
description: It is welcome news that North Korea has agreed to move toward dismantling its nuclear weapons program in exchange for fuel oil and international acceptance  including the hope of eventual recognition by the United States. When dealing with Pyongyang (and for that matter, the Bush administration), a lot can slip betwixt the cup and the lip. But if all goes as agreed, the world will be safer.

title: Manhattan: Man Sought in Handbag Thefts
description: The police are seeking a man in connection with thefts from unattended handbags and wallets at hospitals and Columbia University. The suspect, David Kinlock, is wanted for questioning in connection with thefts of credit cards, checks and cash at Mount Sinai Hospital, St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center, the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Columbia University, the police said. The police said the thefts occurred between Oct. 3 and Jan. 10, and described Mr. Kinlock as 5 feet 7 inches tall, white, partly bald and usually wearing business attire with glasses.

title: U.N. Criticized After Deaths in Protests Over Kosovo
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Feb. 13  Violent clashes last weekend have put the United Nations on the defensive here, even as it works to lead Kosovo toward its long-sought independence from Serbia.

title: Sense of Loss and Unease After Salt Lake Slayings
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 13  The shots that echoed inside the Trolley Square mall on Monday night around dinnertime were evenly spaced, perhaps a second or two apart  a pump of the shotgun, the selection of a victim, another blast.

title: Little Lake Forest Goes Mano a Mano With the Big Guys
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  A week before classes resumed at Lake Forest College after the holidays, the members of Coach Mike Daus team were assembled on campus and sweating. Everyone was lifting weights, jumping rope, sprinting and otherwise engaging in punishing drills in the first of two daily workouts.

title: He Cooks. She Stews. Its Love.
description: YOLANDA EDWARDS was at a friends house in Brooklyn for dinner when the hostess asked her to pull out a pot for boiling pasta. Ms. Edwards froze. As her friend looked at her in disbelief, she said she was not up to the job.

title: Paean to a Chickpea in Its Crunchy Glory
description: SOMETIMES when we eat out, we want a place thats affordable. A nice place to knock back some pasta and a bottle of Chianti. And sometimes we need cheap.

title: Army Giving More Waivers in Recruiting
description: The number of waivers granted to Army recruits with criminal backgrounds has grown about 65 percent in the last three years, increasing to 8,129 in 2006 from 4,918 in 2003, Department of Defense records show.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the Dixie Chicks success at the Grammy Awards, including their honors for album, record and song of the year, misstated the interval since one artist or group last swept those three awards. It had been 14 years, not 13. (Eric Clapton won them in 1993.)

title: Chrysler to Cut 13,000 Jobs in Overhaul
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Feb. 14  DaimlerChrysler said today that it was leaving all options open for the future of its struggling Chrysler Group, which announced a plan to close all or part of four plants and eliminate 13,000 jobs in North America.

title: Council Grills City Officials on School Bus Changes
description: City Council members testily grilled the Bloomberg administration yesterday about virtually every aspect of midwinter changes in school bus routes, accusing officials of bringing about bedlam and a fiasco.

title: Floods Force 68,000 to Flee Homes in Mozambique
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 13  Mozambiques worst Zambezi River flooding since a catastrophic 2001 flood has forced more than 68,000 people from their homes and threatens scores of thousands more, relief officials said Tuesday, but the government said it did not yet need large-scale international aid.

title: Thinking Globally, Rapids and Arsenal See Win-Win Deal
description: No one will ever accuse E. StanLEY Kroenke of thinking small.

title: All-Star Selection May Be What Anthony Needed
description: DENVER, Feb. 13  When Carmelo Anthony was named Friday to his first All-Star Game, he found his groove again. In related news, the Denver Nuggets have won three straight games.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review yesterday about News War, a four-part Frontline series on PBS, referred incorrectly to a correspondent for the series, Lowell Bergman. Although he formerly worked for The New York Times, Mr. Bergman took a leave of absence specifically to work on the News War project. He is not currently a reporter for The Times.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Grew to Another Record in 06
description: The gap between what Americans import and what they export widened to another record in 2006, totaling $763.6 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Celebrating the Ringmaster of the Restaurant Circus
description: MONACO

title: 6 Killed as Affiliate of Al Qaeda Bombs Police Stations in Algeria
description: Seven bombs exploded almost simultaneously in Algeria yesterday, killing six people and wounding more than a dozen in the worst attack in months by North Africas most active terrorist group, which says it has allied itself with Al Qaeda.

title: U.S. Legislators Want Cyprus to Extradite Indicted U.N. Official
description: The top Democrat and Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee asked Cyprus to extradite Benon V. Sevan, a Cypriot and the former United Nations official in charge of the oil-for-food program in Iraq, who was indicted by federal prosecutors in New York on charges that he accepted $160,000 in bribes from an intermediary working for Saddam Hussein. In a letter to the Cyprus mission in Washington, Tom Lantos, a California Democrat, and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican of Florida, said Cyprus should surrender Mr. Sevan for trial as proof that its membership in the European Union meant that it had entered a new era of international cooperation.

title: Giulianis Iraq Views May Provide Cover
description: In every speech he makes, Rudolph W. Giuliani talks about Iraq and makes clear that he sides with President Bush, endorsing the war and the deployment of 21,500 more troops.

title: BBC Names TV Executive for U.S. Unit
description: The BBC named a longtime television executive, Garth Ancier, as president of its United States operations yesterday, a new position that will include all of the American television operations of the subsidiary known as BBC Worldwide.

title: Pact With North Korea Draws Fire From a Wide Range of Critics in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The deal that could lead North Korea to shut its main nuclear reactor came under criticism from both ends of the political spectrum immediately after it was announced on Tuesday.

title: Applebees Explores a Sale of the Company
description: Applebees International, the operator of almost 2,000 restaurants, mainly in North America, said yesterday it might sell the company after its third-biggest shareholder accused management of failing to increase sales and cut costs.

title: No Retrial of Man Convicted in Fatal L.I. Parkway Crash
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Feb. 13  A judge rejected allegations of impropriety against former jurors on Tuesday in denying a motion for a retrial in the case of a man convicted of murder for killing two people when he crashed head-on into a limousine while driving drunk on a Long Island parkway.

title: China: Editor Freed After Three Years
description: A Chinese newspaper editor imprisoned for corruption after his newspaper broke articles about police abuse and a medical cover-up in Guangdong Province was released from prison three years early. Reporters Without Borders, a media watchdog group, said the editor, Li Minying, of Southern Metropolitan Daily, had his six-year prison term cut in half. Another editor of the paper, Yu Huafeng, is still serving a six-year sentence, also on corruption charges. The prosecution of the two men was widely viewed as retribution for reporting on matters that embarrassed powerful Communist Party officials.

title: Private Talks Held in Berlin Spurred Sides to Reach Deal
description: BEIJING, Wednesday, Feb. 14  On a Friday night in late December, the tortuous three-year diplomatic effort to end North Koreas nuclear weapons program finally seemed dead. Two months earlier, North Korea had conducted its first nuclear weapons test, and five days of talks in Beijing had just ended in failure and acrimony.

title: California Freeze Limits Citrus Supply, Sending Prices Up
description: IN New York City, the produce aisles in winter can be grim. This year even citrus  the one bright hope among the unending march of kale, squash and broccoli  offers little relief.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article and chart on Jan. 16 about the rising number of women in the United States living without spouses referred imprecisely to ages of the women included in the Census Bureau survey that was the basis of the finding. The women were 15 and older, not over 15. (Go to Article)

title: Knicks Match Dubious Total in Dramatic Fashion
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13  The 23rd victory, the one the Knicks needed to vanquish last season for good, was again within reach late Tuesday night, in another hostile arena, against another formidable opponent.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Official Indicted in Inquiry Into Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Federal prosecutors in San Diego announced on Tuesday an 11-count felony indictment charging a former high-ranking Central Intelligence Agency official with using his seniority and influence to steer contracts to a lifelong friend who had offered him a lucrative job and paid for lavish vacation travel.

title: Lawyers Defend Christian Prison Program in Iowa
description: Lawyers for Prison Fellowship Ministries and its affiliate, the Inner8Change Freedom Initiative, appeared before the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis yesterday to defend the constitutionality of an evangelical Christian rehabilitation program they operate in a state prison in Iowa.

title: Bush Offers a Rare Look at Relations With Father
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  It was a moment of public sentimentality that seemed almost un-Bush-like.

title: Sperm Donor Father Ends His Anonymity
description: There is no established ritual for how an anonymous sperm donor should contact his genetic children. But for Jeffrey Harrison, Valentines Day seemed as good an occasion as any.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the resignation of Jim Samples of Cartoon Network, which sponsored a marketing campaign that went awry and caused a bomb scare in Boston, misstated his title. He was executive vice president and general manager of the Cartoon Network, not president.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Bombs Kill 3 in Lebanon on Day Before Memorial
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 13  A day before Lebanon prepared to mark the second anniversary of the assassination of its former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, three people were killed and about 23 others wounded when two minibuses were bombed as they ferried passengers to work, to shopping and to Bible study classes.

title: Taking Advantage of Last-Minute Rentals
description: Before buying a second home, prospective buyers often test out the area by visiting and renting. Off-season rentals can be a good opportunity to do so, since rates are low and availability is often high.

title: Greatest Generation Learns About Great Safe Sex
description: The sex educators had come to a Queens housing complex to discuss condoms and foreplay and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Florence Z. Melton, 95, Creator of Slippers, Dies
description: Florence Zacks Melton, who took a material invented as a helmet liner for World War II tank crewmen and turned it into cushy foam-rubber slippers that have soothed billions of tired feet and have been a familiar gift for four decades, died Jan. 8 near her home in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 95.

title: Unlike the Knicks Censors, Jackson Likes Being Frank
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13  The folks at the Basketball Hall of Fame are considering Phil Jackson for induction this year, a nod to his nine N.B.A. championships as a coach. If the Hall had a wing for provocative quotation-makers, Jacksons bust might already be gracing the Springfield, Mass., shrine.

title: Bostons New Transition: From French to German
description: The composer Ned Rorem maintains that everything and everyone falls into either French or German aesthetic camps. The French aesthetic favors lightness, texture and surface beauty; the German is concerned with rigor, depth and structure.

title: Ecuador: Congress Approves Referendum on Constitutional Assembly
description: President Rafael Correa won congressional approval of a plan to hold a nationwide referendum on convening an assembly to rewrite Ecuadors Constitution. The measure was approved by a vote of 57 to 1 in the 100-seat Congress after opposition legislators declined to vote. Mr. Correa, left, a leftist economist educated in the United States and Belgium, says a new constitution is needed to weaken the influence of traditional political parties, which have ousted presidents with ease over the last decade. The countrys top election court set April 15 for the referendum, a court member told a local radio station, according to Reuters.

title: The Diplomatic Option (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the expected selection of Drew Gilpin Faust misstated the name of the school at Harvard of which she currently serves as dean. It is the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, not of Advanced Study.

title: A Night of Fun as the International Stars Turn
description: Most ballet star galas are a bore, short on genuine stars and long on classical war horses and undistinguished new choreography. The annual Stars of the 21st Century, the work of the husband-and- wife production team Solomon Tencer and Nadia Veselova-Tencer, tends to take itself less seriously. And despite its share of tedium, Stars, presented on Monday night at the New York State Theater, was a lot of fun.

title: For a Top New York Export, a Title and Sweet Bragging Rights
description: Of the dozens of facts and figures about sweets and flowers spilling out around Valentines Day, the most surprising may be this: According to city officials, chocolate is New Yorks No. 1 specialty-food export.

title: Board Silly
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Bloomberg Urges More Aid for Those Ailing After 9/11
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on the federal government yesterday to increase health spending sharply for thousands of people who became ill after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, and called for the creation of a special fund to compensate those who are sick.

title: Brooklyn: Boy Killed by S.U.V.
description: A 4-year-old boy was fatally struck yesterday afternoon by a sport utility vehicle, the police said. The boy, James Javarrice of Bond Street, was taken to New York Methodist Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. The accident occurred about 3:30 p.m. at the corner of Third Avenue and Baltic Street as James and his 18-year-old aunt, whom the police did not identify, were crossing Baltic Street, the police said. The aunt, who was also hit, was in stable condition at the hospital last night, the police said. The police determined that the death was an accident and the driver of the S.U.V. was not charged, the police said.

title: I.B.M. Reports a Speed Record for a Type of Computer Memory
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13  I.B.M. researchers say they have set a speed record for a type of computer memory that promises a fundamental performance increase in a coming generation of microprocessors with multiple computing engines.

title: Local Color
description: Eureka, Calif.

title: Helping People Help Themselves
description: From lather, rinse, repeat, to how you invest for retirement, the way you do most things now is the way youll continue to do them. That all-too-human tendency to favor the familiar and resist change, called status quo bias, is a central finding of behavioral economics  a discipline that fuses psychology and economics. Behavioral economics has demonstrated that in money matters (as in life), people are motivated by impulses that are measurable and predictable  and often irrational. That wont surprise anyone who ever threw good money after bad, succumbed to a fad or ate the whole thing. One of the founding fathers of behavioral economics, the late Amos Tversky of Stanford University, once quipped that the scientific exploration of human behavior illuminated what was already obvious to advertisers and used car salesmen.

title: So Naughty, So Nice
description: ITS a cake that can stop traffic. The layers are an improbable red that can vary from a fluorescent pink to a dark ruddy mahogany. The color, often enhanced by buckets of food coloring, becomes even more eye-catching set against clouds of snowy icing, like a slash of glossy lipstick framed by platinum blond curls. Even the name has a vampy allure: red velvet.

title: Albany: Budget Proposal Scrutinized
description: Legislators on both sides of the aisle picked apart Gov. Eliot Spitzers health care proposals during a budget hearing held yesterday by the State Senate and the Assembly. The hearing set the groundwork for what will arguably be the hardest-fought part of the governors $120.6 billion budget: his plan to cut more than $1.2 billion worth of Medicaid and health care spending. In the short term, this will be devastating, said Senator Martin J. Golden, a Brooklyn Republican. In the long term this might work out to some degree, but I dont quite see that.

title: Letters
description: College Cuisine

title: After Killing, Suspects Calls Stopped, Prosecutor Says
description: He called her obsessively, until she died. Then he never called her again.

title: A Film Festival as a Showcase for the Wacky, the Naughty and the Oh-So-Deep
description: Film criticism, as it has been observed, is the rationalization of taste into theory. No matter how involved the argument, writing about the movies almost always comes down to a question of personal taste, to that web of influence through which we filter each new film. In this respect there are no good or bad movies, just good and bad arguments, a thought that serves as a useful introduction to the latest edition of Film Comment Selects, a giddily idiosyncratic annual series that could only have sprung from feverishly partisan minds.

title: Teacher Faces Jail Over Pornography on Class Computer
description: Julie Amero, a substitute teacher at a middle school in Norwich, Conn., said she had simply wanted to e-mail her husband. The authorities contend that she was  purposely or, perhaps, carelessly  exposing 11- and 12-year-old students to pornography rather than teaching them English.

title: Odds Are, Theyll Know 08 Winner
description: On Election Night a few months ago, Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers gave a small party for neighbors and colleagues at their row house in Center City in Philadelphia. They connected their television to a projector, served beer and pizza and watched the returns come in.

title: Gunman Kills 3 Members of Investment Firm and Himself
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13  A shareholder who believed that he had been defrauded by a Philadelphia investment company lured three of the firms executives to an after-hours meeting Monday night where, the police said, he fatally shot them before taking his own life.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Rock Stars and Drug Troubles

title: Jurors Find More Sympathy for Defendant
description: There was surprise yesterday at Ben Odiernos murder trial in a Manhattan courtroom when the jury came back with a verdict after only four hours. But in interviews later, several jurors said that while there was some debate, the verdict was inevitable.

title: Correction: Sea Sends Distress Call in One-Note Chowders
description: An article on Jan. 17 about the response of Maine fishermen to the depletion of groundfish in New England waters misstated the regulations under which a fisherman leaving the business can transfer certain fishing rights to other boats. Such rights, called days at sea, can be transferred from one boat to another boat that is no more than 10 percent longer, or with an engine 20 percent more powerful. Those rights cannot be transferred to much bigger boats.

title: Food Calendar
description: Chinese New Year

title: Tougher Standards Urged for Federal Education Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  No Child Left Behind, the federal education law, should be toughened to judge teachers and principals by their students test scores, and to block chronically ineffective educators from working in high-poverty schools, a private bipartisan commission recommended on Tuesday.

title: With Kidd on the Bench, the Nets Miss the Point
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 13  For all the speculation that the Nets might want to trade Jason Kidd, a move that would inevitably be the first step toward rebuilding, the Nets had a hint of what that process could look like Tuesday night.

title: Troops Sweep 3 Shiite Areas in Baghdad Push
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 14  Thousands of American troops in armored Stryker vehicles swarmed three mostly Shiite neighborhoods of northeastern Baghdad on Wednesday, encountering little resistance during what commanders described as the first major sweep of the new security plan for the capital.

title: Armed With Chocolate, and Peace of Mind
description: PARAMUS, N.J.

title: Barber to Join Today Show
description: Tiki Barbers football career is officially over. By noon yesterday, he had sent his retirement papers to the Giants, the N.F.L. and the players association.

title: Japan Maintains Hardline Stance Toward North Korea
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14  South Korea seized upon the new agreement to freeze North Koreas nuclear weapons program as an opportunity today to quickly resume high-level talks with the North, contacts that the South suspended with some reluctance after the North conducted its first nuclear test detonation last October.

title: Obama, Legally Blonde?
description: IOWA FALLS

title: NBC Gives Barber the Ball, and He Runs With It
description: Tiki Barber looked the way he usually does for news conferences in front of the cameras, wearing a tailored suit, a shaved head and a high-watt grin.

title: Coast Guard Chief Announces Plans to Overhaul the Service
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Acknowledging that the Coast Guard has failed to keep up with changing times, its commandant, Adm. Thad Allen, unveiled a plan Tuesday to restructure its management radically and expand its surveillance efforts along the nations coasts.

title: Claiming Outsider Status, Romney Says Hell Seek White House
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 13  Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, came to a state where he has not lived for 41 years to declare his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination Tuesday, becoming the latest presidential candidate to position himself as an outsider running against Washington.

title: Mexico: Acapulco Mayor in Drugs Investigation
description: The national police have begun an inquiry into whether the mayor of Acapulco has had links to drug traffickers, said the countrys top police official, Genaro Garca Luna. Mayor Flix Salgado Macedonio, who belongs to the main leftist opposition party, said the government was welcome to investigate. My conscience is clear, he said in a radio interview. Acapulco has been besieged by violence as drug gangs battle for control over routes to the United States. President Felipe Caldern has sent thousands of troops and agents to several states and cities, including Acapulco, to try to end the violence.

title: Turkmenistan: All Set for a New Leader, to Be Announced
description: Turkmenistan planned a gala presidential inauguration for today, but did so without officially announcing who the president would be. An election was held Sunday. Dignitaries from around the world, including the United States, China and Russia, were en route to the gas-rich nation to attend the ceremony, which was universally expected to formalize the authority of the acting president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who was a deputy prime minister under President Saparmurat Niyazov, who died in December. An official vote count had yet to be released from the election, criticized from outside as neither free nor fair. Nevertheless, foreign governments were lining up to be the new governments suitors, hoping to secure supplies of natural gas and to urge Mr. Berdymukhammedov to liberalize his predecessors totalitarian state.

title: Cast Aside, Swede Stays Focused on Bottom of the Hill
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 13  When the medals are counted at the end of the Alpine skiing world championships, maybe the bronze that Patrik Jaerbyn of Sweden won in the downhill should be counted in the American column.

title: More Iraqi Refugees Are Headed to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Moving to address the flood of refugees fleeing war-torn Iraq, the Bush administration and the United Nations have developed a plan that would bring several thousand of them to the United States over the next 10 months, officials familiar with discussions of the plan say.

title: Putin Says Russia Would Consider Gas Alliance
description: A summary of top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.

title: House Begins Full Debate on the Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The House opened a full-throated debate on Tuesday over the Iraq war as lawmakers began considering a resolution to denounce President Bushs plan to add troops. Democratic leaders said the debate was the first step in using Congressional authority to intervene in the conflict.

title: Breaking All the Rules, With a Shrug and a Sigh
description: ROME, Feb. 13  The shrugged shoulder is real, a daily reminder here that part of Italys charm rests in the fact that it does not much care for rules. Italians can be downright poetic about it, this inclination to dodge taxes, to cut lines, to erect entire neighborhoods without permits or simply to run red lights, while smoking or talking on the phone.

title: Bent Skovmand, Seed Protector, Dies at 61
description: Bent Skovmand, a plant scientist who helped to create the doomsday vault, a massively fortified cavern to safeguard three million kinds of unique crop seeds against catastrophe, died Tuesday in Kavlinge, Sweden. He was 61.

title: Knowing Their Place and Aiming to Fill It
description: CERAMICS, carpets, baths: certain things are done better in Turkey than in many other countries, and that list includes  and could arguably be led by  the marinating, seasoning and grilling of meat, especially if its skewered.

title: Waiting Game Begins for Torre and Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 13  George Steinbrenner shuffled down the AstroTurf carpet that covers the concrete walkway to the Legends Field clubhouse. Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, wanted to sit in on Manager Joe Torres first meeting with his coaches.

title: Turkmenistans New President Takes Office
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14  A man who quietly served as an aide to Turkmenistans authoritarian first president became its second today, formally beginning a new era for a strange, reclusive nation whose vast natural gas reserves attract global attention.

title: Senator Clinton Cautions Bush on Iran
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton warned President Bush today that he cannot take military action against Iran without first receiving Congressional authorization, and said that the new Democratic majority in Congress would apply lessons from the conflict in Iraq to the unfolding confrontation with Iran over its weaponry and suspected support for Iraqi militias.

title: Sallie Mae Trading Queried
description: Democratic lawmakers said yesterday that they had requested copies of correspondence between the White House and Sallie Mae, the student loan company known as the SLM Corporation, after stock sales by the chairman days before the share price fell with the release of President Bushs budget.

title: Judge Rules Drug Documents Must Be Returned to Eli Lilly
description: A federal district judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that confidential marketing materials belonging to Eli Lilly & Company about its top-selling anti-psychotic drug Zyprexa must be returned to the company by a doctor and a lawyer who, the judge said, engaged in a scheme to leak them to the news media.

title: Two Survivors Emerge in Defeat, Their Tails Still Wagging
description: Lazarus, an Irish water spaniel, was all but dead two hours after he was born in June 2003. He was one of 11 puppies in a litter bred by Tara Darling-Lyon in Port Chester, N.Y., the first litter for his mother. He was healthy for those two hours and seemingly without a problem. The concern for Darling-Lyon and the litters co-owner, Mindy Garbarino, was the last puppy, who was stillborn. They tried, but failed, to bring him back.

title: For a Chilly Winter Day, Beef Pie With Polenta Crust
description: Twin Hens, a company in Princeton, N.J., that sells excellent chicken pot pies, has now introduced individual beef pot pies with polenta crusts. Theyre not much to look at  a yellow topping in a foil container  but the rich aromas and the deep tomato-wine flavor are thoroughly tempting. The frozen pies take about 40 minutes to bake, without thawing first, in a conventional oven. The beef is antibiotic-free, the vegetables are organic and the polenta crust enriched with cheese. They are about $8 each at stores including Dean & DeLuca and Whole Foods.

title: Still in Third Place, but Working Hard to Move Up
description: Diane Sawyer, a host of ABCs Good Morning America, looked an awful lot like a globe-trotting, war-seasoned evening news anchor as she donned a head scarf to confront the president of Iran on Mondays evening news.

title: Paints Mysteries Challenge Protectors of Modern Art
description: LOS ANGELES  In a sprawling, white-on-white lab here that looks like a set from Stanley Kubricks 2001: A Space Odyssey, a British scientist named Thomas Learner recently lifted the top from a small box of slides, the kind that usually contain microscopic samples of bacteria or chemicals.

title: World Bank in the Docket, Charged With Africas Woes
description: I have never seen a film quite like Bamako, Abderrahmane Sissakos seething, complicated and disarmingly beautiful investigation of Africas social, economic and human crises. The agony of Africa has been explored, and exploited, in several high-profile recent documentaries and fictional features, from God Grew Tired of Us, about the lost boys of Sudan, to Blood Diamond and The Constant Gardener. Bamako is something different: a work of cool intelligence and profound anger, a long, dense, argument that is also a haunting visual poem.

title: Man Who Stabbed Wife Is Acquitted
description: A man who stabbed his wife to death after his marriage deteriorated into what he described as a decade-long period of psychological warfare was acquitted of murder yesterday.

title: Sacred Sites
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Winter Storm Travels East
description: A snow and ice storm reached the East Coast on Wednesday after paralyzing parts of the Midwest the day before.

title: Toyota Grooms Its Future Leaders
description: As part of its strategy to hold onto its No. 1 global spot, Toyota has opened a technical high school to train future factory leaders.

title: $100,000 Poetry Prize Awarded
description: One of the richest prizes in poetry, the Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award, has gone to Rodney Jones, a professor of English at Southern Illinois University. Mr. Jones, the author of a collection titled "Salvation Blues" (Houghton Mifflin), will receive $100,000 from Claremont Graduate University, which selects the winner. Claremont chose Eric McHenry, a Seattle poet, as the winner of the Kate Tufts Discovery Award for his book "Potscrubber Lullabies," published by the Waywiser Press. He will receive $10,000.

title: Deconstructing the Megapixel Myth
description: My column in The Times last week, about the general irrelevance of megapixels in consumer cameras, stirred up an enormous volume of feedback.

title: Is an Encore Likely for the Encores! Follies?
description: The talk of Broadway this week has been City Center's Encores! presentation of "Follies," which starred Victor Garber, Donna Murphy and Victoria Clark and closed on Monday.

title: Fund Seeks Data on Delta-Northwest Talks
description: Delta Air Lines, which previously downplayed reports that it held merger talks with Northwest Airlines, acknowledged holding discussions about a possible business combination with Northwest while it was fighting a $10 billion hostile bid from US Airways. The disclosure stemmed from a dispute involving a group of dissatisfied Northwest shareholders, led by hedge fund Owl Creek Asset Management.

title: Personal Style
description: Models made their own fashion statements during New York Fashion Week.

title: Four Car-Rental Brands May Merge
description: A deal to combine four of the nations largest car rental brands  National, Alamo, Thrifty and Dollar  is being discussed as the industry continues to consolidate. Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group is in early talks to merge with Vanguard Car Rental, of Tulsa, Okla., which owns National and Alamo, in a deal valued at more than $3 billion, according to The New York Times.

title: Chrysler to Announce Job Cuts, Plant Closings
description: The Chrysler Group is set to announce a restructuring plan Wednesday aimed at securing its place in the crowded American car market  and within DaimlerChrysler. The plan is expected to include the elimination of about 11,000 blue- and white-collar jobs along with the closing of one and possibly two assembly plants  in Delaware and Missouri, The New York Times said.

title: Under Pressure, CVS Raise Its Bid for Caremark
description: The battle for Caremark Rx, the pharmacy benefits manager, moved beyond a war of words yesterday as CVS raised its bid for the company for the second time, to $25.7 billion.

title: Former Chief of Bawag Bank Is Extradited to Austria
description: The former chief executive of Bawag, the Austrian bank that almost collapsed because of its ties to the failed U.S. futures brokerage firm Refco, was extradited to Austria from France on Tuesday to face trial on fraud charges linked to billions of euros of losses during his tenure.

title: Buyout Shops Doubled Down in Canada Last Year
description: Dramatic growth in the Canadian buyout market led to record levels of private equity investment in 2006, according to a report released Tuesday. The total value of disclosed investments in Canadian companies by buyout funds more than doubled to $10.9 billion in 2006 from the $4.5 billion reported in 2005, Thomson Financial and Canadas Venture Capital and Private Equity Association said in a joint report.

title: U.K. Retail Mogul Takes Sportswear Empire to Market
description: British retail billionaire Mike Ashley has unveiled a plan for a 2 billion pound ($3.9 billion) initial public offering of his Sports Direct empire in a move that could see him pocket up to 890 million pounds. Sports Direct, Britains biggest sportswear retailer, said its shares will be priced at between 250 pence and 310 pence each, valuing the business at between 1.8 billion pounds and 2.2 billion pounds.

title: A Kinder Telecom Market Sparks I.P.O. Chatter
description: Despite the fall from grace that initial public offerings of telecommunications companies took following the tech bust in 1999, some brave souls are once again eyeing the public markets. MetroPCS Wireless, which filed for bankruptcy in the 1990s and canceled a planned I.P.O. in 2004 due to accounting problems, is now hoping to raise $1.2 billion when it goes public in the next few months.

title: Is V.C. Gloom Over I.P.O.s Exaggerated?
description: Last year was the best for venture-backed initial public offerings since the bubble burst, and this year looks even better. So why, wonders The San Jose Mercury News, are venture capitalists so gloomy about I.P.O.s?

title: Nasdaq Chief Says He Chose Not to Win L.S.E.
description: Nasdaq Stock Market Chief Executive Robert Greifeld had what seemed like a somewhat novel take on his resounding defeat on the bid for the London Stock Exchange. Speaking Tuesday during a conference call to announce Nasdaqs fourth-quarter results, Mr. Greifeld said that he chose not to win the war for the overseas rival, after L.S.E. shareholders, calling Nasdaqs bid of 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) too low, suggested higher prices they might accept. Nasdaq ended up with commitments of less than 0.5 percent from L.S.E. shareholders.

title: A $100 Billion L.B.O.? Keep Dreaming
description: Why stop at $39 billion? The Blackstone Group set a record for leveraged buyouts with its deal for Equity Office Properties Trust last week, driving investment bankers mad with the idea that an even bigger whale of a buyout is swimming out there. And in this private equity boom, giants once thought of as unthinkable buyout candidates  Home Depot, Yahoo  have been floated as possible targets.

title: Cerberus Snow Calls on China to Open the Gates
description: Cerberus Capital Management Chairman and former U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow said China needs to open the countrys market for overseas investors to create the 25 million new jobs a year the nation needs. His call comes as New York-based Cerberus is opening a Hong Kong office to expand into China, the worlds fastest-growing major economy, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Societe Generale Reports Profit Increase
description: Societe Generale, Frances third-largest bank, reported a 6.3 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit on higher consumer lending outside its home market and increased revenue at the investment bank. Net income climbed to 1.18 billion euros ($1.54 billion), or 2.71 euros a share, from 1.11 billion euros, or 2.69 euros a share, a year earlier. Profit missed the 1.24 billion euro median estimate of 12 analysts Bloomberg News surveyed by phone and e-mail. Costs and bad-loan provisions exceeded forecasts.

title: Commerzbank Posts Rise in Profits
description: Commerzbank, Germanys second-largest bank by assets, said fourth-quarter profit rose 4.1 percent on higher trading and fee income. Net income climbed to 352 million euros ($459 million) from 338 million euros a year earlier. That missed the 393 million-euro median estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News.

title: Italian Bank Backs Alitalia Bid
description: Intesa Sanpaolo, Italys second-biggest bank, will back Air One owner Carlo Totos bid for a stake in Alitalia with initial financing of 105 million euros ($137 million), the lenders chief said. We are committed to studying together a plan for Alitalia, Corrado Passera told Bloomberg News. The 105 million is only an initial investment.

title: Voice Mail Solutions
description: The Times's David Pogue reviews new services that allow you to check your voice mail quickly and easily.

title: Inside Stephen Schwarzmans Birthday Bash
description: High finance, politics and a bit of celebrity came together Tuesday evening as guests gathered to celebrate the 60th birthday of Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of Blackstone Group.

title: More on Mirrens Inevitability
description: Little Gold Men points us to an item reporting that best actress nominee Judi Dench is opting for knee surgery over attendance at the Oscar ceremony. Not much difference, really, between going under the knife and pretending to smile while losing a competition being watched by the whole world.

title: The Queen Was Not Ever Thus
description: Before people get hung up on Helen Mirren winning everything in sight and coming to believe shes royally entitled, its worth glancing at this story from Reuters and a thought from Tom ONeil of TheEnvelope.com.

title: Real Horrorshow
description: The Rocky Horror Picture Show had a big effect on me. I sang it at a talent show in a negligee at summer camp. There was a period when I did wear womens clothes a little too often for a child entering puberty.Judd Apatow, director of 40 Year-Old Virgin, blogging about musical biopics on MTV.

title: King Me
description: Larry King not only throws softballs on his show, he hands out bonbons whenever a movie is short on blurbs.

title: Oh No You Didnt
LiveOps Rings Up $28 Million
description: LiveOps, which supplies call-center services through independent contractors working out of their homes, said it received $28 million in a third round of funding led by Benchmark Capital.

title: Whats Love Got to Do With It?
description: WARNING, SEMI-SPOILER CONTENT AHEAD

title: Takeover Speculation Heats Up Aluminum Sector
description: Speculation that mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are both circling U.S. aluminum producer Alcoa has, unsurprisingly, turned industry watchers attention to other possible takeover targets in the industry.

title: The End of Guilt-Free Chocolate
description: If youre eating chocolate on Valentines Day, you should worry about more than calories, says The Los Angeles Times editorial page. Leonardo DiCaprio hasnt yet turned up in a movie about Blood Chocolate, but as valentines from coast to coast open heart-shaped boxes of bonbons today, they might give some thought to an industry that is nearly as harmful to human rights in Africa today as the diamond trade was a decade ago, the L.A. Times editorial suggests. About 70 percent of the worlds cocoa is grown in West Africa, with Ivory Coast accounting for about 40 percent. Just as blood diamonds helped finance some of Africas most brutal wars, cocoa helps subsidize political instability and bloodshed in Ivory Coast. But chocolates bitter aftertaste comes from the fact that the industry is a magnet for child slavery.

title: Personal Shopper
description: In Paris, glamorous textiles make a comeback.

title: Currents
description: From Germany, a new chair that wants to be a car, antiques, floor coverings and more.

title: Bill Snares Osama Guy
description: Thats the headline in some editions of the New York Post today, with a story about South Carolina State Senator Robert Fords decision to back Hillary Rodham Clinton  thanks to intervention from her husband  instead of Barack Obama. The headline was fixed for later editions.

title: 2008: Giulianis Insecurities
description: For all the praise he won for his handling of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Rudolph W. Giuliani has a security problem. His campaign playbooks, including blunt assessments of his political liabilities, keep ending up in the wrong hands. This time, 1993 memo about his campaign for mayor of New York is available on TheSmokingGun.com. (Howard Kurtz has highlights in The Washington Post.)

title: A Second Casualty in the Edwards Blog Wars
description: Melissa McEwan, another prominent liberal blogger hired by the John Edwards presidential campaign, has resigned. McEwan explains her reasoning in a post at her blog, Shakespeares Sister: I was not hired as a blogger, but a part-time technical advisor, which is the role I am vacating, she writes. I would like to make very clear that the campaign did not push me out, nor was my resignation the back-end of some arrangement made last week. This was a decision I made, with the campaigns reluctant support, because my remaining the focus of sustained ideological attacks was inevitably making me a liability to the campaign, and making me increasingly uncomfortable with my and my familys level of exposure.

title: Free Condoms on the Subway? And Who Says New Yorkers Arent Friendly?
description: We ask you, dear readers: Is there any more appropriate way to mark Valentines Day in New York City than to have a total stranger approach you at a dirty subway station and hand you a condom?

title: DeLay in Awe
Mets Ease Into Life in Port St. Lucie
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  During the few days before pitchers and catchers report, the Mets work out of the minor-league complex, across the property from their Tradition Field clubhouse, setting the stage for one of the more peculiar spring scenes. Everyone from Class A pitchers to star infielder David Wright changes, showers and eats here. But there is a catch.

title: Yankees Make Tampa Home
description: TAMPA, Fla.  If youre into omens, the skies were stormy over Legends Field yesterday, the official reporting date for the Yankees spring training. But there were also familiar signs of a new season yawning awake.

title: Great Cellar, Now Lets Drink
description: My column this week is about the dream wine cellar of Park B. Smith, one of the worlds great collectors who stores more than 65,000 bottles in what must be one of the worlds great cellars in his weekend house in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Overstocks Foes Win One
description: Gradient Analytics, a research firm known for a willingness to criticize companies, has won a legal battle. It released today a letter from the San Francisco office of the Securities and Exchange Commission saying that no enforcement action would be taken.

title: U.S. Sweeps Shiite Areas of Baghdad
description: Thousands of American troops swarmed three mostly Shiite neighborhoods of northeastern Baghdad.

title: War at Home: The Ad Wars Begin Anew
description: This just fell into our mailbox this morning as another sign that as early as it is, the situation in Iraq has ramifications for senators and representatives up for re-election in 2008

title: Sale of Chrysler Is on the Table
description: Shares of DaimlerChrysler rose 4 percent Wednesday after the company suggested that a sale of its Chrysler unit, which lost nearly $1.5 billion last year, was not out of the question. The idea has been raised a number of times by DaimlerChrysler shareholders and industry analysts, and DaimlerChrysler has previously said that a spinoff of the unit was possible. But Wednesdays declaration that no option is being excluded in the interest of arriving at the best possible solution for the Chrysler Group and DaimlerChrysler as a whole, accompanied by a plan to eliminate 13,000 Chrysler jobs, seemed to increase speculation that DaimlerChrysler was preparing to seek out potential buyers for the unit.

title: Q & A: Nori Sugie
description: Nori Sugie has been in charge of the kitchen at Asiate, which is on the 35th floor of the Mandarin Oriental hotel, since the restaurant opened in December 2003. Before Asiate, he co-owned, and cooked at, Restaurant VII in Sydney, Australia. He has also worked for Charlie Trotter in the past. He grew up in Japan and got his culinary education there and in France. He is 36.

title: Reader Responses to the Column
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's Feb. 14 column on prediction markets:

title: S.E.C. Drops Inquiry into Research Shop, Report Says
description: Gradient Analytics can breathe a little easier now. Citing unnamed sources, the New York Post reported that the Securities and Exchange Commission is dropping an investigation into the independent research firms relationship with short-selling hedge funds. Gradient had faced legal heat from online retailer Overstock.com and Canadian drug maker Biovail, who had accused the company of publishing negative reports on the two companies to help short sellers.

title: Buying Land: A Love Story
description: I didnt know it at the time, but the account of how Paul and I bought land in Florida is a love story.

title: A New Jingle for Your Pocket
description: The U.S. government plans to release new one-dollar coins with the hope that the coins will meet the public's approval.

title: 36 Hours in Mexico City
description: A weekend itinerary in a city whose cultural scene is both classic and kitsch.

title: Rearranging the Furniture for a Trio of Golden Monkeys
description: The Los Angeles Daily News reports (as do other sources) that the Los Angeles Zoo may well be the first in the nation to have hired a feng shui expert to ensure that a trio of blue-faced golden monkeys set to debut next year will enjoy good feng shui vibrations at a $7.4 million enclosure being built there for them.

title: Valentines Day at Legends Field
description: Andy Pettitte was talking with the writers today when his cellphone rang. Pettitte sheepishly took the call  the ringtone was a love song, Amazed, by Lonestar  and his wife Laura was on the line.

title: Bush: Iranian Weapons in Iraq
description: Feb. 14 - President Bush says he's convinced Iran is supplying weapons to fighters in Iraq.

title: Should Blake Zig Just Because Nardelli Zagged?
description: He may have been autocratic and very well compensated, but former Home Depot chief executive Robert Nardelli may also have been onto something. That is the suggestion that a few analysts are making as they evaluate the recent decision by Mr. Nardellis successor, Frank Blake, to consider selling Home Depots contractor-supply business. Building that business was a pet project of Mr. Nardelli, who was convinced that the consumer remodeling market was reaching maturity. He pinned his strategy  and much of the companys capital  on HD Supply, the Home Depot division that serves commercial customers.

title: Will Write for Plaque
description: The publisher of New Political Review  an online newsletter published twice a month from Blue Bell, Pa.  has named Gov. Eliot Spitzer Americas Most Outstanding Leader for the month of February. From the release:

title: Day Two at the Dog Show
description: A 7-year-old English springer spaniel won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York.

title: Trading on 2008 Futures
description: Let us now check in with the most accurate political forecaster in the land. This forecaster correctly called every individual Senate race in 2006 and missed only one in 2004 (Alaska, which wasnt easy). It also made the right call on every state in the 2004 presidential election.

title: Red Bull Snorts to the Front
description: Red Bull must have read my blog entry yesterday, right? (Or could it be because Dietrich Mateschitz, the head of the Red Bull energy drink company, was at the track?) In any case, todays testing times from Barcelona only confirm the lack of any one team in dominating form. There is a report at Autosport quoting Fernando Alonso himself as saying the same. Red Bull said in a statement that more than 21,000 people attended the testing at the circuit over the last three days  imagine how well the race will be attended in May.

title: Where Else Is A Hotel $2 a Night?
description: Im regularly badgering students to travel abroad and, especially, to escape their comfort zones and visit the developing world. So heres a more specific suggestion: take a vacation trip to Ethiopia, for its a perfect place to make a first visit to Africa.

title: Blogtalk: The Borja Case
description: Bloggers continue to weigh in  heres Gawker  on the article by Sewell Chan and Al Baker of The Times about the police officer who became a symbol of 9/11-related illnesses. A selection:

title: Bush and the Houses War Debate
description: At his news conference today, President Bush walked a very measured line on the Iraq war debate that is taking place in the House this week, allowing for Congresss right to express its opinions.

title: Musical Uniforms
description: The Yanks arent the only ones with new uniforms this spring. The Mets new duds are blue pullovers with black and orange stripes along the flanks. No silver, though.

title: Quattrone Drops Hints About His Next Move
description: Few people know exactly what Frank Quattrone, formerly the sine qua non of technology bankers, is going to do next. Lots of people seem to think it will be big. Mr. Quattrone isnt telling.

title: Metaphor Watch
description: Azi Paybarah reports  today in the citys newest tabloid that Eliot Spitzer has a secret plan to scare vulnerable Republican state senators to switch parties, giving him a second Democratic majority to neutralize the one in the Assembly led by Sheldon Silver.

title: The Condom Underground
description: We ask you, dear readers. Is there any more appropriate way to mark Valentines Day in New York City than to have a total stranger approach you on a dirty subway station and hand you a condom? Seems the citys Health Department, with the nod of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, is using Cupids holiday to launch its New York City-themed prophylactic  but this isnt just some tourist attraction.

title: Bloomberg by the Numbers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg put out a self-report card for the year  technically, the Preliminary Mayors Management Report.

title: Bush and the Libby Case
description: President Bush wouldnt take the bait today. He declined to answer when Peter Baker, one of the White House correspondents for The Washington Post, asked about present and former administration officials  other than I. Lewis Scooter Libby  who have been mentioned by witnesses as having disclosed the identity of the C.I.A. operative Valerie Wilson to reporters.

title: Mo Money Will Have to Wait
description: From the sound of it, Mariano Rivera came growling into spring training, threatening to leave the Yankees if he did not get a contract extension. At least, thats the impression General Manager Brian Cashman got from reading some of Riveras comments the other day. But Cashman spoke to Rivera on Tuesday night to get his own version. When youre the GM, you get all the exclusive interviews you want.

title: Children, Let Me Tell You About a Place Called Amsterdam
description: One thing is clear from a new United Nations report on the overall well-being of children in the wealthier parts of the world: Northern European kids  and, uh, Spanish ones  are lucky ducks!

title: Franken Serious About Senate
description: Suddenly, the idea of Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert on a presidential ticket doesnt seem so far-fetched. Not now that Al Franken, the comedian, ex-Air America host (as of today) and author (Rush Limbaugh is a Big, Fat Idiot) is asking Why Not Me? for real.

title: Blogtalk: Smoke and Passion
description: Its Valentines Day and couples everywhere are cooking meals, pouring wine and presenting flowers across candlelight. But, theres a cold wind in Congress as Republicans and Democrats fight over wholl be sleeping on the couch. The bitter debate in the House over the nonbinding resolution of opposition to President Bushs plan to increase troop levels spilled onto the blogs, already heated over Iran.

title: Blogtalk: Roses and Ice
description: Joe Bruno gave bouquets of roses to Gov. Eliot Spitzer (and, later, to Assembly Speaker Sheldon SIlver). [Politics on the Hudson]

title: The Two Haitis
description: There are two Haitis today: one where tourists play and another that is plagued by poverty and violence.

title: The Oscars in Times Square
description: Dozens of Oscar statues magically appear in Times Square and the Bagger is there to greet them.

title: Marijuana Science
description: For researchers studying marijuana, its been a very good week. In one of the most careful studies to date, marijuana was found to relieve pain. And a judge ruled in favor of an agronomist who has has been trying for six years to overcome one of the problems of marijuana research: the lack of an adequate supply of the drug for experiments.

title: John Maine, Division Champion
description: Before most games last season, John Maine sat on a stool facing his locker. He did crossword puzzles or sudoku, often with his headphones blasting Metallica, but he took enough breaks to reveal a wry sense of humor. His personality is shining through more now than ever.

title: Analyst Greenfield Thinks, and Acts, Like an Activist Investor
description: Nearly five years after Wall Streets sweeping settlement with regulators over its conflicted research business, the analytical path of least resistance still reigns, writes BusinessWeeks Roben Farzad. That sounds a little like the dilemma faced by the Washington press corps, often accused with avoiding tough questions to keep lines of communication open. But Richard S. Greenfield of Pali Research may be the Helen Thomas of Wall Street analysts. He stands out in the sea of noncommittal analysis by making pointed demands, the sort you hear from an agitating hedge fund manager, Mr. Farzad writes.

title: A Push for Dollar Coins, Using Presidential Fervor
description: The first in a series of presidential dollars will enter circulation today, showing portraits of all deceased American presidents, in order of their service. The United States Mint hopes that, unlike the Susan B. Anthony and Sacagawea dollar coins, they will actually circulate, not end up in coin collections.

title: Ex-Official Is Not Target of Abramoff Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The governments former top environmental prosecutor has been told by Justice Department officials that she does not face charges in the corruption investigation centered on the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, her lawyer said Wednesday.

title: Russian Trial on Journalists Slaying Opens
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  The retrial of three men charged with murdering Paul Klebnikov, the American editor of the Russian-language edition of Forbes magazine here, opened in confusion today as the two suspects failed to appear in court and the judge postponed the beginning of jury selection for a month.

title: Fisk University Strikes Deal on Paintings
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 15  Fisk University, which has been embroiled in a year-long dispute over two prominent paintings, will be allowed under a settlement to sell the works if a donor is not found to keep the collection intact.

title: Fed Chief Says Outlook Is Positive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, gave Congress an upbeat view of the economy on Wednesday, predicting that unemployment was likely to remain low over the next two years even as inflation declined slightly.

title: Rock-a-Bye Baby With Wireless Melody  and a Field of Stars on the Wall
description: Wireless devices are now ubiquitous, and all those stray radio waves can wreak havoc on cordless phones and baby monitors. The Philips SCD589 DECT Baby Monitor is designed to resist radio interference, offering clear sound over a distance of up to 900 feet.

title: Corrections: Whatever Happened to Jane Fonda in Tights?
description: An article last Thursday about injuries caused by the aerobics trend of the 1980s misstated the year in which Jane Fonda opened her first workout studio. It was 1979, not 1978.

title: Iraq War Planner Was Hired by Military University, Briefly
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Last June, Douglas J. Feith, a former top Pentagon official involved in planning the Iraq war, was hired by a Defense Department graduate school for military officers and diplomats, with a four-year contract that was to pay him half a million dollars, Pentagon records show.

title: Thomas Fairchild, 94, Dies; Tried to Unseat McCarthy
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14  Thomas E. Fairchild, a federal appeals court judge for four decades who tried unsuccessfully to unseat Senator Joseph McCarthy in 1952, died on Monday in Madison, Wis. He was 94.

title: State Farm Ends New Property Coverage in Mississippi
description: State Farm, the largest insurer in Mississippi, said yesterday that it had decided to stop selling new policies on homes and small businesses across the state as it faces hundreds of lawsuits over claims from Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

title: Oil Company to Pay $200 Million in Toxic Dumping in Ivory Coast
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 14  An oil trading company based in the Netherlands has agreed to pay almost $200 million to the government of Ivory Coast to settle claims that it illegally dumped toxic petrochemical waste in Abidjan last August.

title: Bronx: Man Charged in August Killing
description: An 18-year-old Bronx man was arrested and charged yesterday in the August killing of a neighbor, the police said. The man, David Clarke, was charged with second-degree murder in the stabbing of Jonathan Diaz, 20, during a street fight on Aug. 25, 2006. The men lived within two blocks of each other on Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Bay Shore: Fire Destroys Flower Shop
description: A Main Street flower shop was destroyed by fire late Tuesday night, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. Fire was reported at the shop, Patthey Flowers, about 11:30 p.m., the police said. The building was unoccupied at the time, and no injuries were reported. Heavy equipment was used to remove the collapsed roof from the rear of the building to help the firefighters, the police said. The fire is not considered suspicious, the police said yesterday.

title: Keeping Tabs on Your Fat
description: STUDIES have found that a persons body-fat percentage can often be a better indicator of health than weight. So its not surprising that sales of scales with built-in body-fat monitors are up. Last year 436,000 units that measure body fat were sold, up from 316,000 in 2004, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm.

title: Help Not Wanted
description: Washington

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Supercharged With All the Answers
description: WHAT was the first wild-card team to win a Super Bowl? Who was Nixons running mate when he lost to Kennedy? What was the best Broadway musical in 1995?

title: Senate Plans to Vote Again on War Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Senate will convene in an unusual Saturday session to vote on the same resolution under debate in the House that expresses disapproval of President Bushs troop buildup, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, said today.

title: Albany: Governor Announces Appointments
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced several administrative appointments and nominations yesterday, including the president of the Civil Service Commission and a new inspector general for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. John C. Egan, president of the Renaissance Corporation and former chief of the Albany International Airport, was nominated as general services commissioner; Nancy G. Groenwegen, an assistant attorney general, was nominated as president of the Civil Service Commission; Robert Hermann, a lawyer in private practice, was appointed as director of the Governors Office of Regulatory Reform; and Barry L. Kluger, the chief assistant district attorney in the Bronx, was nominated as the transportation authority inspector general. The nominations must be confirmed by the State Senate.

title: Saying He Was Misled by Defense, Judge in Libby Case Puts Some Evidence Off-Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The lawyers defending I. Lewis Libby Jr. against perjury charges rested their case on Wednesday, but not before suffering a series of defeats in rulings by the presiding judge.

title: Volkswagen Withdraws Ad That Involved Suicide
description: For the second time in a week, an automaker has agreed to stop running a television commercial that activists complained made light of suicide.

title: Few Encounters in Sweep of Baghdad, the Americans First Under Bushs Security Plan
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 14  Thousands of American troops in armored Stryker vehicles swarmed three mostly Shiite neighborhoods of northeastern Baghdad on Wednesday, encountering little resistance during what commanders described as the first major sweep of the new security plan for the capital.

title: A Health Care Plan So Simple, Even Stephen Colbert Couldnt Simplify It
description: In his State of the Union address, President Bush proposed tax cuts to make health insurance more affordable for the uninsured. The next day, Stephen Colbert had this to say on his show on Comedy Central: Its so simple. Most people who cant afford health insurance also are too poor to owe taxes. But if you give them a deduction from the taxes they dont owe, they can use the money theyre not getting back from what they havent given to buy the health care they cant afford.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: For Bloggers, Libby Trial Is Fun and Fodder
description: The perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., former top aide to Vice President Dick Cheney, has drawn every major news organization in the country to the federal courthouse in Washington. But none has fielded a bigger team  or was more openly crushed by the defense decision this week not to put Mr. Cheney and Mr. Libby on the stand  than Firedoglake.com.

title: In State Legislatures, Democrats Are Pushing Toward Parity Between the Sexes
description: WOODBURY, Minn.  Three middle-aged Democratic women  a high school English teacher, an economist and an education lobbyist, none of whom had ever run for office  took on three Republican state legislators last year in this conservative, traditionally Republican town and swept the field.

title: Currys Development a Barometer for the Knicks
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 14  Eddy Currys growth spurt as a player and the Knicks gradual revival have been in lockstep since the start of the season. It was only natural, then, that Currys latest feat secured a major milestone for his team and his coach.

title: Study Questions Prospects for Much Lower Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  As Democratic leaders in Congress prepare to put climate change legislation on the agenda, some in the utility industry are arguing that it will take decades of investments and innovation to get substantial reductions in their emissions of greenhouse gases.

title: Germany Battling Rising Tide of Corporate Corruption
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 14  Wolfgang Schaupensteiner has never been so busy.

title: A Push for Dollar Coins, Using Presidential Fervor
description: The United States Mint has been working around the clock to turn out the first of its new series of Presidential Dollar coins for their debut today. And it has been working just as hard to make sure that the new coins dont end up as just another collectors item.

title: Vintage Clothes With an Eye on Tomorrow
description: AT just under 5-foot-3, with a body my mother describes as well covered, I often find my love of high fashion to be a sadly one-sided affair. So when I walked into Frock, a vintage store on the Lower East Side, the first thing I asked was, Do you have anything to fit me?

title: British Court-Martial Drops Charges in Iraq Abuse Case
description: LONDON, Feb. 14  A court-martial on Wednesday dropped charges against four of seven soldiers accused of mistreating Iraqi civilians, an unexpected twist in a politically charged trial that jeopardized the reputation of the British military. It also dropped the remaining charges against a fifth soldier who had already pleaded guilty.

title: With Cars Snowed In, Drivers Lament Tickets
description: New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended the citys decision not to suspend its alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules even after some residents complained that their cars were ticketed for illegal parking when snow plows left them buried in mounds of snow and unable to be moved.

title: Debate Over Children and Psychiatric Drugs
description: Early on the morning of Dec. 13, police officers responding to a 911 call arrived at a house in Hull, Mass., a seaside town near Boston, and found a 4-year-old girl on the floor of her parents bedroom, dead.

title: Brooklyn: Translator Admits Possessing Classified Data
description: A former contractor hired as an Arabic translator by the Army pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to illegally possessing national defense documents, prosecutors said. The translator, who is known to prosecutors by aliases including Noureddine Malki and Almaliki Nour, admitted possessing documents including a classified battle map from the August 2004 battle of Najaf, Iraq, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. F.B.I. agents recovered the documents when searching the translators apartment in September 2005, she said. In December 2005, the translator pleaded guilty to using a false identity to apply for United States citizenship, Ms. Mauskopf said.

title: Why Accuse Iran of Meddling Now? U.S. Officials Explain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  One of the questions posed by skeptics about the Bush administration assertions about Irans meddling in Iraq is why the charges are coming to light only now, when American officials say the shipment of lethal weapons from Iran to Shiite militias was first detected several years ago.

title: All the Worlds a Stage (That Includes the Internet)
description: AT lunchtime, or when he is walking the halls of his workplace, Roy Raphaelis colleagues often beseech him to do a magic trick. Usually, he obliges. I take the opportunity to show people my new stuff and see how they react, said Mr. Raphaeli, 23, a Brooklynite who works for a mail-order camera retailer.

title: Making White Mischief
description: AS long as the temperature drops below freezing for one night, you can make snow with a miniature version of the machines used at ski resorts  essentially air compressors and pressure washers fitted out with water hoses and a spray wand.

title: Freedom for Prisoners of Voice Mail
description: When you dig down past the megahertz and pixels and scroll wheels, all technology boils down to variations of time is money  and nobody knows it better than cellphone carriers. Every time you use your cellphone, youre spending money.

title: Yes, Son of Sam Slept Here
description: YONKERS  The name has been changed. So has the address. But still, 30 years after 1977  the so-called Summer of Sam  they still stop and stare.

title: The Other Brave Volunteers in Iraq: The Envoys (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Has Trumpet, Will Surprise
description: The same night that some rather questionable choices were under consideration in the jazz categories at the Grammy Awards, there was the trumpeter John McNeil, one of the best improvisers working in jazz, performing in the small back room of Biscuit, a barbecue restaurant in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Mr. McNeil plays at Biscuit every Sunday, leading a band with the tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry.

title: U.S. Reverses on Cause of Copter Crash
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 14  A Marine transport helicopter that crashed last week northwest of Baghdad was shot down, the top United States military spokesman in Iraq said Wednesday, reversing the militarys earlier contention that mechanical failures had caused the crash.

title: The Toyota Way Is Translated for a New Generation of Foreign Managers
description: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  It does not occupy much space on the office wall, but Latondra Newton calls it the hardest thing for Toyotas new American employees to accept: those colored bar charts against a white bulletin board, in plain view for all to see.

title: Group Asks Mayor to Rethink Further Changes to Schools
description: A broad coalition of elected officials, parent and community advocates and union leaders urged Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to halt his latest proposed reorganization of the city school system. The group said recent problems, including midyear changes to school bus routes and an increase in school safety incidents, had raised serious questions about the administrations ability to manage the system and carry out further changes.

title: A New Camel Brand Is Dressed to the Nines
description: THE next time R. J. Reynolds Tobacco asks smokers to walk a mile for a Camel, watch how many of them are in high heels.

title: Just Like Old Times, Yanks Look to Pettitte
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 14  In the itinerant world of a baseball player, it is possible to leave home to go home again. That was the sensation Andy Pettitte felt the other day, when he stuffed his suitcases at home in Deer Park, Tex., for a long season with his old team, the Yankees.

title: A Tree-Hugger Shows Her Affection With a Saw
description: I HAD actually been waiting for a hard freeze so I could go out and prune my old pear tree. Those 60- and 70-degree days in my garden last month made me wonder if the shrubs and trees, with their bulging buds, would ever go dormant.

title: The Korea Accord: Hope and Doubt (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brainman, at Rest in His Oasis
description: BROOMFIELD, England

title: Newly Released
description: For publishers February seems to be First Novel Month: five of the six books on this months newly released list are by freshman novelists (though several of the writers have previously published books of nonfiction or short stories). They are set all around the world, from Libya in the late 70s to a New York publishing house seemingly yesterday.

title: Calendar
description: Gardening and Chocolate

title: Manhattan: City Prevails in Lawsuit by Demonstrator
description: A jury in Federal District Court has rejected a claim by a man who said the police falsely arrested him and used excessive force during a protest in 2003, lawyers for the city said yesterday. The plaintiff, Jonathan Bradley, was arrested during an antiwar rally on Feb. 15, 2003.
