On Friday, the federal jury concluded that Mr. Bradley had been falsely arrested, but said the arresting officer had not acted unreasonably, which was a requirement for ruling against the city, city lawyers said. The jury also found that excessive force was not used in the arrest, said Kate OBrien Ahlers, a spokeswoman for the citys Law Department.

title: U.S. Considers Broader Visa Plan for Iraqis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The Bush administration is considering legislation that would allow Iraqis who have been singled out as collaborators for working or associating with American officials to come to the United States on special immigrant visas or through other programs, officials said Wednesday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: White Stripes to Join Police at Bonnaroo Festival

title: Malawi: Campaign to Reduce Maternal Deaths
description: Malawi opened a battle to reduce its high number of maternal deaths during childbirth, pledging to reduce the rate of 984 deaths for every 100,000 live births by 75 percent by 2015. A $2 million program, financed in part by the World Health Organization and the European Union, will address what the Health Ministry called a national emergency. One of Africas poorest nations, Malawi suffers from an acute shortage of medical workers, many of whom migrate to work in Europe, and a lack of emergency facilities. Only Sierra Leone and Afghanistan have higher rates of death during childbirth.

title: A Gift of Roses to Melt the Ice in the Capitol
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  Was it an end to major combat operations? Or was it a mere cease-fire, like the Christmas truce of 1914, when German and British soldiers on the western front took a break from trench warfare to sing carols together?

title: Elegiac Trio and Song Cycles in Festival of English Music
description: If you build a festival around a compositional style or historical movement, presumably your intention is to show how fascinating and unjustly overlooked this music is. And if theres one thing a celebration of the English Musical Renaissance of the early 20th century shouldnt do, it is to make you wonder how much worse the Dark Ages could have been, or why, in this era of cross-disciplinary connections, no one thought to offer a subsidiary festival of great English cuisine.

title: Manhattan: Ball Fields Approved for Randalls Island
description: A city panel approved a plan yesterday in which 20 private schools will pay to renovate and build new ball fields on Randalls Island in return for control over two-thirds of the fields from 3 to 6 p.m. on school days. The 5-to-1 vote by the city Franchise and Concession Review Committee is the final legislative hurdle for the $70 million plan. The dissenting vote was cast by Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, who said he was concerned that the arrangement paved the way for privatizing public parkland and did not include sufficient transportation options for children in public schools to get to the new fields. Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who had originally opposed the proposal for similar reasons, voted in favor after changes were made, including a guarantee that the city would provide shuttle bus service to Randalls Island for some public school children.

title: Canada Is Set to Allow Expiration of 2 Broad Antiterrorism Laws
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14  Two measures introduced by Canada in the rush to protect the country against terrorist threats after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, are expected to be allowed to expire early next week, with opposition politicians here saying there is no longer a need for such sweeping legislation.

title: Greeks Have a Waste Problem, and No Hercules in Sight
description: ATHENS, Feb. 14  Since its only landfill reached saturation a month ago, Athens has been in the grip of a garbage crisis.

title: The New Congress Confronts Iraq in 12-Hour Swatches
description: What the House is calling a three-day debate over the Iraq war is decisively settling at least two points. Its nowhere close to a real debate. And Speaker Nancy Pelosi missed a good bet when she rejected cable televisions plea to open the floor to roving cameras that could reach beyond wooden shots of stationary orators.

title: Tasty Tastemakers of the Runway
description: BRIANNA BARNES lounged backstage at the tents in Bryant Park last week tricked out like a droll buccaneer. Her outfit  a billowing mans shirt cinched at the waist, its cuffs trailing from the sleeves of a cropped leather jacket  was unearthed at a thrift shop, she said. She bought her thigh-high boots on eBay.

title: Bush Declares Irans Arms Role in Iraq Is Certain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  President Bush said Wednesday that he was certain that factions within the Iranian government had supplied Shiite militants in Iraq with deadly roadside bombs that had killed American troops. But he said he did not know whether Irans highest officials had directed the attacks.

title: Reporters Avoid Jail in Balco Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14  Two reporters from The San Francisco Chronicle who wrote a best-selling book about steroid use in baseball will avoid jail time after a defense lawyer agreed Wednesday to plead guilty to leaking them secret federal court documents, prosecutors said.

title: Ruling on Medical-Bill Ministry Upheld
description: A Kentucky trial judge yesterday refused to reconsider a decision exempting an unusual medical-bill ministry from compliance with state insurance laws.

title: A Guilty Plea for Options Backdating
description: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records in a stock-option-backdating scheme and agreed to help state authorities investigate the company, the Manhattan district attorney said yesterday.

title: City Hopes to Allow More Offices in Garment Center
description: Acknowledging that the garment center is no longer the production powerhouse it once was, the city is looking to ease restrictions on converting manufacturing spaces to offices there, the city planning commissioner, Amanda M. Burden, said yesterday.

title: The Soap Scum Challenge
description: TO see if organic cleaners would leave my house as sparkling as the tried-and-true brands that fill the cupboards in my laundry room, I went on a cleaning binge.

title: Printers With a Thrifty Eye Toward the Cost of Replacement Ink
description: Kodak has been all about color for decades, but right now they want you to think about green  as in money. The company is introducing a line of EasyShare all-in-one inkjet printers and selling replacement ink at a price that it says will cut the cost of printing supplies up to 50 percent, without compromising on quality or speed.

title: A New Condom in Town, This One Named NYC
description: With the governments imprimatur and a wrapper inspired by the subways, New York Citys first municipally sanctioned condom arrived yesterday, and it was hard to miss, given that city workers and volunteers handed out more than 150,000 of them across the five boroughs.

title: Flu Spray Most Effective for Children, Study Finds
description: FluMist vaccine  a live virus in a nasal spray  is much more effective than flu shots in protecting young children against the disease, a study has found.

title: Car Bomb in Iran Destroys a Bus Carrying Revolutionary Guards
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 14  A car loaded with explosives blew up on Wednesday in front of a bus carrying members of Irans Revolutionary Guards in the southeastern city of Zahedan, killing at least 11 people and wounding 34 others, the state news media reported.

title: Euronext Deal Is Approved
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved the NYSE Groups $13 billion acquisition of Euronext yesterday, removing the last regulatory hurdle to the creation of a trans-Atlantic stock exchange.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column last Thursday about a newspaper interview with the wife of Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy, that followed her published demand for an apology from him for flirting with other women, misstated Mrs. Berlusconis first name. It is Veronica, not Victoria. (Go to Article)

title: Once Again Recalling Nixon, With Help From Some of the Presidents Men
description: Nixon: A Presidency Revealed is the title of a documentary appearing on the History Channel tonight, and it immediately invites the question: What, really, is left to be revealed? Was John Dean secretly a woman? Were H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman actually receiving their orders from Pluto? Was it because of some previously unknown affiliation with strange fashion cultists that Spiro T. Agnew wore ties with polka dots the size of half-dollars? And, in the absence of such disclosures, what conceivable transgressions committed by the Nixon White House would surprise us even now?

title: Judge Restricts New York Police Surveillance
description: In a rebuke of a surveillance practice greatly expanded by the New York Police Department after the Sept. 11 attacks, a federal judge ruled today that the police must stop the routine videotaping of people at public gatherings unless there was an indication that unlawful activity may occur.

title: In Old Files, Fading Hopes of Anne Franks Family
description: On April 30, 1941, just days after a Gestapo courier may have threatened to denounce Anne Franks father, Otto, to the Nazis, he wrote to his close college friend Nathan Straus Jr. begging for help in getting his family out of Amsterdam and into America.

title: 10 Sites That Pay for Your Video
description: That vacation video from Hawaii may be a long shot to surpass Titanic as a moneymaker, but a number of Web sites now offer ways for individuals to earn a return from the video content they produce. Here are some of the sites that generate revenue from advertising, rentals or paid downloads, and then split it with the creator.

title: 2 Boyfriends Are Focus in Dancers Death
description: Who was in the apartment at the critical moments when Catherine Woods, a dancer who worked as a stripper, was slashed to death  her hometown boyfriend or his New York rival?

title: The Wife, Her Husband and the Doctor, in Retrospect
description: A Very Common Procedure, a new play by Courtney Baron that opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater, suffers from a very common problem besetting plays today. If you make a point of seeing new plays, youll probably recognize the syndrome.

title: When the Divorce Court Leads to a Jail Cell
description: EAST MEADOW, N.Y.  Like many of the one million Americans who go through a divorce each year, Marvin Singer is indignant, depressed, financially stressed and convinced that he is a victim of judicial abuse.

title: Minimum Wage, Minimum Tax Cuts
description: In the coming week, the House is expected to pass a bipartisan bill aimed at scaling down the unwise tax cuts that the Senate has demanded in exchange for raising the federal minimum wage. The House measure contains only modest tax cuts, worth $1.3 billion over the next 10 years, and is focused on the small businesses that are most likely to be harmed by a higher minimum wage, like mom-and-pop restaurants. We would have preferred a straightforward minimum wage increase. But the House bill is a reasonable response to the Senates refusal to move forward without tax cuts.

title: Citizens Groups Take Root Across China
description: LUSHAN, China  For as long as he can remember, Du Jianhuas dream has been to find a way to contribute to society.

title: South Korea and Japan Split on North Korea Pact
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14  The deal to freeze North Koreas nuclear program has had immediate ripple effects in Japan and South Korea, apparently freeing South Koreas hands and tying Japans.

title: A Quest for Knowledge Inspired by a Devastating Loss
description: For Adam Wisharts father, it began as back pain. X-rays revealed a crumbling of neck vertebrae. Surgery repaired the vertebrae but uncovered a tumor, a byproduct of cancer that had originated elsewhere in his body. Doctors could not pinpoint its source.

title: A Prewar Slide Show Cast Iraq in Rosy Hues
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  When Gen. Tommy R. Franks and his top officers gathered in August 2002 to review an invasion plan for Iraq, it reflected a decidedly upbeat vision of what the country would look like four years after Saddam Hussein was ousted from power.

title: A New Work for Cello, Played Upon a Veteran
description: On Tuesday evening there were three performers at the center of the tidy loft that is the Howard Gilman Performance Space of the Baryshnikov Arts Center. They were the composer Philip Glass, playing his own piano music; the cellist Wendy Sutter; and a beautiful and venerable cello.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. I want my Victorian fainting couch to look like Sigmund Freuds. Where can I find upholstery fabric in Persian kilim patterns?

title: Determined Vargas Vies for Mets Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 14  Five-year-old Jason Vargas scampered around the batting cage, helping some of the Victor Valley High players retrieve balls, when he reached a milestone in his development. Vargas did not notice a pitch hurtling toward the plate when he trotted out to grab a stray ball. The player lashed a sharp grounder that slammed into Vargass jaw.

title: A Cheeky Broadsheets Tabloid Makeover
description: The New York Observer, which hit New York City streets Wednesday in a new tabloid format, has always conveyed something about the person holding it. As both accessory and artifact, its peachy hue conveys a certain retro chic, and its size, at least until yesterday, suggested the bearer was a person of sprawling, catholic interests, media gossip chief among them.

title: Should You Trust Your Makeup?
description: FOR decades, companies that make everything from after-shave to lip gloss have conducted safety testing on grooming products and shipped the cosmetics to stores to be sold to consumers, all with very little government involvement. And over the years, there have been few health or safety problems associated with the myriad grooming products and cosmetics on the market.

title: An Outsiders Murder Trial Shakes a Southern Town
description: ABBEVILLE, S.C., Feb. 14  It was a dispute over 20 feet of mean-looking land, a deadly squeeze of the trigger three years ago backed by pure conviction and an unwavering motto.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 8 P.M. (History) NIXON: A PRESIDENCY REVEALED Richard Nixon once described his career as a journey to the mountaintop  and to the despair of lifes deepest valley. Or, as Henry Kissinger put it, Like characters out of Shakespeare, he had flaws in his personality that made him destroy his own achievement. This two-hour documentary examines the life of the nations 37th president  from his vice presidency, his political resurrection a decade later and his struggle to end the Vietnam War through his re-emergence as an elder statesman  using recorded conversations and the recollections of those who worked closest with him. Those offering perspective include Alexander Haig, Mr. Kissinger and John Dean as well as the historians Jonathan Aitken and Robert Dallek, and Ben Bradlee of The Washington Post.

title: A Seductive, Tropical Mix to Melt Chilled Spectators
description: Despite the snow outside, you could almost hear the ice clinking in the caipirinhas inside the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night as DanceBrazil began its weeklong run.

title: Dancers, and Their Company, Held Down by Gravity
description: New Yorkers are adept at running themselves ragged, so perhaps its only fitting that a company that bears the citys name should put its dancers through such grueling paces. Still, while 38 different ballets over eight weeks may be impressive, wan dancers arent, and on Tuesday night the company looked exhausted.

title: Profit Falls at Coca-Cola as Sales Slow but Costs Rise
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that profit fell 22 percent after its largest bottler wrote down the value of its North American unit on reduced soda sales and higher raw material costs.

title: Quinn to Seek $300 Tax Credit for Renters
description: Seeking to grant some renters tax breaks similar to those given homeowners, City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn plans to propose a tax credit for tenants worth $300 to those who qualify, according to prepared remarks to be delivered today.

title: For the Audiophile, Headphones in Aluminum and Mahogany
description: Denon, the maker of high-end audio equipment, is lending its expertise to a new line of headphones for the consumer market. The AH line, which ranges from the $700 AH-D5000 to the iPod-friendly $50 AH-C350 earbuds, has some interesting design advances.

title: This Funny Thing Called Love Wont Make a Fool of Me
description: Some jazz and blues singers project the idea of love as an unfathomable and irresistible force: like gravity, say, or the weather. Ernestine Anderson is much more practical about the whole thing. For her, love might best be described as a negotiation between two interested parties, with good times (and sure, a few bad ones) as part of the deal.

title: Corrections: A Word From Our Sponsor
description: An article on Jan. 25 about a new Clinique-sponsored clinic at Weill Medical College of Cornell University referred incorrectly to a comment about psoriasis by Dr. Richard D. Granstein, chairman of Weills dermatology department. He said that psoriasis can itch, but you dont die from it. Its often a cosmetic issue. For many people it is not debilitating. Dr. Granstein did not say that psoriasis is essentially a cosmetic disease.

title: Nevada: English Mandate Repealed
description: The newly elected Pahrump Town Board has unanimously repealed an ordinance passed in November that made English the towns official language. That ordinance, which was never enforced, also denied town benefits to illegal immigrants. Lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada threatened a lawsuit, but four members of the board, including the three who voted for the ordinance, left office in January.

title: Anti-Bosnian Backlash Feared in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 14  Most of the thousands of Bosnians living in the Salt Lake City area are refugees of war, and all of them are toughened by the experience of making new lives in a new country.

title: So, Now Its White and Inconvenient Enough to Be a New York Winter
description: Laurence Earner said he had 108 feet of snow to shovel.

title: Detroits Slump Could Break Up Chrysler Group
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Feb. 14  Every decade provides a new lesson for the American automobile industry.

title: Whimsy, Pessimism and Lady Chatterley in Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 14  Filmmakers, film-industry types and the journalists who love them often refer to something called the festival circuit, a sequence of hectic, semi-glamorous events that crowd the calendar and circle the globe. But it might be more accurate to speak of a festival system: a complicated, ever-expanding web in which the interests of commerce, art and criticism converge, sometimes in harmony and sometimes at cross-purposes.

title: One Man, Two Worlds, Big Trouble
description: The three actors in Nelson, a funny-creepy play by Sam Marks that opened last night, deliver crackling performances that keep you riveted, waiting for an equally crackling finish. Unfortunately it never comes. Mr. Marks instead sabotages an intriguing premise by falling back on the oldest escape clause in playwriting.

title: Citys First Lady to Leave State Position for Private Firm
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  Diana L. Taylor, who as Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs companion has been called New York Citys de facto first lady, said Wednesday that she is leaving state government to work in the private sector.

title: In Turnaround, a Troubled Chrysler May Prove Attractive to Buyers
description: TIME to start kicking the tires at Chrysler?

title: When Budgets Loom, Its Time to Rent a C.F.O.
description: The chief financial officer just left, paperwork is stacking up and the budget needs to be written. A small-business owner could try doing the work, but would not have enough time to run the company, look for a replacement and oversee the finances. So what to do?

title: Nascar Ejects Waltrips Crew Chief
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14  The 2007 Nextel Cup season will be remembered for the arrival of Toyota, the introduction of the safety-minded Car of Tomorrow, the return of broadcast partner ESPN and the influx of millions of dollars from new sponsors and teams joining Nascar.

title: Needed Fixes for No Child Left Behind
description: The No Child Left Behind Act of 2002  which requires states to close the achievement gap between rich and poor students in exchange for more federal dollars  is the most far-reaching educational reform since the country embraced compulsory education in the early 20th century.

title: Venezuela: Opposition Paper and Humorist Fined
description: A court ordered the opposition newspaper Tal Cual and Laureano Mrquez, a humorist and one of its editorial writers, to pay fines for an editorial viewed as violating the privacy of President Hugo Chvezs 9-year-old daughter, Rosins Chvez Rodrguez. Tal Cual published an editorial by Mr. Mrquez imagining a dialogue between the president and his daughter. He wrote the editorial after Mr. Chvez publicly referred to Rosins, saying she told him the horse in Venezuelas coat of arms looked strange galloping to the right; lawmakers soon approved a measure to reversed the horses direction to the left, in tune with Mr. Chvezs politics. Teodoro Petkoff, the editor of Tal Caul, said it would protest the fines, which could reach almost $20,000.

title: Turkmenistan Hails Leader and New Era After Election
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14  Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, once a quiet aide to the former authoritarian president of Turkmenistan, ascended to the presidency himself on Wednesday, formally beginning a new era for a reclusive nation whose vast natural gas reserves have brought it suitors from governments around the world.

title: Trial of Madrid Blast Suspects Begins
description: MADRID, Feb. 15  A Spanish special tribunal today began a mass trial of 29 people suspected of the terror bombings of commuter trains in March 2004 that killed 191 people and sundered Spains political establishment.

title: Bochy Unfazed by Bonds Drama
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 14  Bruce Bochy managed one superstar who used to stand over a batting tee with his teammates, showing them how to guide outside pitches to the opposite field.

title: U.N. Commander in Kosovo Resigns After Demonstrators Deaths
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Feb. 14  The commander of the United Nations police in Kosovo resigned Wednesday, days after violent clashes between the police and demonstrators left two protesters dead and another critically injured.

title: Fed Chief Suggests Rates  Will Hold Steady
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that inflation is improving as the economy expands at a moderate but manageable pace  the balancing point that the Fed tries to hit as it regulates interest rates.

title: Kansas Gets a Big Lift From an Unlikely Jayhawk
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 11  The Kansas Jayhawks were not sure what to expect from Brandon Rush after he surprised the university, his family and his friends by enrolling there last season. After attending four high schools and battling issues of academic eligibility, he had planned to skip college and turn professional.

title: Masco to Cut Jobs After Quarterly Loss
description: The Masco Corporation, the maker of Behr paint and Delta faucets, posted its first loss in five years and is laying off about 16 percent of its work force as a result of a slump in the housing market.

title: As Streaks Go, One for the Record Books *
description: If youre a golfer and you lost your last tournament, are you on a winning streak?

title: Dog Dies on a Downtown Sidewalk, Possibly Electrocuted
description: A small dog being walked along a downtown sidewalk yesterday was apparently electrocuted moments after crossing an icy manhole cover, according to a veterinarian who examined the animal after a dog-walker brought him in.

title: Russians to Vote, but Some Parties Lose in Advance
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Two candidates in local elections here in March, a soccer star and figure skating champion, have no known intention of giving up sports for legislative politics. If they win, as they almost certainly will, their Kremlin-friendly parties, not the voters, will choose the candidates to fill their seats.

title: Riverhead: Woman Admits Hitting Priest With Van
description: An East Hampton woman who fatally struck a retired Catholic priest with her van last July pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in Suffolk County Court, prosecutors said. The woman, Karen Fisher, 43, admitted striking the priest, Msgr. William F. Costello, 79, on Woodbine Drive in East Hampton on July 18, prosecutors said. A test showed that her blood alcohol level was more than three times the legal limit of 0.08 percent, prosecutors said. Ms. Fisher is expected to be sentenced to 3 1/3 to 10 years in prison.

title: No Apology Needed
description: Far be it from me to get in the middle of a liberal purge, but would anybody mind if I pointed out that the calls for Hillary Clinton to apologize for her support of the Iraq war are almost entirely bogus?

title: Not Enough Snow for You? Talk to Your Father
description: Greenwich, Conn.

title: In New Jersey, a Fight Over Budget Records Is Played Out in Secrecy
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14  For almost a half-dozen years, Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey, has scoured the state, taking on one elected official after another. Now he is wrangling with an arm of the State Legislature, but what he wants and whether he will get it are being argued behind locked doors and cloaked in grand jury secrecy.

title: Bush Says U.S. and NATO Ready to Block Taliban Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  President Bush said today that extending the stay of 3,200 American troops in Afghanistan would help the NATO-commanded force there combat an anticipated spring offensive by the Taliban.

title: Babes in Label Land
description: A NORMAL Fashion Week produces one hot new label to seduce the big stores and the big editors. This season, there were three.

title: Wiretapping Case Is Expanded
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14  Federal prosecutors on Wednesday named two additional people they said had been wiretapped by Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private eye accused of a wide-ranging wiretapping conspiracy. One is the former son-in-law of a noted music and film producer and the other is a prominent entertainment lawyer.

title: New York School Crime Up 21 Percent in First Third of Fiscal Year
description: Major crimes in the New York City public schools increased by 21 percent from July through October of this school year over last, driven by a surge in grand larcenies, according to data released yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs office.

title: Pentagon Blames Iran for Bombs Used in Iraq Against U.S. Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Pentagon leaders blamed the Iranian government again today for deadly explosive devices being used against American soldiers in Iraq and tried to tamp down suggestions of a dispute on the subject.

title: Times Company Forms Alliance With Job-Listing Web Site
description: The New York Times Company and Monster Worldwide, the operator of the popular job-listing site Monster.com, announced yesterday that they were forming an alliance to share brands on the newspaper companys career sites.

title: 12 Republicans Break Ranks on Iraq Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  A dozen Republicans arrived in the House chamber on Wednesday to set aside their party allegiances and lend their names to a resolution intended to rebuke President Bush for his Iraq policy.

title: As a Way to Pay Victims of 9/11, Insurance Fund Is Problematic
description: Public officials are eyeing the $1 billion set aside in an insurance fund to cover New York City against negligence lawsuits related to 9/11 for other potential uses. But tapping into that money may present more than a few problems.

title: New Pay Plan for Control of Air Traffic Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The Bush administration proposed Wednesday to eliminate the tax on plane tickets and air cargo shipments, shifting the cost of the air traffic control system largely to user fees and increased taxes on fuel.

title: For Knicks, Another Game That Epitomizes Their Season
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 14  Everything the Knicks have become in the last two months was on display Wednesday night. This was not a good thing.

title: Looking at the Bottle and Whats in It
description: CONCERNS about chemicals in cosmetics have prompted some consumer groups and researchers to conduct their own lab tests on beauty products.

title: French Police Arrest 11 in Recruitment for Al Qaeda
description: PARIS, Feb. 14  The French antiterrorism police have arrested 11 people, most of them accused of connections to Iraqi insurgency recruitment rings linked to Al Qaeda, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

title: Yoga Teacher Convicted in Killing of Dancer
description: Paul Cortez, a 26-year-old actor working as a yoga teacher, was convicted today of the throat-slashing death of Catherine Woods, a 21-year-old dancer who worked as a stripper.

title: Fighting Snoring, and Its Dangers, Together
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 13  After canceling a planned romantic dinner, Dan Hajjar and Anne Marie Jarka-Hajjar, who have been married 17 years, spent Valentines eve in separate beds, tossing and turning amid a tangle of electrode wires and sensors stuck all over their bodies.

title: Rival Groups Kept Apart at Hariri Memorial in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 14  The military on Wednesday rolled out acres of razor wire and fashioned a no mans land to separate the hundreds of thousands of government supporters who poured into the center of this city from the hundreds of opposition supporters who have camped downtown since December.

title: 2 Former N.F.L. Players Sue Over Sharing of Fees
description: Two former N.F.L. players filed a class-action lawsuit late yesterday in federal court in San Francisco against Players Inc., the licensing subsidiary of the National Football League Players Association, claiming that Players Inc. has improperly represented more than 3,500 retired players and may owe them tens of millions of dollars in back licensing fees.

title: Scientists Warn That Bird-Flu Virus Remains a Threat
description: Last winter, as the deadly bird-flu virus marched out of Asia, across Europe and down into Africa, public health experts warned of the potential for a catastrophic pandemic like the Spanish flu of 1918.

title: Giuliani Says He Is Running for President in 08
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday removed any lingering doubts that he was running for president, and, without mentioning President Bush by name, offered pointed criticism on how the Iraq war has been handled.

title: Pension Costs Widen Loss at Delta Air
description: Delta Air Lines, preparing to exit bankruptcy on April 30, said yesterday its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $2 billion on the cost of ending its pilots pension plan.

title: A Safe House?
description: FELICIA BUSTO-FRAIM always kept her Flushing, N.Y., home clean with traditional brand-name cleaning products like Windex and Fantastik. But her attitude changed the day her daughters school switched to environmentally friendly cleaning products.

title: Canceled TV Speech Points to Hamas and Fatah Split
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 14  In another sign of tension with Hamas over a possible national unity government, the Palestinian Authoritys president, Mahmoud Abbas of the Fatah faction, canceled a televised speech scheduled for Thursday night, his aides said Wednesday.

title: All Talk, No Action, on the War? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Supporting Our Troops
description: How do you explain to the thousands of American troops now being poured into Baghdad that they will have to wait until the summer for the protective armor that could easily mean the difference between life and death?

title: Illinois: Mayor Added to Torture Suit
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago was added as a defendant to a federal civil lawsuit accusing city officials of covering up torture of dozens of criminal suspects by police officers on the South Side in the 1970s and 1980s. Mr. Daley, who is seeking his sixth term as mayor in an election on Feb. 27, was Cook Countys top prosecutor in the early 1980s when some of the most serious incidents of brutality are alleged to have taken place. The lawsuit is one of several filed in federal court in recent years on behalf of men claiming that police officers tortured them into giving false confessions.

title: Singing Songs of Time, While Watching It Stand Still
description: Who Knows Where the Time Goes? When Judy Collins sang this great Sandy Denny ballad on Tuesday evening at the Caf Carlyle, time responded to the question by standing still for several minutes. The title song from her classic 1968 folk-rock album, it has become one of Ms. Collinss musical signatures along with Amazing Grace, Send In the Clowns and Both Sides Now. Broadly speaking, they share a common theme: balancing resignation, hope and a sense of wonder, they distill the long view.

title: A 12-Gigabyte Hard Drive That Slips Easily Into Your Pocket
description: Small on the outside and big on the inside, U.S.B. pocket drives have become a common choice for toting hefty files. The latest version of Verbatims Store n Go U.S.B. Drive holds 12 gigabytes of file storage on a device less than 3 inches high by 1.4 inches wide.

title: A New Place to Strong-Arm Givers: The Gym
description: FOR three weeks, sweet-talking solicitors greeted gymgoers in the lobby of the Atlantic Club in Manasquan, N.J. They were not peddling personal training sessions.

title: Austrias Maier No Longer a Dominator
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 14  The United States ski team is in touch with its feminine side. All three of the medals the team has collected at the Alpine skiing world championships have come from Lindsey Kildow and Julia Mancuso, and the men have been shut out.

title: Uncertain Future Has Rivera Talking
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 14  Mariano Rivera had just finished another feisty but civil discussion about his uncertain contract status with the Yankees when he eased into a folding chair. Four young Latin players surrounded Rivera, three of them plopping on the blue carpet and peering up at him as if they were in kindergarten and he were Spider-Man.

title: Egyptian Is Focus of Attention as Madrid Bomb Trial Opens
description: ROME, Feb. 14  He is charged with 191 counts of murder and 1,755 of attempted murder in the Madrid bombings on March 11, 2004, though he has been secretly recorded saying that he had not been with the men who carried them out.

title: Apples AirPort Extreme: A Wireless Network to Rival the Speed of Being Plugged In
description: Ask any computer geek which is faster, a wired or wireless network, and they would probably tell you to reach for the Ethernet cables  unless, of course, you have upgraded to 802.11n.

title: Cabinet Shuffle May Signal Putins Intentions
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia added intrigue today to the undeclared but widely debated question of who might succeed him in 2008, by unexpectedly promoting Sergei B. Ivanov, his minister of defense.

title: South Africa: Soweto Gets Luxury Train Service
description: The commuter service Metrorail will add luxury express train service next month between Johannesburg and Soweto, the township that once symbolized the poverty and oppression of blacks under apartheid rule. Aimed at business clients who shun Metrorails usually hot and crowded commuter cars, the 530-seat train underscores Sowetos rise from impoverished township to an increasingly attractive location for the black middle and upper classes. The service will feature uniformed attendants, bar service and ticketing and boarding facilities separate from ordinary trains.

title: Buyout Firm Said to Be in Deal to Unite No. 2 and No. 3 Chains in Premium Ice Cream
description: The premium ice cream wars are heating up.

title: For Tavis Smiley, Promises to Keep
description: One of the better-kept secrets in the U.S. is the wide reach and extraordinary commitment of Tavis Smiley.

title: Testing Faith in a Church
description: On Tuesday night, when the Montreal band Arcade Fire started its sold-out five-night stand at the Judson Memorial Church, an audience member shouted, Why a church? Win Butler, the bands leader and main singer, dodged the question. But the obvious answer is the bands second full album, due March 6. Its called Neon Bible (Merge) and has songs about impending apocalypse, fear and faith.

title: As the Dust Bunny Moved, I Drew
description: I ARRIVED home, opened the front door and stepped into what looked like the set of a movie being shot on location in the Old West.

title: Updating Windows Defender
description: Updating

title: Hamas Clears Way for Unity Government
description: GAZA, Feb. 15  After months of difficult negotiations and bloody Palestinian street fighting, the Hamas-led Palestinian government resigned Thursday to pave the way for a unity government that will include Hamas and the rival Fatah movement.

title: Death Propels Anna Nicole Smith Biography From Backlist
description: For all the ink that has been spilled over Anna Nicole Smith, very little of it has been in books  except for a lone decade-old biography.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Hydrangea Grows Legs

title: James Is Ready for His Close-Up ... Sort Of
description: James was exhausted. He had slept for two hours after winning Best in Show Tuesday night at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, and now was 13 hours into his postvictory news media tour. He needed a nap, yet he was not petulant after waiting two and a half hours for the taping to start.

title: An Am Who Plays Like a Pro
description: Pro-am events are usually looked upon by pros as a labor of love. They are giving something back to the game that has given them so much. But the winners are always happy. The am is delighted to receive the accolades of peers, and the pro will have several stories with which to entertain friends.

title: Whereabouts of Iraqi Shiite Cleric Are Disputed
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 15  Questions and accusations continued to swirl about the whereabouts of the militant Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Thursday, and American and Iraqi forces deepened their security push in Baghdad.

title: Where Are They Now?
description: You probably heard that the Yankees traded Randy Johnson to Arizona and Gary Sheffield to Detroit this winter. You may also know they traded Jaret Wright to Baltimore. But what happened to the many bit players from the 2006 team?

title: Lessons in Learning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Modern Abstraction
description: Images from the "Howard Hodgkin" show at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: A Haitian Eden
description: A resort in Labadie, Haiti, is a world away for most people in Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Living Theater Finds a Home
description: The Living Theater, the fiercely political and hugely influential avant-garde theater founded in the 1940s by Julian Beck and Judith Malina, is opening a permanent space, a 100-seat theater in a new building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: A New View in Vail
Enter Mr. Mom
description: Among the latest gender- and genealogy-bending theater experiments was Tuesday night's performance of "A Spanish Play," by Yasmina Reza, at Classic Stage Company.

title: Germany Battles a Rising Tide of Corporate Corruption
description: Corporate profits in Germany have surged across sectors ranging from finance to autos to energy, as German executives have turned the country into one of the worlds largest exporters over the last five years. But, says Wolfgang Schaupensteiner, the head of the Frankfurts financial crime unit, illicit dealings helped create their success, and that in turn has encouraged many executives to believe that crime does pay. These days, Mr. Schaupensteiners backlog of bribery, fraud and other white-collar crime cases runs into the hundreds.

title: Former Take-Two Boss Pleads Guilty to Options Backdating
description: The founder and former head of Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, pleaded guilty to falsifying records in a stock-option-backdating scheme and agreed to help state authorities investigate the company, the Manhattan district attorney said Wednesday.

title: Buyout Firm Takes Two Ice-Cream Scoops
description: The premium ice cream wars are heating up.

title: Pension Costs Widen Loss at Delta Air
description: Delta Air Lines, preparing to exit bankruptcy on April 30, said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $2 billion on the cost of ending its pilots pension plan. The loss a year earlier was $1.24 billion, the company said. Delta did not give per-share data. Without the pension expense and other charges, it lost $179 million, compared with $782 million a year earlier.

title: When Budgets Loom, Its Time to Rent a C.F.O.
description: The chief financial officer just left, paperwork is stacking up and the budget needs to be written. A small-business owner could try doing the work, but would not have enough time to run the company, look for a replacement and oversee the finances. So what to do?

title: Merck to Pay $2.3 Billion to the I.R.S.
description: Merck & Company agreed Wednesday to pay $2.3 billion to resolve several tax disputes, the Internal Revenue Service said. The drug companys payment includes taxes, interest and penalties stemming from the disputes, which cover the tax years 1993-2001 and arose in part from Mercks use of minority equity interest financing, the I.R.S. said.

title: 2 Enron Traders Avoid Prison in Sentences
description: Two of three former Enron traders accused of driving up energy prices during Californias power crisis in 2000 and 2001 were each sentenced on Wednesday in federal court to two years of court-supervised release.

title: NYSE Euronext Is Born
description: As the Nasdaq Stock Market licks its wounds after its failed bid for the London Stock Exchange, all seems to be going as planned for the New York Stock Exchanges overseas deal.

title: Virgin America Refuels With $30 Million
description: Virgin America, the upstart airline backed by British billionaire Richard Branson, said it raised an addition $30 million in financing from Black Canyon Capital of Los Angeles and New Yorks Cyrus Capital Partners.

title: Dell Fills New Position
description: Dell has hired Michael R. Cannon, who has been serving as chief executive of Solectron, to fill the newly created position of president for global operations. Dell said Mr. Cannon, whose departure from Solectron was announced Wednesday, will assume his new role on Feb. 26.

title: Former Monster Lawyer in Plea Deal, Report Says
description: Federal prosecutors are expected to announce a plea deal with a former executive of recruitment service Monster Worldwide in a stock options manipulation case, the Wall Street Journal reported. The companys former general counsel, Myron Olesnyckyj, has agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in Manhattan and is expected to describe the role of founder Andrew McKelvey and others in stock-options practices at Monster, the paper said.

title: EADS Sells Stake in Aircraft Maker
description: EADS, Europes biggest aerospace and defence group, has sold its 2.12 percent stake in Embraer, the Brazilian aircraft maker, as part of moves to strengthen its finances ahead of the announcement next week of costly moves to restructure its Airbus operations. It said the sale had generated proceeds totaling 124 million euros ($163 million) before taxes and fees.

title: Akzo Nobel to Proceed With Organon I.P.O.
description: Akzo Nobel, the Dutch chemicals conglomerate, said Thursday that it was moving ahead with an initial public offering of its Organon Biosciences pharmaceutical division, after rejecting bids from several buyout consortiums last month for the unit.

title: Reed Elsevier to Part With Education Division
description: Reed Elsevier plans to sell its Harcourt Education division by the second half of this year as part of plans to sharpen its strategic focus on the science and medical, legal, and business publishing markets. The company is not in talks with any specific potential buyers, Reeds Chief Executive, Sir Crispin Davis, said, but private equity firms are seen as likely bidders. UBS is handling the sale.

title: Le-Natures Suitors Surface in Documents
description: Supermarket chain Giant Eagle and beverage manufacturer Cadbury Schweppes are two potential buyers of the Le-Natures bottling plant in Latrobe, according to bankruptcy documents filed this week. Also named as a potential buyer is a joint venture between Premier Manufacturing and Greenwood 361 of Chicago, which describes itself on its Web site as a company that focuses on acquiring small to mid-sized U.S. businesses.

title: Citigroup and Blackstone to Launch Indian Infrastructure Fund
description: Citigroup, Blackstone Group and two Indian finance companies have signed an agreement to start a $5 billion infrastructure fund. The fund will aim to improve the countrys roads, ports and other facilities, the Indian finance ministry said in an e-mailed release Thursday.

title: Citys First Lady to Leave State Position for Private Firm
description: Diana L. Taylor, who as Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs companion has been called New York Citys de facto first lady, said Wednesday that she is leaving her job as the states superintendent of banking to join boutique investment bank Wolfensohn & Company. The firm, which acts as an adviser to corporations and governments, as well as investing in private equity, said Ms. Taylor will join as a managing director next month.

title: Troubled Chrysler May Be Attractive to Buyers
description: Time to start kicking the tires at Chrysler?

title: Hedge Fund Thirsts for Sapporo
description: Activist hedge fund Steel Partners has submitted proposals to take a majority stake in Sapporo, Japans number three brewer. The U.S. hedge fund , which already owns 17.52 percent of the beer maker, wants to up its holding to 66.6 percent, with a view to an eventual takeover.

title: Chrysler and GM Hold Talks on Joint Project
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 - The Chrysler Group and General Motors are holding preliminary discussions about a joint project that would provide Chrysler with a version of the big Chevrolet Tahoe sport utility, people with direct knowledge of the talks said Thursday night.

title: Scenes From a Law-Firm Showdown
description: In its never-ending quest to capture the zeitgeist context and sartorial details of the news, The New York Observer weighs in with particularly Observian observations about the juicy legal dispute between the prominent law firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a former associate, Aaron Charney, who has accused the firm of harassing him because of his sexual orientation. The firm, in turn, has accused Mr. Charney of stealing files and disseminating information that could be embarrassing to clients, including Goldman Sachs.

title: Specious Obama Trademark  Denied
description: From our That Which We Call a Rose Chronicles, in which the singularness of Senator Barack H. Obamas name flusters the unworldly, trips up the well meaning, or is exploited by his political opponents, we bring you Alexandre Batlle of Miami Beach, Fla., by way of The Smoking Gun.

title: Dreamgirls Still Hitting the High Notes?
description: There have been recent reports that Jennifer Hudson and Beyonce may not be all buddy-buddy, but as recently as a week ago, it was said that they will be sharing a stage, if not an award, at the Oscars.

title: When a Parade Float and Cinema Collide
description: Dreamgirls makes a bid to become this seasons Crash.

title: Oscar 101
description: If you want a tutorial in all things Oscar  the Bagger audited the class last year  you might want to click around at How Stuff Works. Fun fact to forget? The oldest Oscar winner was Henry Fonda, at 76, for On Golden Pond.

title: The Smart Money
description: The Bagger is a week away from having to make his final picks and is still searching for his backside with both paws. Vegas doesnt seem to know much more: the odds on both The Departed and Little Miss Sunshine are 3-2. Is it starting to get hot in here?

title: Invading Poland
description: Id like a latte, no make that two, and a deep discussion about concentration, gender and script generation. A conversation with Dave Poland and Guillermo Arriaga, the screenwriter who brought you Babel.

title: Speechless
description: Newbies like the Bagger often have to depend upon the kindness of relative strangers, and one of the people who has patiently borne the brunt of the his witless inquiries is John Pavlik, spokesperson for the Oscars. After 39 Oscar shows  he once watched John Wayne cry like a baby after getting an Oscar  Mr. Pavlik is moving on.

title: Bear Stearns May Pay for Failed Hedge Fund Client
description: Bear Stearns may be ordered to pay bankrupt hedge fund Manhattan Investment Fund up to $180 million in a possible test of how much responsibility prime brokerages must bear for their lucrative clients, Bloomberg News reported Thursday. The judge overseeing the case, Burton Lifland, concluded last month that Bear Stearns tried only to cover its own possible losses and did not look into possible fraud at Manhattan Investment.

title: Wonk Splendor
description: The Bagger likes the whole Oscar data set as much as the next Ninny, but he is a piker compared to the real veterans. Over at OscarWatch, the Editors Guild awards, which will be handed out this weekend, are undergoing shaking and baking for all sorts of implications. Not need to know, but nice to know.

title: Whos Pious Now?
Hanks on the Cheap
description: The Baguette ran into Tom Hanks at the Odeon, down in TriBeCa, last night. He was attending the after-party for Starter for 10, a romantic comedy produced by Playtone Productions, Mr. Hankss company, and HBO Films. The film, which opens Feb. 23, is about a working-class kid in 1985 (James McAvoy from The Last King of Scotland) who is obsessed with appearing on a TV quiz show called University Challenge and who falls for his beautiful teammate (Alice Eve).

title: Short, Sweet and Slick
description: The five live-action films in this anthology of Oscar-nominated shorts tend toward sentiment and slickness. "The Saviour," an Australian production about a Mormon missionary in love with a married woman, is charming but cutesy. "West Bank Story," an American musical spoof in which Arabs and Jews make like Sharks and Jets, is lavishly produced but trite.

title: Sasanian Art
description: Images from Glass, Gilding and Grand Design: Art of Sasanian Iran (224-642 A.D.) at Asia Society.

title: A Very Busy Father
description: You think you've got it rough? Monty (Idris Elba), the hero of the playwright-turned-filmmaker Tyler Perry's latest movie, "Daddy's Little Girls," probably has you beat. He's an ex-convict, a mechanic and a limo driver who struggles to raise his three darling daughters after their caretaker, his ex-wife's mother, dies of lung cancer. Then he improbably loses them to his malevolent harpy of an ex-wife, Jennifer (Tasha Smith), and her all-powerful, crack-dealing boyfriend (Gary Sturgis).

title: Last Notes on the Megapixel Myth
description: My column in The Times last week, about the general irrelevance of megapixels in consumer cameras, stirred up an enormous volume of feedback.

title: Blood on His Hands, Philosophy on His Mind
description: Slick as blood, cold as ice, "Antibodies" brings together a philosophically minded serial killer, a devoutly religious cop and a cynical filmmaker clearly itching to go Hollywood.

title: Is Chrysler Worth Less Than Nothing?
description: Daimler-Benz picked up Chrysler nine years ago in a $36 billion deal. But times have changed since then, and some analysts say that Chrysler, which shipped 2.7 million Chrysler, Jeep and Dodge cars last year, may have a net value of zero  or even less  as a standalone entity.

title: Credit Suisses Dougan to Become C.E.O.
description: Credit Suisse said Thursday that chief executive Oswald Grubel would retire in May, far earlier than many had expected, and would be succeeded by Brady Dougan, the head of its investment banking unit. The surprise move will put an American in charge of the Switzerland-based securities giant as it seeks to more closely integrate its operations under what it calls the one bank strategy. Mr. Dougan has been with Credit Suisse for 17 years and became chief executive of its investment banking group, formerly called Credit Suisse First Boston, when John J. Mack abruptly left the firm in 2004.

title: What Exactly Was Romney Trying to Say?
description: Mitt Romney should not be accused of anti-Semitism for launching his presidential campaign at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., says Zev Chafets, author of A Match Made in Heaven: American Jews, Christian Zionists and One Mans Exploration of the Weird and Wonderful Judeo-Evangelical Alliance, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. Chafets writes: Henry Ford has been dead 60 years, and his descendants have spent every day since atoning for the old bigot. There is no known Jewish organization or cause that hasnt benefited from Ford largesse. The familys only villain is William Clay Ford Sr., whose 43-year ownership of the Detroit N.F.L. football franchise has done to the Lions what his grandfather wanted to do to Jews.

title: Dharma, the Elizabethan Way
description: Dharma, the time-honored concept of proper conduct, is a recurrent notion in "The Royal Guard," a somber drama directed by Vidhu Vinod Chopra ("Kareeb"), and while the film takes place in the present, it clearly has a heart for the classics, particularly those of Eastern philosophy, Shakespeare and genre cinema.

title: Yankees to Honor Cory Lidle
description: The Associated Press reports that the Yankees will wear black arm bands to honor the memory of pitcher Cory Lidle who died in a plane crash in October.

title: 2008: Giuliani on Iraq Past, Edwards on Future
description: Theres something about Larry Kings suspenders. Their mesmerizing powers induced Rudolph W. Giuliani to state his candidacy more definitively than ever before and to criticize the White Houses conduct of the war more pointedly than ever before.

title: Sights of Spring
description: Its sunny, the Beach Boys are playing on the sound system, and the Yankees pitchers and catchers are arrayed in the outfield in a wide circle, stretching for their first workout. Baseballs back.

title: Speaking of Oscar
description: Dozens of Oscar statues magically appear in Times Square and the Bagger is there to greet them.

title: A Contract Anyone Would Love
description: Readers of Tyson Foods new proxy, which was filed last week, could be forgiven for concluding that the company had given a huge effective raise to Don Tyson, the companys retired chairman and chief executive.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Adrift in Macao," "Nelson" and "The Jaded Assassin."

title: Crazy Love
description: Was it an end to major combat operations? Or was it a mere cease-fire, like the Christmas truce of 1914, when German and British soldiers on the western front took a break from trench warfare to sing carols together?

title: War at Home: Bush and the Debate
description: For the second day in a row, President Bush pulled attention away from the day-and-night debate in the House over a resolution that disapproves of his Iraq troop buildup.

title: Are You Sweet on LMS?
description: Defamer reports that Fox Searchlight is pushing the frontiers of Oscar marketing into ever smaller niches, giving out cupcakes in West Hollywood eateries. The Bagger, who has no vote but a strong interest, is holding out for Babel M & Ms, a bag of multi-hued candy with a side of portent.

title: Yes, You Have to Move Your Car
description: Some city residents  particularly in Queens  have been complaining about the decision not to suspend alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules after the modest snowstorm that began on Tuesday night. The decision is made jointly by the Sanitation and Transportation Departments.

title: Lo Duca Reports, With Nothing to Do
description: Catcher Paul Lo Duca showed up at 8:15 this morning ready to work out only to discover that he didnt have any official responsibilities.

title: What Warren Buffett Is Buying
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of famed value investor Warren E. Buffett, has revealed its end-of-2006 stock positions, including its $843 million stake in Minneapolis-based U.S. Bancorp. From January through September of last year, Berkshire built up its U.S. Bancorp holdings by 23.3 million shares, representing a 1.3 percent stake in the bank, the nations sixth-largest by assets. Because so many investors watch Mr. Buffetts portfolio, regulators sometimes allow his firm to delay disclosures of its trades in an effort to forestall market mimicry.

title: Holocaust Denial  Crime or Free Speech?
description: BBC News reports that 67-year-old Ernst Zuendel, has been sentenced to 5 years in prison for violating Germanys law against denying the Holocaust.

title: Want to Buy a Hedge Fund? Try eBay
description: Last year brought us Hedge Funds For Dummies. Now comes another potential sign of the frothiness in the business of hedge funds, which are investment pools for wealthy and institutional investors. Available on eBay for a minimum of $70,000 is what claims to be a full authorized and operative hedge fund, offered by someone in Italy with the eBay handle hdgfund.

title: First Impressions: The House and Da Enzo
description: The right physical situation and the right ambience can take a restaurant a long, long way. La Esquina is one of the many places that prove that. Ive seldom heard someone rave with pronounced enthusiasm about its Mexican cooking, though much of that cooking is certainly more than serviceable. And yet almost everyone I know whos been there once expresses a desire to go back, because they so enjoyed its clandestine vibe  the semi-secret doorway that leads to the grungy, bowels-of-building staircase, which in turn deposits you near the kitchen, an edge of which you have to walk through until, at last, youre in the dining chambers, dark and several stories below ground.

title: Publisher of Maxim May Consider a Sale
description: Felix Dennis sold millions of magazine copies by featuring various starlets in states of deshabill. Now his media company, Dennis Publishing, may be trying to sell something else: itself. The publisher of lad magazine titles like Maxim and Stuff said Thursday that it hired Allen & Company to consider strategic alternatives, including a sale.

title: Duke Blue Mets
description: Billy Wagner and Scott Schoeneweis have sort of a kinship, but not because both are left-handed and shorter than 6 feet. Both are rabid Duke basketball fans.

title: The Buyout Flip: It Works For Mansions, Too
description: Buy, fix and sell at a big profit: Thats the private equity mantra. So it is quite fitting that J. Christopher Flowers, the billionaire former Goldman Sachs partner who now private equity fund J.C. Flowers & Company, is aiming for a 35 percent return in just three months on his newly acquired mansion on New Yorks Upper East Side.

title: Court Case Primeval
description: In a sharp rebuke, a federal judge has ordered  the N.Y.P.D. to stop the routine videotaping of people at public gatherings unless there was an indication that unlawful activity may occur,  Jim Dwyer of The Times reports.

title: Introducing Dice K, Again
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  In another sign of how bonkers the lobster-boat crowd is for anything Dice K, a worker at the Red Sox spring training facility wondered if he should have worn a kimono for todays special occasion: the second or third  or is it fourth?  official introduction of Daisuke Matsuzaka. And were pretty sure the employeewas serious about his attire conundrum.

title: Bernie May Be Back
description: Bernie Williams might come back to the Yankees, after all. Joe Torre said Williams called him back yesterday, and they spoke by phone for 20 minutes. Williams has not yet accepted the Yankees non-roster invitation, but he respects Torre deeply, and Torre told Williams he wants him in camp.

title: Yet More Ammo for Those Choosy Mothers
description: For those readers who might have a jar of Peter Pan Peanut Butter lingering in the cupboard, check the lid. If the the product code begins with the numbers 2111, step away from the peanut butter. It has been recalled.

title: Blogtalk: State of the City
description: Christine Quinns State of the City speech. Also: Poofreder needed. [The Daily Politics]

title: The Trials of Carl Pavano
description: It was the spring of 2005, and Carl Pavano had just joined the Yankees. It was a feel-good story, of sorts: a pitcher from Southington, CT, whose family adored the Yankees, coming home to pitch in the Bronx. I planned a feature on him and talked with his parents, who were friendly and gracious.

title: The Senate Set for War on Saturday
description: So much for the Presidents Day recess week for Congress  at least, it seems, for the Senate.

title: Viewers Fast-Forwarding Past Ads? Not Always
description: People with digital video recorders like TiVo never watch commercials, right?

title: Compassion Gets a Promotion
description: In the changing of the guard that has followed the spectacular flameout of former Treasury secretary-turned-Harvard-president-turned-hedge-fund-manager Larry Summers, the Harvard corporation appears to have made a singular statement of principle: masters of the universe need not apply.

title: Luck in the Afternoon
description: Groucho stories, even if youve heard them, are still good. Like the well-known story of his daughter and the restricted country club pool. Groucho: But my daughters only half-Jewish. Can she go in up to her waist?

title: A Generous Ellen
description: Jennifer Hudson strutting her stuff on the cover of Vogue magazine is one thing, but now theres Ellen DeGeneres on the cover of W Magazines March issue, wearing a turquoise wonderbra and showing something not usually associated with her: cleavage.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Bamako'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Bamako," a film that puts Globalization on trial.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Music and Lyrics'
description: Chief movie critic A. O. Scott reviews the new romantic comedy, "Music and Lyrics."

title: Manhattan: 2 More Gun Dealers Settle
description: Two more out-of-state gun dealers who were sued by New York City and suspected of illegally selling guns have agreed to allow their sales activities to be monitored as part of a settlement, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The two  Rooks Sales and Service of Bishopville, S.C., and the Town and Country Pawn Shop of Roanoke, Va.  bring the number of dealers who have settled with the city to 9 out of 27 named in two lawsuits. The two dealers were named in the more recent lawsuit, which was filed on Dec. 7 in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. They have agreed to close monitoring of their records and inventory, including the possibility of videotaped sales activities and undercover surveillance.

title: Art in Review
description: AGENTS OF CHANGE Women, Art and Intellect Ceres 547 West 27th Street, Suite 201, Chelsea  Through Feb. 24

title: Volkswagen Withdraws Commercial That Involved Suicide
description: For the second time in a week, an automaker has agreed to stop running a television commercial that several mental health organizations criticized as making light of suicide.

title: Dear Dan Brown, All Eyes Are on You
description: Take a sacred treasure. Add a secret conspiracy. Attach a name well known to scholars  Dante, Poe, Wordsworth, Archimedes, Machiavelli, Shakespeare, the Romanovs, Vlad the Impaler, Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, whatever  and work it into a story that can accommodate both the Glock and the Holy Grail. If theres any room left for the Knights Templar or DNA samples from Biblical figures, by all means plug them in.

title: Staten Island: Badge Is Said to Aid Theft
description: A Staten Island man has been charged with using a Drug Enforcement Administration badge and fraudulent search warrants to commit robberies over the past few months, state and federal law enforcement officials said yesterday. The man, Tony Clanton, 34, of Narrows Road, is charged with impersonating a federal agent, theft and illegal possession of guns and drugs, said Bridget G. Brennan, the citys special narcotics prosecutor. Ms. Brennan said Mr. Clanton used a high-quality replica of D.E.A. credentials and fake search warrants to gain entrance to homes he intended to rob. He was arrested on Tuesday afternoon, she said.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Arctic Monkeys and Killers Lead the Brit Awards

title: And the Oscar Winner Is Big-Event Television
description: THE Super Bowl and Grammy Awards are barely memories, but Madison Avenue is already beating the drum for the next big live television event, the Oscars.

title: Judge Limits New York Police Taping
description: In a rebuke of a surveillance practice greatly expanded by the New York Police Department after the Sept. 11 attacks, a federal judge ruled yesterday that the police must stop the routine videotaping of people at public gatherings unless there is an indication that unlawful activity may occur.

title: Jury Convicts Actor in Killing of Dancer
description: An actor and yoga teacher who had climbed out of a working-class Bronx neighborhood to attend private schools on scholarship was convicted yesterday of killing a young dancer from Ohio in what prosecutors said was a jealous rage.

title: The Modern Woman (1909 Vintage), Debated by Men
description: Harley Granville-Barker, a contemporary of George Bernard Shaw, was shamefully ignored for generations until recently, when small companies like the Mint Theater brought his intellectually provocative and eerily topical plays back into circulation. And these fascinating works, which touch on everything from abortion to an Enron-like business, have disproved the common wisdom that politics in plays age badly.

title: Vonage Posts Smaller Loss but Says Subscriber Growth Is Off
description: Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, lost less money last quarter, but it gained fewer new customers, indicating that competition may be intensifying.

title: Painting in the Heady Days, After It Was Proclaimed Dead
description: New York painting from the late 1960s and early 70s  when the medium supposedly was dead  is one of the biggest elephants in the room of recent art history. The nonpainting trends of those years have been relentlessly celebrated and valorized by museums, art historians and biennials. The multiple strands of Post-Minimalism that ended paintings dominance  Conceptual, Process, Performance, Earth and video art  have coalesced into a canon and master narrative of their own. The king is dead, long live the king.

title: Delaying of Dubai Port Deal Brings Port Authority Grief
description: The furor over a company from the United Arab Emirates operating terminals at the Port of Newark has been nearly matched this week by turmoil surrounding its exit.

title: Pin Placements Are More Than Just Holes in the Ground
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 15  At the first sign of pink in the black sky at Riviera Country Club, John Mutch slid into his golf cart and set out for the lifting darkness. He had a large cup of coffee in his hand and three golf balls in his pocket. Beside him, rattling softly in a cup holder, sat a can of white spray paint.

title: Molson Coors Profit Rises 343%
description: DENVER, Feb. 15  The Molson Coors Brewing Company, one of the worlds biggest beer companies, said Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit soared on increased sales volume, a lower tax rate and cost savings.

title: People
description: People

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday of Nixon: A Presidency Revealed, a documentary on the History Channel, referred imprecisely in some copies to Alexander Haig, Nixons chief of staff from 1973 to 1974, who was interviewed for the film. He was not convicted in the Watergate scandal, as were John Dean and Charles Colson, other administration figures who were interviewed for the documentary. (Go to Article)

title: Correction
description: A television review yesterday of Nixon: A Presidency Revealed, a documentary on the History Channel, referred imprecisely in some copies to Alexander Haig, Nixons chief of staff from 1973 to 1974, who was interviewed for the film. He was not convicted in the Watergate scandal, as were John Dean and Charles Colson, other administration figures who were interviewed for the documentary.

title: The Health Care Racket
description: Is the health insurance business a racket? Yes, literally  or so say two New York hospitals, which have filed a racketeering lawsuit against UnitedHealth Group and several of its affiliates.

title: Looking to the Future, Living With the Past
description: Life after wartime does not snap back to normal. In the opening scene of Grbavica: The Land of My Dreams the camera slowly pans across the stony, careworn faces of the women in a therapy group in the Sarajevo neighborhood that gives the movie its name. One of them cant stop giggling uncontrollably but is ignored by the others, who remain sealed behind walls of private grief and resignation. Some, like Esma (Mirjana Karanovic), the movies central character, attend only on days when financial aid is distributed.

title: Settlement Would Allow Fisk University to Sell 2 Paintings From Its Stieglitz Collection
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 15  Fisk University, which has been entangled in a yearlong legal dispute over two prominent paintings in its collection, will be allowed under a settlement to sell the works if no donor can be found to keep them at the university.

title: Editors Note
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary column on Monday related a conversation that a contributor, Andrea Silenzi, said she had had with a neighbor on the Upper East Side. The neighbors 5-year-old son had overheard his father, a stock trader, on the phone with a client, and had said to his mother, I know Daddy sells things at his job, but why oh why did he say he would sell my shorts?

title: Adventures in Geometry and Color, as Well as Dancing
description: Of all the titles that the New York City Ballet has come up with for its new fixed programs, For the Fun of It sounds the silliest. But as it turns out, this program, presented for the first time on Wednesday night, is one of the most persuasive groupings that the company has so far presented  and it makes a strong case for being able to see this particular set of works together again. (For those not following City Ballets policy decisions with bated breath, the company previously performed ever-changing combinations of ballets, rotating through about 40 works a season.)

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Estonia: President Rejects Vote to Remove Soviet Monuments
description: President Toomas Hendrik Ilves said he would veto legislation to authorize the removal of Soviet war monuments, specifically a memorial in the capital, Tallinn, known as the Bronze Soldier. The monument, viewed by many in Estonia as a symbol of Soviet occupation after World War II, has become the focus of intense protests in Estonia and had prompted furious denunciations from Russia. Parliament had narrowly approved the legislation to relocate the Bronze Soldier in a third and final vote earlier in the day, but in a statement Mr. Ilves called aspects of the legislation unconstitutional, though he did not elaborate.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Indonesias Avian Flu Holdout
description: Indonesia sent a chill through the World Health Organization recently when it refused to supply any more samples of the avian flu virus that has killed scores of its people. The move, which seemed aimed at gaining access to vaccines at an affordable price, threatens the global effort to track the virus and develop vaccines. But Indonesia has raised a valid point that needs to be addressed: if a pandemic should strike, poor countries would be left without protection.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Sheer Terror on Ice at Breakneck Speeds
description: IT was a frigid Saturday night in Lake Placid, N.Y., a nice time to be indoors, swilling an Ubu ale at the local brewery or warming up by a fieldstone fireplace.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: After Storm, Parking Tickets and an Outcry
description: As drivers dug themselves out from Wednesdays modest but messy snowstorm, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg found himself on the defensive over the citys decision not to suspend alternate-side parking rules. That move had residents complaining that their cars were ticketed after plows buried them in snow.

title: Microsoft Plays Down a Sales Lift From Vista
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15  Wall Street analysts are being too optimistic about sales of Windows Vista, Steven A. Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, told financial analysts in New York on Thursday.

title: A Bigger NATO, but at What Price? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: A Quirky Mountain Is Keeping Its Quirks
description: The Ski Report column last Friday about Mad River Glen in Vermont misstated the costs of membership in the cooperative that owns and operates the mountain. Members pay a one-time fee of $1,750 to join and then must spend at least $200 a year on services or goods at the mountain; there is no annual charge of about $1,800.

title: Married to the Cause, One State at a Time
description: WHEN he was 13 and growing up in Pittsburgh with his gayness under the radar, his own radar included, Evan Wolfson aggravated his parents by deciding to invite President Richard M. Nixon to his bar mitzvah.

title: Mordkhe Schaechter, 79, Leading Yiddish Linguist, Dies
description: Mordkhe Schaechter, a leading Yiddish linguist who spent a lifetime studying, standardizing and teaching the language, died yesterday in the Bronx. He was 79 and lived in Yonkers.

title: Trying Again for a Bill to Limit Tobacco Ads
description: After being thwarted for years, a bipartisan group of members of Congress reintroduced legislation yesterday that would allow the federal government to further regulate the tobacco industry by cracking down on marketing aimed at young people and requiring that reduced-risk tobacco products back up their claims with science.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about bloggers covering the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. referred imprecisely to the role of Robert A. Cox, president of the Media Bloggers Association, in securing credentials. Mr. Cox negotiated access for his association, which was the first blogger group to be granted credentials to cover the trial. He did not negotiate on behalf of firedoglake.com and other blogs that received their credentials later.

title: Blasts of Color, Evoking Memories
description: The Howard Hodgkin show at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is about as beautiful an exhibition of new paintings as I have seen in a while.

title: Donors Sweetened Directors Pay at MoMA
description: Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art for nearly 12 years, has long been one of the highest-paid museum officials in the country, with salary, bonus and benefits totaling $1.28 million in the year that ended June 30, 2005, the most recent period for which figures are publicly available.

title: Dispute Over Iraqi Cleric, Said to Have Gone to Iran
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 15  Questions and accusations continued to swirl about the whereabouts of the militant Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Thursday, and American and Iraqi forces deepened their security push in Baghdad.

title: Rice Is Said to Have Speeded North Korea Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  To win approval of a deal with North Korea that has been assailed by conservatives inside and outside the administration, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice bypassed layers of government policy review that had derailed past efforts to negotiate an agreement, several senior administration officials said this week.

title: C.I.A. Veteran Races Time to Rescue Fledgling Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  A born contrarian, Charles E. Allen has spent an intelligence career immersed in wars, alarms and debacles, often seeing the world differently from his colleagues.

title: In Fraud Case, 7 Years in Jail for Contempt
description: On Jan. 14, 2000, Martin A. Armstrong, a globe-trotting investment manager, was told to produce $15 million in gold and antiquities, as well as documents, in response to a civil suit by the government accusing him of securities fraud involving hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Rice Faces an Uphill Battle for a Mideast Breakthrough
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  On a chilly Saturday morning late last year, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and the Israeli foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, sat down alone in Ms. Rices apartment at the Watergate here and hashed out a plan.

title: A Lift to Backcountry Lite Terrain
description: IT is windy at the apex of the Imperial Express SuperChair at Breckenridge in Colorado, the highest lift-served elevation in the United States. But that doesnt stop about a quarter of the lift passengers from using a boot path in the snow  the Stairway to Heaven  to hike another 150 vertical feet to the very summit of Peak 8. Most of the rest of the crowd scurries over to the sign designating the spot as 12,840 feet above sea level. They will brace themselves against the gusts hoping to stand steady enough for a commemorative picture.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Frustrated Cubs Find Match in Fiery Piniella
