description: MESA, Ariz., Feb. 15  Lou Piniella paced feverishly on the grass behind second base, his arms flailing, eyes bulging, and head bobbing so vigorously that it looked as though his new cap might fly away.

title: The Faithful Aristocrat, Seduced by a Killer
description: Some prisoners are wrongly convicted, but most are guilty. And some of the most well-meaning people lose their innocence by association.

title: Sun, Water and the Mets Put a Nowhere on the Map
description: FOR the 45 years since its inception, Port St. Lucie has often been seen as something of a Florida nowheresville, a suburban city idling between the more attention-worthy municipalities of South Florida (Miami, Fort Lauderdale, Palm Beach) and the tourist magnet of Orlando.

title: JetBlue Flight Snarls Continue
description: As airlines and stranded passengers struggled to deal with hundreds of cancellations and delays caused by Wednesdays storm, things got particularly bad for JetBlue Airways last night when police officers were called to one of its service counters to help with irate customers.

title: Forget What You Know: Listen Anew
description: One way symphony orchestras soothe their subscribers is by creating so-called festivals celebrating composers already so celebrated they dont need festivals in the first place. For the New York Philharmonic this year it is Brahms, including all the symphonies and concertos in concerts extending until June.

title: New Grievance Deepens Old Quarrels
description: Near the end of an hourlong conference call Wednesday, Ronald S. Katz, the lawyer for a group of retired N.F.L. players, characterized a lawsuit that would be filed later that day against the National Football League Players Association.

title: Pressing Allies, President Warns of Afghan Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  President Bush warned on Thursday that he expected fierce fighting to flare in Afghanistan this spring, and he pressed NATO allies to provide a bigger and more aggressive force to guard against a resurgence by the Taliban and Al Qaeda that could threaten the fragile Afghan state.

title: On a Clear Day ...
description: WHO Kurt Skarin, 55, a lawyer from Agoura Hills, Calif., show with his wife, Keli, 46, a real estate agent

title: Highways in Pennsylvania Remain Snarled
description: Long sections of three major interstate highways in central Pennsylvania remained closed today, more than a day after an ice and snow storm glazed the pavement, leading to a string of accidents and a monumental 50-mile backup on Interstate 78.

title: Upshaw Maintains Royalties Were Distributed Properly
description: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, has denied allegations in a federal class-action lawsuit that maintained that the licensing arm of the union has improperly represented retired players and could owe them tens of millions of dollars.

title: Defense Chief Again Says U.S. Will Not Wage War With Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that the United States had no intention of attacking Iran and that any American military efforts against it would be confined to Iraq to disrupt the smuggling of bomb-making materials over the border.

title: Italy Indicts 26 Americans in C.I.A. Abduction Case
description: ROME, Feb. 16  An Italian judge today ordered the first trial involving the American program of kidnapping terror suspects on foreign soil, indicting 26 Americans, most of them C.I.A. agents, but also Italys former top spy.

title: N.B.A. Has Second Chance to Introduce a New Ball
description: The National Basketball Association will give the synthetic ball another look during the All-Star Game weekend in Las Vegas.

title: Bruce Metzger, Scholar and Bible Translator, Dies at 93
description: Bruce M. Metzger, an eminent scholar and translator of the Bible who oversaw the publication of a widely used modern edition that eliminated all the thees and thous and many of the hes, died on Tuesday in Princeton, N.J. He was 93 and a longtime Princeton resident.

title: Fed Says Production Fell 0.5% in January
description: Production at factories, mines and utilities fell 0.5 percent in January after a 0.5 percent December increase, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

title: Germany: Holocaust Denier Gets 5 Years
description: A court in Mannheim sentenced Ernst Zndel, left, a German-born, internationally known neo-Nazi and distributor of anti-Semitic literature, to five years in prison for inciting racial hatred and denying that the Nazis killed millions of Jews. It was the maximum sentence for Holocaust denial under German law. The German authorities arrested Mr. Zndel, 67, in 2005, when he was deported by Canada after a long court battle there. He had lived in Canada for several decades. German prosecutors were able to seek his extradition on the ground that a Web site he ran was accessible in Germany.

title: CityCenter and the Residences at the Little Nell
description: CityCenter

title: On Presidential Coinage
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about the new presidential coin released yesterday is that Congress has asked the United States Mint to issue one for every president from George Washington to Gerald Ford. With four new coins coming out virtually every year, it will be hard to complain about the 2007 series, which offers a bumper crop of Founding Fathers. Washington, who appeared yesterday, will be followed by John Adams, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison.

title: In Foreign Oscar Entries, the Past Masks the Present
description: Presidential candidates may be trolling Hollywood for money and support, yet dramas about American politics fizzled quickly this year. The star-filled Robert Kennedy biopic Bobby was a nostalgic mess, while the muddled Flags of Our Fathers became the Other Clint Eastwood Movie, eclipsed by the more original Letters From Iwo Jima. But as the Academy Award nominees for best picture suggest, it has been a terrific year for films about global politics. The culture clash between Japanese and American soldiers is at the heart of Letters; Babel ranges over several continents and languages to explore the anxiety and violence gripping the world.

title: Yankees Swindal Is Arrested in Florida
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15  George Steinbrenner is used to dealing with legal issues involving the former Yankees Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden. On Thursday, an arrest hit even closer to home.

title: Snowmobilers vs. Hikers in the Adirondacks
description: AT the head of the Pine Pond Trail not far from his home in Lake Placid, N.Y., Jim McCulley revved his sleek black Ski-Doo. A fresh snow had fallen overnight, draping the pines that rise on either side, and Mr. McCulley, the head of the local snowmobile club, looked giddy as he set off.

title: Manhattan: Schools Official Named
description: Chris Cerf, a deputy schools chancellor and former president of Edison Schools Inc., has hired as his chief of staff a former Edison official who ran a tutoring program criticized by investigators who found questionable practices in the city public schools. The chief of staff, Joel Rose, was from 2003 until 2006 the general manager of Newton Learning SES, an Edison division established to tutor children under the No Child Left Behind law. Last year, a report by the special commissioner of investigation for the public schools found that Newton had failed to conduct fingerprint and background checks of some workers, offered students gift certificates for attending tutoring sessions, and directly solicited students after being warned not to by the Education Department. After leaving Newton, Mr. Rose served as a consultant to the Education Department. Mr. Cerf declined to comment. An Education Department spokesman, David Cantor, said Mr. Rose was recovering from surgery and unavailable for comment but described his work with the department as invaluable.

title: Cuomo Raises New Objection to Starrett City Sale
description: The investment group that touched off a political storm with its plan to buy Starrett City  the sprawling low- and moderate-income housing project on Jamaica Bay  for $1.3 billion has been banned from converting rental buildings in New York to condominiums or co-operatives because of financial improprieties, state officials said today.

title: Bear Stearns Told to Pay $160 Million to Investors
description: A federal bankruptcy judge yesterday ordered Bear Stearns to pay nearly $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for failing to properly monitor the activities of the fund before it collapsed in early 2000. The ruling could force Wall Street firms to step up oversight of some of their most lucrative clients.

title: China Covers Up Detention of AIDS Doctor
description: BEIJING, Feb. 15  The photograph and article in Tuesdays Henan Daily could have been headlined Happy Holidays. Three highranking Henan Province officials, beaming and clapping as if presenting a lottery check, were making an early Lunar New Year visit to the apartment of a renowned AIDS doctor, Gao Yaojie.

title: House Passes Iraq Resolution With 17 Votes From G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  After four days of emotional debate over the extent of presidential powers in wartime and the proper role of Congress, the House of Representatives adopted a resolution today denouncing President Bushs plan to send more American troops to Iraq.

title: Ambassador Offers Utah Solace After Deaths
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15  Bosnia-Herzegovinas ambassador to the United States flew in from Washington on Thursday, offering condolences for those killed or injured in a shooting rampage at a mall here on Monday by a Bosnian refugee.

title: Go Early, and Take Your Warm Gear and Your Patience
description: For most late-night comedy shows that broadcast from New York, ticket reservations must be made long in advance. But to maximize the roar of laughter heard by viewers, producers fill any empty seats with standbys.

title: Another Energy Inquiry on Royalties Collection
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Top Democrats on the Senate Energy Committee, citing widespread management problems at the Interior Department, ordered a new inquiry on Thursday into the departments fast-growing program to collect billions of dollars worth of oil and gas from companies that drill on public territory.

title: Putin, Promoting an Ally, Fuels Speculation Over Successor
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday added intrigue to the unsettled but widely debated question of who might succeed him as Russias leader in 2008 when he promoted his minister of defense in an unexpected cabinet tinkering.

title: Look Sharp, Ladies, Youre in the Army Now
description: Soldiers uniforms are supposed to blur identity and present individuals as cogs in an impersonal military machine. Look closely, however, and underneath the uniforms are people with attitudes. Rebels and cynics dont adapt as well to enforced conformity as obedient apple polishers. And when the soldiers are young women, like Smadar (Smadar Sayar) and Mirit (Naama Schendar), spirited 18-year-old conscripts in the Israeli Army, whose routine is scrutinized in the drama Close to Home, the rules change color. In countless small ways its different for girls.

title: What Will My Spy Be? Capitalist, Drone, Deviant...
description: When John le Carr appropriated a nursery rhyme for his 1974 book about spies and spy-catchers, he borrowed just three words, tinker, tailor, soldier, then sexed up the whole thing by adding a fourth word, spy. The new film Breach, about the F.B.I. counterintelligence agent Robert Philip Hanssen, who sold secrets to the Soviet Union and later Russia for more than two decades, suggests that its time to dust off the rest of that same rhyme: rich man, poor man, beggar man, thief. Now in prison, where hes serving a life sentence, Mr. Hanssen was a little of each; he was also greedy, pathetic, malevolent  a creeps creep.

title: Pavano Takes Mound and Mussina Takes Aim
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15  Mike Mussina and Carl Pavano threw side by side on the bullpen mounds at Legends Field on Thursday morning. It is safe to assume they did not have dinner together Thursday night.

title: Home Prices Fall in More Than Half of Nations Biggest Markets
description: Prices for single-family homes fell in more than half of the nations 149 biggest metropolitan areas in the last three months of 2006, according to data released yesterday by a trade group for real estate agents.

title: Freedom From Fear
description: THERE is still time to take the fear out of the Freedom Tower. Despite reports that Gov. Eliot Spitzer has now decided to back the project, the fact is that with a little time it is still possible to rethink the tower and make it both secure and welcoming without setting back the overall ground zero construction schedule.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,121 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: 11 Rescued From Elevator
description: Eleven people were trapped in an elevator for more than two hours last night before being rescued by firefighters with ropes and ladders, fire officials said. The elevator became stuck shortly before 5:30 p.m. between the 15th and 16th floors of a 30-story building in the Polo Grounds Towers housing project in Washington Heights. Rescue workers retrieved the passengers, five adults and six children, through an escape hatch on the top of the elevator car. No one was injured, and the cause of the elevators failure was not immediately known, officials said. Numerous complaints about faulty elevators in the tower have been filed with the Buildings Department over the last several years, including one on Jan. 3, according to city records.

title: Chrysler Said to Seek Help From G.M. on a Big S.U.V.
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15  The Chrysler Group and General Motors are holding discussions about a joint project that would provide Chrysler with a version of the big Chevrolet Tahoe sport utility, people with direct knowledge of the talks said Thursday night.

title: A Collision of Role Players on the Busy Avenue of Life
description: A film about love and art, about passing time and time passing, Avenue Montaigne is a humble pleasure. The modesty feels intentional and misleading: the story is a nominally light affair abuzz with minor incidents, comic faces, choreographed nonsense, melodramatic blips and swells. But there are serious complications too, including a handful of characters facing life-altering decisions. On the face of it the film recalls the light comedies of what the French call boulevard theater, which were meant to entertain well-heeled patrons but at times, as with Avenue Montaigne, also offered more.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the future of the National Collegiate Athletic Associations Division III referred incorrectly to the mens swimming team at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point, a state institution in Division III, and to the national championship in swimming. Stevens Point finished ninth in the country last year, not among the top four teams. The championship is decided at a national meet; there is no Final Four in swimming.

title: Not Just Horses, Mind You, From George Stubbs
description: Art critics have long relegated George Stubbs (1724-1806) to the category of sporting painter. This British artist did make his living primarily by painting aristocrats favorite horses, though thats not all he did.

title: For the Record
description: The Memo From Frankfurt article on Feb. 7, about the efforts of two Red Army Faction terrorists to be released early from prison in Germany, misstated the firearm shown in the groups symbol, as it appeared in a ransom photograph behind Hanns-Martin Schleyer, a German industrialist kidnapped and murdered by the group in 1977. It was a Heckler & Koch MP5 machine gun  not a Kalashnikov, which the group had used earlier in its symbol.

title: Its Now Up to Williams as Torre Invites Him to Legends Field
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15  Bernie Williams is working out near his home in Westchester County, hitting baseballs off a tee, long tossing and running sprints. Manager Joe Torre told Williams on Wednesday that his once-fading chances of playing for the Yankees this season were contingent on him performing the same drills and much more in camp.

title: Russian Judge Dismisses Any Penalty in Piracy Case
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  A Russian judge convicted a provincial school headmaster on Thursday for using pirated Microsoft software in school computers, but declined to impose any penalty, saying that Microsofts loss was insignificant compared with its overall earnings.

title: 1,000 Dogs and Cats Killed After Outbreak at Shelter
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 15  An outbreak of disease that national experts say was of an unusual magnitude prompted a weeklong closing of the regions main animal shelter and the killing of about 1,000 dogs and cats.

title: Council Chief Announces Plans to Help Middle Class
description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, positioned herself as a champion of the middle class yesterday, proposing programs aimed at helping more New Yorkers buy homes, improving public middle schools and creating a savings account for city surpluses.

title: 2 Palestinian Leaders Meet to Pave Way for a New Cabinet
description: GAZA, Feb. 15  After months of difficult negotiations and bloody Palestinian street fighting, the Hamasled Palestinian government resigned Thursday to pave the way for a unity government that will include Hamas and the rival Fatah movement.

title: F.B.I. Raids on the Mayor Make Him Topic A in a Small Town
description: GUTTENBERG, N.J., Feb. 12  The whispers were everywhere in this sliver of a town on the Hudson: Federal investigators were here looking for something.

title: New England Resorts Hail Return of Winter Customers
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15  If a weather system can have impeccable timing, the one that brought more than two feet of snow to parts of northern New England this week arrived with the precision of an atomic clock.

title: Zimbabwes Slide (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Unhappy Wife Entangles Herself in a Sad-Funny Mess
description: Midway through Lauren Foxs first novel, the books heroine, Emily, envisions herself as an exhibit at the local natural history museum: an unhappy mannequin lounging in an apartment-diorama titled Twenty-First-Century Psychological Mess. The exhibition card would read: This species of American female was known for muddling her love life beyond repair. Fortunately, she did not reproduce.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER The all-too-real story of Adrienne Shelly, the 40-year-old actress and director who was founding hanging in her Greenwich Village office in November, gets ripped from the headlines in this episode, in which Detectives Green and Cassady try to prove that her death is anything but self-inflicted. Reza Salazar plays the workman who is eventually charged with her death.

title: Groups Hear Politics Talking When City Cites Code Violations
description: When the Bloomberg administration was accused this month of housing formerly homeless families in buildings with serious housing code violations, city officials came back with an argument they had made before: The number of code violations on a building, they said, is not proof that any one apartment is unsafe.

title: Touring the Quebec Countryside on Canadas White Highways
description: THEIR speed. The acrid stench of their two-cycle engines. And their whine, louder than a hundred chainsaws, shattering the white silence of winter.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: The Autoworkers Pain
description: American autoworkers are suffering through another round of layoffs, factory closings and buyouts. This time DaimlerChrysler has announced that it will cut 13,000 jobs in North America. Ford Motor and General Motors offered buyouts to a total of nearly 200,000 hourly workers in 2006.

title: Stepping Lively at Credit Suisse
description: To prepare for a charity event late last year that called for him to dance with a Broadway star, Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisses investment bank, practiced for two months.

title: Schoeneweiss Jersey Isnt Just Any Number
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15  After signing with the Mets, Scott Schoeneweis figured he had his big chance. Finally, after all these years, he could stop being No. 60. But when he walked into the clubhouse Wednesday evening and saw his new jersey, he recoiled. His last name was spelled correctly. But the new number, a very mainstream 36, suddenly seemed strange.

title: Turners Traveling on Three-City Tour
Amid the Woe, a Haitian Paradise Beckons
description: LABADIE, Haiti  There is Haiti, the poorest nation in the hemisphere. And then there is this slice of Caribbean bliss surrounded by security fencing with all-you-can-eat buffets.

title: 2 Suspects Absent in Moscow in Retrial Over Editors Killing
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  The retrial of three men charged with murdering Paul Klebnikov, the American editor of the Russian-language Forbes magazine here, opened in confusion on Thursday as two of the suspects failed to appear in court and the judge postponed the beginning of jury selection for a month.

title: A Work in Progress, Knicks Receive Good Reviews
description: If only the Knicks could refashion themselves as a big-budget film, their season might be considered a big-time hit. Box-office sales are strong. They provide countless thrills and gripping plot twists. And they have won praise from the nations leading critics.

title: Viewers Fast-Forwarding Past Ads? Not Always
description: People with digital video recorders like TiVo never watch commercials, right?

title: Last-Minute Extension in Afghanistan for Unit Whose Bags Were Packed
description: The 3,200 soldiers of the 10th Mountain Division whose one-year deployment in Afghanistan has been extended by four months were so close to the end of their tour that their uniforms, gear and equipment had been packed into shipping containers and an advance party had already reached Fort Drum, their home in upstate New York.

title: Protecting Those Who Speak Out
description: The plight of federal workers who raise alarms about waste and fraud in government has become a scandal unto itself. That candid air marshal suddenly assigned to desk duty after complaining of shoddy agency practices has plenty of company, including workers who have lost security clearances or found their jobs suddenly relocated far from home. But in a vote this week of bipartisan unanimity, the House government reform committee offered whistle-blowers fresh hope with a much needed measure to protect them against official retaliation.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about growing political opposition to the pending $1.3 billion sale of the Starrett City apartment complex in Brooklyn misspelled the name of a different Brooklyn complex owned by a group headed by David Bistricer, who also wants to buy Starrett. It is Vanderveer Estates, not Vandermeer.

title: Manhattan: Lawsuit Over Building Sale
description: A group of tenants represented by Manhattan Legal Services said yesterday that they planned to sue the Salvation Army over what they said were plans to sell two single-room-occupancy buildings in Manhattan. The tenants, residents of buildings on Gramercy Park South and at 145 East 39th Street, say the Salvation Army should not be allowed to evict them if the buildings are sold. Edwina Martin, a spokeswoman for Legal Services, said a lawsuit asking the court to find that the tenants are protected by city rent laws would be filed today in State Supreme Court. The Salvation Army declined to comment on the pending suit, but a spokeswoman, Laura deBuys, said the organization had been working with the tenants for more than a year to find them suitable alternative housing.

title: U.S. Looks Into Gifts to Ex-Congressman, Now Governor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Federal authorities are investigating gifts and payments that Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada received as a congressman from an executive of a software company that got millions of dollars in federal contracts, government officials said Thursday.

title: Wagner Sharpens His Focus After a Restless Winter
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15  When 2-month-old Kason Wagner wakes up in the middle of the night, his father, Mets closer Billy Wagner, does not.

title: Singapore: Corporate Taxes Cut
description: Singapore cut corporate taxes for the first time in three years to lure more international financial services and technology companies. The government will reduce the maximum tax rate payable by companies to 18 percent from 20 percent from the 2008 year of assessment, according to the second minister for finance, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, above. The tax on goods and services will be increased 2 percentage points, to 7 percent, from July 1 to make up for the revenue shortfall from lower collections from companies, he said. The government of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong intends to attract 11.9 billion Singapore dollars ($7.7 billion) of investment in services and manufacturing industries this year to underpin growth.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Profit up 95% at Drug Maker
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15  Biogen Idec reported Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit nearly doubled on growing sales of treatments for cancer and multiple sclerosis.

title: Orchid Season: Blooms, Exhibitions and Fanatics
description: JUST when the skin-cracking chill and bland winter landscape are getting tiresome, its time to share a warm greenhouse with some orchids. These most flamboyant of flowers thrive while winter rages  many dramatic species bloom from February to April  and collectors and growers will be flaunting them in the next three months in shows around the world.

title: Tighter Rules for Air Tours
description: GETTING to a vacation destination on a scheduled airline is extremely safe. But flying as part of the vacation  like taking a tour of one of the Hawaiian islands or the Grand Canyon in a small plane or helicopter  can be another story. Regulation is so primitive that federal officials say that among the hundreds of small aircraft crashes every year, it is often difficult to determine which ones involve tours.

title: Calm at Jerusalem Holy Site in Spite of Calls for Protest
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16  Despite calls by Muslim religious figures for mass protests today against Israeli excavation work near a site holy to both Judaism and Islam, the Old City section of Jerusalem was largely calm during and after midday prayers at the Al Aksa Mosque.

title: France: Profit Up at Loral
description: LOral, the worlds largest cosmetics maker, said profit rose in 2006 as the company sold more Lancme luxury makeup and Armani Code perfume. Net income climbed to 1.83 billion euros ($2.4 billion), after adjustment for some items, from 1.64 billion euros in 2005, the company said. Revenue for the year rose 8.7 percent, to 15.8 billion euros. In the fourth quarter, it rose 10 percent, to 4.2 billion euros. Sales of luxury cosmetics rose 5.3 percent in the year, helped by Armani Code perfume, while revenue from antiwrinkle products like Normaderm Nuit from Vichy rose 14 percent. LOral, which is based in Paris, said costs related to the acquisition of the Body Shop retail chain last year and an increase in expenses for research and development would hurt profit this year.

title: St. Johns Likely to Make the Big East Tournament
description: It is not that hard to make the Big East mens basketball tournament. Twelve of the conferences 16 teams qualify, but St. Johns has not been there since 2003, which pretty much sums up how far the Red Storms once-storied program has fallen.

description: Here is information about books mentioned in this article:

title: Rings, Ropes and Straps Down That Rabbit Hole
description: Mining the works of Lewis Carroll, the Lookingglass Theater Company of Chicago has populated the stage of the New Victory Theater with a broad menagerie of Carrolls creations and added some circus arts to the mix.

title: Sports Briefing
description: steroids

title: 3 Longtime Executives Advance at NBC
description: Jeff Zucker, newly installed as the chief executive of NBC Universal, announced a series of executive promotions yesterday; all had been expected.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article last Friday about the homecoming of Steven Domalewski, from Wayne, N.J., whose heart stopped when he was struck in the chest by a batted ball in June as he was pitching for his youth team, referred imprecisely to the brain injury he sustained, and to the recovery prospects for other patients dealing with brain injuries. Domalewski sustained damage because of a lack of oxygen to the brain, not because of a traumatic brain injury. Many people with traumatic brain injuries recover fully; a majority of them are not like Steven, whose recovery faces considerable physical and mental challenges.

title: Coach With a Link to Obama Has Hope for Browns Future
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 12  When Barack Obama visited Brown University for a speech last fall, he predicted two upsets in early November.

title: A Move to Heal Anglican Rift, but Short of Conservatives Goal
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 15  The Episcopal Church in the United States has taken steps to heal a rift over homosexuality that threatens to fracture the worldwide Anglican Church, but it has not compromised as much as conservative Anglican leaders have demanded, according to a report issued at a crucial meeting of the Anglican leadership here on Thursday.

title: Think Small
description: WHEN John Friedman and Kristin Shepherd of Berkeley, Calif., purchased 160 acres in the mountains near Telluride, Colo., it was with the intent to build  just not right away. Before designing a small, ecologically sensitive second home they wanted to spend a year or two visiting the land to determine the most suitable building site. But at an elevation of 9,600 feet, living in tents was out.

title: Live From New York, Its Cold People Waiting in Line
description: I THOUGHT I deserved it.

title: My War Away From War
description: I WILL always remember last Aug. 13 as one of the best days of my life. On that day, after 47 days of waiting, and just four days before classes were to begin at Columbia, where I had received a scholarship, I was granted an American visa. Not only would I be able to fulfill my dream of studying in the United States, but I would also find some peace.

title: Democratic Leader Gambles That Weekend Detention Could End Senates Squabbling on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  As the House prepared to pass a symbolic resolution denouncing President Bushs war policy, Senate Democratic leaders on Thursday abruptly scheduled a weekend debate on Iraq in an effort to break a stalemate and avoid impressions that partisan bickering was weighing down deliberations over the war.

title: Washington for Kids, Without Nuance
description: There is nothing for grown-ups in Cory in the House, the Disney Channels new tween sitcom. There are no clever double-entendres. No hidden meanings lurk beneath the boisterous banter of 15-year-old Cory Baxter (Kyle Massey) and his friends at a Washington prep school. Even though Cory is set in the White House, where the heros father (Rondell Sheridan) is the presidents chef, no political messages issue from anyones mouth, least of all that of President Martinez (John DAquino), a genial but clueless commander in chief.

title: Option Lies May Be Costly for Directors
description: For companies that played games with employee stock options, the possible penalties are growing. New rulings in Delaware indicate that directors would be personally liable if options were wrongly issued.

title: Clinton and Her Iraq Credibility Gap (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Chief Presses Sudan to Allow Team to Visit Darfur
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 15  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Thursday that President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan had broken a personal pledge he made last month to give entry permits to a United Nations human rights team, and Mr. Ban urged the Sudanese leader to reconsider.

title: Flaunting Dominion in Ancient Iran
description: The opening of Asia Societys glinting and glowing show of pre-Islamic art from Iran turned into something of a cliffhanger late last week when dozens of objects coming from Paris were held up by customs at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Walter Sondheim Jr., 98, Leader in Baltimore Renewal, Dies
description: Walter Sondheim Jr., a longtime Baltimore civic leader who played crucial roles in desegregating the citys schools and redeveloping its downtown, died yesterday in Baltimore. He was 98.

title: Hershey Cutting Work Force 12%
description: Hershey will close more than a third of its assembly lines and eliminate 12 percent of its work force after sales fell for the first time in 3  years, the company said yesterday.

title: Bostons Matsuzaka Customizes a Classic Japanese Fable
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Transcending Pain, a Friendship Fed on Imagination
description: Despite an ad campaign suggesting wall-to-wall special effects, Bridge to Terabithia is grounded in reality far more than in fantasy. Adapting Katherine Patersons award-winning novel, the screenwriters David Paterson (Ms. Patersons son) and Jeff Stockwell have produced a thoughtful and extremely affecting story of a transformative friendship between two unusually gifted children. The result is a movie whose emotional depth could appeal more to adults than to their offspring.

title: Fed-Up New Orleans Residents Are Giving Up
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15  After nearly a decade in the city of their dreams, Kasandra Larsen and her fianc, Dylan Langlois, climbed into a rented moving truck on Marais Street last Sunday, pointed it toward New Hampshire, and said goodbye.

title: Photos Reveal Mars Had Water Underground
description: New, detailed photographs of Mars show evidence of subterranean streams of liquid, including water, that once flowed long enough that they could have sustained simple forms of life, researchers say.

title: History and Giulianis Run: Theres Good News and Bad News
description: No United States senator has been elected president since John F. Kennedy in 1960, but former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is challenging an even more formidable historical hurdle: No former mayor has been elected president since Grover Cleveland of Buffalo in 1884 and Calvin Coolidge of Northampton, Mass., in 1924.

title: To Protect, Serve, and if Necessary, Stand and Shiver
description: Five layers buffered Police Officer David Kantor from the world, and the enemy still got through.

title: A School District With Low Taxes and No Schools
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 13  Just to be clear, Patrick Flynn says he loves public education. He just does not like the idea of paying for it.

title: Lottery Prize Unclaimed in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 15  For now, there is no millionaire in the making. The deadline has come and gone for claiming the winning $3.5 million Connecticut Classic Lotto jackpot from Valentines Day last year. The ticket, with the winning numbers of 15, 17, 19, 26, 37 and 38, expired at midnight Wednesday, and no one has stepped forward to claim the prize money.

title: Wrigleys Ivy-Covered Walls to Get Ads
description: Under Armours athletic clothing will be the first product advertised among the ivy on the walls of Wrigley Field.

title: Barber Finds the Right Fit and Friendship
description: Nearly six years ago, long before three media conglomerates bid for Tiki Barbers post-playing TV services, Barber started building a friendship with his new boss, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC Universal.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Friday about the acquisition of the Johnny Rockets hamburger chain by Daniel M. Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, referred incorrectly to the car that was repossessed during Mr. Snyders earlier financial troubles. Although it was a Lotus sports coupe, it was not an Elise.

title: Democrats in State Capitols Push Antiwar Resolutions
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15  Frustrated by the inability of Democrats in Congress to pass a resolution opposing President Bushs policies in Iraq, state legislators across the country, led by Democrats and under pressure from liberal advocacy groups, are pushing forward with their own resolutions.

title: For the Record
description: The Insider column in Business Day last Friday, about securities rules and hedge funds, referred incorrectly to the Securities and Exchange Commissions threshold for one category of wealthy individuals to invest in hedge funds. Qualified investors must have investments worth at least $5 million, excluding their home; they cannot just have a net worth of $5 million, which could include their home.

title: Will Russia Bet on Its People or Its Oil Wells?
description: In a high-rise building with a view of Lenins Tomb, the U.S. aerospace giant Boeing is designing key parts of its new 787 Dreamliner, using hundreds of Russian aerospace engineers. Yes, President Putin may be talking cold-war tough, but down the street from the Kremlin, Americas crown jewel industrial company is using Russias crown jewel brainpower to design its next crown jewel jetliner.

title: Credit Suisse Names New C.E.O.
description: ZURICH, Feb. 15  Credit Suisse rewarded its American investment banking chief today for a sharp rise in profit, naming him chief executive to succeed Oswald Grbel, who surprised investors by announcing that he would step down in May.

title: White House Is Reported to Be Linked to a Dismissal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  A United States attorney in Arkansas who was dismissed from his job last year by the Justice Department was ousted after Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel, intervened on behalf of the man who replaced him, according to Congressional aides briefed on the matter.

title: How to Run for Office
description: Should you have even a remote thought of running for office, you need to learn about the conditional apology. Few politicians can live without it.

title: Gun Killings in Britain Prompt Soul Searching
description: LONDON, Feb. 16  With an outpouring of soul-searching and public sorrow, British leaders registered dismay today at a spate of gun crime in south London that has claimed five lives, mainly young men in their mid-teens shot to death in their homes.

title: Bloomberg Backtracks on Parking Tickets
description: A day after telling New Yorkers to stop griping over parking tickets issued to snowbound cars, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued a rare apology and promised to waive all tickets handed out today and Thursday for alternate-side-of-the-street parking violations.

title: Theater Listings
description: BEBE NEUWIRTH This just in from the Times Square police blotter: Velma Kelly, the sometime vaudeville star and accused murderer of two, has offed her fellow jailbird Roxie Hart and assumed her identity.

title: Maryland: Woman Sentenced in Prostitution Conspiracy
description: A Germantown woman was sentenced in federal court in Baltimore to two years in prison for her role in transporting several hundred prostitutes from New York and New Jersey to work in Maryland. From April 2003 to November 2005, federal prosecutors said, the woman, Rosibel Aparicio Jandres, 45, and others picked up the prostitutes on Monday mornings and dropped them off at 15 apartments and houses in Gaithersburg, Langley Park and Wheaton, where they worked as prostitutes for a week at a time. Six co-defendants, including Mrs. Jandress husband, Manuel Jandres, and her sister, Olinda Aparicio, have also pleaded guilty. Another defendant, Jair Francis of Langley Park, was convicted in December of conspiracy to transport women for prostitution and other charges.

title: Silicon Valley Meets American Idol With Prizes to Inspire Inventors
description: FACING down stiff competition to win fame and big prize money? Forget singing for Simon Cowell and Paula Abdul. Try sequencing DNA for a panel of technology investors.

title: Bush and His Iran Credibility Gap (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopes for Healing as Spains Terror Trial Starts
description: MADRID, Feb. 15  A widely broadcast trial of 29 suspects opened Thursday in Spain, with hopes that a public forum could offer a catharsis to a nation scarred by the rush-hour train bombings that killed 191 people in March 2004 and that sundered Spains political establishment.

title: Japan Expected to Hold Interest Rates Steady
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15  Japans surprisingly strong growth in the last quarter of 2006 was just a one-time surge by an otherwise sluggish economy and is not likely to push the central bank to raise interest rates next week, economists in Tokyo said on Thursday.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about continuing snowfall in Oswego County, N.Y., parts of which had already received 110 inches since Feb. 2, misstated the location of the city of Oswego, the countys largest municipality. It is on the southeastern  not southwestern  corner of Lake Ontario.

title: And if the Security Deposit Earns Less Than 1 Percent?
description: Q In the Real Estate Q & A column on Feb. 4, a lawyer answered a question about interest on a security deposit. He said that a landlord is allowed to deduct from the interest earned on the deposit an "administrative expense" equal to 1 percent of the total amount on deposit.

title: Who Pays to Replace a Condos Garage Roofs?
description: Q I live in a condominium complex where most units, but not all, come with a garage. The board is planning on levying a special assessment to replace the garages' roofs. Are those of us who do not own garages responsible for this assessment, too?

title: Pulse: Outshining the Sun
description: Looking for a warm-weather shopping indulgence in the middle of the slush and cold? Spring for patent leather.

title: Current Contexts
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On The Market
Correction: Sea Change for a Dad
description: An article last Friday about a father's experience taking his family on a Disney cruise to the Bahamas misstated the name of the ship. It was the Wonder, not the Magic. The writer's initial booking information had referred to the Magic, and he was unaware the Wonder had been substituted. The two ships are, according to Disney officials, "virtually identical," and the names do not appear in onboard signage.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Sonia Friedman and Boyett Ostar Productions have confirmed that they will move the newest Tom Stoppard play, "Rock 'n' Roll," a sold-out hit at the Royal Court Theater in London, to a Shubert theater on Broadway in October. Casting details have not been announced.

title: Thoma Cressey to Change Name
description: Thoma Cressey Equity Partners, the Chicago-based private equity firm, is changing its name to Thoma Cressey Bravo. The change recognizes the contributions of Orlando Bravo, head of its San Francisco office, the firm said.

title: J.P. Morgan Adds Health Care Banker
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired Barry Blake as a managing director in its investment banking group, where he will cover health care services. Mr. Blake, who will be based in New York, was previously with Lehman Brothers, J.P. Morgan said in an internal announcement.

title: Some Investors Skeptical of a Chrysler-GM Deal
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 - The willingness by DaimlerChrysler to cut loose its careworn Chrysler Group, ending its nine-year trans-Atlantic partnership, is drawing cheers from investors.

title: Silicon Valley Meets American Idol With Prizes to Inspire Inventors
description: Something like an American Idol for the technorati may be coming to Silicon Valley. Venture capital firms are considering contests that offer competing engineers and entrepreneurs multimillion-dollar prize purses if they come up with innovative technologies in various industries.

title: Former Monster Executive Admits Backdating Options
description: A former top executive of Monster Worldwide, the company that runs the Monster.com job search Web site, admitted in court Thursday that he illegally backdated millions of dollars in employee stock option grants. Myron F. Olesnyckyj, 45, of New Providence, N.J., pleaded to securities fraud and conspiracy to commit securities fraud, charges that carry potential penalties of up to 25 years in prison and fines of more than $5.2 million. He promised to cooperate, which can earn him leniency. Mr. Olesnyckyj, a former senior vice president for Monster, agreed to forfeit $381,000, which he said represented the amount he had illegally gained.

title: Delaying of Dubai Port Deal Brings Port Authority Grief
description: The furor over a company from the United Arab Emirates operating terminals at the Port of Newark has been nearly matched this week by turmoil surrounding its exit. Over the past year, DP World, the port operator owned by the royal Maktoum family of Dubai, has been under stiff political pressure to sell its rights to run terminals in ports around the United States. So in December, DP World reached an agreement estimated at more than a billion dollars to sell its leases to A.I.G. Global Investment Group, an arm of the American insurance giant.

title: Conrad Blacks Lawyers Seek to Stifle Tape
description: Lawyers for Conrad M. Black, the former press mogul, have asked a judge to bar prosecutors from showing jurors a tape on which a shareholder calls the then-head of the Hollinger media empire a thief. In a brief, Mr. Blacks lawyers told Judge Amy J. St. Eve of Federal District Court on Wednesday that the remarks by an irate shareholder, Edward Shuffro, at the May 23, 2002, Hollinger International shareholders meeting were hearsay.

title: Mobile E-Mail Firm Visto Raises $35 Million
description: Visto, a maker of software for wireless e-mail, said Friday it received a $35 million investment from Altitude Capital Partners in what it called its last round of financing. In September, the Redwood City, Calif.-based company announced a $51 million funding round led by Oak Investment Partners.

title: U.S. May Charge Ex-Executives of Apple and Broadcom, Report Says
description: Federal prosecutors are strongly considering criminal charges against former executives of Broadcom, Apple, and KLA-Tencor, related to the backdating of stock options, The Wall Street Journal reported. Prosecutors are also nearing charges against a former official of computer-security company McAfee, the report said. In addition, a former executive of Engineered Support Systems, a defense contractor now owned by DRS Technologies, has been told of a likely charge, according to the Journal.

title: A Possible Hitch in Hedge Funds Sapporo Plans
description: Steel Partners, the hedge fund run by financier Warren Lichtenstein, may once again find itself circumvented in a bid for a Japanese target. This time the activist hedge fund is gunning for Japanese brewer Sapporo Holdings, seeking to raise its stake in the beer maker to 66.6 percent in preparation for an eventual buyout.

title: 7 Years and Still in Contempt
description: On Jan. 14, 2000, Martin A. Armstrong, a globe-trotting investment manager, was told to produce $15 million in gold and antiquities, as well as documents, in response to a civil suit by the government accusing him of securities fraud involving hundreds of millions of dollars. When he said that he did not have the items and could not produce them, a federal judge ordered him jailed for contempt of court. Seven years later, Mr. Armstrong sits in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Lower Manhattan.

title: Credit Suisses New No-Frills Chief
description: />One of the things that sets Brady W. Dougan apart from his peers is his aversion to the limelight. But Mr. Dougan, who was anointed Credit Suisse Groups chief executive Thursday, will be the youngest chief executive of a global banking giant, a position that is by no means a private one. Mr. Dougan, whom The New York Times describes a shy, workaholic from the Midwest who ran marathons in near world-class times and acknowledges an addiction to Diet Dr Pepper, stands in contrast with many of Wall Streets top executives, whose aggressive charm has paved their way to the top.

title: German Steel Maker Eyes Canadas Algoma
description: Shares of Salzgitter, Germanys second-largest steelmaker, fell for the first day in four after the company said that it is in talks to buy Canadian competitor Algoma Steel. Salzgitter, based in the German city of the same name, said late Thursday that it is in very preliminary talks with Algoma. Algoma confirmed the talks and said any offer will probably be below its current share price. Shares of Algoma rose 13 percent to a record C$50.44 yesterday, valuing the company at C$1.6 billion ($1.4 billion).

title: Portugal Telecom Wrings Higher Bid from Reluctant Rival
description: Portuguese telecommunications group Sonaecom on Thursday raised its bid for rival Portugal Telecom from 9.50 euros to 10.50 euros a share, increasing the value of its hostile takeover bid from 10.7 billion euros to almost 12 billion euros ($15.7 billion). Sonaecom had been adamant since it launched the bid a year ago that it was not prepared to increase its original offer, despite the insistence of several leading PT shareholders that they were not prepared to sell at 9.50 euros a share.

title: India Cellular Offering Sparks Mad Rush
description: Indias Idea Cellular received offers for at least 50 times the $482 million it sought to raise in an initial share sale, which closed three days after Vodafone Group announced an acquisition in the country. Idea Cellular, owned by the Aditya Birla Group, Citigroup and Providence Equity Partners, drew 16.19 billion bids for 326.9 million shares, according to the National Stock Exchange.

title: VCs Light Up Reactrix With $45 Million
description: Reactrix, which makes interactive advertising displays projected on shopping mall floors, said it closed a $45 million Series D funding round, led by D.E. Shaw Group and Menlo Ventures, both new investors. The funding will go toward expanding its network of malls and theaters and developing new technology, the company said.

title: LVMH and Morgan Stanley Come to Terms
description: LVMH and Morgan Stanley smoked the peace pipe together on Thursday, ending a five-year court battle over the luxury groups accusation of bias and conflicts of interest in research published by the Wall Street investment bank between 1999 and 2002.

title: Is Icahn Over Time Warner?
description: Carl C. Icahn, after a very public campaign against Time Warner last year, during which he attacked its chief executive and tried to force a break up of the company, now apparently has other fish to fry. Mr. Icahn and his Icahn Management affiliate have dumped about 44 million shares of the media company over the course of the fourth quarter, according to a Wednesday filing with the Security and Exchange Commission quarterly filing.

title: The Downside of Club Deals
description: Private equity funds may find that being part of a buyout consortium, which has become increasingly popular in recent years, can be problematic, especially when the time comes to negotiate an exit, Financial News reports.

title: Northwest Expects to Be Worth $7 Billion
description: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that it expected to be worth roughly $7 billion when it emerged from bankruptcy later this year and that it would pay unsecured creditors roughly three-quarters of what they were owed. Continental, which follows Northwest on the list of major airlines, is worth just over $4 billion based on Thursdays stock valuation.

title: HCP Tables Rival Bid for Candian REIT
description: Health Care Property Investors Inc., the largest U.S. owner of real estate for healthcare providers, jumped into the bidding for Toronto-based Sunrise Senior Living Real Estate Investment Trust with an offer of C$2.3 billion ($2.0 billion). HCP said it is offering about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars for Sunrise REITs equity, which represents a 20 percent increase on a rival offer made in January by Ventas. HCP is offering C$18 a unit, valuing the equity at about C$1.4 billion. Ventas has offered C$15 per unit.

title: Spanish Bank Pays $9.6 Billion for Compass
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spains second-biggest bank, agreed to buy Compass Bancshares for $9.6 billion to gain a greater foothold in the consumer-lending market in the southern United States. The Spanish bank is offering Compass shareholders $71.82 in cash or 2.8 new BBVA shares for each Compass share. The offer represents an 8.2 percent premium to Compasss closing price yesterday of $66.37. Speculation about an imminent bid sent Compass shares up $4.59, or 7.4 percent, Thursday.

title: Citis Shake-Up: The Scapegoat Theory
description: Since Citigroups split with former wealth-management head Todd S. Thomson, much of the reporting has focused on his supposedly lavish ways and his ties to a CNBC anchor. But a story in BusinessWeek suggests that some on Wall Street think Mr. Thomson became a convenient scapegoat for Citigroup and that his ouster was a way to distract from deeper problems.

title: Red Kite Calls Investor Withdrawals Insignificant
description: RK Capital Management downplayed reports of investors withdrawing cash from its $1 billion Red Kite Metals hedge fund, after the firm suffered a 30 percent loss last month. We are pleased to report that our investor base, including all of our major investors, has given us strong support and encouragement for the future, Red Kite, run out of London and New York, said in a statement Friday.

title: Ruling Ripples Through Prime Brokerage Business
description: Bear Stearns was ordered yesterday to pay $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for failing to properly monitor the funds activities, and the ruling could have much broader effects. The decision may alter the nature of the relationship between big investment banks and hedge funds, The New York Times wrote Friday.

title: Dirtball Triumph
description: Reuters points out that many of the contenders for best actor played bad guys, including a dictator, a mercenary and a crackhead. Ryan Gosling, who played a teacher mixed up with a white, chalky substance, told Reuters he did his research. I smoke a lot of crack, he said. Such a kidder,that guy.

title: Q. & A.:  Iranian Weapons in Iraq
description: In recent days, American officials, including President Bush, have asserted that the Iranian government has been playing a role in providing lethal weapons to Shiite militants in Iraq that have been used in deadly attacks against American troops. Here some of the questions that have arisen about the American assertions, and some of the evolving answers. 1) What are these weapons, and why does the United States government describe them as so alarming? Iraq is awash with weapons, and increasing numbers of those recovered by the American military there, including some shoulder-fired missiles, are of Iranian origin, American military officials said. But they have become most concerned about the weapons known as explosively formed penetrators, are a particularly lethal type of roadside bomb. Triggered by infrared sensors, the bombs propel a nearly-molten ball of metal at a speed that can penetrate most American vehicle armor. Overall, they account for only a small fraction of attacks in Iraq and of overall American deaths since 2003. But American military intelligence officials say the casualties inflicted by E.F.P.s are disproportionately high. They have been used almost exclusively by Shiite militias, particularly in Baghdad. Since 2004, the weapons have killed more than 170 American soldiers and wounded 620 more since June 2004, the officials say. The number of E.F.P. attacks has increased substantially, particularly in Baghdad, where it reached an all-time high in December 2006. 2) On what basis does the United States claim that these weapons are linked to Iran?  The claims are based on information that ranges from near-conclusive to the circumstantial, American officials say. The strongest evidence is forensic, based on an examination of intact E.F.P.s intercepted as they are shipped into Iraq from across the Iranian border. Similarly, some weapons parts recovered after attacks have borne Iranian markings or other indicators characteristic of Iranian manufacture. Other information is based on human intelligence. American officials note that the Iranian-backed militant group Hezbollah used similar weapons extensively in southern Lebanon, and say they have intelligence that Lebanese Hezbollah forces provided training to Shiite militants. They say that Iranians and Iraqis detained in recent American raids on an Iranian office in Baghdad and another site in Erbil have provided information linking the weapons shipments to the Quds Force, an elite branch of Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. Other claims appear to be analytical conclusions based on inference rather than hard evidence. For example, American officials say they do not believe there are facilities in Iraq capable of manufacturing the weapons but cannot prove that one does not exist. Similarly, they say they have been no evidence that the weapons are available on the black market. American officials say they possess other, detailed information linking the weapons to Iran that they remain unwilling to publicly disclose. Some of that information, including details about the weapons manufacture and their effectiveness, is being withheld by The New York Times at the request of American military and intelligence officials, who argue that its public disclosure would compromise intelligence sources and methods and could endanger American lives. 3) Why has the Bush administration made its assertions public only recently?  In fact, American military and intelligence officials have expressed private concerns about Iranian links to E.F.P.s for well over a year. An Aug. 6, 2005, article in The New York Times attributed to American military and intelligence officials growing concerns among American military and intelligence officials about more sophisticated roadside bombs that could be traced to Iran. Since then, American commanders and Bush administration officials have periodically expressed general concern about what they described as Irans support for Shiite militants. Nevertheless, the American assertions have become much more direct and vocal in the past month. The timing appears to be part of a cycle related to the sharp increase of attacks using the weapons against American forces in 2006. Those attacks prompted deep concern among American military commanders in Baghdad, and they sought authorization for a more vigorous response. In response, American officials now say, President Bush late in the year secretly authorized American military forces in Iraq to raid Iranian facilities in Iraq suspected of playing a role in the weapons shipments. Those raids were not publicly announced, but resulted in the detention of some Iranian diplomats, and when that fact became known it prompted the Iraqi government, the press, and others pressed the White House and military commanders in Baghdad to justify the aggressive American actions. On Feb. 2, the administration made public portions of a new National Intelligence Estimate that said Iran was providing lethal support to Shiite militias in Iraq, but described the conflict in Iraq as largely self-sustaining. An article in The New York Times on Feb. 10, based on weeks of reporting, provided the first extensive account of the American assertions, which it said represented a consensus view among American intelligence agencies. That article was based on interviews with a broad range of civilian and military officials in which The Times solicited views from agencies that had been skeptical about the extent to which Iran was responsible for attacks in Iraq. A day after the article was published, three American military and intelligence officials outlined the assertions to a large group of reporters at a briefing in Baghdad that had been postponed for several weeks while the administration debated how much information to make public. The most specific, public assertions by the United States came on Feb. 14, when President Bush, at a news conference in Washington, and Maj. Gen. William Caldwell, the American military spokesman in Baghdad, both presented detailed accounts of the American claims. 4) What role has the Iranian government played?  Iran has denied all knowledge of any weapons transfers to Iraqis and accused the United States of trying to provoke a confrontation. American officials have generally stopped short of directly blaming the Iranian government for any weapons transfers. They say that the question of high-level Iranian culpability remains the weakest link in their intelligence chain, and that their views are based primarily on supposition. Most notably, Mr. Bush said on Feb. 14 that he did not know whether the actions had been specifically directed Irans leaders. Nevertheless, the American message has often been contradictory, helping to fuel skepticism of those who suggest that the Bush administration is overstating its case. At the Feb. 11 background briefing in Baghdad, officials asserted, without providing direct evidence, that Iranian leaders at the highest levels had authorized smuggling those weapons into Iraq for use against the Americans. Within two days, Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had back away from that claim, saying that he did not believe the evidence does not translate that the Iranian government, per se, for sure, is directly involved in doing this. American intelligence officials say they believe it is highly unlikely that weapons transfers by Quds Force operatives to Shiite militias would occur without authorization from senior Iranian officials. But they describe this conclusion as an assessment, and acknowledge that it is primarily inferential.  5) Hasnt anyone learned from the fiasco involving prewar intelligence on Iraq?  This is exactly the question being posed by many people skeptical of the administrations claims. They say the fact that prewar conclusions about Iraqs weapons arsenal proved to have been so wrong should make American intelligence agencies cautious about reaching hard judgments based on limited facts. American military and intelligence officials say they have learned many lessons, and they say their assertions about Iran were subjected to intensive internal vetting. Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, has said the briefing in Baghdad was postponed at one point because of concern that a draft presentation would have overstated the American case. American intelligence officials say the conclusions have been embraced by representatives all 16 intelligence agencies, under the supervision of the director of national intelligence, a post created after the Iraq intelligence fiasco in part to help subject future judgments to more intense scrutiny. In conducting interviews, The New York Times has found a consensus of support for the American assertions, even among officials whose agencies had previously been skeptical that Iran was playing a significant role in arming Shiite militants. 6) Is the Bush administration preparing for war with Iran?  The United States has begun to respond, in the form of the raids in December and January that resulted in the detention of a number of Iranians in Iraq. Some of those detained are still in American custody, and Mr. Bush has vowed that the United States will take additional action against individuals or networks in Iraq involved in the weapons shipments. But there have also been repeated indications that American action is being tightly constrained. A top official of Irans Quds Force who was captured in a December raid was released by American forces after it was determined that he had diplomatic status. American officials have said any actions against Iranian targets will be confined to Iraqi territory and will not extend across the border into Iran. Both Robert M. Gates, the new defense secretary, and Mr. Bush have said repeatedly in recent weeks that they were not seeking to lay the groundwork for military action against Iran. Democrats and other critics of the administration have nevertheless expressed skepticism about those claims, with some saying they believe Mr. Bush is using the exercise as a provocation in order to seek a military confrontation with Iran. Irans nuclear program remains a major concern to the United States. The Bush administration has used diplomacy as its primary tool to try to persuade Iran to abandon its nuclear activities, but the administration has said it will not rule out the eventual use of military action.

title: Babel Still on Top at EW, but Not for Long
description: Much of the talk lately has been about the race between Little Miss and The Departed, but Entertainment Weeklys experts still have Babel on top. OscarWatch took a peek at the upcoming print issue, however, in which EWs Dave Karger breaks down the leader board thusly:

title: Was There a Question in There Somewhere?
description: Anne Thompson watched Charlie Rose interviewing Peter OToole and Forest Whitaker, in part, but not exclusively, so you dont have to. Turns out Peter is charming and Forest has got it going on when it come to technique and process.

title: A Vision in Leather
description: Eva Mendes, who appears in Ghost Rider, upstaged the star of the film, Nicolas Cage, at the New York premiere Thursday night in Times Square. The movie is based on the Marvel Comics character Johnny Blaze, a motorcyclist who has given up his soul to the devil (dont ask) and pursues demons who have been cast out of hell (dont ask).

title: America, Iran, and the Sound of Sabers Rattling
description: Robert Gates, the secretary of defense, insisted yesterday that the United States was not spoiling for a fight with Iran  despite swirling comments by senior administration officials in recent days that have accused Irans Revolutionary Guards and its Quds force of arming Iraqi insurgents with roadside-bomb technology.

title: Of Course They Want It
description: The Bagger is a bit of a fanboy when it comes to Billy Ray and is fired up to see Breach, his take on FBI agents Robert Hanssens freaky trip to the other side of the fence. Mr. Ray showed directness and muscle in Shattered Glass, one of the few movies about journalism that is actually interesting to watch. The Bagger interviewed him a while back, but he didnt get him talking about his Oscar lust, something Chris Hewitt at the Pioneer Press managed to do.

title: Odds Are
description: The Bagger was using a paint scraper to clean up the old asbestos tux because he will be heading out to The Show next Wednesday. As he was working, he started to wonder: What will be the big surprise this year?

title: In the Shade: Questions of Justice
description: Justice Department appointees serve at the pleasure of the president. And some Senate Democrats are concerned that it was the White Houses pleasure  specifically that of Harriet Miers, who just resigned as White House counsel  to replace one United States attorney in Arkansas with a former Republican Party official and Karl Rove deputy.

title: Mayor: Quit Griping
description: As the blog comments here attest, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg finds himself under fire after the city failed to suspend alternate side of the street parking rules yesterday in the wake of the snow and ice storm.The mayor was at times curt, testy and defensive as he answered questions from reporters at a Sanitation Department garage in Woodside, Queens, even suggesting that New Yorkers stop griping about the situation. But asking New Yorkers not to gripe is like asking for mayonnaise on a pastrami sandwich  highly unlikely. This was the first time many could recall the citiy enforcing the regulations so soon after a storm and complained that they would have nowhere to put their cars once they shoveled them out. (This morning, The Daily News declared the mayor supremely out of touch.)

title: Wasted
Oscar Sell-Out
description: The mystery that is hanging over this years Oscars has apparently been good for business. Stuart Elliot writes in todays New York Times that this years Academy Awards show is sold to the rafters:

title: Simon Wins Mall Developer After Raising Bid
description: It may be having financial troubles, but Mills Corporation apparently still knows how to play bidders against each other. The mall developer has ended its merger agreement with a Canadian firm and agreed instead to be acquired for significantly more by Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management, Simon said Friday in a press release. Simon, the largest mall developer in the United States, and Farallon, a hedge fund, will pay $25.25 per share in cash for Mills, or about $1.64 billion.

title: 2008: Stuck in the Senate
description: Its difficult to tell whether its harder to successfully run for president as a senator or a mayor. In Rudolph W. Giulianis case, it could be his activities as a former mayor, and his private sector business clients, that prove his greatest liabilities. Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons actions, meanwhile, could cause Mr. Giuliani problems. Thursday, she reintroduced a bill that would heighten oversight of Entergys Indian Point nuclear power plant. Entergy is a major client of Giuliani Partners, The Daily News of New York reports.

title: Youth on Display
description: Lost in the craziness of Yankees camp yesterday  a DUI arrest for general partner Steve Swindal; Joe Torres invitation to Bernie Williams; Mike Mussinas criticism of Carl Pavano  was a neat sight on the bullpen mounds.

title: American Airlines Said to Draw Buyout Interest
description: A group including Goldman Sachs and British Airways is considering a bid for American Airlines that could be as high as $11 billion, BusinessWeek reported in its Feb. 26 issue, citing people familiar with the matter. A spokesman for American told the magazine that we talk to lots of people, but until discussions result in anything of substance, we simply do not comment. Reuters, also citing undisclosed sources, reported Friday morning that Goldman and British Airways have no current plans to bid for American.

title: Private Capital Management Shrinks Newspaper Stakes
description: Private Capital Management, which pressured the Knight Ridder newspaper publisher into selling itself last year, has reduced its holdings in several newspaper chains, the Associated Press reports.

title: The House Debate: A Sampling
description: Since Tuesday, the House has been debating a nonbinding resolution that would express disapproval of President Bushs plan to send an additional 21,500 troops to Iraq.

title: War at Home: Q&A With Pelosi
description: The House is poised today to pass a symbolic resolution opposing President Bushs plan to send more troops to Iraq. The debate on the nonbinding resolution is scheduled to continue throughout much of the afternoon, with every Democrat and Republican in the 435-member House afforded an opportunity to speak.

title: Mayor Caves on Snow
description: Mayor Bloomberg says the city has suspended alternate side parking and will cancel parking tickets given out in the wake of this weeks storm.

title: This Land Is Our Land
description: Compared with all the time we spent searching for a place to build our dream home, getting the financing to buy the land was simple.

title: Bloombergs Parking Ticket Amnesty
description: A day after telling New Yorkers to stop griping about parking tickets issued to snowbound cars, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg apologized and promised to waive all tickets issued for alternate-side parking violations yesterday and today.

title: Held Hostage on the Tarmac: Time for A Passenger Bill of Rights?
description: More than 1,000 passengers on nine different JetBlue flights were stranded on the tarmac for what must have seemed an eternity at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York during Wednesdays snow storm. One flight, bound for Aruba, sat for nearly 11 hours, according to some reports.

title: In Pursuit of Perfection, Howell Finds Less Is More
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 16  In the two decades that Charles Howell III has taken golf lessons, he can never remember a time when a teacher did not videotape his swing.

title: For Williams, a Pain in the Neck
description: While the rest of his teammates were buzzing around the clubhouse taking physical exams, Dave Williams sat on a stool in front of his locker. He was wearing jeans and a fleece, and a cumbersome neck brace. Williams underwent surgery in January to repair a herniated disk in his neck, and he cannot do much until the brace comes off in the next two to four weeks, he said. He doesnt expect to resume throwing until May.

title: A Downside of Being a Tech Writer
description: Joel Johnson, a former writer for the gadget blog Gizmodo, has returned to write a weekly column. His first one is a foul-mouthed, offensive diatribe against the stupidity of Gizmodo and technology fans.

title: Housing Slide Continues
description: Big changes in winter housing starts are inherently suspect, since weather can have a huge impact, and for that reason the decline in January housing starts needs to be greeted warily  as did the surprisingly strong report for December.

title: At a Billionaires Bash, Some Jokes Fell Short
description: Friday brought yet more canape-by-canape accounts of the 60th birthday celebration for Blackstone Group chairman Stephen Schwarzman, plus all kinds of analysis about where the bash sits in the pantheon of hot New York parties. David Patrick Columbias New York Social Diary has an especially detailed rundown of the event, reporting that there were some uncomfortably raunchy jokes from comedian Martin Short as well as some unfortunate seating decisions.

title: Google Said to Buy Videogame Advertising Startup
description: The Red Herring is reporting that Google has made another acquisition, this time agreeing to buy Adscape Media, which provides advertising within video games, for $23 million. The article seemed to question the move, however, suggesting that the purchase gives Google little beyond a few potentially interesting patents, and adding, dont expect the Internet giant to announce big in-game ad deals with publishers like Electronic Arts anytime soon.

title: Myers Glove Story
description: There may be no Yankee who better appreciates baseball history and his place in it than lefty reliever Mike Myers. It was no surprise that last fall, Myers was eager to join the team of major leaguers that traveled to Japan for an exhibition series.

title: Mike Mussina, Fashion Critic
description: Carl Pavano wasnt the only target of Mike Mussinas criticism yesterday. Hes not too wild about those new warm-up caps and batting practice jerseys, either.

title: Birds of a Feather: London Fashion
description: Sarah Vine, writing in The Times this morning about fashion at the British music awards, laments the decline of the rock slut: Have you ever seen such a line-up of buffed, coiffed and befrocked style princesses? Where are the laddered tights? Wheres the smudged eyeliner? Next, I suppose, shell be complaining that you cant get a decent mushy vegetable in England anymore. Vine is simply witnessing the last murmurs of another British institution: the fashion rebel. What aspect of Englands culture of oblivion would prevent a rock chick from diving into a bowl of Este Lauder lip gloss in the V.I.P. room?

title: Ending a Tradition That Some Find Racist, Others Noble
description: In a press release posted to the University of Illinois Web site today, the school effectively terminated what critics have called the schools racist athletic mascot, and what fans have said was a decades-old tradition that honored an ethnic minority:

title: Glavines Chase for 300
description: There is the Roger Clemens way to pitch, and then there is the Greg Maddux way. Both approaches have proven more than successful. But in his pursuit of 300 victories, Tom Glavine said he would much prefer to emulate his old teammate Maddux.

title: Out of the Park
description: In 1994, Chan Ho Parks rookie season, Chan Ho-mania (or something like it) was sweeping across the Dodgers compound in nearby Vero Beach. However, Park made his professional debut here, in Port St. Lucie, when he faced 10 batters  all hit ground balls  in three shutout innings.

title: Of Bankers, Models and Bottles
description: In New Yorks West 27th Street club scene, theyre called bottles. In New York magazines recent profile of Club Rows rise and fall, theyre referred to as businessmen. But the anonymous writer of the Bankers Ball blog says he or she knows what they really are: investment bankers. And the blog suggests that Wall Street bankers, many of whom consider nights among models ordering overpriced bottles of premium alcohol to be part of the job description, did their part to build the neighborhood up and then ruin the vibe.

title: The Movies People Are Talking About
description: Last year, apart from having a surprise Crash ending, the race for best picture revolved around topical movies. Race, homophobia, journalistic ethics and governments control of information were weaved in meaningful ways into the films that were in the final hunt. This year, give or take a Babel, not so much.

title: Daimler Shares Rise on Reports G.M. May Buy Chrysler
description: Days after Chryslers parent company said it would not rule out a sale of the struggling unit, there were reports Friday that General Motors was negotiating to buy it. Shares of DaimlerChrysler, which owns Chrysler, rose 3.6 percent. Citing unnamed sources, The Automotive News said that G.M. and DaimlerChrysler executives have held high-level discussions on a deal. But Micheline Maynard  of The New York Times reported on Friday that while investors were cheered by DaimlerChryslers willingness to let go of Chrysler, Wall Street analysts were skeptical that it would be bought outright by G.M.

title: House Resolution on Iraq Passes
