description: As expected, the House of Representatives passed, 246-182, a resolution opposing President Bushs buildup of 21,500 additional troops in Iraq, some of whom are already on their way.

title: Cuomo Raises Starrett Issue
description: Has the New York attorney general found a reason to block the Starrett City sale?

title: Housing and Recessions
description: Heres another way to look at the housing start numbers: Take a three-month moving average of single-family starts, at a seasonally adjusted rate. That smoothes out some of the weather-induced volatility.By that measure, starts have now fallen for 11 consecutive months, and are off more than 30 percent over that period.

title: Girls and High School Wrestling
description: High school girls who want to wrestle often have to practice with, and compete against, boys.

title: Mussina-Pavano Truce
description: Carl Pavano and Mike Mussina emerged from the clubhouse managers office today, with no visible cuts or bruises. In fact, they were smiling.

title: VOWS:  Alex & Matt
description: The marriage of Alexandra Exley and Matthew Seidel began a long time ago.

title: Comptroller Grannis?
description: In The Village Voice, Wayne Barrett quotes a member of the panel of former comptrollers who screened the potential candidates for the post as saying that Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, known as Pete, would have made the list of qualified candidates if Governor Spitzer had not unexpectedly tapped him to be his environmental commisioner.

title: Campaign Webs of Intrigue
description: Campaign 2008 is already immersed in Web 2.0., and were already feeling a little agoraphobic with all the opportunities for interaction.

title: Blogtalk: Holiday Weekend
description: Theres no such thing as Presidents Day. Its Washingtons Birthday (sort of). And for those of you with cars  you dont have to move them until Tuesday. The mayors office has extended the suspension of alternate-side parking rules through the holiday weekend.

title: A Kiss Is Still a Kiss
description: Hoaxes, heartbreaks and misperceptions pile up in Screensland, where unsourced videos descend on us like shooting stars, and we live on gullibility and partial knowledge.

title: Excerpt: The Johnny Carson Show
description: Mr. Carson performs a skit as "Dillinger, the Mental Wizard," a parody of Joseph Dunniger, the mind reader.

title: The Crime Mystery
description: Will crime make a comeback? Last year the rates of homicide and robbery rose a little in America, prompting fears that the steep decline in crime since 1990 was about to reverse. But after putting that question to a panel of experts assembed at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, I have good news  sort of.

title: Jazz and Art
description: Saxophonist Ted Nash explains how he transformed famous works of art into a jazz composition for the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.

title: Simon Property Appears to Have Won Battle for Mall Owner
description: After negotiations that lasted through Thursday night, the takeover battle for the troubled Mills Corporation appeared to have ended yesterday, with the mall operator Simon Property Group emerging as the victor.

title: Familiar Problem Stalls Minimum Wage Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  When Democrats campaigned last fall to recapture control of Congress, few domestic issues seemed to have as much winning potential as raising the minimum wage.

title: You Won? Too Late! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralph Penza, Broadcaster Known for Aggressive Reports, Dies at 74
description: Ralph Penza, an award-winning television news reporter and backup anchor for WNBC-TV in New York City, died early yesterday morning after a long illness, a spokeswoman for NBC said. Mr. Penza was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The American Songbook as the Family Business
description: To observe the musical rapport between the singer Sandy Stewart and her son, the pianist Bill Charlap, is to sense a depth of artistic communication between two musicians that is rare in any area of music. Ms. Stewart and Mr. Charlap, whose new show, Hello, Young Lovers, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, was timed to coincide with Valentines Day, have the timing of ballroom dancing partners executing complicated maneuvers with a finesse that makes it look ridiculously easy.

title: Indonesia Offering Samples of Bird Flu for Vaccines
description: Indonesia will resume sending avian flu virus samples to the World Health Organization as soon as it is guaranteed access to affordable vaccines against the disease, the country and the health agency announced yesterday.

title: Humpty-Dumpty Housing
description: There is no sugarcoating the latest news on the United States housing market. The slump in home prices from the end of 2005 to the end of 2006 was the biggest year-over-year drop since the National Association of Realtors started keeping track in 1982. There are no reasons to believe thats the worst of it.

title: California: Warrant Issued in Attack on Elie Wiesel
description: The San Francisco Police Department issued an arrest warrant for a man suspected of attacking Elie Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor, author and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. The man, Eric Hunt, 22, of Sussex County, N.J., is accused of assaulting Mr. Wiesel, 78, on Feb. 1, as he was attending an interfaith conference. Mr. Hunt, who is not yet in custody but has been located, will be charged with a hate crime, the police said in a statement. He was identified as a suspect, the police said, after claiming to be the attacker in an Internet posting.

title: Is America Just Too Big for Its Own Good? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: After Its Founders Return, Many Are Leaving at Dell
description: Two weeks after he returned to run the computer company that bears his name, Michael S. Dell is making sweeping senior management changes.

title: Port Authority Now Accepts Dubai Deal, Easing Debate
description: A day after two United States senators called the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey greedy and obstructionist, the agency signed off on a deal that would let DP World, a Dubai-based port operator, sell its leases to A.I.G. Global Investment Group.

title: Gordon Wright, Founder of Arctic Chamber Orchestra, Dies at 72
description: Gordon Wright, a conductor who championed obscure composers and made music across the chilly climes of Alaska as founder of the Arctic Chamber Orchestra, was found dead on Wednesday on the porch of his cabin in Indian, Alaska. He was 72.

title: The Jingoism 500
description: San Francisco

title: Analysts Are Skeptical of G.M.-Chrysler Merger
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 The willingness by DaimlerChrysler to cut loose its Chrysler Group, ending its nine-year trans-Atlantic partnership, is drawing cheers from investors.

title: A Loyalty That Extended to the Uniform, and Beyond
description: Manhasset, N.Y.

title: An Instant Link From Head and Heart to Fingertips
description: What draws the listener to Angela Hewitt, who played Rameau, Beethoven and Schumann at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday evening, has to do with contact. Most piano performances arrive in translation: the inner musician making a decision, then issuing a command that makes its way through the body onto the keyboard and into the ear. The process alters the results.

title: Mans Best Friend Only Scratches the Surface
description: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif.  I was buried alive. A pale blue light filtered through two feet of snow over my head. I could hear muffled voices, but I stayed quiet and tried to imagine what it would be like to be buried in a real avalanche.

title: Florida: Padilla Lawyers Can Question Officials
description: Lawyers for Jose Padilla, seeking to prove he is unfit to stand trial, won the right to question government personnel who observed him at a Navy brig and a federal detention center. Judge Marcia Cooke of Federal District Court in Miami ordered eight Defense Department and Justice Department officials to appear for questioning at Mr. Padillas competency hearing next Thursday. The eight were previously interviewed for a United States Bureau of Prisons report that prosecutors cite as evidence that Mr. Padilla is mentally competent. Mr. Padilla, a 36-year-old American citizen accused of being an operative for Al Qaeda, is scheduled to go on trial April 16.

title: Things to Think About Before the Breakup
description: People contemplating divorce are advised to safeguard their money even before they start haggling over alimony. Divorce mediators, financial planners and other specialists say they may want to consider doing the following:

title: Penguins Keep Pressure on the Devils
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 16  John Madden, the Devils defensive ace, took the ice Friday night with a full face mask on his black helmet. Pittsburghs Sidney Crosby was already at the other end of the ice, skating in lazy circles.

title: A Giant Doom Magnet
description: So I was sitting around watching Oprah yesterday afternoon when I realized how I could stop W. and Crazy Dick from blowing up any more stuff.

title: A Forgetful Bidding Moment, but Lady Luck Comes Calling
description: How often does a pair score 77.44 percent or better in a club duplicate?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday, about the Collegiate Chorales concert version of the opera The Maid of Orleans at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, carried outdated information about the cast. After the section went to press, the chorale announced that the role of Agnes would be performed by Karen Slack  not by Carol Vaness, who is ill. (Go to Article)

title: V.C.U. and New Coach Get Their Turn in Spotlight
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 12  Virginia Commonwealth Coach Anthony Grant stands with his arms folded and quietly watches his players stretch after practice. He wears his wedding ring, but not the national championship ring he earned last season at Florida, where he was an assistant for 10 seasons. He does not want his past to be a distraction.

title: History Offers Hope and Fear for Kodak
description: EASTMAN KODAK is an industrial giant of the 20th century that has been cut down to size in the 21st by its failure to keep up with developments in technology and the demands of the marketplace.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 31 about the federal death sentence for Ronell Wilson in the killing of two undercover police officers on Staten Island in 2003 was unclear about the sequence of events in the Brooklyn courtroom. While the jury foreman was reading from the 29-page verdict form, relatives of the victims applauded and voiced their approval, and there were outbursts from Mr. Wilsons family. After the foreman finished, Mr. Wilson stuck out his tongue. The gesture came after the other reactions, not before.

title: Come and Meet Those Stamping Feet, Showing the U.S. What They Can Do
description: When the curtain finally lifted at the Gala de la Bienal de Sevilla at City Center, after some superfluous welcoming speeches contrasting the frigid weather outside with the heat that was about to be generated inside, the sights and sounds on the stage werent, well, especially sizzling. The hollow, amplified echo of miked feet was an instant reminder of why flamenco in large theaters is often a letdown. Nor was the choreography immediately reassuring: in the shows lukewarm opening number, On (En Clave), dancers performed flamenco in prudent unison: imagine a turn, a shoulder roll and two claps.

title: Taking the Debate About God Online, and Battling It Out With Videos
description: A religious battle is taking place on the Internet, with two very different groups arguing over the existence of God.

title: Mexico: U.S. Security Chief in First Visit
description: On his first official visit to Mexico, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said he considered an expanded guest-worker program for Mexican migrants as key to stopping terrorists and criminals from slipping into the United States. Every time a Border Patrol officer is transporting a load of future housekeepers and landscapers to some place to be returned, hes not looking for drug dealers or drug loads, Mr. Chertoff said after two days of meetings with Mexicos top security officials.

title: Furor on Rush to Require Cervical Cancer Vaccine
description: Racing to embrace a new vaccine, at least 20 states are considering mandatory inoculation of young girls against the sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.

title: On to the Hard Part on Iraq
description: President Bush lost touch long ago with Iraqs political reality  not to mention Americans anguish and disbelief at his mismanagement of the war. So we welcome the House of Representatives long-overdue attempt to shake some sense into Mr. Bush with a resolution opposing his decision to send another 20,000 combat troops to fight this disastrous war without any plan to end it.

title: Calm Prevails at Holy Site in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16  Despite calls by Muslim religious figures for mass protests over Israels excavations near a site holy to Islam and Judaism, Jerusalems Old City was largely calm on Friday during and after noon prayers at Al Aksa Mosque.

title: Legal Sideshow, Not Home Run Hoopla, Follows Bonds
description: When Babe Ruth broke Roger Connors career home run record, no one paid much attention. Connor had hit 138 home runs in the 1880s and 1890s, and Ruth passed him in 1921 with little or no fanfare. Much was made of Henry Aaron eclipsing Ruths record in 1974, but even then probably the most notable thing that happened was that Aaron shoved a box of strawberries in a reporters face.

title: Bomb Kills Doctor in Pakistani Border Area
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Feb. 16  A doctor in charge of the polio immunization campaign in a tribal area was killed in a roadside bombing on Friday, apparently the victim of a creeping militancy in Pakistans border regions.

title: Brush Strokes of Sound: Art That Keeps Changing
description: One morning last July, the saxophonist Ted Nash took a spin through the fourth- and fifth-floor galleries at the Museum of Modern Art. It was a visit studded with small realizations, in the placid hour before crowds arrive. Ann Temkin, MoMAs curator of painting and sculpture, was there to answer questions, of which Mr. Nash had a few.

title: Man Is Indicted in Officers Shooting
description: Jose Rivera, who is accused of shooting a police officer in Brooklyn last Saturday, was indicted yesterday on charges of attempted murder and assault, according to the Brooklyn district attorneys office.

title: Monkey Business at a Strict Summer Camp
description: Camp Lazlo is a show on Cartoon Network about a smart monkey who goes to a very oppressive summer camp and generally upsets the rigid order of things. He makes friends. He is not a solitary monkey alone in his cabin reading Niall Ferguson; he has his bunkmates: Raj, an Indian elephant with a vague hint of obsessive-compulsive disorder about him, and Clam, an albino pygmy rhino whose dumb demeanor belies a true intelligence. (He could read Mr. Ferguson and understand him.)

title: A Divided House Denounces Plan for More Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  A sharply divided House of Representatives passed a resolution on Friday formally repudiating President Bushs decision to send more than 20,000 new combat troops to Iraq.

title: Lawmaker Apologizes for Memo Linking Evolution and Jewish Texts
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16  A leader of the Texas House of Representatives apologized Friday for circulating an appeal to ban the teaching of evolution as derived from Rabbinic writings and other Jewish texts.

title: Lawmakers in Trenton Are Drawn Into Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16  The leaders of the New Jersey Legislature said they were served with subpoenas Friday afternoon by federal prosecutors as part of an expanding investigation into corruption.

title: Cycling Race Says It Failed to Test for EPO
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16  In only its second year, the Tour of California, which begins Sunday in San Francisco, has become the countrys most important professional cycling event, attracting more than 1 million spectators last year and a field of riders this year that ranks as the strongest ever assembled for a race in the United States.

title: Agassi Makes His Point Off the Court
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 16  Andre Agassi walked from room to room in the same purposeful manner he used to stride from side to side on the baseline.

title: Wireless Codependency
description: Constantly talking on your cellphone is doing more than annoying the people around you. Calling someone whenever you are in a bad mood, or have a question, may be making you less independent and less able to experience your life as fully as you should.

title: An Awkward Plea
description: Its hard to ask for a raise, especially when youre a judge. Look at poor Justice Anthony Kennedy supplicating before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Valentines Day. With stilted locutions  its frankly most awkward for me  he staked out pedantic points about the constitutional scheme of separation of powers and lumbered toward a conclusion that federal judges need to make more money.

title: As Connecticut Senator Runs for President, He Hopes to Be Heard
description: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 16  On his way from a breakfast with nearly 200 business leaders on Friday morning to an interview on national television, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut spotted a woman grabbing one of the blue and white circular stickers bearing his name off a table.

title: Drivers License Emerges as Crime-Fighting Tool, but Privacy Advocates Worry
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12  On the second floor of a state office building here, upstairs from a food court, three facial-recognition specialists are revolutionizing American law enforcement. They work for the Massachusetts motor vehicles department.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Golfo de Santa Clara Journal article on Tuesday, about the possibility that commercial fishing may be endangering the vaquita porpoise, which lives in the Gulf of California near the mouth of the Colorado River, rendered incorrectly part of a quotation from Karl W. Flessa, a geologist at the University of Arizona, who said the damming and diversion of the river may also be responsible for the porpoises decline. He said the reduction in the river flow was 15 million acre-feet of water a year  not a day.

title: Who Is Army Material? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Delays Hurt Image of JetBlue
description: Can one very bad week for JetBlue Airways wipe out years of industry-leading customer satisfaction ratings?

title: Trade Deficit Peaks and Declines, but It Remains Huge
description: AFTER years of deterioration, the United States trade deficit appears to have finally peaked and started to decline.

title: Dont Buy My Book, Just Read It
description: FOR a time, Seth Godin did not want anyone to buy his book, Everyones an Expert (About Something), on Amazon.com.

title: Suffolk County to Keep Sex Offenders on the Move
description: Suffolk County officials have long searched for ways to provide temporary housing for homeless sex offenders, from the controversial practice of placing them in local motels to the unusual proposal of loading them on a houseboat docked in a marina.

title: Perseus to Take Over Publishers Contracts
description: A bankruptcy court in Delaware ruled yesterday that the Perseus Books Group could take over distribution contracts for more than 100 book publishers left affected by the bankruptcy filing of a major wholesaler.

title: Mostly Good Reports on the Economy, but See Footnotes
description: GOOD luck in trying to persuade many people in Detroit, but times are pretty good. Welcome news about the economy and interest rates touched off a stock market rally that lifted the Dow Jones industrial average to a record.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A credit line with an article on Thursday about plans for community meetings in the aftermath of a deadly shooting rampage at a mall in Salt Lake City misspelled the surname of a contributing reporter. He is Dan Frosch, not Frosh.

title: For Some Unmellowed Metalheads, Middle Age Is Nothing to Fear
description: Who would have thought, back in the 80s, that the clatter of Slayers rhythm section would someday become one of those archaic folk forms worth preserving just as an example of human mastery, like Kansas City swing or flamenco singing?

title: Kidd and Garnett in No Hurry to Move On
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 16  Jason Kidd has heard the trade rumors about himself recently. Kevin Garnett has heard them for a couple of seasons.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Pianists Recordings Draw Praise, but Were They All Hers?
description: PARIS, Feb. 16  In the autumn of her life, decades after she had last performed in public, the British pianist Joyce Hatto was rediscovered by a small group of musicians and critics who contended that her recordings of Chopin, Rachmaninoff, Liszt and others ranked alongside those of the 20th centurys most exceptional virtuosos.

title: Baghdad Plan Is a Success, Iraq Prime Minister Tells Bush
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 16  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki told President Bush on Friday that the increased effort to provide security in Baghdad had gone exceedingly well so far, Mr. Malikis office said in a statement.

title: Deal Ends Case Against Yoko Onos Chauffeur
description: Nearly two months after Yoko Onos chauffeur accused her of destroying his marriage and his self-esteem, and demanded $2 million in compensation, prosecutors yesterday dropped extortion charges against him and allowed him to plead guilty to a lesser charge.

title: A Wide World of Sound With an Argentine Beat
description: Over the last 15 years or so, the pianist and composer Guillermo Klein has made a study of the tensile and elastic properties of rhythm. Along the way, he has built some fascinating bridges between jazz, pop, classical music and the chacareras and tangos of his native Argentina. His best music also carries smart harmonic ideas and surprising bolts of lyricism, but virtually all of it deals purposefully with the subject of groove.

title: Proof Sought on Reliability of Vote Units
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16  A Superior Court judge on Friday gave New Jersey elections officials three months to prove that they had adequately tested the reliability of electronic voting machines or to remove them from service.

title: A Plea to Open the Holocaust Files (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Anglican Prelates Snub Head of U.S. Church Over Gay Issues
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 16  Seven archbishops who say they represent more than 30 million Anglicans worldwide refused to take Communion here on Friday with the new head of the American Episcopal Church, to protest her support of gay clergy members and blessings for same-sex unions.

title: From the Frozen Midwest, Warm Beethoven and Sibelius
description: The Minnesota Orchestra brought its Arctic weather along for concerts at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. It also came trailing rave notices for its work under the Finnish maestro Osmo Vanska, who took over as music director in 2003, and its performances largely bore them out.

title: Opera Orchestra of New York Says It May Reduce Concerts Next Season
description: Opera Orchestra of New York, an institution beloved by the aria-addled for its big voices and little-known works, is facing financial problems that could force it to curtail next seasons performances, said Eve Queler, who founded the company nearly 40 years ago and remains its music director.

title: The Pain of Paying (a Lot) for House Plans You Dont Use
description: A few years ago, when the charm of sharing a room with his brother had worn off for our older son, we decided to look into remodeling.

title: Latest Death of Teenager in South London Unsettles Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 16  With an outpouring of soul-searching and public sorrow, British leaders expressed dismay on Friday at a recent spate of gun crime in south London that has claimed five lives, and particularly at the young men in their mid-teens who were shot to death in their homes.

title: Lawyer Accused of Destroying Evidence in Connecticut Pornography Case
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 16  A well-known lawyer was indicted on Friday on charges that he obstructed justice and destroyed evidence in the investigation of a former church choir director whose laptop computer contained images of naked boys.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) LONGFORD (2006). She was considered the worst serial killer in Britain since Jack the Ripper. He was a respected politician from the upper echelons of society. So why was a nice man like him defending a woman like her? This movie explores the controversial friendship in the 1960s between Myra Hindley, the notorious child murderer, and Lord Longford, who risked his career and reputation when he, believing her to be reformed, campaigned for her release from prison. The film was written and executive produced by Peter Morgan, who wrote the screenplays for The Queen, starring Helen Mirren, and The Last King of Scotland, with Forest Whitaker as Idi Amin. Tom Hooper, whose credits include Elizabeth I and Prime Suspect 6, both with Ms. Mirren, directed. Jim Broadbent and Samantha Morton star as the bizarre couple. Lindsay Duncan plays Longfords loving wife, Elizabeth, with whom he had eight children.

title: In New Orleans, Fighting to Stay (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday, about the Collegiate Chorales concert version of the opera The Maid of Orleans at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, carried outdated information about the cast. After the section went to press, the chorale announced that the role of Agnes would be performed by Karen Slack  not by Carol Vaness, who is ill.

title: After Criticism of Dismissal, Justice Dept. Shifts Course
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The prosecutor whose appointment as an interim United States attorney in Arkansas has ignited a furor in Congress will not be nominated for the job permanently, the Justice Department said on Friday.

title: Home Construction Dropped in January
description: Home builders, grappling with a slump in demand, slowed construction on new homes in January to the lowest level in almost a decade.

title: Banco Bilbao to Expand U.S. Presence by Buying Compass Bancshares
description: LONDON, Feb. 16  Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spains second-largest bank, after Santander, agreed to buy Compass Bancshares of the United States for $9.6 billion, making its biggest acquisition abroad in a market where it seeks to strengthen its foothold.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Ink feature on Tuesday, about a 1929 time capsule from Doctors Hospital in Manhattan that contained, among other items, a vial of diphtheria medicine, misidentified the affiliation of Chris Warren, an academic historian who said that in 1929, diphtheria antitoxin was the closest we had to the magic bullet. He is at the New York Academy of Medicine, not the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Patient Safety Through Technology
description: At least 1.5 million preventable drug-related injuries occurred in 2006 in American hospitals, long-term care institutions and outpatient clinics, according to the Institute of Medicine. And, the institute said, 98,000 deaths occurred both because of mistakes in administering drugs and because of infections contracted in hospitals.

title: Mickelson Finds His Timing and Swing Are Just Right
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 16  The golfer who commits to playing in the Nissan Open at Riviera Country Club is inviting tight fairways, tricky greens and some of the worst traffic on the planet.

title: A Search for Shangri-La Deep in the Subways
description: Given the recent fiasco in Boston in which promotional gadgets for an animated television show were mistaken for terrorist bombs, this may not be the best time to be bragging that your new movie was shot illegally in the subways, sewers and streets of New York City.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about a Congressional resolution on the Iraq war misidentified the military unit for the American soldiers shown searching a business. They are from the Third Stryker Brigade Combat Team, part of the Second Infantry Division. They are not soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division.

title: For Tigers Pitchers, Fielding Comes First
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 16  Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland wanted a timeout. He noticed that some of his infamous fielding pitchers lowered their gloves while running from the mound to cover first base. So Leyland lifted his hands, stopped the workout and started instructing.

title: Against Difficult Odds, Nevadas Coach Plans for Success
description: RENO, Nev., Feb. 15  The neon sign hanging over downtown proudly declares, The Biggest Little City in the World.

description: A day after telling New Yorkers to stop griping over parking tickets issued to snowbound cars, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg apologized yesterday and promised to waive all such tickets issued in the two days after the storm.

title: Smile, Youre on N.Y.P.D. Camera
description: The New York Police Department has generally had the public on its side when it comes to securing the city since the Sept. 11 attacks. For their part, New Yorkers seem perfectly willing to put up with inconveniences, including traffic stops and bag searches. But the police have more and more overstepped by routinely and indiscriminately videotaping demonstrations of every kind, even peaceful ones. A federal judge was right this week to order the police to curb this conduct.

title: Ray Evans, Lyricist of Hit Songs From Movies, Dies at 92
description: Ray Evans, a pop lyricist who teamed up with the composer and lyricist Jay Livingston to write three Academy Award-winning songs and one of Nat King Coles best-known classics, as well as the Christmas standard Silver Bells, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 92.

title: Of Taxes, Newspapers and Family
description: A little more than a year ago, representatives of the Chandler family approached the management of the Tribune Company, hoping to solve a little tax problem. Years before, when the family still owned Times-Mirror, it had set up two partnerships with the company that allowed the family to diversify its holdings without having to actually sell any Times-Mirror stock  thus avoiding a big tax bill. When the family sold Times-Mirror to Tribune in 2000, for $8 billion, a price that now seems be rich beyond belief, the Tribune Company inherited the partnerships.

title: Review Set in Pennsylvania After 50-Mile Traffic Tie-Up
description: HAMBURG, Pa., Feb. 16  Gov. Edward G. Rendell on Friday ordered a review of the states unacceptable response to an ice and snow storm that left thousands of people stranded, some for more than a day, on long sections of three major Interstate highways in eastern Pennsylvania.

title: Detained AIDS Doctor Allowed to Visit U.S. Later, China Says
description: BEIJING, Saturday, Feb. 17  China gave in to international pressure on Friday and agreed to release a prominent AIDS doctor from house arrest so she can attend an awards ceremony in Washington next month.

title: NATO Calls Antimissile Worries Unfounded
description: Gen. John Craddock of the United States Army, who recently took over as the NATO supreme allied commander in Europe, said Russia had nothing to fear from a planned antimissile system that the United States wants to install in Poland and the Czech Republic. Its been clearly stated what the U.S. intention is, he said, and that is to provide defense against missiles from a rogue nation. Although he did not name any country, the antimissile site would be designed to stop attacks by Iran against the United States and its European allies. Last weekend, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reacted angrily to the plan to install a missile defense system in former Soviet Bloc countries, saying it would set off a new arms race. On Thursday, Gen. Yuri N. Baluyevsky, the chief of the Russian militarys general staff, said that if the United States went through with the system, Russia might drop out of the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty of 1987, in which the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to eliminate land-based ballistic and cruise nuclear missiles with a range of 310 to 3,410 miles.

title: As Usual, Its Controversy Sprinkled With Baseball
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 16  So the general partner was arrested, two starting pitchers were bickering and the wayward franchise icon might be on his way back. Just a typical start to spring training at sleepy Legends Field.

title: Brassy City Makes Room for Brahms
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16  Orchestras tend to take on the character of their hometowns and their music directors, at least when the chemistry between the players, the place and the conductor is right. This has certainly been true of the Los Angeles Philharmonic during the dynamic tenure of Esa-Pekka Salonen. A brilliant conductor with an adventurous streak as well as an active composer of bracingly contemporary works, Mr. Salonen has built the Philharmonic into an orchestra that excels in Stravinsky, Messiaen and Ligeti and has made it a home away from home for composers like John Adams, Thomas Ads and Kaija Saariaho.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Like so much else about the Iranian state, the Quds Force, which conducts overseas operations for Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, remains remarkably mysterious even to those who closely study the country.

title: The Devil Made Me Do It
description: Is the world ready for a flaming Nicolas Cage? After a long string of financial flops, this idiosyncratic actor is placing his faith in a comic-book character with a combustible body and an addiction to jelly beans. In Ghost Rider Mr. Cage is Johnny Blaze, a daredevil biker who once made a deal with Mephistopheles (an orange-eyed Peter Fonda) and is now required to hunt down wayward demons while shooting flames from every pore. No wonder he listens to the Carpenters.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about bloggers who are covering the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. included erroneous information from Robert A. Cox, president of the Media Bloggers Association, about the coverage of federal trials by independent bloggers. Gene Borio, an antitobacco activist, received a credential to cover the trial of the federal governments lawsuit against the tobacco industry in 2004 and did so; the Libby trial is not the first time independent bloggers have covered a federal trial. (Sheldon L. Snook, the court official who issued the credentials for both trials, said he was unaware that Mr. Borio was a blogger until after the credential was issued.)

title: How Long Till Next Train? The Answer Is Up in Lights
description: Subways future and subways past seemed to collide on a recent morning at the Jefferson Street station on the L line in Bushwick, Brooklyn. New electronic signs on the platforms showed how many minutes a person would have to wait until the next train: at this moment it was eight minutes for a Canarsie-bound train and four minutes for a Manhattan-bound train.

description: The predicted bottoming-out of the housing market appears, for now, to still be just a prediction.

title: Italy Indicts C.I.A. Operatives in 03 Abduction
description: ROME, Feb. 16 An Italian judge indicted 26 Americans on Friday, most of them C.I.A. officers, in what will become the first trial of the American program of secretly whisking away terror suspects. Italys former top spy was also indicted.

title: Randolph Is Ringing in New Season for the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 16  Willie Randolph usually wears one of his six World Series rings on special occasions: black-tie events, formal dinners, that sort of thing. But the first full day of spring training qualifies, too. He chose to put on his diamond-embossed 1977 model Friday because, he said, 30 years after winning his first World Series, he has positive vibes again.

title: Corrections: For the Record

The village is estimated to be 7,700 to 9,000 years old, not roughly 10,000; the artifact was clay pottery, not bronze.

The big commodity farmers, and the interest groups that represent them, were hoping that Congress would simply extend the 2002 Farm Bill, a regressive grab bag for big agriculture. These hopes have now been disappointed. Mike Johanns, the secretary of agriculture, has unveiled his proposals for a new farm bill, which on the whole seems remarkably promising.

Last night, in the yellow ballroom at Claridges, Marc Jacobs presented his little Marc collection, as the industry likes to abbreviate his younger line, and the choice of such an intimate setting in the belly of new old London says only one thing: show me the money!

title: The Backup Catcher
description: For a reporter, the backup catcher has a unique perspective in a baseball clubhouse. Hes a hitter, so he can talk about the other teams pitchers. And hes an authority on his own teams pitchers  but without as much traffic in front of his locker as the starting catcher has. Most backup catchers tend to be veterans with perspective on the game and a wide range of baseball experiences. Its no accident that so many catchers become managers.

I didnt see one fashionista on the plane, though I can feel them, I swear, in the air. Theyre coming, descending like the plague. I decidedit was such a pretty, mild daythat I had better get a jump on things, and I hoofed it over to Corso Como 10.

The Rev. Peter A. Gregory performed the ceremony at St. Charles Roman Catholic Church in Pittsfield.

title: Mr. Big
description: Ron Jeremy has a big penis. How big? you ask. The answer he likes to give is Two inches ... from the floor! (He credits this line to Milton Berle, who was also known for his generous endowment.) In fact, Jeremy measures the length of his penis at nine and three-quarter inches, significantly smaller than that of the porn star John Holmes, but nevertheless his greatest asset. For its size and his endurance and control of it, Ron Jeremys phallus has made him what one trade magazine called the top porn star of all time; he has performed in more than 1,700 porn films with over 4,000 partners. Ron Jeremy: The Hardest (Working) Man in Showbiz, written with Eric Spitznagel, is an X-rated Candide that recounts the journey of a lad with ambitions as large as his genitals from a childhood in Queens to bawdy adventures in the sex industry to a rather melancholy epilogue in which the woman he loves breaks up with him because he wont forsake his swinging life for monogamy.

But it was nonetheless a rare point of light in one of the darkest chapters of human history, and it set in motion the gradual emancipation of slaves across the Americas.

title: Letters to the Editor
Is It Dance? Maybe. Political? Sure.
description: AS an American who has lived in Germany for more than 30 years, the choreographer William Forsythe has grown accustomed to his role as a foreigner. For two decades he ran the Frankfurt Ballet, one of Europes most adventurous companies. And when it folded in 2004, he created the Forsythe Company, based in Frankfurt and Dresden. But faced with a daily barrage of anti-American sentiment in Europe over the war in Iraq, he said, he found himself constantly reminding people that not all Americans are radical right-wingers.

title: Katharine Bailey, Albert Francke

title: Exhibitions That Focus on Image and Celebrity

Face of Fashion, at the National Portrait Gallery showcases the portraits of five fashion photographers, including Corinne Day (famous for creating the grunge look of the 1990s with Kate Moss), Steven Klein (who has photographed Brad Pitt, Angelina Jolie and Madonna) and Mario Sorrenti (creator of campaigns for Dolce & Gabbana and Nicole Farhi, among others). The exhibition also includes interviews with the photographers and their subjects on the relationship of fashion and celebrity. The show runs through May 28. Booking is recommended (www.npg.org.uk).

title: Rising Crime
description: Older readers may remember a time when there existed something called mainstream fiction. It consisted of realist novels of varying literary quality but solid 19th-century roots: family chronicles, historical sagas, imperiled-marriage studies, medical dramas, war stories. Those sorts of works, by common accord, made up the broad center of fiction; they dominated the best-seller lists, swept the prizes, were accorded respectful reviews in publications like this one. Mainstream fiction was, so to speak, the city, while beyond lay the outskirts: the suburbs and mill towns and trailer parks of genre. Crime novels, fantasy and science fiction were segregated because they were considered mere entertainment bereft of moral sustenance, also because they were perceived as appealing to non-mainstream citizens: uneducated, working-class, possibly even ethnic.

The officers entered with their guns drawn; the local police chief said later that they were prepared for the worst. They had come to serve a warrant for the arrest of the studios owners on the grounds that they had violated the states Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations law, or RICO, a charge often used to lock up people who make a business of selling drugs or breaking peoples arms to extort money. The officers confiscated recording equipment, cars, computers and bank statements along with more than 25,000 music CDs. Two of the three owners of the studio, Tyree Simmons, who is 28, and Donald Cannon, who is 27, were arrested and held overnight in the Fulton County jail. Eight employees, mostly interns from local colleges, were briefly detained as well.

As a 25-year-old sailor on the British ship Resolution, which set sail in 1776 in search of the Northwest Passage, Ledyard contracted venereal disease, was served a roasted human arm (and willingly tasted it, as he had lately been reduced to eating fricassee of rats) and lost his captain, James Cook, when a group of angry Hawaiians ran him through the back with a spear. These horrors were a fitting start to a strange and exciting career  one that, like Cooks, would be cut short by a lust for fame and a streak of bad luck.

Two hotels have reopened in Mexico under the ME by Meli brand, which presents experience-oriented hotels integrating modern design, fusion cuisine and world music with local cultural traditions. ME Cancn, formerly known as the Meli Turquesa, was closed for extensive renovations after Hurricane Wilma and reopened last month. Both properties have extensive spas (www.mebymelia.com). ... Elements is the theme for the Canada Blooms: Toronto Flower and Garden Show, set for March 7 to 11. Cut to a garage, or maybe a basement, where shes whacking the drums like Tommy Ramone. Then to a shot of her leaning back, nonchalantly flipping a drumstick: One less, she says levelly, as if youre going to argue with her. Shes the coolest girl in the room, whatever room shes in.

When the German-born Wolfgang Joas and his Dutch wife, Betsy, took it over in 1967, it was a modest bakery. title: Havana Nights
description: The late 50s in Cuba were so rich with glamour and conflict its a wonder more stories havent been set there. Such a time, such a place, and all these elements in a long, slow collision: the sordid glory of casino culture, the last crest of old-school Hollywood splendor, the vicious florescence of the Italian and Jewish mafias, the worldly style of the Cubans themselves and the gathering rumble of the Revolution, all playing out in a gorgeous city. Is there more in the way of material than this? A great narrative, an elegant and charismatic cast, a setting as alluring as any in the world; but we have little to show for it, in English anyway, aside from a slight Graham Greene novel and a few scenes in The Godfather, Part II. And here is Mayra Montero, a Cuban woman now living in Puerto Rico, and Dancing to Almendra,  her ninth novel, lovingly translated by Edith Grossman: a flawless little book with a deceptively light touch, that covers exactly those years.

title: Her Autistic Brothers
description: Tarah Perry wishes her brothers would remember to put on deodorant. Other 16-year-olds, after all, dont need to be reminded of that by their 14-year-old sister. Other families dont keep a stick of Degree in the glove compartment to enforce deodorant compliance on the way to school in the morning. Granted, Justin and Jason are different from other brothers  they are autistic twins  and Tarahs family is therefore different from other families, and generally speaking she is perfectly O.K. with that. Its all she has ever known. But lately she has been fighting more with her brothers. They irritate her, she says. They stink. She tells them as much, and they squabble about it, as any siblings might  only when youre 14 and your brothers are disabled and you dont know whether theyll ever make it on their own or whether youll be responsible for taking care of them, then even the little things take on greater weight. Because what Tarah also wishes is that her brothers will one day manage to hold jobs and find friends and live the kind of life that regular deodorant-wearing people live, or some semblance of it. And in the meantime, it would be nice if they didnt smell up the car.

They flee in motor vehicles driven at high speed down narrow, overcrowded roads, often at night without lights for fear of enemy fire. The result is a death rate from accidents that often dwarfs the losses from enemy action. Yet despite the wrecks littering the sides of the roads, nothing will persuade the drivers that they are making a false calculation of risk. They think they know how to drive. They do not understand the relative risks of war.

title: Paperback Row

Her protagonist, 56-year-old Anatoly Pavlovich Sukhanov, was a promising young painter who became a party hack, vilifying Western artists as the editor of an official art journal. But as the novel begins in 1985, the year Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, Sukhanov is asked to do the unthinkable: publish a respectful treatise on Marc Chagall. Struggling under a new age of openness, Sukhanov is soon out of a job, and he is consumed by dreams that force him to confront his shameful past. In the Book Review, Liesl Schillinger said Grushin, who was born in Moscow in 1971 and moved to America in 1989, attracts the reader with evocations of places and people, even foods, that reflect the mingled sentimentality and abhorrence of the willing exile.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: MARGHERITA DOLCE VITA. By Stefano Benni. (Europa, paper, $14.95.) The sickly 14-year-old heroine of this charming Italian novel prefers to call things not only by the names that are found in the dictionary but also by names found only in the fictionary, names that I make up and choose. This makes Margherita a bit of an unreliable narrator, but not in the ways you might think. One day a monolithic mansion, an immense black-glass Cube, without any visible doors or windows, appears next to her familys house on the dusty and depressing outskirts of an unnamed town. The building is occupied by a family far more fashionable and wealthy than her own, and its members soon enlist her father in a mysterious business venture, which the ever-suspicious teenager sets out to expose. Satirically portrayed by their daughter, Margheritas parents are so wowed by their neighbors cosmopolitanism that they become blind to the ecological and psychic devastation of the suburban sprawl threatening their once-remote home and its surrounding meadows. Despite (or perhaps because of?) her eccentric musings, Margherita provides an opposing voice of reason. Thanks to Stefano Benni and his translator, Antony Shugaar, we have a renewed appreciation of the imaginations ability to free us from our increasingly mundane surroundings.

title: Unequal treatment
description: In April 1721, sailors arriving from Barbados set off a smallpox epidemic that raged in Boston for a year. Cotton Mather, the powerful Puritan minister, advocated using pus from a smallpox scab to infect another person, producing a mild case and long-term immunity to the speckled monster. Mather first learned about inoculation from an African slave and from reports of the practice in Turkey. For years, he had repeatedly failed to persuade any physician to try it. But on June 26, 1721, Zabdiel Boylston, a physician, administered pus to his 6-year-old son and two of his slaves, an adult and child. All three experienced mild cases and quickly recovered. By the time the epidemic subsided, Boylston had inoculated 244 people, six of whom died  a death rate of 2.4 percent, compared with 14 percent for the nearly 6,000 Bostonians who acquired smallpox naturally.

title: The Banker and the Nun
description: The title and subtitle of John Lanchesters family memoir bear pondering. An only child, raised in Hong Kong and other postcolonial outposts before being sent to boarding school in Britain at age 10, the author was trained to mistrust strong emotions to the point of never expressing them and, ultimately, never feeling them: for instance, when his grandmother died, and later when he lost his father, whom he regarded as one of the best men I have known. By the time he buried the ashes of his formidable Irish mother  the central, most compelling character in the story he tells  he had endured repeated panic attacks and a breakdown and had finally begun to discern the nature of his problem. Once, he informs us, he even managed to tell his mother that he loved her. So, plainly, he isnt deploying the words romance and love ironically; in his own mind, it seems, they represent a kind of victory, the feelings he has finally managed to wring out in the writing of this book, not to mention years of therapy.

title: Paris Mismatch
description: By her own admission, the art historian Eunice Liptons decision to live in Paris makes little sense. In the 1920s, her Jewish father and grandparents fled the rising tide of anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe and emigrated to the Bronx. Growing up there in a predominantly working-class Jewish neighborhood, she recalls in French Seduction: An Americans Encounter With France, Her Father, and the Holocaust, Lipton watched her relatives weep over photographs of Nazi concentration camp detainees. From that moment on, looking at pictures would always be intertwined in my mind with the murder of Jews. How fitting, then, that her fascination with pictures  especially those of the French Impressionists  would lead her to immerse herself in French culture, only to be traumatized by its own history of anti-Jewish sentiment. Didnt I know the French were anti-Semites? she asks, reflecting on the bigotry of Edgar Degas and Auguste Renoir, of the regular folks who rounded up Jews during the Nazi occupation and of the proprietor of her favorite Paris cafe. How can one live with both feelings, loving a culture and knowing that it doesnt love you?

title: Lives in the Arts
description: How many artists subscribe to the notion that creative success depends on input from the fickle muse or her modern avatar, mental illness? Probably very few. Like all romantic conceits, it fails to acknowledge the grubby reality of mortal life, in this case the dedicated, often torturous labor a writer or dancer or sculptor invests in what he or she makes. Among the lucid and often delightful observations Joan Acocella makes in her new collection of critical essays, Twenty-Eight Artists and Two Saints, none is more important than this: What allows genius to flower is not neurosis but its opposite ... ordinary Sunday-school virtues such as tenacity and above all the ability to survive disappointment. In fact, Acocella suggests, the remarkable and sustained career of a prodigy like George Balanchine, to name one of her subjects, proves this artist not an example, but a freak, of ego strength.

It should be a sober warning about the present day. America  never mind Yonkers  still grapples with unsettled issues of poverty and race, and until that conundrum is resolved, it will keep reasserting itself in new and troubling ways.

And Guillermo del Toro's Pan's Labyrinth got six Oscar nods, including one for best foreign-language film. The art scene has also arrived. Curators have been snapping up Mexico City artwork in places like Basel; now they will descend on the city this April for Mexico Arte Contemporneo, its fledging contemporary art fair. title: Through the Prison Camp Fence
description: Theres no direct English translation for cynefin, the Welsh term for a fierce attachment to a patch of land  so fierce among some sheep that land and flock must be sold together or the transplanted sheep will wander, impossible to herd. That idea acts as a kind of touchstone in The Welsh Girl, a first novel by Peter Ho Davies, the author of two short-story collections. Set in rural Wales near the end of World War II, Daviess novel is an ambitious, layered meditation on what it means to be from a particular place. Yet he isnt interested in making tired connections between geography and destiny. Rather, The Welsh Girl is a kaleidoscopic study of the clash between local and national identities; between personal history and history as it plays out on the world stage. These contradictions are explored from such a dizzying array of angles that Daviess readers may be left wondering if terms like ally, enemy or hero mean anything at all outside the realms of public relations and propaganda.

title: I Saw You
description: The first words that reporters exchange with players in spring training are usually hello and how are you. So when Ron Villone, the Yankees reliever, burst up to me outside the clubhouse this week and said, I saw you running, I was briefly perplexed. What? I said. In River Vale, Villone said. I saw you running and I followed you. O.K. Now it made some sense. I live in River Vale, N.J., and run through the streets of the town several times a week. Villone used to live there, too. Since Villones former wife and children still do, he frequents the town. I was beeping at you and I stuck my head out the window, Villone said. But you didnt see me. I had no explanation for Villone, other than the fact that running is a solitary exercise for me. Im in my own world. I was probably lost in some songs on my iPod because I told Villone I had no recollection of anybody in a Mercedes beeping at me and shouting to me. I stayed back about 50 feet, Villone said. I didnt want to scare you. Scare me? Well, I might have been surprised, but not scared. Anyway, I ran in Tampa on Saturday. I kept my eyes peeled for Villone this time. Nothing yet, but it is a long spring.

title: El Duque, 41 going on 21
description: The Mets could be playing in Denver, Phoenix, Washington or Zimbabwe, and the pregame sight is always the same. About five hours before first pitch, Orlando Hernandez can be found running. Some days he runs from foul pole to foul pole. Others, along the warning track. Occasionally, hell run through the stands.But when the season ends, the obsessive training continues. El Duque outlined his daily off-season routine this morning, and its no surprise that, even at 41, he is in tremendous physical shape.On Mondays, he runs for 25 to 30 minutes, about 3 miles, he said. On Tuesdays, he runs up and down stairs and concentrates on agility drills. Wednesdays are devoted to running from pole to pole, over and over again. He switches it up on Thursdays, running in a hilly tropical park near his Miami home. On Friday, he runs for 25 to 30 minutes. And on Saturdays, he returns to the tropical park for a series of sprints.What about Sundays?I enjoy the day, Hernandez said. I eat rice and beans and pork.

title: Should Our Lives Be Unified?
description: Back in 1961, when Theodore Bikel was guest starring on the supremely great TV series Naked City, he played a loving father and husband who, in an early scene, rows a small boat out to where a cabin cruiser is anchored in the Hudson River. He climbs up onto the deck and calmly massacres five men. It turns out that he has a secret life as a contract killer, and after several turns of the plot he agrees to testify against his employers. In the last scene, he is shot going up the steps of the courthouse, and just before he dies, he says to his son (played by Keir Dullea), they will ask you how a man could love his family and then go out and kill five people. What has one thing to do with the other?I have always regarded that dying declaration as a trenchant critique of the myth of the unified life, the idea that we all have, or should have, a set of core values to which we are responsive no matter what it is we happen to be doing  working, worshiping, playing, parenting, voting. It is as if Polonius had added a second line to his advice to his son Laertes in Hamlet. Not only to thine own self be true, but be true in exactly the same way whatever the circumstances. But is that a good idea? Should the different contexts we enter be informed always by the same allegiances? Or is it possible, and perhaps desirable, to compartmentalize ones life so that the convictions adhered to in one area remain cabined and do not spill over into the others?

title: Clinton Woos Black Voters
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton signalled to black voters this morning that they could think of the 2008 presidential contest as a barrier-breaking election even if they voted for her instead of one of their own, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, who is competing with Mrs. Clinton for the Democratic nomination. Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama are aggressively courting black voters; she made her first visit to South Carolina today as a presidential candidate, appearing before a predominantly black audience of about 2,500 people at historically black Allen University, while Mr. Obama was in the state this past weekend. At her town hall forum at Allen, Mrs. Clinton also put her own gentle spin on a controversy that erupted last week when one of her most prominent black supporters in South Carolina, state Senator Robert Ford, said Mr. Obama would be a political disaster as the nominee. "Every Democrat running on that ticket next year would lose, because he's black and he's top of the ticket," Mr. Ford said. "We'd lose the House and the Senate and the governors and everything." The quote has been a big deal in South Carolina, and Mr. Ford has apologized for it. At the town hall, Mrs. Clinton said, "I believe this presidential election is about breaking barriers  and this is the campaign, and I am the candidate with the experience to break the barriers." She also won a standing ovation by saying, "I believe one of the great things about America is, anyone can be president, and what it depends upon is the individual. I'm proud to be a woman." Indeed, the audience was ecstatic when she made her standard can-a-woman-win remarks. Strong applause and standing ovations both. Mrs. Clinton did not refer to Mr. Obama by name, nor did she rebuke Mr. Ford; indeed, he was in the audience, and she thanked him for his support.

description: When hedge funds buy shares of a company and start agitating for changes in the way it is being managed, they may seem to be gunning for a quick killing at the expense of longer-term shareholders. But, in fact, the evidence shows that for the most part, buy-and-hold investors ought to cheer when hedge funds jump aggressively into a stock, according to a new study.

title: For Yales Money Man, a Higher Calling
description: David F. Swensen never appears on lists of the most highly paid money managers. But in his competitive world, he can boast of an extraordinary record: In his 21 years at Yale, Mr. Swensen has generated an annual compound growth rate of 16.3 percent, besting the performance of Harvards endowment and that of every other major school in the country. He has routinely rebuffed lucrative offers to leave Yale and to cash in on his expertise.

title: Frances Scor Makes Unsolicited Bid for Converium
description: Scor, Frances largest reinsurer, offered to buy Converium Holding for 3.1 billion Swiss francs ($2.5 billion) in the latest deal in the global reinsurance sector. Converium rejected the approach, saying that it is not in the interests of shareholders. Scors approach follows last years acquisition by Swiss Re of General Electrics Insurance Solution unit for $7.4 billion. Axa, Europes second-largest insurer, in June agreed to sell its Axa Re reinsurance unit to a group of investors. Reinsurers help primary insurers like Allianz shoulder risks for clients.

title: Safety: Heavy Lifters May Need Longer Breaks
description: People whose jobs involve a lot of lifting may need to take longer breaks than is often the case now to avoid back injuries, a new study finds. This seems to be especially true for people new to the job.

title: British Prince Wants to Go to Iraq
description: LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Britain's official policy on Iraq is that its troops will leave as soon as they can hand over to Iraqis. But there is one particular soldier who, according to a crescendo of British newspaper reports, does not seem quite so replaceable.

title: 3i Makes Another Run at Enterprise
description: The 3i Group is in talks to buy Enterpise, a British pipe-laying company, for 486 million pounds ($949 million), or 605 pence a share, the companys independent directors said in a statement Monday. Such an offer would represent a 30 percent premium to Enterprises stock price on Nov. 7, and a 5.2 percent premium over an offer made on Jan. 12, which was rejected as too low by the companys directors.

title: Qatar May Take a 10% Stake in EADS, Official Says
description: Qatar is in talks to buy a 10 percent stake in EADS, the parent company of Airbus, the countrys foreign minister told news services Monday. Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, who heads the $40 billion Qatar Investment Authority, told Bloomberg News that he was interested if the stake was at the right value, though he declined to say how much the authority would invest or from whom it would buy the stake.

title: London Collections
description: Reviews of the Christopher Kane, Marios Schwab, Nathan Jenden and Gareth Pugh collections.

title: More Chrysler Suitors Emerge, as Deal Talk Boosts Stock
description: Several things have emerged in the wake of the DaimlerChrysler drama. Talk that the German-American car maker may spin off or sell its troubled Chrysler unit has driven the companys stock to highs last seen six years ago. Even as analysts criticize an acquisition of Chrysler as costly, thanks to healthcare liabilities and a poor product lineup, several suitors remain interested. And a report in The Detroit News suggests that General Motors negotiations over Chrysler have been going on for some time.

title: Juan Padilla, the Mets Magic Man
description: Juan Padilla, the Mets resident sleight-of-hand artist, practices card tricks in his spare time. This morning, he dazzled teammates and reporters with an old favorite: He made 4 piles, each with a jack, queen, king and ace, before putting them all in one stack. Duaner Sanchez cut the deck once, then again. Padilla dealt the cards into four piles again: one of jacks, one of queens, one of kings and one of aces.

title: Fresh Clint
description: The overlap between Oscar watchers and regular listeners to NPRs Fresh Air is probably very small, but the Bagger happens to be in that small sweet spot. Long after he got home the other night, he listened to Terry Gross and Clint Eastwood, two soft-spoken people who say a lot every time they open up their mouths, talking about his last two movies and beyond.

title: Far Too Worthy
description: USA Todays excellent Oscar blog, Red Carpet Report  all hail MSM brethren  picked up on a bit of a global symposium that the BBC ran on all things Oscar.

title: Ugandan Box Office
description: The Last King of Scotland, the rare movie about Africa that to use the continent for something besides a backdrop for the great white man theory of history, is a hit in Uganda. Forest Whitaker, who played Idi Amin and will likely reap an Oscar to go with his smashing reviews, told The Associated Press that filming the movie there made all the difference in the world. It allowed him to be surrounded by people who have experienced Amin, who knew the situation emotionally and internally, Mr. Whitaker said. All of the people were helpful in trying to guide us to the truth.

title: Now Not Presenting Borat
description: Looking for a little Borat to go with your best picture watch? Do not stay tuned, says the Envelope. He was asked, Oscar broadcast producer Laura Ziskin said Friday, but he declined.

title: Giving a Hoot, Hoot
description: Melissa Etheridges I Need to Wake Up is up for best song and the Houston Chronicle (thanks to Little Golden Men for pointing us that way) talked to her about how she came up with a song for An Inconvenient Truth, a movie that would seem to offer all the lyrical possibilities of a nice bowl of vegetables.

title: YouTube: Oscars New Frenemy
description: Talk to anybody who is trying to hold down a corner office at a studio and youll learn that they feel about video sites and file-sharing as the buffalos felt about the long rifle. But go to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences official site for a look at their famous quotes ad campaign and the user is directed back out to  YouTube. Guess the Academy has heard the line about keeping your friends close and your enemies closer. Close the bay doors on the way out, Hal.

title: The Lives of the Guy Who Made That Movie
description: People who manage to pull up to The Lives of Others not having heard the hype will no doubt walk away asking, Who the hell made that movie? The answer is 33-year-old first-time German director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, and the Settle Post Intelligencer reports out that he spent a lot of quality time with former Stasi officers before making the film. Tip of the lid to OscarWatch for tipping us off.

title: Snap
description: Mr. Bagger, your date has arrived.(Jeffrey Mayer/WireImage.com)

title: 2008: Less Up Close and Personal
description: One of the features of the Iowa caucus, and to some extent, the New Hampshire primary, as firsts in the nation for presidential contenders, has been their time-tested small gatherings where voters get to question candidates.

title: A Power Greater than Himself
description: Lewis Beale is working out some issues over at The Reeler. Sounds like he and the Bagger might need to head down to a church basement with some bad coffee, stale donuts and like-afflicted people

title: Fetish Object
description: In 1994, the Bagger met a girl  cute, rough and ready, and just gullible enough to buy the baloney he was spouting. They lived in Minnesota and on the spur of the moment decided to drive to Taos, N.M., for some skiing. They took her Saab because he was driving junk at the time, and ripped down there in nothing flat. Their accommodations in an old adobe building in town were gorgeous, but lacked a television. No big deal, except, except, it was Oscar weekend. He admitted he HAD to see the show and they frantically raced all over town on Sunday until they found a bar where it was showing. The Bagger enjoyed the proceedings, give or take Tom Hanks preachy best actor speech for Philadelphia. (Hey, we were all young and full of beans back then.)

title: Oh, That Totally Clears Things Up
description: Oscar technicians were looking to the Eddie Award, the editing citation, to bring some clarity to best picture. So naturally, in a year where every event that is expected to resolve the story only thickens the plot, Babel and The Departed tied for the top spot. Whoa.

title: Sandy Alomar x 2
description: The Mets doubled the number of Sandy Alomars this morning, signing the catcher Sandy Alomar Jr. to a minor-league contract. Junior is expected to report tomorrow.

title: Rubber? Meet Road.
description: No more fooling around. The Bagger is going old-school today, pounding the phones until the wires start to hum in search of the only thing anybody with proper priorities should care about this week: What will win best picture? Not what should. Not what would win a perfect world. Naw, the time for debating the relative merits of a film is giving way to its ability to attract votes.

title: Milkshakes
description: Milkshakes may not be the best indicator of inflation, but the rising cost of a simple blend of milk and ice cream cant go without mention.

title: Clinton Woos Black Voters
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton signalled to black voters this morning that they could think of the 2008 presidential contest as a barrier-breaking election even if they voted for her instead of one of their own, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, who is competing with Mrs. Clinton for the Democratic nomination.

title: Sirius and XM Plan to Cross Signals
description: Update: Sirius and XM announced they would pursue a $13 billion all-stock deal, with shareholders of each company holding about 50 percent of the combined entity. Read The New York Times article here.

title: Prison for Pop-Ups?
description: I caught this article in The Times. Its about a computer-phobic substitute teacher whose classroom PC went nuts with pop-up ads for porn Web sites, and some of the seventh-grade students saw them. Shes just been convicted of risking injury to a child and faces *40 YEARS IN PRISON*.

title: Carter vs. the Worms
description: Nicholas Kristof follows the former president as he travels into the wilds of Ethiopia to help find a cure for river blindness.

title: A-Rods New Strategy
description: Alex Rodriguez reported to spring training with a new strategy for dealing with a touchy topic. Hes no longer going to pretend that he and Derek Jeter are best friends.

title: Swindal Wont Speculate on Future
description: So just as were digesting all of A-Rods words, who walks into the press box but Steve Swindal? He was ready to answer questions for the first time since his arrest early last Wednesday on suspicion of DUI.

title: Video: Carter vs. the Worms
description: Heres a report that accompanies Nicks Sunday column and his Tuesday column. Watch as Nick asks Jimmy Carter why Americans should care about river blindness and other diseases that only affect people in Africa.

title: Prime Clubhouse Real Estate May Be Available
description: Since it is becoming more and more apparent that Bernie Williams will not be back with the Yankees this season, the team will have to decide what to do with his spacious corner locker at Yankee Stadium. Williams took over the locker after Don Mattingly retired.

title: Andy, We Missed You  Now Sign This
description: Andy Pettitte drove last week from Legends Field in Tampa to the gated community where he is staying during Yankees spring training. But it was not until Pettitte had completed the 15-minute drive that he realized he had some company.

title: The Week Ahead
description: The IHT's Alison Smale breaks down this week in global politics.

title: Coping with Epilepsy
description: Kina and Lee Leitner discuss having a daughter with intractable epilepsy.

title: Undermanned Pittsburgh Keeps Seton Hall in a Skid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 19  With the 7-foot center Aaron Gray on the bench, Pittsburgh may be less imposing, but you dont have to be that good to beat a reeling Seton Hall right now.

title: For Foxs Rivals, American Idol Remains a Schoolyard Bully
description: Listening to the Fox networks competitors describe what American Idol has done to the television landscape is not unlike listening to a group of quavering readers offer a synopsis of a Stephen King novel:

title: Irans President Defiant on Nuclear Program
description: Irans president remained defiant today on the eve of a United Nations deadline for his country to stop enriching uranium, as tensions between Iran and the United States continued to mount in various ways.

title: How to Walk a Mile in Your Dream Career
description: AFTER 28 years at an electronics plant in her hometown, Mount Pleasant, Iowa, Toni Cory found herself out of a job when the plant closed. Instead of looking for another manufacturing job, she vowed to start a dog day-care and kennel business.

title: Maryland: Gunman Dies in Fire
description: A two-story shopping center in Frederick was destroyed by fire after a gunman entered a liquor store in the complex, told an employee to leave and then barricaded himself inside. The police believe the gunman, who had no hostages, was killed in the fire. There were no other injuries, said Sgt. Clark Pennington of the Frederick Police Department. Sergeant Pennington said the man fired on police officers, who then set up a barricade. Negotiators had made telephone contact with him before the blaze started. The fire destroyed all 13 stores at the Antietam Village Shopping Center, which is about 50 miles from Baltimore.

title: After a Rampage, Trying to Grasp What Led a Son to Kill
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 19  At 1 a.m. last Tuesday, the parents of Sulejman Talovic called the police to report him missing. After watching television news coverage, they feared he might be among those dead or wounded in a shooting rampage at a mall here. One hour later, with the arrival of detectives, they discovered the shocking truth, that their son, 18, was the gunman.

title: Rape Charge Splits Iraqi Sunnis and Shiites
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 20  The most wicked acts are spoken of openly and without reserve in Iraq. Torture, stabbings and bodies ripped to pieces in bombings are all part of the daily conversation.

title: Letters
description: Debating Climate Change

title: A Clash of Cultures, Averted
description: When Bank of America announced its $35 billion acquisition of MBNA in summer 2005, many people questioned whether it would work.

title: Spitzer Backs Plan for Indian Casino in Catskills
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has approved plans for a $600 million Las Vegas-style casino in the Catskill Mountains for the St. Regis Mohawk tribe and agreed to lead the effort to gain federal approval. His decision is the biggest leap yet in a 30-year struggle to bring gambling to the faded resort area.

title: High Court Rejects $79.5 Million Tobacco Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Supreme Court today overturned an Oregon jurys award of $79.5 million in punitive damages against Philip Morris on the ground that jurors might have improperly calculated the figure to punish the cigarette maker for the harm it caused to smokers other than the man whose widow brought the case.

title: France: Lawmakers Amend Charter for Presidential Impeachment
description: President Jacques Chirac convened both houses of Parliament for a joint session and won approval for a constitutional amendment that introduces an American-style impeachment procedure. Approval of measure, a pledge from Mr. Chiracs 2002 campaign, was widely viewed as his last major political act before he hands over the presidency in May.

title: The Hemp Vote
description: It is high time for bipartisan cooperation.

title: The Silence of the Rational Center
description: As more and more books, articles and government reports on the Iraq war appear, the role that certain ides fixes and ideological preconceptions played in the Bush administrations decision to go to war becomes increasingly clear. Not only was intelligence cherry-picked to support noisily argued but fallacious theories about weapons of mass destruction and Iraq-Al Qaeda ties, but the war itself seems to have been regarded by some members of the White House and the Pentagon as a kind of demonstration model of their ideas about pre-emptive war, unilateral action and the export of democracy.

title: These Chili Peppers Are Hot and Old
description: Hot peppers have been inflaming palates around the planet for centuries. But the earlier history of jalapeos, habaneros and the like in their native region, the Americas, is far from complete. The remains of peppers dont keep in humid climates, so they are almost never found at archaeological sites.

title: The Lights Go Out Yet the Work Goes on
description: PROTECTING data files is as important at small companies as it is at Fortune 500s. But while large corporations have information-technology staffs with big-time budgets, small companies generally have to make do with more meager resources.

title: With Money in Their Pockets
description: KDMA doesnt look like the kind of company that attracts venture investors. Its not in Silicon Valley, nor is it involved in biotechnology. It doesnt even have a fully working Web site.

title: Sense of Progress on Disaster Preparedness
description: Many Americans say that the nation is better prepared than it was a year ago for disasters like terrorist attacks or pandemic flu, and that the change to a Democratic Congress will make things better still, according to a survey commissioned by Columbia University.

title: The Hot Ticket in Hollywood: An Evening With Obama
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 19  Tom Hanks has bought a $2,300 ticket. So have Jennifer Aniston, Eddie Murphy and Denzel Washington. The studio bosses from Universal, Paramount, Disney and 20th Century Fox have all sent checks or faxed their credit card numbers, too.

title: New DVDs: The Cuban Masterworks Collection
description: There was a time in the 1970s and early 80s when hardly a week went by without the screening of a Cuban feature, generally as a fund-raiser or rally point for leftist political groups. The Cuban classics, which almost invariably meant Humberto Solss Luca (1968) and Toms Gutirrez Aleas Memories of Underdevelopment (1968), seemed to strike the right balance between political polemic and telenovela. Strident but playful, deadly serious but punctuated by physical gags and mildly satiric attacks on the Communist bureaucracy, these were the films that radical students of the 1970s saw as models of hope and inspiration. Like much political propaganda, though, they have aged poorly and have effectively dropped out of sight in the last several years.

title: Lets Make Education Our Priority (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors and Defense Sum Up Libby Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The two sides in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. laid out starkly different theories for the jury today, as prosecutors ridiculed Mr. Libbys claims of a faulty memory and defense lawyers belittled the prosecutions case.

title: Rodriguez Doesnt Sugarcoat Rift With Jeter
