description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19  For all of the different ways he has tried to shape his image, Alex Rodriguez has stayed consistent about one thing. He has never apologized for being the highest-paid player in baseball.

title: Swindal Says He Has Steinbrenners Support
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19  Steve Swindal, the general partner of the Yankees and the son-in-law of the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, said Monday that Steinbrenner had been supportive since he was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence last Thursday in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Trial Spotlights Cheneys Power as an Infighter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  A picture taking shape from hours of testimony and reams of documents in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. shatters any notion that the White House was operating as a model of cohesion throughout President Bushs first term.

title: Honoring a Westerner Who Preserved Japans Folk Tales
description: MATSUE, Japan  As snow silently fell on the miniature garden outside, Bon Koizumi sat on the same tatami mat floor where, more than a century before, his great-grandfather wrote down some of Japans best-loved folk tales.

title: Aaron Lerner, 86, Innovative Skin Doctor, Dies
description: Dr. Aaron B. Lerner, a Yale dermatologist and the leader of a team of researchers who discovered melatonin, a powerful hormone regulating human sleep-wake cycles, died on Feb. 3 in New Haven. He was 86.

title: Iran: Man Hanged for Role in Bus Bombing
description: Iran hanged a man convicted of involvement in the bombing of a bus carrying members of the Revolutionary Guards on Wednesday, the ILNA news agency reported. Eleven people were killed in the blast in southeastern Zahedan. According to an official in the governors office, the man, Nassrollah Shanbeh Zehi, had come from Pakistan two days earlier, the news agency said.

title: Old Foes Join in Anger as Train Bombings Toll Rises to 66
description: DIWANA, India, Feb. 19  A day after two homemade bombs killed at least 66 people on a train traveling to Pakistan from India, the governments of both countries on Monday condemned the attack and pledged that it would not deter their aim of reducing longstanding hostilities on the subcontinent.

title: Bank of America Tagline Has Run Its Course
description: BANK OF AMERICA is backing away from Higher Standards  at least in its new national advertising campaign.

title: Defending Nations Latest War, Bush Recalls Its First
description: MOUNT VERNON, Va., Feb. 19  To those who criticize his handling of the war in Iraq, President Bush likes to say that history will be his judge. On Monday, Presidents Day, Mr. Bush wrapped himself in historys embrace, invoking another war, the American Revolution, and another George W.  George Washington  as his guide.

title: See That His Grave Is Clean and His Blues Are Sung Out
description: Blind Lemon Jefferson, a country blues singer in the early days of recorded music, made enormously popular records for Paramount in the mid-1920s, but the known details of his life would fit comfortably inside a small toolbox. His vague biography, however, did not deter Alan Govenar and Akin Babatunde from creating a lively and intelligent new musical about his life and work, Blind Lemon Blues, currently in a limited run from the York Theater Company.

title: And Jebs Candidate Is?
description: Now that President Bushs sister, Dorothy Bush Koch, is planning to be co-host of a fund-raiser for Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and a Republican presidential aspirant, speculation is beginning to focus on the intentions of another presidential sibling, Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida. Mr. Bush has decided not to enter the 2008 race. But his backing would be a hot commodity for any other Republican running this year.

title: Bird Flu Is Still a Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Lets Start a War, One We Can Win
description: AFETA, Ethiopia

title: Job Corps Plans Makeover for a Changed Economy
description: LAUREL, Md.  Over the last four decades, even as failed experiments and partisan disputes took the luster off the war on poverty, the Job Corps, the governments main effort to give poorly educated youths a second chance at a diploma and a trade, was widely seen as one of the few success stories.

title: But Wait, Senator, About the War...
description: Lawmakers have fled Washington for a Congressional recess (or, as they prefer to call it, a district work period). But the debate over the Iraq war is following many of them home.

title: A Round Trip on a Conveyor Belt in China
description: In North American airports, there are warnings posted above the luggage carousels: Please dont step on the conveyor belt. These signs are often missing when you travel internationally, and I recently discovered why.

title: A Wet Wind Tunnel So Ships Can Move Faster and Better
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Out of Control: A True Story of Binge Eating
description: This month, researchers at Harvard published a survey finding that binge eating is by far the most common eating disorder, occurring in 1 in 35 adults, or 2.8 percent  almost twice the combined rate for anorexia (0.6 percent) and bulimia (1 percent).

title: Mets Are Packing Roster for the Early Bird Specials
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 19  The Mets signed catcher Sandy Alomar Jr. to a minor league contract Monday, ending the three-week drought since they last signed a 40-year-old player.

title: Not Lost in Translation
description: With corporate travelers now doing business in all four points of the globe, developing some fluency in foreign languages is getting to be as important as taking along a laptop on an overseas trip.

title: Blood Unsimple: The Ties That Bind, in All Their Complexity
description: The family has provided precious material for writers from Proust to Austen to Jonathan Franzen, but visual art has been somewhat less devoted to the subject. The 19th-century Parisian avant-garde model for living was to escape home and family as quickly as possible, before they zapped your artistic mojo. Gauguin was the paragon; mile Zolas 1886 novel The Masterpiece, based on Czannes early days in Paris, offers further confirmation.

title: In London, Lots of Cheeriness but Little to Cheer About
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  Fashion writers have not felt the same toward England since Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren listed all their hates on a T-shirt, ending with all those blankety-blank culture saints. British fashion rejoiced in pulling your pants down, as Alexander McQueen, who came a generation later, literally did with his bumster trousers. We loved the Brits because, unlike their suave neighbors, they didnt try to pull the wool.

title: Florida Executioner Says Procedures Were Followed
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19  A member of Floridas execution team told a panel studying lethal injection protocols on Monday that intravenous lines had been placed properly in the arms of a condemned inmate who took 34 minutes, twice as long as normal, to die.

title: The Rangers Know Well the Cost of Concussions
description: Maybe theyre superstitious. Maybe they dont want to say the word. Or maybe its just easier for hockey people to use it or them.

title: Italy Wont Block Spanish Bid for a Stake in Telecom Italia
description: MILAN, Feb. 19  Just months after the Italian infrastructure minister, Antonio Di Pietro, blocked a Spanish company seeking to buy the largest toll road company in Italy, he indicated Monday that he would not block Spanish acquisition of a large stake in Telecom Italia.

title: A Winters Discontent, in Arabic
description: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England, Feb. 15  As played by the Syrian actor Fayez Kazak, the title character in Richard III: An Arab Tragedy is a preening, plotting devil with the vulpine intelligence and maniacal charisma of the late Saddam Hussein. But he is not Mr. Hussein, even if the director and adapter of the play, Sulayman Al-Bassam, briefly conceived of him that way.

title: Albany: Special Assembly Elections Scheduled
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that special elections had been scheduled for March 27 to fill two State Assembly vacancies. Elections are set for the 16th Assembly District, in northwestern Nassau County, to replace Thomas P. DiNapoli, whom the Legislature elected state comptroller on Feb. 7, and in the 61st Assembly District, in northern Staten Island, to replace John W. Lavelle, who died on Jan. 24.

title: Recipe for Success: Take Mentos, Diet Coke. Mix.
description: BUCKFIELD, Me.

title: Islanders Keep Coming Back Until They Defeat the Penguins
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Feb. 19  Pittsburgh center Sidney Crosby changed directions with the puck so many times in the final minute of Mondays game against the Islanders that he looked like a skier in a slalom race.

title: Satellite Radio Companies Agree to Merge
description: The nations two largest satellite radio services, XM and Sirius, announced this afternoon that they planned to merge.

title:
Court Backs 
White House on Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20A federal appeals court today upheld the constitutionality of a new law that strips federal courts of the authority to review the cases of foreign prisoners held by the military at the Guantnamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba.

title: Bend in Rules Helps Leipheimer Retain Lead
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Feb. 19  Call it the hometown advantage.

title: Surfing for Status? Thats a Bummer, Dude! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Assault of the Hackers
description: SINCE hanging out a shingle six years ago, Stonebridge Bank, a 50-employee Internet bank in West Chester, Pa., has built up $400 million in assets, virtually from scratch, by managing deposits for Pennsylvania families and lending to small businesses. Its success has also made Stonebridge a tempting target for cybercriminals, who according to the bank make about 100,000 assaults on its Web site each day.

title: Putnam Valley Man Kills Wife and Daughter, Then Himself, Police Say
description: A distraught man strangled his wife and their 14-year-old daughter before killing himself in their home in Putnam Valley, N.Y., the state police said yesterday.

title: A Race and Commercials Almost Merge Into One
description: If the annual whoop-de-do over Super Bowl commercials is based on the search for ads that are humorous, tasteless, memorable or effective, then any analysis of Daytona 500 commercials leads to a calculation of how many drivers were used in them during Nascars Super Bowl.

title: Kirsten Gillibrand
description: BORN Dec. 9, 1966, in Albany.

title: Hercules in the Garden
description: Q. What makes it possible for weeds to grow through a two-inch-thick asphalt sidewalk?

title: Battling Epilepsy, and Its Stigma
description: The first thing you notice about 12-year-old Nora Leitner is the dark circles under her eyes. They stand in stark contrast to the rest of her appearance; at a glance she might be any petite, pretty tween girl, with her blond ponytail, elfin frame and thousand-watt smile. But the circles tell a different story: Nora looks as if she hasnt slept in a month.

title: Dismissed U.S. Attorneys (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan: Crackdown on 2 Islamic Charities
description: The government ordered the closing of the offices and the freezing of the bank accounts of two Islamic charities, Al Akhtar Trust and Al-Rashid Trust, listed by the United States since 2003 as financial sponsors of terrorism. The charities were added to a similar United Nations list in 2005, and the state interior minister, Zafar Iqbal Warraich, told Parliament that the United Nations had notified Pakistan that it would impose sanctions if it did not ban them.

title: Left Holding the Bag in the Land of Fast Food
description: FRANCHISE owners lie awake at night thinking about customers like Stephen Minnis.

title: In Somalia, Violence Is Status Quo
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 20  Fierce mortar attacks killed more than 10 civilians in Somalia today, but this is the new status quo.

title: Mideast Talks Conclude With Little Result
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 19  An American-sponsored meeting between Israeli and Palestinian leaders meant to start a new peace initiative after six years ended Monday with little more concrete than a promise to meet again.

title: The Problems in Modeling Nature, With Its Unruly Natural Tendencies
description: When coastal engineers decide whether to dredge sand and pump it onto an eroded beach, they use mathematical models to predict how much sand they will need, when and where they must apply it, the rate it will move and how long the project will survive in the face of coastal storms and erosion.

title: Student, 16, Finds Allies in His Fight Over Religion
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19  A Kearny High School junior on Monday drew some legal heavyweights into his battle with school officials over a teachers proselytizing in class.

title: Ritzenhein to Run in Central Park
description: Dathan Ritzenhein, one of the United States best distance runners, joined the field yesterday for the United States 8-kilometer championship March 17 in Central Park.Speaking from his home in Boulder, Colo., on a teleconference, Ritzenhein, 23, said he would pass up the world cross-country championships March 7 in Mombasa, Kenya.He said he would run the 10 kilometers in the United States outdoor championships June 21-24 in Indianapolis to try to qualify for the world championships Aug. 24 through Sept. 2 in Beijing. He said he would decide in August whether to run in the United States Olympic marathon trial Nov. 1 in Central Park.

title: Anglicans Rebuke U.S. Branch on Blessing Same-Sex Unions
description: Facing a possible churchwide schism, the Anglican Communion yesterday gave its Episcopal branch in the United States less than eight months to ban blessings of same-sex unions or risk a reduced role in the worlds third-largest Christian denomination.

title: Joseph Low, 95, Illustrator of Childrens Books, Dies
description: Joseph Low, an illustrator who did absurdist covers for The New Yorker and won Caldecott honors for the childrens book Mice Twice, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Edgartown, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard. He was 95.

title: Some Nyack Residents Get Together to Put on a Show
description: NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 15  The Helen Hayes Theater wasnt old or housed in a historic building or even particularly beloved by many in this village on the west bank of the Hudson River.

title: Mr. Spitzers Chance on Warming
description: Given the concerns of the new Democratic Congress, as well as persuasive new scientific evidence of the dangers of climate change, Washington may finally be ready to address the problem of global warming. The chances of that would be better still if New Yorks new governor, Eliot Spitzer, would commit himself and the state to a cause that needs all the friends it can get.

title: In India, Showing Sectarian Pain to Eyes That Are Closed
description: MUMBAI  Rahul Dholakia, an Indian filmmaker and a native of the western Indian state of Gujarat, set out five years ago to make a movie about a friend who lost his son during the Gujarat riots of 2002.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Saturday about national elections in Lesotho attributed an erroneous distinction to the African countrys mountain range, where a young herder was shown with his dogs. While Lesothos Maluti mountain range is the highest range in southern Africa, it is not the highest range in all of Africa. (Both the Atlas and Ruwenzori ranges have higher peaks.)

title: A Singer Harmonizing With Demons
description: Baby Jane Dexter is not the first singer to suggest that The Candy Man, that annoyingly cheery 1972 Sammy Davis Jr. hit from Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, has a dark, alternative subtext about drugs. But in her new cabaret act, Youre Following Me!, at the Metropolitan Room through Saturday, she goes further than anyone in turning the song inside out. Accompanied by a rock trio, Ms. Dexter slows it down, gives it a bluesy edge and sings it from the bitter, frustrated point of view of an addict.

title: Merger Would End Satellite Radios Rivalry
description: The nations two satellite radio services, Sirius and XM, announced plans yesterday to merge, a move that would end their costly competition for radio personalities and subscribers but that is also sure to raise antitrust issues.

title: Alliance Backs Voting Rights for Noncitizens
description: New York City should allow legal immigrants who are not citizens to vote in local elections, according to an alliance of more than 60 organizations that announced a renewed effort yesterday to secure that right.

title: Milledge Looks to Rein in Free Spirit but Retain Flair
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 19  Willie Randolph eyed the 20 or so reporters encircling him in the dugout and, with a sigh, prepared for what he considered inevitable.

title: Frenetic Start in Congress for One Democrat, Class of 06
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  When Kirsten Gillibrand was elected to Congress this past November in a tide of Democratic victories, she soon learned that her campaigning was not over.

title: Flame First, Think Later: New Clues to E-Mail Misbehavior
description: Jett Lucas, a 14-year-old friend, tells me the kids in his middle school send one other a steady stream of instant messages through the day. But theres a problem.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Olivier Award Winners

title: Iraqi Militants Launch Attack on U.S. Outpost
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 19  In a rare coordinated assault on an American combat outpost north of Baghdad, suicide bombers drove one or more cars laden with explosives into the compound on Monday, while other insurgents opened fire in the ensuing chaos, according to witnesses and the American military. Two American soldiers were killed and at least 17 were wounded.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: After a Delicately Worded Pitch, Clinton Draws Cheers
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 19  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told an audience of black voters on Monday that they would be breaking barriers if they supported her for president in 2008  deliberately signaling that they could still take pride in making history if they chose a woman over one of their own, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois.

title: Screening: Many Still Forgoing Tests for Colon Cancer
description: More than five years after Medicare began paying for screenings for colon cancer, many people are still not being tested, especially those who are not white.

title: Looking for Mme. Bonnard? Sorry, but Shes in the Tub
description: Among the hundreds of flattering portraits the French artist Pierre Bonnard painted of his wife, many portraying her in the nude and in the bath, one stands out as different from the rest. In Young Women in the Garden, she is a supporting player, hidden in the corner of the frame; darkly lighted, she is glowering at a beautiful blonde.

title: In New Orleans, Bands Struggle to Regain Footing
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19  When the first Mardi Gras after Hurricane Katrina took place last year, New Orleanians felt something vital was missing: the strutting steps and triumphal horns of the citys proud, immensely competitive high school bands marching between the floats.

title: Hail the Tales of the Chief, the First One
description: No one in this city has figured out how best to observe Washingtons Birthday. It is as forlorn a national holiday as we have.

title: Polk Awards Laud Coverage of Darfur and Katrinas Toll
description: Spike Lees documentary on Hurricane Katrina, and journalists who covered the war in Darfur and exposed medical and environmental dangers and shady financial and political practices were among the winners of 12 George Polk Awards for 2006 announced yesterday by Long Island University.

title: Taliban Seize Rural District in Southwest as Police Flee
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 19  Taliban insurgents seized control of a district in southwestern Afghanistan on Monday as the Afghan police abandoned their post and fled, officials said.

title: Australia Plans to Phase Out Incandescent Lights
description: SYDNEY, Feb. 20  Australia intends to phase out incandescent light bulbs completely within three years, the countrys environment minister said today.

title: Britain: Letter Bomb Suspect Arrested
description: The police arrested a school janitor at a house in Cherry Hinton, near Cambridge, in connection with a series of letter bombings this year that wounded nine people. News reports identified the suspect as Miles Cooper, in his 20s. The seven bombs, in book-size padded envelopes containing explosives similar to powerful firecrackers, were delivered mainly in south and central England and south Wales. The targets seemed to be forensic research labs with ties to the police and offices associated with traffic rule enforcement.

title: Pentagon to Fill Iraq Reconstruction Jobs Temporarily
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Pentagon and State Department have worked out a deal to send a small number of military personnel and Defense Department civilians to Iraq for several months until Foreign Service officers and State Department contract workers with specialized skills can fill those jobs, senior officials said Monday.

title: Guilt-Free Pollution. Or Is It?
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  Two years ago, Sami Grover, an environmentally minded Englishman, vowed to take his last trip by airplane. Then a summer romance in North Carolina turned into a long-distance love affair  and then into months of busy trans-Atlantic travel.

title: Memo Pad
description: ONLINE MARKET HEATS UP The big three third-party online travel-booking sites, Expedia, Orbitz and Travelocity, dropped slightly over all in customer-satisfaction ratings last year. The reason is that individual airline and hotel online sites, and other travel search sites like Kayak and SideStep, competed more aggressively for bookings, according to the annual American Customer Satisfaction Index, to be released today by the University of Michigan and the research company ForeSee Results. Of the three big sites, Expedia had the highest score, 78, a slight drop from 2005. Orbitzs score was 75, up one point from 2005, and Travelocitys was 74, down from 75 in 2005.

title: Revamping at Airbus Is Delayed
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  Mounting pressure from European governments has blocked a long-awaited overhaul plan for the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company that is expected to result in thousands of lost jobs at the companys troubled Airbus unit.

title: From the Dark Ages of Heart Surgery, a Lesson for Today
description: Deena Newberg was the girl across the street four decades ago, and in the last few weeks I hadnt been able to stop thinking about her. In the middle of the afternoon I had taken to wondering: Hows she doing? For days on end I was obsessed with this question: Whats she doing?

title: Stocks With Only One Direction to Go
description: EBERHARD SCHNEBURG knows just how miserable life can be for a company that is on the Pink Sheets, the bargain basement of the stock market, and he knows how hard it is to move a company upstairs, where investors are more likely to notice it.

title: Foreign Minister of Colombia Quits in Scandal
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 19  The foreign minister of Colombia resigned Monday as the government of President lvaro Uribe, the Bush administrations closest ally in South America, struggled with a scandal that has disclosed ties between paramilitary cocaine-trafficking squads and some of Mr. Uribes most prominent political supporters.

title: Many Are Eager to See Data on Chrysler
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 19  Not since Jrgen E. Schrempp announced that he was stepping down 18 months ago has there been this much interest in DaimlerChrysler stock.

title: A Mammal in Winter With a Furnace of Her Own
description: The other day a group of distraught construction workers in a Washington suburb contacted the local animal control agency with an unusual complaint. It seems there were seven large snakes wrapped around the heating pipes in a manhole, and the crew members worried that the snakes might be dangerous.

title: Moral Waivers and the Military
description: The Iraq war has plunged the Army into a vicious cycle of declining standards. Multiple, extended tours of duty have sapped morale and blighted recruiting. New plans for a larger overall force could reduce pressures but would also mean that recruiters would have to meet higher quotas.

title: Russia Will Slow Work on Irans Nuclear Plant
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19  Russia said Monday that it would slow work on Irans nearly completed Bushehr nuclear power plant.

title: Retirees Find Their Place in the Sun, and the Snow
description: JONES BEACH, N.Y., Feb. 16  Barry Lorber, a 70-year-old man in a down winter coat, sat on a beach chair in front of the plate-glass wall of a snack franchise called J&B, which is open here year-round. Behind him lay the planks of the Boardwalk, and beyond that the pale sand, and beyond that the clockwork pounding of the Atlantic Ocean surf.

title: Robert Adler, Zenith Physicist, Dies at 93
description: Robert Adler, a physicist and prolific inventor best known as the co-inventor of the television remote control device, died Feb. 15 in Boise, Idaho. He was 93.

title: Progress Is Reported on a Type of Autism
description: Researchers have found that Rett syndrome, a severe form of autism, may not be so entirely beyond repair as supposed. In mice that carry the same genetic defect as human patients and have similar symptoms, the disease can be substantially reversed, even in adult mice, by correcting the errant gene.

title: Despite Violence, India and Pakistan to Hold Talks
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 20 Indian and Pakistani officials said today that sensitive peace talks between their countries would open in Delhi on Wednesday as planned, despite the bombing that killed at least 68 people late Sunday night on a cross-border express train between the two nations.

title: Europes Plan to Track Phone and Net Use
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  European governments are preparing legislation to require companies to keep detailed data about peoples Internet and phone use that goes beyond what the countries will be required to do under a European Union directive.

title: Lee, Not One to Back Down, Remains a Knick Backup
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 19  The bruise along David Lees right cheek bone is fading, replaced by bags under both eyes. Lee, the Knicks tireless rebounder, returned from a busy weekend in Las Vegas feeling, well, tired.

title: The Week Ahead
description: With Congress out of session  and you can bet certain senators running for president are quite happy about that  this is a week for fund-raising, campaigning and one gathering of potentially high interest. The Democratic presidential contenders are appearing Wednesday in Carson City, Nev., for a forum sponsored by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; George Stephanopoulos of ABC News will be asking them questions.

title: In the World of Life-Saving Drugs, a Growing Epidemic of Deadly Fakes
description: Asia is seeing an epidemic of counterfeits of life-saving drugs, experts say, and the problem is spreading. Malaria medicines have been particularly hard hit; in a recent sampling in Southeast Asia, 53 percent of the antimalarials bought were fakes.

title: JetBlue Begins Reimbursing Stranded Passengers
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it would immediately begin paying penalties, ranging from $25 toward a future flight to a round-trip ticket, to passengers kept waiting by the airlines own mistakes.

title: Parking Rules Suspended
description: The New York City Department of Transportation announced last night that alternate side of the street parking rules, which were suspended last week after an outcry by drivers after last Wednesdays snowstorm, would remain suspended today and tomorrow, Ash Wednesday.

title: Less Flu, Less Squalling
description: FluMist vaccine, a nasal spray that has never quite caught on in the marketplace, turns out to do a better job of protecting young children than a standard flu shot. This is a double blessing: better protection, and without those dreaded needles that send children into crying fits and turn parents into mush.

title: Brooklyn: Atlantic Yards Construction to Begin
description: Construction crews were expected to take the first steps today toward building the huge Atlantic Yards project near downtown Brooklyn, according to an aide to Bruce C. Ratner, the developer. The first stages of the work will involve subcontractors removing contamination from a bus depot, then demolishing that structure. Forest City Ratner Companies will build a temporary Long Island Rail Road yard in its place, so that a giant platform can be built above the permanent rail yard to support much of the $4 billion development. The city and state approved the project despite heated opposition from residents who said it would overwhelmingly congest the local streets and transit system. The development will include thousands of apartments, commercial buildings, a hotel and an arena for the Nets, the basketball team Mr. Ratner owns.

title: Contract Clause Isnt Worth the Distraction
description: The last thing Alex Rodriguez needs right now is the opt-out clause in his contract. If he were smart, he would ask the Yankees to amend the contract and delete the clause from it.

title: Charles Langford, 84, Lawyer Who Represented Rosa Parks, Dies
description: Charles Langford, a civil rights lawyer whose best-known client was a Montgomery, Ala., seamstress named Rosa Parks, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Montgomery. He was 84. Mr. Langford died in his sleep, his niece Audrey Anderson told The Associated Press.

title: Smoke Clears at Daytona, but Cloud Remains
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19  Nascar officials spent the better part of a week at Daytona International Speedway hunting down cheats, suspending crew chiefs and stamping their feet while publicly demanding credibility from their race teams.

title: Despite Poor Record, Turner Is the Chargers Pick
description: After failing in two attempts as an N.F.L. coach, Norv Turner has been given a third chance.

title: Slithering Over the Edge of the Envelope to See What Happens
description: In the program notes for Part II, a new work by LeeSaar/The Company that opened the Harkness Dance Festival last week at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, the troupes Israeli-born founders, Lee Sher and Saar Harari, write, By seeking the extreme within ourselves we hope to expand our limits for a fresh experience.

title: Justices to Revisit Thorny Issue of Sentencing Guidelines in First Cases After Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Supreme Court returns on Tuesday from a monthlong recess to face a daunting and urgent task: explaining what it meant two years ago when it ruled that the federal sentencing guidelines were to be treated as advisory, no longer binding on federal judges.

title: The Price of Flowers (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Skull Full of Mush
description: The Paper Chase is the book youre supposed to read before you go to law school. Paper Chase or One L. Me, I read Scott Turows memoir of his first year of law school, One L. Id seen the movie The Paper Chase when it came out in 1973, but not because I had any thought back then of going to law school. I didnt. It was just a good movie about a young guys struggle with an authority figure, like so many other movies we saw back then. The authority figure just happened to be a law professor.

title: Prospect of Mergers Lifts Foreign Markets
description: LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP)  World stock markets ended higher Monday, as merger and acquisition talk bolstered shares in Europe and Japan. Markets were closed in the United States for Washingtons Birthday, and in much of Asia for the Lunar New Year.

title: Letter From California: Looking for the Pattern of Ordinary Life
description: The other night there was thunder along the lower flanks of the San Gabriel mountains. It began just before dark, and at first I didnt recognize what I was hearing. I thought it was the sound of Thursday night: the rumble of heavy plastic trash dumpsters, a whole street of them, being wheeled out to the curb.

title: Viacom Reaches Deal With YouTube Rival
description: Fear not, MTV fans. Episodes of Laguna Beach and The Real World will soon be back on the Internet, free of charge. But this time, viewing is on Viacoms terms.

title: Airlines Sharpen Sites for Web-Savvy Traveler
description: ABOUT $170 billion is spent each year on business travel in the United States. Nearly 90 percent of that is managed  that is, booked by corporate departments  in-house or under contract with a travel management company, or both.

title: NASA Goes Deep
description: Boulder, Colo.  AFTER years of spending our nations space budget building an orbiting space station of questionable utility, serviced by an operationally expensive space shuttle of unsafe design, NASA has set a new direction for the future of human spaceflight. Once again, we have our sights on the Moon ... and beyond. We are finally, bodily, going to make our way into space, this time to stay.

title: Competing for Fed Contracts Through Your PC
description: BURGETTSTOWN, Pa.

title: Eagerness and Some Resignation as Civil Union Law Takes Effect
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 19  Mark Rado and Degn Schubert could be forgiven for sounding a little jaded on Monday, as they waited with four other couples in the lobby of the Asbury Park Municipal and Police Complex.

title: They Are Linked by Their Genes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Behavior: More Children, Eating More Graham Crackers
description: Puppies do it. Chickens do it. Even preschoolers do it.

title: Call It Serendipity: A Missing Piece of Washingtons War Tent Is Found
description: For nearly a century, a large oval-shape linen tent where George Washington is believed to have slept during the Revolutionary War sat on display in Valley Forge, Pa., with a gaping hole in its roof.

title: The Claim: Mothers Heartburn Means a Hairy Newborn
description: THE FACTS It is an odd adage that has stuck around for ages: women who suffer heartburn during pregnancy will have babies with full heads of hair. But doctors have long shrugged it off.

title: Meet Kate, and Stick Around
description: WITH what they claim to be the worlds largest selection of beads, company officials at Shipwreck Beads near Seattle were not used to seeing customers abandon their online store in droves.

title: Nets Working to Find a Way to Trade Kidd
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 19  The Nets are more serious than ever about trading their star point guard, Jason Kidd, by Thursdays trading deadline, several Eastern Conference officials said Monday.

title: Topping the List: Health Care and Pay
description: WEEKS after the Democrats took control of Congress, important issues to small businesses, like the minimum wage and health care policy, top the agenda.

title: Avoiding an Audit: Its All in the Details
description: IF Americans kept a most-dreaded list, audit notices from the Internal Revenue Service would surely rank at or near the top.

title: Risks and Remedies: Supplements May Help Prevent Stress Fractures
description: Women who take vitamin D and calcium supplements, even for a short time, appear to lower their risk of stress fractures, researchers have found.

title: Officers at Whitestone Bridge Shoot at Stolen S.U.V.; Driver Escapes
description: A man who stole a sport utility vehicle at a car wash in Queens yesterday nearly hit two officers who tried to stop him as he drove up to the Whitestone Bridge toll plaza in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: A Journey Through Hell and Heaven, via Medieval Croatia
description: When Dialogos last performed in New York, in 2005, it was in Chant Wars, a joint program with Sequentia in which these two medieval music ensembles explored competing regional approaches to liturgical chant. On Sunday Dialogos turned up on its own in the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church to present Tondals Vision, a medieval Croatian church drama about what would today be called an out-of-body experience.

title: Whats on Tuesday Night
description: 10 P.M. (VH1) THE AGENCY They call it grooming. This new reality series sidles up to seven booking agents at the Wilhelmina Modeling Agency in Manhattan as they take the raw goods and mold them into some of the citys beautiful people. Its not always pretty.

title: Discontent in Guinea Nears Boiling Point
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 18  For most Guineans, the last straw came two months ago.

title: Dia Appoints a New Director: Next Stop, Manhattan
description: The Dia Art Foundation, after an eight-month search for a new director, has appointed Jeffrey Weiss, 48, currently head of the department of modern and contemporary art at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Bill to Aid Georgian Convicted of Sex Crime Stalls in Assembly
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 19  The second piece of legislation introduced with the intent of helping Genarlow Wilson, a former honor student and star athlete who is serving a 10-year prison sentence for having oral sex with a 15-year-old classmate, may be in trouble in the Georgia General Assembly.

title: North Africa Feared as Staging Ground for Terror
description: TUNIS  The plan, hatched for months in the arid mountains of North Africa, was to attack the American and British Embassies here. It ended in a series of gun battles in January that killed a dozen militants and left two Tunisian security officers dead.

title: Flame First, Think Later: New Clues to E-Mail Misbehavior
description: The emotional signs and social cues that guide our behavior during face-to-face interaction are absent when we sit alone at a keyboard. Often, the result is a problem recognized since the earliest days of the Internet: flaming, or sending a message that is taken as rude or embarrassing.

title: Playing Hot and Cold
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: British Bank Buys U.S.-Based Think Equity
description: Panmure Gordon, the British investment bank, confirmed on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Think Equity Partners, a United States investment bank specializing in telecommunications, media and technology, in a deal worth about $62 million. The deal for Think Equity, founded by two former Merrill Lynch bankers, will heighten Panmures ability to bring technology companies in the United States to the Alternative Investment Market, Londons junior market, The Financial Times reported.

title: Italy Wont Block Spanish Bid for a Stake in Telecom Italia
description: Just months after the Italian infrastructure minister, Antonio Di Pietro, blocked a Spanish company from buying the largest toll road company in Italy, he indicated Monday that he would not block Spanish acquisition of a large stake in Telecom Italia. Pirelli, which controls Telecom Italia through a holding company, Olimpia, said last week that it had held talks with Telefnica of Spain and that the Spanish company might buy a significant stake in Olimpia.

title: Volvo Drives Off With Nissan Diesel
description: The Swedish truck maker Volvo said on Tuesday it would take over Nissan Diesel Motor for $1.1 billion. Volvo, which currently owns 19 percent of Nissan Diesel, said it would acquire the rest of the stock for 540 yen a share ($4.51), a premium of 22 percent over Mondays closing price.

title: Vulcan Pours $4.6 Billion into Deal for Florida Rock
description: Vulcan Materials, the nations biggest producer of highway construction materials, will acquire Florida Rock Industries for $4.6 billion to add concrete-making capability in the Southeast. Florida Rock shareholders will receive cash and stock valued at $68.03 a share, 45 percent higher than the closing price on Friday, Birmingham, Ala.-based Vulcan said Monday. The payment will be 70 percent in cash, it said.

title: Barclays Predicts Slower Growth at Investment Bank
description: Barclays, which said on Tuesday that its second-half profit rose 41 percent to a record, predicted slower growth this year in the securities unit that contributed the most to the banks earnings for the last two years.

title: Russian Bank Closes in on $12 Billion Offering
description: Sberbank, Russias largest savings bank, was tallying the final orders on Monday from investors seeking entry to its $12 billion share sale, a deal that could become the biggest offering in Russian corporate history. The Financial Times reported that Sberbanks supervisory board would convene on Wednesday to decide pricing for the domestic offering of up to 3.5 million new shares. Sberbank management has so far sent conflicting signals on how it wants to price the issue, throwing the stock price into turmoil.

title: Krispy Kreme Refinances Debt
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said it refinanced its debt in a $160 million deal that should cut the companys interest costs. The company, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said it had borrowed $110 million to repay an existing $107 million balance on its existing credit deal, plus costs associated with the transaction. In addition, the company opened a $50 million revolving credit line.

title: Venture Capitalist Dies in Apparent Suicide
description: Todd Brooks, a venture capitalist who spent several years at the Mayfield Fund before leaving in 2003, died from an apparent suicide attempt, peHUB reported. He was 46 years old.

title: Bharti to Put Up $2.5 Billion in Venture With Wal-Mart
description: Indias Bharti Enterprises of India plans to invest up to $2.5 billion to set up a nationwide chain of supermarkets and retail shops in partnership with  Wal-Mart, a top executive at the Indian company said. The investment will be spread over the next eight years and create jobs for about 60,000 people, Bhartis joint managing director, Rajan B. Mittal, told reporters Monday. The company has planned an investment of $2 billion to $2.5 billion by 2015, Mr. Mittal said.

title: Exporting Silicon Valleys Lessons to Europe
description: Start-ups are no longer a rare species in Europe. Moreover, many of Europes new entrepreneurs are returning from the United States, where they learned the start-up culture in Silicon Valley and Route 128 around Boston. After the dot-com bust, the number of European start-ups in the computer and telecommunications sectors began growing again in 2003, according to the Center for European Economic Research, in Mannheim, Germany. And venture capital is pouring into start-ups, attracting about $970 million last year, the highest level since the dot-com boom in 2000.

title: Left Holding the Bag In the Land of Fast Food
American Airlines Buyout Talk Draws Skepticism
description: American Airlines is reportedly drawing takeover interest from British Airways and Goldman Sachs, but Breakingviews suggests there would be major legal obstacles to such a bid, and American would make a poor leveraged-buyout target anyway.

title: For Hedge Funds, a Friend in Europe
description: As lawmakers and regulators the world over call for increased scrutiny of the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry, the much-maligned investment vehicles seem to have at least one highly-placed official in their corner. In an interview with The Financial Times published Monday, Charlie McCreevy, the European Union internal market commissioner, rode to the defense of hedge funds and private equity groups.

title: Deere Adds Lesco to Landscape
description: Deere & Company, moving to bolster its John Deere Landscapes subsidiary, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Lesco of Cleveland, Ohio, for $132 million, or $14.50 a share. Lesco supplies consumable products like fertilizer and seed to lawn-maintenance professionals and golf course operators.

title: Visto Tops Up Haul With $35 Million
description: Still wrapped up in a hotly contested battle for market share that includes lawsuits against its key rivals, a mobile e-mail software developer, Visto, has extended its $51 million Series C funding by accepting an additional $35 million from Altitude Capital Partners. The new money builds on $280 million in existing funding raised over the past decade, spread out over eight rounds including a 2001 recapitalization.

title: Will Time Warner Cable Go Shopping?
description: With Time Warner Cable now an independent operator following the completion of Adelphia Communications reorganization, the company is viewed as a potential dealmaker, according to The Deal.com. The company, which is the cable unit of Time Warner, expects to list on the New York Stock Exchange as early as March 1, which would give it a currency to pursue deals.

title: Venture Firm OVP Tops Off New Fund
description: OVP Venture Partners, an early-stage venture firm, announced over the weekend it had enlarged its latest fund to $250 million, bringing in an additional $43 million since its first close last May, The Red Herring reported.

title: Many Are Eager to See Data on Chrysler
description: As JPMorgan Chase prepares an investment book to circulate to potential bidders of Chrysler, American and foreign auto companies, private equity groups and investment banks are chomping at the bit to inspect the struggling companys financial data. Everybody will take a look, a senior executive at a global car company, which will be eyeballing the book, told The New York Times.

title: A Clash of Cultures, Averted
description: When Bank of America announced its $35 billion acquisition of MBNA in summer 2005, many people questioned whether it would work. MBNA, a stand-alone credit-card giant, took pride in its fast-paced and entrepreneurial spirit, its freewheeling spending and a secretive corporate culture that seemed more like a cult. So far, Bank of America, the acquisition-hungry giant, has let that stand, though it was not easy.

title: British Sterling | Six Newly Minted Design Stars
description:
Londons fashion standing can fluctuate as much as Tony Blairs approval rating. (Consider the
many lives of Giles Deacon.) But after a few years of being relegated to the periphery, the British capital is back in favor with a slew of talented new designers.

title: Yellow Pages Picks Up Aliant
description: The Yellow Pages Group said it would will pay 330 million Canadian dollars ($283 million) to acquire full ownership of Aliant Directory Services, an Atlantic Canadian telephone pages directory company partly owned by Yellow Pages of Montreal. the Yellow Pages Group, Canadas dominant telephone directories publisher, said Monday it had signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire the Aliant directory business, which is owned 87.14 percent by the Halifax-based Bell Aliant Regional Communications Income Fund and the rest by Yellow Pages Income Fund.

title: Satellite Radio Deal Puts Focus on Regulators
description: After Sirius and XM, the United States two satellite radio services, announced plans Monday to merge in a $13 billion deal, speculation quickly turned to how regulators would react to such a combination. The proposal brought immediate comparisons to the proposed merger of satellite television broadcasters EchoStar and DirecTV, which regulators rejected four years ago. But the chief executive of Sirius, Mel Karmazin, wasted no time asserting that this was completely different, because those two firms had only one chief rival, cable television.

title: Shire to Buy U.S. Partner New River for $2.6 Billion
description: Shire, Britains third-largest drugmaker, agreed to buy New River Pharmaceuticals of Radford, Va., for $2.6 billion to gain the rights to the attention-deficit drug Vyvanse. Shire, which makes a competing drug, Adderall XR, said it would pay $64 a share, a 9.7 percent premium to the New Rivers closing price on Friday. Shire plans to raise $800 million in a share sale to fund the acquisition.

title: Warner Music Tries, Tries Again with EMI
description: Will EMI Group and Warner Music Group, who are becoming the Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton of the music industry, finally get hitched? EMI said on Tuesday that it had received a takeover approach from Warner Music, less than a year after the companies abandoned efforts to buy each other.

title: The Get
description: That old standby, retooled.

title: In-Store:Haute Concept
description: For a decade, colette has curated the right bank stuff. Sandra Ballentine stops by.

title: The New Collectibles
description: To have and to hold on to.

title: Theres a Thought
description: JD, among many others, makes a strong case for Little Miss Sunshine on the Baggers blog.

title: Readers Respond to Helping People Help Themselves
description: Augustus P. Lowell, Durham, N.H.: Although the arguments presented make sense overall I must take exception to the implication that paying down the national debt with our budget surplus would have been a better use than giving the money back to the taxpayers.

title: Charting Your Way
description: Kris Tapley at InContention, who has some kind of Ph.D. in Oscarologyh, tracks the viscissitudes of the best picture fight.

title: No Suspense, Just Hardware
description: Richard Corliss of Time magazine finds the elusive Metallica angle while doing a bit of hagiography on Ennio Morricone, the composer and honorary Oscaree.

title: A Look Behind the Curtain
description: Mary McNamara at the Los Angeles Times pulls back the blankets on all of the Oscar campaigning. The Bagger recognized a lot of people he thought were his friends, but it turns out, they are paid to have lunch with him and talk up movies. Who knew?

title: A Bit Beside the Point
description: The Reeler points out that a lot of the famous quotations being used to market the Oscars came from movies that did not fare so well at the awards.

title: Foreign Films  Explained
description: RiskyBiz points us to a foreign films Oscar primer in the Boston Herald. The paper should get a public service award, because the Bagger has discovered, after talking to quite a few members of the Academy, that most of them have seen only one or two of the movies.

title: Full Tilt Boogie
description: The Bagger doesnt usually run his day planner in the blog, but with just days before the Big Event, he wants people to know his 10/20 at all times. He will have a breakfast with a movie muckety muck. Lets just say hes a guy with some skin in the game next Sunday who, if his movie is crowned, will add it to the one worn by his lead character. Then the Bagger is heading to a Robert Altman tribute at the Majestic Theater, one of a number that are underway, before finishing out the night by watching Crazy Love, the documentary about toxic attraction that Dan Klores made and then sold at Sundance. In between time, he will pack up the asbestos tux and his Ouija board in preparation for the trip to L.A. tomorrow.

title: Lawyer Who Inspired the Chinn Up Joins Centerview
description: Adam Chinn, a partner at the law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, who focused on financial-services mergers and executive compensation issues, is joining Centerview Partners, a recently opened investment banking boutique, as a founding partner, Centerview said. A partner at Wachtell Lipton since 1994, Mr. Chinn has helped many top executives beef up their employment agreements, giving rise to the term the Chinn-up. Centerview was founded last year by Stephen Crawford, formerly co-president of Morgan Stanley, Blair Effron, formerly vice chairman at UBS, and Robert Pruzan, formerly president of Wasserstein Perella.

title: Mardi Gras, Indestructible
description: On Mardi Gras Day, laissez le bon temps rouler: There are some things in New Orleans that even Hurricane Katrina and the ineptness of the government cant ruin, says the editorial page of New Orleanss The Times-Picayune. When you lose your home, your neighbors and your most treasured possessions, the ache stays with you for a long time. But as we work to rebuild what was taken in the storm, it is a comfort to realize that no hurricane, no inept bureaucracy, no self-involved politician can change the wealth of our culture and traditions. The Times-Pic editorial also attempts to explain the local affection for Mardi Gras to tut-tutting Americans:

title: Running Out of Matches in a Dark Place
description: The polls close today as the Bagger struggled mightily  actually, he just made a few phone calls, but that sounds too easy  to bring some clarity to the Oscar race. With less than a week to go, its hard to get all the frogs in one wheelbarrow and get them moving toward Sunday night.

title: Trend Spotting
description: Charlotte Rudge reports hot off the runway.

title: The Hemp Vote
description: It is high time for bipartisan cooperation.

title: A Different Outcome on Mt. Hood: Should Locator Beacons Be Required?
description: The bodies of Brian Hall and Jerry Nikko Cooke  two of the three climbers who went missing on Oregons imposing Mt. Hood in December, have yet to be found. The remains of their climbing companion, Kelly James, were located in part by tracing cell phone signals hed made, but only days later. He was found dead in a snow cave near the summit.

title: And Jebs Candidate Is?
description: Now that President Bushs sister, Dorothy Bush Koch, is planning to be co-host of a fund-raiser for Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and a Republican presidential aspirant, speculation is beginning to focus on the intentions of another presidential sibling, Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida. Mr. Bush has decided not to enter the 2008 race. But his backing would be a hot commodity for any other Republican running this year.

title: The Week Ahead
description: With Congress out of session  and you can bet certain senators running for president are quite happy about that  this is a week for fund-raising, campaigning and one gathering of potentially high interest. The Democratic presidential contenders are appearing Wednesday in Carson City, Nev., for a forum sponsored by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; George Stephanopoulos of ABC News will be asking them questions.

title: But Wait, Senator, About the War
description: Lawmakers have fled Washington for a Congressional recess (or, as they prefer to call it, a district work period). But the debate over the Iraq war is following many of them home.

title: 2008: Romney Defends Stem Cell Stance
description: In an interview with The Associated Press, Mitt Romney defended his opposition to embryonic stem cell research despite the fact that his wife suffers from multiple sclerosis, a disease that some scientists believe could be cured with stem cells. He is confident that existing stem cell lines and adult stem cells have just as great scientific promise. The former Massachusetts governor has said that the stem cell debate was the impetus for his conversion to an anti-abortion position. He often describes a meeting with Harvard researchers, saying he bristled at the idea that destroying fertilized eggs after a few weeks posed no moral issue.

title: A Merger J.P. Morgan Would Love
description: The proposed Sirius-XM satellite radio merger would get rid of what J.P. Morgan used to view as excessive competition  the kind that drives up costs but not revenues. If it goes through, the combined company can divert itself to luring listerners without having to pay through the roof for rights in order to keep them from the competition.

title: Franco Impressed With Milledges Attitude
description: Its easy to forget that Lastings Milledge is still 21 years old (sort of like how its amazing that Britney Spears is only 25) but I remember meeting him back in October 2005, before an Arizona fall league game and before his image needed polishing.

title: Time for Democrats to Let Go of the Netroots?
description: The resignations of Amanda Marcotte and Melissa McEwan from the John Edwards presidential campaign havent quite meant the end of LAffair Marcotte, as the flap has now percolated into George Wills Washington Post column. Will, like some Catholic liberals earlier this month, takes issue not with the bloggers but rather with the smarmy insincerity in Edwardss statement that it was never their intention to malign anyones faith, and I take them at their word. Will writes:

title: Jeter Responds
description: Derek Jeter spoke with reporters today in the dugout before the Yankees morning workout. He would not talk about sleep overs or dinners with Alex Rodriguez. The two are good teammates, he said, and left it at that.

title: Al Qaedas Stunning Resurrection
description: Remember when President Bush said of Osama Bin Laden, Wanted: Dead or Alive? Five and a half years after 9/11, the answer  for Bin Ladens organization if not for the man himself  is definitively alive, says Bruce Hoffman on the op-ed page of the Los Angeles Times. Al Qaeda is not on the run but on the march, Hoffman, a senior fellow at West Points Combating Terrorism Center, writes. He adds, Rather than being degraded to the point that it can threaten only softer, more accessible targets like hotels and mass transit, Al Qaeda is very much sticking with its classic playbook of simultaneous, spectacular strikes against even hardened objectives. In other words, we have more to fear from this resilient organization, not less.

title: $2.5 Million Homes
description: A Victorian country estate in Georgia, a golf-community home in Scottsdale, Ariz., and a Spanish-style cottage on Catalina Island.

title: Reflecting on a Community
description: In Brooklyn, the Starrett City apartment complex is being sold and residents are watchful.

title: Office Politics
description: Shortly before George E. Pataki left office, the state sold the governors office in Manhattan, at 633 Third Avenue.

title: Joost Reaches Video Deal With Viacom
description: Viacom, engaged in a public battle with top Internet online video service YouTube, said on Tuesday it had agreed to offer its videos to Joost, the Internet video service created by the founders of Skype.

title: Has Londons Real Estate Market Reached a Top?
description: Is it time to cash out of London commercial real estate? Prognosticators can mull over the latest pair of high-profile sales in that red-hot market. According to The Financial Times, Tishman Speyers latest sale is Goldman Sachs headquarters on Fleet Street, currently priced at 350 million pounds ($685 million), up from the 280 million pounds it paid in 2005. Separately, Merrill Lynch is considering up to four bids for its European headquarters, to the tune of 600 million pounds.

title: Giorgio in Nighttown: Milan Fashion
description: There is no better way to start the Italian shows than with 600 Giorgio Armani outfits. Last evening, Mr. Armani  dont you think he deserves to be called Mister?  invited 1,500 people to his retrospective at the Triennale. Ive never seen so many high-wattage Italians in one room, and I dont blame the paparazzi for looking bored when my turn came to pose with Mr. Armani in the receiving line. Many times as a journalist Ive looked at an Elegant Nobody clogging the line and thought, Get a move on, lady.

title: Casino of France Sells Smart & Final Stake to Apollo
description: The French retailer Casino said on Tuesday it would sell its 55 percent stake in the food and restaurant supply retailer Smart & Final to help it meet its debt reduction goals.

title: Romneys Ad Going Up
description: Mitt Romneys first television commercial touting his presidential candidacy is set to be broadcast in several critical states beginning Wednesday.

title: Its Election Day
description: At least, thats the case in part of Brooklyn, where a special election is behing held today for the seat on the City Council vacated by Yvette Clarke, who won a congressional seat last fall. (Theres also a Council race on Staten Island  see below.)

title: Two Nascar Angles
description: I think this is the first time Ive linked to a story from the IHT opinion pages on this blog  but this one in tomorrows paper is a very relevant one. The question is, does this show what F1 is up against in the U.S., or is F1 looked at differently because it is NOT a homegrown, national series like Nascar? On the other hand, you might want to check out the story we have in another section of the same paper for a different Nascar angle.

title: Bonds Arrives With Less of an Entourage
description: Barry Bonds arrived today at Giants spring training camp in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: The notMac Challenge
description: Apples dot Mac service (www.mac.com) offers a virtual online storage disk, an e-mail account, synchronization (of bookmarks and address books, for example) between multiple Macs, and so on. Its a great service, but its expensive$100 a yearand the storage is puny compared with modern, free services.

title: A Fungus Brings Dinosaurs Fate to Frogs
description: At the end of a report on National Public Radios All Things Considered program over the weekend, the host, Debbie Elliot, asked Dr. Joe Mendelson, an organizer of a project called Amphibian Ark, what it meant to humanity that roughly one-third of the planets 6,000 species of frogs, toads, salamanders, newts and worm-like caecilians may now be on the brink of extinction because of a disease spreading like wildfire among them.

title: At the Border
description: More agents, increased patrols and new walls and fences have made U.S. borders harder to cross.

title: And Now Some Good News from the AAAS: Chocolate in Medicine, Tractors in Space
description: I just spent five days at the Woodstock of science, the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The theme at this years meeting, in San Francisco, was sustainability  not the most sprightly topic. But in between the lectures on environmental degradation, there were some cheerier discussions. A couple of my favorites:

title: Libby Trial Arguments
description: The perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., former chief aide to Vice President Dick Cheney, isnt about his memory losses or about being made a scapegoat, a federal prosecutor told jurors today as closing arguments began.

title: NBCs Outgoing Chair Sees a Sale Down the Road
description: Less than two weeks ago, General Electrics chairman and chief executive Jeffrey Immelt called reports that he was pondering selling off NBC Universal as more or less made-up drivel. This week, Bob Wright, the outgoing chairman of that division, is saying something a bit different. When Fortune magazines Tim Arango asked him about the whether hes be surprised if, in three to five years, NBC Universal were not a part of G.E., he said:

title: Spitzer: Still a Steamroller
description: It has been a challenging two weeks for Gov. Eliot Spitzer, given the Democratic-controlled Assemblys decision to defy him and pick one of their own to be comptroller, and hints from the Republican-controlled state Senate that it would block some of Mr. Spitzers senior appointments.But today, Mr. Spitzer  who was speaking before a convention of town and village executives  sounded upbeat about relations with the Legislature, and about his chances to move forward on an ambitious agenda. Asked if he still considered himself a steamroller, Mr. Spitzer said were putting my foot to the pedal. He also noted that around Valentines Day, the Republican leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, had given him roses.

title: Memories of the Koch Administration
description: In what is probably the last Valentine feature of the season, City Hall News interviews 20 political power couples. Heres a sample, from the interview with City Councilman David Yassky and Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, who met in city government when Ed Koch was mayor:

title: Should Buyout Firms Check Out Kroger?
description: Private equity firms have reportedly been circling the British supermarket chain J. Sainsbury, considering a takeover bid that would be Europes biggest leveraged buyout ever. Could supermarkets in the United States draw a similar crowd? Perhaps, Bear Stearns analyst Robert Summers suggests. Among American food and drug retailers, the major grocery chains are the likeliest candidates for a buyout, he wrote in a note Tuesday. By his math, however, only Kroger  the No. 1 chain in the United States  could provide enough profit to a potential buyer, without making heroic assumptions in terms of margins or exit multiples.

title: Johnson Leaves Hospital
description: Senator Tim Johnsons office just announced that he was discharged from the George Washington University Hospital last Friday. He is continuing his recovery at a private rehabilitation facility, which his office declined to name, citing privacy.

title: Tales From the Caremark Files
description: There is nothing like a legal fight to draw out the inner workings of the normally secretive dealmaking process. TheStreet.coms Melissa Davis examined the court filings in the battle over Caremark Rxs proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS and came up with two major revelations that seemed especially disturbing to the judge in the case. Express Scripts, which has made a hostile offer for Caremark, wants the court to block the CVS merger. The judge expects to rule on the matter next week.

title: Another Brickbat at Ground Zero
description: As Charles V. Bagli of The Times reported last week, Gov. Eliot Spitzer has had a change of heart about the Freedom Tower. Today he made it official, appearing at ground zero with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, where they said they were going ahead with construction of the $3 billion tower.

title: Of Britney and Volatility
description: Who knew that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg followed the travails of the head-shaving pop star Britney Spears?

title: The Road to Spottswoode
description: Greetings from sunny Napa Valley! For the last few days its been bright, clear and in the 70s and 80s here. But having endured the Jet Blue meltdown last week  8 hours in the terminal, 1 hours on the tarmac  I do feel Ive earned it. Now, weve all read about, and some of us have lived through, the Jet Blue horrors, but heres a story about why people liked Jet Blue in the first place.

title: From Hipster to Hasidim
description: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, is widely known for his humorous  some would say corny  quips. He confirmed that reputation this morning at Prospect Park, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn and others announced that Kate Wollman Rink will be replaced by a $39 million Lakeside Center recreation building with two ice-skating rinks, to be completed by 2010.

title: Reasonable Precaution or Unreasonable Demand?
description: From my experiences in restaurants and the comments that come into this blog, its become clear to me that theres a lot of tension between restaurateurs and diners, an enormous disparity between the kinds of rules and procedures that restaurants deem necessary and those that their customers deem fitting.

title: South Africa Calls BBC Racist, Declares Country Soccer-Safe
description: The African National Congress, the ruling party of South Africa under president Thabo Mbeki, and BBC World, the BBCs 24-hour international news channel, are engaged in a bit of a war of words at the moment  stemming, it seems, from a recent BBC World report that described Johannesburg as succumbing to the ravages of violent crime.

title: Bernies Gone, Get Used to It
description: The first full-squad workout came and went today without Bernie Williams, who is not returning Joe Torres calls anymore.

title: Sending dollars, saving lives
description: Readers have asked how to donate to Carters international efforts. Here are three easy methods:

title: Blogtalk: Political Geographic
description: In the earliest start to a presidential contest in memory, an ever-expanding list of dreamers have declared, stumped and jockeyed for position. But, with just under a year before any primary vote is cast, the blogs have few benchmarks of consequence this far out  outside of the candidates positions on Iraq. On other matters, like field zoologists, bloggers are taking notes of every move, making predictions of who might win the latest skirmish or score a point here and there.

title: John Edwards in 2004 and 2007
description: In comparing John Edwards's 2004 and 2007 campaigns, the biggest difference is the candidate himself.

title: Gentleness Counts
description: Dining columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, demonstrates the art of making pudding.

title: Dumping on Carter (and Me)
description: Over at Huffington Post, Jay Winsten of Harvard savages me with a wet noodle for my columns on Jimmy Carter and health. Winstens main complaint seems to be that I give Carter too much credit; perhaps Winsten shares the sourness toward Carter that way too many people feel. Winsten writes:

title: Merck Ends Push for Mandatory Shots for Girls
description: Merck said Tuesday that it would stop trying to get state legislatures to mandate the use of its new cervical cancer vaccine. The vaccine is aimed at a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.

title: Life on a Magazine Crew
description: Current and former door-to-door magazine sellers talk about the industry, which is rife with abuse.

title: The Wonderful: Jil Sander
description: Stefano Tonchi, my colleague at the Times Magazine, was the first person backstage to congratulate Raf Simons after his Jil Sander show. I dont know what Stefano told Simons. No one is more surprised and touched by whats happened to him in the past 18 months than Raf Simons. I told him that he had everyones attention. Thats how it seemed to me during the show, and thats what I ended up writing in the paper.

title: City Council: Eugene and Ignizio
description: In the special election in Brooklyn, Dr. Mathieu Eugene was elected to the City Council, becoming the Councils first Haitian-born member. He will take the 40th District seat vacated by Yvette D. Clarke after her election to Congress in November. She had endorsed him over nine other candidates on the ballot.

title: Afghan Suicide Bomber Wounds 6 Soldiers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 20  A suicide bomber disguised as a doctor blew himself up Tuesday morning at the opening of a hospital ward built by American forces in eastern Afghanistan, wounding six American soldiers as they tackled him at the entrance, officials said.

title: Warner Music Makes Another Bid for EMI
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  The EMI Group, the British music company that produces artists such as Coldplay and the Beatles, said today that it had received a new takeover approach from Warner Music Group, the latest episode in a seven-year merger saga that includes four failed attempts.

title: Rangers Push and Shove, and Then They Fall
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 20  In their seventh meeting with the Devils, their frustrations mounting, the Rangers threw a little nastiness into their cross-river rivalry Tuesday night, trying to knock the Devils off their confident, stubborn game.

title: No Response From Williams
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 20  The Yankees first full-squad workout came and went Tuesday without an appearance by Bernie Williams, who has not returned Manager Joe Torres most recent phone calls. Torre said there was nothing new he could tell Williams, who wants to be guaranteed a place on the 25-man roster.

title: A River Helps Harvick Flow
description: There really is a river. It flows through the hills of Davidson County in North Carolina. When Kevin Harvick talks about his maturity  his relative maturity  that maybe led to the epic victory at Daytona on Sunday, he dates it back to the river.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening Soon

title: Colorful Photographs of the Inanimate That Run the Alphabetical Gamut
description: A is for apple. B is for boy. C is for cat. Its really that simple in Neil Winokurs portfolio of 26 supersaturated color portraits of generic objects (and an occasional living being): one photograph for every letter of the alphabet, from A to Z.

title: Court Endorses Laws Curbs on Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  A divided federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld a new law stripping federal judges of authority to review foreign prisoners challenges to their detention at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Spitzer Makes Switch Official: He Supports Freedom Tower
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he supported going ahead with construction of the Freedom Tower at ground zero, making official his change of mind about a project that he once called a white elephant.

title: The World of Black Theater Becomes Ever Bigger
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 18  Urban theater  or what has been called over the years inspirational theater, black Broadway, gospel theater and the chitlin circuit  has been thriving for decades, selling out some of the biggest theaters across the country and grossing millions of dollars a year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the proposed merger of Sirius and XM, two satellite radio companies, referred incorrectly to advertising sales by XM. The company carries ads on 4 of its 73 music channels; it is not free of advertising.

title: Queens: Man Sought After Sex Attack
description: A 13-year-old girl was sexually assaulted on her way home from school in Hollis on Friday, the police said yesterday, and they are investigating whether the same man exposed himself to three youngsters blocks away earlier that day. No arrests had been made as of last evening. The teenager was attacked at 110th Avenue and 195th Street about 4:30 p.m., the police said. She was taken to a hospital, they said. Two hours earlier, at 109th Road and 190th Place, a man exposed himself to two 9-year-old girls and an 11-year-old boy, the police said.

title: What You Get for ... $2.5 Million
description: Sautee Nacooche, Ga.

title: Drug Gets a Cameo in a Film Backed by Its Maker
description: INNERSTATE, a documentary about three people coping with disabling chronic illness, may be coming to a theater near you. If so, admission will be free, courtesy of the drug maker that produced the film.

title: In the Land of Flamenco, Civil Wars Buried Bones
description: Californians learn not to think about the San Andreas fault. Otherwise, who could summon the nerve to walk out the front door? In Spain, an entire nation has learned how not to address a historical fault line that shifted just 70 years ago, setting one half of the country against the other in a murderous furor that paved the way for 30 years of military dictatorship. Spain, the 19th-century writer ngel Ganivet wrote, is a cage full of madmen all suffering from the same mana: their inability to put up with one another. The Spanish Civil War and Francos regime seemed to confirm the thesis.

title: A Pacific Getaway Where Many Return
description: With its sun-drenched days, gentle trade winds and balmy tropical nights, Hawaii has long been desired for its exotic ambience. Visitors flock to the shores of six main islands dotting the Pacific some 2,500 miles west of the continental United States.

title: Suit Over Fees for Inmates Phone Calls Is Revived
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20  The State Court of Appeals said on Tuesday that a lower court must hear a suit alleging that the state had illegally placed exorbitant charges on collect phone calls made by prison inmates.

title: Colleges New Appeal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Mecca Accord, Clouded Horizons
description: BERLIN, Feb. 20  With Iran steadily gaining power in the Middle East, the United States recently made a strategic decision to encourage Saudi Arabia to take a more active role in diplomacy in the region. Two weeks ago, the Saudis took a bold step, mediating an accord between warring Palestinian factions whose battles in Gaza had left more than 100 dead.

title: Exxon to Abandon a Big Investment in Qatar
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 20  Exxon Mobil announced on Tuesday that it would abandon one of its biggest investments ever, a project with Qatars state-run oil and gas company to produce clean-burning diesel from natural gas.

title: On His First Day, Bonds Digs In
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 20  On his first day of spring training, Barry Bonds spent five hours hugging teammates, hitting 400-foot homers and modeling message T-shirts.

title: Same Leader, Same Hard Feelings
description: SACRAMENTO, Feb. 20  The organizers of the Tour of California cycling race designed this years course with the hope that each days stage would produce a change atop the standings.

title: Kraft Chief Outlines Turnaround Strategy
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 20  If you have trouble remembering the last time you dug into a box of Velveeta or mixed up a glass of Tang, you can appreciate the challenges facing Irene B. Rosenfeld, the chief executive and chairman of Kraft Foods.

title: Elliott Baker, a Screenwriter and Novelist, Dies at 84
description: Elliott Baker, a screenwriter and novelist whose first book, A Fine Madness, was made into a Hollywood film starring Sean Connery, died on Feb. 9 in Los Angeles. He was 84 and had lived in Los Angeles for many years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review yesterday about The Secret of Mme. Bonnards Bath, at the Kirk Theater on West 42nd Street, misstated the playwrights surname. He is Israel Horovitz, not Horowitz.

title: Storm May Cost JetBlue $30 Million
description: The chief executive of JetBlue Airways, David G. Neeleman, said yesterday that last weeks storm that stranded thousands of passengers might cost the company $30 million.

title: One Trial, but Two Visions
description: Following are some of the main points made yesterday in closing arguments in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney:

title: Some Employers Are Offering Free Drugs
description: For years, employers have been pushing their workers to pay more for health care, raising premiums and out-of-pocket medical expenses in an effort to save money for the company and force workers to seek only the most necessary care.

title: Viacom Deal Will Allow Its TV Clips on Internet
description: Fear not, MTV fans. Episodes of Laguna Beach and The Real World will soon be back on the Internet, free of charge. But this time, viewing is on Viacoms terms.

title: Tougher Tactics Deter Migrants at U.S. Border
description: SAN LUIS RO COLORADO, Mexico  For 10 years, Eduardo Valenzuela has been crossing the border illegally near Yuma, Ariz., trekking over desert scrub and hopping a freight train to get back to his job with a construction company in Phoenix.
