The clandestine trip has become an annual ritual for him, as he goes home each winter to see his children.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a dispute over a Bush administration plan to auction off all landing rights at La Guardia Airport referred incorrectly in some copies to one aspect of the plan. The administration has proposed maintaining a cap on the total number of flights into La Guardia  not lifting it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday about record television ratings for the recent friendly match between the United States and Mexico in Glendale, Ariz., referred imprecisely to the viewership of the Spanish-language telecast. It was more than six million, not more than two million. Another report in the roundup, about a reality TV show called Sueo MLS that will appear on Univisions sports magazine show, misstated the name of the show. It is Republica Deportiva, not Republica Deportivo.

title: Back From Sicily, Bearing Olive Oil
description: Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, the owners of Frankies 457 Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, right, and Frankies Spuntino on the Lower East Side, went shopping for oil last year  in Sicily. After tasting many varieties, they found a small family producer that could supply enough mellow oil from organic nocellara del Belice olives for them to sell tins of it with their own label.

title: Israel: Police Say Tip Thwarts Suicide Attack
description: Acting on a tip, the police arrested a Palestinian suspected of planning a suicide bombing in the Tel Aviv area, the authorities said. The police set up roadblocks around Tel Aviv and conducted an intensive search, arresting the Palestinian, identified as Omar Abu Rob, at an apartment in the suburb of Bat Yam. He led the police to the nearby city of Rishon Letzion, where they said he had hidden explosives for the attack. Several men suspected of helping of him were also arrested.

title: A Living Minimum Wage (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hell Take Manhattan (or Chunk of Midtown)
description: The day after Harry Macklowe, the maverick real estate investor and developer, completed a record-breaking $7.25 billion transaction to buy all but one of the buildings in the Midtown Manhattan portfolio of Equity Office Properties, he called one of the citys top commercial brokers.

title: Home Depot Profit Falls as Wal-Mart Reports a Rebound
description: The honeymoon is over for Home Depots new chief executive.

title: 4 Salvadorans Killed in Way That Evokes 80s Conflict
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20  A grisly quadruple killing in a rural part of Guatemala on Monday in which three Salvadoran lawmakers and their driver were shot and their bodies burned may be a sign that the ghosts of the bitter civil wars that raged through Central America in the 1980s still linger.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about Daddys Little Girls misstated the relationship between the hero and the caretaker of his children, who dies. The caretaker is the mother of the heros ex-wife, not his mother.

title: Record Loan Losses at a British Bank
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  The British bank Barclays reported on Tuesday that its securities unit had record earnings last year, but the banks overall results were marred by its biggest write-down ever for loan losses.

title: Patience Turns Milk Into a Foolproof Treat for Dessert
description: WHEN it comes to desserts made of sweetened milk or cream, definitions are more difficult to come by than techniques. For this article, Im going to say that custards are desserts thickened by eggs, and puddings are those thickened by just about anything else.

title: Canada: Gateses Join in Aids Vaccine Search
description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation pledged $119 million for an AIDS research center in Canada to develop a safe AIDS vaccine within a decade. Appearing with Mr. Harper in Ottawa, Mr. Gates said his foundation would contribute $24 million to the project. Mr. Harper was criticized last August when he declined to attend a global AIDS conference in Toronto that featured Bill Clinton and the Gateses.

title: Single Bullet, Single Gunman
description: THE ability to use advanced forensics and minuscule traces of DNA to solve crimes, even cold cases decades old, has turned many Americans into armchair sleuths seeking to solve the unexpected deaths of people like Princess Diana and Anna Nicole Smith. But sometimes, old-fashioned evidence is as useful in solving puzzles as anything under a nuclear microscope.

title: Despite Spitzer Letter, Skepticism About Casino
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Feb. 20  If anyone should be excited about the turn of events this week in the long-running struggle for a casino, it is Alan Barrish, a gambling enthusiast and a product of the once-thriving hospitality industry in the Catskills (his father was a headwaiter at Kutshers Country Club, his mother a waitress).

title: That Sinking Feeling
description: How do you know when its time to improve the countrys roads and bridges, and the water systems and power grids that the United States relies upon? There have been plenty of warning signs: spiking traffic congestion and spectacular blackouts. But at what point does the issue move from the province of anxious engineers to an outright national priority?

title: Half a Shield Is Better Than None
description: Chicago

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Sunday about catcher Todd Pratts presence in the Yankees spring-training camp referred imprecisely to a jubilant playoff scene when Pratt was with the Mets in 1999. Pratt was running the bases when he rushed over to hoist his teammate Robin Ventura after Ventura helped the Mets win Game 5 of the National League Championship Series with a hit that became known as a grand-slam single. Pratt did not rush out of the dugout.

title: Europeans Agree to Cut Emissions Sharply if U.S. and Others Follow Suit
description: PARIS, Feb. 20  Seeking to persuade other nations to curb greenhouse gas emissions, European Union ministers pledged Tuesday to raise their own targets if industrialized countries like the United States made similar efforts.

title: U.S. Official Admits to Big Delay in Revamping No-Fly Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The federal takeover of checking passenger names against terrorist watch lists, a top priority for aviation officials since the 2001 terrorist attacks, is not expected to be complete until 2010, more than five years behind schedule, a top Department of Homeland Security official acknowledged on Tuesday.

title: Somalia Plan Adopted
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 20  The Security Council on Tuesday authorized the dispatch of an African Union peacekeeping force to Somalia to help stabilize the country so a United Nations operation can take over in six months.

title: Cleaner Coal Is Attracting Some Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Within the next few years, power companies are planning to build about 150 coal plants to meet growing electricity demands. Despite expectations that global warming rules are coming, almost none of the plants will be built to capture the thousands of tons of carbon dioxide that burning coal spews into the atmosphere.

title: Two M.L.S. Teams Line Up to Play, Ready or Not
description: D.C. United and the Houston Dynamo were the first Major League Soccer teams to open spring training, which is a good thing. They are also the first league teams to engage in meaningful competition, which is probably not a good thing.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: New National Endowment Awards

title: Bird Flu Outbreak Shuts Farms Near Moscow
description: Farms and markets in the suburbs of Moscow were shut down by outbreaks of the avian flu over the weekend in a sign that the virus was moving westward along migratory bird routes, as it did last winter.

title: Bonds Is the Fall Guy of Spring
description: Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: California: Transfer of Prisoners Is Ruled Illegal
description: A judge ruled that Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers plan to transfer inmates to other states to ease overcrowding was illegal. The judge, Gail D. Ohanesian of Sacramento County Superior Court, sided with two unions representing prison workers and invalidated contracts to move inmates. Mr. Schwarzenegger, defending his plan, promised a swift appeal in federal court. The ruling stems from a dispute over an emergency program established by the governor in October to help address a federal decision ordering California to solve its prison problems or face rulings for the release of inmates. Judge Ohanesian acknowledged that the prison crowding was a crisis but said it was not the type of circumstance generally covered by the Emergency Services Act, the law cited by the governor when he established the plan.

title: In Pakistan, Student Sit-In in Defense of Mosques
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 17  For more than three weeks, 200 female students from an Islamic seminary, veiled in black and armed with sticks, have staged a sit-in at a nearby childrens library in the capital to protest the governments demolition of two illegally built mosques.

title: Nissan Is Offering Buyouts at 2 Tennessee Factories
description: As stagnant sales in the United States end a six-year streak of record profits, the Japanese automaker Nissan is offering buyouts to workers at two plants in Tennessee.

title: In Milan, Raf Simons Sends a Message to Paris
description: MILAN, Feb. 20  On Tuesday a little-known Belgian designer named Raf Simons had the full attention of the fashion world.

title: Mistrial in Malpractice Case After Defendants Aid Juror
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20  A mistrial was declared on Tuesday in a medical malpractice case brought by the head football coach at the University of Notre Dame after a juror collapsed and the defendants, two doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital, rushed to help him.

title: American Faces Charges in Qaeda Case
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 20  A thin and weakened 28-year-old American who the government says was captured last month in Kenya after joining Islamic terrorists fighting in Somalia appeared on Tuesday in federal court here to face charges of conspiring to use an unconventional weapon and receiving military training from Al Qaeda.

title: Warner Music Makes Another Bid for EMI
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  The EMI Group, the British music company that produces artists such as Coldplay and the Beatles, said on Tuesday that it had received a new takeover approach from Warner Music Group, the latest episode in a seven-year merger effort that includes four failed attempts.

title: Island Paradise, With a Few Caveats
description: Questions about real estate in the Caribbean can often be simplified by answering the following question: Are you a belonger or a nonbelonger?

title: Britain to Pull 1,600 Troops Out of Iraq, Blair Says
description: LONDON, Feb. 21  In sharp contrast to the American troop buildup in Baghdad, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain announced today that up to 1,600 of the roughly 7,100 British troops in southern Iraq will begin withdrawing in coming months.

title: An Opera by Verdi That Needs Name Tags
description: The sun does not shine on Simon Boccanegra. Its heroine, Amelia, does share a sunrise with the Metropolitan Operas gaping Act I garden scene, and a little light filters through windows elsewhere, but gloom is the order of the day in this formidable if largely unlovable product of Verdis middle years.

title: Reviving a Barrie Fantasy Not Called Peter Pan
description: The adventures of Peter Pan have flitted across many pages, stages and movie screens in the century since he first sprang from the peculiar imagination of J. M. Barrie. But recently the sad, singular life of the man who created Peter has snatched a sliver of the media spotlight, thanks to the movie Finding Neverland, a gauzy biography of Barrie starring Johnny Depp, in his winsome pallor, as the novelist, playwright and lifelong yearner after a youthful idyll.

title: Delphi Selling a Unit
description: Delphi, the largest auto parts supplier to General Motors, intends to sell its interiors business to a billionaire industrialist, Ira L. Rennert, as part of an effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

title: The Mononym Platform
description: Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Japans Central Bank Raises Key Lending Rate
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 21  The Bank of Japan, the nations central bank, raised its key benchmark overnight borrowing rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 0.5 percent, on Wednesday, citing signs of an expanding economy.

title: City Council Gets First Member Born in Haiti
description: In a special election that highlighted the complicated Caribbean politics of central Brooklyn, Dr. Mathieu Eugene was elected to the City Council yesterday, becoming the Councils first Haitian-born member. He will take the seat vacated by Yvette D. Clarke after her election to Congress in November.

title: American Held Without Bail in Qaeda Case
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 21  The American man accused of joining Islamic terrorists in Somalia will be held without bail while a grand jury decides whether to indict him, a federal judge here ruled today.

title: Justices Overturn $79.5 Million Tobacco Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Supreme Court on Tuesday overturned an Oregon jurys award of $79.5 million in punitive damages against Philip Morris on the ground that jurors might have improperly calculated the figure to punish the cigarette maker for the harm it caused to smokers other than the man whose widow brought the case.

title: California: Judge Denies Request to Unseal Records
description: News organizations including Bloomberg News and The Associated Press lost a bid to unseal documents in a lawsuit accusing the AT&T Corporation of helping the National Security Agency to spy on United States residents. In a ruling filed in San Francisco, Judge Vaughn R. Walker of Federal District Court allowed six news organizations to join the lawsuit, but he denied their request to unseal records filed in April, saying they were not sufficiently related to the legal proceeding. The documents came from Mark Klein, a retired AT&T technician, who said last year that cables and equipment installed at an AT&T office in San Francisco in 2003 for the N.S.A. were tapping into circuits carrying customers dial-in services.

title: Winters Stew Infused With Summer
description: AT a recent dinner in a fancy restaurant, my braised lamb shanks were served pulled off the bone and molded into a neat little brick. The silken shreds of meat were so soft and succulent that neither knife nor teeth were required.

title: A Battle Over the Costs of Global Warming
description: New Haven

title: For Youths, a Grim Tour on Magazine Crews
description: Two days after graduating from high school last June, Jonathan Pope left his home in Miamisburg, Ohio, to join a traveling magazine sales crew, thinking he would get to talk to people, party at night and see the country.

title: Recipe: Lamb Tagine With Apricots, Olives and Buttered Almonds
description: Time: 2 hours

title: A Grandchild of Italy Cracks the Spaghetti Code
description: MY Italian is so bad I have a hard time pronouncing gnocchi, but I grew up hearing enough of it to know when Im being yelled at. And thats definitely what was happening at a table in a small roadside restaurant in Abruzzi.

title: Iraqi Official Fired for Criticizing Maliki in Rape Case
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 21  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki fired a top Sunni official today after he criticized the governments handling of a young Sunni womans account of being raped by members of the Shiite-dominated security forces.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,131 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Grannies Are Flexing Their Muscles, Gently
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Feb. 15  At halftime of the womens basketball game Wednesday night between Coe College and Simpson, two groups of silver-haired women in curious garb took their places along each sideline. The crowd of nearly 300 at Coes brick Eby Fieldhouse fell silent as the public-address announcer described what they were about to see: a history lesson and a gibe at the misguided notion that women of a certain age are fragile.

title: Charade in Jerusalem
description: It speaks volumes when Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice flies to Jerusalem to try to revive peace talks between Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority and cannot even get the two to show up when she reads out the content-free joint statement to which they have grudgingly agreed.

title: As Newark Neighbor Moves Toward Rebirth, Some Pains Are Felt
description: HARRISON, N.J., Feb. 20  For decades, the nicest thing said about this town of withered factories, toxic waste sites and dried-up ambitions was that at least it was not Newark. Or that it was a great place to park and catch a train for Manhattan.

title: Gallaudet Accreditation in Jeopardy, Official Says
description: Gallaudet University, the only United States university for the deaf, may lose its accreditation because of poor governance, low graduation rates and a lack of tolerance on campus for varying views, a review official warned. The official, Linda A. Suskie, vice president of the Middle States Commission on Higher Education, wrote in a Jan. 13 letter to the universitys interim president, Robert R. Davila, that Gallaudets accreditation was fragile. Copies of the letter were distributed yesterday by leaders of protests last year that led to the ousting of the universitys chosen president, Jane K. Fernandes. Gallaudet has until March 1 to submit a supplement to an accreditation report that did not meet the commissions requirements, Ms. Suskie wrote.

title: Stirring Up the Cubicles at eBay
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  By the end of February, most of the employees at eBays San Jose headquarters will collect their possessions, wave a final goodbye to their landline telephones and change cubicles.

title: In Lake Country, the Secret Is Out
description: Anyone who has found a piece of paradise on a lake in the Midwest has just one request when talking about that sacred spot: dont tell anyone else. But the appeal of lakeshore living is not much of a secret anymore, judging by the scarcity of vacant lots along the prime shoreline of the Great Lakes and the nearby inland lakes, not to mention the high prices even for cottages described as teardowns  typically, at least half a million dollars and sometimes a lot more.

title: Nigeria: Court Says Vice President Can Stay
description: The Court of Appeal ruled that Nigerias president, Olusegun Obasanjo, may not unseat his estranged vice president, Atiku Abubakar, because Mr. Abubakar had defected from the presidents party to become a presidential candidate for another party. The ruling, which may be appealed, was the latest round in a legal battle between Nigerias most prominent politicians, who forged a strategic alliance eight years ago. The combination of Mr. Obasanjo, a Yoruba Christian from the south, and Mr. Abubakar, a Hausa Muslim from the north, was intended to cool the ethnic and sectarian flames of Nigeria and guide it peacefully from military rule to democracy.

title: Lower Voter Turnout Is Seen in States That Require ID
description: States that imposed identification requirements on voters reduced turnout at the polls in the 2004 presidential election by about 3 percent, and by two to three times as much for minorities, new research suggests.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Strong Computer Sales Help H-P to 26% Gain
description: Hewlett-Packard said today that its profit increased 26 percent in its first quarter as revenue grew 11 percent.

title: A Mezzo-Soprano Whos Determined to Do It Her Way, With or Without Star Turns
description: She has been called a force of nature. Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Operas general manager, says she has one of the greatest voices in the history of opera. The Mets current program book fetes her as one of the leading divas of our time.

title: Bush Goes on Road to Push Health Plan
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. Feb. 21  President Bushs plan to expand health coverage by revamping the tax code has been pronounced dead by leading Democrats on Capitol Hill. But Mr. Bush, ever the optimist, forged ahead today, conducting an Oprah Winfrey-like chat session here with people who are uninsured.

title: Shift on Antitrust Issues May Aid Sirius-XM Deal
description: Mel Karmazin, the chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, made a lot of phone calls seeking advice before he entered into a merger deal with XM Satellite Radio on Monday.

title: Senator Clinton Pressured on Iraq
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 21  Two Democratic presidential rivals of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton applied more pressure to her over Iraq today, extolling the virtue of admitting mistakes about the war  which she has not done  and comparing politicians who do not to President Bush.

title: Rosetta Miller, Museum Philanthropist, Dies
description: Rosetta Miller, a benefactor of the World Monuments Fund and the Newark Museum, died Saturday night or Sunday morning at her home in Sarasota, Fla., where she was spending the winter. She was thought to be 73, and also had homes in Manhattan and on Pawleys Island in South Carolina, her home state.

title: Israeli Leader Willing to Meet Again With Abbas
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said today that he was willing to meet again and again with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas. But the Israeli leader also made clear that serious peace negotiations are unlikely unless the Palestinian government is willing to recognize Israel.

title: Some Sunny French Accents  for a Cold-Weather Braise
description: TWO weeks ago I was in France, dining in small restaurants near the vibrant food market in Nice, in the old city. I marveled at the bright flavors of everything I ate.

title: Brooklyn Tenants Reflect on Successful Experiment
description: Life on the sixth floor of Building F3 continued more or less as usual last week. Fran Garcias 2-year-old grandson, in his pajama bottoms, padded down the hall to 6G, where Ethel Banks, 78, was lighting a candle in memory of her identical twin sister, June.

title: Las Vegas Adapts to Reap Chinese New Year Bounty
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 20  Zhu Yu was not the least perturbed that faux Italian frescoes  rather than Asian silk screens  decorated the ceiling of the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino hallway where he and his family watched on Saturday as a 25-foot-long red-and-yellow dragon shimmied through a traditional Chinese New Year dance.

title: Are Thin Mints on Thin Ice?
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Manhattan: 9/11 Health News in Pension Checks
description: New York City will send information cards about two 9/11 health programs to 82,000 retirees in the citys five pension systems, City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. announced yesterday. The cards will be mailed, along with pension checks, on Monday to promote awareness of the two monitoring and treatment programs, one run by Mount Sinai Medical Center and the other by Bellevue Hospital Center. The cards urge retirees to contact the program if they have symptoms they believe were caused by exposure to the dust and debris from the collapse of the World Trade Center. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released a report last week urging a vast increase in health spending and a special compensation fund for rescue workers, business owners, residents and others who became sick after the 9/11 attack.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about an examination of Pennsylvanias response to a major snowstorm referred incorrectly to the part of the state where motorists were stranded on three major highways and misstated the direction of one of the highways, Interstate 81. The area was eastern Pennsylvania, not central Pennsylvania. Interstate 81 is designated north-south, not east-west. (Go to Article)

title: After 9/11, Ailing Residents Find a Place to Turn
description: They say they suffer the same rasping cough, shortness of breath and gastrointestinal pains as thousands of rescue and recovery workers who fell ill from the dust and smoke at ground zero. They worry, as the others do, that the future may bring more health problems.

title: Foreign Forces in the American-Led Coalition in Iraq
description: With the announcement today of pending troop withdrawals by Britain and Denmark, here is a summary of the foreign forces now in Iraq as part of the American-led coalition, according to news agencies, government offices and research organizations. Nations with personnel in Iraq under United Nations or NATO auspices, not under the command of the American-led military coalition, are not shown.

title: Britain to Announce Trimming of Iraq Force, Reports Say
description: LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 21  Prime Minister Tony Blair is planning to announce Wednesday that up to 1,500 of the 7,000 British troops in southern Iraq will begin withdrawing in coming weeks, the British news media reported, quoting unidentified sources.

title: Nets Kidd and Carter Could Still Be Traded
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 20  After a week dominated by speculation surrounding the future of one of their star players, Jason Kidd, the Nets should be eager for Wednesday nights game against the Hornets.

title: New York Tops 8 Big Cities in Taxes, Study Shows
description: New York City has long had a notorious reputation for high taxes, but an independent analysis released today shows just how much the city stands out in this regard: state and local taxes swallow $9.02 out of every $100 in taxable income, putting New Yorks tax burden far above those of the eight other American cities with populations over 1 million.

title: A Reunion of Refugees, Class of 57
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

title: 2 Leaders Rebuff Russias Nuclear Threats
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20  Officials in the Czech Republic and Poland vowed Tuesday that they would not be intimidated by Russia, a day after a general in Moscow declared that nuclear weapons could be aimed at their countries if they allowed the Bush administration to build ballistic missile defenses within their borders.

title: India and Pakistan Say They Will Fight Terrorism Together in Spite of Deadly Train Bombing
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 21  The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan, meeting here today, pledged to work together to fight terrorism, following an incendiary bomb attack on a cross-border express train late Sunday that killed 68 people of both nationalities.

title: Brooklyn: Couple Charged With Medicaid Fraud
description: A former funeral home manager and his wife were arrested yesterday and charged with illegally collecting more than $20,000 in Medicaid benefits, the authorities said. The couple, Abraham Levy, 36, and Miriam Levy, 37, of Brooklyn, lied about their income and neglected to tell welfare officials about a bank account into which they deposited more than $1.5 million in less than two years, according to the state welfare inspector general, Brian P. Sanvidge. In 2003, the Levys, who both worked at Shomrei Hadas Chapels, a funeral home in Borough Park, underreported their income on their Medicaid applications by more than $105,000, Mr. Sanvidge said. They were charged with welfare fraud and grand larceny and face up to seven years in prison if convicted of the top fraud charge.

title: Iraqi Militants Use Chlorine in 3 Bombings
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 21  A truck bomb that combined explosives with chlorine gas blew up in southern Baghdad on Wednesday, and officials said it may represent a new and deadly tactic by insurgents against Iraqi civilians.

title: Present at an Empires Corrupted Birth
description: Like the Neo-Classical history paintings on which it is based, Eve Sussmans film The Rape of the Sabine Women never lets you forget that it is serious art. Extravagantly beautiful, endlessly noble and largely devoid of humor, it self-consciously pushes every aspect of movie-making toward sensorial overload.

title: Manhattan: New Borough Commander
description: Assistant Chief James Tuller has been appointed borough commander of Patrol Borough Manhattan South, which covers Manhattan south of 59th Street, including the United Nations, the Empire State Building and Wall Street. Chief Tuller, 54, was most recently the borough commander of Queens North, and succeeds Assistant Chief Bruce H. Smolka, who retired last week after three years in the post and 33 years with the Police Department. Chief Tuller, who lives in Queens, joined the New York City Housing Police Department in 1973.

title: Teacher Defends Religious Comments in Class
description: KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 20  The teacher who is the subject of a potential lawsuit regarding proselytizing in a public high school history class denied on Tuesday night that he had preached in class and said that the student who taped him had never expressed discomfort to him about his comments.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE MARINES They call it warrior culture  the smallest but fiercest branch of the United States armed services. This special ventures into Marine Corps training facilities in Parris Island, S.C.; Quantico, Va.; and Twentynine Palms, Calif., to reveal what it takes to be a Marine  from a recruits arrival at boot camp and often grueling training, including the martial arts program, confidence course and rifle range instruction, to the demanding Officer Candidate Leadership reaction course and the infamous Quigley exercise, which requires navigating a four-foot-deep stretch of 50-degree swamp water. More than 30 Marines weigh in on the history, traditions and importance of being the proud and the few.

title: Merck to Halt Lobbying for Vaccine for Girls
description: Reacting to a furor from some parents, advocacy groups and public health experts, Merck said yesterday that it would stop lobbying state legislatures to require the use of its new cervical cancer vaccine.

title: Even With Change, an Affordable Capital
description: BRUSSELS  Apartments here dont get much more central than Gregg Svingens one-bedroom place just off Boulevard Emile Jacqmain, a busy thoroughfare that snakes through the Belgian capital.

title: Obamas Big Screen Test
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: Parties Face Off Over Burial Site for Anna Nicole Smith
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20  The battle over Anna Nicole Smiths final resting place was slogging along in Courtroom 850 on Tuesday when the judge got an urgent call. It was Broward Countys medical examiner, warning by speakerphone that the body of Ms. Smith, who died in a South Florida hotel room on Feb. 8, was decomposing much faster than expected despite its recent embalming.

title: Brooding, Complex 2004 Chteauneufs
description: A GOOD Chteauneuf-du-Pape is first and foremost a wine-lovers wine.

title: Recipe: Short Ribs Provenal
description: 6tablespoons extra virgin olive oil

title: Talk of Race as Theft Case Heads to Jury in Brooklyn
description: Defense lawyers and prosecutors agreed on one thing yesterday as they delivered closing arguments in the corruption trial of Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic Party leader  that race played a role in the election campaign that led to the larceny charges against him.

title: Newark: Longtime Escapee Caught, Officials Say
description: Perhaps after 33 years, James Quisenberry thought he had made a clean getaway. In 1974, Mr. Quisenberry escaped from Bayside State Prison in New Jersey, where he was serving time for aggravated assault with intent to kill, the authorities said. In 2004, a detective from the State Corrections Department dusted off Mr. Quisenberrys cold-case file, said Michael Schroeder, a spokesman for the United States Marshals Service in Newark. The trail led through half a dozen states and eight aliases to a 1992 Buick parked in the Oakland suburb of Union City, Calif., with a for-sale sign in the window, Mr. Schroeder said. Yesterday, Mr. Schroeder said, investigators called the number, spoke to a woman and went to her apartment, where they found Mr. Quisenberry, 59, hiding in a closet. When the investigators asked if he knew why they had traveled from New Jersey to find him, Mr. Quisenberry replied, Well, I got a pretty good idea, Mr. Schroeder said. He was arrested and will be returned to New Jersey.

title: Equity Firm Said to Raise Big New Fund
description: Providence Equity Partners, a private firm that focuses on media and communications, is expected to announce today that it raised $12 billion for what would be the largest specialized fund in the world, according to people briefed on the matter. Providence owns stakes in businesses including Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Warner Music.

title: Arts Organizations Adjust to Decline in Funding
description: When the Altria Group announced in the fall that it was planning to spin off its Kraft Foods division, Wall Street cheered. But among cultural institutions, the response was considerably less upbeat: as part of the restructuring, Altria, formerly Philip Morris, is phasing out its significant support for the arts, which has funneled $210 million to cultural groups over the last four decades.

title: Satellite Radio in Canada Faces Its Own Uncertainties
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 20  While many questions surround the planned merger of the XM and Sirius satellite radio systems in the United States, the situation for the two companies Canadian affiliates may be, if anything, more uncertain.

title: One Troublesome Word
description: A tempest has been brewing over a childrens book that contains a word some find naughty and unsettling. The word is scrotum. It appears only a few times in the book, The Higher Power of Lucky, which is recommended for grades four to six. The scrotum in question belongs to a dog, who is bitten there by a snake.

title: Jeter Says Theres No Rift, and Means It
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 20  The loudspeakers at Legends Field played The Boys of Summer on Tuesday morning. Fans clustered into the first few rows to sit in the sun and watch the first full-squad practice of spring training. The Yankees played catch in the outfield, with Derek Jeter throwing to Alex Rodriguez.

title: Keeping an Eye on a New Home
description: Most clients on the roster of Everest Construction have one thing in common: They live hundreds of miles away, or even farther, from the homes they are having built at the Tamarack Resort, a new ski and golf community in Donnelly, Idaho, 95 miles north of Boise.

title: Australia Is Seeking Nationwide Shift to Energy-Saving Light Bulbs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 20  Australia looks ready to become the first country to phase out incandescent light bulbs in favor of more energy-efficient compact fluorescent bulbs, as part of its drive to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

title: Action, and Inaction, on the War (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Something New for the Mostly Mozart Festival: A Composer in Residence
description: With the Mozart year of 2006 turned to dust, the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center has found a new composer to celebrate, and one very much alive.

title: Many Episcopalians Wary, Some Defiant After Ultimatum by Anglicans
description: There was a time when the Episcopal Church in the United States was known as the Republican Party at prayer, but in the last 30 years it has evolved into the Rainbow Coalition of Christianity.

title: Supreme Court Will Review the Way New York Selects Judicial Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The United States Supreme Court agreed on Tuesday to review New Yorks method of selecting candidates to its own Supreme Courts  the 324 judges who have general trial jurisdiction throughout the state and whose nomination to 14-year terms is tightly controlled by a political process that two lower federal courts declared unconstitutional last year.

title: Bush Friends, Loyal and Texan, Remain a Force
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Israel Hernandez was a fresh-faced college graduate from the Texas border town of Eagle Pass in the summer of 1993 when he landed a job in Dallas as the personal aide to the part-owner of the Texas Rangers George W. Bush.

title: A History Department Bans Citing Wikipedia as a Research Source
description: When half a dozen students in Neil Waterss Japanese history class at Middlebury College asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan, he knew something was wrong. The Jesuits were in no position to aid a revolution, he said; the few of them in Japan were in hiding.

title: Going to Where the Action Is
description: With 127 miles of densely populated coastline hugging the Atlantic Ocean from Sandy Hook to Cape May, the New Jersey shore is nobodys idea of an escape from civilization. On the contrary, civilization engulfs you, from the sweaty strangers lying two inches from your beach towel to the hordes of overexcited children on the boardwalk with cotton candy stuck to their faces.

title: Iraqi Official Fired After Seeking Rape Inquiry
description: Political tensions ran high in Iraq today as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki ordered the dismissal of a top Sunni official who called for an international investigation into the alleged rape of a Sunni woman by Iraqi security forces.

title: Rape Accusation Reinforces Fears in a Divided Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 21  The most wicked acts are spoken of openly and without reserve in Iraq. Torture, stabbings and bodies ripped to pieces in bombings are all part of the daily conversation.

title: Brookhaven: New Power Plant for Long Island
description: Siemens Power Generation has won a $450 million contract from Caithness Long Island L.L.C. to build and operate the first major power plant to be constructed on Long Island in more than 30 years, the companies said yesterday. The electric power plant will be built in Brookhaven and supply up to 350 megawatts of electricity to the Long Island Power Authority, using natural gas as the primary fuel, the companies said in a statement. The electricity will be distributed to Brookhaven and other parts of western Suffolk County. Construction is expected to begin soon, and the plant will start generating electricity in the summer of 2009, the statement said. Siemens, a German company, will handle the operations and maintenance for 17 years.

title: Padilla Says He Still Has Something Up His Sleeve
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 20  As Juan Padilla closed his eyes and turned away, Jorge Sosa showed a crowd of onlookers his card  the two of diamonds  before he shoved it into the bottom of the deck. Padilla shuffled the cards with a little too much force, and most of them crashed to the ground. No problem. He picked them up, reshuffled them to his satisfaction and put them back into their box. Then he grabbed a manila envelope from a nearby locker and placed it on the floor.

title: Five New Picks for Top Ratings in Michelin Guide
description: Five restaurants are new recipients of Michelins highest rating, three stars, in the 2007 edition of its guide to restaurants in France, the largest crop of additions to the top rank in the guides history.

title: Which Is the Higher Art Form: The Wine or the Label?
description: In 1945 Baron Philippe de Rothschild began commissioning artists to create labels for his wine, Chteau Mouton Rothschild. Many of the greatest painters of the 20th century, including Mir, Dal, Chagall, Picasso and Warhol, were represented over the years. An exhibition of 60 paintings used on vintages from 1945 to 2004, including the Chagall at left and the Mir at top right and the Warhol below it, will be on display from Friday through March 10 at Sothebys, 1334 York Avenue (72nd Street).

title: Rhode Island: Ex-Lawmaker Gets More Prison Time
description: Former State Senator John Celona, who was sentenced last month to two and a half years in federal prison for taking corporate payoffs, was sentenced to an additional year and a half in prison after pleading no contest to similar state charges. Mr. Celona, a Democrat from North Providence, will serve the sentences concurrently starting on March 2. He pleaded no contest to one state count of taking money under false pretenses and to an ethics charge for drawing a legislative salary while being paid as a consultant by a hospital.

title: City to Give 20 Small Special Education Schools Extra Funds
description: The New York City Department of Education, faced with criticism that special education students and those who are not proficient in English are being shut out of many small middle and high schools, announced yesterday that 20 schools set to open in September would receive extra money to serve those students.

title: That Old Tale About S.I.? Hold On Now
description: Like the sale of Manhattan to Dutch settlers for $24, it is a historical legend that has been repeated time and again: Staten Island became part of New York rather than New Jersey, the story goes, because of a sailing contest in the 17th century.

title: The New Somalia: A Grimly Familiar Rerun
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 20  Fierce mortar attacks killed at least 15 civilians in Somalia on Tuesday, and for a country that had seemed on the verge of ending 16 years of chaotic violence this is the new status quo.

title: Hoping to Keep Orlando Blooming
description: Editors note: In Advertising comes to you today because of the Presidents Day holiday yesterday. Look for In Advertising next week on Feb. 26, its regular publication day, Monday.

title: A Demure Start, With a Flourishing Dash Toward the Finish
description: The awful thing about a conductor becoming geriatric is that you seem to become more desirable, not less, Neville Marriner said in 2000. Now a fit and dapper 82, he is still going strong as the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, the chamber orchestra he founded in 1958, approaches its 50th anniversary.

title: Bringing Laboratory Space Back to New York
description: When Eric Kandel, a Nobel laureate at Columbia University, formed a life sciences company, Memory Pharmaceuticals, in 1998, a lack of lab space options in New York City eventually forced the business to Montvale, N.J.

title: India and Pakistan Talks to Go On Despite Deadly Train Explosions
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 20  Indian and Pakistani officials said peace talks between their countries would open here on Wednesday as planned, reaffirming their determination not to allow the train bombings that killed at least 68 people on Sunday to upset the delicate negotiations.

title: U.N. Nuclear Deadline for Iran Passes
description: Unbowed by international pressure, Iranian leaders vowed to press ahead with the countrys controversial uranium-enrichment program, even as a United Nations-imposed deadline to shut the program down passes today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about Gov. Eliot Spitzers approval of plans for a casino for the St. Regis Mohawk tribe in the Catskill Mountains of New York misspelled the name of the upstate New York town that is near the tribes Akwesasne reservation. It is Massena, not Messena.

title: A Senators Ambitious Path Through Race and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Maybe it is his compelling life story. Or perhaps its his insistence that Americans can look beyond race and rally around fresh ideas and the possibility of change. But by the time the charismatic African-American senator begins to speak passionately of his unwavering opposition to the war in Iraq, it is clear that something about the man and his message is resonating with the audience.

title: German and French Leaders to Meet on Job Cuts at Airbus
description: PARIS, Feb. 20  The leaders of Germany and France will meet this week in an effort to resolve the latest eruption of tensions at EADS, the parent company of Airbus, which wants to shed thousands of jobs in Europe.

title: Jury Begins Deliberating in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by the Mills Corporation to accept a takeover bid by a partnership led by the Simon Property Group misidentified the location of the Mills headquarters. It is in Chevy Chase, Md., not Arlington, Va.

title: More Than Just a Sequel to a Noodle Bar
description: THERE are reviews that introduce an unheralded chef to an unaware public and reviews that take a renegade view, saying a chef disrespected must be redeemed. Then theres this one. If it came with a soundtrack, youd hear the clattering of a bandwagon, along with the heavy thump of an overfed critic landing squarely (or is that roundly?) on it.

title: Careful Hands Forging Tandoori
description: HAVE you ever held your hand over a tandoor at full blast? Its no fun at all. The tandoor, the top-loading oven from which a whole subcuisine of Indian food springs, gets superhot: at Earthen Oven, on the Upper West Side, Durga Prasads tandoor reaches 700 degrees.

title: Real Health Care Plans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann Barzel, 101, Dies; a Writer Whose Passion Was Dance
description: Ann Barzel, a dance writer and historian whose tenacity and passion for the art form were legendary, died on Feb. 12 in Chicago. She was 101.

title: One City Down and 10 to Go
description: It was the start of the 11-city tour to sell the Oscar De La Hoya-Floyd Mayweather Jr. bout on May 5, and the staples of major boxing promotion were in evidence: well-fed reporters, thumping music, interminable video clips, Bert Sugar (boxings living logo) in his fedora and unlit cigar, late-arriving fighters, intercamp insults and each boxers fierce vow to hurt the other.

title: The Bright Side of Human Nature (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fannie Mae to Withhold Bonus Pay for 46
description: Fannie Mae, the largest United States mortgage finance company, will withhold $44.4 million in long-term incentive pay to former and current executives, including its chief executive, Daniel H. Mudd, the company said yesterday.

title: Just Another Desperate Day in the Life of a Drug Casualty
description: Watching wasted people stumble from one fix to the next is rarely riveting cinema, and Cocaine Angel does little to disprove that rule. Yet Michael Tullys shambling observation of a day (and a bit more) in the life of Scott (Damian Lahey, who also wrote the wisp of a story) refuses to wallow in addiction angst. Harnessing the twin virtues of drollness and economy, Mr. Tully keeps scenes brief and melodrama on the margins. In his hands, the search for syringe and vein is neither noble nor ridiculous. It just is.

title: Rape Accusation Reinforces Fears in a Divided Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 20  The most wicked acts are spoken of openly and without reserve in Iraq. Torture, stabbings and bodies ripped to pieces in bombings are all part of the daily conversation.

title: New York Town Justice Is Admonished Over His Request for a Raise
description: The town justice wanted a raise, and his pitch certainly caught officials attention in the western New York community of Alabama: At a town board meeting, he suggested that if he did not get the money, he could slash municipal income by setting lower fines.

title: PETA Criticizes Egg Farm at South Carolina Monastery
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20  An egg farm operated by Trappist monks at a monastery in South Carolina is an ugly stain on an otherwise blessed community, an animal rights group said Tuesday as it released the results of an undercover investigation into egg production practices there.

title: In Closing Pleas, Clashing Views on Libbys Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Defense lawyers and prosecutors in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. made their final summations on Tuesday, offering the jury two starkly different ways to evaluate the evidence presented over the last few weeks.

title: A Song Form Is Updated, but Not in the Alleys of Its Origin
description: LISBON  Jos de Oliveira bellows, occasionally off key, the melancholic songs known as fado.

title: Golf Match Play Means One Opponent, No Leader Board
description: MARANA, Ariz., Feb. 20  If the Ryder Cup is played for continent and country, the Accenture Match Play Championship is about selfishness and survival. It is a five-day tournament that has more in common with ultimate fighting than with the Masters.

title: Siegfried Landau, Conductor, Dies at 85
description: Siegfried Landau, the founding conductor of what is now called the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, died on Monday night, along with his wife, Irene Gabriel, in a fire at their home in Brushton, in northern New York State. Mr. Landau was 85. His wife, a former ballet dancer, was 77.

title: A Very Altmanesque Tribute to Altman
description: Robert Altman, the pirate king of American filmmaking, was honored yesterday at the Majestic Theater in Manhattan by friends and colleagues including Lily Tomlin, E. L. Doctorow, Harry Belafonte, Julianne Moore, Kevin Kline and Tim Robbins.

title: Gathering Once a Month for a Voyage to Narnia
description: On a recent Friday night, 30 fans of the writer C. S. Lewis sat in folding chairs under a vaulted ceiling surrounded by gilt-framed oil paintings of Episcopal priests. Like Lucy Pevensie, the youngest of the four children in Lewiss book The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, who opens a wardrobe to discover the icy land of Narnia, the members of the New York C. S. Lewis Society immerse themselves in the writers fantastical realm.

title: Negroponte Advises New Diplomats to Seek Challenging Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Entering his first full week as deputy secretary of state, John D. Negroponte on Tuesday urged a graduating class of new diplomats to seek overseas assignments in challenging, difficult and even hazardous posts.

title: Heated Competition. Steaming Neighbors. This Is Frozen Yogurt?
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: Correction: So Naughty, So Nice
description: An article last Wednesday about red velvet cake referred incorrectly to a recipe for the cake in Craig Claibornes Southern Cooking (Times Books, 1987). The recipe contained cocoa, it was not cocoa-free.

title: Union: Crash Snarls Route 22
description: A high-speed police chase down Route 22 ended with several accidents and closed the eastbound lanes to traffic yesterday morning, the Union police said. The police were pursuing two stolen cars on the eastbound lanes of the highway around 10:30 a.m. when one of the cars crashed, causing a chain-reaction accident that involved a New Jersey Transit bus and at least four cars. The other crashed into a car in the parking lot of the Garden State Motor Lodge. No one was seriously injured, the police said, but the accidents and the investigation shut down traffic for several hours. Three people were arrested, but the police did not identify them yesterday evening.

title: Testing the Limits and Cost of Revolution
description: The chain-link enclosure occupies most of the room. It is filled with naked men. They struggle to put on their clothes, muttering to themselves, barely kept under control by three tough guards. The audience is seated all around the central enclosure; those at the sides are trapped between it and two holding pens at either side of the room.

title: Shielding the Powerful
description: The Supreme Courts decision yesterday overturning a nearly $80 million punitive damage award against Philip Morris is a win for corporate wrongdoers. It stretches the Constitutions guarantee of due process in a way that will make it easier for companies that act reprehensibly to sidestep serious punishments.

title: Hewlett-Packard Net Jumps 26% in the Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20  Notebook computers flew off shelves over the holidays, helping to propel Hewlett-Packards first-quarter net profit 26 percent higher and to bolster its lead atop the PC heap.

title: Astronomers Find No Water on 2 Distant Planets
description: And now the alien planet weather report: scorching, dry, dark and windy.

title: Marbury Turns 30 as the Knicks Win No. 24
description: For all their blemishes, and the Knicks can hardly hide them, the shrinking gap between them and the Eastern Conferences playoff field was never more obvious than it was last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: When Meals Played the Muse
description: THE artist Gordon Matta-Clark, who died in 1978 at age 35, loved to cook, but he could never quite unbraid his culinary passions from those of artmaking, with sometimes bizarre dinner party results. At one, recalled his widow, Jane Crawford, he cooked a lovely whole sea bass, but it emerged from the kitchen encased in a block of aspic nearly three feet long. He unmolded it, then gave the table a good kick, so that the aspic wobbled wildly and the bass seemed to fishtail upstream.

title: Romney Mounting an Early Presidential Ad Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Mitt Romney, who entered the race for the Republican presidential nomination last week, will run television advertisements in five states starting Wednesday, the latest sign of how quickly the 2008 campaign is moving.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jay Adams joined Popular Science magazine, New York, as advertising director. He succeeds Howard Mittman, who left to join Wired magazine, New York, as associate publisher. Mr. Adams had been advertising director at FHM, New York, which is being closed. Popular Science is part of the Time4Media unit of Time Inc., a division of Time Warner; it is among 18 magazines that are being sold to the Bonnier Group by Time Inc. Wired is part of the Cond Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about an examination of Pennsylvanias response to a major snowstorm referred incorrectly to the part of the state where motorists were stranded on three major highways and misstated the direction of one of the highways, Interstate 81. The area was eastern Pennsylvania, not central Pennsylvania. Interstate 81 is designated north-south, not east-west.

title: Johnstown: Teenagers Death Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a Bronx teenager in November who had been restrained at a state juvenile detention center has been ruled a homicide, the Fulton County district attorney said yesterday. The teenager, Darryl Thompson, 15, was restrained by two staff members at the Tryon Residential Center for Boys in Johnstown on Nov. 18, said Louise K. Sira, the district attorney. Shortly after being handcuffed, he stopped breathing and later died at St. Marys Hospital in Amsterdam, she said. Ms. Sira said the cause of death was cardiac arrhythmia, possibly linked to a pre-existing heart abnormality and spurred by the stress of the conflict. She said that the ruling did not indicate use of excessive force or negligence and that the matter would be reviewed by a grand jury.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Football League roundup yesterday about coaching changes for the San Diego Chargers misstated the given name of the teams new linebackers coach in some copies. He is Ron Rivera, not Ray.

title: Recipe: Italian Meatballs
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: The Tier Garden
description: Where horticulture meets the avant-garde.

title: Diary of the Leak Trial
What a Knockout
description: Meet the knockout who scaled fashions color barrier.

title: Afrocentric
description: This season, black power rules the runways.

title: Made in China
description: The new status symbol in the West is a work of art from the East.

title: The Girl Who Fell to Earth
description: Out-of-this-world, high-tech glamour.

title: Cool and Collected
description: In this modern Baltimore house, art and life find a happy medium.

title: Marchesa and the Red Carpet
description: The fledging fashion line attracts a following as well as steaty gossip.

title: Graphic Material
description: An X-rated girl in her summer dresses.

title: Hollywood Swag
description: During Oscar season, celebrities get free meals, free gifts and free pedicures at high-end "branded retreats" around L.A.

title: New National Endowment Awards
description: The inaugural International Literature Awards of the National Endowment for the Arts, intended to give Americans greater access to worthy foreign literature in translation, went yesterday to three nonprofit literary presses: Archipelago Books of Brooklyn; Dalkey Archive Press of Champaign, Ill.; and Etruscan Press of Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Each received $10,000 from the endowment to support the translation and publication of a work from Greece or Spain, the focus of the first awards, as well as matching awards from each country. Dana Gioia, chairman of the endowment, said, "Translation provides Americans with as direct a connection as possible to both the individual voice of the author and the heart of a culture." Archipelago Books is to publish "Vredaman," a novel by the Basque writer Unai Elorriaga, in a translation by Amaia Gabantxo. Dalkey Archive Press will publish Karen Emmerich's translation of "I'd Like," 13 linked short stories by Amanda Michalopoulou of Greece. Etruscan Press is to publish "Amerikaniki Fouga" ("American Fugue"), a novel by Alexis Stamatis of Greece, in a translation by Diane Thiel.

title: IPods Get Jiggy
Justices Reject Antitrust Award
description: The Supreme Court threw out a $79 million award against Weyerhaeuser on Tuesday in a lawsuit accusing the company of trying to monopolize the hardwood lumber market in the Pacific Northwest. The decision, which was unanimous, came in the case of a defunct lumber mill that said it was driven out of business when Weyerhaeuser overpaid for logs that it allegedly did not need.

title: Kraft Chief Outlines Turnaround Strategy
description: When the Altria Group announced its long-awaited spin-off of its Kraft Foods unit, Wall Street cheered, but not for the maker of Velveeta. The feeling was that once sluggish Kraft, and its portfolio of brands that are about as fresh as a Brady Bunch rerun, had been jettisoned, the groups tobacco brands could realize their full value.

title: Apollo Offers $2 Billion for British Real Estate Broker
description: Apollo Management, the buyout firm run by Leon Black, is squaring off with a London rival, the 3i Group for control of Countrywide, the largest residential real estate broker in Britain. Apollo has offered 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) for Countrywide, only a couple of months after it agreed to fork over $9 billion for Realogy, the biggest residential real estate brokerage in the United States.

title: Higher Offer Brings Enterprise Back to the Table
description: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. Enterprise said on Monday that it is talking to the buyout shop about a revised offer valuing the company at 554 million pounds. In a regulatory statement, Enterprise said the talks were based on a potential offer of 605 pence a share, up from the 575 pence on the table in January.

title: ScanSafe Raises $15 Million Second Round
description: ScanSafe, an Internet security company, said Tuesday that it had raised $15 million in a second round of financing led by Scale Venture Partners. Benchmark Capital, an early investor in ScanSafe, also participated in the round, ScanSafe said.

title: Providence Equity Raises $12 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Providence Equity Partners, a private company that focuses on media and communications, said Wednesday that it had raised $12 billion for its sixth buyout fund. It will be the largest specialized fund in the world and among the largest buyout firms in the United States, The New York Times reported. Providence owns stakes in businesses including Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Warner Music Group. Its new fund is almost three times the size of its previous one, raised in 2004.

title: Citigroup Raises First Asia Property Fund
description: Citigroups property unit said it had raised $1.29 billion for its first fund to invest in real estate and related assets in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on China and India. Citigroup and its investment professionals committed $200 million to the fund, CPI Capital Partners Asia Pacific LP, the bank said. The fund will be managed by a team of more than 25 employees based in Hong Kong and led by managing director David Schaefer. About 40 percent of the fund has been invested or pledged already.

title: Germanys Linde Wants the Rest of Malaysian Oxygen
description: The Linde Group, the worlds largest maker of industrial gases, offered 310.2 million euros ($408 million) for the shares it does not own in Malaysian Oxygen as it restructures assets to meet European regulations.

title: Man Financial Settles Fraud Allegations
description: Federal regulators fined the commodities trading firm Man Financial $317,000 on Tuesday to settle allegations that a former employee committed fraud when recruiting new customers to use the companys trading systems.The Commodity Futures Trading Commission filed charges against Steven M. Camp of Chicago and Man Financial on Tuesday, and also entered into a settlement with Mr. Camp and the company to settle the charges.

title: SV Life Sciences Closes 4th Fund
description: SV Life Sciences has closed its fourth investment fund with $572 million in committed capital, signaling optimism about opportunities ahead after a strong year of M&A exits in 2006. The $572 million in commitments eclipses by 43 percent the $402 million SV pulled in for its third fund. The firm plans to continue to make early-stage investments in biotech and medical devices and leveraged buyouts of healthcare services ranging from $5 million to $25 million.

title: S.E.C. Says Energy Firm Bilked investors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Braintree Energy on Tuesday of bilking investors of $9 million by using high-pressure sales tactics and promises of extraordinary returns to induce them to buy shares in unproductive oil and gas projects. The S.E.C. also said Howard Graham, who ran Braintree Energy, misappropriated up to $3 million of proceeds from investors for his personal use.

title: American Skiing Unloads 2 More Vermont Resorts
description: American Skiing has agreed to sell the Killington and Pico ski resorts in Vermont for $83.5 million, four days after disclosing the sale of Mount Snow in southern Vermont and the Attitash ski area in New Hampshire. The resorts were sold to SP Land, a Dallas real estate investor, and Powdr, a resort company based in Utah and the sales include all of the real estate owned by Killington and Pico. SP Land will assume about $5 million in debt as part of the purchase.

title: For Prosecutors, Clock Is Ticking on Backdating Charges
description: Federal prosecutors investigating the backdating of stock options are bumping up against a legal deadline that may affect when they file charges and what charges they bring. Under federal law, prosecutors typically have five years to bring charges of securities fraud. But, notes The San Jose Mercury News, for many of the backdating cases, that time window could be closing, because the misdating of stock options largely ended in 2002 thanks to new regulations.

title: US Airways Chief Sentenced for DUI
description: US Airways chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, was sentenced to one day in jail and a fine of $1,646 after pleading guilty to driving under the influence. Mr. Parker was pulled over for speeding Jan. 31, the same day that US Airways dropped its $10 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. Mr. Parker, who will serve his 24 hours behind bars on March 15, pleaded guilty Tuesday to the DUI against the advice of his attorney, the airline said.

title: Its Buyout Time, and the Interest Rates Are Easy
description: Henry Kravis and Stephen Schwarzman never had it so good, at least in terms of getting the lowest interest rates on loans from their bankers. Just three months after borrowing $12.8 billion to pay for the hospital operator HCA in November, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its partners negotiated a new loan with lower rates, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Canadian Regulators to Force Hedge Funds to Register
description: As lawmakers in the United States and Europe mull ways to bring greater transparency to the largely unregulated hedge fund industry, Canada is moving ahead with its own plans to force hedge fund managers to register with regulators and pass tests to prove their proficiency. Under the plan, hedge fund managers and sales staff also would have to clear a background check, the Canadian Securities Administrators said at a Toronto news conference Tuesday.

title: Warner Says Independent Music Group Backs EMI Deal
description: Warner Music on Tuesday confirmed that it has restarted talks with Britains EMI Group about a possible merger of the two music labels, adding that the Independent Music Publishers and Labels Association had agreed to support such a deal before the European Commission. Warner, which has tried unsuccessfully to combine with EMI several times over the last few years, said it believes the agreement with the association improves its chances of getting regulatory approval. The New York Post said the deal was the first time that the group, known as Impala, has worked in tandem with a major label.

title: Hedge Fund Calls for Break-Up of ABN Amro
description: The British hedge fund that forced the ouster of the Deutsche Borses top executives now has the Netherlands biggest bank in its sights. ABN Amro Holdings is significantly undervalued and should be broken up, according to TCI Fund Management, which holds a stake of more than 1 percent in the bank.

title: Shift on Antitrust Issues May Aid Sirius-XM Deal
description: While XM Satellite Radios merger deal with rival Sirius Satellite Radio has drawn numerous comparisons with EchoStar Communications failed effort to merge with DirecTV four years ago, the regulatory climate that led the Federal Communications Commission to block the deal has changed, The New York Times reports.

title: Hoop Life
description: For the residents of Zwolle, La., in the poor but ethnically diverse Sabine Parish, basketball is more than a game. It's a birthright.

title: Renault-Nissan Says No Thanks to Chrysler
description: DaimlerChryslers potentially pending auction of the Chrysler Group may field bids from a slew of buyers. The RenaultNissan alliance, however, will not be among them, despite its interest in taking on a North American partner. A Nissan spokeswoman said Wednesday that the two car makers are focusing on righting their own finances, a task that would be difficult if the companies were saddled with ailing Chrysler. Last year, Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of both companies, entered talks with General Motors about a potential alliance, but none was formed.

title: One Morning at Microsoft
description: Microsoft's ultra mobile PC has everything except the keyboard and mouse.

title: A Shining Cast upon a Hill
description: Come here, Watson, I want you. The Hillcast is up.

title: Iraq Vote Haunting Hillary
Currents
description: A child of the '80s, recruiting and outfitting a new generation, embroidered pillows, papers soft to the touch and more.

title: A Plan to End at Least One Ethnic Feud
description: Looking to study a new ethnic rivalry after finally mastering the differences between Shiites and Sunnis? Then turn your gaze to Vienna, where talks on the final status for Kosovo are starting today.

title: Personal Shopper
description: A new doorknob can summon Flash Gordon or Louis XV.

title: Carlos Gomez: The Next Best Thing?
description: Philip Humber spent about six weeks with top outfield prospect Carlos Gomez at Class AA Binghamton last season and came away thinking that aside from Jose Reyes, hes the best athlete Ive ever seen.

title: Elusive Oscar Angle No. 7
description: Which of those nominated for best actor knew you-know-who back when she had hair?

title: The Webs Next Killer Ap
description: Homeless guys doing Man-on-the-Streets is all the rage, according to New York magazine by way of RiskyBiz.

title: Babel is Bugsy
description: OscarWatch does not bury the lede when talking with Damien Bona, the author of Inside Oscar. Turns out Mr. Bona is thinking Babel has the juice, which seems to be a trend of late.

title: Remembering Altman
description: A tasteful, funny and sad send-off for Robert Altman took place at the Majestic Theater in New York yesterday.

title: Maybe We Could Outsource TSA?
description: Reuters reports that the two men in charge of the counting the ballots and stuffing the most mysterious envelopes in the Western hemisphere dont divulge, ever, who came in second in the various categories: Thats something that we keep to ourselves, take to the grave, if you will, said Brad Oltmanns, who is conducting the tally with fellow PricewaterhouseCoopers executive Rick Rosas.

title: Werent the Globes Last Month?
description: Reuters points out that seven of ten actors in the best actress and best supporting actress category are not only not from anywhere near the 90210 zip code, but theyre not Americans either. Between The Queen, Babel and Letters From Iwo Jima, maybe the whole U.S.A. as the software headquarters of the world should be rethought.

title: Mistrust in the Middle East
description: We are in the ditch in the Middle East. As bad as you think it is watching TV, its worse, writes David Ignatius, with a Qatar dateline, in his Washington Post column. Ignatius relays some numbers from a Zogby poll taken last year in six countries that are usually regarded as pro-American: Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates:

title: Bush and Cheney Owe an Explanation
description: One way or another, the Scooter Libby trial will soon be over. Whatever the verdict, President Bush and Vice President Cheney owe the American people a candid explanation of what went on in that period in the White House.

title: The Royal Shaft
description: If Little Miss Sunshine swoops in for best pic, two of the guys who got the van rolling, Ron Yerxa and Albert Berger, will not be allowed to take a bow, and their fellow producers are not happy about it.

title: Pauls Revelation
description: The road to paradise is lined with strip malls.

title: Sapporo Said to Consider Management Buyout
description: Sapporo, Japans third-largest brewer, may resort to a management buyout to stymie Steel Partners, a hedge fund based in the United States that is trying to take over the company, the Kyodo news agency reported Wednesday. Previous reports said that Sapporo was in talks with its rivals, Asahi Breweries or Kirin Brewery, about a possible joint venture to thwart Steel Partners, which has said it mightlaunch a tender offer to raise its stake in Sapporo to 66.6 percent from 18.6 percent.

title: When Dads a Senator
description: The Village Voice examines complaints that New Yorks senior senator, Charles Schumer, did not do enough about the ground zero health concerns. (He disputes that interpretation).

title: Spring Fever
description: A delirium of flirty fashion fit for a garden party.

title: A Five-Day Marriage Tour
description: Faced with a shortage of potential brides at home, many South Korean men are traveling to countries like Vietnam to pick wives and hold weddings.

title: Much Help Wanted
description: You still have a shot at the Oscars, or at least going to them, as long as you dont mind having a a bitter nerd as your companion for the evening. Defamer found this gem on Craigslist, and as Cindy Adams might say, only in L.A. kids, only in L.A. The Bagger has helpfully brought out the all-important subtext through his annotations in bold.

title: Greetings from Japan
description: Now that weve gotten this blog up and running again, Id like to introduce a recurring feature I think readers will find interesting. C.J. Nitkowski, the veteran major league left-handed reliever, has agreed to answer our email questions throughout the season as he embarks on a new career in Japan.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's Feb. 21 column on a debate over the economics of climate change:

title: New Miserable Experience
description: The Bagger will be locked in steerage on his way out to LA when you read this, and judging by the traffic updates from there, he better get credentialed up in a hurry. Weather-wise, the Bagger is leaving behind the proper cloth coat because it looks like there will be no freakish cold snap this time around.

title: Hand Maiden's Tale
description: Once upon a time, women were fickle. Sometimes they were girlish. Sometimes they were boyish. Sometimes they were half and half...

title: 2008: Early Ads, First Debate and Other Front-loading Symptoms
description: Today, still about 10 months away from the first caucuses and primaries, we see two significant signs of just how much earlier the campaigns are gearing up.

title: A Photo Treat
description: Todays photo treat: A series of photos of people walking through subway turnstiles. Bizarrely compelling.

title: Lights, Camera  Guest Blogger!

description: A new national poll by Quinnipiac University shows once again that the candidates with the highest name recognition generally, at least for now, have the most support among the voters.
