title: Canos Big Hit
description: Two springs ago, the Yankees had Tony Womack to play second base. Womack was a bad fit from the start: he had declining skills in every area and he was so clueless about the Yankees that he actually asked the clubhouse manager to let him wear No. 5. (It is retired, of course, for a fellow named Joe DiMaggio.)

title: Subprime Crash
description: Novastar has for years ranked in the top five stocks  at least as measured by controversy. At last report, it had about 37 million shares outstanding, and a short position of nearly 13 million shares. It has been on the Regulation SHO list of stocks that had a significant number of failures to deliver for 190 consecutive days. (That ranks No. 2 on the New York Stock Exchanges list, behind Fairfax Financial.)

title: Associates Told to Rise and Shine  or Else
description: Nearly a year ago, when DealBook posted this item on rising salaries for first-year associates at top law firms, we were flooded with comments, many describing the grueling hours that associates were often made to work. So we were intrigued to see Tuesdays post on The Wall Street Journals Law Blog, inspired by an internal memo that recently made the rounds at Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maws New York office. From reading the memo, it appears that, though they may stay late in the evenings, the associates in Mayer Browns securitization practice are not always the earliest of risers.

title: Britains Boldly Anti-Rehab Pop Star
description: Britney Spearss very public downward spiral (shes reportedly fled rehab two times in the past week) has given one late-night comedian pause.

title: State of Affairs: Miuccia Prada
description: Everybody has been talking about the Prada show. Did you like it? Did you hate it? I must say it wasnt one of my favorite Prada shows, but I love the fact that Miuccia Prada will just wing it every now and then. Wreck house, as my son likes to say when youve done something big. Ms. Pradas fall collection seems a continuation of her fascination with banalities. The cheap coat. The vulgar color. She put out a lot of new fabrics that would certainly draw comparisons to upholstery and bath mats. And the blues and oranges made you think of those stuffed wind-up ducks and rabbits you see sold on the streets here. All this is fascinating and proof, I suppose, of Ms. Pradas rich imagination. My problem is that, on most days, I dont want to look like a stuffed duck or a bath mat. Knowing the legitimate war that Ms. Prada wages within herself about commercialism, I heartily admire her guts. We should all be bold. But this time I felt she was rather too immersed in the realm of ideas and abstractions to be effective.

title: All Stars: In the Streets
description: You cant go anywhere in Milan, it seems, without running into a television crew stalking a celebrity. I was on the Via Montenapoleone this afternoon, outside Dior, when I nearly got tomahawked by a TV camera. I couldnt make out who the object of attention was. Everyone on that street looks like somebody trying to be Somebody.

title: Conservatives Bash Grannis
description: Assemblyman Alexander Pete Grannis continues to face trouble on the right over his nomination to be the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, leading some to wonder if he could become a casualty of the political battles between the governor and the Republican-led Senate.

title: Local Call
description: Ah, nice to be on the Left Coast again, taking in a big lungful of particulates, with traces of heavy metals. LAX never looked so good, in part because the Bagger had a rugged commute. He sat next to the bulkhead, which means a nice view of first-class and a persistent reminder of his place in hierarchy.

title: Whos Next: Technology Companies
description: There was time, not that long ago, when private equity firms did not even consider technology companies as potential buyout candidates. Tech companies often have unpredictable cash flows, making it difficult to cover the interest payments in a debt-funded takeover. They can also require huge capital expenditures, which means more investment front and lower returns down the line. Things have changed, however  consider last years hotly contested $18.8 billion deal for Freescale Semiconductor  so analysts at Citigroup took a look at which tech companies might draw buyout interest.

title: Whole Foods to Buy Wild Oats Markets
description: In a deal that will combine two leading retailers of natural and organic foods, Whole Foods Market said Wednesday it will buy Wild Oats Markets for $565 million in cash, its largest acquisition ever. Whole Foods has offered $18.50 per share for Wild Oats, whose largest shareholder is Yucaipa Companies, the investment firm controlled by supermarket mogul Ronald W. Burkle. Yucaipa, which holds a stake of about 18 percent in Wild Oats, has agreed to tender its shares in the offer, the companies said in a press release.

title: Clinton-Obama Hollywood Brawl: Scene 2
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, appearing at the non-debate forum in Carson City, Nev., just responded to a question about the Hollywood brawl between her campaign and Senator Barack Obamas over remarks made about the Clintons by David Geffen, the Hollywood billionaire heavyweight. See our earlier post, with the controversy first teed up by our very own Maureen Dowd.)

title: How to Get to the Moon by 2020
description: President Bushs call a few years back for a manned flight to the moon by 2020 prompted more than a few notes of caution from the space exploration community. The success rate for bold new visions in human spaceflight is about the same as that for missions to Mars, namely two out of three fail, Howard E. McCurdy, a space historian at American University, told The Times on the day it was announced in 2004.

title: Blogtalk: Long Telegrams
description: In happier days, Bill Clinton snubbed the father of containment theory, George F. Kennan, to gossip with his pal David Geffen at a White House dinner. [Kurt Andersen]

description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer took his Bringing Home the Budget tour to Niagara Falls this afternoon, and our stringer David Staba reports that the governor did not call out any of the local legislators by name over their votes for comptroller earlier this month.

title: Oscar Excitement Reaches Uganda
description: Forest Whitaker was in Kampala, Uganda, for the premiere of the movie "The Last King of Scotland," which depicts the reign of dictator Idi Amin.

description: When Gary Sheffield is in the mood to talk, which is most of the time, he might as well put a sign above his locker that reads: Gary Sheffield, unplugged.

title: Obama-Clinton: Scene 3 in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  When Senator Barack Obama arrived here late this afternoon, Iowa reporters were assembled outside the Statehouse for a brief news conference with the Democratic presidential candidate. Step aside, ethanol. The topic of the day? David Geffen.

description: R. Crumb, a pioneer of underground comics, and his wife, Aline Kominsky Crumb, who often draws with him, sat down to discuss their new work.

title: Jet-Lagged in the South China Sea
description: Dont expect much here today. I am somewhere in the South China Sea, bound for Hong Kong, and am suffering from a case of jet lag that would kill an ordinary man. Thanks to New Yorks recent ice storm, my flight to Sydney was canceled. For no good reason, I then had to get to Australia by way of Hong Kong in order to board a ship that was bound for  you guessed it  Hong Kong. I am now the possessor of the sour fruits of a 23-hour air journey and the mental consequences thereof. I am a mess.

description: The New York City school system is planning to give principals new discretion over the spending of millions of dollars that until now have been specifically earmarked for a wide range of arts programs.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 21  Negotiators for state government and for unions representing 35,000 workers have reached an agreement on a proposed contract that would for the first time require that New Jersey employees pay a portion of their health insurance premiums and would increase their contribution to the state pension fund.

title: Iraq Insurgents Employ Chlorine in Bomb Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 21  A truck bomb that combined explosives with chlorine gas blew up in southern Baghdad on Wednesday, and officials said it might represent a new and deadly tactic by insurgents against Iraqi civilians.

description: Students who are bullied by other students because of their sexual orientation are protected by New Jerseys antidiscrimination law, and school districts must take reasonable steps to stop such harassment, the states Supreme Court unanimously ruled yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Senior American officials here and in Moscow attempted again today to allay Russian concerns about Washingtons plans to install antimissile defenses in Eastern Europe, but they also issued a firm message: that NATO will not be cowed or deterred from continuing to enlarge to the east.

title: To Move on, Mickelson Goes Back to the Range
description: MARANA, Ariz., Feb. 21  Phil Mickelson has prepared for tournaments in a number of unique ways. He has tossed a baseball around in the parking lot. He has placed golf balls in a circle on the practice green. After his opening-round victory Wednesday in the Accenture Match Play Championship, Mickelson was asked about his latest pretournament ploy: a driving-range practice session Tuesday with Butch Harmon, Tiger Woodss former teacher.

description: SOON after renovating their brownstone in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, in blow-out modern style two years ago  with a concrete floor, a back wall of glass and not one scrap of period trim  Kirsa Phillips and Doug Cardoni opened it up to a local house tour. Later, Ms. Phillips went to brownstoner.com, a blog devoted to historic Brooklyn brownstones, to find out what her visitors had really thought.

title: Albany: Spitzer Names 2 New Officials
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday announced an appointment and a nomination of a senior official to his administration. Sylvia B. Hamer, now an official at the state attorney generals office, will be Mr. Spitzers deputy secretary for government operations and labor relations. Richard H. Neiman, a banking executive, will be nominated to become banking superintendent; State Senate approval is needed. The annual salary for Ms. Hamers post is $150,000, and for Mr. Neimans, $127,000.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Two advocacy groups for refugees said on Wednesday that the Bush administration routinely detained immigrant families in prisonlike housing that separated young children from their parents and sometimes provided inadequate medical care, food and educational opportunities, despite calls from Congress to house such families in nonpenal, homelike environments.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 21  Forty years after a draft board here rejected his bid for conscientious objector status, Muhammad Ali plans to return to live in the city where he was born and where resentment engendered by his refusal to be drafted into the Vietnam War has not entirely died away.

title: History vs. Homogeneity in New Orleans Housing Fight
description: NEW ORLEANS  In this hard-pressed city a proposal by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to demolish four public housing complexes has touched a raw nerve. The demolition, which would affect more than 4,500 housing units, represents for some the plight of a poor, black underclass displaced by Hurricane Katrina and struggling to return. It also represents the problems that faced the city even before the hurricane: poverty, crime and racial divisions.

title: Brooklyn: Car Strikes Officer
description: A police officer was injured yesterday when he was struck and dragged a short distance by a car whose occupants had been smoking crack, the police said. The officers partner fired at the car as it sped off, the police said. Neither officer was identified. They had walked up to the car, which was stopped at 3414 Fulton Street, around 3 p.m., the police said, when it drove off, knocking one officer to the ground. The car was found a half-mile away, unoccupied. The police said the passenger was caught several blocks away, and charges were pending last evening, but the driver had not been found. The injured officer was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center.

description: EDGEWATER, N.J.

description: LONDON, Feb. 22  The British government made headlines on Wednesday by saying it would withdraw some troops from Iraq. Today, it made even more waves here by saying it would send one soldier in the opposite direction.

title: Mugabe Gets Ready to Eat Cake While Fellow Zimbabweans Cant Find Bread on Shelves
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 21  President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe turned 83 on Wednesday to the strains of the song God Bless President Mugabe on state-controlled radio, along with an interview on state television, a 16-page paean to his rule in Harares daily newspaper and the prospect of a grand birthday party  costly enough to feed thousands of people for months, his critics argued  on Saturday.

title: France: Restaurants Rise and Fall
description: Five restaurants won a third star, Michelins highest rating, in its new guide for France. Three are in Paris  Le Meurice in the Htel Meurice, Le Pr Catelan in the Bois de Boulogne, and Astrance, a 25-seat Right Bank restaurant. Also promoted were Lameloise in Burgundy and Pic in Valence. Demoted to two stars were Taillevent in Paris, which had had three since 1973, and Le Cinq, in the Four Seasons George V hotel, also in Paris. Two three-star establishments disappeared from the guide, La Ferme de Mon Pre in Megve, sold, and LEsprance in Vzelay, in bankruptcy. Another, Buerehiesel in Strasbourg, where Eric Westermann took over from his father, received no stars. The moves keep the number of three-stars in France at 26.

description: Some video buffs may want to relay their high-definition programming all over the house or take it with them on the road. Pinnacle Systems addresses that urge with the PCTV to Go HD Wireless.

description: American movies and music have done very well in some countries like Sweden and less well in others like India. This may sound like a simple difference in human tastes, but decisions to consume culture have an economic aspect.

description: Microsoft finally got its Windows Vista software out the door. Now comes the hardware.

title: Korean Men Use Brokers to Find Brides in Vietnam
description: HANOI, Vietnam  It was midnight here in Hanoi, or already 2 a.m. back in Seoul, South Korea. But after a five-hour flight on a recent Sunday, Kim Wan-su was driven straight from the airport to the Lucky Star karaoke bar here, where 23 young Vietnamese women seeking Korean husbands sat waiting in two dimly lighted rooms.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some copies yesterday about employer efforts to provide free drugs to workers with chronic medical conditions misidentified the state in which one of the employers, Polk County, is located. It is in Florida, not Georgia.

description: I HAVE my grandmothers ring, as well as a brooch that belonged to my husbands grandmother, which makes me as familiar as anybody with the concept of passing down jewelry through generations.

title: Budget Fight Finds Spitzer in a Faceoff With 2 Groups
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21  As Gov. Eliot Spitzer tours the state to drum up support for his budget, a leading labor union and a hospital group are putting legislators on the spot, asking them to pledge to fight against it.

title: Cracked Ribs or Not, Kidd Could Still Be Traded
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 21  Jason Kidd, the Nets star point guard, has been playing with cracked ribs for the past couple of weeks, according to two Eastern Conference officials. But the injury might not stop Kidd from being traded to the Los Angeles Lakers by the 3 p.m. trading deadline Thursday.

title: National Guard May Undertake Iraq Duty Early
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  The Pentagon is planning to send more than 14,000 National Guard troops back to Iraq next year, shortening their time between deployments to meet the demands of President Bushs buildup, Defense Department officials said Wednesday.

title: A Pocket Digital Camera That Holds Its Breath Under Water
description: Pentax updates its line of waterproof, compact digital cameras with the aluminum-alloy Optio W30, a 7-megapixel model out next month.

title: Good Things Come From a Large Warehouse
description: On a cold day, foraging in the Olde Good Things mother ship, a 100,000-square-foot warehouse in Scranton, Pa., is particularly challenging. Last week I came upon a couple stranded and shivering in the vast iron section, which is filled with a seemingly infinite selection of wrought-iron gate sections (about $175 for a three-foot piece) and fluted columns ($350 to $5,000), along with things like fat tugboat chains that have been made into table bases ($300 to $3,500). Kevin Browne, the companys president, is a great bear of a man with a laid-back manner. He said gently into his walkie-talkie: Couples freezing out here. Can we get some help on a price?

title: American Said to Have Ties to Al Qaeda Is Denied Bail
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 21  An American convert to Islam who the government says took his family on jihad to Somalia and then lied to the F.B.I. was ordered held without bond Wednesday after a federal judge found sufficient evidence that he had been trained in weapons and bomb making by Al Qaeda.

title: Jeter Was Once Rebuked for Ties to Rodriguez
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 21  Chad Curtis collected 1,061 hits across 10 seasons in the major leagues, he hit a game-winning home run for the Yankees during the 1999 World Series and he was a part of the memorable team that won 125 games in 1998. But to some fans, Curtis is remembered mostly for being the teammate who dared to challenge Derek Jeter in public.

title: Saudi Arabia: 7 Return From Guantnamo
description: The Interior Ministry said seven Saudi nationals who had been detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, had been freed and transferred to Saudi custody. A ministry spokesman, quoted by the official Saudi Press Agency, said the mens families would be allowed to visit with them. About 60 Saudis held at Guantnamo have been released; more than 65 are believed to remain.

title: Bank of Japan Raises Short-Term Interest Rates
description: TOKYO, Feb. 21  Wednesdays rate increase by the Japanese central bank doubled short-term borrowing costs, but it hardly seems enough to interrupt the huge flow of cheap yen out of Japan that now helps prop up global markets, economists said.

title: John Lederle, 94, UMass President, Dies
description: John W. Lederle, who as president of the University of Massachusetts in the 1960s led the transformation of a rural campus with fewer than 6,000 students in Amherst into a major research center with more than 18,000 students and who also directed the development of two campuses, died on Feb. 13 near his home in Naples, Fla. He was 94.

title: Staten Island: Indictment in Killing
description: A retired New York City police sergeant has been indicted on murder charges in the shooting of his ex-wife last month in a park-and-ride lot off the West Shore Expressway in Pleasant Plains, prosecutors said yesterday. The retired sergeant, John Galtieri, 61, of Punta Gorda, Fla., has also been charged with stalking, said Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney. Mr. Galtieri is accused of shooting his ex-wife, Jeanne Kane, 58, of Staten Island, on Jan. 30. Mr. Galtieris car was pulled over in South Carolina, and he was arrested, Mr. Donovan said. New York prosecutors are seeking his extradition.

title: A Grown-Up Brouhaha Over a Book for Kids (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Maryland: Early Voting Advances
description: The State Senate, following the House, has approved changing the states Constitution to allow voters to cast ballots two weeks before Election Day. The amendment would need approval from voters in 2008. Democrats proposed the measure after the states highest court ruled that early voting violated the Constitution. Democrats say early voting would enable more people to vote, but Republicans have opposed it. Registered Democratic voters in the state outnumber Republicans roughly two to one.

title: Bush, in Talk-Show Manner, Promotes His Health Plan
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 21  President Bushs plan to expand health coverage by revamping the tax code has been pronounced dead by leading Democrats on Capitol Hill. But Mr. Bush, ever the optimist, forged ahead Wednesday, conducting a chat session here in Oprah Winfrey style with people who are uninsured.

title: In Hartford, Rebuked Justice Apologizes for Delaying News of 06 Ruling
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 21  Connecticuts former chief justice, William J. Sullivan, apologized repeatedly to lawmakers on Wednesday for delaying the release of a court opinion while deliberations on his successor were beginning, saying he realized that his actions had ended up derailing the appointment.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about the resurging residential real estate market in parts of New York City misstated the surname of a woman who has not been able to find a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan for less than $750,000. She is Katalin Staveley, not Shavely.

title: UConns Youth Is Served With a Berth in the Big East Tournament
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 21  For the young Huskies, a bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament remains a long shot, but Connecticut is at least keeping its hopes alive. With its fourth win in its last six games, a 65-55 victory Wednesday night over Rutgers, Connecticut clinched a spot in the Big East tournament, improved its overall record to a respectable 17-10 and is beginning to build some momentum with the postseason approaching.

title: First, the Madcap Spirits, Then a Turn for the Haunted
description: There are so many marvelous elements in Vicky Shicks program at Dance Theater Workshop this week that its tempting simply to list the collaborators, gratefully offer your thanks and call it a night.

title: Bathroom Dcor Takes a Look Back
description: Urban Archaeology is now known mostly as a temple to the new-but-old-looking bathroom, selling tiles, marble or copper-clad free-standing baths, sinks and other accouterments.

title: The New Kitchen Is Done. So Why Cant I Be Happy?
description: AFTER finishing a renovation that nearly doubled the size of her house in Mountain View, Calif., Anne Toth should have been celebrating with Champagne from her new G.E. Monogram refrigerator.

title: Home Lenders Hit by Higher Default Rates
description: The toll is mounting for lenders that operate in the riskiest, and until recently, the fastest-growing, segment of the mortgage business.

title: Spitzer to Review Pataki Panels Choice for Racing Franchise
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who wields the most power in deciding the fate of New Yorks thoroughbred racing franchise, does not feel bound to ask the State Legislature to award it to the group recommended by a Pataki administration committee, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: Splits Emerge Between U.S. and Europe Over Aid for Palestinians
description: BERLIN, Feb. 21  Fractures between the United States and Europe began to appear Wednesday over whether the new Palestinian unity government was likely to receive international economic support even as the Middle East peace negotiators officially continued their wait-and-see approach.

title: Zimbabwe: Takeover of Diamond Mines
description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, below, said he plans to take control of the nations diamond mines in response to allegations of smuggling and a diamond rush in the eastern district of Marange. Zimbabwe has two diamond mines, one known as Murowa, owned by Rio Tinto and RioZim, and the other as River Ranch, which is held by private investors. Only government will mine diamonds, Mr. Mugabe said in a televised interview on Tuesday. It is unclear whether Mr. Mugabes pronouncement will be made law, said David Murangari, chief executive of the Chamber of Mines, a business association that represents most mining companies in the country. Andrew Cranswick, chief executive of African Consolidated Resources, criticized the measure. If the state takeover of diamond mines is passed into law, it will destroy diamond exploration in this country, he said.

title: Ordinary, but in a Heroic Fantasy Kind of Way
description: One normally wouldnt go to a New York bail bondsman for help in searching for the ancient treasure of the Knights Templar, but George Stobbart is no ordinary bail bondsman.

title: Strong Spade Suit Helps Decide a Hard-Fought Match in Japan
description: The 12th NEC Bridge Festival was held Feb. 7 to 12 in Yokohama, Japan. In the main event for the NEC Cup, 47 teams played eight 20-board matches in a Swiss format, from which eight teams qualified for the knockout stage. The quarterfinals and semifinals were over 40 boards, the final over 64.

title: An Evening of Piano Quartets, Introspective Yet Commanding
description: The 92nd Street Y has been trying to liven up its chamber music series by inviting more guest players  ideally relatively starry ones  to perform with members of the core ensemble, the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio. On Tuesday two-thirds of the trio  the violinist Jaime Laredo and the cellist Sharon Robinson  were joined by Peter Serkin, the pianist, and Steven Tenenbom, the violist, for a program devoted mostly to piano quartets.

title: Rivals at Democratic Presidential Forum Push Positions on Iraq War Into Spotlight
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 21  Two Democratic presidential rivals of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton applied more pressure on her over Iraq on Wednesday, extolling the virtue of admitting mistakes about the war  which she has not done  and comparing politicians who do not with President Bush.

title: Whole Foods Makes Offer for a Smaller Rival
description: Stung by competition and investor expectations, Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, was expected to announce another quarter of rather mundane earnings yesterday, at least by the standards of a company that has experienced more than a decade of breakneck growth.

title: Italian Prime Minister Resigns
description: ROME, Feb. 21  Italys fragile government snapped suddenly on Wednesday under the weight of its own internal divisions as well as a broader skepticism about the European role in the worldwide fight against terrorism.

title: Smith to Be Buried in Bahamas Near Her Son
description: A judge in Broward County, Fla., urged this afternoon that Anna Nicole Smith be buried in the Bahamas, where her son is interred, and the parties who were arguing over her remains later agreed.

title: Jury in Libby Case Begins Deliberations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  The jury deciding the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. began deliberating late Wednesday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Sports Business column yesterday about the elaborate rituals of boxing promotions misidentified the fighter who was involved in a scuffle with Marco Antonio Barrera while on a publicity tour for a bout in 2002. He was Erik Morales, not Fernando Vargas.

title: New York Tops 8 Big Cities in Taxes, Study Shows
description: New York City has long had a notorious reputation for high taxes, but an official analysis released yesterday shows just how much the city stands out in this regard: State and local taxes swallow $9.02 out of every $100 in household and business income, putting New Yorks tax burden far above those of the eight other American cities with populations over one million.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL In her first Oscar salute, Ms. Winfrey asked three Academy Award-winning actors to interview the Oscar winner theyd most like to hear from. The pairings: Julia Roberts meets George Clooney at his Los Angeles home; Nicole Kidman takes on Russell Crowe in the Beverly Hills Hotel; and Jamie Foxx interviews Sidney Poitier on the stage where he won his Oscar for Lilies of the Field in 1963.

title: Colombia: Gunman Kills 2 Performing Clowns
description: An unknown gunman killed two circus clowns in Ccuta, on the border with Venezuela, before a crowd of about 20 children and adults. The traveling circus had been performing for more than a week. The shootings, which follow the killing of another clown in Ccuta last year, drew attention even in a country hardened by one of the worlds highest homicide rates because it took place in front of children.

title: Balms for the Blue in the Face
description: EVERY winter, outdoor athletes face a challenge: how to protect their faces. The combination of cold temperature, wind chill and low humidity creates perfect conditions for dry, irritated skin.

title: Moms Mad. And Shes Organized.
description: A BABY was passed around like the hors doeuvres  in this case, bruschetta, a fruit plate  among the 10 mothers who crowded into Ann Clarks Sacramento home on a Tuesday night this month. No matter if the baby was crying; this was a child-friendly crowd.

title: In Writing, as in Murder, a Hammer Is So Handy
description: EASTPORT, Me.

title: Consumer Price Gauges Rise More Than Expected
description: The Federal Reserve may expect more subdued inflation this year, but a small jump in consumer prices last month served as a reminder that those expectations are still far from being fulfilled.

title: Grades Rise as Reading Skills Drop in H.S. Study
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Todays high school students are taking seemingly tougher courses and earning better grades, but their reading skills are not improving, according to the results of a national assessment released here today that cited grade inflation as a possible explanation.

title: Newark: Conviction in Police Officers Shooting
description: A Newark man was convicted of attempted murder in State Superior Court yesterday for shooting a Newark police officer in October 2004, prosecutors said. The man, Omar Bridges, 27, was convicted of shooting Officer Eduardo Patinho, 36, in the face and shoulder after a high-speed chase, said Paula T. Dow, the Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Bridges was shot in the stomach during the gunfight and later arrested in Pennsylvania while undergoing treatment at a hospital. He faces up to 40 years in state prison.

title: Lesson One: The Price the Contractor Quotes Is an Estimate
description: IN a recent letter to her readers, Dominique Browning, the longtime editor of House & Garden magazine, wrote about the agony of renovation, but suggested her experience was so painful that she preferred not to give details. Im still in shock and not ready to talk about it, she wrote.

title: U.S. Says It Found Chemicals at Iraqi Bomb Factory
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 22  American troops on a raid near Falluja discovered three car bombs under construction in a bomb-making factory that appeared intended to be used with chemicals, the chief American military spokesman in Baghdad said Thursday.

title: Bad Taste Is Their Kryptonite
description: AMONG the unlikely superheroes to be introduced tomorrow at a comic book convention at the Javits Convention Center are a skateboarding cyborg who battles terrorism, three cutesy girls from the intergalactic military police and one high school student who is capable of shape-shifting. But those characters come across as rather two-dimensional when compared with a team called Seven, whose most substantial superpowers could be described as a sensitivity to astrology and a keen sense of fashion.

title: Recovered Artworks Heading to Auction
description: A year ago the settlement was hailed as one of the largest restitutions of art seized by the Nazis. Now about 170 old master paintings returned to the heirs of Jacques Goudstikker, a prominent Dutch dealer who fled Amsterdam in 1940, are to be offered at Christies in three sales, beginning in April in New York. The auction house says the paintings, many on view in Dutch museums and government buildings since the 1950s, could fetch from $22 million to $35 million.

title: In Both Parties, 2008 Politeness Falls to Infighting
description: The sun was not yet up yesterday, and members of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign team were confronted with the kind of attack that most infuriates them: one questioning the character of Mrs. Clinton and her husband.

description: The Worm Turns

title: Wimbledon to Pay Women and Men Equal Prize Money
description: It has been a long time coming  39 years, to be exact  but womens tennis players will receive equal prize money to the men at Wimbledon this year.

title: Lofty Hopes, Suspended
description: It was a simple pitch: Investors would put little to no money down and take out construction loans that a developer would use to build modest homes in a fast-growing stretch of Southwest Florida. When finished, the homes would be flipped for tidy profits of $30,000 to $40,000 apiece.

title: That Drought in Southwest May Be Normal, Report Says
description: The Colorado River Basin is more prone to drought than had been thought, a panel of experts reported yesterday, and as the climate warms and the population in the region grows, pressure on water supplies will become greater.

title: Dodgeballs and Jokes May Seem Too Close for Comfort
description: In a lot of ways, David Price is the struggling New York actor from central casting. He once had a role on the NBC show Ed, he said, but now he works as a nanny between auditions. He has to buy his trendy clothes in thrift stores. He is 30 and hopes his big break is around the corner.

title: Far From Music Capitals, an Ohio Conservatory Fosters Contemporary Sounds
description: Its a little like Haydn must have felt at Esterhazy, said Lewis Nielson, a professor of composition at the Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio, explaining some of the factors that make the institution a hotbed for new music. We arent isolated any more than he was, but just isolated enough to focus our energies.

description: Q. How can I create a bedroom in my studio without building a permanent wall?

description: Orchids and Chocolate

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Playing and Winning Together in Louisianas Sabine Parish
description: PLEASANT HILL, La., Feb. 18  After nine hours of basketball, the air-conditioning system seemed to have a nervous breakdown. Still, more than 500 fans shoehorned into the tiny, sheet-metal gym at Pleasant Hill High School on Saturday night. When the bleachers filled, some people grabbed folding chairs. Others sat on the floor along the baseline. Flashes of yellow rippled through the crowd as spectators fanned themselves with a booklet of team rosters.

title: Top of the Heap: A Business Built on Salvage
description: SALVAGE men tell good stories. The other day Gil Shapiro, whose high-end salvage-turned-reproduction company, Urban Archaeology, is a case study of the architectural remnant business as it has evolved over the past four decades, described his first purchase, as a high school senior in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.

title: South Dakota: Abortion Bill Rejected
description: A bill that passed the House last week and would have outlawed most abortions in the state has failed a crucial Senate vote. The State Affairs Committee voted 8 to 1 not to send the bill to the floor. Last year, the Legislature passed a law banning almost all abortions, but voters rejected it in a referendum. The new bill included exceptions for cases when a womans health was at risk or in cases of rape or incest.

title: Italian Fashion in the Time of the Trollop
description: Milan

title: Taking Your Presentation, and the Projectors Utility, to a Whole New Level
description: If the Three Stooges were around in the age of PowerPoint, one can only imagine the result. But a small piece of hardware from NewSoft can allow any threesome of presenters to get through a meeting with nary an eye-gouge.

title: Even for Rungs Below the Top, Goldman Bonuses Were Hefty
description: Goldman Sachs already has the highest-paid chief executive on Wall Street. Now, even his lieutenants make more than nearly all other C.E.O.s on the Street.

title: Corzine to Propose a New Jersey Budget With No Tax Increase and More School Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21  Less than a year after he shut down state government to balance the budget with a sales-tax increase, Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to propose a budget on Thursday that would avoid raising taxes and increase local school aid for the first time in at least five years.

title: Brooklyn: Murder-Suicide in Canarsie
description: A husband and wife were found fatally shot yesterday in their home in Canarsie, the police said, and their deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide. A note suggesting marital problems was discovered, according to the police. It is thought that the man, Keith Davis, 43, shot his wife, Hester, 42, then turned the gun on himself, the police said. The couples two sons, 16 and 17, found the bodies yesterday morning in a bedroom of the semiattached home at 1248 East 105th Street, the police said. Mr. Davis was found lying on the floor near a .357 handgun, and Mrs. Davis was lying in bed; each had a gunshot wound to the head, the police said. Officials said Ms. Davis recently retired after a 20-year career with the citys Correction Department. Neighbors said Mr. Davis drove a city bus.

title: Patent Held by Genentech Is Revoked by Government
description: The Patent and Trademark Office has decided to revoke a fundamental patent held by Genentech, the biotechnology company, that was at the center of a recent Supreme Court decision.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 13 about Gary B. Pruitt, chief executive of the McClatchy newspaper chain, referred incorrectly to 55 jobs that are being outsourced to India by The Boston Globe, which is owned by The New York Times Company. They are support jobs, not newsroom positions. (The Globe has said it is eliminating 17 newsroom jobs and 2 positions on the editorial page staff.)

title: Irans President Vows to Keep Enriching Uranium Despite Expiration of U.N. Deadline to Stop
description: Unbowed by international pressure, Irans president vowed yesterday to press ahead with the countrys uranium enrichment program, even as a United Nations deadline to shut the program down passed.

title: IPods Groovy Factor
description: WHAT do flying plastic pigs, dancing daisies and robotic Barbie dolls have in common? An iPod.

title: The Poor Are Different From You and Me. Or Are They?
description: Since William T. Vollmanns idea of a long book is one that fills seven volumes (Rising Up and Rising Down, his extended critique of violence), its reasonable to wonder what he regards as a short one. Poor People provides an answer.

title: Report Finds Iran in Breach of U.N. Order
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  In open defiance of the United Nations, Iran is steadily expanding  rather than freezing  its efforts to enrich uranium, the International Atomic Energy Agency reported today. The findings have prompted the Bush administration to press for more severe sanctions against Iran, at a moment of greatly increased tensions between Washington and Tehran.

title: Hospitals Outline Plan for Health Care for All Americans
description: Joining the national debate over the 47 million people without health insurance, a group of the nations largest for-profit hospital chains plan to propose on Thursday that individuals be required to have basic health coverage.

title: Camcorders That Come With Footnotes
description: What have you got against videotape, anyway?

description: Stung by competition and investor expectations, Whole Foods Markets, the natural-foods grocer, was expected to announce another quarter of rather mundane earnings Wednesday, at least by the standards of a company that has experienced more than a decade of breakneck growth.

title: 12-Year-Old Dies in Harlem, Apparently in 5-Story Fall
description: In an apartment building in Harlem where residents have long looked out for one another, they were especially protective of 12-year-old Jonathan Batista.

title: Inquiry Is Going to Camp
description: Manny Ramrez, who received permission from the Boston Red Sox to report late to spring training for family reasons, was scheduled to attend a car auction in Atlantic City on Saturday, according to the promoter of the auction.

title: So You Want to Run ...
description: I want you to know Ive shelved the idea of writing a book called The Idiots Guide to Winning the Republican Presidential Nomination. But that doesnt mean I dont have ideas. Here are a few rules the G.O.P. contenders should follow if they want to sweep this thing.

title: American Liberty at the Precipice
description: In another low moment for American justice, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that detainees held at the prison camp at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, do not have the right to be heard in court. The ruling relied on a shameful law that President Bush stampeded through Congress last fall that gives dangerously short shrift to the Constitution.

title: Everything You Knew About Good Abs May Be Wrong
description: IT used to be that the only time someone told you to suck in your gut was when the family had lined up for a photo at the Grand Canyon.

title: For Doors From the Early 1900s, Step Right In
description: Open since the late 1990s, Demolition Depot conflates two businesses, an uptown warehouse space and Irreplaceable Artifacts, Urban Archaeologys old East Village competitor, whose building fell down, rather infamously, in 2000. It may be the best local source for early-20th-century doors and sinks, particularly if you are trying to match something in a prewar apartment. A pair of 1920s French doors is $750; a five-foot cast-iron tub is $850. Last Saturday a couple shopping for a summer house in Ontario liked a nickel pantry sink from the 1920s ($3,000). In front of it was a backless stainless steel medicine cabinet that was a ringer for Urban Archaeologys Lenox cabinet (a reproduction of a cabinet in Helena Rubinsteins apartment, and that stores best-selling item). Evan Blum, Demolition Depots owner, said his was a copy of one found in Cary Grants house; this one had a slight defect, he said, and was discounted to $500. Future copies will cost $1,200.

title: His Father May Write About It, but Newhan Plays the Game
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 21  The father and son walked into Yankee Stadium together and went down a narrow stairwell last August. At the bottom, they paused.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Jacqueline Melendez Rivera, a New York City police officer accused of covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn, misidentified her neighborhood at one point. She lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn  not Park Slope.

title: During Climb, Riders Play Catch-Up
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 21  Some 40 miles into Stage 3 of the Tour of California on Wednesday, Chris Wherry, who rides for the Toyota-United cycling team, was worried. A group of 17 riders had broken away from the main pack on what is probably the toughest stage of the eight-day race  a 94.6-mile trip from Stockton to San Jose  and it was now nearly four minutes ahead.

title: No Sex, Please, Were Engaged: Couples Who Wait for the Wedding
description: When premarital sex no longer scintillates on MTVs many reality shows, the channels think tank has done right to consult its man-bites-dog playbook. There on Page 1 it has found a new way to excite the channels base: presexual marriage.

title: Settlement Lets Apple Use iPhone
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21  Apple and Cisco Systems have decided that a name is not worth fighting over.

title: After 45 Years, Lorin Maazel Is to Conduct at the Metropolitan Opera
description: It took only 45 years, but Lorin Maazel is returning to conduct at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Abu Ghraib and Its Multiple Failures
description: The problem with the Fox thriller 24 is not that it justifies torture but that it fosters the illusion that the American government is good at it.The practices of Abu Ghraib suggest the opposite. The mystery of that shameful episode was not the cruelty of American troops assigned there. After the initial disbelief over the obscene snapshots, their smile-for-the-camera barbarity turned out to be another painful reminder that the banality of evil has no borders.

title: Celebrating a Saxophonists Art and Heart
description: The memorial program for the saxophonist Michael Brecker that filled Town Hall on Tuesday night kept landing on the theme of generosity. Mr. Brecker died of leukemia on Jan. 13 at 57. During his illness he enlisted family members and friends in sending out a call for bone-marrow donors  not just for himself  that resulted in tens of thousands of donor registrations. His friends in jazz and pop music all implied that this wasnt just an isolated case of conscientiousness.

title: NASA Deal With Virgin
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced an two-year agreement with the Virgin Group to explore collaboration on spacesuits, heat shields for spaceships and rocket motors. No payments are involved, NASA said.

title: Keeping Bees Among Us
description: Mention honeybees, and most people think two things: stinging and industriousness. A beekeeper thinks: jubilation, harmony, the civilization of insects. Nothing in nature is more vibrant  literally  than a strong hive on the increase in late spring and early summer. And few things are more depressing than opening the lid on a hive and pulling apart the supers, the boxes where bees raise young and store honey, and finding that the colony inside has died.

title: Beyond the Body, Making Spirit Move
description: In the middle of Association Noa/Company Vincent Mantsoes Men-Jaro at the Kumble Theater at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University on Tuesday night, Mr. Mantsoe performed a solo of such fierce stamping, writhing intensity that he appeared to enter into a trancelike state. He was extricated by another dancer, who gripped him by the shoulders, slowing his ritualized turns, then supported his sagging body until consciousness seemed to return. After a while the two began to dance in unison, once again simply (or not so simply) performers on a stage.

title: Celia Franca, 85, Dies; Founded National Ballet of Canada
description: Celia Franca, the London-born founder of the National Ballet of Canada and a pioneering figure in Canadian dance, died on Monday in Ottawa. She was 85.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,136 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: U.S. Tries to Ease Concerns in Russia on Antimissile Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Bush administration officials tried Wednesday to tamp down Russian concerns, voiced in strikingly harsh terms, over American plans to base missile defenses in Eastern Europe.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with an article on Tuesday about the rescue of three climbers and a dog stranded on Mount Hood in Oregon carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Don Ryan of The Associated Press  not Doug Beghtel of The Oregonian, via Associated Press.

title: Bronx: Racehorse Euthanized After Injury
description: A thoroughbred racehorse was euthanized yesterday after his leg was seriously injured as he was being transported from a stable in Ghent, N.Y., to a track in the metropolitan area. The horse, a 3-year-old gelding named Please Be Quick, was in a trailer on the Cross-Bronx Expressway about 4 p.m. when the driver noticed that one of the animals hind legs had broken through to the outside, said Joseph Pentangelo, assistant director of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Veterinarians at Belmont Park in Elmont, N.Y., decided that the injuries were too severe for the horse to be saved, Mr. Pentangelo said.

title: Canada: Quebec Campaign Revisits Separation
description: With polls favoring his Liberal Party, Jean Charest, the premier of Quebec, called a provincial election for March 26. The election that brought Mr. Charest to power in 2003 was the first in some 40 years that did not spotlight the French-speaking provinces relationship with the rest of Canada. But Andr Boisclair, the leader of the separatist Parti Qubcois, has promised to hold a referendum on taking the province out of Canada if he is elected.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Thursday about Thomas Fairchild, a federal appeals court judge who once ran for the Senate against Joseph R. McCarthy, referred imprecisely in several references to his actions as a judge in the case of the Chicago Seven protesters, who were convicted on charges of crossing state lines to incite a riot. He sat on the three-judge panel that heard oral arguments on their appeal, and on behalf of that panel he wrote the opinion that vacated the convictions and ordered a new trial. He did not by himself overturn or vacate the convictions or order a new trial. The writing of the opinion, not the case itself, was originally assigned to another judge.

title: The Japanese Gyroball Mystery
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 21  Most major league pitchers throw a fastball, a curveball, a slider and a changeup. Some mix in a sinker. The experimental ones use a knuckleball. None of them throws a gyroball, at least not on purpose.

title: Telling Time, and a Little About Yourself
description: THE human eye is really rather amazing. Just consider how, across a busy power-lunch restaurant or a crowded conference room, a well-trained male eye can zero in on the wrist of another man, potential friend or foe, and instantly size him up by the square inch or so of information held in place by a strap of metal or leather.

title: Rhode Island Steps Toward Recognizing Same-Sex Marriage
description: BOSTON, Feb. 21  The Rhode Island attorney general said Wednesday that same-sex marriages performed in Massachusetts, the sole state where they are legal, should be recognized in Rhode Island.

title: Hospital Group Offers Plan on Health Coverage for All
description: Joining the national debate over the 47 million people without health insurance, a group of the largest commercial hospital chains plans to propose today that individuals be required to have basic health coverage.

description: Forget the mad scrum over elite colleges. Liam Walsh, age 10, is in a frenzied battle for a sixth-grade seat in a Manhattan public school.

description: IF the 20th century was known in marketing circles as the advertising century, the 21st may be the advertising measurement century.

title: Maliki Fires Official for Criticizing Response to Rape Account
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 21  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki fired a top Sunni official on Wednesday after he criticized the governments handling of a young Sunni womans account of being raped by members of the Shiite-dominated security forces.

title: Outfitters to Presidents, Preppies, Me
description: THE last time I was at Brooks Brothers, 23 years ago, my mom took me there to be fitted for a suit during her You Need Some Nice Clothes campaign. I remember her tugging at my cuffs while I stood there humming the Go-Gos to myself. Not much has changed. I have Vacation on my iPod, and I still need nice clothes.

title: Campbell Moses Jr., 89, Who Linked Doctors Through TV, Dies
description: Dr. Campbell Moses, an internist and a former medical director of the American Heart Association who in the 1950s and 60s made innovative educational television programs intended for fellow physicians, died on Feb. 11 in Upper Saddle River, N.J. He was 89.

title: State Ousts a Town Justice and Criticizes the System
description: In court one December night in 2003, the town justice in Cuyler, N.Y., told the towns lawyer that she would postpone four zoning cases. She set a January date for the next proceeding.

description: An article yesterday about Texans in the Bush administration misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, one of three cabinet members from Texas. He is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez.

description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an art review of Family Pictures, at the Guggenheim Museum, referred incompletely to the photograph described as Mom and Dad, by Janine Antoni. The image shown is part of a triptych entitled Mom and Dad; it is not the complete work.

title: Britain to Trim Iraq Force by 1,600 in Coming Months
description: LONDON, Feb. 21  Prime Minister Tony Blair announced Wednesday that up to 1,600 of the roughly 7,100 British troops in southern Iraq would begin to withdraw in coming months, a sharp contrast to the continuing American troop buildup in Baghdad.

title: Moms Mad. And Shes Organized.
description: A generation of mothers who are largely perceived as postfeminist in every way, from sex to economic discrimination, has begun a consciousness-raising that is almost old-fashioned were it not for the technology involved. Raised to believe that girls could accomplish anything, these women have reached parenthood, only to find they faced many of the same pay, equity and work-family balance issues that were being fought over decades before.

description: Walter Bobbie and Judy Kaye will star when "Encores!" revives the 1932 Irving Berlin and Moss Hart musical, "Face the Music," at City Center for five performances from March 29 through April 1.

title: A Modern Minstrel Show
description: At a ceremony in Hollywood on Monday night, the playwright Jason Christophe White was presented with the best playwright award by the Beverly Hills/Hollywood branch of the N.A.A.C.P. for a local production of his show "The Dance: The History of American Minstrelsy."
