title: The Suitors for Chrysler Grow Sparse
description: DaimlerChrysler would prefer to sell the struggling Chrysler Group in one piece rather than let potential bidders pick and choose among its assets, The New York Times reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the situation. But it is hard to find anyone who will admit to being interested in buying Chrysler, at least before J.P. Morgan Chase sends out the offer book that it is preparing on the struggling American car company.

title: State Bank in Russia Sells Most of Its Stock
description: Russias state savings bank, Sberbank, was poised to raise $8.8 billion in a secondary stock offering that closed on Wednesday, a government official said. The offering would be the second largest in Russian history, after that of the state-controlled oil company Rosneft, which raised $10.6 billion in an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange in July.

title: Raymond James Fined in Lack of Oversight
description: NASD, the brokerage firm regulator, said Wednesday that it had fined Raymond James Financial $2.75 million for failing to supervise more than 1,100 branch managers nationwide, including one who urged an 84-year-old woman to put most of her money into a single aggressive mutual fund. According to NASD, Raymond James let branch managers supervise their own sales activities from April 2000 to September 2004 and failed to assess properly whether the investment advice was sound.

title: U.S. Wont Seek to Restore Fraud Conviction of Ex-Westar Officials
description: The government will not try to reinstate the fraud convictions of two former executives of Westar Energy, prosecutors said Wednesday. The United States attorneys office in Topeka, Kan., said it would not ask an appeals court in Denver to reconsider its decision in January to reverse the convictions of the executives, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake. The appeals court said that evidence at the trial did not justify the guilty verdicts.

title: U.S. Judge Voids Guilty Verdict of Big Board Specialist in G.E.
description: A judge took the unusual step Wednesday of reversing a jury verdict, finding that the evidence did not support the conviction of a former New York Stock Exchange supervisor who once oversaw trading in General Electric stock.

title: Veritas-S.E.C. Settlement for $30 Million
description: Securities regulators have fined Veritas Software, a business software maker, $30 million to settle accusations that the company engaged in an assortment of accounting schemes in the years leading to its sale to Symantec in 2005. The civil penalty, disclosed Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was announced four and a half years after regulators opened an inquiry into a deal that Veritas negotiated with AOL in 2000.

title: Citigroup May Take Nikko Matters into Its Own Hands
description: Citigroup may seek to take over its Japanese investment-banking venture with Nikko Cordial after an accounting scandal led to the resignation of six top Nikko executives, Bloomberg News reported. Nikko, Japans third-biggest securities firm, admitted to overstating earnings in 2004 and an outside panel found evidence of fraud. Furthermore, the Tokyo-based company, whose shares have dropped 19 percent since Dec. 15, may lose its stock-market listing.

title: Operator of Parking Lots Accepts Bid
description: Central Parking, an owner and operator of parking lots, said Wednesday that it had accepted a takeover bid of about $733 million from a private equity consortium led by Kohlberg and Company. The deal with the consortium, which also includes Lubert-Adler and Chrysalis Capital Partners, values the parking and transportation services company at $22.53 a share, a 6 percent premium over its closing stock price on Tuesday.

title: Babcock Posts 2nd Quarter Profit Increase
description: Babcock & Brown, Australias second-biggest investment bank, said second-half profit increased 84 percent after the firm started new funds and earned more from managing property and energy assets. Net income rose to 188 million Australian dollars ($148 million) in the six months ended Dec. 31, from 102 million Australian dollars a year earlier, the Sydney-based company said Thursday.

title: Chinese Financial News Service to Offer Shares
description: Xinhua Finance Media, a provider of financial news and data on Chinas markets, plans to raise as much as $371.5 million in a share offering in the United States to repay debt and finance acquisitions. The company plans to sell 23.1 million American depositary shares for $12 to $14 each and has applied to list them on the Nasdaq Stock Market under the symbol XFML, Shanghai-based Xinhua Finance Media said in a regulatory filing in the United States.

title: Buyout Shops to Take Rexel to Market
description: Rexel, the worlds biggest distributor of electrical equipment, filed initial public offering documents with the French regulator. The filing is the first step toward a share sale, the Paris-based company said in a statement Thursday. The offering comes two years after Rexel was purchased for 3.7 billion euros ($4.9 billion) by the buyout unit of Merrill Lynch and private-equity firms Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Eurazeo.

title: Pillsbury Winthrop Seeks to Recover Back Pay from Ex-Partners
description: Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, a global law firm based in New York, has asked at least eight former partners to return a portion or all of last years earnings within 30 days, The Recorder reports. Most say they have no intention of paying back anything, even if it means going to court.

title: Morgan Stanley to Carve its Own Path in India
description: Morgan Stanley, deciding it wants a bigger piece of the pie, ended its joint venture in India with JM Financial. Morgan will pay $445 million for the seven-year-old ventures business trading stocks on behalf of foreign and local institutions, while JM Financial will pay $20 million for the ventures investment banking business.

title: Video Sharing
description: Theres been a bit of a change so you can now share the recent video about Jimmy Carters fight against river blindness with your friends and family who dont subscribe to TimesSelect. Its easy to share. On the video page, just click the e-mail this video link.

title: Morgan Stanley Poaches Rivals for Latin America Office
description: Morgan Stanley hired eight people from Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch for its Latin American private wealth division, bringing total additions at the unit to 27 so far this year.

title: Friendship Dairies on the Block
description: Friendship Dairies, a New York-area maker of cottage cheese and sour cream, is close to wrapping up an auction run by Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, according to The Deal.com. Friendships annual revenue is around $90 million to $100 million, and its Ebitda is around $11 million, the report said. The companys products, which it describes as all-natural, are a refrigerator-shelf staple in the Northeast and have made incursions farther south. Daisy Brand of Dallas, a 90-year-old, family-owned maker of sour cream, is among the interested buyers, The Deal said.

title: Imperium Raises $113 Million From VCs for Biofuel
description: A biofuel developer, Imperium Renewables, raised $113 million in new equity to build four biodiesel processing facilities in a deal that highlights a maturing financing market for alternative fuel development, The Deal reported. The new money brings in a slew of private equity and institutional investors to round out what will be the largest single investment round for a biodiesel fuel developer.

title: Blackstone Continues to Unload Equity Office Properties
description: Even with the sale of more than $18 billion in assets of Equity Office Properties Trust, Blackstone Group does not appear to be done dealing. In the latest sell off of properties it acquired in the biggest leveraged buyout in history, Blackstone sold 24 properties in downtown Los Angeles and Orange County, Calif., to Maguire Properties for $2.88 billion.

title: Startup Valuations Show Strong Growth
description: The median valuation of venture-backed companies in the United States, before the capital infusion, climbed to $18.5 million in 2006, the highest level since 2000, Dow Jones VentureOne reported. Startups are getting higher values because the opportunities for a profitable exit through an initial public offering or a sale have improved, an analyst told The Red Herring. Some of the largest gains were among information technology companies, whose median valuation has doubled from 2003.

title: General Atlantic Mulls London Listing for Xchanging
description: General Atlantic, the private equity firm, is considering an initial public offering of Xchanging, a British outsourcing and processing business that ranks as one of its largest European investments. Xchanging, which General Atlantic formed in 1998, has been in discussions with a number of investment banks about an I.P.O. on the London Stock Exchange that could value the group at about 500 million pounds, The Financial Times reported. However, the paper said, those plans could still unravel.

title: Dean Foods to Go Shopping
description: Dean Foods, which grew into the nations largest dairy producer through a steady stream of mergers and acquisitions, may be testing the waters again. When asked at an analysts conference Wednesday whether the company was planning to use its rich coffers for a dividend or an acquisition, Deans chief financial officer, Jack Callahan, indicated that the time for more deals was nigh.

title: In Muslims We Do Not Trust
description: A couple of updates this morning from the clash of civilizations, otherwise known as our department of Shiny Happy People Holding Hands:

title: Mixed Media
description: Images from the International Fair of New Art.

title: Cisco Connects With Reactivity
description: Cisco Systems said Wednesday it will spend $135 million in cash and options to buy Reactivity, a small company that makes equipment to help route XML Internet traffic. Reactivitys equipment is designed to help companies more easily and quickly deploy XML (Extensible Markup Language), a standard for Web documents. The company, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., was founded in 1998 and has 56 employees.

title: Conrad Black Sues Author of Sadistic Biography
description: It seems to be all litigation all the time for Conrad Black these days. In the latest courtroom battle, however, Mr. Black is the one doing the suing. The former head of the Hollinger media empire is demanding 11 million Canadian dollars ($9.5 million) in libel damages over a critical biography that depicts the fallen press baron as an overweight teenager from a loveless home who grows up to be a criminal sociopath.

title: Exploration Fires Up Deal for Output
description: Exploration said Wednesday that it would acquire a Houston-based exploration and production company for $95.6 million in a cash and stock deal that would be the biggest transaction in the companys history. The acquisition of privately held Output Exploration will double the San Antonio-based companys proven reserves and boost its current oil and gas production by almost two-thirds.

title: NASA Teams Up With Virgin Galactic
description: NASA and Virgin Galactic on Wednesday signed an agreement to explore the possibility of working together to develop new spacesuits, hybrid rocket motors and other space technology. Under the two-year memorandum of understanding, neither the NASA Ames Research Center nor Virgin Galactic would have to pay fees or fund the exploratory collaboration.

title: Reports of a 3i British Flip Provokes Outrage
description: Reports that the London private equity shop 3i Group  is in exclusive talks with Australias Macquarie Bank about the sale of National Car Parks, a business it acquired from crosstown buyout rival Cinven just 18 months ago, has met with heated words on the evils of private equity. News of the possible flip stoked union anger as workers at National Car Parks went on strike in north London to protest the refusal of 3i to recognize the union.

title: Ronald Burkle Harvests His Wild Oats
description: After stocking up on shares of Wild Oats Markets, Ronald W. Burkle is set to check out at a tidy profit. Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, agreed Wednesday to pay $565 million for Wild Oats, a smaller competitor whose largest shareholder is Mr. Burkles investment firm, Yucaipa. At $18.50 a share, Whole Foods offer values Yucaipas nearly 18 percent stake at about $94.4 million. Yucaipa paid about $54 million, net of commissions, for its 5.1 milion shares, regulatory filings show.

title: Strain at Home
N.Y.U. Student Republicans Mount Jaunty (Racist?) Immigrant Hunt
description: Theyre not exactly descending upon Washington Square Park with horse and hound, but members of the College Republican club of New York University have certainly managed to offend some rather more proletarian sensibilities with their Find the Illegal Immigrant challenge, scheduled for today between 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.

title: No Ring. No Vote.
description: Married women outnumber single women at the voting booth in this country, cycle after cycle. Representing almost a quarter of the electorate, unmarried women are a political gold mine, according to Page Gardner, the founder and president of Womens Voices. Women Vote., a nonprofit that works to turn out this group. With an estimated 20 million not registered to vote, women on their own make up the largest non-voting bloc in the country.

title: Altman Brings Out the Best
description: This may be the Web, but the Bagger still cant relate in detail Julianne Moores charming, loving and very funny remarks at the tribute for Robert Altman at the Majestic Theater in New York on Tuesday. Lets just say that when the director told her she would have to do a nude scene in his 1993 film Short Cuts, she bragged that her status as a redhead was a natural, observable fact. Actually, Ms. Moore told the crowd at the Majestic, she doesnt remember saying anything of the kind. But Mr. Altman did and so she had to listen for years as he cackled his way through the story, which he embellished over time, telling it to reporters and friends.

title: The Time is Nigh
description: Later today, the Bagger will lock up his Oscar picks and post them for your viewing pleasure tomorrow. But for the time being, you can see where almost everyone is landing over at OscarWatch. Its a beautifully done color chart, but instead of clarifying the race, it demonstrates that this year people are going to be all over the road right up until the last minute.

title: Finally, Some Recognition for Winslet
description: You can use the Web site at Stardoll to get all dolled up for the Oscars, even if you have no place to go. The digital paper doll site  my, that sounds weird  says it has 5.5 million members, who seem to have pretty good taste in acting. Stardoll asked them who they thought deserved the best actress award, and over half of those who responded chose Kate Winslet.

title: Geffen and Grey: This Years Goobers
description: Patrick Goldstein, who writes for the Los Angeles Times, gets out the X-Acto knife and maims a few folks, among them those darn bloggers and David Geffen for coming away without a best picture nomination for Dreamgirls, a pet project of his for years. But it is Brad Grey who gets flayed with the most glee.

title: Getting Carded
description: Remember those lines at Walt Disney World where it looks short but gets longer the farther along you go? Getting Academy credentials at a hotel next to the Kodak Theater was like that. Eventually, the Bagger made it in front of the camera, where they took not one, but two pictures. He did not smile sufficiently for the first shot, so the woman doing the shooting said, Cmon, act like youre excited.

title: The 10,000 Foot View
description: The Bagger spent quite a bit of time winding his way through the hills of Los Angeles last night, looking for a party for Matthew Hiltzik, a guy with a Ph.D. in the theromodynamics of spin and the head of the American arm of Freud Communications, an international public relations company. Mr. Hiltzik used to work for Harvey Weinstein and has a lot of pals in the business, including Jason Blum, a producer, who offered the use of his amazing home in the hills.

title: The Ivy League Takes a Break From Presidential Politics
Pickup Pix
description: Great lines at even greater prices.  "Didn't I see you at Miami Basel?"

title: A Cubist Family Portrait
description: A bit of patience is required to get through "The Taste of Tea," but patience is often rewarded, and it certainly is by this droll and oddly touching film by Katsuhito Ishii. The movie is a family portrait as painted by a moderately demented Cubist: the family involved is nothing like yours, yet somehow, in its fractured way, exactly like yours.

title: A Week in the Life of Ars Nova
description: A look at the performers, playwrights and crew members who work at the New York theatrical outpost Ars Nova.

title: My Life in Pictures
description: The stylist and designer Patricia Field wasn't always a redhead - we have proof!

title: Will the Next President Want Even More Power?
description: Comments from two different writers about two different presidential candidates suggest that, in opinionland at least, a politicians views on executive power are the most important matter for examination during the 2008 campaign. Slate editor Jacob Weisberg, a New Yorker, says a Giuliani White House would be a scary place. Giuliani was a hero on 9/11, Weisberg concedes, but on other days he was a self-sabotaging, thin-skinned bully. To put it more bluntly, we know hes a bit of a dictator. Weisberg writes:

title: Speculation Unleashed
description: Tales of Florida real estate speculation gone wild used to feature stories of underwater lots and swindled northeners. But now, according to an article in Thursdays Times by Christine Haughney and Vikas Bajaj, we have investors who knowingly signed up to finance homes they would then flip. They are stuck partially built houses, construction liens and little market for the homes.

title: HSBC Ousts Its North American Chief
description: Amid profit warnings steming from mortgage troubles in the United States, HSBC has replaced its head of North American operations, the European bank said Thursday. The resignation of Bobby Mehta, the chief executive of HSBC North America and of HSBC Finance, was effective Feb. 15. He will be succeeded by Brendan McDonagh, who was appointed chief operating officer at HSBC Finance earlier this month.

title: The First Casualty of Spring
description: The Mets camp has been quiet  a little too quiet, perhaps  with the only noise coming from players responding to what others have said (see Rollins, Jimmy and Floyd, Cliff ).

title: Hedge Fund Offers to Buy Catalina Marketing
description: ValueAct Capital has offered to buy Catalina Marketing for $32 a share, or about $1.5 billion, in an effort to restart the sale process that the company began in December. Catalina announced Thursday morning that it had received the bid, but the offer was actually disclosed Wednesday, shortly before the close of trading, in a regulatory filing by ValueAct, sending Catalinas shares sharply higher. In a letter to Catalinas board, ValueAct said it hoped it would flush out higher offers and argued that a special committee of Catalinas directors had ended the sale process prematurely.

title: 2008: McCain Revs Up Attacks
description: As The Timess Patrick Healy and Jim Rutenberg pointed out in their article today, the Hollywood brawl between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama isnt the only example of infighting. Senator John McCain has been on the attack lately against the Bush administration, especially by declaring that Donald Rumsfeld would go down as one of the worst secretaries of defense in history. On Wednesday, Mr. McCain opened up a new line of attack on the president and leader of his own party during an appearance with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger in Long Beach, Calif.

title: An Experiment in Virtual Living
description: This past Sunday, my report on the Second Life phenomenon aired on "CBS News Sunday Morning." (You can watch it here.)

title: Cuomo Hires NYPIRGs Horner
description: Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said this morning he was hiring Blair Horner, the legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, to run what he calls project sunlight, an uber-database he proposed during his campaign that will track activity of lobbyists, donors, elected officials and special interests. Horner has been the dean of the good government groups in Albany and a go-to quote for Empire Zone and other members of the Fourth Estate, and his hiring will likely be seen as a pr win for the attorney general.

title: The Budget Ad War Begins
description: 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East and Greater New York Hospital Association have begun their ad war against Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposed health care budget cuts, with two commercials that can be found here. The commercials say that Gov Spitzer is right to want to reform health care, but hes doing it the wrong way. Instead of cutting $1 billion from hospitals and nursing homes, the governor should be going after savings in the HMO and drug industries, the ads say. The groups have also set up a new website, www.stopthecuts.org.

title: The Most Popular Chavez in Venezuela?
description: Endy Chavez returned to his hometown, Valencia, Venezuela, three days after making one of the most unbelievable catches in postseason baseball history. As you might guess, he received quite a reaction.I couldnt go in the streets, he said. Everyone was crazy. They kept asking me how I did that. And I said: I dont know. It just happened. Chavez played winter ball for Magallanes, where he made another splendid catch. Not quite the level of the National League Championship Series Game 7 miracle, but impressive nonetheless.I try, Chavez said.

title: Morning in the Clubhouse
description: Heres something you dont see every day, outside of a college study hall, maybe. Matt DeSalvo, a pitching prospect wearing No. 74, sat peacefully in front of his locker in a crowded clubhouse this morning, reading a paperback: The Myth of Sisyphus.

title: And Only 34 Years After Billie Jean King Beat Bobby Riggs!
description: The All England Club, which organizes the Wimbledon tennis championships, said today that from now on it will offer women the same prize money as men. The chairman of the club, Tim Phillips called the decision good for tennis, good for women players and good for Wimbledon (and besides, the men-women differential had shrunk to near insignificance over the years anyway).

title: Clinton-Obama: The Morning After
description: The Clinton-Obama tempest drew a lot of media coverage in the last 24 hours, whipping around the Internet and on television like a brushfire. And Howard Wolfson, a top adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, continued to fan it with his were-not-gonna-take-it strategy against criticism of the Clintons, insisting again that Senator Barack Obama should denounce David Geffens remarks.

title: Multiple Choice Love Quiz
description: "Starter for Ten," an amiable, nostalgic British comedy from the director Tom Vaughan, tackles a lofty subject  the allure of knowledge  with down-to-earth charm. Set in 1985, the movie follows a gauche, working-class kid named Brian (James McAvoy) during his freshman year at Bristol University. But beneath the formulaic embarrassments and fumbled learning curve lurks a more somber theme: the inevitable rupture between those who pursue an education and those left behind.

title: Sam Brownback: Wilberforce Republican
description: Senator John McCain calls himself a Teddy Roosevelt Republican, and both Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mitt Romney, the other perceived frontrunners for the G.O.P. nod, have tried to tie themselves to Ronald Reagan.

title: Going Private to Get a Raise?
description: Private equity firms have been offering compensation on an unprecedented scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that they have bought out. Could that be why so many companies are choosing to go private these days? If, so, we would have a more serious problem than I thought, Representative Barney Frank recently said, because that would be elevating the private interests of the C.E.O. above every other consideration.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Coast of Utopia: Salvage" and "Mary Rose."

title: Footloose and Fork-Free
description: At dinner at the restaurant Cookshop the other night, I ordered the baby chicken. It was one of the dishes on the rotisserie section of the menu, and I wanted to see how the restaurant was doing with that piece of equipment, prominently displayed in the open kitchen. Although I had reviewed Cookshop very positively after its opening in late 2005, I hadnt always been impressed by what the rotisserie wrought.

title: War Story
description: Photographs from the Broadway production of "Journey's End."

title: Congress Tunes Into Satellite Radio Merger
description: In a sign of just how closely Washington plans to examine the proposed merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio, the House Judiciary Committee announced Thursday that it had formed a special group  the Antitrust Task Force  to consider the deal, which would create a single provider of satellite radio in the United States (albeit one that must still contend with old-fashioned radio as well as portable digital-music devices). Still, some analysts say they believe the markets are being too pessimistic about the deals chances of winning regulatory approval.

title: She Had a Cow: Milan Fashion
description: Yesterday, the strangest thing happened to Miss Horyn before the Gucci show. I was standing in the middle of the runway, discussing babies with two Gucci publicists, when an Italian fashion writer came up and asked if it was true that Giorgio Armani had banned me earlier in the afternoon from his Emporio Armani show. The next thing I knew I was surrounded by five or six journalists from La Stampa, Il Giornale and Il Messaggero, among other Italian papers.

title: Zell Defends His Dealmaking Prowess
description: Samuel Zell has an answer for critics who argue that the $39 billion deal he made to sell his Equity Office Properties to the Blackstone Group could have been even more lucrative. DealBook suggested as much in its recent column in The New York Times, writing that while Mr. Zell played the Blackstone Group and Vornado Realty Trust like two fiddles, he also left money on the table when he accepted a higher breakup fee in return for Blackstones raised bid, because it limited Vornados ability to come back with an even bigger offer.

title: An Experiment in Virtual Living
description: This past Sunday, my report on the Second Life phenomenon aired on CBS News Sunday Morning. (You can watch it here.)

title: The Academy Holds Forth
description: The Baguette placed a dozen calls to Academy voters the other day to see which way the award winds were blowing. As the Bagger has noted, the intrepid duo was working from an old list and a depressing number of names on it are, alas, alive in name only.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Astronaut Farmer'
description: The Times's chief movie critic, A. O. Scott, reviews "The Astronaut Farmer," starring Billy Bob Thornton and Virginia Madsen.

title: Its My Glove, I Promise
description: While chatting yesterday with David Newhan, he pulled out from his locker a first basemans mitt with Carlos Delgados signature on it. I asked him if he was borrowing it from Delgado.

title: YouTube Rival Catches Microsofts Eye
description: Sony bought video-sharing Web site Grouper in August. Google picked up YouTube, the king of video sites, in October. Now comes a report that Microsoft has taken a look at Revver, yet another venture-backed video-sharing startup. CNET News.com reports that executives from Microsoft toured Revvers Los Angeles headquarters last month to determine whether that companys service could enhance Soapbox, Microsofts own, newly launched service.

title: Clemens Schilling Hughes?
description: Phil Hughes threw live batting practice today, and his teammates were quite impressed. Jason Giambi compared Hughes to a young Rocket  he means Roger Clemens  and Todd Pratt said he looked like a young Curt Schilling.

title: A Campaign Strategy for the Taking
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Feb. 22 column, So You Want to Run . . ..

title: Idle Worship
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 22 column, From Anna to Britney to Zawahri.

title: Solo Collaboration with Rick Rubin
description: Travis and Jonathan do nice, well turned humor. Take just one recent vid: a great fake Rick Rubin, the guru-like music producer, cutting up with a great fake Ray Stevens, whos one of those Weird Al-style novelty singers. (You can trust Wikipedia on this one.)

title: Current Hedge Fund Regulations Work, Report Says
description: A group of top United States regulators on Thursday recommended market discipline and risk awareness, rather than new regulations, as the best safeguards for the burgeoning hedge-fund industry. The conclusions, intended as guidelines, were part of a report published by the Presidents Working Group on Financial Markets, which includes the Federal Reserve Board, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Gov Slugs Back at 1199, Hospitals
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer cracked back at 1199 S.E.I.U., the health care workers union, and the Greater New York Hospital Association over their new ad campaign bashing his budget with some of his sharpest rhetoric on the issue yet.

title: House Update: Georgias 10th District
description: Citizens of Georgias 10th Congressional District will have to wait until June 19 for representation in Congress. But on the upshot, explained Gov. Sonny Perdue, they wont face a gap in state legislative representation as current state lawmakers run to replace Representative Charles Norwood, who died on Feb. 13 after a long battle with cancer.

title: Weiner Explores 2009 Mayoral Bid
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn and came in a close second in the Democratic mayoral primary in 2005, has filed papers with the State Board of Elections in preparation for a mayoral run in 2009.

title: McCain Speech Spurs Culture War
description: Senator John McCain will be in Seattle this Friday, where hell give an address, presented by the World Affairs Council and the CityClub of Seattle. [Updated for clarification:] The councils release said Mr. McCain would talk about his vision for the United States in the world. It said he would answer questions such as:

title: Dice Ks Long Day
description: When Daisuke Matsuzaka stepped onto the mound for a bullpen session with the Boston Red Sox this morning, he had a lot of spectators. There were more than 100 members of the news media, most of them Japanese, trying to catalogue every pitch and every bead of sweat. In addition, John Henry, the owner of the Red Sox, Larry Lucchino, the teams president, Tom Werner, the chairman, and General Manager Theo Epstein were also watching Matsuzakas every move. It is rare when a teams hierarchy is so interested in a bullpen session.

title: Red Carpet, um, Highlights
description: The Bagger has spent the season in variety of poses: free-loader, Oscar savant, handmaiden to the stars, but for the most part, he has been in his basement mostly typing, lots and lots of typing. But every now and then he got out to mingle with the stars. Here is a selection of those red-carpet moments.

title: Campaign Cash: Obama
description: Sorry, folks, this isnt another post about the Hollywood slapfest between the 2008 campaigns of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. (And yes, we know, many of you are already so over that.)

title: Blogtalk: Lieberman and the G.O.P.
description: Joe Lieberman attracts bloggers like bread crumbs draw pigeons. In an interview today with The Politico, Mr. Lieberman said that while he had no desire to change parties, Democratic positions on the Bush admininstrations Iraq war policies  particularly over funding the troop levels  could persuade him to become a Republican. (Hes voted twice in recent weeks with Republican senators against moving forward with resolutions that oppose President Bushs troop buildup.)

title: Why Rebecca Died
description: If you havent been reading the Boston newspapers, then youve missed the awful details in the story of 4-year-old Rebecca Riley, who on Dec. 13 was found on a pile of clothes in her home in Hull, Mass., wearing a pink diaper and a pair of gold earrings, her lungs filled with fluid. Shed died of a drug overdose  murdered by her parents, local prosecutors claim, who had purposefully administered excessive doses of her bipolar and attention-deficit disorder medications in order to keep her calm and quiet.

title: Spending a Day at the Rockefellers
description: THE tranquil hamlet of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., has been bound up with the Rockefellers for more than a century. The familys imprint is everywhere: In the thousands of acres of nearby pastures, woodlands and lakes that John D. Rockefeller Sr. began acquiring as he created his familys estate in the 1890s. In the august stone walls enclosing a collection of even more august mansions. And in the stunning stained-glass windows by Matisse and Chagall that grace a simple stone church.

title: The Witty Modern Woman, and the Men Who Loathe Them
description: If you have read Helen Fielding, then you know that the millennial young British woman, of even just moderately good breeding, is a clever creature: witty, insouciant, unrestrained in matters of consumption, alluring to men no matter how actively her insecurities have conspired to make her believe otherwise.

title: Watchwords at Chrysler Are Hurry Up and Wait
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 22  One week after DaimlerChrysler signaled its plans to put the Chrysler Group on the auction block, the company indicated on Thursday that it might be weeks or months before the future of the ailing American automaker can be determined.

title: Florida: Charges Linked to Cuba Travel Licenses
description: Two men have been charged with conspiracy to violate regulations on travel to Cuba by fraudulently obtaining religious travel licenses under the names of nonexistent churches, federal prosecutors said. The men, Victor Vazquez and David Margolis, are accused of selling the licenses for $250 each through travel agencies to about 4,500 travelers from April 2006 to January 2007. United States citizens and residents are prohibited from traveling to Cuba without federal authorization but people in religious groups can travel there to engage in religious activities under the auspices of an organization that holds travel licenses.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the slow pace of home building by Habitat for Humanity in areas hit by Hurricane Katrina referred incorrectly in some copies to the Jesuit School of Theology at Berkeley, where Jerome P. Baggett, who wrote a book about Habitat, is a professor. It is an independent institution; it is not part of the University of California.

title: Prince Harry, 3rd in Line to Throne, to Fight in Iraq
description: LONDON, Feb. 22  Britain made headlines on Wednesday by saying it would bring some troops home from southern Iraq. On Thursday, it made even more waves here by saying it would send one soldier in the opposite direction: Prince Harry, second son of Diana, Princess of Wales, and third in line to the throne.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: Manhattan: Cabaret Rules Affirmed
description: A state appeals court yesterday dismissed a challenge to the citys rules governing the location and operation of cabarets and dance clubs. Opponents of the regulations had argued that the city could not restrict dancing in bars and restaurants because dance was a form of speech protected by the Constitution. But a panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that recreational dancing was not protected speech, and that the city had a right to regulate dance clubs to minimize noise, congestion and other hazards.

title: Circumcisions Anti-AIDS Effect Found Greater Than First Thought
description: Circumcision may provide even more protection against AIDS than was realized when two clinical trials in Africa were stopped two months ago because the results were so clear, according to studies being published today.

title: Brooklyn: Man Charged in 2002 Killing
description: A Brooklyn man has been indicted in connection with a 2002 shooting that killed a woman and wounded her son, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Wayne Davidson, 39, of Coney Island, is charged with second-degree murder, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Davidson was among a group of people who planned the attack on the son after he beat Mr. Davidson in a fistfight. The group went to the house of their intended victim in Coney Island on June 20, 2002, and opened fire when his mother opened the door, Mr. Hynes said. The mother, Audrey Townsend, 46, was killed. The intended target, whom prosecutors did not identify, was shot in the leg, but survived, Mr. Hynes said.

title: Now Playing: Inconvenient Truths

Directed by Davis Guggenheim and mainly consisting of a lecture about climate change given by Al Gore, the movie has had the highest profile and the largest box office of the five nominees, but its title could, without too much distortion, apply to any of them. For the moment, at least, one of the jobs of nonfiction filmmaking, perhaps its major responsibility, is to deliver uncomfortable news to a reluctant audience. While other documentary modes continue to flourish and cross-pollinate  biographies of the famous and notorious; wrenching tales of individual misery; uplifting stories of success against the odds; archival excavations of history  the Academy seems at the moment especially focused on larger problems, on public issues that wont go away no matter how fervently we might wish they would.

title: The Imperfect Soul Who Helped Bring an End to the Slave Trade
description: Amazing Grace, a prettified take on the life and times of the 18th-century reformer William Wilberforce, carries a strong whiff of piety. It isnt a bad smell; there are notes of roses and treacle in the mix, but also elements of sweat and pain. Wilberforce, born in 1759, was an abolitionist for much of his adult life and helped bring about the end of the slave trade in the British Empire and then slavery itself. He was an evangelical Christian and social conservative who rallied for animal rights and against trade unions, which makes him a tough nut to crack. Its no wonder he makes a first-rate movie saint.

Whereas The Bird Artist blended these elements into a wonderfully odd, fablelike tale that attested to the authors distinctive voice, Devotion feels curiously tired and synthetic, a mannered mix of Mr. Normans own idiosyncratic narrative tics and more traditional storytelling tropes. Worse, the tenderness and compassion that animated Mr. Normans best earlier fiction  like Kiss in the Hotel Joseph Conrad and Other Stories and the luminous Northern Lights  have given way in these pages to condescension and an impatience with his characters, whom he has afflicted with bad cases of stupidity, narcissism and hard-heartedness.

description: IN the 1870s, miners around Ouray, Colo., wielded pickaxes in search of gold and silver. Today people are still swinging axes in Ouray, but instead of following veins of ore, they blaze their way up vertical curtains of ice. Even novices can join in, and after the ice climbing, everyone can thaw out in Ourays simmering hot springs.

title: Iran Expanding Nuclear Effort, Agency Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  In open defiance of the United Nations, Iran is steadily expanding its efforts to enrich uranium, the International Atomic Energy Agency reported Thursday. In response, the Bush administration immediately pressed for more severe sanctions against the country, at a moment of greatly increased tensions between Washington and Tehran.

title: Pakistan and Al Qaeda (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bile and Vitriol by the Ton, and Yet Still Never Enough
description: Doctors took a piece out of Jackie Hoffman last year. But they left her bile duct and her spleen intact, meaning that Ms. Hoffman remains as endearingly tactless as ever. In Jackie With a Z, her delectably outrageous new show at Joes Pub, Ms. Hoffman is continuing her love-hate relationship with the audience. She hates; they love.

title: Guardian Chooses Bahamas Burial for Model
description: MIAMI, Feb. 22  A judge on Thursday gave custody of the body of Anna Nicole Smith to the court-appointed guardian for Ms. Smiths infant daughter, who said later that Ms. Smith would be buried in the Bahamas.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Diversity but a Hollywood Fiction?

title: As Asia Keeps Cool, Scientists Worry About the Ozone Layer
description: MUMBAI, India  Until recently, it looked like the depleted ozone layer protecting the earth from harmful solar rays was on its way to being healed.

title: Proposal by Obama on Public Financing Appears to Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  The staff of the Federal Election Commission has drafted an opinion that would allow the two major parties presidential nominees to adopt what amounts to a fund-raising truce.

title: Discovery Tightens Hold on Lead
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Feb. 22  After a disappointing 2006 season, the Discovery Channel cycling team still set some ambitious goals for this year at its training camp in January: Win the Tour of California. Win Paris-Roubaix. Win the Giro dItalia. And win the Tour de France.

title: Stepping to the Plate, Giuliani Is Seeing Only Softballs
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Feb. 21  In a swing through South Carolina this week, Rudolph W. Giuliani chose to campaign at a fire house, which is a little like Derek Jeter meeting with Yankees fans  a most unlikely forum for hostility, or even much skepticism.

title: The Bankruptcy Development That Has Wall St. Worried
description: LAST week, Burton R. Lifland, a judge in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, ordered Bear Stearns to pay almost $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for doing business with that fund but failing to detect that it was a fraud.

title: Collections of Noble Silver in Three U.S. Exhibitions
description: COLLECTIONS OF NOBLE SILVER

title: One Immigrant Familys Hopes Lead to a Jail Cell Suicide
description: It took 20 years of sacrifices and separations for Nery Romeros parents, immigrants from El Salvador, to obtain legal residency for the whole family in the United States. But Mr. Romero, 22, quickly forfeited his right to stay.

title: 2 Executives Are Ousted at HSBC
description: LONDON, Feb. 22  The deterioration in the United States mortgage market has now forced the departures of two top executives at HSBC Holdings, one of the worlds biggest banking companies.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Siegfried Landau, the founding conductor of what is now the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, referred incorrectly to the history of the New York College of Music, whose faculty he joined in the 1940s. It became part of New York University in 1968; it is not now, nor has it ever been, Mannes College of the New School. (The music program at the New School is known as Mannes College of Music and has been part of the school since 1989.)

title: Spitzer Backs Off  Remarks on Listing of 9/11 Names
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration has backed away from from remarks the governor made earlier this week that suggested there would be further discussions about how to arrange the names of the dead at the 9/11 memorial.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). What we got here is failure to communicate, says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman), a war hero, has been sentenced for two years after cutting the heads off parking meters. Mr. Newman earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as a prisoner who refuses to break under a brutal system. George Kennedy won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Dragline, the gangs top dog. At 10:30, Steve McQueen and Dustin Hoffman play convicts trying to escape Devils Island in Papillon (1973).

title: MP3 Patents in Upheaval After Verdict
description: Microsoft was ordered by a federal jury yesterday to pay $1.52 billion in a patent dispute over the MP3 format, the technology at the heart of the digital music boom. If upheld on appeal, it would be the largest patent judgment on record.

title: Trading Deadline Passes Without Impact Deal
description: Days of aggressive negotiating by any number of N.B.A. general managers came to an anticlimactic conclusion yesterday when only three deals were reached at the 3 p.m. trading deadline, none of them involving star players.

title: A Foreign Policy Built on Do-Overs
description: Watching the Bush team wrestle with Iran, North Korea and Iraq reminds me of something that used to be said of the Reagan administration: The right hand never knew what the far right hand was doing.

title: Official in Furor on AIDS Policy in South Africa Is Hospitalized
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 22  Dr. Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, the South African minister of health whose promotion of garlic and beetroot as protection against AIDS came to symbolize her nations slow response to the H.I.V. epidemic, is in a Johannesburg hospital with severe anemia and a lung infection, the government said Thursday.

title: A Tale of Love, Drought and Desperation
description: One plausible moral of The Wayward Cloud, Tsai Ming-liangs enigmatic and confrontational film from 2005, is a variation on a durable piece of fruit-based folk wisdom: If life hands you watermelons, make love to them. This, at any rate, is what happens in an early scene of juicy, pulpy sex, featuring one of the main characters, an actor in pornographic films; a colleague in a nurses uniform; and a seedy supporting player. The melon seems to get the best of it.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, passages in an Op-Ed article yesterday, about the British presence in Iraq, appeared out of order in some copies. A corrected version can be found at nytimes.com/opinion.

title: Satellite Radio: A Good Idea, but a Bad Investment
description: It is the genius  or perhaps the great flaw  of the American capital system that really clever, but totally uneconomical, ideas can be financed by investors.

title: A Fairs Strategy: Solo Artists, Themes and Specters of Blockbusters
description: The Art Show, organized by the Art Dealers Association of America, now in its 19th year, is among the more staid art fairs. Absent are the sexy shipping-container showrooms of Art Basel Miami Beach or DiVA Streets in Chelsea and the flashing multimedia of the Armory Show. The associations membership includes a range of galleries devoted generally to more traditional mediums, leading to a show that is literally and figuratively planted on terra firma  on Park Avenue rather than the beach or a pier hovering over the roiling Hudson River.

title: When Seeing Isnt Quite the Same as Believing
description: MILAN, Feb. 22  Authentic lives, like the life of Lee Miller, the photographer and onetime lover of Man Ray  whose sparse advice to Vogue upon delivering her pictures of concentration camps was Believe it  often feel short-changed by designers of luxury products.

title: Detour From High Road in Clinton-Obama Clash
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  After weeks of watching in frustration as Senator Barack Obama presented himself as a fresh face gliding above partisan politics, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has drawn Mr. Obama onto a muddy political field, engaging him in a back-and-forth that recalls the kind of Washington bickering Mr. Obama has decried.

title: Prosecutor Urges Public to Help Fight Corruption
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 22  Christopher J. Christie, the federal prosecutor who has aggressively pursued New Jersey politicians believed to be corrupt, said in a speech here on Thursday that the public should help stem the tide of corruption by voting out officials who break the law.

title: One Thousand Ocean and the Club at Black Rock
description: One Thousand Ocean

title: Manhattan: Weiner Files for Election
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn and came in a close second in the Democratic mayoral primary in 2005, has filed papers with the State Board of Elections in preparation for a possible mayoral run in 2009. Ive got a great job now, and Im committed to a lot of the same issues I talked about in 2005, Mr. Weiner said yesterday in a telephone interview, citing education reform and the high cost of living. Its becoming a tougher and tougher place for many New Yorkers to live. Mr. Weiner, a member of Congress since 1999, said he had not made a final decision on whether to run.

title: Guatemala: Policemen Arrested in Killings of 4
description: The authorities arrested four police officers in connection with the killings this week of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver outside Guatemala City. Officials have speculated that the killings were politically motivated and linked to organized crime.

title: Making Police Obey the Rules That Bear Her Name
description: BARBARA ELLEN HANDSCHU, whose corkscrew Orphan Annie curls have faded to gray since her heyday as lead plaintiff in a class action lawsuit, alongside notorious agitators like Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin, against surveillance tactics used by the New York City Police Department in the 1960s and beyond, seems uncannily at home in her home away from her actual home, a cat-dominated house in Buffalo.

title: Correction
description: A letter from New York yesterday about the controversy over a childrens book misspelled the surname of the letter writer, an author of juvenile and young adult novels. She is Sheila Solomon Klass, not Klaus.

title: Manhattan: Singers D.W.I. Case Dropped
description: Drunken-driving charges against the Metropolitan Opera tenor Jerry Hadley have been dismissed by a Manhattan Criminal Court judge, the authorities said yesterday. Mr. Hadley was arrested on May 12, 2006, after officers smelled alcohol on his breath and observed keys in the ignition of a parked car he was in at 81st Street and Riverside Drive. Although he failed a blood alcohol test, Mr. Hadley has maintained that he never intended to drive the car, and that he had put the keys in the ignition only to listen to the radio. Jennifer Kushner, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said that the office had moved to dismiss the charges after deciding it could not make a case that Mr. Hadley intended to drive while intoxicated.

title: Remembering Warhol: A Tomato Soup Can and a Pocketful of Coins
description: BETHEL PARK, Pa., Feb. 22  For 20 years, it has appeared every month: one Campbells tomato soup can and a pocketful of change left on the plain black granite tombstone.

title: Green Theft Auto
description: Los Angeles

title: Profiteering Colleges
description: The Democratic leadership in Congress plans to make college affordability a central theme of this legislative session. The pending bills that would increase federal aid to low-income students and lower the costs of student loans are good, as far as they go. But Congress must do more to ensure that scarce federal aid dollars are legitimately spent and not gobbled up by for-profit diploma mills that bilk the government and students alike.

title: The Anglican Rift (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Richardson Is Running on a Rsum Both Local and National
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When a governor runs for president, local issues can suddenly loom large. Take cockfighting. Gov. Bill Richardson has come out against it after ignoring the question for years.

title: Bronx : No Retrial in Murder Case
description: A man whose 1993 murder conviction was overturned last December will not be retried, his lawyer said yesterday. The lawyer, Martin B. Klotz, said the Bronx district attorneys offices two-month window to move to retry Jose Garcia closed yesterday. Mr. Garcia served 15 years for the 1991 murder of a friend, even though he said he was in his native Dominican Republic at the time. In December, a federal judge overturned the conviction because Mr. Garcias former lawyer had failed to pursue solid evidence that he had been out of the country when the killing occurred. Mr. Garcia, whose wife and four children are American citizens, still faces deportation because he was an illegal immigrant at the time of his arrest.

title: Wimbledon Agrees to Even Out Its Prize Money
description: When the gates of the All England Club open for Wimbledon this summer, there will still be tentacles of ivy crawling up its stadium walls and players dressed pristinely in white. But, as club executives announced yesterday, at least one thing will change: The tournament will award equal prize money to men and women for the first time.

title: Canada: Pornography Service Halted
description: After a call for a boycott from a Roman Catholic archbishop, hundreds of complaints and one lawsuit from customers, the Canadian phone company Telus abandoned a service that allowed cellphone customers to buy soft-core pornography. Telus, based in Vancouver, began offering pornography to its five million wireless customers along with more conventional downloads like music and ring tones last month. Jim Johannson, a spokesman for the company, said the decision to end the service was based in part on customer feedback. Mr. Johannson, however, did not rule out a change in policy. We operate in a really, really competitive business, he said. In this environment, its very difficult to predict the future.

title: Boston Police to Destroy Pepper-Spray Guns
description: BOSTON, Feb. 22  More than two years after a pepper-spray pellet fired from a police officers gun killed a college student as a crowd gathered outside Fenway Park to celebrate a Red Sox victory, the Boston Police Department has said it will destroy the pellet weapons.

title: Trapped on an Airplane
description: JetBlues horrendous performance during the recent ice storms that paralyzed New York Citys airports has reinvigorated calls for a passengers bill of rights to protect air travelers against what can only be deemed abusive treatment. JetBlue has moved rapidly to make amends, but its shocking failures and those of other airlines in recent months make a federal law the best solution.

title: Arab States, Wary of Iran, Add to Their Arsenals but Still Lean on the U.S.
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 22  As fears grow over the escalating confrontation between Iran and the West, Arab states across the Persian Gulf have begun a rare show of muscle flexing, publicly advertising a shopping spree for new weapons and openly discussing their security concerns.

title: Old Problems Undermine New Security Plan for Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 19  It looked like a scene out of a counterinsurgency training video. Dressed in crisp uniforms with a computer-generated camouflage of blue, gray and brown, Iraqi national police officers joined United States troops on searches late last week through relatively calm districts of Shaab and Ur in northeast Baghdad in the first large operation of the Baghdad security plan.

title: A Belated Gift in Belleayre Mountain
description: THE line of cars that approached Belleayre Mountain last Sunday had clogged two-lane Route 28 in the Catskills, but it was a patient procession. People did not seem to mind the wait. They had, after all, been waiting for this day for months.

title: Venezuela Rivals U.S. in Aid to Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  To understand Venezuelas growing influence here, consider that more than two dozen ambassadors are in this capital city, including those of Bolivias leading trading partners like Brazil, the United States and Argentina. Yet none enjoy the direct conduit that the Venezuelan ambassador, Julio Montes, has established with President Evo Morales.

title: Dumping of Homeless by Hospitals Stirs Debate
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22  For a year, reports have surfaced that hospitals here have left homeless patients on downtown streets, including a paraplegic man wearing a hospital gown and colostomy bag who witnesses say pulled himself through the streets with a plastic bag of his belongings held in his teeth.

title: Cuba: 2 Foreign Reporters Ousted
description: Cuba effectively silenced foreign correspondents from The Chicago Tribune and the Mexican newspaper El Universal this week, denying them new press credentials and journalist visas. The Universal reporter, Csar Gonzlez-Calero, was told yesterday that he must cease writing about Cuba because his coverage was not good for the government, the newspaper reported. On Wednesday, officials told Gary Marx of The Tribune that his credentials would not be renewed because the government was not pleased with his work, said George de Lama, the managing editor for news. Four other foreign news organizations  the BBC, Agence France-Presse, Reuters and El Pas  have yet to be told if they will be accredited again, journalists on the island said.

title: Joseph E. Gallo, 87, Brother Who Left Wine for Cheese, Dies
description: Joseph E. Gallo, the California cheese maker who battled his winemaking brothers over the use of the family name, died Saturday at his home in Livingston, Calif. He was 87.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a confrontation at the Whitestone Bridge toll plaza in the Bronx involving a stolen Range Rover referred imprecisely to the officers who fired on the Range Rover as it barreled down upon them and misidentified the agency that employs them. They are peace officers, not police officers, and they work for M.T.A. Bridges and Tunnels, also known as the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority; they do not work for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police Department.

title: France Enters Fight Over Londons Road Charges
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  Ever since the municipal authorities in London imposed a charge to drive into the city center in 2003, the American Embassy has stood as a beacon of automotive defiance, refusing to pay what it calls a tax on the ground that diplomats are exempt from taxes by international treaty.

title: Germany: Chemical Makers Profit Up
description: BASF said its fourth-quarter profit rose 31 percent on growth in its chemicals division, helped by acquisitions like the Engelhard Corporation, a maker of catalysts. The results were better than expected, and the company said its sales would be significantly higher this year. BASF earned 732 million euros ($962 million) in the quarter, up from 560 million euros in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 23.5 percent, to 14.47 billion euros ($19.02 billion).

title: From Catalonia, a Tomboy Carmen (and Her Inner Child)
description: Catalonia has a proud modern-dance tradition. And Ramn Oller (pronounced OH-yay) is one of its best-known choreographers, familiar to New York audiences from the works he created for Ballet Hispanico. Now he is back with his own Compaa Metros in Carmen, which opened on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater for a two-week engagement.

title: An Auction House Buys a Contemporary Gallery
description: It is no longer unusual for an auction house like Sothebys or Christies to buy an art gallery as a way of purchasing its dealers expertise, contacts and stock. But now, for the first time, an auction house has acquired a gallery primarily to enter the market for new works by living artists.

title: That Sanitation Truck Parked on the Pier? Its Part of the Show
description: The Armory Show, which opens today on Pier 94, began life more than a dozen years ago as a funky, bed-bath-and-beyond affair in the guest rooms of a downtown hotel. Paintings were propped on pillows, drawings Scotch-taped to walls. One artist made love to a motorcycle; another took a three-day shower. The whole thing was kids playing Art Fair. If some of them took home some cash, that was nice but not really the point. Or maybe it was the point. I dont know.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Bronx: Corpse Is Found After Fire
description: Firefighters responding to a one-alarm fire yesterday discovered the body of a 58-year-old man in an apartment at 2507 Cruger Avenue, in Bronxdale. Two firefighters were sent to a nearby hospital with minor injuries. The police did not identify the dead man, but neighbors said officers told them that he had been stabbed. A Fire Department spokesman called the fire suspicious but did not elaborate.

title: Springtime for Hits End: The Producers to Close
description: They had a great big Broadway smash, and their pockets are unquestionably stuffed with cash, and now the producers of The Producers, the Broadway musical that broke a batch of records and changed the business, are calling it a day.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 9 about New York States plans to sue five companies to force them to clean up an oil spill in Brooklyn referred imprecisely to a 1990 agreement to recover the oil reached by one of the companies and state environmental officials. When the company struck the deal, it was known as Mobil  not Exxon Mobil, which has been its name since a 1999 merger.

title: Corzine Forecasts Financial Gloom, but Not This Election Year
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22  Gov. Jon S. Corzine warned on Thursday that New Jerseys fiscal outlook is so bleak, the state is facing an avalanche of growing fixed costs that would soon require drastic measures.

title: All the Bodys a Stage
description: If you were to get a celebrity tattoo, who would it be?

title: And the Oscar Goes to
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On the Market
The Future of a Family Business
description: At some point, nearly all families have to hand over all or partial control of their businesses to outsiders, and the transition can be as unique as the family itself.

title: Struggle for Baghdad
Watchwords at Chrysler Are Hurry Up and Wait
description: One week after DaimlerChrysler signaled its plans to put the Chrysler Group on the auction block, the company indicated on Thursday that it might be weeks or months before the future of the ailing American automaker can be determined. That word came in an e-mail message sent to employees by the Chrysler chief executive, Thomas W. LaSorda, which the company posted on a media Web site.

title: Stock Exchanges in a Rush to Forge Links With One Another
description: Multibillion-dollar mergers are not the only way to bring stock exchanges together. Many exchanges around the globe are instead connecting through stake sales, partnerships and joint ventures with their overseas peers. The price tags, if there are any, are tiny, but the hope is that these alliances will set the stage for more substantive ventures in the future.

title: Fox Interactive Acquires Technology Ad Company
description: Fox Interactive Media, the unit of News Corporation that operates the Web site MySpace, said Thursday that it had acquired the Strategic Data Corporation, an advertising technology company based in Santa Monica, Calif., to help increase revenue from the popular social networking site.

title: The Slow Pace of Justice on Options Backdating
description: A sweeping investigation into the backdating of stock options at more than 100 companies has so far led to relatively few enforcement actions or resolutions. Lawyers and executives at the companies under scrutiny have been waiting to see how investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as well as those by United States attorneys, will play out.

title: HealthSouth Official Avoids Prison Term
description: Malcolm E. McVay, the former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, avoided prison Thursday and was granted five years probation, the same sentence that an appeals court threw out last year as too lenient. Judge Inge P. Johnson imposed the sentence in Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., saying that Mr. McVay played a relatively small role in the $2.7 billion accounting fraud at the company. The government had asked for a 28-month term; he could have served nine years.

title: Japan Gets Its First Shareholder Revolt
description: Scott Callon, a former banker at Morgan Stanley, has led the first successful shareholder revolt in Japan, blocking the takeover of Tokyo Kohtetsu by a rival steel producer, Osaka Steel, after arguing that it offered no incentive to investors. An investment fund, Ichigo Asset Management, started a rare proxy fight against what it saw as an unfair share-swap ratio for Tokyo Kohtetsu, a small but highly profitable maker of steel sheets and H-beams.

title: Getty Images to Buy Celebrity Photo Distributor
description: Getty Images, the No. 1 provider of stock and editorial photographs, said on Thursday that it planned to buy the celebrity photo distributor WireImage for $200 million and is in talks to acquire another rival, Jupitermedia. The acquisitions would help Getty expand its product offerings at a time that it faces competition from smaller rivals, especially in its royalty-free images business  photographs sold at a set price to clients like advertisers.

title: Gamco Offers to Settle S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Gamco Investors, asset manager headed by Mario Gabelli, said Thursday that it had offered to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into mutual fund share trading and, as a result, has increased its legal and regulatory reserves by $3 million. The company, based in Rye, N.Y., had previously taken a $12 million charge against earnings as a result of talks with the agency, which it said began last June. It said it expected to settle with the S.E.C. in the near future.

title: Icahn: Buyout Firms Are the Real Raiders
description: Carl C. Icahn is not afraid to shake things up at big, publicly traded companies. In the 1980s, the billionaire financier was known as a corporate raider; these days activist investor is the preferred term. But in an interview in BusinessWeek, Mr. Icahn suggests that private equity firms are the new corporate raiders  and it does not seem intended as a compliment. Mr. Icahn takes issue with private equity firms habit of buying cash-rich companies from public shareholders, piling on debt and selling them later at a profit. Cash is a great asset, he told BusinessWeek. But if private equity investors get their hands on it, theyll reap the benefit instead of the shareholder.

title: With Biotech I.P.O.s, Investors Get a Mixed Bag
description: Biotech offerings are in remission, according to BusinessWeek, which notes that while small pharmaceutical developers continue to stream toward the public markets, investors are yawning. Too often, says the magazine, initial public offerings for small biotechs offer little short-term upside-and ask investors to take on the major risks of drug development.

title: Judge Denies Banks Motion to Delay Enron Suit
description: A $40 billion lawsuit filed by former Enron shareholders and investors alleging investment firms and banks played key roles in the companys collapse will go to trial in April despite a pending appeals court decision on the case, a judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon denied efforts by Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse First Boston and Barclays to delay the trial while the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rules on whether the case can proceed as a class-action suit.

title: A.I.G. Gets Green Light for U.S. Ports Deal
description: U.S. antitrust authorities said Thursday they approved plans by American International Group to buy the U.S. port facilities of state-owned Dubai Ports World. Officials completed their antitrust investigation of the deal without taking any action, the Federal Trade Commission said in a notice. DP World said in December it agreed to sell the facilities in New York, New Jersey, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Miami, Tampa and New Orleans to A.I.G.

title: Oscar, We Hardly New Ye
description: The Bagger has been mired for months in all manner of Oscarnalia, and even though he is up to here with any story that includes the acronym AMPAS, he has to admit that Gregg Kildays work in the Hollywood Reporter has been a pleasure. In a corner of journalism that is long on attitude  ahem  and short on thoughtful reporting, he sticks out, in a nice way. His wrap up on how this year did not go according to plan, especially the one laid out by the blogerati, is an explainer worth reading.It concludes with a nice grace note, and with a nice elbow to the blogs for good measure.

title: And It Will Star a Little Gold Statue Dancing in the Middle of It
description: Variety is reporting that Martin Scorsese, who might weigh eight-and-a-half more pounds at the end of the weekend, is in talks to direct a kids picture, of all things.Warner Bros. is hoping the director of Goodfellas, might take on Brian Selznicks best-selling childrens novel, The Invention of Hugo Cabret, which the studio scooped up a month after its release by Scholastic.

title: An Empty Slate
description: This year, Kim Masters is picking to not make her picks, a bold move that comports nicely with the realities of the race.Then again, maybe its just a smarty-pants ways of ducking the confused issue. (BTW, Masters has a really smart piece on Oscar presenter Tom Cruise as well.)

title: Morgan Stanley Moves into Canada With Infrastructure Buy
description: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay about C$460 million ($396 million) for a majority stake in a Montreal-based container-shipping operation, making its first venture into Canada. The financial services firm is buying Montreal Gateway Terminals from TUI, a German shipping and tourism conglomerate, in a move that pits Morgan Stanley against the likes of Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Australias Macquarie Bank Ltd. and Toronto-based Brookfield Asset Management for control of Canadian infrastructure assets.

title: Best Picture Throwdown for the Ages
description: The best best picture of all time? The Godfather. The worst? Why of course, its The Greatest Show on Earth. So says Rotten Tomatoes, which has a keen web portfolio that rates all the best pictures in Academy history from a critical perspective.

title: Toronto-Dominion Posts Profit Increase
description: Toronto-Dominion Bank kicked off bank earnings season Thursday, beating expectations on stronger results at its retail division and U.S. discount brokerage. The banks profit before one-time gains jumped 20.8 percent to C$1 billion ($861 million) or C$1.38 a share from a year-earlier C$835 million or C$1.15 a share.

title: The Flap of a Butterflys Wings
description: The Bagger attended the opening of Superstition, a show of works by Damien Hirst at the Gagosian Gallery in Beverly Hills. The Bagger had no idea why he was there, other than the fact that Baguette told him to go  that it was the unofficial start of the Oscar parties  and he does everything she tells him to. There was a block long line to get in, which the Bagger busted just by keeping moving and carrying an air of insouciance.

title: Two Large Advertisers Place Accounts in Review
description: Two large advertisers  Hyundai and CareerBuilder  placed accounts in review today, and both will have new agencies because the incumbents are bowing out rather than try to keep the assignments.

title: Hustle and Flow
description: Jason Binn, who publishes Gotham, among other magazines, can invent and work a party like no one else. This time around, he talked Forest Whitaker into showing up at the Mondrian (and on the cover of L.A. Confidential) and Naomi Campbell, Russell Simmons, Ludacris and Mary K. Blige showed up, too.

title: Maxed Out
description: Miramax threw a party for its nominees last night, including prohibitive favorite Helen Mirren and stealth hopeful Peter OToole. A wide-open fete at the Sunset Towers with those mini-burgers that the Bagger all but lives for, it gave both actors a chance to visit with pals and skate around the rink, picking up the roses one more time before Sundays doings.

title: Trouble at HSBC Stemmed from Household Purchase
description: The deterioration in the United States mortgage market has now forced the departures of two top executives at HSBC Holdings, one of the worlds biggest banking companies. HSBC said on Thursday that Bobby Mehta was stepping down as head of its North American business and as chief executive of HSBC Finance. Sandy Derickson, chief executive of HSBC Bank USA and vice chairman of HSBC Finance, is also leaving.

title: CBS Unlikely to Go Private Soon, Analyst Says
description: CBS is unlikely to be the target of a buyout any time soon, Jonathan Jacoby, an analyst at Banc of America Securities, said Friday in a research report. The broadcasting companys rising stock price and falling ratings are two obstacles to a potential take-private transaction, he wrote. Separately, CBS announced it had reached agreements with cable system operators that would generate a new stream of revenue for the network.

title: EMI Tries Luring Private Equity to the Table, Report Says
description: Is EMI trying to cook up a bidding war after receiving the latest takeover offer from Warner Music Group? According to The New York Post, buyout shops Apollo Management and Permira Advisors have resurfaced as potential suitors for EMI, but the paper said that a new bid from the private equity groups seemed unlikely.

title: Lotto Picks
description: The Bagger knew this day would come. All of his juking and jiving could not avoid the day of reckoning, when idle speculation would be replaced by landing hard on some softly held convictions. But confession, or at least disclosure, is good for the soul.

title: Satellite Radio: A Good Idea, but a Bad Investment
description: Despite investor enthusiasm after the announcement of merger plans by XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio, it is hard to see what will allow these companies to ever become profitable  particularly given the eventual threat of good mobile Internet service, which could give drivers access to Internet radio without having to pay hefty subscription fees, says The New York Times Floyd Norris.

title: Private Equity Saves Jobs, Permira Chief Says
description: Under fire from government officials and labor unions alike, Permira Advisers chief executive insists that private equity does not destroy jobs. Permira, one of Britains largest buyout firms, has been criticized for its stewardship of Birds Eye and the Automobile Association; each company has shed more than a quarter of its total workers since being acquired by the firm.

title: Pulse
description: What I'm wearing now, the recall of the wild, pajamas in pint in parent sizes and more.

title: Capitalias C.E.O. Survives Fight over Merger Plans
description: The chief executive of Capitalia, Matteo Arpe, on Thursday defeated an attempt by the chairman, Cesare Geronzi, to remove him, winning the backing of the Italian banks leading investors after a fight over the banks merger strategy. After issuing a public apology to Mr. Geronzi, Mr. Arpe received the support of Capitalias main investors at a meeting in Rome, according to a statement from a shareholders group that owns 31 percent of the bank. Capitalia directors had been scheduled to meet later Thursday to decide whether to oust Arpe.

title: Wall Streets Prime Brokers Fret Over Ruling
description: A ruling last week that ordered Bear Stearns to pay almost $160 million to investors in a hedge fund has inspired true fear on Wall Street, The New York Timess Jenny Anderson reports. For banks, servicing hedge funds is a business so lucrative that it makes the go-go years of bringing technology companies public look quaint. For one, hedge funds do billions of dollars of business in multiple parts of the bank, while many technology companies promptly evaporated after going public.

title: On Naming a National Fish
description: Their countrymen had a hand in bringing the world high-tech titles like Skype, KaZaa, and by way of early venture capital, Hotmail. But Estonians have been sorting out much more down-to-earth matters of late, and it seems a breakthrough was reached yesterday.

title: "The Plow That Broke the Plains"
description: This 1936 film, directed by Pare Lorentz with original scores by Virgil Thomson, was aimed at aiding refugee families devastated by floods, droughts and dust storms.

title: "The River"
description: This film is a government-financed documentary from the 1930s that tells a grim saga of unchecked development in  the Mississippi River network.

title: Democratic Gloves Off
Pole Dancing in Book Club Country
description: Pole dancing, once exclusively the province of exotic dancers, is the new star at racier versions of Tupperware parties in well-heeled areas.

title: Say Cheese
description: Remember those cheesy baseball cards of your youth, the close-up shots of players with a bat over their shoulder or their glove at their chest? You looked at them and sighed because you really wanted an action photo, not some posed shot from spring training. Well, theyre taking those photos out on the field this morning.

title: War at Home: The Senate Moves On
description: Carl Hulse, our chief congressional correspondent, writes today that during the Congressional recess this week, several Democratic Senate leaders have been busily working on binding proposals that would repeal, or at least alter, the 2002 Congressional authorization for use of force in Iraq. And they may offer language that would shift the nature of the American mission to pave the way for removing combat troops. Quoting officials, he reports:

title: Hedge Fund Report Draws Mixed Reactions
description: Guidelines for safeguarding the hedge fund industry released yesterday by the Bush administration drew applause from much of Wall Street for their laissez-faire approach. A combination of common sense and market forces should be enough to keep this trillion-dollar-plus asset class from disrupting markets or decimating workers pensions, the report suggested.
