But there was criticism from some lawmakers and industry observers  as well as the attorney general of Connecticut, home to many of the biggest hedge funds  who complained the reports recommendations were too weak.

title: 2008: When the Dust Settles
description: In the 2004 Iowa Democratic caucuses, Howard Dean and then-Representative Richard Gephardt spent so much time tearing each other apart that by staying out of it, Senator John Kerry and John Edwards came out the winners when the dust settled.

title: How to Make Them Really, Really Like You
description: A market-based solution to a boring Academy Awards: Not satisfied with his historic reputation as the developer of the Feiler Faster Thesis, Bruce Feiler now wants to introduce market incentives as a way to improve acceptance speeches at the Oscars. Feiler writes at The Huffington Post (and at his Feiler Faster blog):

title: Incognito: Milan Fashion
description: This morning I got up early, seven-ish, put on an old white T-shirt, faded black Capri pants, my Prada loafers that the dog chewed, the black knit cap, and went out for breakfast in the Piazza Cavour. The orange trams were already astir, the air coolish, gray. Read Suzy M. in the Herald-Trib and gather, between the lines, she appreciated Dolce & Gabbanas technical finesse (must say I loved the crumpled tin foil effect) but wasnt rocked by the porno trip. Fashion is too much a package-deal (to use Lagerfelds term) for designers to ever go to the real edges of the human experience. Artists can go there; writers certainly. But who is the Kafka of couture? I wasnt invited to Dolce. The only thing noteworthy about writers being banned from shows is why designers bother to do it all. Its old business. And what these designers dont appreciate is that in the time they have satisfied this ritual pose, the writer (and the rest of the world) has moved on. When I need to clear my head and think straight, I read two books: The Great Gatsby, for the perfect language, and the German newspaper reports of Joseph Roth, who reminds us to trust what we see with our own eyes.

title: Vilsack Drops Out
description: Former Iowa Gov. Tom Vilsack is announcing today that hes dropping out of the Democratic presidential race. His campaign said Mr. Vilsack will make a major announcement at 11 a.m. in Des Moines.

title: Australias Coles Reconsiders the Buyout Option
description: Last fall, Coles Myer spurned offers to take the Australian supermarket chain private. Now, its parent company has changed its mind. Coles Group put itself up for sale Friday, citing several interested buyers  presumably who would offer more than the A$18.2 billion ($14.3 billion) bid it previously rejected. Shares in the company shot up 10 percent in Friday trading.

title: Comment Zone: Spitzer and Borglum
description: While other Empire Zone readers continue to aim fire at the legislature over the comptroller selection, Shirley Engel of Kendell Park, N.J., was troubled. She sent along this observation by e-mail:

title: Its All Ours.  (But What Do We Do?)
description: Alison was absolutely right about my loving 92 North Shore Drive, Anna Maria, Fla. (We found out at the closing that the sixth of an acre of dirt we had just bought already had a street address.)

title: Another Day, Another Blackstone Real Estate Deal
description: In its continuing efforts to wring cash out of its record-breaking buyout of Equity Office Properties, the Blackstone Group plans to sell 10 San Francisco office buildings to Morgan Stanley for more than $2.5 billion, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources. Among the 3.9 million square feet Morgan Stanley will acquire are the One Market office complex and One Maritime Plaza.

title: Trefethen Riesling
description: You dont find much riesling in Napa Valley. Its a region dominated by cabernet sauvignon and the Bordeaux varietals, with shares of zinfandel, chardonnay and sauvignon blanc, except in the cooler Carneros region to the south, where plenty of chardonnay and pinot noir is planted. But only occasionally will you come across some oddballs  some chenin blanc or gewrztraminer that somebodys attached to and wont give up, even though it would most likely make better economic sense to tear it out and plant cabernet.

title: Giulianis First Big Fund-Raiser
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani will hold the biggest fund-raising event of his young presidential campaign on March 14, a $2,300-a-plate dinner expected to draw hundreds of people to the Sheraton New York Hotel & Towers.

title: Bankers Go Long on Bling and Beach Houses
description: Wall Street bankers throw around billions of dollars of other peoples money each day. What do they do with their own? As far as last years bonuses are concerned, it appears that they are spending about 11 percent of it on jewelry. Another 26 percent is going to new homes (often second or third ones) and home improvements. The average savings rate: a relatively modest 16 percent.

title: A Step Toward A Cluster Bomb Ban
description: At an international conference in Oslo today, 46 of 49 nations agreed in principle to seek a treaty in 2008 that would ban cluster munitions  air-dropped bombs, artillery shells and missiles that spew hundreds of smaller bomblets over a wide area, rather than detonate in a single large blast as most bombs do.

title: Who Is Responsible for Temporary Parking?
description: Q Is a landlord required to reimburse rent-stabilized tenants for the cost of parking in a private lot if the building's rent-stabilized parking garage becomes temporarily unavailable for use?

title: Ichiros 31,284 Steps to Fitness
description: When Ichiro Suzuki, who wields a baseball bat like a magician, reported to spring training for the Seattle Mariners this week, he said it was possible that he would test free agency after the 2007 season. The Mariners surely shuddered since Suzuki has been their best and most dynamic player since arriving from Japan in 2001.

title: Non-Regulating Regulators
description: In the debate about hedge funds, three types of reasons have been offered for additional regulation. Lets look at the state of all three in the wake of the presidential working group announcement yesterday.

title: Lo Ducas Pain
description: For seven consecutive years, Paul Lo Duca has attended spring training with a nagging case of tendinitis in his right hand. And every year, Lo Duca thinks it will go away. After he takes a few rounds of batting practice  poof!  its back, worse than ever.

title: Stock Specialists Said to Push Harder for Help
description: As grimly illustrated by a Barrons cover story last November  the one headlined Death on the Floor, with the suit-wearing skeleton standing in the middle of the New York Stock Exchange  these are perilous times for stock specialists. Specialists manage the buying and selling of particular stocks on the trading floor, but the rise of electronic trading has greatly cut into their business. Now, CNBC reports that the heads of major specialist firms recently met with John Thain, the chief of NYSE Group, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, and gave him an ultimatum, threatening to leave the business altogether unless he helps them out.

title: Big Papis Book Brain Lock
description: David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox is impossible to overlook. He is big. He is loud. And when he swings a bat and connects, he seems a lot bigger and a lot louder.

title: Hedge Funds at the Oscars
description: On Sunday, many movie fans will sit through the broadcast of the Academy Awards in hopes of winning a few dollars in their office Oscar pools. There are likely to be a few hedge fund managers tuned in as well, banking on a much richer payoff.

title: Cannabis: Contraband Here, Cottage Industry There
description: So, if you find yourself in N.Y.C. this weekend, you can always consult the Times nifty Urbaneye (O.K., shameless plug there). But if youre wandering the northern climes of Europe  hmmm, what to do, what to do?

title: Twisting in the Wind
description: The Yankees started their practice today with an eventful pop-up drill. Each of the starters took his position while the pitchers took turns pretending to throw off the mound. After their delivery, a coach would put a ball in a pitching machine aimed skyward.

title: The Overstock Story
description: Would you like to be a director of a company where the losses keep growing and management blames Wall Street for its problems? There is an opening.

title: Time to Act on Global Warming
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Feb. 23 column, Colorless Green Ideas.

title: No More Mulligans in This Game
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Feb. 23 column, A Foreign Policy Built on Do-Overs

title: Id Like to Thank My Underwear
description: Djimon Hounsou, nominated for the best supporting actor Oscar for Blood Diamond, will be featured in the launch of a new line of underwear called Calvin Klein Steel, the fashion house just announced.

title: Solved: The Mystery of the Miserable Models
description: Kudos to the readers (well get to the honor roll later) who aced the models quiz and solved the mystery of their misery. (If you didnt try yet, you can take it here.) And special kudos to the readers who brought something more to the table: field reports from the fashion world confirming the scientists theory.

title: A Kinder, Softer Daniel Loeb?
description: For years, Daniel S. Loeb was best known for his viciously witty poison pen, which he used against companies he sought to shake up. But is it possible that the activist hedge funder is mellowing out?

title: Blogtalk: On War and Vilsack
description: With talk of new Senate movements to try to repeal parts of the resolution in 2002 authorizing the use of force in Iraq, the blogs lit up and havent stopped.

title: Blogtalk: Steamroller.com
description: Governor Spitzer has apparently filed to take the domain names eliotspitzer.com and eliotspitzer.org away from a New Jersey man who registered them in 2001. Watch out, steamroller.com (and can anyone explain what thats about?). [workbench]

title: In Studio With The Stooges
description: The band talks about the challenges of making the first Stooges record in 33 years.

title: K.K.R., Texas Pacific Plan Record Buyout of TXU
description: The biggest leveraged buyout ever is about to be surpassed. Again.

title: Unmasking the Sock Puppets
description: Two articles acted as bookends this week to problems that are becoming more familar to any of us who surf the Web, moderate readers comments and follow political campaigns.

title: DealBook: Sirius and XM Merge
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin tells us why the Sirius-XM merger is not one of equals.

title: Interview With Thierry Mugler
description: T Style editor Horacio Silva interviews designer Thierry Mugler about how the fashion world is embracing his brand of hard-edged otherworldly glamour.

title: Ronald Hilton, 95, Scholar of Latin America, Dies
description: Ronald Hilton, an influential scholar on Latin America who played a role in uncovering secret preparations for Cuban exiles invasion at the Bay of Pigs, died Tuesday at his home on the Stanford University campus, in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 95.

title: Trifles That Arent, but Feel a Lot Like Improv Sketches
description: Three people walk into an airport. A man loses his keys in an art museum. Another sits for a job interview. Sound like the sort of mundane situations thrown at members of an improv troupe? Such were the premises posed by the choreographer Claire Porter at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Wednesday night as part of the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival. In the end, she confounded the odds. Her collection of seven short works, Words Away From Home, was generally charming.

title: Voter ID Laws Are Unfair (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidd Has Triple Double, Again Proving His Value
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 23  Jason Kidd is not much of a talker, a fact best demonstrated in the relentless work ethic he uses to inspire his teammates.

title: Unknown Is Now the One to Beat
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23  Last June, at the United States outdoor track and field championships in Indianapolis, some of Americas best runners lined up for the start of the 800-meter final. Most wore singlets with the name or logo of their shoe-company sponsor. One runner, the 22-year-old Nick Symmonds, wore an old shirt with the initials B. K.

title: South Africa: 8 Accused of Plot Found Not Guilty
description: Eight South African men accused of joining in a March 2004 attempt to overthrow the dictatorship of Equatorial Guinea were found not guilty by a South African court, which ruled that a number of them thought that their efforts had been endorsed by South Africas government. Others apparently believed that they were en route to guard a diamond mine in Congo, the judge, Magistrate Peet Johnson, said. He called it eerie that the men had been brought to trial, saying South African prosecutors own witnesses contradicted the governments case. The men were seized after landing in Harare, Zimbabwe, in March 2004, apparently to refuel and pick up weapons.

title: A Software Maker Goes Up Against Microsoft
description: VMware, a young Silicon Valley company, is the early leader in a fast-growing market for what is called virtual-machine software. And that puts it on a collision course with Microsoft, the industrys Goliath.

title: Some Leveraged Buyout Myths
description: THE leveraged buyout boom shows no sign of abating. But Robert F. Bruner, dean of the University of Virginias business school, asks a troubling question about the trend, which has been driven by past success in increasing cash flow, asset utilization and real rates of return:

title: The Philadelphia Orchestra Names a Chief Conductor
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, facing the imminent departure of its music director, is buying time in its search for a replacement by naming Charles Dutoit chief conductor and artistic adviser.

title: Brooklyn Junkyard Fire Is Subdued After 18-Hour Battle
description: It is hard to imagine that anything is worth saving in a junkyard fire.

title: Misguided Missiles
description: Fifteen years after the cold wars end, it would seem that everyone involved should know better. But the Bush administrations tone-deaf plan to station parts of a missile defense system in Eastern Europe and Moscows snarling response show that all sides could use a refresher course in diplomatic sense and civility.

title: U.S. Seizes Son of a Top Shiite, Stirring Uproar
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 23  American troops seized and then released the eldest son of Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, perhaps the most powerful Shiite political leader in Iraq, after he crossed the border from Iran into Iraq on Friday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Tuesday with an article about plans to auction artworks belonging to the heirs of Jacques Goudstikker, a Dutch art dealer who fled the Nazis, misstated the title of a painting by Jacopo del Casentino in some copies. It is St. Lucy, not St. Mary.

title: The D-Day Heroes Who Werent White
description: With his garrison cap, steady gaze and square jaw, Allen Price of the 3275th Quartermaster Service Company, Omaha Beach, looks like another avatar of the Greatest Generation. He even complains as those superhumans do: levelly, economically, without anger or sadness.

title: Blast That Killed U.S. Diplomat Tied to Qaeda
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 22  The suicide bombing that killed an American diplomat here last March, just before a visit by President Bush, was organized by a small cell of Pakistani militants and masterminded by an operative of Al Qaeda based in the Pakistans tribal areas, Pakistan says.

title: U.S. Fugitive Starts Over in Namibia
description: Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology wanted in the United States for securities fraud, has formed a company in Namibia that will invest in construction, tourism and agriculture.

title: Vilsack Ends Bid for Presidency
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,144 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Thomas Praises Johnsons Great Play
description: The greatest highlight of Dennis Johnsons career was also one of the worst moments in the career of Isiah Thomas. Twenty years later, Thomas calls it simply a great play.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about books by presidential candidates misstated part of the title of Senator Barack Obamas 1995 memoir, which has been reissued in hardcover to capitalize on renewed interest. It is Dreams From My Father, not Dreams of My Father. The article also misidentified the original publisher of that book and of a book by Bill Clinton. It was Times Books/Random House, not PublicAffairs.

title: Canadian Court Limits Detention in Terror Cases
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 23  Canadas highest court on Friday unanimously struck down a law that allows the Canadian government to detain foreign-born terrorism suspects indefinitely using secret evidence and without charges while their deportations are being reviewed.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 5 P.M. (IFC) 2007 INDEPENDENT SPIRIT AWARDS Sarah Silverman is host of this annual celebration of filmmaking that meets four criteria: uniqueness of vision, provocative and original subject matter, economy of means, and independent financing. Some 250 submissions are competing in categories like first feature, first screenplay and the John Cassavetes Award, honoring the best feature made for under $500,000. At 4:30, WE will look at how that unique vision translates into attire in Red Carpet Arrivals From the 2007 Independent Spirit Awards.

title: Early Stops on the Sweet-Talk Circuit
description: KEENE, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton ordered a chai latte. Molly Kelly went with the regular latte.

title: A Developing Story
description: THE developer Bruce Ratner broke ground this week on his Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, despite an eminent domain suit over property he must raze to build a basketball arena for the Nets. This preparatory work is Mr. Ratners latest maneuver in a maddeningly effective campaign to make his instant city  a 22-acre swarm of 16 residential skyscrapers (and a 20,500-seat arena) that would create the densest population swath in the United States  look and feel like a foregone conclusion.

title: A New Model for Schools in the Boston Archdiocese
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Feb. 21  To the Rev. James Flavin, pastor of St. Edith Stein Roman Catholic Church here, the notion of giving up control of his parishs elementary school is one of the best ideas he has heard in a long time.

title: Authorities Search for Gunman Who Abducted a Florida Boy
description: PARRISH, Fla., Feb. 23  A 13-year-old boy was abducted at gunpoint at a school bus stop on Friday morning and was found hours later in a wooded area where he had been left bound by his captor.

title: Subscription Peddlers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island University Taking Diverse Road to Success
description: It was two in the morning the first time Valerie Nainima spoke to her future basketball coach at Long Island University, Stephanie Gaitley. Nainima was at home in Fiji, Gaitley was calling from L.I.U.s campus in Brooklyn, and the extreme time difference was something Gaitley had overlooked.

title: Rap Meets Rock Again, Looking for the Emo Generation
description: Hip-hop and rock, onstage together: its an idea whose time has come. And gone. And come again. And gone again. And so on.

title: Tuning In to One Company
description: Vigorous competition in the private sector has served the United States economy and consumers extremely well, providing a greater array of choices, more innovation and lower prices. The two  and only  satellite radio companies are now eager to merge and are arguing that together, they will prove to be the exception to the rule.

title: A Triangle Most Irregular
description: The three women in No Where start the performance standing still.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 50 of The Times Magazine this weekend, about Sam Nunn, head of the Nuclear Threat Initiative and former chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, misstates the name of a company on whose board he serves. It is Chevron, not ChevronTexaco. The article also misspells the surname of a former secretary of state with whom Nunn and others wrote a recent op-ed article for The Wall Street Journal. He is George P. Shultz, not Schulz. And the article misspells the surname of the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency in several references. He is Mohamed ElBaradei, not ElBaredei.

title: London and Tokyo Exchanges to Collaborate
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  The London Stock Exchange, Europes largest stock market, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange have agreed to work together to facilitate market access and create a 24-hour trading environment.

title: Fantasies of Women, When They Were New
description: As the stage version of My Secret Garden at the 45th Street Theater makes evident, in 1970 Nancy Friday applied herself to exploring the carnal longings of the modern American woman with the gusto of Coronado setting out for the Seven Cities of Gold. At the time, Ms. Friday, who was living in London, had been writing magazine articles instructing women in the ways of attracting wealthy and debonair men, and while she considered that a worthy pursuit, the fiery air of the sexual revolution along with her own distaste for anonymity compelled her to mark the shifting terrain more spectacularly.

title: Garbled on the Subway (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Supervision of Race in Little Rock Schools Ends
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 23  The Little Rock School District was released on Friday from federal court supervision of its desegregation efforts, almost 50 years after President Dwight D. Eisenhower dispatched federal troops to enforce an integration order that the Arkansas governor defied.

title: A Contract Is a Contract, Right?
description: So what would you do if you ran State Farms Mississippi operation?

title: Panel Cites Voter Error, Not Software, in Loss of Votes
description: Florida election officials announced yesterday that an examination of voting software did not find any malfunctions that could have caused up to 18,000 votes to be lost in a disputed Congressional race in Sarasota County, and they suggested that voter confusion over a poor ballot design was mainly to blame.

title: Swishers Workout Went Way Back to Basics
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 22  Parked in front of the Oakland Athletics spring-training complex Thursday morning was a blue big rig that had underwater treadmills for sale.

title: Burglaries on Staten Island Have Residents Ill at Ease
description: In residential areas of Staten Island, in neighborhoods with detached homes on tree-lined streets, there have been 15 more burglaries this year than in the same period last year. Nearly all of them are thought to have been committed by the same man, who has yet to be caught.

title: Record Fine Expected for Univision
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  When Univision began broadcasting a show three years ago about the misadventures of 11-year-old identical twin girls who swapped identities after discovering they had been separated at birth, it characterized the episodes as educational programming for children.

title: Canada: Native Canadians File Rights Complaint Over Child Welfare
description: A national organization representing Native Canadians, the Assembly of First Nations, filed a complaint with the Canadian Human Rights Commission over what the group says is a lack of financing for child welfare programs that has put thousands of indigenous children at risk. It is really sad we have been pushed to do this, said Phil Fontaine the groups leader.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Joseph Low, an illustrator of magazine covers and childrens books, omitted part of the name of the private press of which he became the proprietor in 1960. It was Eden Hill Press, not Hill Press.

title: Former Democratic Leader in Brooklyn Is Convicted
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the deposed Democratic assemblyman and party leader from Brooklyn, was convicted yesterday of extortion in what prosecutors said was a scheme to shake down judicial candidates in exchange for party support. It was his third conviction on corruption charges in 17 months.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Rural Maine Scrambles in Midst of a Propane Shortage
description: ETNA, Me., Feb. 22  At the Etna Variety store here, the conversation is plentiful, the coffee cup is bottomless and the cookies, pies and sandwiches are abundant. But the propane that many customers use to heat houses and hot water is in short supply.

title: Defense Secretary Vows Action on Medical Center Conditions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Friday that he would move swiftly to improve conditions for wounded soldiers being treated as outpatients at Walter Reed Army Medical Center and warned that senior officials would be held accountable for the poor conditions.

title: Sheldon K. Friedlander, Smog Scientist, Dies at 79
description: Sheldon K. Friedlander, whose research helped identify the various pollutants in smog and quantify them by source, died on Feb. 9 at his home in the Pacific Palisades section of Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Middle School Choices (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., Mexico and Canada Discuss Border Issues
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 23  American, Mexican and Canadian cabinet ministers met here on Friday to set the agenda for a meeting later this year by the leaders of the three countries, with the discussions taking an increased focus on protecting cross-border trade in the face of increasing border security measures.

title: Blackstone Said to Plan Sale of 10 San Francisco Buildings
description: The Blackstone Group, which has been rapidly dismantling its new acquisition, Equity Office Properties, plans to sell 10 buildings in downtown San Francisco to Morgan Stanley for $2.65 billion, according to an executive involved in the transaction.

title: A Failed Meeting on the Mideast (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man Who Traded a Jets Uniform for Ballet Shoes
description: I TOOK my first tentative steps in executive pursuit of ballet when I tiptoed up to the door of an apartment building in Lower Manhattan. It was one of the coldest days of the year. My 55-year-old muscles and bones were wrapped in layers of cotton, cashmere and wool. But I felt as if I was going to freeze into an ice sculpture before I even managed to learn the difference between a pli and a pirouette.

title: Aquatic Visitor Becomes a Jersey Shore Tourist Attraction
description: MANASQUAN, N.J., Feb. 23  Since Valentines Day, a dark-faced visitor with a tanned, blubbery physique has been breaking hearts along the Jersey Shore.

title: Leaving the Options Open With Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  As the Bush administration tries to rally allies to tighten sanctions on Iran yet again, it is sending mixed messages to Tehran about its commitment to a diplomatic solution, trying to create new openings for negotiations even while holding open, ever so vaguely, the possibility that the United States might some day resort to force.

title: Coughlin Defends His Approach, Offering Rebuttal to Barber
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 23  Before taking the podium at the N.F.L. scouting combine Friday, a smiling Tom Coughlin stood outside an exhibit hall at the Indiana Convention Center chatting cordially with reporters.

title: Soda Promotion Backfires in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23  Another guerrilla marketing campaign has backfired in Boston, but this time it involved coins, not cartoons.

title: Family Hands Off Its Business, and Its Philosophy
description: HOLLAND, Mich.  Right up there with putting an aging parent in a nursing home stands the wrenching job of handing over a family business to be run by outsiders.

title: Richard Lehman, Creator of Crucial Intelligence Memo, Dies at 83
description: Richard Lehman, a high-ranking Central Intelligence Agency analyst who, on orders from a perturbed President John F. Kennedy, developed the succinct intelligence summary that has been handed to presidents each morning for 45 years, died last Saturday near his home in Concord, N.H. He was 83.

title: How a Cast Got Its Kicks. And Throws. And Punches.
description: The rule at rehearsals was simple: If you hit someone for real, you owe them a beer, said Timothy Haskell, director of The Jaded Assassin, which runs through March 4 at the Ohio Theater in SoHo and includes more than an hours worth of onstage martial-arts combat.

title: A Cat Without Whiskers
description: SEATTLE

title: Italian Kennedy Polishes Eyewear and Image
description: BOLOGNA, Italy

title: Retired Politicians Spend Unused Campaign Funds
description: When Michael J. Bragman, a onetime Assembly majority leader, retired from the New York State Legislature in 2001, his campaign committee had about $1 million in the bank. Six years later, Mr. Bragman is still retired, and $400,000 of that money is gone.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 79TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Ellen DeGeneres sidles up to Oscar - again - as host of this granddaddy of award ceremonies, broadcast from the Kodak Theater in Hollywood. Presenters include Ben Affleck, Cate Blanchett, George Clooney, Daniel Craig, Rachel Weisz, Kate Winslet, Reese Witherspoon, Tom Cruise, Penlope Cruz and Nicole Kidman. Celebrity arrivals will be swooned over on "Live From the Red Carpet: The 2007 Academy Awards" at 6 on E!; "An Evening at the Academy Awards: The Arrivals" at 6:30 on ABC, and "Road to the Oscars 2007" at 8 on ABC. Post-festivity specials include "Live 2007 Academy Awards Post-Show" at midnight on E!, and "Jimmy Kimmel Live: After the Academy Awards," featuring Ms. DeGeneres (above) and scenes from the five best picture nominees, performed by Guillermo, a security guard, at 12:05 a.m.

title: French Join U.S. Rsistance Over London Traffic Charge
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  Ever since the London authorities imposed a charge to drive into the city center in 2003, the United States Embassy has stood as a beacon of automotive defiance, refusing to pay what its diplomats call a tax from which they should be exempt.

title: Bondss Lawyer Begins Offensive Against Inquiry
description: The criminal defense lawyer for Barry Bonds is going on the offensive in an attempt to discredit the governments investigation of Bonds just as a new federal prosecutor steps in to oversee the inquiry.

title: Pole Dancing Parties Catch On in Book Club Country
description: KINNELON, N.J.  Johnna Cottam was showing a group of her girlfriends how to do a move called the Fireman.

title: Late Move-In Imperils Victory of Candidate in Council Race
description: A Brooklyn mans election to the City Council this week has created confusion over the states murky election laws that govern city candidates residency requirements, raising questions that could imperil his victory.

title: Yes, Its Vivaldi, but Phrased as Youve Never Heard Him
description: In its decade together, the Venice Baroque Orchestra has thrown itself into the Italian Baroque repertory, with Vivaldi as a particular specialty. When the group performed at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening, Vivaldi was plentiful. The only other composer on the program was Tartini, and Vivaldis works outnumbered his seven to one.

title: Correction
description: A letter yesterday about the Anglican rift misstated the final word in a quotation from the former bishop of New Hampshire, the Rt. Rev. Douglas Theuner. He said, Were talking about the wrong H word: its not homosexuality, but honesty (not hypocrisy).

title: Co-Defendants of Padilla Are Seeking to Split Cases
description: MIAMI, Feb. 23  As a competency hearing for Jose Padilla gets under way in federal court here, his co-defendants in a terrorism conspiracy case are seeking separate trials because of what they fear is the taint of his notoriety as the accused dirty bomber.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the growing market for carbon-offset trading companies misstated the year in which the total sales of offsets was $6 million. It was 2004, not 2005.

title: New Parts in Old System Are Cited in Amtrak Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  The power supply system for trains running between New York and Washington, a concatenation of parts whose oldest links date back 80 years, failed last May 25 because of a hidden flaw in some of the newest equipment in the chain, the railroad said Friday.

title: Rhode Island: Governments Days Off
description: Gov. Donald L. Carcieri, a Republican, signed an executive order to shut down state government for four days during the rest of the 2007 fiscal year to help ease a budget deficit of $350 million. All employees except state police, corrections officers and health workers will be ordered to stay home from work without pay on March 30, April 6, May 25 and June 8, at an estimated savings of $9.6 million. The state will also require three furlough days in the 2008 fiscal year, for an estimated savings of $7.7 million.

title: President Promotes Alternative Energy With a Car Show of Sorts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Bush turned to alternative fuels, and alternative companies, to argue Friday that his goal for reining in gasoline consumption in the coming decade was realistic.

title: New Republic Cuts Back, but Bulks Up Its Image
description: The New Republic, the thinning, left-leaning weekly magazine whose circulation has been hurt by the Web and possibly by what some of its core readers view as an insufficiently progressive stance against the Bush administration, has a new ownership and a new publishing schedule. CanWest Global Communications, a Canadian media conglomerate, which has held a minority share in the 93-year-old magazine, has now obtained majority control. It plans a substantial overhaul of the magazine and its Web site, including cutting back publication of the magazine to every two weeks while almost doubling the number of pages.

title: Woods Meets His Match as Winning Streak Ends
description: MARANA, Ariz., Feb. 23  High on a hill framed by desert clouds, Nick OHern walked to the collar of the first green of the Gallery Golf Club and prepared to remove his cap in defeat.

title: At Intuit, What Comes After Taxes?
description: Intuit is in an enviable position. It dominates every business it is in from small-business accounting software, with QuickBooks, to tax-preparation software, with TurboTax.

title: In Clintons Backyard, Its Open Season as an Obama Fund-Raiser Lines Up Donors
description: Twenty-eight stories above Sixth Avenue in Manhattan, Jeh Johnson was dialing away.

title: Deeply Concerned, Special Panel Will Extend Study to Small-Town Courts
description: Saying its members are deeply concerned about the quality of justice in New Yorks town and village courts, a state commission will conduct an intensive review to consider changes in the widely criticized system, a report to be released on Monday says.

title: When Disillusion Sets In
description: On Nov. 27, Bhupinder Baber walked into a Quiznos restaurant on the outskirts of Los Angeles. He spoke briefly with the manager before stepping into the restroom and shooting himself three times in the chest.

title: Read It? No, but You Can Skim a Few Pages and Fake It
description: PARIS, Feb. 23  It may well be that too many books are published, but by good fortune, not all must be read. In practice, primed by publishers, critics, teachers, authors and word-of-mouth, a form of natural selection limits essential reading to those classics and best sellers that become part of civilized intellectual and social discourse.

title: For a Wine Whose Labels Are Noted for Artistry, the Latest Has a Royal Touch
description: Being Baroness Philippine de Rothschild is not easy, it turns out. You have to watch out for do-gooders like William Rush Jenkins who are always trying to brush that little red speck off your dress  that little speck east of your rather large Rene Boivin necklace and west of your shoulder.

title: Italy: 19 Migrants Dead at Sea
description: At least 19 people trying to migrate to Italy from northern Africa on a rubber dinghy died in the waters between Tunisia and Sicily, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. A group of 31 survivors were rescued from the dingy this week and told the authorities about the others who died during the trip. Their bodies were thrown into the sea, one of the survivors was quoted as saying in Lampedusa, Italys southernmost island. The causes of death were unclear and none of the bodies have yet been found. The group had set sail from Libya.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the Indian film Parzania, about a boy who disappeared during violence in Gujarat state, where theater owners have refused to show it, referred incorrectly to the reason another film encountered problems being screened in India. The Central Board of Film Certification held up the release of the film Black Friday, about the 1993 terror attacks in Mumbai, after those on trial for the attacks argued that the film could prejudice a court against them  not that it could prejudice potential jurors. (India does not have a jury system.)

title: New Airport X-Rays Scan Bodies, Not Just Bags
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 23  X-ray vision has come to the airport checkpoint here, courtesy of federal aviation security officials who have installed a new device that peeks underneath passengers clothing to search for guns, bombs or liquid explosives.

title: New Inquiry on Options at KB Home
description: The United States attorneys office in Los Angeles is looking into stock-option backdating at KB Home, the national home builder, but the company said yesterday that it was not the target of the investigation.

title: A Nation at War, Ogling the Famous (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Chrysler Unit, Buyouts for Older Workers
description: The Chrysler Group, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, took a step toward its promised job cuts yesterday and said it would offer some of its older employees three months pay if they leave the company by May 31.

title: A Folk-Pop Voice Making Sly Asides About Our Times
description: If the singer-songwriter Richard Julian had come of age 25 years ago, he would probably have joined a long list of musicians hailed as the latest new Dylan  a critical sobriquet, promiscuously bestowed, that turned out to be a career curse for many of the heirs apparent to Bob Dylans artistic crown. Mr. Julian, who appeared on a triple bill at the Allen Room on Thursday with his fellow New York singer-songwriters Sasha Dobson and Jesse Harris as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, writes aphoristic folk-rock songs packed with sly, joking wordplay. Keen social observation is tinged with a hipsters sarcasm.

title: A Mountain of Margin Debt May Not Be Cause for Concern
description: American investors are now deeper in debt  at least in their margin accounts  than ever before. And that is starting to arouse concern of excessive speculation.

title: In N.F.L. Draft, This Competition Has No Winners
description: Indianapolis

title: Eighth U.S. Attorney Dismissed From Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  A United States attorney in Grand Rapids, Mich., is leaving her job, the eighth federal prosecutor to be removed in a Justice Department shake-up of prosecutors, government officials said Friday.

title: Where the Flamingos Dance a Shuffle
description: Flamingos, as a group, need a better agent. Their mating dance, simultaneously ridiculous and beautiful, is the high point of Andes: The Dragons Back, tomorrow night on PBSs Nature. But you can probably guess who, or what, hogs a large chunk of the screen time: those increasingly annoying penguins. Enough, already, with the tuxedoed hams. Yes, theyre cute and interesting, but so was Rachael Ray, for a while; now you just wish you could find a television show or a Ritz box without her on it.

title: Better Pay for Judges
description: Justice Anthony Kennedy of the Supreme Court told the Senate this month that the salaries paid to federal judges are so low that they threaten both the quality and the independence of the judiciary. The problem is real, and Congress should quickly pass a bill to fix it.

title: Modern Premiere Attended by Gershwin and Mozart
description: On Thursday night the New York Philharmonic played the world premiere of a fine trombone concerto by Melinda Wagner. But from the program, you might have thought the point was to obscure the work, not highlight it.

title: Eyes Wide Open, With Stories to Tell
description: Jeff Walls large color transparencies mounted on electric light boxes fill 10 galleries at the Museum of Modern Art with a pulsating and purposeful, if slightly sedate, optimism. Alluring to the point of transfixion, the 41 works measure as much as 10 feet high or 16 feet across. These are outright gorgeous, fully equipped all-terrain visual vehicles, intent on being intensely pleasurable while making a point or two about society, art, history, visual perception, the human animal or all of the above.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: All You magazine, New York, promoted one executive and hired another. Tracy Stalzer, Midwest manager, became associate publisher, a new post. And Jos R. Prez became vice president for consumer marketing, assuming duties from Gary Foodim, consumer marketing director, who became digital brand marketing director at People magazine, New York. Mr. Prez remains vice president for consumer marketing at a People sibling, People en Espaol. All You, People and People en Espaol are all part of the Time Inc. division of Time Warner.

title: Cutting Back Without Deprivation
description: It sounds like something that would happen in San Francisco. In 2005, a few friends gathered for dinner and started bemoaning the fate of the planet, the environmental impact of consumer excess  and ended up challenging one another to not buy anything new for six months.

title: Knicks Win a Close One, but It Still Is Painful
description: It took an unexpected whistle, a television replay and two clutch free throws for the Knicks to fashion their latest dramatic victory. In a season packed with last-second stunners, this one will rank as the oddest.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Bright New Look For the Bronze Figures Watching Over Philadelphia

title: Times Company Nominates Board Member
description: The New York Times Company has nominated Daniel H. Cohen to its board after Cathy J. Sulzberger chose not to stand for re-election.

title: Congressional Democrats Wrestle Over How to Force Bush to Alter Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Congressional Democrats, divided over how to press President Bush to alter his policy in Iraq, are wrestling over whether to use the power of the purse to wind down the war, and they seem headed for a confrontation among themselves, possibly as early as next week, over a proposal to revoke the 2002 resolution authorizing the war.

title: In Time Trial, Leipheimer Adds to Lead
description: SOLVANG , Calif., Feb 23  So intent was Levi Leipheimer on winning the Tour of California this year that, oddly enough, he had to force himself to stay off his bicycle on some days last fall so he would not burn himself out too early.

title: Indian Film With Roots So Deep That It Defies Borders
description: Win or lose tomorrow night at the Academy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles, one contender  Deepa Mehtas Water, a nominee for best foreign-language film  will already have scored its greatest triumph simply by existing.

title: Protecting All Students
description: Like all too many school districts, Toms River, N.J., has done a poor job of protecting gay students from bullying. According to the New Jersey Supreme Court, the district punished students for being one minute late for class, but made harassing another child for being gay punishable only after a third offense.

title: Rudy & Mitt Hem & Haw on Abortion
description: Were seeing some awfully complicated positions on abortion from some of the presidential candidates. Its easy to hoot with derision.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Deals in Radio and Food; Remorse From an Airline
description: TWO deals punctuated a holiday-shortened week: one, a combination that might run into heavy regulatory scrutiny, the other, less so. In any case, regulators will have a little more time on their hands as the Bush administration and a working group of agencies rejected more oversight of the rapidly growing hedge fund industry.

title: A Martyr for France, and for Love
description: According to legend, Joan of Arcs heart was not consumed by the flames as she was burned at the stake. Neither, according to historical sources, was her heart inflamed with love for a knight while she was alive.

title: Mets Bench Coach Prefers Being Heard and Not Seen
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 23  Jerry Manuel sat in his hotel room in Dearborn, Mich., early in the 2000 season watching his Chicago White Sox eke out a tense victory against the Detroit Tigers when he started planning a welcome back party. Manuel, who was serving the first day of a suspension for his role in a brawl, went downstairs, borrowed a uniform from a doorman and waited for his team to return.

title: David Berger, Lawyer and Class-Action Hero, Dies at 94
description: David Berger, a lawyer who achieved fame, fortune and influence by helping to expand the ability of groups of people to file suits jointly in federal courts, died on Thursday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 94.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: Title-Worthy Declarer Play, Courtesy of the Netherlands
description: The 12th NEC Bridge Festival was held Feb. 7 to 12 in Yokohama, Japan. Israel, the winners of the NEC Cup for the last two years, lost in the quarterfinals to the Netherlands, this deal being decisive and featuring many peoples choice for the best piece of declarer play from the event.

title: Tournament Winner Says He Was Wrong
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 23  After resolving a lawsuit over his victory in the World Series of Poker last summer, Jamie Gold acknowledged he had some regrets about his experience at the tournament, although none of them were about his legal issues.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Wednesday about Mary Rose, at the Vineyard Theater on East 15th Street, misidentified the actor who plays a vicar. He is Tom Riis Farrell  not Ian Brennan, who portrays another character, Mr. Cameron.

title: Borders Without Fences
description: Kelly, Wyo.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 10 P.M. (13) STING: SONGS FROM THE LABYRINTH The songs of John Dowland have been gently haunting me for over 20 years, Sting said of the English composer and court musician who was born in 1563 during an age of religious and political discord. For me they are pop songs written around 1600 and I relate to them in that way: beautiful melodies, fantastic lyrics and great accompaniments. In this Great Performances special, filmed at his estates in England and Italy, Sting performs songs like Can She Excuse My Wrongs, Come Again, Flow My Tears and In Darkness Let Me Dwell with Edin Karamazov, a lutenist, and recites lines from Dowlands personal correspondence.

title: Starbucks Chairman Fears Tradition Is Fading
description: The last thing that Starbucks wants is watered-down coffee.

title: State Reduces Tax Breaks for Developers
description: The great shortage of 2007 in New Yorks real estate market is not of land, concrete or electricians.

title: At $45 Billion, New Contender for Top Buyout
description: The biggest leveraged buyout ever is about to be surpassed. Again.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A brief report in Science Times on Feb. 13, about a study of hormonal responses to the odor of a substance in male sweat, misspelled part of the name of an institution in Israel where the senior author of the study works. It is the Weizmann Institute of Science, not Weissman.

title: At Least JetBlue Is Sorry (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Haunted by Ghosts of the Past, Beckoned by a Homeland
description: At the end of The Abandoned, a horror movie about a woman who goes to Russia in search of her past, a voice-over muses that the wiser course might have been to leave the past alone and forget all about it. This advice might have been more useful, to the heroine and to me, if it had come about 90 minutes earlier, but what can you do? Whats done is done.

title: Fear of Return of Berlusconi Reunites Left Behind Prodi
description: ROME, Feb. 23  It wasnt love or even any real faith that they could stick together long. Rather, it seems, a singular frightening thought pushed nine bickering parties to agree late on Thursday to come together again: that Silvio Berlusconi might soon lead Italy again.

title: Chvez Ends Busy Week Aiding Venezuelas Latin Neighbors
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 23  President Hugo Chvez met here on Friday with President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua to discuss an array of Venezuelan assistance programs, capping an unusually frenetic week for this countrys efforts to enhance its political and economic influence in parts of Latin America.

title: Zimbabwe: Teachers End Strike After Pay Deal
description: Teachers ended a three-week strike after President Robert G. Mugabes government partly met their demands for a 400 percent pay increase, raising basic salaries to more than $100 a month, still below the poverty line for a family of five. Because Zimbabwe struggles with rampant inflation, now at an annual rate of nearly 1,600 percent, it was unclear how long the new salaries would satisfy union demands. Mr. Mugabes government has struggled in recent weeks with threats of strikes by civil servants, the bedrock of popular support for his government. Raymond Mjongwe, the head of the Progressive Teachers Union of Zimbabwe, called the pay increases a starting point and said the teachers were returning to work to avoid inconveniencing families with children.

title: Sharing the Wealth at MTV
description: A WEEK before Viacom announced that it would make video content available online through a site called Joost, the Viacom-owned MTV Networks said that it would soon allow other Web sites to embed video clips from its own sites: MTV.com, VH1.com, Comedycentral.com, BET.com and others.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The headline with an obituary on Sunday about Steven Pimlott, a British theater and opera director, misidentified his role in the 1993 Broadway revival of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat. He was the director, not the producer. The obituary misidentified the theater officials who announced that they would proceed with a production of The Rose Tattoo that Mr. Pimlott had been directing in rehearsals. The officials were with the National Theater in London, where the festival will be staged  not officials at the Chichester Festival Theater, where Mr. Pimlott had been an artistic director.

title: $45 Billion Bid for a Texas Utility in Biggest Buyout Ever
description: The biggest leveraged buyout ever is about to be surpassed. Again.

title: When Arctic Char Are Biting, It Takes a Close Eye to Notice
description: GEVSJON, Sweden  It seems like a gratuitous insult to vegetarians that the Scandinavian method of ice fishing involves a reindeer pelt. But that is what Norwegians and Swedes traditionally use as a warm cushion while they lie face down on frozen lakes, peering into the holes they have drilled in the ice, watching their bait wiggle.

title: Think Your Social Security Number Is Secure? Think Again
description: It should come as little surprise that Social Security numbers are posted on the Internet. But, says Betty Ostergren, a former insurance claims supervisor in suburban Richmond, Va., who has spent years trolling for them, people are always astounded to learn that theirs is one of them.

title: The Dos and Donts on Disclosing Data
description: Why is it difficult, if not impossible, to get electricity or buy a cellphone without disclosing your Social Security number?

title: In Reserve Role, Yankees Plan to Keep Cabrera Busy
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 23  The Yankees starting outfielders have combined for almost 5,000 career games in the major leagues and Japan. Hideki Matsui, Johnny Damon and Bobby Abreu will all be 33 by midseason, and they all could use a break now and then.

title: Ethiopian Adviser Denies New York Times Report
description: A senior Ethiopian official yesterday denied a report in The New York Times detailing the close and largely clandestine collaboration between Ethiopia and the United States to kill or capture leaders of Al Qaeda in the Horn of Africa.

title: Morgan Trade Head Is 2nd-Highest Paid
description: Morgan Stanley, the securities firm, paid its co-head of trading, Neal A Shear, $35 million for 2006, making him the firms second highest-paid executive.

title: U.S. in Talks With Britain on Installing Missile Defense System
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  Britain and the United States said Friday that they were discussing the stationing of an American antiballistic missile defense system on British soil.

title: Cool Studes
description: Studebaker set styling trends and still arouses passions. Browse seven classic models and see why.

title: Please Don't Tip the Robots
description: Take a tour of AutoMotion Parking Systems' automated garage at 123 Baxter Street in Chinatown, the first of its kind in New York City.

title: The Latest Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: Sharp elbows characterize this months round-up of authors on the stumps and soapboxes. Whether they are shaking hands or kissing babies, (or as some might conflate it, kissing hands and shaking babies), merely kissing up or shaking things up, there are a lot of viewpoints expressed here whose only common ground is their cloth bindings.

title: Jeff Wall
description: Images from the Jeff Wall show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Berkshire-Hathaway and Darfur
description: After my column on Darfur divestment, noting that Berkshire-Hathaway is the largest investor in H-shares in Petrochina, a major and insidious player in Sudan, the company put out a statement. It essentially says that theres not much that Berkshire-Hathaway can do, that the entity in China is slightly different from the entity that Berkshire-Hathaway invests in, and that dumping the shares would be costly.

title: Thats My Wife!
description: So while I was gallivanting around Ethiopia and Somaliland, my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, was hanging out with jokers on Comedy Central. Sheryl was on Colbert Report the other day to talk about China. Heres the segment.

title: Killer Movie
description: The Bagger joined Manohla Dargis, one of the chief film critics at the House of Many Doors, last night with some other pals. They all went to Lou, which is named after her husband, possibly because he owns the joint. There is something called Pig Candy on the menu that involves bacon and sugar, so the Bagger was in high blood sugar heaven. Its a serious wine bar with all manner of meat, cheese and olives  the three best food groups  tucked into a very cool room in a shopping center at the bottom of Hollywood.

title: The Complete Package
description: Mr. von Donnersmarck with one of his stars.

title: Straw Man, Straw Poll
description: There was a nice little lunch out in Brentwood at Arianna Huffingtons house yesterday. It was sort of fancy  the Bagger spent 15 minutes trying to figure out which fork to use  but the conversation was rocking. There was a lot of talk about Clinton, Obama and Geffen, as there has been all week at every place Priuses gather.

title: Indie Cred
description: There will be a lot of busyness this morning: the Bagger is making a video as the Kodak Theater gets built out  cheesy we know, but the conventions of broadcast must be observed. Then a trip out to the Independent Spirit Awards in Santa Monica. The Bagger gave up his seat to Mrs. Bagger  dont tell anyone, please  so he will be working the proceedinga from the press gulag, but he is so there for you, man. If host Sarah Silverman wanders out of the tent and begins doing a street person monologue, he will be there. If Maggie Gyllenhaal causes a stir by her mere presence, he will be there. And if one of the independent-minded celebs gets a little too jiggy with it at the swag tent, well, count on the Bagger to issue a full report.

title: Who Do You Think We Are?
The Security Challenge
description: Marc Santora explains the complicated, violent insurgency American and Iraqi forces confront in Samarra.

title: Scott Speed at Toro Rosso
description: Today the Toro Rosso team decided to put an unequivocal end to the strange story it had been stringing out about whether or not Scott Speed would race for them again next year.

title: Every One Calls Him Sandy
description: The royal we has landed at the Spirit Awards and conditions on the carpet are treacherous, give or take the beach, the palm trees and the movie stars. We did get a nice little moment with Lawrence Bender, the producer of An Inconvenient Truth, who told us there is nothing to the rumors that Al Gore might announce for 2008 if he gets to the podium tomorrow night. The rest of the afternoon looks long and fun  as soon as we finish making video and get off the carpet, we will find a place to sit and update you on the proceedings. As a bit of an indie-film geek, the Bagger has to admit he is actually looking forward to the proceedings.

title: A Fight to Save Mothers
description: Why doesn't the world care enough to save the lives of mothers? Maternal mortality rates have remained constant for 30 years.

title: Abraham's Mother
description: How will a newborn survive without his mother in rural Ethiopia?

title: A Struggle to Survive
description: The Addis Ababa Fistula Hospital works to help women who have sustained serious injuries during labor.

title: Video: How Many Mothers for a Mercedes?
description: There are several wonderful people featured in the video that accompanies Nicks Sunday column. Im confident that one person will stand out, Edna Adan.

title: Mothers at Risk
description: How did the sale of a Mercedes result in the saving of so many lives?

title: Carl Is Hit, Damon Is Missing and A-Rod Is a HitIn Tampa, at Least
description: Carl Pavano, the $40 million pitcher who cannot or will not figure out a way to pitch in a major league game, nearly endured another mishap on Saturday. During live batting practice, Pavano was hit in the bottom of the left foot by a line drive.

title: Conflicted Interest
description: Seen at Tradition Field this morning: A woman with a Yankees tattoo on her right ankle was wearing a Dominican Republic Martinez 45 T-shirt. Dont see that combination every day at Mets camp.

title: Host of Issues
description: Sarah Silverman got right to business, saying, Hey, theres Britney Spears. Oh wait, its Djimon Hounsou. I always get them mixed up.

title: Shortcuts
description: Robert Downey Jr. and Lily Tomlin offered tributes to Robert Altman, to very good effect.

title: Unchained Rhetoric
description: John Waters mentioned Christina Ricci, who he said was to present the best screenplay awared, adding, appropos of Black Snake Moan, I wouldnt mind if Samuel Jackson chained me to a radiator.

title: The Worst Segue of This Show or Any Others
description: America loves its guns almost as much as they love this next presenter.  Voice of God announcer introducing Doogie Howser, of all people.

title: Whoa
description: The Bagger had a few technical difficulties. Actually, it was a massive you know what. He has since walked down the beach and found a connection that works.

title: Your Comments on Maternal Mortality
description: You can comment here on my Sunday column on maternal mortality. Just click on the comment button below. And since I started inviting comments on this blog, the letters editor says that letters to the editor relating to my columns have fallen off, so remember that you can also send your comment to letters@nytimes.com.

title: The Winter That Wasnt (Until It Was)
description: THE world is supposed to contract in the winter, to shrink inside a dark shell, to tighten like a drum. The sun retracts, the light drains, the warmth leaks away. A bony carapace grows over the land, and the soul. Everything soft and green deflates, hardens to a gray, stony core.

title: The Great Carrot Caper
description: Last December, right around Christmas, I received a small package from Jean-Marc Montegottero, an artisanal-nut-oil producer in Burgundy. The package contained a shoebox filled with dust. Flummoxed, I phoned his American distributor and importer and our mutual friend, Olivier Wittmann, to inquire about this strange gift.

title: Hart Crane
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mayor Goes One-on-One
description: Every few weeks, Newarks mayor, Cory Booker, goes to a school or some other meeting place and talks with anyone who shows up. He does not give speeches, nor does he seek to dominate conversation. He mainly listens and, from time to time, after hearing about a problem, he will pick up his cellphone and ask a city official or private organization to help solve it.

title: One Path to Rebirth in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: In Big Buyout, Utility to Limit New Coal Plants
description: Under a proposed $45 billion buyout by a team of private equity firms, the TXU Corporation, a Texas utility that has long been the bane of environmental groups, will abandon plans to build 8 of 11 coal plants and commit to a broad menu of environmental measures, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Magazine

title: Street Theater at the Pull of a Curtain
description: VIEWS are a relatively modern travel discovery. Granted, much of the stuff they're made of has very likely been there a while, but historically speaking, one stopped at the inn to get off the congested and foul-smelling streets, not to look out at them.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Christopher Shinn
description: To me its almost like a democratic responsibility to write sad plays, said Christopher Shinn, whose latest work, Dying City, is in previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, where it opens March 4. My favorite American play is Long Days Journey Into Night, one of the saddest plays known to man, he added. What I admire about all of those great American playwrights was their fearlessness in writing very sad plays.

title: The Eisenhower Decade Is Back, at Least Onstage
description: IN various pockets of the fashion and design worlds, the years of the new millennium have been characterized by a return to the visual language of the 1950s. We have seen the arch-frump style of Prada, the housewife-at-the-country-club dresses from various American designers, the pink KitchenAid mixers that might have come from the cabinets of Ozzie and Harriet. Sometimes the take has been wistful, sometimes cheeky. Often the players involved hope to call our attention to some of the more insidious aspects of midcentury social and cultural conformism.

title: Al Qaeda Resurgent
description: Almost five and a half years ago, America  united by the shock of 9/11  understood exactly what it needed to do. It had to find, thwart and take down the command structure of Al Qaeda, which was responsible for the deaths of 3,000 innocent people on American soil. Despite years of costly warfare in Afghanistan and Iraq, America today is not significantly closer to that essential goal.

title: Quality of Care at Retail Clinics; Yet Another Place for Good Movies (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dressing Down
description: It may be that I am too sensitive, but I cringe when I hear a luxury tycoon say, as he kisses his manicured fingertips, Fay-shunn should make you dream. Easy for him to say. Fashion is horribly expensive. And when did designer clothes get so far beyond ordinary reach that it became necessary to give them an air of sanctity and suffering, as though we were pilgrims not for Mecca but for Prada?

title: And the Mirror Says: Go for It, Dreamgirl
description: THREE years ago, Jennifer Hudsons best-known fashion statement was a pantsuit that Simon Cowell, the resident acerbic of American Idol, compared to a roll of aluminum foil. But Ms. Hudsons not holding a grudge. He talked about me bad, but maybe I needed to be talked about, she said. At that time I didnt really understand the language of fashion.

title: Theodora Skipitares
description: ALL the seats in Theodora Skipitaress East Third Street living room were occupied, and like a good hostess, she introduced her guests.

title: Two in the Bush
description: Safari is the Swahili word for journey, but it also vaguely means that you are unobtainable. It means your cellphone does not work. Your watch is in your backpack. You wear the same clothes several days in a row. Your eyes become accustomed to darkness at night, and your ears become attuned to individual birdcalls. After a while, you begin to speak a different language.

title: A Thaw in the Housing Market
description: WHEN it comes to home sales in Westchester, spring seems to be arriving earlier than usual this year, according to brokers and others who monitor the residential real estate market.

title: Alpines vs. Armchairs
description: SEATTLE

title: Citigroup Expected to Name a New Financial Chief
description: Citigroup, one of the worlds largest banks, is expected to name Gary L. Crittenden as its new chief financial officer in a move that aims to appease frustrated investors and end weeks of top management turmoil.

title: Starting Life Organic
description: Gourmet Organic, better known around Jersey Citys hip Harsimus Cove neighborhood as just GO, is no Whole Foods  youll have to get your bulk chickpeas elsewhere. But it is something like a port in the storm of nearby burrito and bagel joints.

title: Same Stooges. Different World. Finer Wine.
description: THERE are the Stooges, from Ann Arbor, Mich., accidental inventors of punk, in the summer of 1970, on nationwide television. And theres Iggy Pop, their singer: bare torso and sausage-casing jeans, silver gloves, dog collar, chipped front tooth.

title: Letters
description: Making Money for Yale

title: Christian Right Labors to Find 08 Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  A group of influential Christian conservatives and their allies emerged from a private meeting at a Florida resort this month dissatisfied with the Republican presidential field and uncertain where to turn.

title: Tiny State, Big Ambitions
description: HAS Connecticut become an incubator for presidential ambitions?

title: Siem Reap, Cambodia:  Htel de la Paix
description: THE BASICS

title: Digital Deprivation in a Land of Affluence
description: Sharon, Conn.

title: The Heir Bag
description: My government will introduce legislation bequeathing all my titles, dominions, realms, chattels, corgis, etc., and so on, in perpetuity, to my loyal collection of handbags . . .

title: Clearing the Decks, and Staterooms, for the Whole Clan
description: WHEN the Norwegian Cruise Lines Sun sails out of New Orleans for Central America in April, Kelli Darcy, her husband, her two sons and 51 other friends and members of her family, including both sets of her boys grandparents, will be among the ships passengers. The group, ranging in age from 2 to 78, will cave dive, zip line and tour their way through Belize, Guatemala and Mexico on the seven-day trip.

title: The Way of No Flesh
description: In his tireless quest to wean England from meat in the early 18th century, the famously corpulent Dr. George Cheyne set out to poison the novelist Samuel Richardson. It may not really have been a premeditated attempt at murder. Richardson, who was a literary pioneer with his epistolary novels Clarissa and Pamela, so valued the good doctors advice that he had every letter Cheyne sent him transcribed and eventually bound into a volume, the way his novels heroines might cherish the communications of a handsome rake. And Dr. Cheyne, whom Tristram Stuart calls the most influential vegetarian in 18th-century Britain (as well as a man renowned as a drunken fatso), may also have really believed that the best way to treat the writers cold was with large doses of mercury.

title: The Truth About Coal
description: Last Wednesday, members of the Rainforest Action Network, a scrappy little advocacy group, assembled in New York outside the Citigroup Center, where Merrill Lynch has a branch office. Dressed in top hats, carrying bags of coal and calling themselves Billionaires for Coal, the group was protesting what it felt was the hypocrisy of a giant investment bank that proclaims a devout commitment to environmental excellence even as it provides financing for dirty power plants.

title: When Religious Needs Test Company Policy
description: MANAGERS must deal with big issues all day long  from acquisitions to runaway health care costs  but in many cases it is the little things that count the most. That can be especially true in matters of faith in the workplace.

title: When Renters Reach the Breaking Point
description: WHETHER they preferred apartments uptown or downtown, walk-up or doorman buildings, and old or new construction, many New Yorkers agreed on one thing about the Manhattan real estate market in the last year: it was safer to rent than to buy.

title: Knicks View of Nets Bumper Is Closer Than Usual
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 24  Detroit leads the Eastern Conference, Toronto leads the Atlantic Division and a pair of Florida teams stand between the Knicks and a playoff berth. Yet somehow the Knicks still seem to be chasing the team just across the river  out of habit, if nothing else.

title: A Wave of Change for a Quiet Block
description: SLOPING down from the crest of Carnegie Hill, East 93rd Street from Madison to Fifth Avenues is a peaceful block in the Carnegie Hill Historic District, with a mix of old brownstones and later town-house renovations of the 1920s and 1930s. Now workers trucks double-park here as several renovations bring a fresh wave of change.

title: Correction: Second Thoughts Pay Off
description: A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday, about the conversion of part of the Christian Science church on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village into condominiums, misstated the year that the church was modernized. It was in 1966, not 1996.

title: In a Fight to the End, the Billboards Lose
description: AT the moment, the Rev. Kristopher Okwedy has only one billboard on public view on Staten Island. No bigger than a poster and sitting above Misus Unisex Salon on Victory Boulevard in Tompkinsville, it shows a pair of hands holding a box wrapped with pink ribbon. The text assures passers-by that eternal life is the Prescribed Lifestyle for All Humanity.

title: Off Rent Stabilization and Facing Renovation
description: Q My one-bedroom apartment went off rent stabilization last year, and the landlord immediately raised the rent to $3,000. Now he says that unless I agree to a full kitchen and bath renovation  leaving me without plumbing for weeks and allowing him to raise the rent another several hundred dollars  he will not renew my lease. Since Im no longer rent-stabilized, do I have any rights?

title: Surprise Subpoenas
description: Just as the movers and shakers in Trenton were about to close up the State House for the Presidents Day weekend, federal investigators arrived with a set of subpoenas that could open up the way business is done in the New Jersey capital.

title: History Swims in the Bronx
description: How clean can the Bronx River get? And how much biological diversity can such an urban river sustain? These are the questions posed by the recent appearance of a male beaver, lodge and all, in the Bronx. Unlike the manatee that swam up the Hudson last year  its species has never called New York home  beavers were synonymous with this city until they were trapped out 200 years ago. Like so many species, they display an extraordinary tolerance for the presence of humans, as long as humans are able to leave them alone.

title: Op-Art: Who Do You Think We Are?
description: IN Alan J. Pakulas 1974 film The Parallax View, the nefarious Parallax Corporation uses a questionnaire to recruit potential assassins. Sociopaths and psychopaths are weeded in with a battery of questions that expose their psychological strengths and weaknesses, secrets and predilections. At the opposite end of the moral spectrum, and with utterly benign intent, the General Social Survey has been performing a similar exploration of the American psyche for 34 years.

title: Raising a Child With Roots in China
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24  Peter Fenton, 43, who is of English and Dutch heritage and grew up in South Africa, was dressed in a blue Chinese mans shirt.

title: A Move to Establish New Life Near the Station
description: Elizabeth

title: Childrens Psychiatry (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: State Workers Pressured From 2 Sides
description: TRENTON

title: Acting Up
description: Q & A: Although youve been working steadily in independent films, Breaking and Entering, which opened last month, represents a kind of big-release comeback for you. Were you intentionally staying away from more mainstream films?

title: Now Playing | Heavy Metals
description: At a time when kinky fembots are motoring down the runways, designers have a soft spot for X-rated hardware. Witness Hermss thick collar necklace ($900, at Herms stores); Giles Deacons lipstick-red case for Mulberry ($795, at Mulberry stores); Christian Louboutins mesh heels ($570, at Bergdorf Goodman). Worried that these provocative accouterments will attract overeager admirers?

title: From India With Spice: Comfort Food
description: TRUST the myriad flavors and colors of Indian cuisine to bring a taste of warm, bright summer to these gray winter days. For the last eight years, the kitchen at Royal Palace has been doing its best to make every meal a sunny one. Now, both the buffet and table menus have been refined to include what might be Indias greatest culinary hits, with dishes representing almost every region.

title: Yo, Adrienne
description: It happens all the time. A beautiful young woman decides she wants to become a model and asks a photographer friend to take some head shots. Seventy years ago this ordinary series of events took an unlikely turn. That was because the beautiful woman was black; the photographer was her lover Man Ray; and one of the photographs landed in the September 1937 issue of Harpers Bazaar, making her the first black model to appear in a major fashion magazine.

title: Life With Dull Elbows
description: The bar at the new Greenwich Village hot spot was packed on a cold winter night. The ceilings were low, music loud, volume of customers high. I wasnt having much luck getting drinks for my party of three. A tall and wan woman with long blond hair who elbowed her way in managed to get a drink. So did a handsome man half my age. Sweat formed on my forehead. My friends were waiting and this was taking forever.

title: Hoboken in the 70s: Stayin Alive
description: HOBOKEN

title: Where Color and Brushwork Meet in Sensual Beauty
description: Howard Hodgkin: Paintings 1992-2007 is not an easy show. The surest sign is that visitors inside the gallery can be heard proclaiming that they dont understand what the artist is trying to say, as they did the day I visited the Yale Center for British Art. And who can blame them, for Mr. Hodgkin has always been circumspect in explaining his colorful abstracts.

title: Reese Wants Deeper Bond to Aid Giants Passing Game
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 24  Jerry Reese, the Giants new general manager, said Saturday that he would like to see tight end Jeremy Shockey and receiver Plaxico Burress forge a deeper connection with quarterback Eli Manning.

title: Sally Sharp and Stephani Fried
description: Sally B. Sharp and Stephani R. Fried of Milltown, N.J., were joined in a civil union last evening at the Van Wickle House, a historic home and events space operated by the Meadows Foundation in Somerset, N.J. Rabbi Ruth E. Smith officiated.

title: What a College Education Buys
description: How important is college to Americans? Put it this way: When Philip Zelikow, the State Department counselor who worked often on Israel-Palestine issues, resigned in November, he cited some truly riveting obligations to college bursars. Thats how important college is  its more important than peace in the Middle East.

title: A Plan to Protect New York Water
description: New York is in an elite club among major American cities; its one of five that does not require filtration of its drinking water. Thats largely thanks to a visionary strategy devised a century ago that established an upstate watershed consisting of 19 reservoirs and a system of aqueducts. That enviable system contributed to the phenomenal growth of the city and even now delivers nearly pristine water to 8 million people every day. But its days as an essentially filtration-free system could be numbered unless the city takes firm action to protect it.

title: Of Tax Cuts and Those $10 Million Bat Mitzvahs
description: TWENTY-FOUR hours in the life of my rapidly aging brain:

title: A Slice of Simplicity
description: A CONSUMERS willingness to master a gadget tends to vary in direct proportion to the gadgets technological sophistication. No one minds spending several minutes fiddling with a new smart phone or digital camera. But if something as straightforward as a pocketknife baffles within the first 30 seconds, the tendency is to become frustrated and give up.

title: Street Cred
description: A FEW weeks ago, most Brooklyn residents would have pleaded ignorance about the person for whom Manhattan Beachs Corbin Place is named. But with the recent airing of the distasteful history of the man Corbin Place memorializes, local politicians have been leading a charge to rename it. A public hearing on possibly renaming the street is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Correction: Mothballed 19th-Century Village Waits for Revival
