description: SEAFORD

title: We Are Not a Muse
description: In some, middle age breeds a new kind of fury. Francesca von Habsburg is one such. In fewer than five years, in a flurry of collecting and curating, she has transformed herself from a minor society-page attraction into one of the most influential players in contemporary art. Maybe she needed to kick off the dust of her antiquated past. Von Habsburg is the 48-year-old daughter of the late billionaire-industrialist Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza. If that werent enough, in 1993 she married Karl von Habsburg, otherwise known as Archduke Karl of Austria, Prince Royal of Hungary and Bohemia, and the couple set up home in Salzburg, producing two archduchesses and an archduke. But after 10 years, bored with the cultural stuffiness of Salzburg, she separated  amicably  from Karl; around the same time, her father died. The baron had married five times, ensuring a lively legal battle over his prodigious estate, which included the second-largest private art collection in Europe  surpassed only by the Queen of Englands. Thus, free and wealthy, von Habsburg got the bug. Her urge to collect, as with much that she does, started on an impulse.

title: Channing Charmers
description: The wines that James Christopher Tracy makes at Channing Daughters, in Bridgehampton, may not yet be the most polished on Long Island, but they are the most provocative. This chef-turned-winemaker packs more flavor surprises into his whites, especially, than anyone else.

title: Travel by Rail in Europe Is Set to Get Even Faster
description: European rail companies are cutting the time it takes to get from one city to the next. Thanks to a series of new international fast rail projects, taking a train from Edinburgh to, say, Moscow may no longer be unthinkable, and perhaps even preferable to flying.

title: Sing Out, Buffy!
description: THE lights had just dimmed when a young woman wearing a flowered dress made her way along the first row of seats of a theater at the IFC Film Center in the West Village with a pile of dry cleaning in her arms. Do you want to dance on stage with us during the They Got the Mustard Out song? the woman whispered to members of the audience as she handed out freshly laundered shirts.

title: Dim Rays of Sunshine on Housing
description: IS the housing market about to climb out of the cellar or sink further? The stock market was rattled last week, just briefly, by data showing a 10-year low in housing starts. Even so, one economist is beginning to glimpse signs of recovery that he says may be confirmed this week by a pair of reports on home sales.

title: A New Orleans Neighborhood Rebuilds
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Julie Gold and Glen Anderson
description: FOR Julie Anderson and Glen Anderson, who were married on May 27, 2001, marriage is more like a pickup truck than a convertible. It is more about responsibility, practicality and protection than about being reckless and carefree together in the wind and sun.

title: Coming or Going, Studebaker Sold Style to a Postwar Generation
description: THE military victories of 1945 that ended World War II were also a starting gun for the American auto industry, setting off a scramble to resume production of civilian vehicles. New cars had not been available for years, and with a stream of G.I.s returning from overseas, automakers sensed a sales boom in the making.

title: Jessica Morrow, Adam Packard
description: Jessica Eve Morrow, the daughter of Carol Klaperman Morrow and Ira Jay Morrow of New York is to be married this afternoon to Adam Isaac Packard, the son of Kathi H. Packard and Jeffrey Packard of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman, a grandfather of the bride, will perform the ceremony at Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Peggy Gilbert, 102, Dies; Led Female Jazz Ensembles
description: Peggy Gilbert, a noted jazz saxophonist and bandleader who for decades led all-female ensembles in hot jazz, a daring venture when she began her career more than 80 years ago, died on Feb. 12 in Los Angeles. She was 102 and had lived there for many years.

title: A Gloves-Off Season, as Theatrical Giants Prepare to Do Battle
description: FROM a theatergoers point of view matches made in heaven are a bore: no friction, no fireworks, no clash of contrasts. When two stars are united in creative matrimony on a stage, whats wanted is a dash of antagonistic hellfire, of surface incompatibility, to bring out the fighting best in each.

title: Venezuela Spending on Arms Soars to Worlds Top Ranks
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 24  Venezuelas arms spending has climbed to more than $4 billion in the past two years, transforming the nation into Latin Americas largest weapons buyer and placing it ahead of other major purchasers in international arms markets like Pakistan and Iran.

title: Robert Falls
description: TALL and a bit bearlike, the director Robert Falls has full command of the God mike, otherwise known as the directors microphone. Facing the stage at the Longacre Theater from a long table covered with a script, a PowerBook and other tools of the trade, he booms suggestions to his actors  from sexier, more Southern accents to more extreme comic actions  as he subtly (and sometimes not so subtly) hones their performances. Although they have been rehearsing for several weeks, this Tuesday in February is the first day in the theater for Liev Schreiber and the rest of the cast of the revival of Eric Bogosians 1987 play, Talk Radio, which opens March 11.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 5: On the Observance of the Fourth Commandment Among Horse Thieves

title: Zip Line, Today? A New Array of Onshore Thrills
description: FOR some passengers, taking a cruise means lounging on the open sea, ordering pia coladas and curling up with a book. The most exercise they get is walking around the buffet.

title: Groups Unite to Treat Lingering 9/11 Illnesses
description: Seven philanthropies are announcing today that they will contribute more than $4.3 million to help treat uninsured workers and residents who developed serious illnesses after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Drawing the Line on Chance Meetings
description: ALAS, the average suddenly single person does not have layers of security personnel. But that has not kept exes from inventing ways to steer clear of each other.

title: High School Hell
description: Even in the Television Universe, warp drives, androids and photon torpedoes all seem to have vague scientific plausibility, especially today when robotic vacuum cleaners and laser pointers have become commonplace. But what place does physics have in a fantasy world in which a teenage girl and her friends spend their formative years fighting vampires, demons and killer snot monsters with magic and martial arts, all in a contemporary alternate reality known to its fans as the Buffyverse?

title: Polishing the Grit Out of a Neighborhood
description: AFTER a three-year scrubbing, the Flatiron Building, whose terra-cotta walls loom over the intersection of Broadway and 23rd Street in Manhattan, has emerged from a cocoon of scaffolding, with its Roman goddess and acanthus leaf details looking clean and fresh.

title: French Dressing | Rent--Porter
description: Now that the euro has taken the joie out of buying clothes in Paris, why not rent? At the appointment-only boutique Quidam de Revel, vintage couture and ready-to-wear are available for a one- (or two-) night stand. Owned by an antiques dealer and an art historian, the Marais shop is a favorite with costume designers who hire pristine couture and prt--porter pieces, from 1940s Balmain opera coats to 60s Courrges dresses as well as a growing collection from 80s designers like Claude Montana. Call ahead so that they can set aside a rack for you, and then enjoy your finds for about 180 euros (about $235) and up, depending on the outfit, for a weekend (cheaper than buying a vintage Grs dress and a mink stole for your elopement). Accessorize with mint-condition shoes from Roger Vivier and Charles Jourdan and trunks filled with jewelry from the likes of Pierre Cardin and Lalanne. With the sous you save, you can buy a pair of Gaspard Yurkievich shoes at Hoses down the street. 24-26 rue de Poitou, 011-33-1-42-71-37-07; www.quidam-de-revel.com.

title: How to Help
description: Contributions may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. All gifts to the fund received by April 1 will go to the new 9/11 Neediest Medical Campaign. Donors may earmark their gifts for the Mount Sinai or Bellevue programs or both. Unspecified contributions will be divided equally between the two hospitals.

title: A Divide, and Maybe a Divorce
description: SLAVERY divided not only the United States, but also its churches. The Methodists, Presbyterians, Baptists and others all split North from South, and some did not reunite for more than 100 years. Others, like the Southern Baptist Convention, never did.

title: An Affair to Remember
description: I DONT claim that my recent letter to William Clay Ford Jr.  a cri de coeur about my problematic Jaguar  led to his giving up the chief executives post at his familys car company. But it certainly was part of his problem. You see, rising on my 70th birthday, I thought: Does my car define me? I knew the answer.

title: Editors Choice
description: DANCING TO ALMENDRA, by Mayra Montero. Translated by Edith Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Fact and fiction rub together in this rhythmic story of a reporter on the trail of the mafia, set mainly in 1950s Cuba.

title: Quinn Is at the Combine but Is Not in the Combine
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 24  Brady Quinn, the former Notre Dame quarterback, has come to the N.F.L. scouting combine to patch the leak in his reputation, a chore complicated because he cannot figure out what is causing it.

title: Katherine Criner and Andy Bellin
description: Katherine Lane Farish Criner, a daughter of Susan Criner and Sanford Webb Criner of Houston, was married yesterday to Andy Bellin, a son of Dr. Howard T. Bellin of New York and the late Countess Christina Paolozzi Bellin, who lived in New York and Rome. The Rev. Nicolas R. D. Dyke, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Houston.

title: That Night You Opened, and There You Are
description: THE theater is rich with superstitions. Consider how many actors refuse to call Shakespeares Scottish play by its actual title, or those who cant abide hearing good luck instead of break a leg. And just as there are things one cannot do in the theater, there are also things one must do: knock on wood, pray, do a headstand. Hey, whatever it takes to calm jittery nerves and ward off bad luck, especially before the most anxiety-filled performance of all: the opening.

title: A Whole New Ballgame for Blomberg
description: Starting a new career is difficult enough, but doing it without the staples of ones life? That may be asking too much.

title: Dead Stock
description: Many years ago I received a phone call from a fellow traveler in the vintage-clothing world, directing me in hushed tones to a rummage sale in a church basement on the Upper West Side. Sunny von Blow, he whispered. Go.

title: Very Big Plans for Hempstead Village
description: HEMPSTEAD

title: Escape From New York
description: NUMBER 143 Metropolitan Avenue, at Berry Street. A huge  I mean large, livable, stretch your legs, lets call it home  studio apartment. Room for a desk to write on, a kitchen with a real refrigerator, a colossal closet, a stoop to sit on, all for $975. Had I found the last studio in Williamsburg for under $1,000?

title: Audra McDonald
description: IT took more than music to bring Audra McDonald back to Broadway.

title: Descendants
description: Insolence, Guerlain (*)

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Rediscovering Alexander Herzen
description: AT the end of The Coast of Utopia, Tom Stoppards trilogy about Russias radical intelligentsia in the 19th century, the aristocratic socialist Alexander Herzen has a dream. Karl Marx appears before him, expounding his theories of determinism and the proletariats forward march. Herzen protests. History knocks at a thousand gates at every moment, and the gatekeeper is chance, he argues. We shout into the mist for this one or that one to be opened for us, but through every gate are a thousand more. We need wit and courage to make our way while our way is making us.

title: Going Green, One Spring Break at a Time
description: Environmentally concerned travelers worried about taking the family on safari to Africa or snorkeling the Great Barrier Reef (both high-carbon journeys) might consider booking their spring break vacations through REI Adventures (www.rei.com/adventures).

title: Red Carpet Confidential
description: BACK in the fall I went to the Museum of Modern Art for the New York premiere of Little Children. It was the beginning of the film industrys red carpet season, five long months that I would spend covering galas and awards shows right up until the Oscars Sunday night, as a blogger for this paper. But on that night it was all new, all lovely.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: Civil Union Door Opens to Same-Sex Couples

description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.

title: Pivotal Development
description: FOR better or worse, Levittown has come to be a powerful symbol of Long Island life. Some people look nostalgically upon the towns early days as a time when young families could make a new start in a home of their own. Others regard Levittown with derision as a stereotype of suburban conformity.

title: Mosh Pit Meets Sandbox
description: Can we please get over the hipster parent moment? Can we please see the end of those Park Slope alternative Stepford Moms in their black-on-black maternity tunics who turn their babies into fashion-forward, anticorporate indie-infants in order to stay one step ahead of the cool police?

title: Dont Let an Automated 401(k) Lull You to Sleep
description: THANKS to the Pension Protection Act of 2006, you may be seeing a good deal more automation in your employers 401(k) retirement plan.

title: Holding Back the Hudson
description: Holding Back the Hudson

title: As March Looms, Winthrop Cannot Rest Easy
description: ROCK HILL, S.C., Feb. 21  To see how intense Winthrop Coach Gregg Marshall becomes this time of year, all his wife, Lynn, has to do is wake up in the middle of the night.

title: Millions of Videos, and Now a Way to Search Inside Them
description: THE World Wide Web is awash in digital video, but too often we cant find the videos we want or browse for what we might like.

title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Agenda
description: Recently I received an e-mail message from a curator friend inquiring about a painter and sculptor named Liu Wei. I had included his work in a show I organized in Turin called AllLookSame? that featured pieces by young Korean, Chinese and Japanese artists. Do you believe that Liu Wei is just a good artist or a very good artist that will be famous in the future like Zhang Xiaogang? my friend asked. (Zhang Xiaogang is a Chinese art star whose paintings fetch six figures.)

title: Brooke Lasky, Jeffrey Fina
description: Brooke Lasky, a daughter of Harriet and Barry Lasky of Merrick, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey R. Fina, a son of Jane and Charles Fina of Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Klein performed the ceremony at Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Investors Mostly Glum in a Short Trading Week
description: After a string of uneven days, the stock market closed mostly lower last week amid renewed inflation fears. Announcements of big merger plans  between Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio, and between Whole Foods and Wild Oats Markets  were not enough to offset investors mild economic gloom.

title: In Greenwich Village, People Try to Catch a Glimpse of the Rat Pack
description: New Yorkers rarely go out of their way to look at a rat. They usually dont have to. Vermin sightings are frequent, and often unexpected.

title: Robby Gordon Keeps Blazing Own Path
description: There is something about Mexico that draws Robby Gordon to that off-road racing world across the border. Maybe its the dirt. Maybe its the sometimes treacherous terrain.

title: Governors Worry Over Money for Child Health Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  As the National Governors Association began its winter meeting, 13 governors expressed alarm on Saturday that they were about to run out of federal money for a popular program that provides health insurance to children.

title: A Weak Dollar Is Music to Foreign Tourists
description: The lure of Times Square, Rodeo Drive and points in between is stronger than ever to foreign tourists. In 2006, international travel receipts in the United States reached a record $107.4 billion, according to the Commerce Department. That represents a full recovery, and then some, from the effects of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Music to Heal a Land of Dust and Floods
description: NEVER in American history, many argue, have political parties and administrations been more brazen about image manipulation and message control than they are now. But recent examples  the Mission Accomplished carrier landing, the new Democratic leadership teams victory lap packaged as a listening tour  seem hapless in comparison with The Plow That Broke the Plains and The River, two government-financed documentaries from the 1930s that were shameless propaganda efforts.

title: Now at Camp, a Tantalizing Hint of the Future
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 24  Out beyond the right-center-field fence of Field No. 4, past a concrete path, a gully and a golf cart, stands a maintenance shack. It is about 430 feet from home plate, which on Saturday morning put the workers in the area within range of a Fernando Martnez batting-practice blast.

title: They Think Theyve Been Cursed by God
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

title: The Final Buzzer for a College Fixture
description: The City University basketball tournament had no games scheduled Monday, but the day was especially dark because Burt Beagle had died of cancer at 73 in a Bronx hospice.

title: When Germs Talk, Maybe Humans Can Answer
description: IT can take years, sometimes decades, for the commercial applications of a scientific or intellectual breakthrough to become apparent  like the notion that brainless bacteria communicate through networks to cause diseases that can also wreak social or economic havoc.

title: Petal Pushers
description: I bought 20 grocery store roses last week  a rich yellow tinged with red  and am now thoroughly tired of them. They never fully opened, they have no scent and although theyve gotten a little crinkly, they refuse to die. I may have to beat them to death.

title: Does the Shoe Fit?
description: Edmund Wilson said of Proust that we always feel as if we are reading about the end of something  the society of the dispossessed nobility and the fashionable and cultivated bourgeoisie, with their physicians and their artists, their servants and their parasites. So it is when we think about the house of Yves Saint Laurent. Whether or not YSL is the last great Paris house  it was founded in 1961, 15 years after Dior and 48 years after Chanel  we have the feeling that it is. And, as with so many things that occupy Saint Laurent and his faithful partner, Pierre Berg, not least posterity, this feeling was the result of a very deliberate effort.

title: Would You Like That in Tens, Twenties or Normans?
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ETHICS OF IDENTITY, by Kwame Anthony Appiah. (Princeton University, $19.95.) This elegant, discerning book explores the scope and limits of individual and group rights as they relate to the hot-button controversies of our time: affirmative action, gay marriage, the human rights movement, even the teaching of evolution in the public schools. Drawing on John Stuart Mills classic essay, On Liberty, Appiah, a Princeton philosopher, argues for a rooted cosmopolitanism, emphasizing the individual while recognizing the importance of collective identities based on race, religion, language and sexual preference. Appiahs examples range from the proceedings of the Pueblo tribal council to the experience of his own multicontinental family. To read The Ethics of Identity is to enter into the world it describes; it is also to imagine what it might be like to live in so urbane and expansive a place, Jonathan Freedman wrote in the Book Review.

title: Sure, Lunch Isnt Free, but Late-Night Snacks Are
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23  The nighttime gathering begins about a quarter to 10. The scavengers circle nonchalantly, as if to avoid looking too eager to pounce.

title: Correction: Biodiesel Fuel Raises Hopes of Greening Cars
description: An article last Sunday about biodiesel-driven cars referred incorrectly to the biodiesel blend sold at gas stations around the country. The biodiesel is mixed with diesel, not with gasoline.

title: Dragon Sea: A True Tale of Treasure, Archaeology and Greed Off the Coast of Vietnam
description: By Frank Pope

title: Dead in Our Backyard
description: At sunrise one week ago, Orlando Moreno was freshly dead, a corpse wrapped in rags and filthy clothes and laid out on a mattress resting on a slab of ice and frozen dirt. He died at home. Home was a tent in a dense patch of woods in Huntington Station, a few yards from a park, baseball fields, a lumber yard and a big Long Island Rail Road station, where thousands of white-collar commuters wait every weekday morning with coffee and newspapers for the hourlong ride to Manhattan.

title: Road Seeks Owner: Needs Love (and Cash)
description: Bass River Township

title: Moya Doherty and John McColgan
description: WHY watch Grease: Youre the One That I Want on television once a week, when you can see the reality show of the new Broadway musical The Pirate Queen at any moment by logging on to the shows continuously updated Web site? The show begins previews at the Hilton Theater on March 6, but at thepiratequeen.com you can spy on actresses rejoicing as they enter their first Broadway dressing room; watch musicians clown during a break from playing uilleann pipes; hear dancers discuss new steps; and take in the exuberant words of the Pirate Queen herself, Stephanie J. Block: You guys, its a big, fat Broadway show! Can you not smell the greasepaint?

title: Honoring a Colonial-Era Teacher and Hero
description: BEFORE he uttered one of the most famous lines in American history and was hanged by the British, Nathan Hale taught at schoolhouses in New London and East Haddam.

title: Sailing With Few Frills or Inhibitions
description: O.K., so the guy from Southern California was telling me about Seaman's, the strip club on the island of St. Martin where he'd made the acquaintance of two prostitutes, while behind me the self-proclaimed Almost Cool Crowd  a handful of hard-partying Americans ranging from 26 to 42 years old  were drinking Carib beers and rum punches and dancing barefoot to Euro-ish rhythms spun by D.J. Dan, a diminutive music maestro with oversized black plastic eyeglasses and an unshakably ebullient demeanor.

title: Fictional Favoritism
description: I teach in a creative-writing graduate program. A colleague submitted a students story to a fiction anthology without the students knowledge. The story was accepted and the student is thrilled, but I am uneasy. If other students find out, they may see this as favoritism. Did my colleague act improperly? Should our department establish rules about such things? Name Withheld, Alabama

title: A Big Fist and Some Trash Talk
description: WITH the arrival of the 2007 Tundra this month, Toyota has made its most serious move yet into the full-size pickup market, which it calls the single largest opportunity for Toyotas future growth in the United States.

An article last Sunday about David F. Swensen, who supervises Yale Universitys endowment, misidentified the institution where his grandfather was a chemistry professor. It is Wartburg College in Waverly, Iowa, not the University of Wisconsin-River Falls.

title: Correction: Time-Traveling in Oxford, England
description: The Day Out column on Feb. 11 about visiting Oxford, England, misidentified the stone used in buildings there. It is Cotswold limestone, not sandstone.

title: Correction: An Air Pass That Gives You Asia  la Carte
description: A brief report in the In Transit column on Feb. 11, about a Singapore Airlines air pass promotion, gave an incorrect Internet address for information on the program. It is www.asianairpass.com.

title: A Winter-Spring Mix
description: The green days of spring seemed to be ready to sprout until a blast of cold finally arrived.

title: A Moving Canvas
description: It's dark in David Lynch's world. You wish that Laura Dern had brought a flashlight for her role in "Inland Empire," his latest film, as she repeatedly ventures into blackness, her presence reduced to the rhythmic clicking of high heels on concrete. The experience is a familiar one to Lynch's fans of long standing, beginning in 1977 with "Eraserhead," his bizarre and haunting breakthrough featuring a mutant baby and shot in black and white (mostly black, a little white), continuing through "The Elephant Man," "Blue Velvet" and "Mulholland Drive": time and again, characters disappear into darkness; characters emerge from darkness into light. The shadows, with their implicit sense of menace, define the contours of a body or a face, carving out the hollows. Lynch paints with darkness the way other filmmakers slather on the sunbeams and fluorescent glare. The images unfold  breathtaking, perplexing  and we watch, in the grip of beauty and fear.

title: A Is for Armani
description: By ERIC WILSON

title: Brand Loyalty
description: I have a large, red quilted Chanel bag that I borrowed from my sister Ashley. I wore it to an event and never gave it back. Luckily, she's moved on to another bag, so I'm safe for now. I'm not quite sure how many bags I have, but let's just say I have a few. When I find a bag I like, I tend to wear it to death until I become obsessed with another one. This probably happens three to five times a year. But I always come back to the Chanel. The size isn't overwhelming, and it has enough subtle detail to keep it interesting.

title: Acting Up
description: Q & A: Although you've been working steadily in independent films, "Breaking and Entering," which opened last month, represents a kind of big-release comeback for you. Were you intentionally staying away from more mainstream films?

description: THEATER

title: Correction: 36 Hours: Mexico City
description: The 36 Hours column on Feb. 18 about Mexico City referred incorrectly to the population of the Distrito Federal (D.F.), which encompasses Mexico City. The population of the D.F. and the surrounding suburbs (the greater metropolitan area) is 20 million to 21 million; the D.F. itself is not 20 million to 21 million. Also, the article and a map misstated the location of the restaurant La Bipolar. It is in El Carmen, Coyoacn  not in Condesa, which is a half hour north of Coyoacn. The article also misstated the deity depicted by a stone monument at the Templo Mayor found by archaeologists near the citys main square. The monument depicts Tlaltecuhtli, the Aztec earth goddess  not Tlaloc, the rain god.

title: Rockin Robin
description: One of the most exclusive clubs in Paris just got a little easier to get into. The celebrity colorist Christophe Robin's new atelier in the Sixth Arrondissement is more than 10 times bigger than his old space and offers a lot more than highlights. "It's my dream of a salon," says Robin, whose clients include Catherine Deneuve, Kylie Minogue and John Galliano. Set in a courtyard, the three-level former art gallery is decorated with spoils from the colorist's travels and has a bar, restaurant, library, vintage shop and separate area for men, "so famous politicians who cover their gray can have some privacy." Clients may also book facials with Jolle Ciocco, osteopathic massages with Grgor Schultze and medical pedicures with Bastien Gonzalez  all standouts in their respective beauty fields. Pampering aside, the real draw is Robin's homemade waffles, whose secret (until now) ingredient is a dollop of Bordier butter from Brittany. 9, rue Gungaud; 011-33-1-42-60-99-15.

title: Red Carpet
Preparations for the Oscars
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) observes the preparations the day before the 79th Academy Awards.

title: The Spirit Awards
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) at Film Independent's Spirit Awards on Saturday, Feb. 24.

title: Who Do You Think We Are?
Red Carpet
description: Scenes from the red carpet at this years Academy Awards.

description: Shortly after the end of the Daytona 500, crews packed up and traveled 2,455 miles to Fontana, Calif., for the next race.

title: Broken Wings
description: If your kitsch meter starts clicking when you learn that a novel features a flock of swans  oh no, here comes a trumpeting parade of clichs about fidelity  dont worry. Howard Norman is too good a writer to use this image to such banal effect. As it happens, the swans in Devotion belong to an estate in Nova Scotia that takes in wounded birds, and none of them have a mate. Rather than romanticize them, Norman notes their awkward, comical swagger and the painful way, when their keeper tries to feed them, their bills jabbed the palm of his hand. These are real-world creatures in a story not just about fidelity but about betrayal and atonement.

title: Not Your Grandmothers Cruise Ship
Say It Aint So
description: Sasha Stone, the den mother of Oscar bloggers, suggests in an interview with E! that the rest of the world may not care what happens tonight. The Bagger read the whole thing with his eyes closed.

title: Not So Easy Listening
description: The Bagger found a Reuters story about score for Notes on a Scandal, by Phillip Glass, which argued it was actually a threat to win this year. The Bagger would give it a vote for Score Most Likely to Peel Paint and Distract.

title: The Beltway Version of the Oscars
description: Little Golden Guys are doing some predicting of their own about who, based on the trial of I. Lewis Libby, deserves to take home a statue or go to the Big House in handcuffs.

description: Despite the winter temperatures, racing horses and their fans deal with it at Aqueduct Race Track in Queens.

title: Overture
description: I AM SITTING IN MY LIVING ROOM, AND THE REPORTER is eyeing me nervously, tapping his foot out of sync with the salsa beat drifting down the stairs. He looks as though he's raced here straight from the offices of a high-school newspaper, Adam's apple jumping in his delicate neck, large blue eyes set wide with earnest curiosity in a smooth egg-white oval of a face, though I understand (he's brought me a collection of clippings as proof) that he's more established than he looks: recent arts editor of the Yale Daily News, minor freelancing assignments everywhere from The Village Voice to People since he graduated from college last June. His specialty is arts profiles, as he let me know the moment I opened the front door, pushing into my hands the two quarter-page jobs he's done for Entertainment Weekly; I didn't tell him that the names in these articles mean nothing to me. We share some tenuous connection, this boy and I, and I am eager to put him at ease: he is the son of the cousin of the brother of God knows who, a line that eventually traces back to my college mentor, Robert Masterson, which is the only reason the kid is sitting here, experiencing what he has now called several times "the most awesome day" of his career.

title: Nixon and Mao
description: On Thursday, February 17, 1972, President and Mrs. Nixon walked out to the south lawn of the White House, where a helicopter waited for them. A small crowd, among them Vice President Spiro Agnew and his wife, Republican and Democratic congressmen, and the two Nixon daughters, Tricia and Julie, saw them off as they started the first leg of their long trip to China. The brief ceremony was carried live on American radio and television. Nixon spoke briefly. He was making, he said, "a journey for peace," but, he added, he was under no illusions that "twenty years of hostility between the People's Republic of China and the United States of America are going to be swept away by one week of talks that we will have there." Nevertheless, he was going in an optimistic spirit: "If there is a postscript that I hope might be written with regard to this trip, it would be the words on the plaque which was left on the moon by our first astronauts when they landed there: 'We came in peace for all mankind.'" It was classic Nixon, that mixture of pragmatism and grandiloquence.

title: Call Me by Your Name
description: "Later!" The word, the voice, the attitude.

title: Devotion
description: Here is what happened. In London on the morning of August 19, 1985, David Kozol and his father-in-law, William Field, had a violent quarrel on George Street. In a cafe they came to blows. Two waitresses threw them out. On the sidewalk they started up again. William stumbled backward from the curb and was struck by a taxi. The London police record called it "assault by mutual affray."

title: Remainder
description: About the accident itself I can say very little. Almost nothing. It involved something falling from the sky. Technology. Parts, bits. That's it, really: all I can divulge. Not much, I know.

title: Bringing Down the Mob
description: Longtime business associates Allen Dorfman and Irwin Weiner frequently lunched together. On a day in January 1983, they emerged from Dorfman's Cadillac onto the icy parking lot of a suburban Chicago restaurant, ten minutes late for their one o'clock reservation. According to Weiner, they were walking between parked cars when two men ran up behind them and yelled, "This is a robbery." One of the men fired a .22 automatic at least half a dozen times. Only Dorfman was hit. He fell to the ground in a large pool of blood that quickly froze into red ice. When the paramedics arrived, he showed no signs of life.

title: Why We Travel
description: "I dont know if it was him or my husband, but they discovered they could get free room service, and that included milk and oatmeal cookies in the evening."

title: Scenes From the Oscars
description: Bright moments from this years Academy Awards.

title: 36 Hours in Rio
description: A weekend in Rio, where the beaches, bars and caipirinhas are waiting for you.

title: Spirited Reporting
description: For those of you who were underwhelmed by the Spirit Awards reporting here  the tech gods did not smile on us  check out the far superior work over at RiskyBiz, including word that all five producers of Little Miss will take the Big Walk if they win. Good call.

title: Big Willie Style
description: Todays workout lasted about two hours  about an hour shorter than normal  perhaps as a reprieve for players having to report by 7:30 a.m. for photos. So, aside from a few questions, the post-workout press conference with Willie Randolph dealt with such pressing topics as his Oscar picks (The Departed), music and  and I have no idea how the conversation evolved to this point; it may have been Jerry Manuel praising his old 1963 Chevy Impala  the gangsta lean.

title: Politics Means Always Having To Say Youre Sorry
description: Last week I was rushing to meet my wife at a restaurant when I took the wrong highway entry by mistake. I telephoned her and said, I went south when I should have gone north and Ill be a little late. Sorry. Was I apologizing to her, and if so, what for? The question is not as simple as it might first seem because sorry is a tricky little word with more than one meaning and use.

title: A Last Evening on the Carpet
description: Life on the Oscar carpet was fast and furious. The Bagger managed to mistake Rachel Weisz, star of the The Fountain and The Constant Gardiner, for Emily Blount, star of The Devil Wears Prada.

title: In Answer To Your Questions
description: A couple of people asked me about the numbers in my maternal mortality column and multi-media piece, so let me explain. But the first point to note is that nobody has much idea what the numbers are. For example, the official figure in Ethiopia for maternal mortality is roughly 800 deaths for women for every 100,000 live births. But that figure is based on hospital data, and the Fistula Hospital estimates that the real figure is probably more like 2,000 out of every 100,000 live births. In addition, the causes can be multiple: For example, malaria is particularly lethal to pregnant women, so the cause of death may be malaria but it is also a consequence of her pregnancy and should be concidered a case of maternal mortality.

title: Red Carpet Farewell, No. 2
description: There is a kind of striving out on carpet that leaves the Bagger confused and not knowing where to look. Al Gore or Maggie Gyllenhaal, Nicole Simpson or Guillermo del Toro?

title: Upset City
description: Alan Arkin was the name they announced when it came time to open the envelope for best supporting actor, leaving Eddie Murphy with a frozen smile and Mr. Arkin with a significant bit of recognition for a lifetime of work. It was the nights first surprise, and it sent a pronounced ripple through the press room. The Bagger, btw, never saw it coming.

title: White Whine
description: Can the Bagger just say that the Academy and all of the trolls that are doing security for them need to take a deep breath? Its not that there is too much security, but that when things go wrong the whole system freezes and everyone just throws their hands in the air.

title: Lifestyle Issues
description: William Monahan, the winner for best adapted screenplay, spoke in the press room afterward of how Jack Nicholson added texture to the character of the Boston mob boss. I dont know too many 68-year-old Boston Irishmen who are into cocaine, he said, but Jack wanted to sexualize the character and I think it totally worked.

title: Oscar Is Speaking a Lot of Spanish and a Little German
description: Lots of Spanish is being spoken tonight by the winners in the press room. Pans Labyrinth won the makeup, cinematography and art direction awards, but the ultimate prize  best foreign film  eluded the dark fairytale look at Spanish fascism. Instead, The Lives of Others, a film about East Germanys history of spying and the havoc it wreaked on those who spied, as well as those who were spyed upon.

title: All About the Amor
description: Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, the director of The Lives of Others, said he was thrilled to win, but sorry it came at the expense of Guillermo del Toro, whose Pans Labryinth has had a huge night, winning three other Oscars.

title: Gore Wins Hollywood in a Landslide
description: For those of you tuning in the to Academy Awards tonight to see if Al Gore would, 1) win an Oscar for his documentary, An Inconvenient Truth, and 2) use the platform of the awards ceremony to announce he was running for president - well yes, the documentary won an Oscar.

title: One in the Side Pocket
description: Larry David, on the arm of Laurie David, who was nominated as a producer of An Inconvenient Truth  the winner for best feature-length documentary had a plan to get through the long night when the Bagger saw him on the carpet. I have a pocket full of candy bars and Im not sharing one of them. Not a bite. But I wont crinkle the wrappers when I open them.

title: Mud, Dust, Whatever
description: If Bill and Hillary Clinton were the stars of a reality TV show, it would be a weekly series called The Connivers. The Clintons, the most powerful of power couples, are always scheming at something, and theyre good at it.

title: Why Have So Many U.S. Attorneys Been Fired? It Looks a Lot Like Politics
description: Carol Lam, the former United States attorney for San Diego, is smart and tireless and was very good at her job. Her investigation of Representative Randy Cunningham resulted in a guilty plea for taking more than $2 million in bribes from defense contractors and a sentence of more than eight years. Two weeks ago, she indicted Kyle Dustin Foggo, the former No. 3 official in the C.I.A. The defense-contracting scandal she pursued so vigorously could yet drag in other politicians.

title: Mets Try to Avoid Rushing Talent
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 25  Of the nine Mets pitchers in the mix for three starting spots, Philip Humber and Mike Pelfrey clearly have the most potential. They are tall, polished right-handers from strong college programs and are projected to be frontline starters. It can be tempting to want to rush such talent, but the Mets are mindful of protecting their former No. 1 draft picks.

title: Brooklyns Team-to-Be Hasnt Found Welcome Mat
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: For Carter, Focus Turns to Push for Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 25 Vince Carter of the Nets twisted around Knicks forward Channing Frye on Sunday night for a left-handed finger roll that rimmed out. Carter got the rebound, went up for a reverse layup and was slapped on the arm by Frye.

title: Dark-Star Irish Boys Spell Trouble
description: Paul Haggiss much-celebrated 2004 film, Crash, used shortcuts  clichs in the score, camerawork and color mix  to induce emotional responses. The same methods inform his latest television series, The Black Donnellys. Actually the show lays bare his form of aesthetic condescension so baldly that it may cause viewers to rethink his earlier achievement.

title: The Toast of MySpace Tries the Music Business
description: There will soon be an answer to a question making the music industry very nervous: is having a lot of friends on MySpace better than having a record deal?

title: The Departed Wins Best Picture, Scorsese Best Director
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 25 Twenty-six years and seven snubs after his first Oscar nomination, for Raging Bull, Martin Scorsese finally felt the warm embrace of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Sunday as he was named best director and his murderous mob thriller The Departed was named the best picture of 2006.

title: Playing Perfectly Without Star Power
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 25  The Duke womens basketball team went into this regular season rated no better than third in the Atlantic Coast Conference. But the Blue Devils finished second to none in the country.

title: Tribune Considering Late Offer From Real Estate Magnate
description: The Tribune Company, in discussions about its future, is weighing a proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate maverick and billionaire who sold his huge office development company this month for $39 billion in the biggest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Pinstripe Memories: Joe D. From Brooklyn Was Living a Dream
description: Long before Joe DiMaggio joined the Yankees, the other Joe D was in pinstripes.

title: Looking Ahead
description: HURRICANE KATRINA CLAIMS A judge in Mississippi plans to hold a hearing on the terms of a proposed settlement that calls for State Farm Insurance to pay at least $50 million to roughly 36,000 policyholders whose damage claims can be reopened, reviewed and possibly paid (Wednesday). He is also scheduled to hear arguments from lawyers on whether to allow a class action against State Farm by policyholders whose homes were destroyed.

title: Nation of Islam at a Crossroad as Leader Exits
description: DETROIT, Feb. 25  Louis Farrakhan, the departing leader of the Nation of Islam, gave what was billed as his last major public address here on Sunday, with his extended illness throwing into sharp focus the question of whether the group will shift toward more mainstream Islamic teachings to survive once it loses its central charismatic figure.

title: Libby Juror Dismissed Over Media Exposure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  A juror in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheneys former chief of staff, was dismissed from the panel today after acknowledging that she had had outside contact with information related to the case.

title: Google in Content Deal With Media Companies
description: Google built an empire delivering advertisements across the Internet, and now it plans to distribute content from media companies just as aggressively.

title: Too Few Friends? A Web Site Lets You Buy Some (and Theyre Hot)
description: Popularity was never easily measured, until the advent of social-networking sites. Now, prospective employers and others can gain some insights into an applicants lifestyle and character by looking at a persons social-networking page, including the roster of friends.

title: Manhattan: Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 57-year-old woman was killed in a small fire in a high-rise apartment in Harlem yesterday, the police said. The woman was found on the 30th floor of 2979 Eighth Avenue, part of the Polo Grounds Houses, by firefighters responding to the blaze, which was reported at 12:42 p.m. and extinguished quickly, fire officials said. Neighbors identified the woman as Rebecca White and said she had lived alone and had been in poor health. The cause of the fire and the cause of her death were under investigation, officials said.

title: Bush to Warn Pakistan to Act on Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Bush has decided to send an unusually tough message to one of his most important allies, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, warning him that the newly Democratic Congress could cut aid to his country unless his forces become far more aggressive in hunting down operatives with Al Qaeda, senior administration officials say.

title: Which Videos Are Protected? Lawmakers Get a Lesson
description: As the new Congress experiments with the wide world of blogging and video clips, members are learning the complexities of copyright law, much the way the casual YouTube user has learned that there are corporations out there that own Lost and can stop you from posting a favorite episode.

title: Stenson Comes in From the Wild
description: MARANA, Ariz., Feb. 25  Nearly six years ago, Henrik Stenson walked off a golf course in the middle of a round, tired of sideways shots and his caddie rustling through his bag for another ball.

title: Lamar Lundy, Lineman on the Rams Fearsome Foursome, Dies at 71
description: Lamar Lundy, a longtime defensive end for the Los Angeles Rams who in the 1960s was part of the Fearsome Foursome, one of the National Football Leagues most renowned defensive lines, died Saturday in Richmond, Ind. He was 71.

title: Deals Broader Effect on Coal Plants Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The deal between environmental groups and the investors seeking to buy the TXU Corporation may stop that companys construction of eight new coal-fired power plants in Texas, but may have hardly any effect on the broader course of new power plants being built, according to other participants in the battle over the Texas plants.

title: Parking Rules Eased
description: Alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended today to help with snow removal, city officials said yesterday. Other parking regulations will remain in effect, and the alternate-side parking rules were to return tomorrow.

title: At Versace, a Testament to Genius
description: MILAN, Feb. 24  It will be 10 years this summer since Gianni Versace was killed in Miami Beach, and there are now more reasons than ever to wonder what fashion would be like if he had lived. Would his keen eye and sense of timing kept us better informed on the subject of sex than Dolce & Gabbana and Dsquared? Would he have tempted us without losing our trust, without forgetting that we still care about fit and quality?

title: Leroy Jenkins, 74, Violinist Who Pushed Limits of Jazz, Dies
description: The violinist and composer Leroy Jenkins, one of the pre-eminent musicians of 1970s free jazz, who worked on and around the lines between jazz and classical music, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: On Niche Dating Sites, Many More Women
description: During the week of Feb. 5, men and women visited online dating Web sites in nearly equal numbers, according to Hitwise, which measures online traffic. And to look at the 10 most popular sites not directed toward gay people, you might think that every dating site on the Internet was rigorously gender-balanced. All but one of the 10 largest sites came within 10 percentage points of being evenly split.

title: Bush Gaffes, Set to Music and Video
description: Its a shame that William Forsythe is getting all the attention for Three Atmospheric Studies, his antiwar production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this week. Guta Hedewig, a less famous New York choreographer, just wrapped up a weekend of performances at Danspace Project with a political work that happens to be one of the finest dances shes ever created.

title: Substance Over Image
description: Six years ago a man unsuited both by intellect and by temperament for high office somehow ended up running the country.

title: Manhattan: Tax Preparation Proposal
description: City Councilman Eric Gioia of Queens and several other Council members plan to introduce a bill this week to strengthen consumer protections against inflated fees and interest rates charged by some tax preparers. The legislation would require tax preparers to provide a written estimate of the total cost for each refund and tax preparation they offer, including filing fees, interest rates and refund-anticipation loan processing fees. The Council has been critical of tax preparation firms that offer rapid-refund loans, saying that consumers who use them are often charged excessive fees when they can receive their full refund, with no interest payments due, in as little as 10 days.

title: Man, 20, Is Killed After Argument on Brooklyn Subway Platform
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man returning home from a party was fatally stabbed as he was preparing to board a subway in Brooklyn early yesterday after arguing with a group of men, the police said. Detectives were questioning five young men, the police said, but no charges had been filed by last night.

title: U.N. Court Issues Ruling on Bosnia Genocide
description: The International Court of Justice ruled today that Serbia had failed to prevent the 1995 massacre at Srebrenica during the Bosnian war, but cleared the country of direct intent to commit genocide.

title: Webb Toys With Tactics and the Field in Winning the Mile
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25  Alan Webb remains Americas best young miler, with a career best of 3 minutes 48.92 seconds. But at 24, he is still learning and still experimenting.

title: I, the Prosecutor: A Murder Case Told From the Inside
description: Some people say that the truth is stranger than fiction. But you, ladies and gentlemen of the jury, have reason to question what that means. The evidence shows that even the most successful stars of the fiction world, like John Grisham, can flounder when they try to make sense of reality (as Mr. Grisham does in An Innocent Man). They find out, to their certain chagrin, that reality is unwieldy.

title: A Team Feared by Rivals Now Sits Idle, and Angry
description: His build is slight and he stands only 5-foot-6, but Kyle Sierra grew up playing basketball on the courts of East New York, Brooklyn, and is tough enough to take the physical pounding that passes for high school basketball in the city.

title: Surveying 08 Field, Governors Urge Moderation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is the front-runner and will probably win the Democratic presidential nomination. Rudolph W. Giuliani could do well in Mississippi. And the length of the presidential campaign is insane.

title: Thais Struggle With Violent Insurgency
description: PATTANI, Thailand, Feb. 22  Some are already calling it war, a brutal Muslim separatist insurgency in southern Thailand that has taken as many as 2,000 lives in three years with almost daily bombings, drive-by shootings, arson and beheadings.

title: Children Tell Their Own Stories in New Series
description: Heres Madison Walston-Eickhoff, who lives with her two mothers in Grand Rapids, Mich., on the issue of gay marriage: It just matters that everybody in the world gets treated the same, she said, with the philosophical clarity of an 8-year-old.

title: Cheney Warns Pakistan to Act on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Just hours after Vice President Dick Cheney delivered a stiff private message to President Pervez Musharraf in Pakistan, the Pakistani government lashed out today with a series of statements insisting that Pakistan does not accept dictation from any side or any source.

title: Queens: Man Is Killed in Crash
description: A 48-year-old Queens man was killed yesterday afternoon when his Toyota collided with a Lincoln at a busy intersection in Fresh Meadows, the police said. The driver, Daniel Luey, of 189th Street in Fresh Meadows, was pronounced dead at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. Two passengers in the Toyota, a 49-year-old woman and a 12-year-old boy, were also taken to the hospital, where they were in stable condition last evening, the police said. Their names were not released by the police. The driver of the Lincoln, an 88-year-old man, was taken to the same hospital for observation, the police said. His name was not released, and no charges were filed against him.

title: A Push for Citizenship to Honor Anne Frank, but Its No Easy Sell
description: SAYVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 23  A congressman from Long Island wants the United States government to grant honorary citizenship to Anne Frank, at least in part to atone for having denied her family entry in the years before her arrest and deportation to a Nazi concentration camp.

title: Seeking New Israeli Settlers, Synagogue Draws Protesters
description: TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 25  As several dozen people screamed at one another across West Englewood Avenue on Sunday, waving Palestinian flags, Israeli flags and clenched fists, Rabbi Steven Pruzansky stood inside Bnai Yeshurun synagogue, smiling. He proclaimed the day a success.

title: 2-Year Study of Polar Changes Set to Begin
description: Scientists from more than 60 countries are preparing to fan out around the North and South Poles in an ambitious two-year effort to understand the vital, shifting dynamics of ice, oceans and life at the ends of the earth.

title: Citigroup Finds Taker for Hard Job
description: Talk about a tough job description: Help wanted. Chief financial officer for one of the world's largest banks. Must be able to reverse a course of underperformance for which the company's chief executive has taken the blame.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Feb. 16 about Mordkhe Schaechter, a leading Yiddish linguist, misidentified the language in which his doctoral dissertation was written. It was German  not Yiddish, which was the subject of the dissertation.

title: Horrid First Half Dooms St. John's Against Aggressive Duke
description: St. Johns played a terrific second half yesterday, shooting 50 percent from the floor and outscoring No. 18 Duke by 7 points. Not that it mattered one bit.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 3 about the corruption trial of Clarence Norman Jr., the former assemblyman and Brooklyn Democratic Party leader, misstated the profession of Ernest Lendler, who designed a campaign flier for a judge who ran on the partys ticket during the 2002 primary. Mr. Lendler is a political consultant, not a printer. (The error first appeared in an article on Jan. 24 that referred to Mr. Lendler without naming him, and was repeated on Feb. 2 in an article about the trial.)

title: As Candidate, Obama Carves Antiwar Stance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Senator Barack Obama is running for president as one of the few candidates who opposed the Iraq war from the beginning, a simple position unburdened by expressions of regret or decisions over whether to apologize for initially supporting the invasion.

title: Software Tool of Pirates Gets Work in Hollywood
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25  Hollywood studios are going into business with one of their biggest tormentors: the peer-to-peer pioneer BitTorrent.

description: MARNIE STERN In Advance of the Broken Arm (Kill Rock Stars)

title: An Ad Upstart Challenges Google
description: Google and Yahoo have been fighting it out over which company will dominate the online advertising business, with Google maintaining the upper hand so far.

title: Giambi in the Infield Is Only a Spring Fling
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 25  The black first basemans glove appeared barely used. Jason Giambi kept it cupped on his left hip as he chatted with Doug Mientkiewicz and Andy Phillips, whoever was not manning first base during a morning drill at Legends Field.

title: Design on Diagonal Path in Pursuit of a Faster Chip
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Imagine how useful it would be to stand on a Manhattan street corner and then walk diagonally through a block to get to your destination more quickly.

title: Moving Kosovo On
description: Earlier this month, a United Nations envoy, Martti Ahtisaari, presented a sensible plan for the future of Kosovo. The small Serbian province has been administered by the United Nations since 1999, when NATO went to war to defend its ethnic Albanian majority. Mr. Ahtisaaris proposal would effectively grant Kosovo independence, but with strict limits, extensive international supervision, and protection for the ethnic Serbs and other minorities who live there.

title: For the Record
description: An art review on Wednesday about The Rape of the Sabine Women, a film by Eve Sussman and the Rufus Corporation, misidentified the architectural style of the Tempelhof airport in Berlin, where a scene takes place. It is Fascist-era style, not International Style.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Buyout Deal That Has Many Shades of Green
description: About two weeks ago, Fred Krupp, the president of a nonprofit advocacy group called Environmental Defense, received an unusual phone call.

title: Making the Return Trip: Elderly Head Back North
description: For the first time since the Depression, more Americans ages 75 and older have been leaving the South than moving there, according to a New York Times analysis of Census Bureau data.

title: A Prince? Ugly Stepsisters? It Must Be ...Well, You Know
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Quick, name this ballet. Its narrative is created by an onstage storyteller who sits on the moon and enlists the help of a young assistant to play the leading character. A Marlene Dietrich figure vamps, backed by a chorus of female dancers visible from the knees down. A real-time video of the conductor guiding his orchestra through the score is projected on a backdrop. And guests at the ball are served oranges laced with an amnesia-causing potion.

title: Towns Elders Plead for Help With Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 24  Taliban fighters who seized control of a remote town in southern Afghanistan three weeks ago have started a campaign of arrests and reprisals against tribal elders and townspeople, according to tribal elders. The elders called on NATO forces and the government to move against the insurgents, even if it means bombing the town.

title: Seeking Skills, Indians Find Career Path to Sky
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 24  This is a story that Abhinanda Shukla, 25, is fond of telling at job interviews, so perfectly honed that it has the ring of an overdrawn fairy tale.

title: Canadian Rail Workers End Their Strike
description: The Canadian National Railways striking employees returned to work yesterday, a day after their union reached a tentative settlement for a new labor contract.

title: Brunos Business Touch Wasnt Always Golden
description: It is an oft-told tale that has become part of Albany lore. Long before he became the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno borrowed $5,000 to start a telephone equipment company, built it into a profitable business and sold it for $23 million in 1990. Born into poverty, Mr. Bruno became a millionaire.

title: Bringing a Touch of Daytime to Hollywoods Biggest Night
description: Aim lower, Ellen DeGeneres joked about her unexalted childhood ambitions, and last night the Oscars did. She was dressed semiformally in an open collar and red velvet suit on a night that usually commands black tie or white. As she sometimes does on her daytime talk show, Ms. DeGeneres cruised the aisle with a microphone, chatting idly with Martin Scorsese and Clint Eastwood  bringing a casual Friday mood to Fancy Sunday.

title: Bombing at Iraqi Ministry Injures Vice President
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  An explosion inside the headquarters of the Iraqi Ministry of Public Works killed at least five people today and injured Iraqs vice president and the minister in what Iraqi official described as a possible assassination attempt.

title: Films View of Islam Stirs Anger on Campuses
description: When Obsession: Radical Islams War Against the West, a documentary that shows Muslims urging attacks on the United States and Europe, was screened recently at the University of California, Los Angeles, it drew an audience of more than 300  and also dozens of protesters.

title: The New Video Arcade in Spain Might Be the Movie Theater
description: MADRID  For the last three years, Enrique Martnez has been toiling like a 3-D warrior to let the games begin.

title: In Battle Below .500 Mark, Carter Powers Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 25  Vince Carter did not migrate across the Hudson River last week, keeping his springy legs, his timely shooting and his larger-than-life image firmly ensconced in the Meadowlands.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the popularity of Las Vegas for Asians and Asian-Americans celebrating the Chinese New Year referred incorrectly to Macau, where several Las Vegas casinos have built lavish hotel-casinos in the last decade. It is a special administrative region of China, not a province.

title: New Hot Properties: YouTube Celebrities
description: No one would mistake the Ask a Jew guy for Lonelygirl15, but these days YouTube contributor Shmuel Tennenhaus is feeling like a hot commodity.

title: Gambian Defends the International Criminal Courts Initial Focus on Africans
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 25  The windows of Fatou Bensoudas office high up in the International Criminal Courts headquarters here offer her a sweeping view of orderly Dutch flatlands. But her attention is turned to her native Africa, on the chaos and killing at the heart of the courts first atrocities cases.

title: Nightmare Sounds of David Lynch in Operatic Translation
description: Knowing more is usually helpful, but I suspect that Olga Neuwirths operatic take on Lost Highway at the Miller Theater on Friday night will have had a better effect on those who dont know David Lynchs movie than on those who do.

title: Bombing at Iraqi Ministry Injures Vice President
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  An explosion today inside the headquarters of the Iraqi Ministry of Public Works killed at least five people and injured Iraqs vice president, the police and witnesses said.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the appointment of a new director of the Dia Art Foundation referred imprecisely to the foundations presence in Manhattan. While it has no museum in Manhattan, it does oversee two art installations there. The article also misspelled the name of the organization that supports Dias oversight of two other installations, in Nevada and Utah. It is the Lannan Foundation, not Lannon.

title: City Council May Change Menu Rule on Calories
description: Spurred on by the restaurant industry, the City Council may soon consider a bill that would overturn a new rule requiring calorie information to be prominently displayed at most major fast-food and chain outlets.
