title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Monday about Jacqueline Melendez Rivera, a New York City police officer accused of covering up for her husband after the shooting of another officer in Brooklyn, misidentified her neighborhood at one point. She lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn, not Prospect Heights. The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Thursday, and appeared in a correction in some copies on Feb. 14.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: France Loves Lady Chatterley

title: Knowing What to Do if a King Falls Early
description: Many great plays go unrewarded. Even though declarer makes the contract with the best line of play, the opposing cards are distributed so favorably that all sane approaches would have worked. But occasionally virtue sits firmly on its throne, as in the diagramed deal from a Chicago game at the Regency Whist Club in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: Times Photographer Honored for 06 Work
description: Tyler Hicks, 37, a staff photographer for The New York Times, was named the newspaper photographer of the year by the Missouri School of Journalisms Pictures of the Year International contest, known as POYi.

title: Adding to Security but Multiplying the Fears
description: Foreigners arriving at the American border must present both index fingers for fingerprinting, but that will soon change. The Department of Homeland Security now wants 10 fingers.

title: Sharpton Learns His Forebears Were Thurmonds Slaves
description: On the eve of the Civil War, in segregated Florida, a white man died in debt at age 40, leaving his wife, Julia Thurmond Sharpton, alone to raise their four children and to honor his financial obligations.

title: Burt Beagle, Ever-Present Sports Statistician, Dies at 73
description: Burt Beagle, an accountant who never met a sports statistic he did not love, a passion that put him on the sidelines of New York City high school and college sporting events for many years, died Monday in the Bronx. He was 73.

title: Israeli Crackdown in West Bank City Continues
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26  Israeli troops searched for militants and weapons in the West Bank city of Nablus today, going door-to-door for a third straight day and periodically clashing with gunmen and stone-throwing youths.

title: The $145 Billion Question
description: Comptroller may be a sleepy job title, but the New York State comptroller is one of the most powerful officials in the nation. He is single-handedly responsible for investing a $145 billion pension fund that state workers need to rely on when they retire, and he is the fiscal watchdog over the rest of state government. The importance of the position leaves New Yorkers with a big problem.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 17 about an inspection for stray voltage on New York City streets after the apparent electrocution of a dog that walked over an icy manhole cover misstated the definition of e-field, a term used by a consultant to Consolidated Edison. It is electric field, not electronic field.

title: The First International Polar Year
description: Nearly a century before the first spacecraft offered humans a wide-angle view of their home planet, the first International Polar Year (1881-84) sought to look at the big picture by setting up a network of research stations all around the Arctic.

title: Building New Homes in New Orleans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Senegalese Vote Hinges on Views of Economic Growth
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 25  Moudou Gueye was confident that Senegals presidential election on Sunday would turn around his fortunes, at least in the short term.

title: Israeli Troops Place Curfew on West Bank City
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25  The Israeli Army put the large West Bank city of Nablus under curfew on Sunday in one of the biggest military operations there in two years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 2 about a controversy over a naming agreement with Barclays, the British bank, for the basketball arena that is part of the planned Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misstated Barclays response to accusations by several black politicians that the company had cooperated with the apartheid regime in South Africa. Barclays says it withdrew from the country in 1986, which it considers to be eight years before the end of apartheid; the company did not say it withdrew six years before the end. (Apartheid was dismantled over several years beginning in 1990, but there is no generally agreed-upon date for the official end of apartheid.) (Go to Article)

title: Midmajors Seem to Have Bids Sewn Up
description: With 15 conference tournaments tipping off this week, the pressure is on for regular-season champions in midmajor and small conferences to secure automatic berths to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: For TXU, One of the Streets Fabled Barbarians Is Back in the Hunt
description: He has been there, done that, and now, close to 20 years after clinching the grandest buyout deal ever, Henry R. Kravis seems to be doing it again.

title: U.S. Says Raid in Iraq Supports Claim on Iran
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 25  A raid on a Shiite weapons cache in the southern city of Hilla one week ago is providing what American officials call the best evidence yet that the deadliest roadside bombs in Iraq are manufactured in Iran, but critics contend that the forensic case remains circumstantial and inferential.

title: A Closer Eye on State Aid to Political Allies
description: ALBANY  State Senator Martin J. Golden, a Brooklyn Republican, has directed several hundred thousand dollars worth of state aid to a community group run by the husband of a longtime staff member who is also an important political ally.

title: For Buckeyes, a Victory to Remember Oden By
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25  As the student section emptied out onto the floor in the aftermath of Ohio States 49-48 victory against top-ranked Wisconsin on Sunday, a chant as nave as it was loud reverberated through Value City Arena.

title: Iraqi Cabinet Approves Draft of Oil Law
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law today that would set guidelines for countrywide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the immense oil industry.

title: Manhattan: City Is Hiring 1,000 Lifeguards
description: The New York City Parks and Recreation Department has begun an effort to recruit more than 1,000 lifeguards for the citys beaches and pools this summer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday in his weekly radio address. The lifeguards will work at seven beaches, which open on May 26, and at 53 outdoor pools, which open on June 29, until Labor Day. The base pay is $11.72 an hour for a 48-hour week. Applicants must be at least 16 years old, meet vision requirements and pass a swimming test. Swimming tests are offered twice a day through mid-April at the departments lifeguard school at 553 West 59th Street. The city will provide and pay successful applicants for 40 hours of swimming, rescue, first aid and CPR training over 16 weeks.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Tuesday about the construction work expected to begin at the Atlantic Yards project near downtownBrooklyn referred imprecisely to the development. Although it has been endorsed by the Bloomberg administration and the City Planning Commission, it is a state project that does not require formal city approval.

title: At Dutch National Pastimes Top Event, Mother Nature Wields the Starting Gun
description: LEEUWARDEN, the Netherlands, Feb. 23  This is the town from which, when it is run, a grueling 125-mile race takes off across frozen canals and ice-locked lakes and under quaint bridges and past trim brick villages.

title: New York Cant Limit Damages in Ferry Crash
description: A federal judge today rejected New York Citys attempt to use an obscure 19th-century maritime law to cap its liability in the 2003 crash of the Staten Island Ferry at $14 million.

title: Iran Says It Launched Suborbital Rocket Into Space
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 25  Iran announced Sunday that it had launched a research rocket that attained a suborbital altitude, a test that appeared to move it closer toward its aim of putting its own satellites into space.

title: Can Video Help Save the Satellite Radio Business?
description: If the plan to merge XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio is approved, one result may be less music and less talk radio beamed into cars around the country.

title: New York Escapes Worst of Storm From Midwest
description: Snow once again delayed or forced the cancellation of hundreds of airline flights today and snarled highway travel across the Midwest and Eastern states, but the New York area escaped the worst effects of the storms.

title: How Can Opera Carry On? For Some Clues, Look to Where It Started Out
description: MANTUA, Italy, Feb. 25  The world of culture loves anniversaries, but rare is the occasion when an entire art form can celebrate a major birthday as opera did this weekend, exactly four centuries after Monteverdis pioneering work,  LOrfeo,  was performed in this medieval Italian city.

title: Pressure Mounts for Crackdown on Crime Wave
description: Over the weekend, the N.F.L. scouting combine in Indianapolis was all about 40-yard times, bench presses and vertical leaps during pro footballs annual inspection of prime beef on the hoof before the April 28 college draft. But what may prove to be the most important session at the combine was Thursdays summit meeting of management and player minds on the leagues personal-conduct policy.

title: Utopians Dreamt of Revolution, Yet the World Woke Unreformed
description: History has no culmination! proclaims the intellectual Alexander Herzen to Karl Marx in a dream at the close of Tom Stoppards Coast of Utopia. It has no goal. There is no libretto.

title: A Necessary Vaccine
description: Debate over a new vaccine to prevent cervical cancer and genital warts has reached a high pitch. State legislatures are debating whether to mandate the vaccine or insist that its use be kept voluntary. The manufacturer stopped a vigorous lobbying campaign lest it provoke more opposition than support. And some health professionals who had been championing the vaccine flinched at making it mandatory, at least for now.

title: N.F.L. Prospect Is a Prodigy in Helmet and Pads
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25  As he made his round of scheduled appointments, filling out forms in one place and sitting for a mug shot at another, Amobi Okoye tugged at the straps of the black backpack that he was wearing.

title: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Leipheimer Wins Tour of California
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 25  Two years after the retirement of Lance Armstrong and one year after Floyd Landis threw the sport into turmoil with a positive drug test at the Tour de France, a new cyclist has taken their place at the top of the American pack.

title: Two Bands in Concert, Both With the Same Members
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Feb. 23  You guys got to pick each other up. Gerard Way had ordered his band to stop, and now he was holding forth on concert etiquette. If somebody  even one person  falls down, everybody around them stops what theyre doing and picks them up off the ground. Did the fans agree? They did. So the music came roaring back.

title: Lawmakers Promise to Push Starrett City Rent Protection
description: State and city lawmakers vowed yesterday to begin a new push to persuade the State Legislature to extend rent regulation protections to certain publicly subsidized housing developments built since 1974  a proposal that could have a major influence on the future of Starrett City, a huge residential complex in Brooklyn that a group of investors wants to buy for $1.3 billion.

title: Hasan Ozbekhan, 86, Economist Who Helped Found Global Group, Dies
description: Hasan Ozbekhan, a Turkish-born economist and management expert who helped found the Club of Rome, a group of thinkers who came together to examine unwieldy global problems like food shortages and overpopulation, died on Feb. 12 in Philadelphia. He was 86.

title: Law School Experience (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Carpet Recycling: Who Said Knockoff?
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 25  Watching the designer Randolph Duke as a commentator for ABC describing what a wonderful impact dressing an Oscar-nominated actress for the red carpet has on a designers career, it was hard not to wonder how the man ended up so far on the wrong side of the velvet rope, speaking from a perch so distant it had to be called the Fashion Skyway. You could imagine Sally Kirkland running him over in the skyways H.O.V. lane with her loopy butterfly getup  she called it a rabbi and a reverend  that she claimed was made by her cabala teacher.

title: Trading Skates for a Suit, Snow Finds a New Calling
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Feb. 23  Garth Snow is the general manager of the Islanders now, not the backup goaltender. But he says he still likes to go to dinner with Islanders goalie Rick DiPietro, his former teammate, road roommate and protg.

title: U.S. Arm of Hyundai Places Account in Review
description: Hyundai Motor America in Fountain Valley, Calif., has parted ways with the Richards Group in Dallas, its creative agency since 2002, and placed the account in review.

title: Nike Commissions a Rap Song in Honor of Its Air Force 1 Shoe
description: Since last summer, Nike has been selling workout music on Apples iTunes store, including some original tracks from several electronic music artists. Now the company is offering songs for those who enjoy its sneakers as lifestyle accessories.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline on Friday about Gov. Eliot Spitzers retreat from his earlier suggestion that there would be further discussions about how to arrange the names of the dead at the 9/11 memorial in Lower Manhattan paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The mayor, discussing a conversation he had had with Mr. Spitzer, said, Youll have to ask him his views. Mayor Bloomberg did not say that the two men were now apparently in agreement. (A spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer indicated that he had revised his position after Mr. Bloomberg explained to Mr. Spitzer how the decision about the arrangement of names had been made.)

title: Suicide Bombing at an Iraqi University
description: A female suicide bomber wearing a vest packed with explosives and ball bearings blew herself up in Baghdad, killing at least 40 people.

title: Its Getting Hot in Here
description: Al Gore didnt have to worry about chads this time and arrived in the press room with an Oscar in hand for An Inconvenient Truth.

title: Wake-up Call
description: Melissa Etheridge, whose I Need to Wake Up, from An Inconvenient Truth, came out of nowhere to win for best song, held up the Oscar in the press room and said, This is the only naked man who will ever be in my bedroom.

title: Martys Party
description: The only real cheer of the night from the press came when Martin Scorsese won the best director award. The whole room erupted in a huge roar.

title: The Recently Arrived
description: Marty, after years in the desert, is suddenly not just best director, but the progenitor of the best picture as well. He should be feasting for days.

title: Times Photographer Honored
description: Tyler Hicks was named the newspaper photographer of the year by the Missouri School of Journalisms Pictures of the Year International contest.

title: The Skinny on Sororities
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Some Help in Buying Secondhand
description: If the idea of stepping off the consumer grid is appealing, but the reality of living the secondhand lifestyle seems daunting. The Compact members say that you are not limited to shopping at Goodwill and yard sales. Plenty of previously owned and lightly used goods can be found at a variety of resources. Some are listed below:

title: Man, 20, Is Killed After Argument on Brooklyn Subway Platform
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man returning home from a party was fatally stabbed as he was preparing to board a subway in Brooklyn early yesterday after arguing with a group of men, the police said. Five Brooklyn teenagers were arrested and charged in the assault last night, one of them with manslaughter.

title: Pure-Play Investment Banks Make Hay From M&A
description: Goldman Sachs and other specialist investment banks are reaping greater benefits from the recent mergers and acquisitions boom than their universal rivals, according to a report from a financial institutions analyst at Bear Stearns.

title: Citigroup Finds Taker for Hard Job
description: Talk about a tough job description: Help wanted. Chief financial officer for one of the worlds largest banks. Must be able to reverse a course of underperformance for which the companys chief executive has taken the blame. For Gary L. Crittenden, who was named on Sunday as Citigroups new finance chief, it is the best job I could ever imagine.

title: With Ericsson Bid, Tanderg TV Develops Bidding War
description: Ericsson, the worlds largest maker of wireless network gear, made a 9.8 billion-kronor ($1.4 billion) cash bid for Norways Tandberg Television, topping a rival offer by the Arris Group. Ericsson, based in Stockholm, is bidding 106 Norwegian kroner for each share of Tandberg TV,which boasts more than a quarter of the global market for video processing. Arris offered 96 kroner in cash and stock on Jan. 15. Tandberg Televisions stock rose 11 percent.

title: JPMorgan Brings Equity Broking Back to Pakistan
description: JPMorgan Chase will resume onshore equity broking services in Pakistan after an absence of five years to gain a share of a stock market that has grown 10-fold since 2001. The move underscores a rebound in emerging markets, which have recovered since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States There is more liquidity and the market capitalization has gone up, Reza Rahim, a senior country officer, told Bloomberg News. The Pakistan market has cheaper multiples compared with other emerging markets.

title: Swiss Cement Maker Bids for Canadian Rival
description: Switzerlands Holcim, a cement maker, will offer 571 million Canadian dollars ($493 million) for the remaining 21 percent of the St. Lawrence Cement Group that it does not already own to improve efficiency and take advantage of demand on the eastern seaboard of the United States. Minority shareholders of the cement producer will be offered 36.5 Canadian dollars a share, 12 percent more than St. Lawrences closing share price on Feb. 23.

title: T.D. Head Gets a Raise, Canadian-Style
description: Compensation for the chieftains of international investment banks is all relative, it seems. The Toronto-Dominion Bank of Canada increased the pay of its chief executive, Edmund Clark, 3 percent last year after profit more than doubled to a record. Mr. Clark received 11.4 million Canadian dollars ($9.85 million) in salary, bonus and stock options for the year that ended Oct. 31, according to a filing with regulators Friday.

title: China Grain Trader Plants I.P.O. Seeds
description: China Agri-Industries Holdings, a unit of Chinas largest grain trader, may raise as much as 2.6 billion Hong Kong dollars ($332 million) in an initial public offering in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported. The unit of Hong Kong-traded Cofco International Ltd. will sell 697.8 million new shares, equal to a 20 percent stake, Bloomberg said. The shares are being offered at between 3.10 and 3.72 Hong Kong dollars each, Cofco said in a release Monday.

title: Report of French Bid for Jones Lang Is False, Company Says
description: Sodexho Alliance, the worlds second-largest caterer, denied a report in La Lettre de LExpansion that it plans a $5 billion bid for the United States real-estate broker Jones Lang LaSalle. The report is false and contains wrong information, a spokeswoman for Sodexho told Bloomberg News. According to the report, the caterer has hired Lazard to advise on the offer, which would take place this year and be financed with a $1 billion sale of debt and stock. Chicago-based Jones Lang, the worlds second-largest commercial real-estate broker, has a market value of about $4 billion.

title: Nintendo Stock Falls on News of Share Sale
description: Shares of Nintendo, the worlds largest maker of handheld video-game players, posted the biggest decline in three weeks after the company said Japans government would sell its stake, about 1.4 percent of the outstanding stock. The stock fell 2.7 percent to 32,950 yen on the Osaka Securities Exchange on Monday.

title: Televisa Gets Green Light for Mexican Cable Buy
description: Grupo Televisa, Mexicos largest broadcaster, obtained conditional approval from antitrust regulators to buy a stake in a cable company in northern Mexico it plans to use to offer telephone services. Televisa will be allowed to buy 50 percent of Television Internacional de Monterrey on the condition that it offers its free channels to all pay-TV providers nationwide, Mexicos Federal Competition Commission said in an e-mail Sunday.

title: Daimler Said to Consider G.M. Stake
description: DaimlerChrysler is considering taking a minority stake in General Motors as payment for Chrysler if a deal between the two automakers takes place, the Financial Times reported.

title: Goldman Media Banker to Defect to Credit Suisse, Report Says
description: Sebastian Grigg, one of Europes best-connected media bankers, is in talks to leave Goldman Sachs for Credit Suisse, where he would become head of British investment banking, according to The Financial Times. Mr. Grigg, who The F.T. said was close to finalizing the terms of the move Sunday night, has worked at Goldman Sachs since the start of his banking career and has advised prominent United States and European media owners in recent years, including the publisher Houghton Mifflin and VNU.

title: CBS Gives Cash to Get a (Second) Life
description: CBS announced over the weekend that it has injected cash into The Electric Sheep Company, a creator of virtual-world content, as part of a strategic partnership to increase the broadcasters presence on Second Life and other online virtual worlds.

title: Fortress May Jump into EMI Fray, Report Says
description: A hedge fund, the Fortress Investment Group, may be joining the pack of bidders circling EMI, the troubled British music company. The Sunday Telegraph reported that Fortress, which last month became the first hedge fund in the United States to go public, raising $635 million in its I.P.O., is undertaking detailed work on EMI ahead of a possible bid for the label.

title: Tribune Considering Late Offer From Real Estate Magnate
description: Tribune, in discussions about its future, is weighing a proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire who sold his huge office development company this month for $39 billion in the biggest leveraged buyout ever completed. A special committee of Tribune board members was close to settling on an internal overhaul when Mr. Zell made a last-minute entry into the discussions, The New York Times reported.

title: Firms Said to Quit Claires Stores Auction
description: The auction for preteen trinket retailer Claires Stores appears to be stumbling after several private-equity firms dropped out ahead of the deadline for final bids Wednesday, according to The New York Post. The retail chain, which has been on the block since November, recently reported less than stellar fourth-quarter earnings, prompting several buyout firms to drop out of the auction, The Post said.

title: Babylon Rejoices
description: Seeing Michael Arndt standing outside the Vanity Fair party at 2:00 a.m. with his Oscar in his hand for writing a screenplay that nobody liked for a movie that nobody wanted to make made the Bagger feel a little soft and mushy about the little golden guy.

title: Caremark Delays Vote on CVS Deal
description: Caremark Rx, responding to a court ruling on Friday that it must provide more information on its proposed merger with CVS, delayed a shareholder vote by a week and assured shareholders Saturday they had the right to seek a courts intervention if they are concerned about CVSs offer for the pharmacy benefits manager. Caremark also sent notice that $35 million in payments to its investment bankers are contingent on their favorable recommendations about the merger with CVS, the nations largest retail pharmacy chain.

title: Station Casinos Agrees to $5.4 Billion Buyout
description: Station Casinos said on Monday it had agreed to a $5.4 billion management-led buyout after the investor group buying the company raised its offer by about 10 percent.

title: Off Somalia, There Be (Lots of) Pirates
description: A United Nations-chartered cargo ship, the MV Rozen, was reported hijacked by pirates off the coast of Somalia yesterday. An American warship was on its way to the scene, this morning, BBC News reported, adding that there were no immediate demands from the pirates, who boarded the ship armed with AK-47s.

title: XM and Sirius: A Merger of Not-So-Equals?
description: Heres a tip about deal-making: When companies start talking about a merger of equals, someone is usually getting the better deal. It is especially true in the proposed merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio.

title: Dont Move the Car
description: If you have one in the city, that is. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has learned a lesson from the last storm, when irate city drivers complained about having to shovel out their cars. Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended today; they will resume on Tuesday. Other parking regulations remain in effect.

title: A History of Surviving
description: Survival in extreme circumstances has become a habit for Rulon Gardner, who won a stunning victory in wrestling at the 2000 Olympics.

title: Giving Obama His Due
Congress Returns to Face the War
description: Congress returns from its Presidents Day break today and is set to pick up just where it left off  confronting the President Bush over his policy in Iraq.

title: Wilkes University
description: An ad for Wilkes University.

title: Wilkes University, Ad 2
description: An ad for Wilkes University.

title: Wilkes University, Ad 3
description: An ad for Wilkes University.

title: 2008: Secondary Virginity for Conservatives
description: In the eyes of many on the Christian right, each of the Republicans seeking their support has a significant flaw. Senator Sam Brownback supports a guest worker program. Representative Duncan Hunter wants protectionist trade policies. Some feel that Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, was responsible for tax increases in his state. And skepticism of Mitt Romneys social conservatism remains strong. But Grover Norquist, an anti-tax advocate, told The Timess David D. Kirkpatrick that with the right promises, any of the four could redeem themselves in the eyes of the conservative movement despite their past records, just as some high school students take abstinence pledges even after having had sex.

title: G.O.P. Chairmans Secret Weapon
description: Joseph Mondello was in for a rude shock when he took over as chairman of the State Republican Party after the November election: I was left with zero. I was left with enough money to pay the one secretary we had until the second week in January.

title: Will the Real Rudy Please Stand Up?
description: In the Republican primaries for the 2008 presidential nomination, Rudy Giuliani is foolishly selling himself as something hes not, write Ross Douthat and Reihan Salam in The Weekly Standard. Giuliani is not a George W. Bush Republican, and he shouldnt paint himself as one, Douthat and Salam write. They continue:

title: The Top 10 Buyouts
description: Being the worlds largest leveraged buyout is a fleeting honor these days. Last years acquisition of the hospital chain HCA held the title for a few months, only to be upstaged by the Blackstone Groups deal to buy Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord. That transaction, completed just a few weeks ago, now takes a backseat to the proposed takeover of TXU, led by the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group.

title: In TXUs $45 Billion Deal, Many Shades of Green
description: TXU, the Texas energy giant, announced Monday it had agreed to be taken private by a group of investors led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group for $45 billion in what would be the largest leveraged buyout in history. (See a list of the 10 biggest buyouts.)

title: The Man of My Dreams
description: By now youve figured out that Paul and I are not careful decision makers. We dont extensively research all the options before acting. Look before you leap is not a phrase we use.

title: Raising the Titanic, Sinking Christianity?
description: With no film in the running this year, director James Cameron might muffle some post-Oscar rhapsodizing as he looses the publicity hounds on his latest project, which strikes at the foundations of Christianity and already has Church authorities upset.

title: The Comfort of the Familiar
description: The menus are still yellow, long and narrow and to the point, just what you would expect at a brasserie. The glowing lights behind the shiny red lacquer door still beckon on a bitter cold night, just as it did the first time I visited its sister restaurant, Quatorze, in 1984, when I reviewed it.

title: Clintons Loyal Black Backers
description: For a change yesterday, Hillary Rodham Clinton was on her home turf of New York. But this time, the discussion, of course, was presidential politics, as she hosted a celebration of black history at the Lower Manhattan headquarters of District Council 37, New York Citys largest union of public employees, where a throng of union members, the vast majority of them African-American, treated her as a celebrity.

title: Sam Zell Seeks Value
description: In my job, Im not supposed to get emotional about investments. The Times does not let me own stocks, to avoid conflicts of interest, and I stick to broad-based mutual funds.

title: Let the Games Begin
description: The springs first intrasquad game has been moved up a few hours to 10:45 a.m. to account for the threat of rain. Willie Randolph will cede his managing powers to his bench coach, Jerry Manuel, and his third-base coach, Sandy Alomar. For the hitters, this will be their first chance to see live pitching  when they dont know what pitch is coming. For the pitchers, this will be another prime opportunity to make a good impression. Only Jorge Sosa, Ambiorix Burgos and Jason Vargas are considered in the mix for a roster spot.

title: Pavano Has a Bone Bruise
description: The Yankees announced that an MRI exam and X-rays of Carl Pavanos injured left foot indicated a bone bruise, The Associated Press reports. The oft-injured Pavano was hit by a line drive in practice Saturday.

title: Googles Moves Rekindle Microsoft-Yahoo Speculation
description: Talk that Microsoft might (or at least, should) acquire Yahoo has been going on for months. On Monday, TheStreet.coms Vishesh Kumar joined the chorus, writing that Googles continued encroachment on Microsofts territory might force the software giants hand. Last week, Google, already the leader of the online search business, introduced an upgraded version of its applications suite, which directly targets Microsofts venerable Office product.

title: Apax and Morgan Stanley to Buy Hub for $1.8 Billion
description: Hub International will be acquired by Apax Partners and the private equity arm of Morgan Stanley for about $1.8 billion, the insurance broker said Monday. The two firms will pay $40 a share, or a 16 percent premium over Hubs closing price Friday of $34.49. Under a go-shop provision in the agreement, Hub may solicit other proposals until March 19. The breakup fee is $21 million.

title: Share Your Opinion: Martys Best?
description: After seven snubs, Martin Scorsese finally won an Oscar. But did he win for the right movie?

title: Dow Chemicals Shares Surge Amid Buyout Speculation
description: Just as investors were receiving news of TXUs record-setting buyout agreement, a report has stirred up rumors about an even larger one. Shares of Dow Chemical jumped more than 5 percent on Monday, hitting a new 52-week high, after a British tabloid reported over the weekend that private equity firms might be preparing a $54 billion takeover bid for the company. Several analysts expressed doubt that any deal was in the works, but trading in Dow Chemicals stock was extremely heavy Monday, with volume of more than triple the daily average by early afternoon.

title: Small Pleasures: Paris Fashion
description: Ever since Saturday, when I left Milan like a bat out of hell, Ive been a citizen-tourist of Paris. First, I went to the Caf de Flore, where I had two soft-boiled eggs and read the English papers while I dipped the long straws of sourdough bread into the yolks and wondered if all French men take a holiday from shaving on Saturday mornings. Then I walked down the Boulevard St.-Germain, quite a ways, until I reached the Club Latin Quartier, where for about $3 you can go for a swim. Paris has wonderful public pools. After that, I moseyed over to Karl Lagerfelds bookstore, on Rue de Lille, where I bought a book of Martin Munkacsis photographs. Munkacsi, a Hungarian, once said, Think while you shoot! It seems good advice, in general.

title: A Case of Gay Bias or Thin Skin?
description: There is little question that the comments allegedly made by Aaron Charneys boss at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell  if he made them  were rude and juvenile. It is far less clear whether they were discriminatory, Robert Kolker suggests in his article on Mr. Charney and the lawsuit he filed against the firm, which appears in this weeks New York magazine. The story is just the latest account of a legal battle that has generated intense debate about office culture at a top New York law firm.

title: CareerBuilder.com
description: An ad that aired during the Oscars on Feb. 25.

title: Whos the Most Substantive One of All?
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Feb. 26 column, Substance Over Image.

title: Schemers vs. Dreamers
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Feb. 26 column, Mud, Dust, Whatever.

title: Aura
description: An ad that aired during the Oscars on Feb. 25.

title: Whos Next: Energy Companies
description: TXUs agreement to go private shows how competition among buyout firms is sending them into areas they had once avoided. There was a time when casino operators were considered off limits to private equity firms because of the industrys heavy regulation; now Harrahs Entertainment and Station Casinos have both agreed to buyouts.

title: An Ancient Parenting Problem  Solved!
description: Should children watch television?

title: Farrakhans Reading List Includes Carter; A.D.L. Does Not Approve
description: As Neil MacFarquhar reported for The New York Times today, Louis Farrakhan, the departing and controversial leader of the Nation of Islam, made what was billed as a farewell speech in Detroit yesterday, calling for Muslim-Christian unity and for President Bush to be impeached over the war in Iraq.

title: Amid Pressure from Icahn, Temple-Inland Plans Breakup
description: Chalk up another win for Carl C. Icahn. Under pressure from the activist investor, the diversified holding company Temple-Inland announced Monday that it would spin off its real estate and financial services units and timberlands. Temple-Inland will instead focus on its packaging and building products, with proceeds from the sales to be distributed through a shareholder dividend and a debt restructuring, the companys chief executive said in a conference call Monday morning.

title: Giuliani Grilled on Foreign Policy
description: It had to happen eventually, and it is a testament to Rudolph W. Giulianis popularity that it did not happen sooner.

title: Senatorial Stand-Up
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton received a rousing wave of applause last night before a packed audience in the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y, where she introduced New Yorks senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, who discussed his new book about the middle class.

title: A New Sheriff in Town
description: Albany, which has sometimes been said to have a whiff of the Wild West about it when it comes to issues of ethics, has a new Sheriff. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo just named Ellen Nachtigall Biben as a special deputy attorney general for public integrity, where she will be charged with overseeing landmark initiatives to fight government corruption.

title: The Happy Recap

title: S.E.C. Chair Turned Activist to Take the Stage
description: Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator in the United States, has been fairly tight-lipped for almost a year about his new career as an activist hedge fund investor. He declined to comment in January when The New York Times profiled his fledgling firm, Breeden Capital Management, and wrote about its proxy fight with restaurant chain Applebees International. Now, Mr. Breeden plans to open up  not to a group of fellow investors, but to a group of his former colleagues: lawyers.

description: The Associated Press reports that Yankees right fielder Bobby Abreu strained an oblique muscle during batting practice today and will miss at least two weeks.

title: Daimler Minus Chrysler = Buyout Target?
description: As rumors swirl about who might buy Chrysler, Reuters asks a different question: Would a Chrysler-less Daimler-Benz be a candidate for a leveraged buyout? Shares in the combined company, DaimlerChrysler, are trading above where they were when the company first announced that all options were on the table for its troubled American unit. Since then, there has been speculation that hedge funds or private equity firms might try to buy the assets that remained after a Chrysler sale, including the prized Mercedes brand.

description: Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune looks at developments in world affairs.

Bruno, the Republican majority leader, had some unkind words today for David Grandeau, the executive director of the soon-to-expire state lobbying commission and a onetime F.O.B. (Friend of Bruno). Mr. Grandeau has been hoping for a position with the soon-to-be-created new ethics commission, which will replace, in part, the lobbying commission. Mr. Bruno did not seem exactly in love with the idea. Chatting with reporters this morning, Mr. Bruno was asked if Mr. Grandeau was still his man.

title: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
description: Microsofts drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled yesterday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers.

title: In Medieval Architecture, Signs of Advanced Math
description: In the beauty and geometric complexity of tile mosaics on walls of medieval Islamic buildings, scientists have recognized patterns suggesting that the designers had made a conceptual breakthrough in mathematics beginning as early as the 13th century.

title: British Court Affirms Order to Deport Cleric to Jordan
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  A British court ruled Monday that the government could deport a radical Islamic cleric to Jordan, setting the stage for the deportation of other foreign terrorism suspects in Britain to countries with poor human rights records.

title: Albany: Lawyer Named to Lead Anticorruption Bureau
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced the appointment of Ellen Nachtigall Biben yesterday as special deputy attorney general for public integrity, to lead efforts to fight government corruption. Ms. Biben has worked in the Manhattan district attorneys office for more than 10 years, and as deputy chief of the rackets bureau since 2001. She is a graduate of Wesleyan University and the University of Southern California law school.

title: La Isabelas Final Failure
description: Christopher Columbus may have been one heck of an explorer, but as an administrator he left a lot to be desired. La Isabela, the settlement he established on his second voyage with high hopes of finding silver and gold, lasted just four years. The colony found precious little save for disease, storms and hunger before it was abandoned in 1498.

title: Manhattan: Criticism of Homeland Security Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized a bill before the United States Senate that would carry out some of the recommendations of the 9/11 Commission. He said the bill embraced the discredited approach of allocating homeland security funds based on population and froze the pool of money distributed to cities according to risk and threat level. The mayor made the criticism in a letter to Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut and chairman of the Senates Homeland Security Committee, and Susan Collins of Maine, the committees ranking Republican. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, issued a statement agreeing with the mayors objections. The full Senate has not voted on the bill, and the grant formulas will probably be decided in a conference committee that will try to reconcile whatever bill the Senate passes with one already adopted by the House.

title: Honeybees Vanish, Leaving Keepers in Peril
description: VISALIA, Calif., Feb. 23  David Bradshaw has endured countless stings during his life as a beekeeper, but he got the shock of his career when he opened his boxes last month and found half of his 100 million bees missing.

title: A Mix of Medicines That Can Be Lethal
description: The death of Libby Zion, an 18-year-old college student, in a New York hospital on March 5, 1984, led to a highly publicized court battle and created a cause clbre over the lack of supervision of inexperienced and overworked young doctors. But only much later did experts zero in on the preventable disorder that apparently led to Ms. Zions death: a form of drug poisoning called serotonin syndrome.

title: Fresh Opera for Next Season
description: New productions at the Metropolitan Opera, 2007-8 season:

title: Bombing at Iraqi Ministry Wounds 2 Top Officials
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  An explosion inside the Ministry of Public Works on Monday wounded an Iraqi vice president and the public works minister and killed at least five people, in what officials described as a possible assassination attempt.

title: Ullrich Leaves Behind Racing, but Not Suspicions of Doping
description: Jan Ullrich, the cyclist who elevated and then crushed the sports profile in his native Germany, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: Station Casinos Accepts Offer From Founder and Buyout Firm
description: Station Casinos Inc., which owns 12 casinos in the Las Vegas area, agreed yesterday to a sweetened $5.4 billion takeover bid from the founders family and a buyout firm.

title: Justices Decline Case on 200-Year Sentence for Man Who Possessed Child Pornography
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  An Arizona man who received a 200-year prison sentence for possessing 20 pornographic images of children failed Monday to persuade the Supreme Court to consider whether the sentence was unconstitutionally excessive.

title: Lawmakers Raise the Ante in the States Budget Process
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Legislative leaders put a few more cards on the table on Monday in the high-stakes poker game that is the state budget process, insisting that the state will have nearly a billion dollars more to spend than Gov. Eliot Spitzer has projected.

title: Cutbacks at Airbus Approved, but Details Are Not Yet Public
description: PARIS, Feb. 26  The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent of the aircraft maker Airbus, said on Monday that its board had unanimously approved a turnaround plan, one week after the Airbus chief executive had pleaded with its shareholders to overcome narrow national issues.

title: A License to Blog?
description: Unlike a lot of other political bloggers, I started blogging with a distinct lack of interest in politics. My first post about a presidential campaign, back in January 2004, the first month of my blog, was purely an accident. I was reading The Isthmus, our free alternative newspaper here in Madison, Wis., when I ran across a chart comparing the Democratic candidates for president.

title: Mississippi Expects to Be Site of a Toyota Assembly Plant
description: The governor of Mississippi is expected to announce this morning that his state will be the site of Toyotas eighth assembly plant in North America.

title: The Claim: Duct Tape Removes Warts
description: THE FACTS A small study in 2002 gave credence to an old remedy for an ugly problem when it stated that duct tape, that ever-popular emblem of inventiveness and quick fixes, was a highly effective treatment for warts.

title: YouTube Has New Fans in League Offices
description: YouTube, only 2 years old, has grown so rapidly as a cultural force that it is difficult to recall its roguish roots when folks uploaded their videos and those they pulled off television and sent them to the Web site.

title: An Early Environmentalist, Embracing New Heresies
description: Stewart Brand has become a heretic to environmentalism, a movement he helped found, but he doesnt plan to be isolated for long. He expects that environmentalists will soon share his affection for nuclear power. Theyll lose their fear of population growth and start appreciating sprawling megacities. Theyll stop worrying about frankenfoods and embrace genetic engineering.

title: Judge Dismisses Juror in Libby Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The judge presiding over the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. dismissed one of the jurors in the midst of deliberations Monday and ruled that the case should go forward with the remaining 11-member jury.

title: Ganache on Deadline, With a Little Help From Home Depot
description: Sometime between the age of Marie Antoinette and the point at which a young man named Duff Goldman decided to study pastry making in Napa Valley, Calif., the fashion for cakes shifted. Cakes made to look as if they should be exhibited in vitrines trickled down from court life to ordinary citizens intent on celebrating their milestones more fantastically.

title: On Friday, a Debut. On Saturday, a Farewell.
description: Two events  Valery Gergievs appearance on the podium at the New York State Theater on Friday night, and Miranda Weeses farewell performance on Saturday night  dominated the final weekend of the New York City Ballets winter season. But never mind the wonderfully resonant shimmering sound that Mr. Gergiev drew from the orchestra. When Sara Mearns entered the stage for her debut in Balanchines Walpurgisnacht Ballet, all else was forgotten.

title: Astronomers May Have Found New Star in Southern Cross
description: Astronomers may have found another star to add to the Southern Cross, one of the most familiar constellations in the southern sky. Beta Crucis, the bright star that forms one arm of the cross, apparently has a small companion undetectable by optical telescopes.

title: Spacecraft Closes In for a Look at Jupiter, With Pluto Next on the List
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The New Horizons spacecraft, launched from Earth by NASA some 13 months ago, is moving in for a close encounter with Jupiter on Wednesday that should let it test its suite of instruments before being flung off toward the distant target of Pluto and its trio of moons.

title: Iraqis Reach an Accord on Oil Revenues
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law on Monday that would set guidelines for nationwide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the immense oil industry. The endorsement reflected a major agreement among the countrys ethnic and sectarian political blocs on one of Iraqs most divisive issues.

title: Awareness: Too Much Acetaminophen? Few Seem to Know
description: People who take Tylenol and other medicines that contain acetaminophen are largely ignorant of the safe dosages, a new study has found, and unaware that an overdose can cause severe liver damage.

title: A Wharton Dean Is Named to Lead the Conference Board
description: The Conference Board, a business research and consulting group that publishes some of the nations leading economic surveys, has selected Jonathan Spector, a vice dean at the Wharton School, as its chief executive.

title: Old-Line Hollywood Takes Back the Night
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26  The victory of The Departed at the Oscars on Sunday night represented many things: fair tribute to Martin Scorsese, recognition of the movies brute force at the box office, and an acknowledgment that stars not only make movies, they make the movie.

title: Regulatory Clearance  Seen as Slow but Sure
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 26  The sale of the biggest utility in Texas to private investors faces months of state and federal regulatory hurdles, but experts predict that the broad support for the deal from environmentalists and other important interest groups should help it clear them with ease.

title: Diplomats to Begin Drafting New U.N. Sanctions on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The coalition of six world powers that has been trying to get Iran to rein in its nuclear program will begin drafting a new United Nations Security Council resolution to ratchet up the pressure again, officials said Monday after a meeting in London.

title: A Mystery Ailment, but Not for the Right Doctor
description: This is the story of a sore foot. In the annals of illness, a sore foot is a humble woe unless it is your foot, and if searching out its cause has led you nowhere.

title: Canadas Move to Restore Rights
description: The United States was not the only country to respond to the horror of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks with policies that went much too far in curtailing basic rights and civil liberties in the name of public safety. Now we see that a nation can regain its senses after calm reflection and begin to rein back such excesses, but that heartening news comes from Canada and not the United States.

title: Billions Over Baghdad
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Exploring Beethovens Talent for Turning Straw Into Gold
description: Beethovens later years were partly spent making something out of nothing. Other composers struggled for the full-blown inspiration. Beethoven took the downright tacky, hacked away at it sometimes for years and came out with what he wanted. The uses of the mundane are best illustrated in his last two piano pieces: the Six Bagatelles (Op. 126) and the Diabelli Variations, both of which the splendid young Polish-Hungarian (as he describes himself) Piotr Anderszewski played at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Cheney Unhurt After Bombing in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 27  A suicide bomber blew himself up this morning outside the main gate of the United States military base at Bagram while Vice President Dick Cheney was inside the base. Mr. Cheney was not hurt in the attack.

title: Halliburton to Complete Split With KBR
description: Halliburton, the oil field services provider, said yesterday that it would complete its separation from KBR Inc. by offering current stockholders the remaining 81 percent stake in KBR, its former subsidiary.

title: Cheney Warns Pakistan to Act Against Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Just hours after Vice President Dick Cheney delivered a stiff private message to President Pervez Musharraf in Pakistan, the Pakistani government lashed out Monday with a series of statements insisting that Pakistan does not accept dictation from any side or any source.

title: Study Points to Genetics in Disparities in Preterm Births
description: Black women have significantly higher rates of premature birth than white women, and a new study suggests there may be underlying genetic factors even when other known risks are taken into account.

title: Game With No Winner
description: Its almost enough to make us nostalgic for streaking and sitting on flagpoles. College students from Michigan to Florida have found a new way to get attention, offend others and make a right-wing statement all at once. Its a game with a name that says it all: Catch the Illegal Immigrant.

title: Yankees Need an Outfielder, but It Wont Be Williams
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 26  Until Monday, Bernie Williamss refusal to accept a minor league contract and an invitation to spring training was a noteworthy yet cosmetic issue for the Yankees. Even if the 38-year-old Williams had reported on time and in spectacular shape, it probably would have taken a significant injury to an everyday outfielder for him to make the team.

title: Lacey Township: Panel Rejects States View on Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday rejected New Jersey officials contention that the threat of terrorism should be taken into consideration as part of an application to extend the license of the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant here. The commission found that the consideration of a potential terrorist attack was beyond the scope of the license hearing. Lisa Jackson, the state environmental commissioner, expressed disappointment with the decision and said the state would decide whether to appeal it.

title: U.S. Officials to Meet With Iranians at Talks on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  American officials said today they had agreed to hold the highest-level contact with Iranian authorities in more than two years as part of an international meeting on Iraq.

title: Heinz Berggruen, Influential Picasso Collector, Dies at 93
description: PARIS, Feb. 26  Heinz Berggruen, a German-born Jewish art collector who in the mid-1990s made a powerful gesture of reconciliation by moving his modern art collection to Berlin, died outside Paris on Friday. He was 93.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about a court ruling that blocked Nigerias president, Olusegun Obasanjo, from unseating his vice president, Atiku Abubakar, misstated Mr. Abubakars ethnic background. He is a Fulani from the Hausa-dominated north of the country, not a Hausa. (Go to Article)

title: Remaking the City's Image, With 50 Million Tourists in Mind
description: George A. Fertitta has helped sell a lot of pricey Belgian chocolates and French cognac to New Yorkers. Now he has to sell New York to Belgians, Frenchmen and others who may consider the city too costly, too dangerous or too American to visit.

title: UConn Coach Has New Reason to Like New Jersey
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 26  As challenges go, this was supposed to be a big one for third-ranked Connecticut, the obstacle that stood between it and a perfect regular season in the Big East Conference.

title: Studies Show Anemia Drugs May Harm Cancer Patients
description: New studies are raising questions about whether drugs that have been used by millions of cancer patients might actually be harming them.

title: Alan D. Eames, 59, Scholar of Beers Around the World, Dies
description: Alan D. Eames, who cultivated his reputation as the Indiana Jones of beer by crawling into Egyptian tombs to read hieroglyphics about beer and voyaging along the Amazon in search of a mysterious lost black brew, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Dummerston, Vt. He was 59.

title: U.S. and Iraqi Troops Storm Militant Stronghold
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 27  American and Iraqi troops on Tuesday stormed several buildings in Sadr City, Baghdads main bastion of Shiite militancy, and detained at least 16 suspected militiamen accused of operating murder, kidnapping and torture cells, the American military and local officials said.

title: Will Maslow, 99, Lawyer Who Fought Discrimination, Dies
description: Will Maslow, a former executive director of the American Jewish Congress who fought discrimination against African-Americans as well as Jews, particularly in employment and education, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Justices Take Up Police Use of Lethal Force
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  There was no dispute in the Supreme Court on Monday about the disastrous consequences of a high-speed police chase over the back roads of a rural Georgia county six years ago.

title: Chief Judge Plans Center to Ease Divorce Process
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, in her annual address on the judiciary, announced plans to create a new family law center in New York City that is intended to make divorce faster and cheaper for couples who want amicable settlements.

title: Asians Flex Muscles in California Politics
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26  When Leland Yee ran for the San Francisco school board in 1986, Asian-American elected officials in California were rare and misconceptions about them rampant. Mr. Yee, who immigrated from China at age 3 and has a doctorate in child psychology, recalled that some people at the time wondered if he knew how to speak English properly.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Frances Kissling has been called the philosopher of the pro-choice movement by her friends and an abortion queen by her critics.

title: Court Monitor Reports Progress in the Overhaul of New Jerseys Child Welfare System
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26  After more than three years of false starts and persistent failures, an independent monitor said Monday that New Jersey had begun to make progress in a court-ordered plan to overhaul its beleaguered child welfare system.

title: Electronic Arts Brings Back Its Ex-President as Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26  In a surprise to investors, Electronic Arts said on Monday that its chief executive, Lawrence F. Probst III, would step down April 1, ending a 16-year tenure during which the company grew into the dominant independent publisher of video games.

title: Smith & Wollensky to Sell Restaurants Outside of New York
description: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a Los Angeles restaurant group for $79.5 million. Its properties in New York, however, will remain in the hands of its founder.

title: Tiffany to Hear Peltz Funds Ideas
description: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it would consider suggestions on strategy from Trian Fund Management, a New York investment firm that has become its largest shareholder. The companys stock price rose more than 5 percent, reaching a three-year high of $45.06.

title: Brooklyn Mans Bound Body Found at Home
description: The body of a Brooklyn man, bound and with a bag over his head, was found in his apartment in East Flatbush yesterday afternoon, the police said.

description: HOORAY for Hollywood: Once again, the commercials that appeared during the Academy Awards seemed better than the commercials that appeared during the Super Bowl.

description: Every time Sue Gogilis starts her shift driving the company truck she gives her steering wheel a good rub with a few disinfectant wipes.

title: Judge Rejects Cap on Awards in Ferry Crash
description: A federal judge yesterday rejected New York Citys attempt to use an obscure 19th-century maritime law to cap its liability in the 2003 crash of a Staten Island ferry at $14 million.

title: Stain of Racism Feeds N.B.A.s Renegade Image
description: My wife and two sons were with me at the recent N.B.A. All-Star weekend in Las Vegas. The crowds made us feel more claustrophobic than threatened, but maybe that was because we werent roaming the nightspots any more than we would have in Los Angeles or New York.

title: One Mans Survival Story Becomes a Rallying Cry
description: It was many weeks before ABCs Bob Woodruff realized how lucky he was to survive a roadside bomb explosion in Iraq in January 2006. It took months for him to understand how lucky he was to recover as fully as he did.

description: Keeping track of constant changes in airline frequent-flier and other travel-loyalty programs makes me feel as if my head is about to explode.

title: Finding a Way to Stay on the Go
description: The one thing worse than traveling too much for work may be the opposite: not being able to travel at all.

title: Iranian Scholars Denounce Conference That Denied Holocaust
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 26  A group of Iranian academics, writers and artists has denounced the Holocaust conference held in Tehran late last year, calling it a move that endangered peace and hurt the reputation of Iranian academics.

title: Presidents Behaving Badly in Age of Unwinnable Wars
description: In recent months, President Harry S. Truman has been claimed by both sides of the political aisle as a visionary architect of the grand strategy that won the cold war. In a 2006 book, The Good Fight, the New Republic editor at large Peter Beinart hailed Truman as a cold war liberal, who cannily built a tough-minded but resilient foreign policy  with important lessons for todays Democrats  based on the intertwined principles of containment, overseas economic development, and humility and restraint on the world stage.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Tsunami Memorial Unveiled

title: In a Hopi Labyrinth, Strings Flicker and Flow
description: The concerts that the New York Youth Symphony is presenting at Carnegie Hall this season are bittersweet affairs: each brings closer the impending departure of Paul Haas, the groups dynamic young music director, who will step down in May. This lanky conductor is surely on the brink of a noteworthy career, judging by the evidence of his work with this fine group.

title: Song Wakens Injured Pride of Afrikaners
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 26  "Proudly South African" is this nation's E Pluribus Unum, a slogan stamped on products, echoed in radio commercials and inculcated into the new South African DNA. Much as America's motto celebrates melding many into one, South Africa's says that it doesn't matter what you look like  we can all be proud of our young country.

title: Court Ruling Delays Burial of Model
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26  A Florida appeals court agreed Monday to hear a challenge by Anna Nicole Smiths mother to a ruling last week giving custody of Ms. Smiths body to her infant daughters court-appointed guardian.

title: Temple-Inland Will Separate Into 3 Companies
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP)  Temple-Inland, the packaging, forest products, real estate and financial services company, said on Monday that it planned to separate itself into three stand-alone public companies and sell its timberlands.

description: To the Editor:

title: Practical Fusion, or Just a Bubble?
description: LOS ANGELES  Brian Kappus, a physics graduate student at U.C.L.A., tipped the clear cylinder to trap some air bubbles in the clear liquid inside. He clamped the cylinder, upright, on a small turntable and set it spinning. With the flip of another switch, powerful up-and-down vibrations, 50 a second, started shaking the cylinder.

title: Shuttle Repairs Might Delay Launch
description: The space shuttles external tank suffered damage in a hailstorm on Monday, and the launch scheduled for mid-March could now be delayed for repairs.

title: S.E.C. Says Firm Traded on Information Stolen From Computers
description: An accounting firm in Hong Kong made $2.7 million from illegal insider trades by hacking into computers to view press releases before they were published, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday in a lawsuit.

title: France: Anti-Semitic Attacks Rise
description: Anti-Semitic attacks soared by 45 percent from 2005 to 2006, according to Frances main Jewish organization, the Representative Council of Jewish Institutions. The council reported that 112 cases of assault were reported to a hot line for victims of anti-Semitism last year, compared with 77 the previous year. Anti-Semitic acts, both lesser physical violence and vandalism, rose 40 percent, to 213 incidents, from 134. In virtually all cases of assault, there is no doubt that anti-Semitism is a motive, the council said in a statement.

title: A Majority of One
description: The growing ability of advertisers to more precisely target potential audiences through media like direct mail and the Internet has led pundits to proclaim the arrival of the era of one-to-one marketing. A campaign for a small university in Pennsylvania is taking advantage of the trend toward personalization in a surprising  and delightful  way.

title: Rappers Find That a Small Label Can Have Its Uses
description: B. G., the New Orleans rapper whose hit Bling Bling popularized the term, has a new album out today. Sort of. So does Slim Thug, the Houston rapper who helped Beyonc top the pop charts last year. (He rapped on her No. 1 hit Check on It.) Again, sort of. Because neither of these new albums is really a new album.

title: Infield to Outfield to Pitchers Mound
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 26  As a lanky 16-year-old third baseman playing in the Dominican Republic town of Salcedo, Jorge Sosa booted four or five balls during one game. After the game, when Paul Egins, a Colorado Rockies official, went over to talk to Sosa, he took one look at his mitt and remembered thinking, This is a glove?

title: Federers Reign Goes on and History Follows
description: As befits somebody who is leaving a permanent stamp on his sport, Roger Federer will be honored by the Swiss Post in April.

title: East Village or East Egg, Its All About Ego
description: Vacuousness and self-absorption, it appears, never go out of style. In a new play with an unpublishable title, Michael Domitrovich introduces five 20-somethings who are awash in both  irritating people who could be from a Warhol posse or a Gatsby party but, alas, are present-day East Village types. New century, same narcissism.

title: Director of Sex, Lies and Videotape Is Cut From Real Role as Sex-Trial Juror
description: You would think that the writer and director of a film called Sex, Lies and Videotape would be the perfect choice for the jury in a sex trial.

title: Riley, Without a Spark Plug, Prepares for the Playoff Push
description: Dwyane Wade is expected to rejoin the Miami Heat today in Washington, Coach Pat Riley said before last nights game against the Knicks. But that is only because the Heat is scheduled to meet with President Bush at the White House, one of the perks of winning last seasons N.B.A. title.

title: Paraguays Ruling Party Faces Threat of a Populist Bishop
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay, Feb. 24  No political party currently in power anywhere in the world has governed longer than the Colorado Party here, not even the Kim familys Communist dynasty in North Korea. But a charismatic Roman Catholic bishop recently suspended by the Vatican is threatening that hegemony and has emerged as the front-runner for next years presidential election.

title: A Police Stakeout for One Crime Interrupts Another
description: On New Yorks streets, police activity can often result in considerable confusion, at least initially, with details of criminals and their crimes not untangled until hours later. description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Feb. 26  The ruling in The Hague on Monday that Serbia had failed to prevent genocide in Bosnia greatly disappointed relatives of the mainly Muslim victims of the conflict.

title: Nutrition: Study Questions Limits on Fish in Pregnancy
description: The Food and Drug Administration advises pregnant women to avoid eating certain fish entirely, because they may contain unsafe levels of methylmercury, and to limit seafood to 12 ounces, or about two servings, a week. But a British report, published in The Lancet on Feb. 17, suggests that this may not be the best advice.

title: N.H.L. Trade Deadline Nears and the Trading Accelerates
description: The National Hockey League trading deadline was made two weeks earlier last season, and team executives, no strangers to telephones, were not bashful about swinging deals. They completed a league-record 25 trades on an entertaining deadline day.

title: Nepal to Seize Property Acquired by Its King
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  Nepals multiparty government plans to seize the property held by the countrys king, Gyanendra, and set up a panel of ministers to collect details on assets held by him, a cabinet minister said Monday.

title: Court Declares Bosnia Killings Were Genocide
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 26  The International Court of Justice on Monday for the first time called the massacre of Bosnian Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995 an act of genocide, but determined that Serbia itself was not guilty of the enormous crime.

title: Zookeeper Death to Be Reviewed
description: DENVER, Feb. 26  The federal Department of Agriculture is sending a veterinarian to Colorado to figure out why a jaguar attacked and killed a zookeeper here on Saturday.

title: You Want Some Truth With That?
description: New Yorks effort to compel fast-food restaurants to list calories alongside menu prices is being challenged. Representatives for a host of restaurant chains have persuaded the chairman of the City Councils Health Committee to introduce a bill that would gut the new regulations before they took effect. The complaint is that compliance would be too onerous and very expensive. Its more likely that compliance might be really embarrassing or, worse, thought-provoking.

title: Youngest Workers Lose Ground in Citys Strong Job Market
description: The strongest job market New York City has had in decades has not helped the citys youngest workers find jobs, leaving them at risk of becoming permanently unemployable, according to a report an anti-poverty group released yesterday.

title: Crypt Held Bodies of Jesus and Family, Film Says
description: A documentary by the Discovery Channel claims to provide evidence that a crypt unearthed 27 years ago in Jerusalem contained the bones of Jesus of Nazareth.

title: A Land of Camel Milk and Honey
description: HARGEISA, Somaliland(?)

title: City Will Add 10 Weeks to Training for Firefighters
description: The Fire Department will add 10 weeks to its 13-week training program for probationary firefighters at an annual cost of $12.4 million, fire officials said yesterday during a City Council hearing on the plan.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about the disputed works of the pianist Joyce Hatto, misidentified a music critic for Gramophone magazine. He is Jed Distler, not Jeremy Distler.

title: International Court Names Darfur War Suspects
description: The International Criminal Courts chief prosecutor said today that he is presenting evidence accusing two senior figures in Sudan of crimes against humanity and war crimes linked to the conflict between the Sudanese government and rebel fighters in Darfur.

title: Accusations of Agency Error in Disaster Loans
description: Last September, the Small Business Administration, which provides most long-term rebuilding aid to disaster victims, accelerated its lending to homeowners and businesses in the Gulf Coast, responding to criticism that it had been slow to respond to Hurricanes Katrina and Rita of 2005.

title: In Noble Campaign Against a Slur, Reasons for Pause
description: An exercise in legislative high-mindedness played itself out yesterday in the New York City Council chambers.

title: Brooklyn: Teenagers Charged in Fatal Stabbing
description: Five teenagers have been charged in connection with a fatal stabbing on a subway platform in East New York early Sunday morning, the police said yesterday. The stabbing, which took place about 3 a.m. at the New Lots subway stop, occurred after an argument between members of the group and a deli worker, Gerlin Collado, 20, of Manhattan. Mr. Collado, who was returning home with his brother after a party, was stabbed several times in the chest, the police said. Those charged are Samuel Villanueva and Jonathan Gonzalez, both 18; Wilson Rodriguez, 17, and Franklyn Ciprion, 16, all of Brooklyn; and Michael Estrella, 17, of Queens. They are charged with assault, gang assault and criminal possession of a weapon. Mr. Villanueva is charged with manslaughter.

title: Finding Humor, and Blood, in a Classic Greek Tragedy
description: In the last few years, David Johnstons fertile imagination has run wild in a giddy comedy about a pornographic comic strip (Busted Jesus Comix) and a supernatural fantasy featuring the Warhol superstar Candy Darling and the Roman Catholic activist Dorothy Day (Candy & Dorothy). So it comes as a surprise to see it somewhat shackled in his new retelling of Aeschylus Oresteia, which includes some of his trademark off-kilter sensibility but none of his familiar flights of fancy.

title: Private Equity Buyout of TXU Is Enormous in Size and in Its Complexity
description: Wall Street banks have provided billions of dollars to finance takeovers in the last year, essentially serving as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms, which are among the banks best-paying customers.

title: A Bad Report Card
description: The news from American high schools is not good. The most recent test results from the National Assessment of Educational Progress, commonly known as the national report card, finds that American 12th graders are actually performing worse in reading than 12th graders did in 1992, when a comparable exam was given. In addition, 12th-grade performance in reading has been distressingly flat since 2002, even though the states were supposed to be improving the quality of teaching to comply with the No Child Left Behind education act.

title: Suit Against Ex-Citi Officers Is Dismissed
description: Two former Citigroup executives won dismissal yesterday of a lawsuit in which the government accused them of keeping tens of millions of dollars for the banks asset management arm that should have gone to reduce mutual fund fees.

title: Former Olympian Adds a Harrowing Tale to List
description: When the small plane he was flying in hit the water in a remote part of Lake Powell in southern Utah on Saturday, Rulon Gardner said, his first thought was that it was a dream.

title: Outcomes: Heart Disease Linked to Poor Parts of Town
description: Living in a poor neighborhood may increase the risk for heart disease, a Swedish study reports.

title: That 10,000-Mile Commute to the New York Office
description: I live in Bali, where our workshops are located, and I work in New York. Ive been known to make the 25-hour flight to Indonesia every month or so. Its probably the worlds longest commute.

title: Bargaining Down That CT Scan Is Suddenly Possible
description: Patrick Fontana twisted his left knee last spring while hitting a drive down the fairway on a golf course in Columbus, Ohio. But what really pained him was the $900 bill for diagnostic imaging ordered by his doctor.

title: Top Lawyer at WellPoint Is Selected as Next Chief
description: As pressures mount in Congress and the states for a larger government role in financing and regulating health care, WellPoint, the nations largest health insurer, has picked a lawyer and public policy specialist to become its next chief executive.

title: Gunmen Kill 3 French Sightseers on Road Near Saudi Holy City
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 26  Gunmen killed three French citizens and wounded a fourth near the holy city of Medina in Saudi Arabia early Monday, in a brazen reminder that attacks on foreigners there have not stopped despite an aggressive three-year security crackdown.

title: Met to Add Seven New Productions for 2007-8
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present seven new productions next season, the most since it moved into Lincoln Center in 1966, and intensify its campaign to make opera hot  or at least mildly picante in a media-saturated world.

title: Citigroup Has a C.F.O. Now What?
description: By hiring Gary L. Crittenden, Citigroup is hoping that a seasoned chief financial officer will bring the credibility and operational expertise needed to reverse the banks disappointing performance.

title: Viewer Numbers Increase a Bit for Oscars Show
description: Sunday nights telecast of the 79th annual Academy Awards on ABC posted some modest gains in ratings and audience totals over last years numbers, though the special continued to lag well behind the highest-rated editions of the ceremony.

title: Tantalized by the Hint of a Cure for Autism
description: If lightning strikes once, then why not again? This irrational logic will tempt the victims of any senseless tragedy to believe in miracles, or so Portia Iversen assures us by way of explaining her long, determined slog toward a miracle of her own. Whether she actually found one or not, readers will have to decide for themselves.

title: In Fallout After Blackout, State Agency Shares Blame
description: The chairwoman of the states Public Service Commission said yesterday that the agency bore some responsibility for the nine-day blackout that crippled western Queens last July, even though her staff had placed the blame for the loss of power squarely with Consolidated Edison.

title: Arizona: Special Courts Survive Challenge
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit by the Maricopa County prosecutor in Phoenix challenging the constitutionality of post-sentencing courts serving Spanish-speaking and Indian offenders of drunken-driving laws. The judge, Earl H. Carroll of Federal District Court, did not rule on the merits of the programs, which have for the past few years allowed participants to enter plea arrangements that provide them closer supervision from probation officers and access to drug treatment programs. Instead, Judge Carrolls decision was more technical, finding that the prosecutor, Andrew Thomas, the county attorney, who had denounced the courts as race-based, lacked sufficient legal standing to bring the case. A spokesman said Mr. Thomas would appeal.

title: Scientists Urge New Look at Feeding in AIDS Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26  Sometimes experience shows that seemingly logical solutions to a health problem are not as simple as they first appear.

title: Review Clears Bristol-Myers
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, has been cleared of securities law violations in connection with its botched Plavix patent settlement last year, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing.

title: Deal Reached on New York Workers Compensation
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced a deal today to overhaul the states workers compensation system, forging consensus in an area that had eluded Gov. George E. Patakis efforts for years.

title: In New Jersey, Districts Find Aid Increases Insufficient
description: Nearly half of the increased state aid that Gov. Jon S.
