Corzine promised for schools in his budget proposal last week will be eaten up by teachers benefits and school construction, and much of the remaining $300 million is earmarked for literacy and early childhood programs, education officials in New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Al Qaeda Is on the Move. Are We? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Strings Sampling Surprises From Haydn and Ligeti
description: Audacity sometimes appears where you least expect it. When the Cuarteto Casals, a young string quartet formed in Madrid in 1997, made its Carnegie Hall debut on Friday night at Weill Recital Hall, it seemed safe to assume that the boldest work on offer would be Ligetis String Quartet No. 1, a youthful creation by one of the 20th centurys most restless innovators.

title: Nordstrom Quarterly Earnings Up 22%
description: Nordstrom, the department store chain, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose by 22 percent, less than analysts estimated, on increased sales of womens clothes.

title: Fanciful in La Mancha: Cheeky Young Lovers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Much has been made in recent years of the Western look of todays Russian ballet dancers. They perform Balanchine, for one thing, with a light, quick attack that would once have been the antithesis of their larger-than-life classicism. Don Quixote, that robust, unwieldy 19th-century staple of the Bolshoi Ballet repertory, was a prime repository for Russian ballet dancing at its most powerful and vivid.

title: Knicks Get the Bounces and Beat Miami Again
description: Eddy Curry had another growth spurt last night  a powerful, rumbling explosion that blew back two of the games mightier icons. Stephon Marbury regained the look of an All-Star. Still, the Knicks needed the luckiest of lucky bounces to claim a major victory.

title: Rhode Island: Lead Paint Makers Appeal Rejected
description: A judge rejected a bid by three companies that manufactured lead paint to throw out a case in which they were found guilty last year of creating a public nuisance with their product and later ordered to clean up lead paint throughout the state. The judge, Michael Silverstein of Providence Superior Court, ordered the appointment of a special master to advise him on how to proceed with the cleanup and paint repairs. Judge Silverstein did not specify how much it might cost. The companies, Sherwin-Williams, NL Industries and Millennium Holdings, said they would appeal.

title: The Best After-Party? Sorry, Theres No Competition
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26  Long past midnight, Martin Scorsese stood in the center of the celebrity scrum at the Vanity Fair party here.

title: Memo Pad
description: HIGH FLYING More people are going abroad in style. International premium travel  that is, first-class and business-class flying  grew 4.3 percent last year compared with 2005, according to the International Air Transport Association. Premium travel on the trans-Atlantic routes, which represent 16.1 percent of international premium traffic (the biggest proportion when travel within Europe is not counted) rose 7.8 percent in December compared with December 2005, and rose an overall 3.5 percent for the year. Premium traffic on Europe to Asia routes and all routes to the Middle East continued to grow in double digits, said the group, which represents 250 world airlines. Worldwide there were about 2.1 billion passengers in 2006, and 10.5 percent of them flew premium classes, the group said.

title: New Jersey Moves to Join Early Presidential Primaries
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26  With a June primary that had become all but irrelevant, New Jersey would be romanced by presidential aspirants for its money  but rarely for its voters.

title: Knicks Crawford Likely Out for the Season
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 27  The Knicks quest for a playoff berth was dealt a major blow this morning when Jamal Crawford was found to have a stress fracture in his right ankle.

title: U.S. Displays Bomb Parts Said to Be Made in Iran
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26  In a dusty field near the Baghdad airport on Monday, the American military laid out a display of hundreds of components for assembling deadly roadside bombs, its latest effort to embarrass the country it contends is supplying the material to armed Shiite groups here: Iran.

title: Whats on Tuesday Night
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) TO IRAQ AND BACK: BOB WOODRUFF REPORTS On Jan. 29, 2006, only weeks after being named co-anchor of World News Tonight on ABC, Mr. Woodruff was seriously injured when a roadside bomb struck his convoy as he patrolled with United States troops near Taji, Iraq. In this special, his first on-air reporting since being wounded, Mr. Woodruff discusses his severe injuries and painstaking recovery, including his stay at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., and speaks with soldiers who have learned to carry on after their own life-altering injuries. Mr. Woodruffs wife, Lee, also discusses for the first time the gravity of her husbands medical condition and its impact on their family.

title: Kazaas Creators Do Latest Venture by the Book
description: Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis made names for themselves as renegade Internet entrepreneurs by taking conventional tasks like talking on the phone or listening to music and giving consumers an unconventional  and free  way to do it.

title: Red Sox Bring in a Friendly Face to Greet Matsui
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Feb. 26  Hideki Okajima was so eager to discuss coming duels with his old Yomiuri Giants teammate that he waved his hands and nodded his head as he spoke. Okajima, a newly recruited left-handed reliever for the Boston Red Sox, was using Japanese, his language, and a little body language to explain how he was looking forward to opposing the Yankees Hideki Matsui, his ally in Japan for eight seasons.

title: One Pianist, Two Sounds and a Single Composer
description: It may be that only 10 of Beethovens 32 piano sonatas have secure places in the standard repertory, but the rest are heard plentifully as well. Every few seasons, someone sweeps into town to play the full cycle. So a pianist offering an all-Beethoven series is inevitably caught between two opposing forces. One is the pressure to find something new to say about this familiar music. The other is to avoid sounding so desperate to say something new that the interpretations run off the rails.

title: It Seems the Fertility Clock Ticks for Men, Too
description: When it comes to fertility and the prospect of having normal babies, it has always been assumed that men have no biological clock  that unlike women, they can have it all, at any age.

title: Review Finds Drug Makers Issue More Positive Studies
description: Clinical trials sponsored by drug companies to look into the treatments of breast cancer are significantly more likely than independently financed studies to find that the treatments are effective, a new study finds. But the authors say the explanation may have little to do with bias.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Pianists Widower Admits Fraud in Recordings Issued as His Wifes
description: PARIS, Feb. 26  The widower of a much-praised but little-known British pianist has admitted passing off recordings by other pianists as those of his ailing wife to win her the recognition that poor health had denied her, according to Gramophone, a British magazine.

title: Demand for English Lessons Outstrips Supply
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  Two weeks after she moved here from her native Brazil, Maria de Oliveira signed up for free English classes at a squat storefront in this working-class suburb, figuring that with an associates degree and three years as an administrative assistant, she could find a good job in America so long as she spoke the language.

title: Child Health Care Splits White House and States
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Governors clashed with the White House on Monday over the future of the popular Childrens Health Insurance Program, an issue that some members of both parties said was as important as money for the Iraq war.

title: California Stem Cell Research Is Upheld by Appeals Court
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26  Californias stem cell research program is legal, a state appeals court ruled Monday in a decision that could hasten the day when the states $3 billion research effort can get fully under way.

title: Nostrums: Garlic Research Shows No Effect on Cholesterol
description: Although garlic and garlic supplements are widely promoted as cholesterol-lowering agents, a randomized study published Monday has found no evidence that garlic works any better than a placebo in reducing blood lipid concentrations.

title: Comparison Chart: Digital Cameras With Big Zoom Capabilities
Bargaining Down That CT Scan Is Suddenly Possible
description: Medical care is often priced with the same maddening, arbitrary opacity as airline seats and hotel rooms. The nations 850,000 providers negotiate prices with more than 6,000 health plans, resulting in differing rates for the same procedure. But consumers almost never get information on prices before treatment.

title: Two Kinds of Flesh
description: Frank Bruni offers his observations of the seductive scene at Robert's Steakhouse in the Penthouse Executive Club.

title: Coast Lines
description: For these up-and-coming mens-wear designers, Los Angeles and New York are more than just points of departure.

title: Polar Projects
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: NYSE Names New President
description: The NYSE Group said Monday that it had appointed Duncan L. Niederauer, currently a managing director at Goldman Sachs, president and co-chief operating officer effective April 9. Mr. Niederauer, who spent 22 years at Goldman Sachs, will be responsible for United States cash equities operations, including institutional and member firm client group sales and client services for both the New York Stock Exchange and its online securities exchange, NYSE Arca.

title: Live from Private Equitys Confab in Frankfurt
description: Talk about a big kickoff.

title: Video rsum Contest Proves the Importance of Being Earnest
description: The forces of good apparently are not as much fun as the forces of evil. That, at least, seemed to be the lesson learned from the winners of career web site Vault.coms Wall Street Video Resume Challenge for college students hoping to land a summer internship at a New York bank. The folks at Vault made it clear from the start that they werent holding a competition for the likes of Aleksey Vayner, the Yale student whose Impossible Is Nothing video resume became the butt of Wall Street jokes last fall.

title: In Mammoth L.B.O., Risk Just Got Riskier
description: There are risks in the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU, as there are in any large buyout, but for the Wall Street banks behind the deal, it could be even riskier, The New York Times notes. Wall Street banks have provided billions of dollars to finance takeovers in the last year, essentially serving as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms, which are among the banks best-paying customers. Now the lenders have created a new type of loan that has them ponying up part of the down payment on these deals as well.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about a court ruling that blocked Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, from unseating his vice president, Atiku Abubakar, misstated Mr. Abubakar's ethnic background. He is a Fulani from the Hausa-dominated north of the country, not a Hausa.

title: Kazaas Creators Do Latest Venture by the Book
description: Executives at Googles YouTube might want to take a page out of the playbook of Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis. This time, the duo behind the file-sharing service Kazaa and the Internet telephone service Skype are dotting their is and crossing their ts when it comes to their latest venture, the web video start-up Joost. Revenue-sharing agreements have been signed. Licenses have been granted.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about the strain on families and marriages created by prolonged military deployments referred incorrectly to the redeployment of 14,000 National Guard troops to Iraq next year. The Guard notified four states last month that units that had done previous tours in Iraq and Afghanistan could be designated to return to Iraq next year. The Pentagon did not announce plans to do so on Wednesday.

title: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
description: Microsofts drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Microsoft is buying Medstory, a small start-up in Foster City, Calif., for an undisclosed amount. Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.

title: Is Private Equity Ready For Its Close-Up?
description: David Bonderman, the founding partner of the Texas Pacific Group, opened todays Super Return 2007 private equity conference in Frankfurt with no hint of the coup his firm scored less than 48 hours earlier  helping to lead the largest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Elevation Founder Heads to Electronic Arts
description: Bono is losing one of his key players  but U2 fans can rest assured that its not the The Edge. John Riccitiello, who along with Bono and others, helped found the private equity firm Elevation Partners, is going back to his roots at indie video game publisher Electronic Arts.

title: Suit Against Ex-Citi Officers Is Dismissed
description: Two former Citigroup executives won dismissal on Monday of a lawsuit in which the government accused them of keeping tens of millions of dollars for the banks asset management arm that should have gone to reduce mutual fund fees. The Securities and Exchange Commission claimed that Thomas W. Jones, the former chief executive of Citigroup Asset Management and Lewis E. Daidone, the former vice president of Smith Barney Management, kept the savings from a contract they had renegotiated with First Data Investment Services.

title: S.E.C. Says Firm Traded on Information Stolen From Computers
description: An accounting firm in Hong Kong made $2.7 million from illegal insider trades by hacking into computers to view press releases before they were published, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Monday. The S.E.C. sued the company, Blue Bottle, a Hong Kong-chartered firm that says it is based in London, and its chief executive, Matthew Charles Stokes. Blue Bottle made $2.7 million by hacking into computer systems shortly before the release of market-moving information, the S.E.C. said in a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Halliburton to Complete Split With KBR
description: Halliburton, the oil field services provider, said on Monday that it would complete its separation from KBR by offering current stockholders the remaining 81 percent stake in KBR, its former subsidiary. Halliburton, once led by Vice President Dick Cheney, will offer its 135.6 million shares of KBR in exchange for its own stock. KBR is the largest American military contractor in Iraq. If the offer is not fully subscribed, any remaining KBR shares will be given to stockholders as a special dividend on a pro rata basis, Halliburton, which is based in Houston, said.

title: Smith & Wollensky Goes West Coast
description: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group said on Monday that it had agreed to be acquired by a Los Angeles restaurant group for $79.5 million. But fans of its New York flagship restaurant need not fear: Its properties in New York will remain in the hands of its founder. Smith & Wollensky said that it had agreed to be acquired by the Patina Group of Los Angeles, which operates restaurants in New York, New Jersey, California and Las Vegas, for $9.25 a share, a premium of 12 percent over its closing share price on Friday. The bid topped an offer of $7.50 a share made last month by Landrys Restaurants of Houston.

title: Tiffanys Polite Exchange With Nelson Peltz
description: Tiffany & Company said on Monday that it would consider suggestions on strategy from Trian Fund Management, the investment firm run by the activist investor Nelson Peltz. The companys stock price rose more than 5 percent, reaching a three-year high of $45.06.

title: Review Clears Bristol-Myers
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, has been cleared of securities law violations in connection with its botched Plavix patent settlement last year, the company said on Monday in a regulatory filing. The company said that it has been informed by the United States attorney in Newark, Christopher J. Christie, that a review found no violation of securities laws or breach of an earlier consent order the company had signed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Markets Fall
description: A stock sell-off in China was felt around the world.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about reactions in the campaigns of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton to remarks by David Geffen, a Hollywood executive who once supported the Clintons but now supports Mr. Obama, misstated the time and place of a gathering where Terry McAuliffe, a Clinton ally, jokingly told guests that contributors to Mrs. Clinton's campaign would be rewarded with limousine rides and ambassadorships. It was on Jan. 28, not "two weeks ago." The occasion was a party for the publication of a memoir by Mr. McAuliffe, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee  not a fund-raiser for Mrs. Clinton.

title: Volvo Revs Up Construction Business
description: Volvo said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy the road development division of Ingersoll-Rand for $1.3 billion in cash to expand its construction equipment business, particularly in the United States. Volvo, which also makes trucks, buses and engines, expects the acquisition to save it about 600 million Swedish kronor ($85.2 million)  mainly within sales and distribution  over five years, the company said. The transaction is due to be completed in the second quarter, subject to regulatory approval.

title: UBS Employee May Face Charges Over Tips to Hedge Funds,  Report Says
description: Federal authorities have uncovered a scheme in which at least one UBS employee was allegedly selling information about upcoming changes in analyst ratings on stocks to hedge fund traders, BusinessWeek reported. The report said that federal prosecutors in New York and securities regulators in Washington could file criminal and civil charges against a number of individuals as early as Tuesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Feb. 14 about an increase in the number of waivers granted to Army recruits with criminal backgrounds referred imprecisely to the crimes for which the Army grants the bulk of its "moral waivers." While they indeed include serious misdemeanors, they also include felonies such as aggravated assault, burglary, robbery and vehicular homicide. (The error was repeated in an editorial last Tuesday.)

title: Wal-Mart Inks Bounteous Deal in China
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the worlds biggest retailer, struck a deal reportedly worth $1 billion to take over a Chinese rival by 2010, challenging Carrefour as the largest operator of super-centers in booming China. Wal-Mart said it had bought 35 percent of Bounteous, a deal that could trigger consolidation in Chinas ferociously competitive $1 trillion retail market.

title: Citigroup Has a C.F.O. Now What?
description: Investors who were hoping that Citigroups appointment of Gary L. Crittenden to the post of chief financial officer was a signal that the financial services giant was considering a sale or spin-off of some of its parts may be disappointed. The New York Times notes that while Citigroups chairman and chief, Charles O. Prince III, is using his new hire to shore up investor support for himself, the appointment is not expected to produce startling change or immediate results.

title: Icahn Goes Wireless With $50 Million
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier, has invested $50 million in a wireless content startup, Motricity. Motricity, which announced in August it plans to raise $75 million from investors, said it has completed the equity funding agreement with Mr. Icahn through an affiliated company. Mr. Icahns son, Brett Icahn, an investment analyst with New York-based Icahn Associates and a number of affiliated companies, will join Motricitys board of directors as a result of the investment.

title: Mace Says Bidder Needs to Dig Deeper into the Pocketbook
description: Mace Security International said on Monday that it had rejected a $3-a-share buyout offer from Kelly Capital Management but was holding talks for a possible higher offer from the investment firm. Mace asked investors for patience, saying that once its car-wash chain was liquidated, Mace would be in an ideal position to grow its security business, or pursue other opportunities. In recent years, Mace has tried to grow its surveillance and security businesses, which include the Mace pepper spray. The security business generates about $23.5 million a year in sales.

title: Grease Car Makes Pit Stop
description: A vehicle carrying the Danny Zuko and Sandy Olsson of a Dutch production of the musical "Grease" wound up in the orchestra pit during a performance on Sunday night in Almere, nine miles east of Amsterdam, The Associated Press reported.

title: Cruise Nears Financing Pact With Merrill for United Artists
description: Wall Street may be ready to show Tom Cruise the money.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some editions on Saturday with an article about a new screening device being tested at airports incorrectly described an X-ray image from the machine. The image of a woman showed what a scan from the device looked like before software was installed to hide body contours  not after the software was applied. (An X-ray on the front page did show a software-modified image of a man's body.)

title: Street Fighters: Paris Fashion
description: After the haute finesse and futurism of the last two seasons, Balenciaga this morning was like a rumble in the streets. Nicolas Ghesquieres fall look is a close-fitting preppy or British school blazer, in a solid or with a band of color around the edge, and slim, low-riding cargo pants. The other key look is a loose-fitting chemise done in a mlange of prints and fabrics, including velvet and silk, with metallic fringe sometimes worked into the patchwork. Stiletto sandals were made of plastic components in primary colors that resembled athletic shoes, even elements of snowboard bindings. The overall impression was cool and young. It certainly recalls the street energy of Ghesquieres early Balenciaga collections, yet it falls short of the design direction we expect from him.

title: For Travelers, a New Name and a Classic Image
description: Red umbrella in hand, St. Paul Travelers has officially changed identities. The St. Paul-based insurer announced Monday that it would begin trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange under its new name, The Travelers Cos., and under a new ticker symbol. The firm also closed on its previously announced agreement to reacquire the red umbrella trademark from Citigroup.

title: $40.6 Million in Pay for Lehmans Chief
description: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the brokerage firm Lehman Brothers Holdings, made $40.6 million in compensation last year after the company reported near-record profits, according to a regulatory filing on Monday. Mr. Fuld made a salary of $750,000 and a bonus of $6.24 million, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 17 about conservative opposition to Senator John McCain of Arizona in his home state referred imprecisely to his position on a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. While he has indeed supported a state constitutional ban, he has opposed a federal amendment.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The This Land column on Sunday, about an experiment with alternative currency called BerkShares, in Berkshire County, Mass., reversed the identities of people depicted on the five BerkShare and the ten BerkShare. Robyn Van En, champion of community-supported agriculture projects, is on the ten; W.E.B. Dubois, the civil rights pioneer, is on the five.

title: A Wharton Dean Is Named to Lead the Conference Board
description: The Conference Board, a business research and consulting group that publishes some of the nations leading economic surveys, has selected Jonathan Spector, a vice dean at the Wharton School, as its chief executive. Mr. Spector, 50, will succeed Richard E. Cavanagh, former executive dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who has led the group since 1995. Mr. Cavanaugh announced last March that he was retiring. The selection of Mr. Spector, which is to be announced Monday by the Conference Boards trustees, came after a yearlong search in which about 250 candidates were evaluated.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Tuesday about Kirsten Gillibrand, a freshman Democratic congresswoman from New York, misstated the surname of a constituent who confronted her about her stance on the Iraq war. He is Dave Bronner, not Browner. Because of an editing error, a capsule biography of Ms. Gillibrand referred erroneously to her husband, Jonathan. He is a financial consultant, but not also a lobbyist. It also misstated part of the name of Ms. Gillibrand's former law firm. It is Boies, Schiller & Flexner  not Boise.

title: Spoken Word Performance
description: The Bagger had lunch with director James Toback for three hours at the Polo Lounge in the Beverly Hills Hotel. Of course, the Bagger is an absolutely fascinating lunch date, but he had the feeling that Mr. Toback was also avoiding work on his latest screenplay. In any case, the guy is a living repository of Hollywood lore, complete with the wiseguy accents and impossibly dark tales. It was L.A. in full cry and that was before Warren Beatty dropped by the table to say hello.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about movie theaters in Spain that also serve as video game arcades misidentified the maker of Pro Evolution Soccer, a video game for which a theater is organizing tournaments. It is Konami, not Electronic Arts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about the season-opening game for the Duke lacrosse team, misstated the New Jersey hometown of a former player. It is Essex Fells, not Essex Falls.

title: Photographs
description: Images from the Yeshiva University Museums exhibition And I Still See Their Faces.

title: Dont Believe the Hype
description: Reuters asks whether the millions and millions of dollars spent on Oscar campaigning actually went down a rat hole.

title: Party Pooped
description: Anne Thompson of the Hollywood Reporter was so busy doing real work that, wiped out, she skipped the parties afterwards. The Bagger could suggest that her priorities out of whack, but then again he spent an hour at three a.m. trying to get his car out of a park lot that had shuttered for the night. The events may have been pretty, but the aftermath was not.

title: Dont Hold Your Breath on a Blackstone I.P.O.
description: In the fierce competition between the giant private equity firms Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Blackstones Stephen Schwarzman appears to have ceded at least one piece of ground to his rival.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column yesterday, about performances by Michel Legrand at Birdland, misstated the dates. They are March 6 through March 11, not March 11 through 16.

title: Soho West
description: Defamer went to the Oscar Soho House so you didnt have to. You arent fabulous or vacuous enough to get in anyway. The Bagger gets skeeved out when he goes to the one in Manhattan  it seems like the kind of club they built to get away from people like him  so he wasnt exactly trying to bust the door at the West Coast version.

title: Deaths in Custody: Excited Delirium or Excessive Force?
description: For more than a decade now, a controversial malady known as excited delirium has been bandied about in police departments.

title: As If
description: The Bagger just saw David Letterman of all people making fun of the quality and length of the Oscars. While the thrill of watching his own faceplant was missing this year, the show had its moments. TrailerSpy has some nifty clips of the night.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the 400th anniversary of the premiere of Monteverdi's opera "L'Orfeo" misstated the dates of two of his later works. "Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria" was first performed in 1640, not 1540, and "L'incoronazione di Poppea" in 1643, not 1543.

title: Ellen DeGeneres: Piata
description: Every year, the day after, people talk about how miserable the broadcast was. Whacking the Oscars is like hunting baby doe on a game farm. But you know what? The Bagger saw some of the show in between reporting and he thought Ellen DeGeneres did a wonderful job. It is one of the toughest gigs in show biz. It flattened David Letterman, who is not exactly a dummy when it comes to working a room. And please, sorry it did not touch the shimmering comic brilliance of Billy Crystals braying fake show tunes. Yeah, the Bagger could have done without the Pilobolus interludes, but then he has issues with interpretive dance.

title: End Game
description: Today, the Oscarator will heave and buck, throwing the Bagger clear somewhere near LAX, where, if his luck holds, hell be able to hail a flight back to Jersey. (Please, guy with arms like hams , take another flight.)

title: J.P. Morgan Banker to Head to Treasury, Report Says
description: Another seasoned banker is set to leave Wall Street for Washington. The Bush administration will soon announce that Tim Ryan, a J.P. Morgan Chase vice chairman, will be the Treasury departments next under-secretary for international affairs, The Financial Times reported Tuesday. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Ryan, who currently serves as the banks vice chairman of financial institutions and governments, will replace Tim Adams, who announced his desire to retire by the summer.

title: Will Iowa Now Turn to Edwards?
Talking About Green (the Other Kind)
description: And I want to say, God bless this takeover of TXU by the private equity market this week.

title: Pouring Cold Water on a Hot Question
description: Al Gores extended moment in the spotlight at the Oscars on Sunday didnt end with his thanking the academy for honoring An Inconvenient Truth. Backstage later, reporters kept addressing him as Mr. President. (I was president of the Senate, so its not improper, he said.)

title: Still Fund-Raiser in Chief
description: With the presidential cycle in full swing, some pundits have suggested that President Bush is no longer relevant. But Mr. Bush remains a powerful force when it comes to raising money for his party, as he showed last night, when he helped rake in $10.4 million at an annual fund-raising gala for Republican governors.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Two big events coming up on the presidential campaign circuit, one interesting for who is there, and the other for who is not.

title: 2008: Romneys Strategy Memo
description: Scott Helman of The Boston Globe got his hands on a 77-page PowerPoint presentation about Mitt Romneys campaign strategy. They include concerns that his hair looks too perfect, hes not a tough war time leader, and he has earned a reputation as Slick Dancing Mitt or Flip-Flop Mitt.

title: Fund-Raising at Full Bore
description: For candidates, the time of staged introductions (think Barack Obama in Springfield, Ill.; Mitt Romney in Dearborn, Mich.; Hillary Rodham Clinton on the Internet; Rudolph W. Giuliani, sort of everywhere) is over, and the serious business of the early phase of running for president, raising money, is at full tilt.

title: Needed: A Law on Bundling
description: The Washington Post editorial page is pleased that Hillary Clinton has decided that her presidential campaign will reveal the identities of its major fundraisers, after all, by disclosing the names of her bundlers, the individuals who collect six- and seven-figure sums for political campaigns by delivering scores of smaller checks from donors.

title: $675,000 Homes
description: Condos in Bradenton Beach, Fla., and Chicago and a Spanish-style golf home in Klamath Falls, Ore.

title: In Search of Carrie Bradshaw
description: New Yorkers, brace yourselves for the Eurofans.

title: More From Francis M. Naumann Fine Art
description: More images from the show that includes a portrait of the art historian Robert Rosenblum, posing as Ingress 1826 portrait of the Comte de Pastoret, now at Francis M. Naumann Fine Art.

title: Wholl Stop The Rain?
description: Thats the song playing over the public-address system at Legends Field right now. Theres snow on the ground in the Northeast (I know, I spent a long weekend at home), but be assured its not paradise here, either. The Yankees just came hustling off the field when it started pouring.

title: Workers Comp Deal Expected
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, legislative leaders and representatives from the business and labor community are holding a press conference at 1 p.m. and are expected to announce a deal to overhaul the workers compensation system. This is an issue that Albany has tried to address before, but the governor made it an early priority of his administration.

title: North Carolina Bank Company Acquires a Rival
description: LSB Bancshares, a North Carolina bank holding company, said it had agreed to buy a rival, the FNB Financial Services Corporation, for about $124.8 million in stock. FNB shareholders will get 1.07 LSB common shares for each FNB share held, which offers a premium of about 18.6 percent to FNB shareholders based on the companies closing prices on Monday.

title: Freddie Mac Toughens Policy on Risky Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Mortgage finance giant Freddie Mac said Tuesday it would no longer buy high-risk home mortgages that it deems to be highly vulnerable to foreclosure, in a surprise move that came amid a deteriorating market for subprime loans affected by slumping home prices and rising interest rates

title: After China Move, Is Wal-Mart Eyeing Russia Next?
description: On the tail of a landmark deal with a Chinese retailer, Wal-Mart may be trying to sew up a prominent position in another emerging market. Reuters reported Tuesday that the retail giant is in talks with Karusel, a Russian hypermarket chain. A source that was not named told Reuters that an investment bank retained by Karusel, which opened 13 hypermarkets last year, has been holding talks with Wal-Mart.

title: The (Potential) Rise of Silicon Alley 2.0
description: Unlike the last Internet boom, entrepreneurs in Silicon Alley, New Yorks venture-capital community, is filled with older, more experienced entrepreneurs who focus more on long-term profits. Internet heavyweights like Google have opened up ambitious new offices in the Big Apple. But some things never change, according to The New York Suns Jay Akasie: Just like in the olden days, Silicon Alley still takes a distant second to the West Coast.

title: When Trolls Attack
description: Giant German director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck attacked by pasty faced troll  survives and goes on to win best foreign film for The Lives of Others.

title: Mountain Man of the World
description: Im back in New York after a wonderful week in Napa Valley, but while there I was sad to learn of the death of our dear friend Gordon Wright, a longtime Alaskan who founded the Arctic Chamber Orchestra, which traveled far and wide across the Arctic Circle to spread the joys of live classical music.

title: Rest for Abreu
description: Bobby Abreu met with reporters this morning and said he would basically be idle for two weeks. The pulled oblique muscle on his right side leaves him limited to treatment in the trainers room and no baseball activity.

title: What Keeps Buyout Bigwigs Up at Night
description: Private equity chiefs are used to making daring, debt-heavy bets that would cause other investors to go pale. So what strikes fear into the hearts of a buyout veteran?

title: CSTV
description: An ad for CSTV.com.

title: CSTV, Ad 2
description: An ad for CSTV.com.

title: CSTV, Ad 3
description: An ad for CSTV.com.

title: CSTV, Ad 4
description: An ad for CSTV.com.

title: CSTV, Ad 5
description: An ad for CSTV.com.

title: Bloomberg on the Rats
description: The city Department of Investigation has gotten involved in the infamous rats episode last week at a KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village. The fast-food place had passed a city inspecton the day before the disturbing-yet-fascinating video was shot.

title: Were From the Government. Were Here to Help
description: Many business leaders have complained about the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other measures passed in reaction to the scandals at Enron and WorldCom. Advocates for these reforms say they were needed to cut down on corporate fraud, but critics argue that they created onerous costs for companies and new risks  not the least of which is the potential for being sent to prison  for their executives.

title: Out of Sight
description: The Bagger has gone to his happy place, the smoking cage at LAX. The muse comes quickly here  at least it had better, the flight leaves in 22 minutes.

title: Weill: Citi Breakup Is a Crazy Idea
description: The people who are calling for a breakup of Citigroup are off their mind, the banking giants chairman emeritus Sanford I. Weill said on CNBC Monday. (That was actually a fairly mellow reaction, considering that, when Barrons suggested the notion of a breakup to Citigroup chief executive Charles Prince last summer, Mr. Prince called it the dumbest idea Ive ever heard of.)

title: All In Stride
description: After a captivating scoreless, no-hit tie in todays two-and-a-half inning intrasquad game, Willie Randolph asked his team to practice their inside-the-park homers. He picked arguably the fastest guy in the organization, Carlos Gomez  not Jose Reyes  to lead off. Gomez zipped around the bases, sliding home with a flourish, and popped up from the dirt to find his teammates gone.

title: The Downside of Using the Best: A SuperMadam Tells All
description: Readers may or may not recall Jody Babydol Gibson, but she is arguably Hollywoods second-most famous madam, second only in repute to one Heidi Fleiss, who earned the title of the Hollywood Madam upon her arrest in 1993.

title: Blink Shot
description: Ive written in The Times about Canons cutting-edge digital camera software. Its face-recognition software, already in some current models, calculates focus and exposure based on faces in your scene. But Canon is also working on a next-generation feature called Blink Shot that wont take the picture until everybodys eyes are open. (Its also got Smile Shot in the works; Im sure you can figure out what that one does.)

title: Edwards on the Truth
description: Former Senator John Edwards ventured onto Hillary Rodham Clintons home turf today with a speech that drove home the liberal themes that he has been using to distinguish himself from the New York Senator.

title: V.C. Firms Rumble over Web Sites
description: What do venture capitalists do with the time they are saving from their lack of exits? In the case of Sequoia Capital and ComVentures, they scrutinize eachothers corporate Web sites and end up in court over them.

title: Caremark in Mergerland
description: Delaware Chancellor (that is, judge) William Chandler has put into words what some people may have been vaguely thinking about the proposed merger of drugstore chain CVS and pharmacy benefits manager Caremark. He apparently thinks it is a bit like Through the Looking Glass  and specifically the chapter on Humpty Dumpty.

title: Violent Endings, Far From Home
description: Its not been a great month for global tourism. As BBC News reports, officials are trying to make sense of the killing of two Russian women who were shot dead while reclining in deck chairs on a beach in the southern resort city of Pattaya, Thailand, one of the countrys major tourist centers.

title: Quick Bread
description: Dining columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes wholesome quick bread.

title: And the Winner Is No One
description: The Veterans Committee has spoken and elected no one to the Hall of Fame, again.

title: Eliots Domain Dispute
description: A reader who says he is Eric Keller, the registered owner of the Web domains eliotspitzer.com and eliotspitzer.org, has posted some correspondence about a dispute he is having with the Spitzer administration over control of the two domains.

title: Clintons Gore Card on Environment
description: In only 20 minutes or so, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hit an impressive array of high notes. She was speaking, mainly, to convey her capacity for big, serious ideas contained in her new clean energy bill (more on that later). But she also:

title: Alley Oop
description: So lets score this big new bid by the National Basketball Association to get in on the YouTube action.

title: Amphibian Cataclysm: A Clarification
description: So, following up on our post from last week regarding the potentially bleak future facing the globes amphibians, we heard from the organizer of the Amphibian Ark project, Dr. Joe Mendelson, who wanted to fine-tune  and in once case, flat-out correct  a couple of points made in that earlier post.

title: The Workers Comp Deal
description: A plan to overhaul New Yorks workers compensation system eluded Gov. George E. Pataki for years, but today, at the end of his second month in office, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced he had reached an agreement with legislative, business and labor leaders.

title: Blogtalk
description: Comptroller DiNapolis ethics policy. [The Daily Politics]

title: Blogtalk: The Hair Memo
description: Leaked campaign memos are nothing new in politics  a secret strategy paper by Rudy Guilianis staff caused a stir earlier this year. So when a 77-slide PowerPoint presentation by Mitt Romneys staff outlining their concerns was reported today by The Boston Globe, bloggers did not seem surprised at the leak itself, but rather at what the leak revealed.

title: Records Made to Be Broken
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar picks out his best career moments, and explains why he remains the N.B.A.'s highest scorer.

title: On Being Muslim in America
description: Raised a Catholic, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar says his conversion to Islam was spiritual, not political.

title: Importance of Black History
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar believes achievements by people of color have been overlooked in America.

title: Globalization of the N.B.A.
description: Why is basketball so popular globally? Kareem Abdul-Jabbar says it is more exciting and accessible than other sports.

title: Generation of Spoiled Kids?
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar says many N.B.A. players lack maturity because they did not attend college.

title: Intrasquad Round-Up
description: Didnt mean to tease everyone by mentioning the intrasquad game without giving a result. The Yogis beat the Reggies, 5-1. Igawa pitched two scoreless innings for Yogis squad, surviving a bunt single by the speedy Brett Gardner on the first pitch of the game.

title: Spitzer Cuts Budget Request by Panel That Polices Judges
description: There is growing agreement in Albany that New York States town and village courts are in need of help after decades of neglect, meager financing and inadequate training of the justices, many of whom do not even have a high-school diploma.

title: The Things They Left Behind: Photographs From Polands Lost Jews
description: They are exquisitely ordinary family snapshots: six young men and women on the beach, playfully arranged in a pyramid; a bourgeois family flaunting its Sabbath best of fur-lined topcoats and rakishly angled hats; a dark-haired Orthodox mother with an infant cradled in her arms and her five children, three barefoot, lined up stiffly in front of a tumbledown shack.

title: Panel Finds Flawed Data in a Major Stem Cell Report
description: An inquiry panel has found what it called significantly flawed data in a major stem cell paper published in Nature in 2002.

title: Officials Welcome U.S. Move to Join Iran in Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Lee H. Hamilton, co-chairman of the Iraq Study Group, said today that he welcomed the Bush administrations decision to attend meetings about Iraq that will include Iran and Syria, noting that it reflected a huge change in the White Houses approach but that American diplomats would need to be patient to sustain the new effort.

title: Manhattan: Accountant Charged With Stealing $4 Million
description: An accountant for three Manhattan mens clothing companies was charged yesterday with stealing more than $4 million from the businesses, prosecutors said. The accountant, Stephen Schorr, 46, of East 90th Street, was charged with grand larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Prosecutors said Mr. Schorr stole the money from the companies  Andre Romanelli Inc., Andre Romanelli International Inc. and Van Giles International Inc.  from 2000 to 2004. Mr. Schorr has pleaded not guilty.

title: New Republics Editor in Chief Sells His Share of the Magazine
description: Martin Peretz, who has been a part owner of The New Republic for more than three decades, has given up his share of the magazine, selling his interest to CanWest Global Communications, which now assumes full control. Mr. Peretz is to remain as editor in chief.

title: C. T. Oliver, 93, Envoy and Professor, Dies
description: Covey T. Oliver, a former assistant secretary of state, ambassador to Colombia and a professor of international law, died Thursday at his home near Easton, Md. He was 93.

title: Battle in Maine Pits Lobstermen Against Fishermen
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 27  For decades, two groups of Maine fishermen, its trawler captains and its lobstermen, harvested the ocean floor in relative harmony. The trawlers netted cod, haddock and other so-called groundfish. Lobster boats trapped Maines best-known delicacy.

title: Deal in Albany Overhauls Pay for Worker Aid
description: After years of stalemates and false starts, New York leaders yesterday announced a far-reaching deal to overhaul the states much-criticized workers compensation system by significantly increasing the weekly benefits that go to injured workers while cracking down on employers who cheat the system.

title: John Galliano Kicks Up His Heels
description: PARIS, Feb. 27  We should always ask ourselves when looking at the new fashion of a first-rate designer if these are clothes we want to wear on the street. If the answer is an enthusiastic yes, then the designer has not done his job. All he has done is to meet the most meager of our expectations.

title: City Opera Lures Director From Paris
description: Gerard Mortier, an iconoclastic impresario and one of the opera worlds premier provocateurs, will become general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera in 2009.

title: Dow Average Falls 416 Points After China Sell-Off
description: Stocks in the United States plummeted today after a surprising plunge in the Shanghai market provoked worries worldwide about the global economy and the valuation of share prices.

title: The Good, the Bad and Those Truly French
description: Marion Cotillards feral portrait of the French singer dith Piaf as a captive wild animal hurling herself at the bars of her cage is the most astonishing immersion of one performer into the body and soul of another Ive ever encountered in a film. Her portrayal of Piaf, plucked from the streets of Paris and molded into a music hall legend, ignites Olivier Dahans screen biography La Vie en Rose, which opens the Film Society of Lincoln Centers annual Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series this evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: A CBS Take on the YouTube Madness
description: WITH March coming in tomorrow, the March Madness days of college basketball are not far away. A division of CBS is hoping to intensify the mania by offering students and other fans a chance to create exuberant, exhortatory video clips and share them with friends, family and strangers  and use them, not incidentally, to taunt anyone who roots for opposing teams.

title: Two Soccer Pioneers End Journey at the Hall of Fame
description: Girls rule.

title: Brooklyn: Fire Violations Shut Factory
description: Fire officials shut down a garment factory on 60th Street near 12th Avenue in Borough Park yesterday, ordering about 15 workers to leave because of safety hazards posed by piles of cloth and other materials in the basement and insufficient access to the exits. A Buildings Department official said citations were issued to the factory owners for blocked exits, prior construction on the premises without a permit and illegal occupancy.

title: Four Visionaries With Cloudy Visions
description: The story of how Nixon came to meet Mao in 1972 has been told by journalists, historians and many of the principals themselves. It has been memorialized in film and mythologized as opera. Nixon to China must be one of the most widely understood terms of art in politics and diplomacy.

title: Cablevision Posts Loss and Stays Silent on Future of Programming Unit
description: New York sports fans have asked the question all season: What are the Dolans thinking? Now its Wall Streets turn again.

title: Italy: Island Volcano Spews Lava
description: Eruptions from a volcano on Stromboli have strengthened to the point that emergency procedures to protect the islands 750 residents have been put in place. Civil defense officials say the measures are, at this point, precautionary. But lava has begun flowing into the sea, and two new craters have appeared at the summit of the volcano, active for the last 2,000 years. An eruption in 2002 caused a small tsunami and closed the island, north of Sicily, to tourists for months.

title: Jailers Testify About Padillas Confinement
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27  As Jose Padilla dropped his head and grew still, a senior official from the naval brig in Charleston, S.C., testified on Tuesday in federal court here that he had twice observed Mr. Padilla weeping in the electronically monitored cell where the military detained him for three years and eight months.

title: State Trooper Is Charged With Vehicular Homicide
description: A state trooper whose patrol car slammed into a minivan last September in southern New Jersey, killing two teenage sisters on their way home from buying milk, was charged yesterday with two counts of vehicular homicide, the authorities said.

title: Senegal: Incumbent on Course for Second Term
description: Preliminary results of the presidential election on Sunday announced on public and private radio appeared to give the octogenarian incumbent, Abdoulaye Wade, a solid majority that would allow him to avoid a runoff. A runoff would be required if none of the 15 candidates won more than 50 percent. A spokeswoman for the candidate of the Socialist Party, which governed for four decades until Mr. Wades election in 2000, said it planned to contest the results.

title: Films With Black Stars Seek to Break International Barriers
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27  When Jennifer Hudson, Beyonc Knowles, Anika Noni Rose and company blasted their way through three Dreamgirls songs on Sundays Academy Awards broadcast, they also had a message for the millions watching around the world:

title: Legal Fight to Decide Whether to Free Man in 94 Killing
description: One night in February 13 years ago, outside a sports bar in Yonkers, a college student was stabbed to death during a brawl between rival Albanian and Italian gang members, some with mob ties.

title: As Ethics Panels Expand Grip, No Field Is Off Limits
description: Ever since the gross mistreatment of poor black men in the Tuskegee Syphilis Study came to light three decades ago, the federal government has required ethics panels to protect people from being used as human lab rats in biomedical studies. Yet now, faculty and graduate students across the country increasingly complain that these panels have spun out of control, curtailing academic freedom and interfering with research in history, English and other subjects that poses virtually no danger to anyone.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: One Night Only. Gingrich vs. Cuomo in Elevated Discourse.
description: On Feb. 27, 1860, a large and enthusiastic assemblage of 1,500 or so actually paid to hear a relatively obscure and recently defeated United States Senate candidate from the Midwest audition for the presidency.

title: Wal-Mart Buys Stake in Retail Chain to Gain Stronger Presence in China
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 27  With growth slowing at its outlets in the United States and its stock price slumping, Wal-Mart Stores is aiming to gain greater access to the worlds most rapidly growing major economy by buying into one of Chinas biggest retailers.

title: Romney Pushes Turnout in Conservative Straw Poll
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The straw poll at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference beginning here on Thursday has never played a pivotal role in a Republican presidential primary. But the Mitt Romney campaign nonetheless is paying for three buses, scores of registration fees and at least a half-dozen hotel rooms to pack collegiate supporters into the event.

title: Scandal at Siemens Tarnishes Promising Results
description: MUNICH, Feb. 27  Klaus Kleinfelds office here is dominated by a photograph of a storm-tossed sea off Iceland. Mr. Kleinfeld relishes the churning image, he said, though as counterpoint, he has hung a soothing watercolor with pink blossoms on another wall.

title: Saving Radio in the Satellite Era
description: RADIO is our most intimate medium  it wakes us in the morning, follows us into the shower, accompanies us during commutes and becomes a lifeline in emergencies. But radio is struggling to attract and retain an audience.

title: Voices From Gritty Side of Film and TV
description: Two days after the Academy Awards, as many boldface names still basked in glory, some of their way-behind-the-scenes colleagues testified at a forum in Midtown Manhattan about life in the real world of film and television.

title: Wall St. Tumble Adds to Worries About Economies
description: Stock markets around the world plummeted yesterday in a wave of selling set off by a plunge in China that was reinforced by worries of weakening economies. The falling prices continued in early Asian trading today, but by midday the Chinese market seemed to be stabilizing.

title: Global Markets Fall Again on Fears About U.S. Economy
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 28  Stock markets fell sharply across most of Asia again today and continued to decline in Europe as investors worried about weakness in the American economy.

title: California: Immigration Seen Raising Worker Pay
description: The huge influx of immigrant workers to California since 1990 generated a 4 percent increase in the wages of the average American worker in the state, according to a study by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. American workers moved into higher-paying jobs as immigrants filled low-skilled occupations, concluded the study by Giovanni Peri of the University of California, Davis. The study also found no evidence that immigrants arriving after 1960 had displaced American workers with the same education in the states job market.

title: Ozone Man Sequel
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: China: Premier Rules Out Democratic Reform in Near Future
description: In comments published by state news media less than a week before the annual parliamentary session is to open, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao ruled out any plan for more democracy in the near future as the country focuses on economic and social development. He said that while China was committed to political reform, progress toward democracy would be difficult because the economic, political and legal systems were still immature.

title: Albany: State Reverses Housing Decision for Tenants With H.I.V.
description: David A. Hansell, the new state commissioner of temporary and disability assistance, yesterday reversed a decision by the Pataki administration that required about 2,200 poor adults in New York City who live in government-subsidized housing and have H.I.V. or AIDS to pay more of their income toward rent. The tenants, who had been paying rent amounting to 30 percent of their income from federal benefits, were required as of Nov. 1 to pay all but $330 each month toward rent, but Housing Works, an AIDS advocacy group, won an injunction blocking the change from taking effect.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a newly elected New York City Council member, Dr. Mathieu Eugene, whose eligibility to serve is in dispute because he did not live in his district on the day of the election gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of an election lawyer who said courts have interpreted state election law to mean that residency must be established as of the day of the election. He is Jerry H. Goldfeder, not Goldfelder. The article also gave an erroneous middle initial in some copies for a former chairman of the city bars election law committee who agreed with Mr. Goldfeder. He is Henry T. Berger, not Henry J.

title: Plan for Airbus Includes Job Cuts
description: MUNICH, Feb. 27  Some information about the revamping plans for Airbus, the beleaguered European aircraft company, began to trickle out on Tuesday.

title: Where Only the Salad Is Properly Dressed
description: IT may be laughable when someone says he gets Penthouse magazine for the articles. Its no joke when I say I went to the Penthouse Executive Club for the steaks.

title: New General Manager at New York City Opera
description: Gerard Mortier, one of the opera worlds pre-eminent modernizers, who made his mark over a quarter century with sometimes shocking, up-to-the-minute productions, will become general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera in 2009.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a soda company contest with clues that led players to the Granary Burying Ground in Boston misidentified a patriot buried there. He is Samuel Adams  not John Adams, who is buried at United First Parish Church in Quincy, Mass.

title: A Loner Wanders Junior High, as a Lion Strays on Campus
description: The moment at the dawn of adolescence when hormones and daydreams swirl into a heady fog of confusion and longing is poetically evoked in Cam Archers film Wild Tigers I Have Known. A surreal, fragmented masturbatory fantasy whose vision of adolescence borrows elements from Elephant, Tarnation, Mysterious Skin and Donnie Darko, the movie dives into the consciousness of Logan (Malcolm Stumpf), a lonely 13-year-old junior high school student who lives with his hard-bitten single mother (Fairuza Balk). When a mountain lion strays onto his school campus and is shot, Logan identifies with the animal as much as he fears it and connects the beast with his sexual curiosity, dread and deepening sense of alienation.

title: Outsource the Cabinet?
description: Yes, its true, a picture is worth a thousand words  but some are worth a whole dictionary. I came across one the other day on BBC.com. The story was headlined Israeli Minister in Vision Gaffe.

title: Veterans' Hall of Fame Vote May Be Subject to Change
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27  The members of the veterans committee of the Baseball Hall of Fame are filling out their ballots. The problem is that they are not voting for enough of the same candidates. The results of their latest election were the same as their previous two: no one made the cut.

title: Music Chief at EMI to Join Sony Venture
description: Martin Bandier, the chairman and co-chief executive of EMI Groups EMI Music Publishing unit, will take the reins of the music-publishing unit at the rival Sony Corporation after his EMI contract expires at the end of next month.

title: Toyota to Build $1.3 Billion Plant in the Land of Elvis
description: Toyota, the Japanese automaker, said yesterday that it would invest $1.3 billion to build its eighth North American assembly plant in Blue Springs, Miss., just outside Tupelo in northeastern Mississippi.

title: Divided Congress Prepares to Debate Financing and Strategy for Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The Democratic-controlled Congress began a five-week struggle on Tuesday over the financing of the war in Iraq and the overall mission there. Though the Democrats are divided over strategy and stymied by ideological divisions, they still hope to step up pressure on the White House to change the course of the war.

title: New United Nations Chief Tackles the Agencys Tradition of Patronage Jobs
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 27  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is installing tough new requirements for hundreds of jobs at the United Nations that he hopes will begin to dispel the reputation for inaction and bloat that has long dogged the institution, according to officials in his office.

title: Search for Safe Haven Raises Bond Prices
description: Treasuries posted their biggest gains yesterday since December 2004 as a rout in global stocks and bonds bolstered demand for what is regarded as the safest debt.

title: Canada: Profit Down at Auto Parts Maker
description: Magna International, the Canadian auto parts maker, said that fourth-quarter profit fell 65 percent because of lower profit margins and one-time charges. It cut its quarterly dividend to increase cash on hand. Net income was $29 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $83 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier, Magna said. Sales rose 8.7 percent, to $6.4 billion. The company, cut its quarterly divided in half, to 19 cents a share, adding $84 million in cash to the $1.9 billion the company had on hand at the end of 2006. Excluding one-time items, Magna earned 99 cents a share, missing the $1.16 a share that was expected by Wall Street analysts.

title: 3 Teenagers Are Accused of Raping Girl, 13, at School
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y., Feb. 27  Three teenagers were arraigned in court here on Tuesday on charges that they gang raped a 13-year-old classmate at a school for troubled students.

title: Recipe: Georgia Cracker Salad
description: Adapted from "The Lady & Sons Savannah Country Cookbook," by Paula H. Deen (Random House, 1998)

title: Manhattan: Officials Call for Reimbursement for Military Service
description: Since 2001, 1,832 city workers have been deployed for military service in Iraq and Afghanistan and collectively missed more than 600,000 days of work, at a net cost to New York City taxpayers of $57.1 million, according to a report released yesterday by Representative Anthony D. Weiner of Queens and City Councilman Michael E. McMahon of Staten Island. Police officers and firefighters have missed 350,000 days of work at a net cost to the city of $43.4 million, they said, adding that the federal government should reimburse the city for that sum because emergency services are essential. City workers are required to return the lesser of their military or their city pay  which continues during deployment  on returning to their jobs.

title: The Intersection of Retail and High Finance
description: Among storied New York buildings, the old J. P. Morgan headquarters at the corner of Wall and Broad Streets, encompassing 23 Wall Street and 15 Broad Street, has been a notable presence for decades. It was once considered the very intersection of high finance, where investment bankers churned out initial public offerings of stock, but over the last two years it has been converted into condominium apartments.

title: Changing a Process Would Aid the Hall
description: Three strikes and youre out. Three outs and the other team is up. Three votes without even one worthy former player being voted to the Baseball Hall of Fame by the revamped veterans committee (two votes on managers, executives and umpires) and its time to tweak, if not transform, the process.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Brown (Bobby) Is Jailed

title: Canadian Parliament Decides to Let 2 Measures Passed After 9/11 Expire
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 27  Canadas Parliament voted Tuesday not to extend two measures that were passed as part of a sweeping package of antiterrorism laws weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States.

title: Craft Brewers Turn to Whiskey Chasers
description: Newport, Ore.

title:
Afghan Bombing
Sends a Danger Signal to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The audacity of a suicide-bomb attack on Tuesday at the gates of the main American base in Afghanistan during a visit by Vice President Dick Cheney underscores why President Bush sent him there  a deepening American concern that the Taliban and Al Qaeda are resurgent.

title: North Carolina: Duke Panel Urges Policy Changes
description: Duke University should tighten campus drinking policies, reduce the time student-athletes practice and travel, and alter student housing policies, said a committee created to review the campus culture in the wake of last years rape accusations against Duke lacrosse players. The committee report said that social life at Duke was too often organized around drinking and that the risk of alcohol-related death in the Duke community is very real. It suggested the university should alter campus social life to include more nonalcohol events.

title: Sirius Radio Chief Urges Merger
description: The chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, Mel Karmazin, is taking the campaign to sell his companys proposed merger with XM Satellite Radio to Washington.

title: Kitchen Chemistry Is Chic, but Is It a Womans Place?
description: HERES how Loretta Keller, the chef at Coco500 in San Francisco, makes chocolate cake, one of her trademark desserts: She melts butter and chocolate together, stirs in egg yolks, sugar and flour, and adds beaten egg whites. She bakes and cools the cake, refrigerates it for two hours to give it the texture she likes, and brings it to room temperature before serving with whipped cream.

title: An Audience-Friendly Theatrical Town, Chicago Is
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26  This city is known for its bare-knuckled political brawls, but a spirit of greater fellowship reigns in the cultural sphere. The easy flow of audiences and artists between Chicagos large, established theaters and the scrappy up-and-comers has been instrumental in maintaining its stature as the countrys most vibrant dramatic capital after New York, allowing now-celebrated artists  from David Mamet to John Malkovich to Mary Zimmerman  to make their way from the fringes to the mainstream.

title: Manhattan: City to Expand Housing Program
description: The City Department of Homeless Services yesterday announced a citywide expansion of its HomeBase program, which now serves people in six neighborhoods who are at risk of becoming homeless. The program, begun in September 2004, has provided job training, housing relocation and legal and financial services to 6,300 families and adults and 8,200 children in six neighborhoods: the South Bronx and East Tremont in the Bronx; Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick in Brooklyn; East Harlem in Manhattan; and Jamaica, Queens.

title: With Idol, the Family Text-Votes Together
description: Foxs American Idol is a joy to behold. Like a cotton gin, a Model T or an iPod, the contraption just goes. Season after season, and despite monkey wrenches and glitches that might ground a lesser show, the baseline engineering of Idol holds up.

title: Mississippi to Be Site of Toyota Assembly Plant
description: Toyota said today it would invest $1.3 billion to build its eighth North American assembly plant in Blue Springs, Miss., just outside Tupelo in northeastern Mississippi.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the fallout from a possible merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio omitted the word not in a quotation from Susan Kevorkian, an analyst with IDC, about the marketing of satellite radio to users. She said, The way its been sold to date has not demonstrated that value to consumers.

title: Letters
description: For a Sauce, Tears of Joy

title: Nets Starting to Gain Consistency, and Ground
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 27  In the aftermath of distractions caused by the All-Star Game break and a week of trade speculation, the Nets have quietly put together a three-game winning streak in which they have finally shown signs of promise.

title: After Inquiry, Grand Jury Refuses to Issue New Indictments in Till Case
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 27  After a new investigation of the notorious 1955 killing of Emmett Till, a grand jury in Leflore County, Miss., has declined to issue any new indictments, effectively ending any further prosecution of a crime that fueled the civil rights movement.

title: Rangers Stand Pat, Mostly, but They Do Not Stand Still
description: With the dust of the N.H.L. trading deadline settling around him, Jaromir Jagr smiled as he showed up for work at Madison Square Garden yesterday. He laughed about the trade rumors that had surrounded him and that had finally become part of the dust.

title: Corzine to Lead Governors Organization
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine has been elected chairman of the Coalition of Northeastern Governors, the organization announced yesterday. Mr. Corzine was elected during the groups meeting in Washington on Monday, the group said. Accepting the chairmanship, Mr. Corzine asked the governors to join to improve rail service along the Northeast Corridor rail network.

title: Guatemala: U.S. Cautions on Adoptions
description: The State Department cautioned American parents who are considering adopting Guatemalan children, saying the system there is not adequately protecting all children. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents have found evidence of children who are candidates for adoption being smuggled into the United States, the State Department said, while embassy officials have found wrong and unethical practices involving some cases. The United States is not planning an immediate shutdown of adoptions from Guatemala, the statement said, but it termed the situation volatile and unpredictable.

title: Freddie Mac Tightens Standards
description: The easy money is making a quick exit out of risky mortgages.

title: Making Your Second Home Green
description: When James Seligman and his wife, Kathleen, were building a second home in Three Rivers, Calif., last year, they decided there was only one way to go: green. Their two-bedroom house has double-paned windows, nontoxic cotton insulation, energy-efficient appliances and clay-based wall coverings.

title: Snow Makes the Deal of Deadline Day, Acquiring a Scorer for the Islanders
description: Garth Snow, a mere backup goaltender a year ago, stole the show at the N.H.L. trading deadline yesterday. Snow, now the general manager of the Islanders, might also have swiped a playoff berth for his tenacious team.

title: A Recession That Arrived on Cats Paws
description: The nations manufacturing sector managed to slip into a recession with almost nobody seeming to notice. Well, until yesterday.

title: Padilla Ruled Fit for Trial on Terror Charges
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28  A federal judge ruled late this afternoon that Jose Padilla was competent to stand trial on terrorism conspiracy charges, granting a significant victory to the government in the high-profile criminal case of a United States citizen who was initially designated an enemy combatant and held without charges.

title: What You Get for ... $675,000
description: Bradenton Beach, Fla.

title: For Manufacturing, a Recession Has Arrived
description: The nations manufacturing sector managed to slip into a recession with almost nobody seeming to notice. Well, until yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about an identity crisis among Afrikaners, who invented the apartheid system that ended about a dozen years ago, misstated the colors of South Africas old apartheid flag. It is orange, blue and white, not orange and green. The article also referred incompletely to the name of a soccer stadium where an Afrikaner pride song was temporarily banned, and misstated the stadiums location. It is Loftus Versfeld Stadium, not Loftus Stadium, and it is in Pretoria, not Johannesburg.

title: From Phobia to Fame: A Southern Cooks Memoir
description: IS mayonnaise the food lovers Botox?

title: The Latest Woman to Join a Very Exclusive Club
description: Anne-Sophie Pic, above, the third-generation chef at Pic, in Valence, France, has just joined an elite club: female chefs with three Michelin stars. There have been only four women so honored since Michelin started the star system in 1931; Ms. Pic is the only current one.

title: In Secret 1996 Tape, Doomed Woman Pleads With Her Killer
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Feb. 27  A cluster of stereo speakers was arrayed in front of a jury box. A switch was flipped. And within moments, the courtroom here filled with the sounds of the futile, decade-old pleas from a doomed woman to the teenager who would soon take her life.

title: New Idea for the Turnpike: Let the Pension Fund Run It
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27  With legislators lining up against the possibility of leasing the New Jersey Turnpike to a private company, New Jersey lawmakers are now considering another option: having the state pension fund run the Turnpike Authoritys operation.

title: Coming Soon, Maybe: An Iraqi Oil Law
description: It would be a big step forward if Iraq actually approved and carried out long-promised and never-delivered legislation equitably sharing the nations oil revenues among all Iraqis. Unfortunately, the draft oil agreement approved by Iraqs cabinet on Monday is still a long way from that.

title: U.S. Set to Join Iran and Syria in Talks on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  American officials said Tuesday that they had agreed to hold the highest-level contact with the Iranian authorities in more than two years as part of an international meeting on Iraq.

title: The Costs and Risks of a Vaccine (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank M. Snowden Jr., 95, Historian of Blacks in Antiquity, Dies
description: Frank M. Snowden Jr., a historian who was a leading authority on the lives of black people in the ancient world, died on Feb. 18 in Washington. He was 95 and had lived in Washington for many years.

title: A Fighter for Colleges That Have Everything but Status
description: BAILEYS CROSSROADS, Va.

title: West Bank: Israeli Forces Leave Nablus
description: Israeli troops withdrew from Nablus, the largest city in the West Bank, after three days of searches for militants and their weapons. The operation had placed the central casbah area under a curfew and kept tens of thousands of residents confined to their homes. Israel arrested five suspected militants and found three bomb-making laboratories, according to the military. A Palestinian man was killed during the operation.

title: Competing in the Money Marathon
description: If nothing else, the disheartening frenzy to raise huge campaign donations in this front-loaded presidential race is making money  lots and lots of money  a public issue. In the cross-fire, federal election regulators are expected to approve Senator Barack Obamas clever but cagey attempt to claim a reformers mantle: he wants to let the nominees keep bagging unlimited private donations in the run-up to the primaries, then have the choice of returning a chunk of it after the conventions and accepting limited public financing for the general election.

title: Iconoclastic Art Historian, Seeing the Old in the New
description: It was the Summer of Love. The carnival capers of the flower children could not have seemed more distant from the neo-Classical world of late-18th-century European art. Yet that same year  1967  saw the publication of a book that collapsed the distance of two centuries into the twinkling of an educated eye.

title: U.S. and Iraqi Forces Arrest 16 Suspected in Killings and Kidnappings
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 27  American and Iraqi troops on Tuesday stormed several buildings in Sadr City, Baghdads main bastion of Shiite militancy, and detained at least 16 people suspected of participating in militia violence including killings, kidnappings and torture, the American military and local officials said.

title: Its Not Just for the Gondolas
description: VENICE

title: Qaeda Rebuilding in Pakistan, Spy Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The new director of national intelligence told members of Congress on Tuesday that senior leaders of Al Qaeda were steadily rebuilding the networks bases inside Pakistan and that future attacks against the United States could be planned from Pakistans remote western mountains.

title: 2 Face Trials at The Hague Over Darfur Atrocities
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 27  International prosecutors on Tuesday designated their first suspects in atrocities in the Sudanese region of Darfur, selecting a government minister and a militia commander to bring to trial.

title: From Shanghai, Tremors Heard Around the World
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 27  In Chinas wild cowboy stock market, record-breaking run-ups have been followed by mini-crashes that have been largely confined within this countrys borders.

title: Chvez Shares Some Airtime With Castro
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 27  How are you? President Hugo Chvez asked Tuesday in his nightly live radio program after a special guest phoned in from Havana.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Islamic Jihad Militants in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 28  Israeli undercover forces shot and killed three Islamic Jihad militants in the West Bank town of Jenin today, and a large contingent of Israeli soldiers re-entered the nearby city of Nablus just a day after withdrawing.

title: Colombias Drug War (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dromedary Dash
description: Camel racing, a popular sport in many Arab countries, has been criticized for exploiting underage, and sometimes enslaved, jockeys.

title: Steep Drop in Orders for Durable Goods Disappoints Wall St.
