description: American manufacturers reported a sharp drop in demand last month for expensive heavy-duty items, renewing concerns about softness in the economy.

title: 4 Tied to Pharmacy Are Arrested in Inquiry Into Steroid Sales
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27  Federal and state investigators on Tuesday arrested four people with ties to a pharmacy in Orlando, Fla., that law enforcement officials said accounted for a large part of the national market in steroids and other performance enhancers that are sold illegally online.

title: Italian Prime Minister Wins Vote of Confidence
description: ROME, Feb. 28  Italys political crisis ended, for the moment, on Wednesday night after the Senate narrowly passed a vote of confidence in Prime Minister Romano Prodis fragile government.

title: Updating an Old Way to Leave the Baby on the Doorstep
description: ROME, Feb. 27  In the Middle Ages, new mothers in Rome could abandon their unwanted babies in a foundling wheel  a revolving wooden barrel lodged in a wall, often in a convent, that allowed women to deposit their offspring without being seen.

title: State Agency Criticizes Con Ed for Poor Performance in Two Westchester Windstorms
description: The New York Public Service Commission issued a report yesterday that criticized Consolidated Edisons performance during and after two powerful windstorms in Westchester County last summer and made nearly 50 recommendations for improvement.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,149 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Texan Calls for Takeover of States Juvenile Schools
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 27  A long-simmering scandal over sexual abuse of juveniles at schools for youthful offenders broke into the open on Tuesday with an outraged state senator calling for a takeover of the troubled Texas Youth Commission.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 9:30 P.M. (SportsNet New York) BASEBALL IN AFRICA: A DIAMOND IN THE ROUGH Soccer may be the game of choice for children in the impoverished West African nation of Ghana. But a delegation of Major League Baseball officials and players  including the Mets general manager, Omar Minaya; the Hall of Famer Dave Winfield; the former Cubs and Giants manager Dusty Baker; the former Mets pitcher Al Jackson; and the outfielder Reggie Smith  hope to change that. This documentary follows the group from the countrys dirt fields to its historic sites, as it delivers baseball equipment, conducts clinics, inaugurates a four-team Little League and surveys a brush-covered lot that will be trnsformed into a field of dreams.

title: Why Spitzer Succeeded Where Pataki Fell Short
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27  Gov. Eliot Spitzer considers Theodore Roosevelt a political role model, but he has shown that he is not one to speak softly even as he carries a big stick.

title: Daley Easily Wins Re-election in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27  Mayor Richard M. Daley won a landslide victory over two relatively obscure challengers here Tuesday, putting him in a position to become the citys longest serving mayor.

title: Clinton vs. Obama: A Revealing Picture (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Endorses First Vaccine for Avian Flu
description: The first vaccine against avian flu for the United States was endorsed by a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel yesterday, but merely as a stopgap measure until better vaccines are developed.

title: Greek Classics, Without the Tragedy
description: ONERA ousted! Dona, done! Both of those celebrated restaurants have been consigned to antiquity. And so, the only place to catch Michael Psilakiss cooking at the moment is Kefi, where he presides over a menu of classic Greek cooking in the Upper West Side space that once housed Onera.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about the jazz violinist Leroy Jenkins misstated the date of his death. It was Saturday, not Friday.

title: Bread, Quick and Savory
description: MOST people think of quick breads and muffins, which are essentially the same, as sweet. With commercialization, that has become increasingly so. But it need not be the case.

title: Buyers Assurance to Starrett City Tenants Is Questioned
description: The investment group that wants to buy Starrett City, the sprawling low- and moderate-income complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, for $1.3 billion has tried to reassure tenants and elected officials that there will be no vast displacement of occupants, because most residents would qualify for federal rent vouchers.

title: Correction: Winters Stew Infused With Summer
description: The Good Appetite column last Wednesday misstated the given name of the author of Couscous and Other Good Food From Morocco, which inspired the accompanying recipe for lamb tagine with apricots, olives and buttered almonds. She is Paula Wolfert, not Paul. (Other references in the article referred correctly to Ms. Wolfert.)

title: A Mile From Cheney, Afghan Bomber Kills at Least 23
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 27  A suicide bomber blew himself up on Tuesday morning outside the gate of the United States air base near Kabul where Vice President Dick Cheney was staying, killing at least 23 people. The vice president heard the blast from a mile away.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report by The Associated Press in the college basketball roundup yesterday misstated the score for Syracuses victory over Georgetown. It was 72-58, not 72-68.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Findings column in Science Times yesterday, about the environmentalist Stewart Brand, gave the incorrect surname in some references for an economist who made a bet about the prices of natural resources in the 1980s. He is Julian Simon, not Sinon.

title: Clinton Foundation Not Listed on Senators Disclosure Reports
description: The charitable family foundation that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton have operated since 2001 has not been listed on Mrs. Clintons annual Senate financial disclosure reports for five years.

title: Family Second
description: THE Senates expected introduction this week of a revamped immigration bill will draw needed attention to the question of who may live and work in the United States. Making sure that the workers we need can come here legally should be a priority  but its not. Of the permanent-resident visas (green cards) awarded in 2005, 58 percent went to foreign-born relatives of United States citizens; only 22 percent were connected to employment.

title: Study Raises Possibility of Jewish Tie for Jefferson
description: Was Thomas Jefferson the first Jewish president? Researchers studying Jeffersons Y chromosome have found it belongs to a lineage that is rare in Europe but common in the Middle East, raising the possibility that the third president of the United States had a Jewish ancestor many generations ago.

title: Justices Hear Arguments on Autism-Case Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  While federal law gives people the right to represent themselves in court, there has been a notable exception to that general rule. Most federal courts have barred parents of children with disabilities from appearing without a lawyer in cases filed under the statute that guarantees all children a free appropriate public education.

title: Wall St. Plunge Fuels Worries on Economy
description: Stock markets around the world plummeted today in a wave of selling set off by a plunge in China that was reinforced by worries of weakening economies. The falling prices continued in early Asian trading on Wednesday.

title: Horse Racing Officials Move Toward Steroid Ban
description: At virtually every racetrack in America and in the barns of some of the sports most successful trainers, there are horses who have been treated with anabolic steroids. With steroid use legal in horse racing in every state but Iowa, it is not a matter of breaking the rules but a case of some trainers using steroids to create a more fit, more powerful horse that they believe is more likely to hit the finish line in front.

title: Nevada: Chinese Gambling Venture Approved
description: The states Gaming Control Board voted unanimously to recommend approval of the MGM Mirages joint venture in Macau, China, with the daughter of a prominent Hong Kong businessman reputed to have ties to organized crime. The 3-to-0 ruling came after five hours of hearings in which the woman, Pansy Ho, insisted that while she had in the past received money from her billionaire father, Stanley, she had for many years operated businesses independent of him.

title: Winter Storm Threatens Midwest
description: A storm developing over the western parts of the Midwest today is expected to dump snow and freezing rain over northern states and to produce thunderstorms, and possibly tornados, over areas to the south.

title: Iran to Take Part in Iraq Security Conference
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 28  The top Iranian national security official, Ali Larijani, indicated Wednesday that Iranian officials would probably take part in a regional security conference on Iraq next month, which would include the first high-level diplomatic contacts between American and Iranian officials in more than two years.

title: Next Step in TXU Deal Is Backdrop of Conference
description: Will anyone dare to mount a rival bid for TXU?

title: U.S. and Iraqi Troops Storm Militant Stronghold
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 27  American and Iraqi troops on Tuesday stormed several buildings in Sadr City, Baghdads main bastion of Shiite militancy, and detained at least 16 suspected militiamen accused of operating murder, kidnapping and torture cells, the American military and local officials said.

title: Queens: Man Sentenced for Shooting Police Officer
description: A Cambria Heights man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 12 years in prison for injuring a police officer during a struggle in June 2005, prosecutors said. The man, Lasana Philbert, 23, of 229th Street, was convicted last month of assault on a police officer, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Philbert struggled with Officer Christopher Wiesneski, 32, as the officer tried to arrest him after he spotted him with marijuana. During the struggle, Mr. Brown said, Mr. Philbert grabbed the officers pistol, which discharged, striking Officer Wiesneski in the leg.

title: Gnapa Batrice Komb, Choreographer, Dies at 35
description: Gnapa Batrice Komb, the powerful dancer and choreographer from the Ivory Coast whose all-women troupe, TchTch, introduced her to the international festival circuit as a leader of Africas new experimental dance, died on Thursday in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. She was 35.

It is orange, blue and white, not orange and green. The article also referred incompletely to the name of a soccer stadium where an Afrikaner pride song was temporarily banned, and misstated the stadiums location. It is Loftus Versfeld Stadium, not Loftus Stadium, and it is in Pretoria, not Johannesburg.

title: Military Aware of Threat of Afghan Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 28  NATO and American forces were aware that a suicide bomber was at large in the Bagram area before the suicide bomb attack there on Tuesday, a NATO spokesman said Wednesday. The bombing killed 23 people at the main gate of a United States air base where Vice President Dick Cheney was staying.

title: Yankees Weigh the Other Half of a Blockbuster Trade
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27  For someone with the telltale high number of a minor-leaguer (83), pitcher Ross Ohlendorf drew a lucky locker location in the Yankees spring training clubhouse. He dresses near the corner just left of the main entrance, within handshake distance of the veteran Mike Mussina.

title: Bronx: Settlement in Pyramid Scheme
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a settlement in a continuing investigation of an illegal pyramid scheme that operated in the Bronx under the names Women 4 Change, the Womens Gifting Circle and Women Empowering Women. Under the scheme, participants paid $5,000 and hoped to receive $40,000 eventually as others joined. Many of the participants were employees of the Morris Heights Health Center in the Bronx. Marie Latibeaudiere of Spring Valley, N.Y., and Robbi Olivas of the Bronx, both employees at the center, agreed not to participate in such schemes and to pay penalties of $7,500 and $8,377, respectively, Mr. Cuomo said.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Saturday, about the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, incorrectly rendered the given name of a city councilwoman opposed to the project in some copies. It is Letitia James, not Leticia.

title: Coveted, French, and Now in Tennessee
description: CHUCKEY, Tenn.

title: The Ultimate Cruelty: Abandoned by Ravioli
description: IN New York things disappear all the time. Corner markets, tailors, opticians  one day theyre there, the next day theyre the branch of yet another bank youve never heard of. Just another fact of city life. But when food disappears ... well, thats personal.

title: Fracture for Crawford; Crisis for Thomas
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 27  The worst news of the Knicks season came to Isiah Thomas in two parts. First came the alarming late-night call from the team doctor after Mondays victory against Miami. Then, 12 hours later, came the crushing words: Jamal Crawford, the Knicks best clutch shooter, is out for the season.

title: Two Victims and Three Officers to Testify in Shooting Inquiry
description: A Queens grand jury weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man on his wedding day in November is entering its final stages with two prime witnesses set to testify on Friday. Three of the five police officers who fired their guns that day are also set to sit for the panel beginning next week.

title: Chinese Investors Shrug, and Shanghai Rallies
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 28  Seated before a row of computer terminals flickering with stock charts in a large brokerage house in this bustling city, Li Ruichang insists he is not too worried about Tuesdays massive stock sell-off.

title: 7, Mantle Novel, Finds a Publisher
description: 7: The Mickey Mantle Novel, Peter Golenbocks occasionally racy account of the life of Mickey Mantle, which was canceled last month by its publisher, HarperCollins, was revived yesterday by Lyons Press.

title: Shuttle Flight Postponed After Damage From Hail
description: NASA has postponed next months space shuttle launching because of thousands of dings and gouges from a hailstorm, mission managers announced yesterday.

title: As Voter Registration Soars, French Presidential Candidates Woo Troubled Suburbs
description: PARIS, Feb. 27  Sgolne Royal, the Socialist candidate for president, took her campaign on Tuesday to the tough Parisian suburb that set off nationwide unrest in 2005, assuring residents there that they were not a problem for France.

title: Food Calendar
description: From Tuscany to 21

title: Some Immigrant High Schoolers Receive a Lesson in Disappointment
description: Two winters ago, Pablo Oliva began the process of applying to public high schools in New York. A complicated process at best, it looked utterly byzantine to a 13-year-old who had only recently come to America from Argentina. But there in the vast list of choices, amazingly, Pablo found the ideal place.

title: A.& P. Negotiating to Acquire Pathmark
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the owner of the A.&P. and Food Emporium supermarket chains, said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Pathmark Stores for $652.5 million.

title: Inspector Is Out After Giving Rat-Infested Restaurant Passing Grade
description: The city yesterday removed from duty a health inspector who gave a passing grade to a KFC/Taco Bell restaurant in Greenwich Village one day before television cameras captured a swarm of rats scurrying about in the restaurant.

title: Teenager Dies, Raising Toll to 4 in Attack at Saudi Site
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 27  The death toll from the attack Monday on French citizens in Saudi Arabia rose to four after a teenager who had been in critical condition died Tuesday, Saudi and French officials said.

title: Staten Island: Development Planned for Terminal Area
description: The citys Economic Development Corporation said yesterday that it would sell three acres on the waterfront next to the St. George Ferry Terminal to Triangle Equities Development Corporation of Whitestone, Queens. Triangle plans to redevelop the site, known as Lighthouse Harbor, into a $100 million retail and residential complex, said Elysa Goldman, Triangles director of development. Triangle will build 150 units of housing, renovate three historic buildings and turn a network of underground vaults into a restaurant, Ms. Goldman said. The vaults, built into the side of a hill, were used to store whale oil and other fuels and supplies for lighthouses, said Jerry Roberts, a director of the planned National Lighthouse Museum.

title: Ranks of Child Welfare Caseworkers Swell
description: Nearly 500 child welfare caseworkers have graduated in the last two weeks, part of the surge in hiring by the Administration for Childrens Services since Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old girl in Brooklyn, was beaten to death on Jan. 11, 2006, prompting intense scrutiny of shortcomings at the agency.

title: Missouri: Student Arrested After Anthrax Scare
description: A 22-year-old graduate student forced a temporary shutdown of the University of Missouri, Rolla, when he falsely told the police he had anthrax and a bomb, the authorities said. Twenty-two people who were exposed to a powdery substance that the student claimed was anthrax were held in quarantine for several hours, said Lance C. Feyh, a university spokesman. Mr. Feyh said tests showed that the substance was powdered sugar. The bomb threat was also declared false. The student was arrested, but no charges were immediately filed. His name was withheld.

title: Government by Law, Not Faith
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that could have a broad impact on whether the courthouse door remains open to ordinary Americans who believe that the government is undermining the separation of church and state.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Feb. 10 about efforts by Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican presidential contender, to distance himself from the position favoring abortion rights that he espoused when he ran for mayor of New York attributed an erroneous distinction to New York State. It was the second state to legalize elective abortion  not the first, which was Hawaii.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the selection of Gary L. Crittenden as the chief financial officer of Citigroup misidentified the group at the bank that hired the executive search firm, Prince Goldsmith. It was Citigroups management, not its board of directors.

title: Call to Expand Union Rights Could Derail Antiterror Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Democrats in Congress are pushing to extend union protection to 43,000 federal airport security workers, reviving a debate that stalled the creation of the Department of Homeland Security and could now derail broad antiterrorism legislation.

title: A TV Station on the Verge of a Takeover in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Feb. 27 Thailand is poised to take over a television station once controlled by its former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, who was ousted in a coup in September. The move would end a long dispute between the broadcaster and the military-appointed government, but would leave the future uncertain for the only private station in the country.

title: A Green Deal on Coal
description: People who worry about global warming and want the United States to do more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions received some very good news over the weekend from a very unlikely source. As part of an ambitious buyout deal, TXU, a Texas utility that has long been a target of environmentalists, will abandon plans to build eight old-style coal-burning power plants, which would have dumped huge amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

title: Arthur Schlesinger, Historian of Power, Dies at 89
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian whose more than 20 books shaped discussions for two generations about Americas past, and who himself was a provocative, unabashedly liberal partisan, most notably in serving in the Kennedy White House, died last night in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Recipe: Spicy-Sweet Ham Salad
description: Adapted from "Paula Deen: It Ain't All About the Cookin'," by Paula Deen (Simon & Schuster, 2007)

title: For Central Connecticuts Mojica, a Nightmare, Then a Dream
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 27  Long before Javier Mojica was a basketball player at Central Connecticut State University, he was a 10-year-old boy in a troubled home in Massachusetts. His mother, Nancy Mojica, said that she had an abusive boyfriend and that she used drugs to numb her pain.

title: Is Whole Foods Straying From Its Roots?
description: THEY came together in what seemed like a perfect marriage: earnest former hippies and Whole Foods, the clean, well-lighted version of the old natural food store. The chains stores were filled with organic foods and socially responsible ingredients. They were decorated with pastoral scenes of the local farmers who sold to them; signage explained why local and organic are better for the environment.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The NYC column yesterday, which raised questions about the New York City Councils resolution declaring a symbolic moratorium on the use of a racial slur in the city, misidentified the group founded by Marcia Harris, who spoke at a Council hearing. (The caption for a photograph of Ms. Harris also included the error.) The group is Ban the N-Word, not Abolish the N Word.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup last Wednesday about the future of Fabio Capello, the manager of the Spanish club Real Madrid, referred incorrectly to the teams fortunes in recent years. Real Madrid won the European Cup in 2002; it has not gone without a major trophy since 2000.

title: Settlement Approved in Suit Against Italian Insurer
description: A federal judge approved a settlement of a class-action suit yesterday against an Italian insurance company, ending a long-running dispute over payments on life insurance policies taken out by Holocaust victims.

title: The Fringe, Now Embraced by Main Street
description: Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: Setting a Reflective Mood, a Timeless Voice Ruminates
description: I dont want you to be happy, because if youre happy, you wont remember me, the Welsh singer-songwriter Judith Owen said on Monday evening at the Living Room. I want to be the girl who devastated you and left you unable to walk home without a bottle of vodka inside you.

title: Low Pay and Broken Promises Greet Guest Workers
description: To a rice farmer from Thailand making $500 a year, the recruiters pitch was hard to resist  three years of farm work in North Carolina that would pay more than 30 times as much as he earned at home.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Debut to Remember, and One to Forget
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 27  The pristine white uniform with the Old English D and No. 65 that Lino Urdaneta wore in his major league debut hangs in a closet in his home in Venezuela, just above his glove and spikes.

title: 2 New Drugs Offer Options in H.I.V. Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27  Two new AIDS drugs, each of which works in a novel way, have proved safe and highly successful in large studies, a development that doctors said here on Tuesday would significantly expand treatment options for patients.

title: Service Members Sign Appeal Calling for Troop Withdrawal
description: In a small but growing sign of dissent, a group of active-duty military personnel and reservists, including many who have served in Iraq, is denouncing the war and asking Congress for the prompt withdrawal of troops.

title: Cheney Denies Aiming to Beat Up On Musharraf
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Vice President Dick Cheney, thinly veiled as a senior administration official, told reporters on his plane on Tuesday that it was not correct that he went in to beat up on the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, for failing to confront Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

title: Lower Manhattan: A Relative Bargain but Filling Up Fast
description: It was not long ago that prospects for Lower Manhattan seemed so dire that many people predicted it would not survive as a financial center. Within days  even hours  of the destruction of the World Trade Center, a number of companies with offices in Lower Manhattan were searching for space in Midtown or outside the city.

title: Arti-Factual Evidence
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Idol Juggernaut
description: American Idol does exactly what it promises to do: It makes platinum music stars, where The Apprentice on NBC mints no great businesspeople, and The Bachelor on ABC cant consecrate a single marriage. And it regularly attracts more than 33 million viewers.

title: The Buzzer Beaters
description: Six coaches recall what went into six memorable tournament finales.

title: Super Zoom Digital Cameras
Harry Potter Passes a Test
description: Harry Potter did the full monty in the West End, and the critics liked what they saw.

title: Random House Introduces New Search Tool
description: Random House has introduced a search tool on its Web site that will make available a small portion of text from 5,000 of its new and backlist titles, the company announced yesterday. As much as 10 percent of each book, typically a front cover, introduction and first chapter, will be accessible on the Random House Web site (randomhouse.com) by clicking on the individual book and entering keywords. Several thousand more titles will be added to the database this spring, and the company hopes to eventually allow searching across all books, rather than just within an individual title. Publishers have been scrambling to compete with Google Book Search and Amazon, which both offer free digitized book content. HarperCollins introduced a similar browsing tool on its Web site (harpercollins.com) last week.

title: Folk Wear
description: Looks from some of the fall 2007 Paris shows.

title: Scandal at Siemens Tarnishes Promising Results
description: Siemens, the German engineering giant, has reported buoyant financial results, in part reflecting the ambitious overhaul of operations by the companys chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld. But Siemens is immersed in a fast-expanding corruption scandal that threatens to torpedo its reputation. On Tuesday, Mr. Kleinfeld said the results of Siemens internal investigation into accusations of bribery and other misdeeds would not be known before he presented the companys next strategic plan in April.

title: Is Another Dolan Bid for Cablevision to Be Found at the End of the Rainbow?
description: New York sports fans have asked the question all season: What are the Dolans thinking? Now its Wall Streets turn again.

title: TXU Deal Provides Conference Buzz
description: Will anyone dare to mount a rival bid for TXU? That was the question being whispered yesterday in Frankfurt where many of the worlds private equity chiefs were gathered for Super Return, one of the industrys best-attended gatherings.

title: Mr. Karmazin Goes to Washington
description: The chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, Mel Karmazin, is taking the campaign to sell his companys proposed merger with XM Satellite Radio to Washington. On Monday, Mr. Karmazin appeared on the often-bawdy Howard Stern show on Sirius. Today, he will speak at a hearing of the newly created House Antitrust Task Force in Washington.

title: TV Station on the Verge of a Takeover in Thailand
description: Thailand is poised to take over a television station once controlled by its former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, who was ousted in a coup in September. The move would end a long dispute between the broadcaster and the military-appointed government, but would leave the future uncertain for the only private station in the country.

title: McAfees Ex-Lawyer Indicted
description: The former top lawyer of McAfee was charged on Tuesday with stock options tampering that muddied the finances of the computer security software maker. A federal grand jury indicted the lawyer, Kent Roberts, nine months after McAfee fired him as its general counsel for improper handling of stock options issued in 2000. The indictment includes seven criminal counts of fraud, accusing Mr. Roberts of deceiving investors by filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and falsifying McAfees books.

title: On the Corner of Retail and High Finance
description: Among storied New York buildings, the old J. P. Morgan headquarters at the corner of Wall and Broad Streets, encompassing 23 Wall Street and 15 Broad Street, has been a notable presence for decades. It was once considered the very intersection of high finance, where investment bankers churned out initial public offerings of stock, but over the last two years it has been converted into condominium apartments.

title: Purloined Picassos in Paris
description: BBC News is reporting that two Picassos went missing, sans signs of a break-in, from the home of his granddaughter, Diana Widmaier-Picasso, in Paris Monday night  a roughly $65 million dollar heist.

title: Buyout Firms Draw Up Hedge-Fund Blacklists
description: Some private equity firms are barring certain hedge funds from participating in the loans and bonds that back their deals, a sign of growing tension between the two kinds of investors, the Financial News reported. Apollo Capital Management and JLL Partners are among those that have tried to exclude hedge funds known to be tough negotiators, it said.

title: Centro Properties of Australia to Buy U.S. Real Estate Trust
description: The Centro Properties Group and Centro Retail Trust of Australia have agreed to buy the New Plan Excel Realty Trust for about $3.4 billion in cash, accelerating Centros push into the United States. The acquisition will be Centro Properties third purchase in the United States. It said in a statement that directors of New Plan, which is based in New York, had unanimously recommended the offer.

title: At Blockbuster, 28% Profit Dip and Dispute Over the Chiefs Pay
description: Blockbuster, which on Tuesday reported a 28 percent decline in its fourth-quarter earnings, said it was trying to resolve a dispute with its chairman and chief executive, John F. Antioco, over his 2006 bonus. On Jan. 25, the board of the movie rental company awarded Mr. Antioco a bonus of $2.28 million, on top of his 2006 salary and deferred compensation of about $2.5 million. But according to a statement in the companys earnings report, Mr. Antioco claims he is entitled to a total of $10.15 million.

title: Super Zoom Digital Cameras
E.ON Faces an 11th Hour Upset in Deal for Endesa
description: In yet another twist in the ongoing saga of E.ONs attempt to buy its Spanish rival Endesa, Enel, Italys biggest power company, said on Wednesday that it might increase its stake in Endesa to almost 25 percent. In a move that threatens to thwart E.ONs yearlong, 41 billion euro takeover bid for Endesa, the Italian utility said onTuesday it had acquired 9.99 percent of Endesa for about 4.13 billion euros ($5.47 billion). Enel said Wednesday it is considering raising the stake to as much as 24.99 percent.

title: By Raising Man Stake, Volkswagen May Jump-Start Merger Talks
description: Volkswagen has increased its stake in the German truck maker MAN to 29.9 percent in a move that Volkswagen said Tuesday could help pave the way for a merger between MAN and the Swedish company Scania. Volkswagen, the largest European carmaker, held about 20 percent of MAN before increasing its holding Monday. It is also the biggest shareholder in Scania, with 18.7 percent of the capital and 34 percent of the voting rights.

title: China Pacific Clears Obstacle to I.P.O.
description: China Pacific, a life insurer, has struck a crucial shareholder agreement with the Carlyle Group, paving the way for a $1 billion initial public offering of China Pacific this year, The Financial Times reported. Preparation for the listing of state-owned China Pacific has been on hold for several months pending talks with a Carlyle-led consortium, which acquired a 25 percent stake in the groups life insurance arm for $410 million in December 2005.

title: Nonprofit Wikipedia Founder Now Looks for Profits
description: Wikipedias founder, Jimmy Wales, has become a star with the non-profit online encyclopedia, now he is looking for gold with his latest venture, Wikia, writes Business 2.0. But the road to profits is apparently a somewhat rocky one for Mr. Wales, who now finds himself playing in a different league.

title: G.E. Chief Gets $17.9 Million, Plus Time on the Jet
description: General Electrics chief executive, Jeffery Immelt, received $17.9 million in compensation last year, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a proxy statement detailing executive compensation, G.E. said Mr. Immelts payout included $3.3 million in salary, $5 million in bonus, $7.4 million in stock awards and options valued at $574,322. But, as the commercial says, thats not all: Mr. Immelts payout also included other benefits  such as payments for life insurance, retirement plans and use of the company aircraft  valued at about $1.6 million.

title: Who Gets Credit for Heinz Results?
description: Nine months of solid economic growth at H.J. Heinz, with net income increasing nearly 13 percent and total sales climbing almost 10 percent, brings up question: Is it Heinz, or is it Nelson Peltz? Analysts and industry watchers told The Pittsburgh Tribune-Review the positive results at Heinz are a combination of the two.

title: EGL Chairman Finds New Buyout Backers
description: EGLs chairman said Wednesday that he had found a new group of investors, including Centerbridge Partners and the Woodbridge Company, to participate in his offer to take the transportation company private. His previous buyout partner, General Atlantic, withdrew from the original deal, after it was announced in January.

title: Will Market Jitters Chill Deal-Making?
description: As major stock indexes in Asia and Europe continued to slide on Wednesday, there were fears that the choppy markets would cool the recent deal-making frenzy. Volatility is the enemy of deal negotiations, and many Wall Street firms have been banking on China, where the recent stock slide was most severe, for much of their growth potential.

title: New Republics Top Editor Sells His Stake to CanWest
description: Martin Peretz, who has been a part owner of The New Republic for more than three decades, has given up his share of the magazine, selling his interest to CanWest Global Communications, which now assumes full control. Mr. Peretz is to remain as editor in chief. CanWest, which bought a 30 percent interest in the magazine last year, announced Tuesday that a subsidiary, CanWest Media Works International, had acquired a 100 percent interest in The New Republic. Terms were not announced.

title: Univision Gets a New Chief
description: The private investor group that is acquiring Univision Communications said Tuesday that it had named Joe Uva, president and chief executive of the ad-buying firm OMD Worldwide, to become chief executive when the acquisition closes. Mr. Uva, 51, will succeed A. Jerrold Perenchio, 76, Univisions longtime chairman and chief executive, on April 1, the investor group, Broadcasting Media Partners, said. The terms of Mr. Uvas contract were not disclosed. He will remain based in New York when he takes control of Univision, which is based in Los Angeles.

title: Vantage Media Raises $70 Million
description: Vantage Media, which provides search-based Web marketing services, said Wednesday it had completed a $70 million preferred financing round led by Montgomery & Company, the investment bank that helped sell the social-networking site MySpace to the News Corporation. Vantage also hired a new chief executive, Steve Jillings, who told Reuters that an initial public offering was possible in 2008.

title: Currents
description: B&B Italia rearranges its furniture, a centenarian offers a toast to a young millennium, decorators who cast a wide net and more.

title: A.&P. Goes Shopping for Pathmark
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the owner of the A.&P. and Food Emporium supermarket chains, said Tuesday that it was in talks to acquire Pathmark Stores for $652.5 million. Great Atlantic is offering Pathmark shareholders $12.50 a share in cash and stock, a 3.7 percent premium above Pathmarks closing price Monday of $12.05 a share, if a deal is reached, Great Atlantic said.

title: Rock On, Tipper
description: Tipper looks stunning and never more so than at an event like this.  Al Gore, showing off his date on the carpet.

title: Personal Shopper
description: For those who want to make their shower a destination.

title: Thats Mr. Donut to You
description: Hollywood is a doughnut and I work in the middle of it, said David T. Friendly, one of the producers of Little Miss Sunshine. Its $100 million movies and LMS and nothing in between.

title: Darkness Visible
description: Maggie Gyllenhaal showed up before the big crowd on the carpet. How about that, were early, said her boyfriend Peter Sarsgaard. We never come on time, There were people  O.K. the Bagger was among them  who thought Sherrybaby, deserved a better shake at the box office and at the awards. Those who did manage to see it were riveted by Ms. Gyllenhaals portrayal of a junkie with a brittle heart who could not get her arms around her child or being a mother.

title: And She Will Be Monstrous
description: Doug Jones, a tall handsome man who played Pan in Pans Labyrinth, has worked with Guillermo del Toro before and will again in Hellboy II, reprising his role role as one of the freaks in the original. He was asked on the carpet at the Oscars if he was tired of being trapped in latex?. Guillermo tells me that I have the power to project through the mask and the costume, he said.

title: The Dumbest Thing at the Oscars Besides the Security Guys
description: Oscar program book would seem to be a fairly straightforward affair  a user-friendly booklet that allows the audience to follow along, right? Not so fast. In an instance of fixing something that was not broken in the first place, the Academy came up with a horizontal booklet that was a foot long and six inches tall. It had a rivet in the middle so the thing only opened up halfway and the type ran both horizontally and vertically. The Bagger saw a number of people try to figure out how to use it  it was plenty handsome  then give it a toss.

title: The Dweeb Demo
description: With George Clooney and Gwyneth Paltrow and god knows who else spilling out of the Vanity Fair Oscar party, one fan took off running to catch up with a short man whose car was parked away from the queue. The kid, who had thick glasses and seemed to be hyperventilating, was blocked by a security guy.

title: Idol Headquarters
description: The Bagger did not want to say anything while he was staying there, but all of those first round guys from Idol were also staying at Le Meredien. Chris, Antonella and Jared were there, going in and out of the place. Its funny to watch nascent celebrities. They dont know whether to act important or excited, haughty or happy.

title: That Would Be a Hollywood Promise
description: I definitely plan on thanking my two other producers, said Graham King, talking on the carpet before he went inside to pick up a trophy for The Departed. Mr. Grey had petitioned the Academy to be counted as a producer because he put the movie together, even though he now runs Paramount.

title: Missing Links
description: Even though the Bagger is filled the brim by his Oscar experience  hes been spontaneously doing that little penguin dance for the past few days  there were a couple of things missing from this season. Coulda, woulda, shoulda? Sure, but this would have been an even better Oscar season with some of these elements.

title: An Inconveniently Easy Headline: Gores Electric Bills Spark Debate
description: An obscure conservative group in Tennessee claims to be offering up the utility bills on Al Gores 10,000-square-foot Nashville mansion (wow!) as evidence that the former vice president doesnt put his money where his mouth is on conservation.

title: In Cairo, Life Apart From Government
description: In a ruralized metropolis, people live by their wits and devices, cut off from the authorities, the law and often each other.

title: Putting a Gag on Greenspan
War at Home: Looking for Balance
description: Scheduled negotiations with Iran and Syria could lessen some concerns about Iran for a little while.

title: A Lesson From the Master
description: Is the decline in the Shanghai stock market yet another sign of the Chinese success at imitating American-style capitalism? Business journalist Daniel Gross sees evidence in two comments made by a Chinese stock analyst to the Associated Press: The most important reason for todays decline was pressure for profit-taking, said Peng Yunliang, a senior analyst at Shanghai Securities; People viewed 3,000 as a psychological benchmark. Its understandable they might want to pull back after the market hit that peak, Peng added.

title: Treasury Official Defends New Hedge Fund Guidelines
description: Days after a presidential commission recommended a hands-off approach to regulating hedge funds, the Treasury Department is defending its new guidelines against critics who say the new rules dont go far enough, according to The Financial Times. Answering naysayers  who include several state attorneys general  Robert K. Steel, a deputy to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., said that the Presidents Working Group on Financial Markets would stand firm on its reports recommendations.

title: Buyout Chief: We Cant Continue Like This Forever
description: There is no bubble in the buyout business, David Rubenstein, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, said Wednesday. But is it near the top of the cycle? Probably, he suggested. There will be declines, Mr. Rubenstein said Wednesday at the Super Return conference in Frankfurt. We cant continue like this forever. His remarks were part of a speech called Comparing Tech Bubble & Private Equity Today, in which he examined whether the booming private-equity industry could be headed for a crash similar to what the technology sector suffered in 2000.

title: 2008: Trading Campaigns
description: Senator John McCains campaign just announced that hell participate in a press availability on the trading floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange this afternoon. Hes in New York attending an Irish-Americans awards dinner tonight with the Womens National Republican Club.

title: El Duque Is Back
description: Orlando Hernandez resurfaced this morning, throwing about 40 pitches from a mound for the first time since being diagnosed last Thursday with arthritis in his lower neck. El Duque acknowledged a crowd of reporters waiting for word on his progress with nothing more than a nod.

title: Newt and Mario at Cooper Union
description: Invoking the spirit of Abraham Lincolns transformative Cooper Union speech, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Newt Gingrich, the former House Speaker and Georgia Republican, will appear tonight on the stage of Cooper Unions Great Hall at 6:30 tonight for a free, public discussion to encourage todays presidential candidates to spurn sound bites for serious debate of the issues.

title: What They Get You For?
description: It was love at first sight, the moment Alison and Johnny Agnelli  the man destined to be our builder  met. I instantly became the proverbial third wheel  and I could not have been happier.

title: Bloombergs Waistline
description: Just heard, moments ago, in a news conference in the Blue Room at City Hall:

title: Greenhills Miller Said to Consider Return to Law
description: Harvey Miller, the veteran corporate bankruptcy lawyer, is considering leaving the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company, where he is vice chairman, The Deal reported. Mr. Miller declined to comment for the article, but The Deal, citing undisclosed sources, reported that he might return to the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, whose high-powered bankruptcy practice he founded and led for 31 years.

title: Caf Boulud Responds
description: In a post last week, I wrote about situations in which restaurants ask diners to provide credit card numbers to secure a reservation. The post was prompted by an e-mail from a diner frustrated with the restaurant Caf Boulud, which asked her not just for a credit card number but also for a sheet with her signature on it. The woman didnt have a fax machine at the ready, and so found the request so cumbersome that she took her business to another restaurant.

title: Quest for a Desktop Image
description: Read this delicious tale of one mans attempt to track down the photographer and location of one of the default Windows desktop backgrounds. Its hilarious, gripping, and enlighteningin that its phone calls and human intervention, not Google or the Web, that ultimately lands his quarry.

title: He Lives in L.A., but His Heart Is Still in Holland
description: The Baguette agrees with the Bagger that Volver should have gotten more love from the Academy. Shes sweet on Pedro Almodovar, one of the few directors who genuinely loves and understands women. As he told the Baguette back in September, he finds women more fascinating than men.

title: Range Fuels Gets U.S. Funding for Ethanol Plant
description: Venture-backed Range Fuels will receive up to $76 million in funding from the Department of Energy to build a plant that produces ethanol from wood chips and forest residue. The funding is one of six grants the Energy Department announced Wednesday, all for the construction of cellulose-based ethanol plants, with a total value of up to $385 million.

title: Paris Dreaming
description: Nicolas Ghesquieres shows for Balenciaga always have the audience in a state of near-collapse. His is the first big show of the week, and I sometimes feel the excitement in the room following his racehorse presentations can influence peoples opinions. Of course they want to like the collection, and Ghesquiere is extremely generous with his ideas and his enthusiasm. My own feeling is that while I liked the silhouette  shes the girl of his dreams, arms pressed to her sides, hands buried in her pockets  the look essentially continues a thought hes had before. Thats okay, I suppose. And theres something to be said for acknowledging a multicultural world  the Arabic scarves tied at the neck of preppy blazers, the vivid African colors, the shoes that evoked athletic gear.

title: After The Glitch, the Wall Street Blame Game
description: Wall Street and the financial press spent much of their day Wednesday looking for someone or something to blame for The Glitch  that seemed to be the preferred term  that caused trading delays Tuesday afternoon on the New York Stock Exchange, even as the market was plunging and the system that calculates the Dow Jones Industrial Average was having trouble keeping up with it all. The NYSE Group said it was assessing the situation, which raised questions about the exchanges new hybrid market, a platform that combines electronic trading with old-fashioned floor trading.

title: Marks & Spencers Chief Ponders Sainsbury Bid
description: The list of potential bidders for J Sainsbury may have grown to include another major British marque: Marks & Spencer. Stuart Rose, the chief executive of Marks & Spencer, Britains largest clothing store, said at a conference on Wednesday that he was mulling an offer for Sainsbury.

title: Deutsche Bank Reshuffles Its M&A Roster
description: In an effort to coordinate its international mergers and acquisitions advisory work, Deutsche Bank on Wednesday appointed two global co-heads for the division, as well as a host of regional staff changes. Most notable are the appointments of Tony Burgess and James Stynes to new roles that report directly to the firms head of global banking, Michael Cohrs.

title: Powerball

title: Former Technology Analyst to Join Brunswick Group
description: A veteran technology analyst, Steven Milunovich, will become a New York-based partner at the Brunswick Group to help strengthen the public relations firms investor relations business, the company said Wednesday. Mr. Milunovich spent many years as a top-ranked computer hardware analyst and managing director at Merrill Lynch until he left the firm in 2005 to start his own hedge fund, Financial News reported. He returned to Merrill in early 2006.

title: Half Day for the Yanks
description: Like most  if not all  teams, the Yankees have only one day off during spring training. But today was essentially a half day. The last item on the workout list began at 11:08 a.m., and most of the players were dressed and gone by noon.

title: Signs from the Heavens: Ditch the Shuttle, Head for Mars
description: I ordinarily try to keep religion out of science. I dont believe in attributing technical difficulties to divine retribution. title: When Age Flatters Flesh
description: Its increasingly common for steakhouses to make emphatic claims about the care and devotion with which they age their beef, but I wonder. Sometimes these putatively aged steaks dont taste remarkably different from steaks that arent touted as aged.

title: Looking at the World With Blinders On
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Feb. 28 column, Outsource the Cabinet?

title: More Bad News at NovaStar
description: NovaStar Financial, the subprime lender, posts delinquency figures every month, but it does so by pool of mortgages that it sold to investors. That makes it relatively easy to track how any pool is going, but hard to figure out how they are all going.

title: The Q & A: Riccardo Tisci
description: Givenchy has seen designers come and go: John Galliano, Alexander McQueen, Julien Macdonald. Right from his first couture collection, two years ago, Riccardo Tisci seemed to connect with young women. They got his modern romance. But did editors? So often his shows are a tangled mess of mood and ideas. Still, young women manage to see his substantial gifts. How does a talented designer reconcile this divide in perception?Between fittings for his fourth ready-to-wear collection, tonight, Tisci talked about the unique problem of being Riccardo.

title: Big Penalty Imposed in Ad Case From 2004
description: The Progress for America Voter Fund has agreed to pay a $750,000 penalty to settle a complaint before the Federal Election Commission over its political activities in the 2004 election campaign. This was the third largest civil penalty in the agencys 32-year-history.

title: Northeast Power Plant Operators to Merge
description: Two privately owned power plant operators servicing the Northeast will combine in a potentially $5 billion deal aimed at creating a 5,000-megawatt giant in the lucrative market. Astoria Generating, which services New York City, and EBG Holdings, which provides power to the Boston area, will form a new entity to be called U.S. Power Generating, the two companies said Wednesday.

title: They might want to wear extra gloves
description: Im strongly for the deceptively lowkey Sarah Silverman Program, and Im not sure why people think its so mean. Its just the regular amount of mean.

title: The Villages Inside Cairo
description: In Cairo, where citizens often fix water and electricity lines on their own, many people are resigned not to expect anything from politics or government.

title: What My Uncle Knew About War
description: Tell me, are you too getting just a little bit fed up with our leaders war? Isnt everybody? Do you actually know anyone who thinks its all going to turn out fine? Except that chubby optimist Dick Cheney, of course, who thinks the Titanic is still afloat.
